HEADLINE: German Church Crisis

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "German Churches, Ever Giving, Ask to Receive" (news article, Jan. 6): The financial crisis of the German churches was foreseen 50 years ago by Protestant leaders like my father, Werner Schmauch, who left the Silesian Church in 1950 in protest of the territorial church system your article describes. 
 The financial dependency on state-collected taxes was too comfortable for the hierarchy, so no effort was made to change the system to one of voluntarism and active church membership. It is interesting to note that the East German churches made tentative steps in this direction under the pressure of circumstances, but in the process of unification they were forced to adopt the anachronistic West German system.
It is a pity that the situation had to deteriorate in order to reveal the absurdity of a system that should never have been invented in the first place.
 
(Rev.) W. CHRISTOPH SCHMAUCH
North Conway, N.H., Jan. 6, 1998

HEADLINE: Classical Musicians Team Up With Actors In the AIDS Battle

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
Some say that given the fluidity of today's economy and the pace of technological change, people should no longer cling to the idea of having one job for life.
If this is so, Charles Hamlen could be a poster person for such adaptability. He began his working life as a French teacher, but kept busy on the side as a pianist, primarily accompanying professional singers. Then he moved into artist management, founding his own company, which later merged with I.M.G. Artists, a leader in the field. In those days he worked in a well-appointed office on Madison Avenue and handled clients like James Galway, Yevgeny Kissin and Itzhak Perlman. 
 But for the last five years, Mr. Hamlen has been the executive director of Classical Action: Performing Arts Against AIDS, a nonprofit organization that draws upon the donated talents of performers, mostly classical musicians, to raise money for AIDS services. Now Mr. Hamlen operates out of a bare-bones Manhattan loft on West 45th Street and administers a staff of three, including himself. And at 54, he sees how everything was leading to his current work.
In the mid-1980's, while his management business was thriving, the AIDS crisis was spreading. On New Year's Eve in 1988, he lost his lover to AIDS. As numerous friends got sick, he ministered to them, which in those days mostly meant providing support as they faced death.
"I remember thinking then that, as well as I do artist management, others do it as well and better," Mr. Hamlen said recently. "But I was the only one who could be there for my friends. How this might connect to my professional life in music I didn't see at first." But, in a sense, Mr. Hamlen added, his life has been about networking, not backslapping and swapping favors, but listening to people, sensing needs and remembering.
His gift for reaching out has been critical to the success of Classical Action. The organization has distributed more than $2 million to AIDS services groups nationally, like God's Love We Deliver, which provides meals for homebound people with AIDS in New York; the Hospice of Pasadena, in California; the San Francisco AIDS Foundation, and the Starfish Foundation for Children With AIDS, which is based in New Jersey.
Additional results of Mr. Hamlen's networking will be clear tomorrow night, when Classical Action marks its fifth anniversary with a benefit concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which is co-sponsor of the event and is donating the use of its Majestic Theater. Among the participants will be the soprano Dawn Upshaw, the violinist Joshua Bell, the pianist Fred Hersch, the dancer-choreographer Bill T. Jones, the bassist Edgar Meyer, the pianist Ursula Oppens, the clarinetist David Shifrin, the Orion String Quartet and Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo.
But the benefit will also acknowledge a new partnership. In October, Classical Action merged administratively with Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, the highly visible nonprofit group that emanated from the theater and that has distributed, in 10 years, some $25 million to more than 100 AIDS services and agencies. This, too, is a result of networking, for, since its founding, Classical Action has been situated on the same floor of the Actors' Equity building as Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.
These two scrappy AIDS organizations have recognized, as many fund-raising agencies in other fields have not, that there is more to be gained from cooperating than from competing. Tom Viola, a founding director of Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, suggests that comparable organizations are sadly reluctant to pool resources in similar ways.
"This merger is not about treading on each other's turf," Mr. Viola said in a recent interview. "While we don't operate in the same artistic neighborhoods, we can get much more bang out of our efforts by sharing administrative costs. Neither organization has to lose its identity or control. But we can get more of the money we raise to the people we raise it for if we are not paying two rents, two phone bills, two bookkeeping salaries."
Mr. Hamlen agrees. "It frees me to contact artists and put projects together," he said, "which is what I do far better than payroll and taxes." The corporate sponsors of each organization have been enthusiastic about the merger, he said. "They tell us we are demonstrating leadership, cutting back on infrastructure and maximizing staff."
Mr. Viola's organization had prior experience with a merger. Its two branches were founded separately. Broadway Cares was primarily set up by a collective of theater producers. Equity Fights AIDS emanated from the Actors' Equity Association. They joined together in 1988. "Many of the service organizations we fund are today facing the same issues we did," Mr. Viola said. "And if they don't begin to cooperate, some of them are going to close down."
Indeed, when Mr. Hamlen started Classical Action, his model was Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. The perception persists that the classical music field was slower to respond in an organized way than other arts and professions. But Mr. Bell suggested in a telephone interview that the lag among classical musicians had only to do with the initial absence of a leader.
"Everyone I knew felt strongly about this issue," Mr. Bell said. "So many people in our field have been stricken. It has affected us all, in a deeper sense. If classical musicians didn't organize themselves at first, it was probably because we were waiting for someone like Charlie to come along and spearhead the effort. He organized and set up everything. He makes it easy for me to help. All I have to do is show up and play."
Mr. Bell remains devoted to Mr. Hamlen, who was his first manager. "Charlie heard me play my debut with the Philadelphia Orchestra at 14, and we started talking," he said. "At that time, he had his own company. Going with him instead of a bigger agency was the best career decision I ever made. He so sincerely loves music. He is one of the rare people in this profession everybody likes. That's why he has been successful with Classical Action."
Mr. Hamlen's ease with people came about in steady, careful stages during his earlier years. Born in Schenectady, N.Y., he attended Harvard, where he majored in French, and studied piano. He also played in the cello section of the college orchestra, along with his demon pianist friend, Ms. Oppens, who also played cello for fun. After graduation, while teaching French at a private school in New Hampshire, Mr. Hamlen started a chamber music series. At the suggestion of some friends, he considered going into management.
In retrospect, Mr. Hamlen says that his bold decision to shake up his life at 34, move to New York City with no money to speak of, and begin a new career was an outgrowth of confronting himself. Having previously been married, he now understood that he was gay.
"I was still uncomfortable about it," he said. "But I subliminally had accepted it already. I knew that New York would help me figure it out."
When his friends started dying, Mr. Hamlen felt compelled to respond with more than just personal care. There had already been occasional AIDS benefit concerts called Music for Life, presented by classical musicians. He thought that this work should be continuing, and national.
"I remember grappling with the possibility of changing my life and taking this on," he said. "One moment you think, what a great thing; the next you think, you are out of your mind?"
What emboldened him was the reactions of many clients when he told them he would be leaving. "The first person I talked with was Andre Watts," Mr. Hamlen recalled. "Andre said, 'Charlie, I've wanted to be involved for a long time, but no one asked me.' The same happened with James Galway. The first words out of his mouth were, 'What can I do to help?' "
Since then, many people have helped: Emanuel Ax, Yo-Yo Ma, Thomas Hampson, Leonard Slatkin, Mark Morris, Cecilia Bartoli, Van Cliburn, Carol Wincenc, Jean-Yves Thibaudet, Michael Tilson Thomas and dozens of others.
Ms. Upshaw, a friend of Mr. Hamlen, was stunned by his decision. "I was very moved by his courage," she said recently. "Nothing in my lifetime has been quite as devastating in the way AIDS has been. It was like dealing with a plague for my generation. And I was outraged at the reaction of those who saw AIDS as some sort of justified punishment for people involved with the same sex."
Ms. Upshaw said she felt that if Mr. Hamlen could change his life so drastically in order to help, then all artists should do the same. "But Charlie has done it for us," she said. "So now we all have a way to give, through his organization. Like everyone else, I'm the one who is grateful."
At the benefit, Ms. Upshaw will sing Rodgers and Hart songs. Mr. Bell will play solo works by Fritz Kreisler, but will probably also perform duos with his friend Edgar Meyer, the bassist, fun pieces Mr. Meyer wrote for them to play together.
There is no reason, Mr. Hamlen said, that a concert benefiting AIDS service agencies need be joyless and grim. A certain degree of high spirits should be assured by the presence of Nathan Lane and Madeline Kahn as co-hosts.
This is exactly the kind of cooperation between people from different artistic neighborhoods that Mr. Hamlen sees as one good result of the merger with Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.
"On our own, Classical Action could never have reached out to such stars of the theater world," Mr. Hamlen said. "But now this kind of collaboration will just keep happening."
Given past experience, however, Mr. Hamlen is prepared for more unexpected turns, should they come.
 
An Anniversary And a Benefit
Classical Action: Performing Arts Against AIDS celebrates its fifth anniversary and its merger with Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS with a benefit concert tomorrow at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene.
The event will feature a duet by the violinist Joshua Bell and the bassist Edgar Meyer and the world premiere of a piece by the dancer-choreographer Bill T. Jones, performed with the Orion String Quartet. There will also be performances by the clarinetist David Shifrin, the pianists Fred Hersch and Ursula Oppens, the soprano Dawn Upshaw and Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo. Nathan Lane and Madeline Kahn will be the hosts.
The concert begins at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $100 for the concert only, $250 including a preconcert reception at 7 P.M., and $500 including the reception and a postconcert Champagne toast with the performers, and can be purchased by calling Classical Action at (212) 997-7717.
On April 13, Classical Action will present "Fred Hersch and Friends: The Duo Concert" at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan. Mr. Hersch, the jazz pianist and composer, will perform with the saxophonist Joe Lovano, the vibraphonist Gary Burton, the pianist Kenny Barron and the singer Andy Bey.

HEADLINE: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work

BYLINE: By Robert D. Reischauer 

 BODY:
The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget "is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged" and that surpluses should start piling up soon.
So rosy is the picture that Democrats and Republicans have already begun suggesting ways to spend the money. Some envision new Government programs. Others see tax cuts. Here, some leading experts offer their recommendations: 
 Robert D. Reischauer, a fellow at the Brookings Institution and former director of the Congressional Budget Office.
 The budget surpluses projected for the next decade are an illusion. They occur only because the budget includes the surpluses in Social Security. Apart from Social Security, tax payments will still fall tens of billions of dollars short of covering the full costs of providing Government services.
Debates over how to spend these surpluses should be shelved until the Government's revenue and spending -- excluding Social Security -- are in balance and Social Security's long-term fiscal position has been bolstered.
Until then, we should husband the surpluses, not spend them.
Surpluses will increase the nation's capital stock, boost worker productivity and expand the economic pie. That larger economy, in turn, will ease the burden when the baby boomers begin to draw their Social Security and Medicare benefits.
 Furthermore, the projected surpluses are both small and uncertain. They rest on economic and political assumptions that, while reasonable, are by no means certain. A recession of average depth and duration could transform a balanced budget into one with a $100 billion to $150 billion deficit.
And policy makers may not have the political will to cut discretionary spending as the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 requires. Most cuts would have to come out of civilian programs now that the Pentagon has been cut by more than one-third.

HEADLINE: Jack F. Grimm, 72, Is Dead; A Seeker of Oil and Legends

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Jack F. Grimm, a flamboyant West Texas wildcatter who found his share of oil in Texas and Oklahoma but had less luck searching for Sasquatch in the Pacific Northwest, the Abominable Snowman in Nepal, the Loch Ness Monster in Scotland, Noah's Ark in Turkey and the Titanic in the North Atlantic, died on Tuesday at a hospital near his home in Abilene, Tex. He was 72 and had insisted to the end that he really had discovered the ark and had been the first to find the Titanic.
His family said the cause of death was cancer. 
 To suggest that Mr. Grimm was a perpetual seeker would hardly do justice to a man who was so inspired by his grandfather's tales of buried treasure that at the age of 11 he blew up a creek bed near his home in Wagoner, Okla.
Never mind that the blast, using dynamite the youngster had bought at the local hardware store, turned up nothing but a few arrowheads, some lead bullets and an old frying pan.
"That was it," he said years later. "That was all it took to hook my imagination."
His imagination was fired even further a few years later when Mr. Grimm, who served as a demolition expert in the Marines in the Pacific in World War II, hitchhiked to Houston to visit a Navy buddy and discovered that the friend he knew as Bunker was the son of the billionaire oil wildcatter H. L. Hunt.
Mr. Grimm, who was studying oil geology at Oklahoma University, was so impressed by the Hunt wealth that after graduation he turned down offers to work for major oil companies and struck out on his own, but only after he had married a fellow geology student and spent his honeymoon panning for gold in California.
Getting rich seemed easy at first. The first well he drilled struck oil in Oklahoma, but when he moved to West Texas, his luck changed. After 25 straight dry holes, he was so poor that his telephone service was turned off, a major blow to a man who spent so much time on the phone that he once said he planned to have one installed in his coffin.
With two young children to support, Mr. Grimm was on the verge of taking a job, but with his wife's blessing, he tried one more deal. The well came in, and he had phone service from then on.
Mr. Grimm's more quixotic searches began in 1970, when he read about a planned expedition to find the remains of Noah's Ark on Mount Ararat and signed on for what turned out to be the first of three expeditions to Turkey. Although by most accounts the efforts failed to turn up fragments of the biblical ark, Mr. Grimm, who returned with a hand-carved oaken timber dug out of the frozen peak and always carried a hunk of it in his briefcase, maintained otherwise.
As he put it a few years ago, "This is the ark; that's my story, and I'm going to stick to it."
The ark expedition brought Mr. Grimm to the attention of other seekers, and during the 1970's he helped finance other quests, always, he proudly maintained, as business deals, never as a hobby.
Although he put up some of his own money, Mr. Grimm, a master salesman, raised most of the money from other investors, including his old buddy, Nelson Bunker Hunt, who proved such an easy touch that when Mr. Grimm was presented with a proposal that even he found outlandish he would placate the promoter by giving him Mr. Hunt's private phone number.
By far his most ambitious quest began in 1979 when he was approached by Michael Harris, a Florida film maker who had made documentaries of searches for Spanish treasure in the Caribbean and wanted to find the Titanic. Mr. Grimm all but took over the project, raising several million dollars, arranging for reputable scientists to accompany the expedition with advanced sonar equipment and even hiring the William Morris agency to promote what became three expeditions to the North Atlantic.
Although the scientists acknowledged that the expeditions produced invaluable data about the configuration of the ocean floor, Mr. Grimm alone maintained that they had actually found the Titanic.
Whether or not a grainy undersea photograph taken in 1981 was a picture of the Titanic's anchor, as Mr. Grimm, who helped write a 1982 book, "Beyond Reach: The Search for the Titanic," maintained it was, after a 1985 French-American expedition led by Robert Ballard found the full remains of the sunken ship, Mr. Grimm's claims were swept aside by the courts.
The expeditions and the vagaries of the Texas economy took their toll on Mr. Grimm's business, but after a brush with bankruptcy he had made something of comeback, though not enough, perhaps, to satisfy a man who once described his life as "a continuous search for the unknown."
His survivors include his wife Jackie; two children, Theda Carpenter of Buffalo Gap, Tex., and George, of Brisbane, Australia; three brothers, four grandchildren and a great-grandchild.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Stay Tame, With 1.2% Drop Last Year

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Producer prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1.2 percent in the full year, the largest annual decrease in a decade, the Government said today.
The report on prices at the wholesale level was issued on the same day that the nation's major retailers reported that sales in December were relatively strong, although much of that strength was concentrated in a few days toward the end of the month. The sales gains indicated that economic growth remained healthy without pushing prices up. 
 "I was thinking today it couldn't get much better than this, but it may," said Gary Thayer, an economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. "The consumer is going to benefit from the low interest rates we're getting. It's a pretty good environment -- low inflation and steady growth."
Even lower borrowing costs could be on the way. A Federal Reserve governor, Laurence H. Meyer, said today in a speech that the Fed might decide to lower interest rates if the Asian economic crisis caused the American economy to slow more than currently expected.
Last year's decline in producer prices followed a 2.8 percent increase in 1996. The decrease was the largest since a 2.3 percent drop in 1986, when oil prices were falling sharply, and the first since prices dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in 1991. Prices rose during only three months last year.
The core rate, which excludes producer prices for energy and food, rose one-tenth of 1 percent last year, the smallest annual gain on record and below 1996's increase of six-tenths of 1 percent. In December, the core rate fell one-tenth of 1 percent.
A separate report today showed that the number of workers applying for first-time state unemployment benefits rose last week by 20,000, to a seasonally adjusted 334,000. That was the second consecutive weekly increase.
The four-week average for new jobless claims rose to 318,250 last week from 313,250 the previous week, a sign job growth may lose some momentum this year.
As for the inflation outlook, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, raised the issue of falling prices -- or deflation -- in a recent speech. "Inflation has become so low that policy makers need to consider at what point effective price stability has been reached," Mr. Greenspan said. "Indeed, some observers have begun to question whether deflation is now a possibility."
However, Mr. Meyer, the Fed governor, appeared to express a different view today. Asked whether he saw a potential for deflation in 1998, he said that by not mentioning the subject in his speech, he "gave deflation its appropriate attention." He was speaking to the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Spot Gold Price Is Under $280 Briefly in London and New York

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
For the first time in more than 18 years, the spot price of gold dropped below $280 an ounce in both London and New York yesterday as the fear of sales by central banks and low inflation continued to undermine the outlook for this precious metal.
Despite a record for the amount of gold used in fabrication in 1997, the spot price of gold plunged almost 24 percent last year and has continued its fall this year. 
 A report showing tame inflation in the United States as well as comments on central bank sales pushed gold lower yesterday. The spot price fell to $278.45 an ounce, before it rebounded to finish at $281.05, just 20 cents above the 18 1/2-year low reached Tuesday. On the Comex Division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, February gold dropped to $279 before closing at an 18-year low of $281.80.
Adding to the gloom was a year-end report from Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd. of London, that highlighted the central bank sales in 1997 and indicated that they could continue early this year.
"I can't see any reason why central bank selling won't continue," Philip Klapwijk, the senior metals analyst at Gold Fields, said yesterday in an interview.
The report also noted how much gold's role as a haven in times of financial distress had diminished, being replaced in the case of Asia's turmoil by the United States dollar and the American bond market.
But Mr. Klapwijk suggested that the formation of a new European central bank as Europe shifts to a single currency next year could halt such sales for a while, bringing some stability to the price of gold.
"You can make a case for the central bank weight on the gold market becoming less, maybe in the second half of the year," he said.
He said that there may be more sales to get under the wire, but once the countries eligible for the single currency are chosen and the central bank begins to be established, individual European central banks may feel they have to hold off on any further sales until the new central bank establishes much gold it wants to hold in reserve.
At that point, Mr. Klapwijk said, the new central bank may decide to set a policy that would make it clear to investors how much gold could be sold by old central banks and when the sales would be.

HEADLINE: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work

BYLINE: By Laura D'Andrea Tyson 

 BODY:
The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget "is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged" and that surpluses should start piling up soon.
So rosy is the picture that Democrats and Republicans have already begun suggesting ways to spend the money. Some envision new Government programs. Others see tax cuts. Here, some leading experts offer their recommendations: 
 Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a professor of economics and business at the University of California, Berkeley, and chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers during the first Clinton Administration.
I would advise against using projected surpluses to finance either additional spending or tax cuts for several reasons. First, the surpluses are very small, and relatively minor changes in underlying economic conditions could cause them to disappear altogether.
Second, with the economy enjoying high levels of employment and price stability, there is no macroeconomic reason for changing the Government's net fiscal stance at this time.
Why not save any small surpluses that may develop over the next few years in a rainy-day fund for use when the economy hits a rough patch? Wouldn't it be sensible for the Government to put aside some resources to finance a temporary increase in unemployment compensation, job training and welfare payments in the event of a recession?
Third, we have a long-term financing problem for Social Security and Medicare. Why not use some of the surpluses now to build up the assets of the Social Security trust fund and to secure adequate financing for Medicare?
Instead of frittering away the surpluses we don't even have yet, let's savor the nation's hard-earned victory on the deficit and spend some time thinking seriously about the long-term future.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Says Brokerage Firm Engaged in 'Yield Burning'

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had accused Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, a large regional brokerage firm, and a former employee, of defrauding investors and the State of Arizona in a 1992 municipal finance deal.
The case against Rauscher -- a major participant in municipal finance -- is notable because it is the first time the S.E.C. has brought a securities fraud complaint against a brokerage firm for a municipal bond practice that has come to be called "yield burning." 
 For several years, Federal regulators have been looking into allegations that brokerage firms, big and small, illegally overcharged state and local governments in the early 1990's by selling them Treasury bonds at artificially high prices to make a hefty profit.
When interest rates fall, state and local agencies often refinance old debt by issuing new municipal bonds. The proceeds are placed in an escrow account, which by Federal law is usually stocked with Treasury bonds. Firms handling the account typically buy the Treasuries.
But in marking up the prices of Treasuries sold to the state and local governments, some firms, investigators say, thereby lowered, or burned down, the yield -- which moves in the opposite direction of the price -- so that the yield appeared to conform with Federal regulations.
In doing so, those firms may have jeopardized the tax-exempt status of many municipalities and also pocketed hundreds of millions of dollars that the local governments would have otherwise forwarded to the Federal Government.
Officials at Rauscher, now part of the Dain Rauscher Corporation of Minneapolis -- strongly deny any wrongdoing, arguing that their activities were entirely proper and that Arizona officials had reviewed the case in 1993 and determined that nothing wrong took place. Dain Rauscher changed its name from Interra Financial Inc. earlier this month.
Yesterday, a spokesman for the Department of Administration in Arizona would say only that the agency was cooperating with the S.E.C. and the Internal Revenue Service, which is conducting its own investigation.
According to the S.E.C., Rauscher Pierce and its lead investment banker on the deal, James R. Feltham, defrauded Arizona in a $129 million debt refinancing deal by charging Arizona "above market prices" for Treasury securities in 1992.
"This case illustrates how a firm like Rauscher can take advantage of its position to enrich itself," said Paul Gerlach, an associate director at the S.E.C., which is seeking to recover the losses and impose penalities on the firm. "They put tax-exempt bonds at risk."
In serving as both a financial adviser and an investment adviser, S.E.C. officials said the firm also had an obligation to inform the agency that it would make a $700,000 profit on the deal and that Mr. Feltham would earn more than $115,000 in compensation for his work, about a third of his annual salary in 1992.
Rauscher issued a copy of a pair of 1993 letters yesterday from the Arizona agency and its bond counsel, Squire, Sanders & Dempsey in Phoenix, stating that the 1992 transaction had been reviewed. The agency, which may have been under investigation at the time by the I.R.S., said that the prices were found by bond counsel to be "reasonable and appropriate."
There is some evidence, however, that at the time, state officials were trying to prove they were not overcharged because if they had been, the I.R.S. might have held the state responsible and ordered the agency to repay the money lost to Rauscher or risk having the tax-exempt status of the 1992 bonds revoked.
Through his lawyer, Mr. Feltham, who no longer works for Rauscher, denied any wrongdoing in the 1992 deal, saying that Rauscher officials were aware of his actions at the time, and that he was being made a "fall guy" by the Government.

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 464 words

HEADLINE: Putting the Surplus, if Any, to Work

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich 

 BODY:
The Federal budget picture is suddenly not the grim splotch of red that it once was. The Congressional Budget Office said this week that the budget "is likely to be essentially balanced for the next 10 years if current policies remain unchanged" and that surpluses should start piling up soon.
So rosy is the picture that Democrats and Republicans have already begun suggesting ways to spend the money. Some envision new Government programs. Others see tax cuts. Here, some leading experts offer their recommendations: 
 Robert B. Reich, professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis and Secretary of Labor in the first Clinton Administration.
In the likely event that the Federal budget begins to show surpluses, let's give the largesse to Americans who have not shared in the huge surge of wealth in recent years. (Note to readers who now mutter to themselves, "Ah, they've allotted this one to the liberal who wants to spend it all on big government." Indulge me a moment more before your eyes wander.)
We can help them gain ground without relying on a large bureaucracy, and do so in ways that give them more power over their lives. Herewith, four apple pies in the sky.
First, boost the Earned Income Tax Credit. This tax credit is a reverse income tax, originally conceived by conservative economists and celebrated by no less than Ronald Reagan. It works reasonably well, but it's still too small.
Lift the maximum benefit so that a very poor working family with two or more children receives $6,000 a year. (They get around $3,500 now.) Phase out the credit only gradually as incomes rise, so it doesn't vanish completely until a family reaches the median income (now about $50,000 for a family of four).
Next, subsidize the wages of lower-income workers who have lost jobs and whose new jobs pay less. Set the subsidy at half the difference, and make it available for a year. This will ease the pain of job transitions. Call it "re-employment insurance." It's better than an unemployment check.
Then do something big for poor kids who are getting a lousy education. Add $2,000 a year to what the states and locales are already spending on each child of a lower-income family. (If you're intent on vouchers and school choice, just add $2,000 to the value of vouchers for lower-income families.)
Finally, give every child who finishes high school, and who is from a family whose income is below 120 percent of the median, a "grubstake" of $25,000 upon graduation. The money has to be used for further education or it must be invested in stocks or bonds for at least four years. Here, the nation gets a twofer: We encourage completion of high school, and we create a new cohort of capitalists.
That's a start. Give me more money and I'll find more uses.

HEADLINE: Consumers Trimmed Debt in November

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing unexpectedly declined in November, the first drop in more than four years, the Federal Reserve said today.
Borrowing fell by $4.2 billion, to $1.231 trillion. In October, consumer credit rose a revised $11.4 billion. 
 All major categories of borrowing registered declines during November. Credit card borrowing fell $1.8 billion, auto loans decreased $1.3 billion and other types of personal loans declined $1.1 billion.
November's decline indicated that consumers had become more cautious in their spending. Indeed, retail sales early in the Christmas season, which begins after Thanksgiving, were considered weak. Christmas spending gathered strength toward the end of December, however.
"Consumers are beginning to cut back on their new borrowing and pay back some of their existing debt with the improvement in employment and earnings," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla.
At the same time, Ms. Reaser said, "we are seeing some substitution of home equity loans for credit card and other installment debt." Loans backed by real estate are not part of the Fed data.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Bonds Up 5th Time in 6 Sessions As Foreign Money Seeks Refuge

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose yesterday for the fifth time in six sessions, in a rally driven largely by foreign investors seeking refuge from the turmoil of Asian markets. The rally advanced after a Federal Reserve official suggested that the Asian crisis could lead to lower United States interest rates.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 105 13/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.75 percent, from 5.78 percent on Wednesday. But some traders suggested that the gains were limited ahead of today's release of the December employment report. 
 Still, the report is expected to confirm the market's view of slower growth and restrained inflation.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and manager of bond trading at Cowen & Company, said the Treasury market opened strong after sharp overnight declines on Asian markets, leading to a flight to quality into Treasury securities.
"Coupled with that, we had excellent economic data today," Mr. Gamba said.
The Labor Department said yesterday that producer prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1.2 percent in the full year.
"And perhaps what was most important about the inflation numbers were that the core and intermediate goods, which are still in the manufacturing pipeline, have shown significant declines," Mr. Gamba said.
Comments by Laurence H. Meyer, a Fed governor, helped further the rally. He told the Economic Strategy Institute in Washington that "a much larger spillover from the Asian crisis could encourage an easing" in interest rates by the central bank.
Mr. Meyer's comments were made at the end of speech in which he suggested two possible near-term economic outcomes, one leading to an easing and another to a tightening.
In other activity, the Treasury sold $8 billion of 10-year Treasury inflation-protected securities, called TIPS. The securities came with an interest rate of 3.73 percent, much better than expected. But with inflation remaining tame, retail demand was low.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new 10-year inflation- indexed securities:

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Uncertainty Over Earnings Batters Stocks for Third Day

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Uncertainty about the prospects for earnings growth of American companies touched off another wave of selling across Wall Street yesterday, pushing stocks lower for the third day in a row.
From Alcoa to Seagate Technology, a steady diet of news about anticipated earnings shortfalls and disappointments is beginning to take a deeper toll on the stock market, analysts and investors say. 
 While the market has endured volatile swings recently, what is different this time, analysts say, is that investors' sentiments are beginning to gravitate toward bearishness, making rebounds less likely.
"For the first time in a number of years we are raising some cash," said Richard I. Sichel, chief investment officer at Investment Counselors of Bryn Mawr, an investment management firm in Conshohocken, Pa.
Concerns about Asia's financial crisis and a belief that analysts' earnings forecasts for American companies with exposure there are too high has made the firm more defensive, he said. As a result, it is increasing cash positions in most portfolios from 5 percent to 15 percent by selling stocks that have seen strong gains in sectors like energy, technology, health care and consumer goods.
"I don't know one portfolio manager who hasn't been bitten by the Asian flu, or blindsided by a bad earnings report," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
"When that occurs, the stock has a very sharp drop. It's very disheartening. It tends to make you gun-shy. If there's any hint there will be an earnings disappointment, you try to stay clear. Nobody has the sense of urgency" about needing to buy stocks, Mr. Johnson said.
Such lack of enthusiasm about stocks comes during a month when stocks have generally risen, aided by heavy flows of cash into equity mutual funds. In fact, the last time the Dow Jones industrial average ended lower during the month was in January 1990.
"In a seasonally strong period, we're not seeing any real commitments being made," said Michael W. Clark, a managing director and head of United States equity trading at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"We're seeing institutional selling and people playing defensive games around the perimeter," he said, by selectively buying a few stocks they consider cheap.
Investor skittishness could continue for the next few months, he said.
"It really has to do with this story that's just blossoming in the Pacific Rim," Mr. Clark added. "They say we need a broader sample of fourth-quarter earnings reports, but there will be the same uncertainty for the next set of earnings" for the first quarter.
Yesterday, the Dow average closed down 99.65 points, or 1.26 percent, at 7,802.62. This week, the blue-chip indicator has fallen 162.42 points, erasing more than half of last week's 285-point gain. Two weeks into the new year, the index is 105 points lower.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.96 points, to 956.04.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index suffered less, slipping just 6.16 points, to 1,555.54. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks also took a lighter hit, slipping 4.08 points, to 425.71.
Although small-company stocks fell less sharply than larger-company issues yesterday, few analysts believe that performance marks the beginning of a small-cap rally, or January effect.
"When the market's down this heavily, you would really expect the small caps to do much better," said Lawrence G. McMillan, president of the McMillan Analysis Corporation, a Morristown, N.J., investment firm that specializes in futures and options strategies.
Small-company stocks historically have done better in the first five trading days of the year, even when the broader market is declining, which is why the phenomenon is known as the January effect. That has not happened this year.
Instead, technology and smaller- company shares did better yesterday because some investors were looking for bargains. But that trend may not continue, Credit Suisse First Boston's Mr. Clark said. "If you're nervous about the market it's sort of a safe place to put your money -- in something that's already taken the pain," he said of technology shares. "You can argue that you're buying value."

HEADLINE: Strong Finish to Christmas Season Cheers Retailers

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
In a remarkable turnaround from a weak season, American retailers reported strong December sales yesterday, aided in huge part by shopping that occurred after Christmas.
The Goldman, Sachs & Company same-store sales index, which compares the results of stores that have been open at least a year, reported that retail sales were up 4.4 percent in December, compared with a meager 2.9 percent gain in December 1996 and well above the 3 percent gains most retail experts were forecasting. 
 But underscoring the profound shift in the way America shops, those strong showings were due almost entirely to the 48 hours before Christmas and the week after Christmas.
"Christmas arrived for us between 4 and 5 P.M. on the 23d of December," said Robert Burton, director of investor relations for the Kmart Corporation. "The last two weeks made the month happen." The discount retailer said that thanks to the week after Christmas, sales in Kmart stores open at least one year rose 2.9 percent for the season.
They were not alone. Interviews with more than a dozen retail executives and analysts made it clear that for the most part, the Christmas selling season that began the day after Thanksgiving was a disappointment -- until it ended with a brawny finale as December came to a close. "Santa came late and stayed for after Christmas," said Richard N. Baum, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs.
The Dollar General Corporation, for example, a discount chain, said that holiday sales gains for the first and second weeks of the selling season were 3.6 percent and 4.1 percent, respectively; for the fourth week, same-store sales leaped 19.8 percent.
More surprisingly, the after-Christmas period, which started on Friday, Dec. 26, when much of the country had the day off, essentially bailed many retailers out of an otherwise miserable performance.
"The week after Christmas was really what pulled us up to a positive number," said Elaine Crowley, the vice president for finance for the Bombay Company, a seller of home decor and furniture items.
Indeed, on the Friday after Christmas shoppers raced to the stores in search of half-price wrapping paper and tree ornaments, to redeem gift certificates and to spend their cash gifts on toys.
In Houston, local television news crews parked themselves in front of the Galleria mall, reporting with glee about the parking lot Santas who guided the glut of cars into spaces and the shoppers who swarmed in for marked-down sling-back shoes, ties and bread makers.
"The first couple of weeks of December found us below plan," said Jan Drummond, a Sears, Roebuck & Company spokeswoman. But the few days before the holiday and the final week of the month pushed the chain's gains to a healthy 4.5 percent, against a difficult comparison of 9.5 percent gains the previous year.
The last-minute shopping habits of consumers had merchants ripping their hair out for the better part of the season. "We are all optimists," said Michael Goldstein, chief executive of Toys "R" Us Inc. "So you say, 'It is coming at the end.' But we were all nervous."
Mr. Goldstein said his managers were unhinged by weak sales early in the season, and were relieved by the strong showings in the final two weeks that led to the company's gain of 5 percent, a big improvement over last year's flat sales.
"We can't figure it out," Mr. Goldstein said. But children who got money for the holiday may have hit the stores the week after Christmas and Hanukkah, which this year ran from Dec. 23 through Dec. 30, increasing sales for that period.
In the last few years, time-deprived consumers have pushed their holiday buying closer and closer to Christmas Day, playing chicken with retailers on potential markdowns and leaving the dreaded trip to the mall for the last minute. People have also leaned toward nontraditional gifts such as travel, services and gift certificates for things as odd as drivers education classes or reflexology, leaving general merchandise retailers scrambling for sales.
Most significant, though is shoppers' insistence on value, which means they will give gift certificates or cash so that after-holiday sales can be taken advantage of, or buy gifts for the following season the week after Christmas to get the bargain. The American Express Company said sales of its gift checks -- essentially nicely wrapped gifts of cash -- rose 17 percent this season, compared with last year.
"Christmas doesn't mean buying gifts for Christmas anymore," Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Lehman Brothers Inc., said. "Retailers can still have a good December now because the month is weighted with the week after."
Many trends that marked the retail business all of last year were evident in holiday sales patterns.
Discounters, which offer everything from apparel to coffee makers, were one example. The Dayton Hudson Corporation's Target division posted 6.4 percent gains, while Family Dollar Stores Inc. said its sales rose 7.9 percent. Off-price apparel retailers had a similar Christmas story to tell, and one that reflected their strong 1997. Ross Stores Inc. and the TJX Companies both said their sales rose 7 percent.
Department stores, whose results have been inconsistent for the last year, remained so last month.
While the luxury players had a great season -- Harcourt General Inc.'s Neiman Marcus unit gained 8.8 percent and Saks Holdings Inc. saw a 6.1 percent rise -- those in the middle mostly suffered. Dillard Department Stores Inc.'s sales rose only 2 percent, and Federated Department Stores Inc. squeaked in with a 1 percent gain, which was particularly weak considering last year's sales were flat. The J. C. Penney Company saw its sales fall 2.3 percent.
And the women's specialty stores continued their run of ho-hum merchandise and sales to match. The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation said sales fell 10.1 percent, and Talbots Inc. fell 11 percent. Limited Inc. enjoyed a 7 percent gain, but that was a result of the stellar performance of its Intimate Brands unit and huge price promotions in its women's apparel stores.
Intimate Brands, which runs Victoria's Secret and Bath and Body Works, offers the kinds of things that women like to get and give, and the unit's success underscores the fact that the old retail standbys like sweaters and scarves no longer cut it with many shoppers.
It was also clear that the retailers with the very best showings had one strong week after another, even though the last two weeks of the month were the best for them as well. Dollar General proved this, as did Gap Stores Inc., which posted a 10 percent sales gain. "We did a better job of being in stock on key items this year," Larry Shushan, a company spokesman, said. "I think we also had improved merchandise this year, especially on the men's side."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
South Koreans Appear to Get Debt Extension

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
The world's leading banks have tentatively agreed to extend payment on as much as $28 billion in short-term loans to South Korea that come due on March 31, a crucial precursor to easing the country's financial crisis.
All banks have committed to one-month extensions, or rollovers. This follows an extension agreed to last week on loans that came due at the end of December. 
 Many parties to yesterday's negotiations, including major American banks, have agreed to 90-day rollovers. Bankers who attended the meeting said international banks that have yet to commit formally to a 90-day rollover are expected to do so soon.
The negotiations on the loans have been slowed by disagreements among the banks on how to proceed and continue to be overshadowed by escalating financial problems ravaging Southeast Asia. But bankers who went into yesterday's negotiations at the New York headquarters of Citicorp nervous about potential fissures in the international banking coalition said they were now optimistic that all of the banks would soon be on board for 90 days.
Once the 90-day rollovers appear to be firmly in place, South Korea can take the more important step of repackaging its short-term loans as long-term debt and thus ease the credit shortage that is strangling the local economy.
But American commercial banks have yet to marshal the support they will need from Wall Street for a refinancing proposal that they presented in preliminary form to the South Korean Government last week, opening the possibility that the Government may find alternative proposals more attractive. Some Wall Street investment banks interested in helping American commercial banks float a huge South Korean bond offering are concerned about Japanese commitment to the plan. Japanese banks are said by other bankers to be hesitant to commit to the proposal until the South Korean position on a repackaging becomes clearer.
While it was hoped that the South Koreans, who were present at yesterday's meeting, would be sending a delegation back to the United States next week to discuss refinancing options, the Koreans now plan to wait until Jan. 19 to return here.
The South Korean Government, which has hired Goldman, Sachs & Company, Salomon Smith Barney Inc. and E. Gerald Corrigan, a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as financial advisers, also recently retained Mark Walker, a highly regarded New York lawyer who is a leading expert in debt restructurings.
American banks are proposing a $25 billion to $30 billion bond offering guaranteed by the South Korean Government, of which $10 billion would be used to replenish the country's foreign-exchange reserves and the remainder would replace short-term loans. The proposal is much larger than what the banks were considering only a week ago. Other options are being discussed by South Korea with its financial advisers. Goldman and Salomon have been considered potential rivals of American commercial bankers to lead any South Korean repackaging effort -- and to snare a lion's share of the big fees that will accompany it.
"Early on, I think there were suggestions that it was the investment bankers versus the commercial bankers competing for business in South Korea, but I think both sides have great interest in helping the South Koreans recover as quickly as possible," one American investment banker said. "Commercial banks have to be kept in the game."
There is still concern that a huge bond offering by South Korea could be a tough sell -- whoever leads it.
"People are wary of exposure to Asia right now and the more caveats and complexities that are associated with this, the less likely it is to go down well with investors," said John Davitte, an emerging-market bond analyst in London with the financial advisory firm I.D.E.A. "The size of this will be daunting and it's a matter of whether the appetite for Korean paper will be that strong."
A failed bond offering would have potentially disastrous repercussions in that could affect all of Southeast Asia, as well as Japan, South Korea's single largest creditor.
Indeed, representatives from Citicorp, J. P. Morgan & Company, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, Goldman, Sachs and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation will be having lunch today at the Essex House hotel with the Japanese Vice Finance Minister for International Affairs, Eisuke Sakakibara, to discuss the possibility that the Japanese Government will supplement recent moves to stimulate its staggering economy.
The International Monetary Fund, which released an additional $2 billion payment to South Korea yesterday as part of its $57 billion rescue package for the country, briefed attendees at the Citicorp meeting about South Korea's financial position. The I.M.F. declined to comment.

GRAPHIC: Charts: "The Debt Picture"
International banks are trying to extend repayment, or "roll over," short-term loans so the loans can be repackaged as longer-term debt to ease South Korea's cash crunch. About $35 billion to $40 billion in total short-term foreign currency loans owed by South Korea's banks and corporations comes due before March 31. Only South Korean bank debt is a candidate for blanket rollovers. Corporate debt other than bank debt will be decided on a case by case basis. The South Korean Government has no external short-term debt.

HEADLINE: Where Business Rules;
Forging Global Regulations That Put Industry First

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

 BODY:
The gilded Palais des Nations in Geneva is a perfect setting for the elite group of industry executives and government regulators who regularly meet there to establish worldwide auto safety regulations for the next century. A sign marked "Private" prevented anyone not part of the official 90-member delegation from entering the last gathering held in November.
As they decide public safety issues from emission standards to safety belts that will affect drivers and passengers around the world, the Geneva negotiators do not have to adhere to many of the rules requiring openness to the public and interest groups that govern similar proceedings in the United States. 
 In the interest of breaking down trade barriers, negotiations like these are trying to harmonize or create common regulations for products to be sold around the world. The auto negotiations in Geneva are on the cutting edge of this new regulatory world, where government agreements on everything from drug testing procedures to food safety standards are driven largely by the business interests most affected.
At the dawn of this new worldwide regulatory machinery, it is premature to predict its impact. But corporate executives are generally ecstatic, consumer advocates are increasingly critical and many regulators from the United States have mixed feelings. This reflects the tension that can sometimes arise between the expansion of trade and the retention of high standards for safety and health.
Barely noticed outside a small circle, the international rule making has sparked an underground debate over who gets to write the rules. Already, one of its creators is worried about the shape it is taking.
"This is about sovereignty, multinational corporations, the new post-cold-war world, global standards and international harmonization," said Mickey Kantor, chief trade negotiator and Commerce Secretary for President Clinton during his first term. "These are very important issues. But it is like they are being dealt with in a closet somewhere and no one's watching."
The final automobile standards agreement is expected by March but few consumer advocates will have had a say. There were 62 government regulators and 26 industry representatives who took part in the Geneva auto committee last November, under United Nations rules, but only one consumer representative from London and one auto club member from France.
Many American regulatory operations -- from those designed to prevent unsanitary meatpacking plants and adulterated drugs at the turn of the century to those put in place in the 1960's in response to unsafe cars -- were created to address social concerns and before global trade was so important. Now some of these rules are seen as impediments that can block markets and cause inefficiency.
Paula Stern, the chairwoman of the United States International Trade Commission under Presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, is one of the architects of what she calls "entrepreneurial diplomacy." Paid these days by corporations as a trade consultant, Ms. Stern applauds the role of businesses in what she sees as a valuable effort to streamline international regulation while maintaining public protection as worldwide trade expands. She said it was possible to "adapt the necessary goals of protecting health in a way that is also the most efficient and the most streamlined and that will make the U.S. economy the most competitive."
But since the regulation and standard setting is increasingly taking place in less open or accessible international forums, like the United Nations committee in Geneva, safety advocates worry that their concerns will be slighted. Already, David Snyder, an assistant counsel with the American Insurance Association, has criticized the "closed door" nature of the road to Geneva.
The United States wants to open up the process, but does not always get its way in international standard-setting forums. Last year, for example, Codex Alimentarius, a Rome-based group that sets global food safety standards, rejected United States efforts to cut in half the acceptable levels of lead in mineral water and to require dairy products to be pasteurized.
International business diplomacy was jump-started in 1995 with the creation of the World Trade Organization, which calls for single standards and shared regulatory systems across borders in the name of reducing barriers to trade.
Members of the W.T.O., like the United States, can theoretically retain their own higher standards, but those standards would be harder to defend before its international panels against a charge by another country that they represent a barrier to imports, according to trade experts. There are few legal precedents.
More and more standards are likely to be set in such global forums. The same week as the Geneva meeting, 70 corporate leaders from the United States and Europe gathered at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome. They drafted plans for streamlined government regulation of many industries, like chemicals and agribusiness, and acted at the behest of their respective governments. The group, the Trans Atlantic Business Dialogue, was conceived in December 1994 by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. In November 1995, six months before his death in a plane crash, Mr. Brown attended the group's first meeting, in Spain.
"We should put the business 'horse' before the government 'cart,' " he told the group. The business leaders recommended that their governments create common regulations, a plan adopted by President Clinton and European leaders at the end of 1995. The industrialists also called for common auto safety regulations through a United Nations committee -- the same committee that met last November in Geneva.
But the emphasis on business first bothers negotiators like Ricardo Martinez, the United States auto safety czar, who was at both the Geneva and Rome meetings. Dr. Martinez, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in Washington, thinks global regulation can be helpful to both industry and consumers. But he is concerned that the Trans Atlantic Business Dialogue and American car makers put too much emphasis on knocking down trade barriers rather than raising safety standards.
"I have great concerns that the perspective is not broad enough to respect the real issues of safety and health," he said in a recent interview in Rome. "The dialogue so far has been very much one way."
Dr. Martinez, 42, took office in 1994 with an unusual background for a regulator. Before he joined the highway safety agency, he was an emergency-care physician who attended to the victims of motor vehicle accidents -- the leading cause of death for Americans under the age of 44.
From the outset, Dr. Martinez had concerns about a lack of openness. In April 1996, he attended an industry conference in Washington where auto executives asked governments in Europe and the United States to follow their detailed road map to common international regulations.
That conference was not open to the public, either. Dr. Martinez, who was invited to attend, told the group he was sympathetic to their goals, provided there was no degradation of safety and more public involvement.
Over the next few months the highway safety agency and car executives listened to consumer and safety advocates. The agency held a public hearing, but by then an accord for Geneva was already drafted.
Safety advocates, used to playing a significant role in Federal rule making, complained of being left out of the early planning.
"Only when the train was well down the track were the groups brought into the process," said Mr. Snyder, a safety advocate who works with a group of American insurers. By contrast, consumer groups and ordinary Americans weigh in loudly on a variety of safety issues in the United States, both at public hearings and through the public comment periods that are mandated before any new regulation is approved.
Mr. Snyder cites the recent dispute over air bag safety for children as a vivid example of the critical role advocacy groups play in shaping regulations: The public comment period lasted most of last year.
In response, the car makers say that promotion of trade by governments can improve, not lower, safety standards.
It is not easy to combine European and American standards: Europe has higher standards in some areas and lower in others. American car makers certify their own products, while governments perform that job in Europe. European regulators say the United States is asking for too much control over the process. And they complain that Washington, while pushing for more openness, is leading the charge to intimately involve Detroit in the process. French officials "don't accept that businessmen can sit down and set policy," one European regulator said.
Dr. Martinez flew to Geneva last November carrying Washington's Draft Agreement Concerning the Establishing of Global Technical Regulations for Vehicles, Engines and Components, which called for the achievement of "high levels of safety" as well as the reduction of "technical barriers to international trade." It had been revised to address some but not all of the concerns of safety advocates.
For some, its twin goals of safety and trade can conflict. Mr. Snyder, the insurance lawyer, criticized the agreement for not calling for the "highest attainable levels of safety," a point Dr. Martinez called "constructive."
But Ms. Stern, a member of President Clinton's Advisory Committee on Trade Policy and Negotiations, sees no inherent conflict.
Indeed, she questioned the role played by consumer advocates in the United States. In Congressional testimony last September, she cited various "obstacles" to regulatory reform, including "strong grass-roots citizens organizations and their Congressional champions" who achieved legislation that "give ample time for comment, input and representation by any interested party but also have the effect of retarding or even blocking regulatory change."
By moving some rule making to an international setting, Ms. Stern added, corporations on both sides of the Atlantic "have become a chorus to their individual governments so the governments can't run and hide and use many of the excuses governments typically resort to."
In fact, business is not just the chorus, but often in a starring role.
In December 1996, as President Clinton and European Union leaders announced a deal to begin recognizing each other's regulatory systems in several product areas, he thanked "the Trans Atlantic Business Dialogue for their leadership in achieving these agreements."
Then Mr. Clinton responded to a question about the agreement by turning to Dana Mead, the chairman of Tenneco and the co-chair of the dialogue. Mr. Mead, not the President, answered the question.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "No Welcome Mat"
Since the World Trade Organization was created three years ago, the decades-long effort to expand global trade has shifted from a focus on tariffs to efforts to reduce other types of trade barriers. Consequently, international standards-setting forums -- many of which originated before the W.T.O. -- have taken on a growing importance. But a lot of these groups, mostly consisting of business and government interests, do not have to respond to public comments and have restrictive elegibility requirements for outsiders. Here are some of the issues these global rule makers are dealing with.
 
MOTOR VEHICLES
Standards for energy efficiency, pollution controls, and safety, including brakes, tires and seat belts, are on the table.
 
FOOD SAFETY
Acceptable levels of food additives, lead content in mineral water and pasturization of dairy products are just a few of the hundreds of standards being set by one group.
 
ACCOUNTING
Proper ways to account for derivatives and other financial instruments are being discussed as part of a larger effort to standardize global accounting principles.
 
DRUG APPROVAL
Procedures for conducting drug trials and reporting the results are under review.
 
FINANCIAL SERVICES
Setting minimum standards for how much capital banks must hold in reserve to reduce the risk of a global financial panic is a central element in a broader review of banking regulation.

HEADLINE: Guardian Insurance's Plan Adds to Downtown Rebirth

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
After scouring Manhattan for nearly two years, the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America signed a letter of intent yesterday to move its headquarters and 1,500 employees to 7 Hanover Square in lower Manhattan from Union Square.
If the deal is completed, it would be the first time that Guardian, founded just before the Civil War, has moved outside the Union Square neighborhood. It would also be the largest corporate relocation in at least a decade to lower Manhattan, the beleaguered office district that has staged a remarkable comeback in the last year. 
 Despite the improving economy and relatively cheap rents downtown, the Giuliani administration has agreed to provide the insurance company with a package of tax breaks worth roughly $10 million, according to real estate executives and a city official involved in the negotiations. Although the company's search has focused on Manhattan, Guardian, like many large corporations, had threatened to move to the suburbs.
"This would be in many ways the most important relocation downtown because of the combination of size and the prestige of the company," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. "I'm delighted about the prospects of them moving here."
Peter Hutchings, chief financial officer of Guardian, declined comment, as did the landlord at 7 Hanover Square, the Milstein Organization. Real estate executives familiar with the deal said that Guardian initially would lease 450,000 square feet at 7 Hanover and gradually expand to take over the entire 880,000-square-foot building over the next 10 years.
"Guardian's a great company," Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said in confirming the deal. "This will be great for the continued revitalization of downtown Manhattan."
Founded in 1860 as the Germania Life Insurance Company, the company changed its name to Guardian to avoid marketing problems during World War I. In 1911, the insurance company had built its current headquarters, a Renaissance Revival building at 201 Park Avenue South, just opposite the old Tammany Hall on the corner of 17th Street. The company later added an adjacent annex on 17th Street. Real estate sources said the Guardian, which also leases space in several nearby buildings, is expected to sell its Union Square properties.
Guardian's decision to move downtown follows in the path of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which recently sold its midtown building and leased 461,000 square feet at 1 World Trade Center. In turn, the vacancy rate in office buildings downtown has fallen to 17.6 percent, from a devastating 25.1 percent in 1995.
Budget watchdogs, as well as some politicians, say that the Giuliani administration should now end its policy of granting tax breaks to large corporations looking for office space. In 1995, the city instituted a series of property tax breaks and zoning changes designed to revive lower Manhattan. Since then, the Giuliani administration has provided additional tax incentives to 12 corporations located downtown that totaled more than $158 million.
"Even in a boom, there's no end to corporate welfare," said Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge.
In any event, Guardian's pending deal at 7 Hanover Square would bring to an end a game of musical chairs, real estate style, that has come to characterize corporate relocations in Manhattan.
Reliance Insurance, which had been negotiating for months to lease the same space at 7 Hanover Square, was left without a chair yesterday. Just last month, Guardian had scuttled talks to relocate to a far more luxurious site in a proposed new tower called Rockefeller Plaza West, according to two sources involved in the negotiations.
Guardian's decision to go downtown was a disappointment for the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation, which owns the parking lot on Seventh Avenue and 50th Street where it has long wanted to build the new office tower. The company began talks with Guardian last fall, after negotiations foundered with another potential tenant, Bear Stearns & Company.
In late November, Rockefeller executives expected to strike a deal with Guardian and began negotiating to buy unused development rights from the Shubert Organization, which owns the Winter Garden Theater across the street.
City officials intervened, however, suggesting that the Giuliani administration would not provide tax breaks for Guardian and the project unless the Rockefeller company built a musical theater in the tower with the Shuberts, according to people on all sides of the negotiations.
Neither the developer nor the insurance company were very interested in the idea, executives say, because it would have increased the cost of the building and taken longer to build. Guardian eventually broke off talks in December and focused its efforts on 7 Hanover, where the company is expected to have its name emblazoned on the building.
Mr. Millard of the Economic Development Corporation declined comment on those negotiations.
With vacancy rates falling sharply in midtown, Rockefeller executives expect to land an anchor tenant soon.
"Interest in Rockefeller Plaza West is extremely strong, with a number of major corporations looking at the project," said Vincent Silvestri, a spokesman for the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation. "We fully expect to make an announcement this year."

HEADLINE: New Data Suggest Universe Will Expand Forever

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Examining the distant light from stars that exploded before the Sun was born, astronomers have determined that the universe has apparently been expanding at a slow, steady rate since the beginning and is destined to expand forever.
The findings, if supported by further observations, suggest the answer to the fundamental question about the fate of the universe: Will it go on expanding, as it has since its creation in a theorized Big Bang? Or will the gravity of its mass eventually bring the universe to a halt, or possibly cause its collapse in a Big Crunch? 
 The new research also means that the universe could be as much as 15 billion years old, thus resolving a paradox posed by earlier findings that suggested an age for the universe that was younger than many of its constituent stars. But some theories about the early universe may have to be reconsidered.
In a remarkable display of agreement for the contentious field of cosmology, two teams of astronomers today reported observations of a certain class of exploding stars, or supernovas, showing that galaxies and other objects about halfway back in cosmic time were receding at velocities comparable to those of objects in more recent epochs. The results were announced at a meeting here of the American Astronomical Society.
"All the indications from our observations of supernovas spanning a large range of distances are that we live in a universe that will expand forever," said the leader of one team, Dr. Saul Perlmutter of Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California. "Apparently there isn't enough mass in the universe for its gravity to slow the expansion, which started with the Big Bang, to a halt."
Dr. Peter Garnavich of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., a leader of the other team, said the low deceleration of the expansion rate means that the universe is much older, about 15 billion years old, than had been calculated by some astronomers, whose estimates had ranged as low as 8 billion years. If the universe was not expanding at a faster rate earlier, then it has taken longer for it to reach its present size.
When the astronomers speak of matter in their calculations, they include everything -- ordinary matter that is seen or has not yet been detected, as well as the dark matter that is thought to include exotic particles, the existence of which has only been theorized. Recent research indicates that the mass of such matter is no more than 20 percent to 30 percent of what is considered the critical density needed to hold the expanding universe in check.
In an independent study of the expansion rates of 14 distant radio galaxies, Dr. Ruth A. Daly, a Princeton University astronomer, said "our results are basically almost identical" to those of the Berkeley and Harvard-Smithsonian supernova observations. "We are 95 percent confident that the universe is going to expand forever," Dr. Daly said.
Remarking on the close agreement of the different studies, Dr. Neta A. Bahcall, a Princeton astrophysicist, said this reinforced confidence that the conclusions are correct, or else everyone has overlooked some hidden flaw.
None of the astronomers at a news conference could think of any reasons for skepticism. But they cautioned that many more supernovas would need to be observed in detail before the issue could be resolved and a more precise value placed on estimates of the universe's deceleration.
"The field is moving very quickly," Dr. Perlmutter said at the news conference. He had just returned from the Keck Observatory in Hawaii with more data. By the beginning of the new millennium, he predicted, the extent to which the universe has decelerated, if at all, should be known.
The findings were not entirely unexpected. For more than a year, astronomers have been reluctantly coming to the realization that the universe is lightweight; it has a low mass density. The higher the density, the greater would be the deceleration of the expanding universe. But preliminary studies of distant objects like supernovas had begun to show little, if any deceleration.
The supernovas being studied belong to a class known as Type Ia. Their intrinsic brightness can be determined by how quickly each supernova fades away, making them reliable distance milestones for clocking any deceleration, compared with the expansion velocities of supernovas in more recent times.
Because the light of these supernovas fades in a month or so, astronomers must act quickly to make their measurements. They are using telescopes in Chile, the Canary Islands, Hawaii and Arizona, as well as the Hubble Space Telescope. The Hubble is called upon to study the most distant supernovas, some as far as seven billion light-years away, that are difficult to measure accurately from the ground.
The research confronts theorists with new challenges. A low-density universe does not readily conform to what is known as the inflationary model of the Big Bang theory. According to this model, in its first moments the universe underwent an extremely rapid expansion, then settled down to a more stately pace as it cooled off and gathered matter into stars and galaxies.
One prediction of the inflation model is that the universe should have a critical density. That would be just the right amount of mass to keep it from collapsing of its own weight or expanding into vanishing infinity. At the critical density, expressed as omega-equals-one, the universe would be in a state of equilibrium between collapse and eternal expansion.
If, as it now seems, the universe falls considerably short of critical density, theorists have already begun to add to their equations something called the cosmological constant. This is a kind of theoretical antigravity force -- an energy in the vacuum of space that attenuates the effects of mass gravity. In the absence of sufficient mass -- if omega is less than one -- this force could slow down cosmic expansion to allow for a bigger, older universe.
Like most astronomers who observe the heavens, Dr. Daly said it was now up to particle physicists and cosmologists to "figure out a way to have a cosmological constant, if you want to preserve inflation" as a keystone of their theories explaining the origin and evolution of the universe. Some theorists are already pondering ways that the inflation model could still be compatible with a low-density universe.
"I never underestimate the power of a theorist to come up with a new model," Dr. Perlmutter said.
