HEADLINE: Keeping a Clamp on the Bubble;
Call It Overdue, but Japan Credit Squeeze Inflicts Pain

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Surrounded by piles of cardboard boxes in her cluttered office, a middle-aged businesswoman remembered angrily how her bankers once tried to force money on her, urging her to take out a loan to buy a golf club membership as an investment.
Now she desperately needs $80,000 to finance the importing of chemicals for her medical supply business, and her bankers are saying no. She won a contract for medical equipment, but her bankers refused to finance that deal, too. 
 "This is a real credit crunch," said the woman, who runs a company with $1 million a year in sales and who refused to be identified for fear of reprisals from her bankers. "Everybody is feeling it, though people try not to show it because they need to stand tall to survive. You mustn't let your tears be seen."
All across Japan, the largest economy in the world outside the United States, small and medium-size companies are getting the same bad news from their bankers, who are cutting credit lines or refusing to renew loans as they come due. Some experts worry that the squeeze may push the long-faltering Japanese economy into even deeper trouble, worsening Asia's financial crisis and increasing the peril of a global slowdown.
"For the first time in seven years, we are facing a major credit crunch," said Richard C. Koo, chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute. Yoshiteru Iwai, who runs a financial consulting company that has been inundated with calls from credit-starved clients, added: "It's awful, very severe and widespread. Japanese financial institutions have gone crazy."
Or they have just come to their senses, in the view of some analysts here and abroad. For years, the banks lent profligately, helping to send real estate prices soaring throughout the country. Even after that speculative bubble burst in the early 1990's, the banks neglected to rein in their recklessness, refusing to confront a huge mountain of bad loans on their books.
Now, as a wave of bankruptcies sweeps across Japan and as the Government cracks down with tougher regulation, the banks are slamming on the brakes. Their new approach threatens to throttle the hobbled economy. But many experts say that in fact tighter lending standards are just what the country needs to fix its financial system in the long run.
"What credit crunch?" said Alicia Ogawa, managing director at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. "A lot of what people call credit crunch is simply the banks getting wise." In many cases, she said, they have called loans held by struggling companies that the banks have tried to revitalize for a year or two. The cutting off of credit, she added, is simply "good business."
Good or bad, the squeeze has gained less attention than one might expect, both in Japan and the United States, because so far it has not affected the largest companies. The Toyota Motor Corporation and the Sony Corporation, for example, are flush with cash and have bankers knocking at their doors to lend more, even as many small businesses that are the backbone of Japan's economy are stunned by the rejections they are getting from their lenders.
Paradoxically, with near-zero interest rates, this would seem at first glance to be a time of easy money. But though rates are extremely attractive, money is simply unavailable to many business customers, and one result is that Japan's economy is about as fragile as it has ever been in the 1990's.
The situation is reminiscent of the United States in the early 90's, when rates were low but money was similarly tight. That squeeze was also a result of speculative lending, by the American savings and loan industry, whose portfolios were bulging with bad real estate loans.
For now, in Japan, tight credit has sent the outlook for business to its lowest level in nearly 15 years, according to a Government-sponsored survey late last month of smaller companies. Central bank officials said they were surprised to find that even large banks had a "negative attitude" toward lending.
Unpaid debt is once again going up, bankruptcies are mounting, and the Government has been forced to retreat from its pledge that the nation's top banks are "too big to fail." In November, the Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, among the nation's 20 biggest, was allowed to fail. A few weeks later, Yamaichi Securities, one of Japan's Big Four securities houses, collapsed.
One reason for the credit squeeze is a fear of the unknown and unexpected that was symbolized by the failure of Yamaichi. What frightened the banking world was the disclosure that Yamaichi had more than $2 billion in off-the-book liabilities. Now banks and companies shrink from clients who they suspect may have hidden problems. "There's no more trust," said a Japanese financier who has dealt with South Korean and Southeast Asian clients. "I've had to unwind deals. And that means goodbye for good."
Banks have reason to be wary of even one another. In the fall, during a liquidity run that ended up with the bankruptcy of a medium-size brokerage firm called Sanyo Securities, one regional Japanese bank defaulted on its payments in the interbank market, according to a central bank official. That incident was hushed up to preserve confidence, but it underscores the risks.
The mistrust in the marketplace is so great that both foreign and domestic suppliers are stiffening their terms for payment. Instead of simply trusting a customer to pay within 30 days, they are demanding letters of credit or payment in advance.
Bankers are also tightening credit because their portfolios look like minefields. The Toshoku Company, a major food supplier, suddenly filed for bankruptcy in late December, providing a number of banks with unexpected losses. Now, the banking industry as a whole is wondering which of its borrowers will turn out to be the next Toshoku.
For the year through November, there were 14,772 bankruptcies, the highest number in 13 years, among companies with debt of at least 10 million yen, or $75,000, according to the Teikoku Data Bank, a research agency. It projects the number for the entire year to be about 16,000. The agency added that since the credit squeeze began just recently, only a small number of those bankruptcies were directly related to "kashi-shiburi," or "reluctance in lending," as the situation is described in Japanese.
Another reason for the credit squeeze is tighter regulations. By March 31, Japanese banks with overseas branches will have to meet international standards for capital strength -- requiring them to have capital equivalent to 8 percent of their assets at risk, meaning loans.
For even the most solid of the banks that is a tall order, particularly since they have been depleting their capital base over the last couple of years by starting to write off bad debt and setting aside provisions for losses from more bad loans.
So, most banks, pressed to improve their capital ratios, are finding it easier to reduce their loans outstanding than to raise new capital.
Indeed, Fuji Bank, one of the nation's largest, announced that by 2000 it would reduce its loans and other assets by 6 trillion yen, or about $45 billion, representing 10 percent of its assets at risk. The Yasuda Trust and Banking Company, another large institution, said it planned to cut its assets, including loans, by 45 percent over three years.
The depressed stock market -- which is at less than half its peak in 1989 -- is still another reason for the problems. A fair share of a bank's capital is in the market, and as the market tumbles, so does its capital. That is where the pressure comes to curb loans to stay within the 8 percent requirement.
Government officials have tried to reassure the markets that there will be no more major bankruptcies. But they made a similar promise in 1995 -- and again last year -- when they said that the nation's top 21 banks were too big to fail, at least until 2000. Many bankers now feel that the Government has largely lost control over the economy and the financial sector.
The Finance Ministry is trying to ease the credit squeeze by making a loan pool of 25 trillion yen, or $190 billion, available to small and medium-size businesses over the next 15 months and by guaranteeing other loans. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto also announced a $15 billion income tax cut in mid-December.
Since then, the Government has eased the pressure on purely domestic banks by giving them an extra year to meet the new capital requirements, which were to go into effect for them on April 1. It also loosened the reporting requirements on stock portfolios for banks, allowing them to report losses on their short-term holdings as a whole rather than forcing them to mark down each stock. Though the moves may appease a few banks, they are a step backward from market discipline, some financial analysts say.
Indeed, some see the whole credit squeeze as a step forward, in the sense that banks are finally caring about risks. In the past, they often allocated cash based on relationships, more than on any kind of serious analysis of creditworthiness, and one reason borrowers are facing difficulties now is the painful transition to a more systematic evaluation of risk.
Still, a consequence is that many mom-and-pop businesses, including a good number that are basically sound and have a long record of repaying on time, are being brought to their knees all across Japan.
Take the case of the woman who has been turned down for loans to import chemicals and medical equipment. She had given the banks collateral -- the building she works in -- to back her previous credit line of $4 million, but the banks said that the value of the building had sunk so low that they could no longer lend to her.
Now, she fears that without access to money for her daily operations, she might miss a payment to creditors -- or have to turn to loan sharks.
"This is bullying against the weak," the woman grumbled. "We could end up defaulting on a bill. If that happens once, you are on a blacklist. If it happens twice, you are out of business."

HEADLINE: For the Sexes, Equality Under the Law and Under the Hair Clippers

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
It may pale beside the right to vote, expanded employment opportunities or corporate-subsidized child care, but a new law signed yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave women in New York City hope for liberation from a lingering, undeniably pesky manner of oppression.
At long last, they may escape the tyranny of higher prices for the laundering of a shirt or the cutting of hair that is essentially no different from a man's. 
 Then again, they may not. City Council Bill No. 804-A seeks to ban all gender-related price discrimination in establishments like dry cleaners and hair salons. But merchants may well find ways to sidestep the requirements of the law, and it is unclear how vigorously it will be enforced.
The new law forbids merchants to post prices that distinguish between male and female customers. Existing laws require that retail establishments post all prices for general, basic services.
Its backers called the law a milestone that would, at the very least, begin to erode a tradition of women automatically -- and inexplicably -- paying more for certain services.
"It was an injustice what was being done to women," said one of the bill's sponsors, Councilwoman Karen Koslowitz, a Democrat from Queens. Ms. Koslowitz helped coordinate a 1996 survey of 200 randomly selected hair salons in New York City that found that 48.5 percent of them charged women more than men for a basic cut.
"Nowadays," she said, "it's the same thing: Men color their hair; they have it blow-dried; they have it styled. Where I go, you see men in there all the time. What we want is the same price for the same service."
But while Ms. Koslowitz sounded impassioned, the reactions of women interviewed at random on city streets this week were as likely to tend toward blase.
While some called price discrepancies grossly unfair, others said the gender gap made sense.
"Most women tend to be pickier," said Dannette Bock, an actress who walked out of an Upper West Side hair salon yesterday evening with a freshly trimmed mane of lustrous brown hair. A male friend was at her side, and while she had paid $30 for her cut, he had paid $25.
But Ms. Bock said that she had been under the scissors for 45 minutes while her friend was finished in 20, so the bargain was really hers. "If anything," she said, "it should be charged on an hourly rate."
The new law, similar to one that went into effect in California two years ago, gives the city's Consumer Affairs Department the power to send inspectors into retail establishments to check on posted prices and, if those prices make distinctions based on gender, issue fines of $50 to $500.
A department spokeswoman did not return two phone calls this week requesting information on plans to enforce the law.
The law's backers conceded that some retail establishments may simply change the language on their price lists to eliminate references to gender while making other distinctions: long hair versus short or plain shirts versus ones with more decorative buttons.
But the city's Public Advocate, Mark J. Green, another sponsor of the law, said he intended to make sure it did not languish as idle symbolism, because it was simply too important. He said working women were being hit by a double economic whammy: lower wages and higher prices to launder or dry-clean the clothes they wore to the office.
Mr. Green said several surveys had documented a widespread pattern of dry cleaners and hair salons routinely overcharging women for virtually the same services men received.
But many hair cutters and dry cleaners said that discrimination is the wrong word for the price differences, because the services provided to men and those provided to women differ substantially.
"As far as a woman is concerned, a blouse is just like a shirt," said Bill Seitz, executive director of the Neighborhood Cleaners Association, a trade group. "Except it isn't.
"There are blouses that have beads and blouses that have trimmings and blouses that have lace and all kinds of very exciting and inventive ideas to make Mrs. Consumer or Miss Consumer more beautiful but are difficult to clean and press," Mr. Seitz said.
He said that even when a woman's shirt is almost identical to a man's, it often cannot fit easily onto old machinery designed for the size and shape of a man's shirt. Critics of pricing discrepancies countered that such antiquated equipment should be the industry's problem, not female customers'.
Hair stylists, meanwhile, said most women's hair takes more care and time than men's. "You can't charge the same because it's a different look," said Lyova Shikhil, owner of Belnord Unisex on the Upper West Side. Mr. Shikhil charges both men and women $18 for a basic cut, but for more extensive styling, he charges men $22 and women $34.
"You can cut men one, two, three," he explained. "Women -- you have to make them a princess."
The standard prices at the Panache salon in Forest Hills, Queens, showed that women do not always come out on the short end, revealing an unexpected discrepancy to which the new law would also apply.
Like many salons, Panache charges men $8 for a manicure, but women $6. "Men have a lot more cuticle," said Novell Kuedsak, a stylist there. "Plus, they don't maintain their nails every week like women. They need a lot more buffing."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Tumble in U.S. As Asian Worries Mount
Stocks tumbled, driven down in huge waves of selling on fears over how deeply America's economy will be hurt by Asia's festering financial crisis. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 222.2 points, or 2.85 percent, its sharpest drop since October's plunge. For the week, the Dow was down 4.8 percent. Broader market measures were also sharply lower.
 
 The slump comes as more investors are worried that American corporations will increasingly feel the pinch of a global economic slowdown caused by the rapid deterioration in Asia. But while Asia is bad news for stocks, it is good for investors in the bond market. Long-term rates slipped to near 30-year lows as the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.73 percent. Page A1.
 
Peregrine Investments, one of the brashest symbols of Asia's 1990's boom, was fighting for its life after the collapse of a $200 million deal with a Swiss investor. Hong Kong regulators plan to limit the company's business. D3.
 
H.M.O. Curtails Fertility Coverage
Aetna, one of the country's biggest health insurers, said its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, effective April 1. Aetna had been under pressure from investors to reduce costs and increase profits. A1.
 
Owens Corning Cuts Back
Owens Corning will dismiss 2,200 people, close plants and report unexpectedly weak earnings, reflecting intense competition in the home-insulation business. The company, a leading maker of building materials, said it had been hurt by falling prices despite a boom in the housing industry. Shares of Owens Corning fell $1.625, to $32. The stock has declined 36.6 percent from a 52-week high of $49.875 last Jan. 14. D2.
 
Inspection of Boeing Plants
A team of Federal Aviation Administration inspectors will be sent to two Boeing plants after the discovery that part of the tail of a Boeing 737 that crashed in Indonesia last month appears to have separated from the plane before impact. A10.

Delay in Texas Tobacco Suit
A Federal judge delayed the start of jury selection in a lawsuit filed by Texas against the tobacco industry as the two sides sought to resolve disputes that have impeded a settlement. The tobacco companies named in the lawsuit offered to settle it last week for $7.25 billion, but there remains disagreements over lawyers' fees and over who will decide to divide them. A16.
 
German Unemployment Increases
Germany's jobless rate unexpectedly rose to a postwar high of 11.9 percent in December. It was the ninth consecutive monthly increase and cast doubt on the pace of recovery in Europe's biggest economy. D2.
 
Lloyd's Profits Expected to Drop
Lloyd's of London, the world's oldest insurance market, will likely report a 41 percent decline in profits for 1996 and a 32 percent decline for 1997 because of diminished premium income, a group of Lloyd's analysts estimates. The company reports its financial results belatedly to allow time for claims to be calculated. D2.
 
China's New Consumerism
Glossy, ad-packed newspapers -- with titles like Fine Goods Shopping Guide and Shopping Guide -- have become hot sellers on newsstands in Beijing. The tabloids are evidence that a new generation of Chinese has entered the global consumer culture, whether all can afford it or not. A1.

HEADLINE: Iranians Receptive To Opening To America

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 9

 BODY:
President Mohammad Khatami's "message to the American people," delivered in a television interview the other night, has begun to play well in Iran.
An impressionistic sampling of Iranian public opinion, consisting of two dozen interviews in the rich and poor sections of Teheran today, suggested that Mr. Khatami had succeeded in his evident attempt to sway public opinion at home as much as to reach out to the United States. 
 Most of the Iranians interviewed expressed satisfaction with the President's interview, which was printed in full in a newspaper here and broadcast twice on television in its entirety. But like American officials and other Western analysts, they had widely different interpretations of what he said.
"It was ambiguous," said a 57-year-old homemaker who refused to give her name. "People can interpret it the way they want, whether he was for or against relations with the U.S."
Some Iranians believe that Mr. Khatami's message was the first step toward the renewal of diplomatic relations, even though he went out of his way to say that while he favored cultural and academic exchanges, he did not believe that a dialogue between the two estranged Governments was needed.
"My son is in the States, and I believe we should resume ties," said a 55-year-old textile producer, who gave only his first name, Hassan.
Iran is a country that thrives on conspiracy, and some Iranians are convinced that the Government already has a secret relationship with the United States. "I believe that Iranians have already started relations with America and this interview was to pave the way to tell this little by little to the Iranian people," said Bhnaz Fallahi, a 31-year-old computer engineer.
But a minority of those interviewed said their President's acknowledgment that Americans had been hurt by the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran in 1979 and his denunciation of the burning of the American flag were proof that he was soft on the United States.
"The President was soft," said a 25-year-old university student whose father was killed in the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980's. "We will never allow relations with the United States."
The first official reaction came today from two Iranian clerics who preached at the authoritative weekly Prayers to tens of thousands of worshipers gathered for the open-air service at Teheran University despite a raging blizzard.
The clerics' remarks were not exactly a ringing endorsement of their new President. But the fact that they did not criticize him either was proof enough that he had not alienated the clerical leadership with his modest proposal for cultural exchanges and his praise for American civilization.
Ayatollah Mohammad Imami Kashani, one of Iran's most important clerics, reserved his criticism for those Americans who, he said, distort the truth and who ignored Mr. Khatami's assertion in his interview that American foreign policy is made in Israel.
"The trumpets of the world's oppressors take a sentence they like from Mr. Khatami's speech and give it their own interpretation," he told the worshipers.
In the same vein, he added: "There was a poor man who couldn't afford anything, so he rubbed a piece of fat on his lips every day and told people what delicious food he had eaten, but people knew he was a liar and didn't believe him. Americans are like that. They lie to people."
It takes a lot for an ayatollah to keep a sermon short, but Ayatollah Kashani's lasted only six minutes. It was not, he said, that he did not have more to say. It was the snow.
Ayatollah Kashani's opinion carries enormous weight. The spokesman for the powerful Guardian Council, which insures that legislation conforms to Islamic principles, he had endorsed Mr. Khatami's hard-line opponent in the presidential campaign in May.
An unidentified cleric who preceded Ayatollah Kashani said the President's remarks were "inspired" by Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who has rigidly opposed any warming of relations with the United States. The cleric also endorsed Mr. Khatami's statement that Iran's most popular mantra, "Death to America," was not directed at the American people.
"The crimes of American politicians come from the Israelis," the junior cleric said. He adapted the mantra to the changing times, chanting, "Death to those American politicians who commit these crimes!"
Then he gave an order: "Now shout 'Death to America!' "
The worshipers did, several times.
Morteza Arvandi, a 53-year-old former bookstore clerk explained why "Death to America" was still such a powerful chant. "It's because the Americans have put us under tremendous economic pressure with sanctions," he said. A single tomato, he added, costs almost $2.
Mr. Khatami's interview was not seen by most Iranians when it was broadcast on CNN in Teheran at 2:30 A.M. Thursday. CNN is available only through satellite dishes, which are forbidden in Iran, except for high-ranking officials, foreign diplomats, one or two hotels and a few other privileged individuals.
Iranian television viewers had to wait until official Iranian television broadcast the interview later Thursday morning and evening.
Marziyeh Vahid Dastjerdi, a leading female member of Parliament, who said early this week that only Ayatollah Khamenei, not the President, had the authority to decide on opening an official dialogue with Washington, praised Mr. Khatami's performance in the interview.
"It was very, very good," she said in an interview. "The President followed the leader and criticized having a dialogue between governments. I'm satisfied."
Few Iranian newspapers have weighed in with comment, which is expected over the next several days.
The English-language daily Iran News called Mr. Khatami "a shrewd politician," adding that it would have been politically dangerous for him to go further than he did in bridging the 19-year-old chasm between Iran and the United States.
"Anyone who takes the first step to establish ties with the U.S. without obtaining concessions from Washington to justify the move and to appease the domestic pressure groups would be committing political suicide," the newspaper said.
Only the hard-line daily Kayhan has so far leveled any specific criticism against Mr. Khatami, chastising him for calling the seizure of the American Embassy a revolutionary act that could not occur today and expressing regret that it had hurt the feelings of the American people.
"Why do we have to stand trial and define that revolutionary act as an emotional act just to satisfy Western norms and tastes?" the newspaper asked. "It's a shame that instead of expressing regret, the President did not try to convey the grievances of the Iranian nation to the American people."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
ANXIETIES ON ASIA PUSH U.S. STOCKS DOWN NEARLY 3%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER and DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market suffered its worst drop since the plunge of late October yesterday, driven down by huge waves of selling on fear over how deeply America's economy could be hurt by Asia's festering financial crisis.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 222.20 points, or 2.9 percent. Equally large declines in broader measures gave the stock market its steepest weekly loss since 1989. 
 The concern over Asia has been ebbing and flowing since the crisis began last summer. At the first peak of worry the Dow fell 554 points, or 7.2 percent, on Oct. 27. Yesterday's decline came after the apparent stabilization of Asia last month gave way to sharp new declines in stocks and currencies.
More and more investors are worried that American corporations will increasingly feel the pinch of a global economic slowdown caused by the rapid deterioration in Asia.
But while Asia is bad news for stocks, it is good for investors in the bond market, where interest rates are determined. That could signal good news for homeowners and consumers, who will probably feel the benefits of lower rates on loans.
Bond investors see Asia bringing slower growth and lower inflation, which make bonds an attractive investment, especially when the outlook for the stock market is uncertain. This belief more than offset what normally would have been negative news for bonds: a strong increase of 370,000 in new jobs in December.
Rather than raising fears of higher interest rates because of too rapid economic growth, short-term interest rates in the bond market plunged enough yesterday to indicate many investors are convinced the Asian situation will slow growth here enough to force the Federal Reserve to lower its interest-rate target.
"People are really being forward- looking and are willing to overlook economic statistics," said Russ Sheldon, chief economist at MCM, a market research firm.
The yield on the two-year Treasury note, a benchmark of short-term interest rates, dropped to 5.17 percent from 5.29 percent and is now down almost half a percentage point this year. More important, the yield is below the central bank's 5.5 percent target for short-term interest rates, a clear sign that investors are now betting the Fed will move its target lower. Long-term rates also slipped to levels near their lowest in 30 years as the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.73 percent, just above its recent low of 5.72 percent.
The decline in bond yields has already pushed mortgage interest rates below 7 percent and they might go lower, which could generate a round of mortgage refinancings as more people seek to reduce their monthly payments. That could bolster consumer spending by giving homeowners more cash each month. And if the Federal Reserve does follow through with a cut in interest rates, other consumer interest rates -- on car loans, credit cards and consumer and small-business loans -- could begin to fall.
The changing and varied fortunes of stocks and bonds are largely a result of the economic shock waves from Asia. What began last summer as a currency crisis in Thailand, quickly spread to Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong and South Korea.
But even though the International Monetary Fund has assembled bailout packages totaling more than $100 billion, and private lenders are working to help, each day this year the crisis has seemed to deepen, especially since the collapse this week of the Indonesian currency sent the stock market there tumbling and pulled other markets down.
As the Asian outlook worsened this week, there were daily warnings in the United States that fourth-quarter corporate profits, which will soon be announced, may have been weakened by slowing demand in Asia.
Yesterday, for instance, Adaptec, a maker of computer components, said third-quarter earnings would be sharply lower than expected. Adaptec shares fell 40 percent. It was one of many technology companies to issue such a warning in recent weeks.
As a result, scores of technology stocks have been beaten down and that momentum carried over into yesterday. Oil, banking and brokerage firm stocks were hit hard.
Nearly five stocks fell for every one that rose on the New York Stock Exchange, sending all the major stock indexes sharply lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a major barometer of market health, fell nearly 3 percent, while the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks sank by an equal amount on one of the heaviest trading days ever, with more than 746 million shares changing hands on the Big Board.
"People are beginning to realize that Asia is not going to go away," said Michael Metz, the chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "Every day we get a warning from corporations that Wall Street's earnings estimates are too high. And that's for the fourth quarter. What's going to happen in the spring?"
The selloff this week, which pushed the Dow down nearly 5 percent, is troubling to Wall Street forecasters partly because the market's behavior in early January has historically been a fairly reliable, albeit unscientific, forecaster of the year.
"There is market lore here in the U.S. that the first five days of the year set the tone for the rest of the year," said Philip J. Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. "If you put any faith in that legend we're in for some tough sledding."
Many on Wall Street, however, have for some time been expecting 1998 to be a difficult year, largely because the major indexes have just completed an unparalleled third consecutive year of annual gains of 20 percent or more.
Richard McCabe, chief market strategist at Merrill Lynch, and others are advising investors to be more cautious by buying shares of domestic companies that will probably be less affected by the Asian crisis.
The rally in the bond market, some analysts contend, is a sign that some investors have decided that they want to protect themselves by investing in the safety of Treasury bonds, which do not offer the potentially high rewards of stocks but also carry much less risk.
"The surge we are getting in the bond market is coinciding with a decent pullback in the stock market," said Nancy Kimelman, the chief economist at Technical Data in Boston. "There is certainly a reassessment going on of where the risks lie in 1998."

HEADLINE: Seeking to Halt Rutgers Skid, The Governor Sends In a Play

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 8

 BODY:
The Rutgers University football team has stumbled for years, but when it lost every game this last season, New Jersey's powerful sports and political establishments decided that enough was enough.
Last month, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman took the rare step of intervening in the university's affairs and proposed her own candidate to run its long-troubled athletic program: Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, the president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. During her annual meeting with the university president, Francis L. Lawrence, the Governor urged him to hire Mr. Mulcahy, said Pete McDonough, a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman. 
 Like the Governor, state legislators from both parties said that a successful sports program would draw more attention and dollars to the state's largest university. And they, too, are pushing the candidacy of Mr. Mulcahy, who has been widely praised in his role as the overseer of the Meadowlands sports complex.
The winless season has also galvanized faculty at Rutgers who have long criticized Dr. Lawrence for investing too heavily in sports at the expense of academics. They argue that money being spent on sports should be used to hire more professors, reduce class sizes and buy more library books.
Rutgers's predicament is not unusual. Across the nation, other state-supported institutions are pouring money into intercollegiate sports in hopes of making headlines and hefty profits. If their teams fail, they not only waste millions of dollars a year but face dizzying deficits. They also lose standing with legislators, alumni, corporate donors and prospective students.
But winning teams can fill stadiums with thousands of fans, attract lucrative television and radio contracts and raise revenues and a school's reputation. In 1996, when the Northwestern University football team made it to the Rose Bowl, admissions applications increased by 21 percent and game attendance soared.
"High-profile, winning athletic teams attract attention to the school," Mr. McDonough said, "they attract resources and they attract prestige. The Governor thinks it's a very important part of the university's whole program."
While Dr. Lawrence, in an interview, repeatedly stressed the importance of academics, he said that improving the sports program was a top priority because it would increase alumni and legislative financial support. He said that despite losing $31.5 million on the athletic program in the last decade, Rutgers would remain a member of Division 1 of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in basketball and a member of the Big East football conference, which both require significant investments. He said that spending on sports, about $20 million a year, was an "infinitesimal" portion of the university's $1 billion budget. Dr. Lawrence also said that improving the sports program would give Rutgers more visibility and prestige.
"Sports takes up one whole section in the newspaper," he said, his voice hoarse from having shouted the men's basketball team to an 81-49 victory over Seton Hall, their main rival, on Wednesday. "We want athletics to complement the university and develop its stature to the point where we are as successful as our peer institutions."
Rutgers has been trying to get to that point since the 1970's, when Sonny Werblin, a Rutgers alumnus and former part owner of the New York Jets, insisted big-time sports was the way to attract national attention to the university. The university joined the Big East football conference in 1991. The state also invested heavily in the effort to raise the stature of the football program, providing $29 million in bonds through the sports authority to build a 40,500-seat stadium in Piscataway in 1994.
But the football team kept losing, the new stadium failed to draw crowds, and ticket sales, which are supposed to provide the biggest portion of revenue for athletic programs, dwindled. Rutgers dismissed one football coach, Doug Graber, in 1995, but promised to pay his $290,000 salary until his contract expired next month. Meanwhile, the university hired another coach, Terry Shea, for $300,000 a year. Rutgers is also paying two basketball coaches: Bob Wenzel, who was dismissed in 1996, and Kevin Bannon, his replacement.
"The program is a dinosaur and it isn't competitive with the real world," said State Senator John A. Lynch, a Democrat from New Brunswick who said he canceled his season football tickets for the first time last fall. "Once they chose to play the Big East they needed to do marketing and make sure the athletes succeed academically. They have not done a good job."
But Dr. Lawrence and the Governor do not necessarily agree on who can rejuvenate Rutgers's program, a conflict that could damage Dr. Lawrence's already-shaky standing in Trenton. Mrs. Whitman, top legislators and several members of the Rutgers Board of Governors have said the university should snap up Mr. Mulcahy, whose term at the sports authority ends this month and who is said to want the job badly.
But instead of hiring Mr. Mulcahy immediately, Dr. Lawrence said he would conduct a nationwide search for a new athletic director after seeing the results of two studies of the athletic program that are due this month. He said he would not choose a candidate until spring.
"We don't want to make a quick or a rash decision," Dr. Lawrence said. "Bob Mulcahy has been very successful on behalf of New Jersey. On the other hand, I believe it is too early to speculate on the likelihood of any particular individual being appointed."
One legislator and several people close to Mr. Mulcahy said they saw Mrs. Whitman's intervention in the search for an athletic director as a sign of her disappointment in Dr. Lawrence's performance at Rutgers. Those same people said that Mrs. Whitman has talked to former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, now the president of Drew University in Madison, N.J., about the possibility of replacing Dr. Lawrence.
But Mr. McDonough said the Governor is not motivated by any dissatisfaction with Dr. Lawrence. "I've not heard her say anything about it," he said. "It's just not an issue for the moment."
Mr. Mulcahy, 61, is a Democrat who has led the sports authority since 1979. With a salary of $182,875, he is one of the state's highest paid officials. The Rutgers job, now held by Fred Gruninger, pays $114,000. Mr. Gruninger announced last Oct. 10, a day after the football team suffered a humiliating 50-3 loss to Syracuse, that he would be retiring in June.
Mrs. Whitman has generally praised Mr. Mulcahy for his role in the growth and success of the Meadowlands. Last year, it had $206 million in revenues and a surplus of $34.3 million. People close to Mr. Mulcahy, who was State Corrections Commissioner in the 1970's, said he had enough respect from both the political and sports establishments to turn the Rutgers program around. They said he saw the job as a final challenge before his retirement.
"If you think of the A.D.'s job only as an A.D.'s job, maybe it's a step down for Bob," said Michael Rowe, president of the New Jersey Nets. "But if you want to raise funds, work with legislators and establish Rutgers as a premier entertainment option with sports as a basis, Bob can do it."
Mr. Mulcahy himself would not comment on the prospect of the Rutgers job. "I'm just focused on what I'm doing," he said.
But even with the savviest of athletic directors, Rutgers could have trouble making money on sports because of its location, said Richard McCormick, the university historian. With the New York Giants, the New York Jets and the Philadelphia Eagles nearby, New Jersey residents are less likely to attend college football games, he said.
"The kind of enthusiasm for college games that you get in the South and the West does not exist here," Mr. McCormick said. "We don't have a glorious athletic tradition, and it would be very hard for us to get into that club."
Mr. McCormick argued that the money that Rutgers is putting into sports would be better spent on academics, technology and programs for New Jersey residents. He said that Rutgers was in "a holding pattern" and that many programs sorely needed resources.
"There is more to be achieved in terms of academic programs and public services," Mr. McCormick said. "We have, aside from athletic prowess, a lot of good messages for the people of New Jersey but many are not being heard."
But Dr. Lawrence said other programs had suffered because of the recession in the early 1990's, not because of sports. He said that spending on instruction, research and libraries nearly doubled over 10 years and that last year alone, he dedicated $7 million to hiring professors, buying books and journals and creating new academic programs.
"People are always looking for something to blame for why they didn't get the funds," Dr. Lawrence said. "Those whose programs we're stressing will be very happy, and those that we're not will continue to limp along. It doesn't mean we don't value them."
But, he said, top-notch football and basketball teams could stir enough state pride in Rutgers to bring in more public and private funds, not just for sports but for academics, construction and technology. Legislators -- 22 of whom are Rutgers alumni -- did not hesitate to agree.
"It's a lot easier when a school comes up for a budget hearing if that school has a winning team," said State Senator Richard J. Codey, the Democratic minority leader who said he rarely attends Rutgers games these days. "It wouldn't hurt if you had legislators begging for tickets. It would do wonders for the university."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Backlash At the Pump

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I like to think of the world as four different gas stations. At the Japanese gas station, gas is $5 a gallon, four uniformed men wait on you and wash your windows, and you drive away at ease. At the American gas station, gas costs $1 a gallon, you pump it yourself and four homeless people mug you around the corner and steal your hubcaps. At the European gas station, gasoline costs $5 a gallon, one person who works only 32 hours a week and has six weeks' vacation waits on you, and four people living on generous unemployment insurance are playing boccie ball across the street. At the Communist gas station gas costs only 50 cents a gallon, but there is none. The four attendants have sold it all on the black market for $5 a gallon.
What is happening, for the moment, is that the American gas station model is triumphing over all others. But not without a struggle. Korea, Japan and the other Asians are scrambling to avoid having to emulate the U.S. system. They like their kind of gas station, which has kept a lot of people employed and preserved social harmony, by using crony capitalism and walls of protection. 
 Question: What will be the backlash in Asia from everyone being forced into our gas station? I see several scenarios:
1. The anti-American backlash. What happened in Asia is that a lot of private businesses in Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, working through their local banks, borrowed money from private American, Japanese and European banks. Then the Asian currencies collapsed and they were unable to pay back their loans. The I.M.F., to stabilize the situation, steps in and asks the Asian governments to take over the failing banks, in order to sort out the bad loans and repay the foreign banks. The I.M.F. also insists that these countries open their economies and let foreigners buy controlling interests in local banks and businesses. In return the I.M.F. lends them money to pay off their debts. Then, when the crisis is over and these countries start growing again, their citizens can repay the I.M.F.
In short, the Asians are being told: Let America in, have your taxpayers pay America's banks back, let Americans buy your crown jewels at bargain-basement prices, and, by the way, get rid of those three extra guys working in your gas station.
Some Asians won't mind this. A Thai friend told me that a friend of his recently lost his wallet with four bank cards in it, one from American Express and three from Bangkok banks. American Express sent him a new card that evening by motor scooter. He still has not heard from the three Bangkok banks. If American Express is now able to buy one of those Bangkok banks and improve its services, will my friend care? Not at all. But a lot of Thai businessmen might when they discover that American Express won't lend money the old crony way, or that they have to sell their Thai hotels and banks to Americans, at fire-sale prices, to stay solvent.
2. The anti-free-market backlash. There is going to be a big push now to see if there is a "third way" between the American gas station and the old Asian one. A lot of countries are going to try to avoid huge layoffs by reducing the workweek, pumping some money into the economy (despite the I.M.F.), keeping some large projects going and asking their people to save more and cash in their gold earrings. Maybe they will lay off one of the four people at their gas station, but still keep three. Their attitude is that there was an Asian capitalist way before and there can be one again. Anything but the American gas station.
3. The political backlash. If you talk to Indonesians today, what's interesting is that they don't blame the I.M.F. or the U.S. for their troubles, yet. They blame the corrupt, greedy, unaccountable Suharto ruling family. As they say in Indonesia, "The Suhartos have everything, except a sense of shame." Open markets ultimately need an open political system, and the emerging middle classes in Asia know it and are pressing for it as a result of this crisis.
4. The ethnic backlash. In Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia, small Chinese merchant classes dominate the economies. If these societies really go into economic turmoil, there is real danger the Chinese minorities throughout Southeast Asia will be attacked. How will China react to that? Hmmm.
My bet: We are going to witness all four backlashes at the same time. It's not easy to change gas stations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: AETNA IS REDUCING FERTILITY BENEFITS

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1.
The company said that women who had fertility problems had been joining the U.S. Healthcare plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available. Aetna has recently been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits. 
 The decision was sharply criticized by doctors and advocates for infertility patients, who said that many couples were already struggling to cover the costs of such treatments out of their own pockets.
"We don't question what it costs to fix a tennis elbow or a football player's knee," said Pamela Madsen, a spokeswoman for Resolve, a national patient advocacy and support group for people with fertility problems. "Where are our priorities?"
U.S. Healthcare, which began offering this coverage in 1995, was one of the first managed care companies to do so and set an example that other health plans followed.
Fertility is a problem for 6.1 million Americans, but fewer than half of those who are infertile obtain the expensive medical services, a 1995 survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found. Cost is considered to be a major factor.
A growing number of states require health plans to offer a variety of fertility treatments. But these laws do not apply to most workers because they are covered by plans whose administration is structured in such a way that they are exempt from state jurisdiction under provisions of a 1978 Federal law.
States that require coverage for some form of infertility treatment include New York, Connecticut, California, Texas, Illinois, Massachusetts, Ohio, Maryland, Arkansas, Montana, Rhode Island, West Virginia and Hawaii.
A bill will be introduced in Congress this year to require all health plans to provide for fertility treatments, said Sean Tipton, a lobbyist for the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, a doctors' group.
The Aetna decision, which evoked emotionally charged concerns about working mothers and childbearing, added fuel to the debate over whether health plans and the employers who pay for them should be required to cover specific expensive treatments and procedures.
Many managed care companies have been reporting weak profits or losses, and analysts expect them to raise rates and pare benefits. It was not clear, though, whether companies besides Aetna would eliminate fertility coverage.
Mr. Tipton assailed the Aetna move as an example of "a health system that is driven by the interest of shareholder dividends rather than the interest of patients."
Sari Madden, 30, a second grade teacher at Public School 152 in Woodside, Queens, said U.S. Healthcare had paid for procedures at a Manhattan fertility center that eventually led to her becoming pregnant five months ago. She and her husband had been trying to have a baby for two years. "I'm surprised that they are doing this," Ms. Madden said. "If it wasn't for that program, I wouldn't have gotten pregnant at all. I couldn't have afforded it."
Employers can arrange for advanced fertility treatments through a number of health plans, including Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. About 40 percent of large employers offer some form of advanced fertility treatment, including in vitro, artificial insemination and drug therapy, according to a 1996 survey of employers with 500 or more workers by William M. Mercer, a benefits consulting firm.
Nineteen percent of health maintenance organizations offer in vitro fertilization, the Mercer survey said.
In vitro fertilization, in which eggs from a woman typically are combined with her husband's sperm in a laboratory dish and reimplanted in the woman, can cost $8,000 to $12,000 for each procedure. Ms. Madden said U.S. Healthcare paid for her first unsuccessful attempt and arranged a special price of $5,000 for the second, successful attempt at in vitro, which she paid for herself.
But the cost of adding the in vitro benefit to a standard package of health benefits is only about 26 cents per month for each member of a health plan, said Diana Dean, a consultant with Mercer.
An Aetna spokeswoman would not comment on the economic basis for the change in U.S. Healthcare policy, which patient advocacy groups announced on the Internet several weeks ago. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported the action yesterday.
Aetna said the change applied to 750,000 female members of U.S. Healthcare from 20 to 45 years old. It said about 1.5 percent, or 11,250, had fertility problems, of which fewer than 2,500 had the in vitro procedure. The fertility treatments were not offered as a basic benefit by other Aetna health plans.
Dr. Zev Rosenwaks, director of the Center for Reproductive Medicine and Infertility of New York Hospital/ Cornell University Medical Center in Manhattan, said it was "unfortunate that the insurance companies don't see the treatment of infertility as an important medical condition to be covered."
Dr. Rosenwaks said, "The inability to conceive is a disorder like any other medical condition."
Dr. John Nelson, an obstetrician in Salt Lake City who is a trustee of the American Medical Association, said he had "concerns about insurance measures that specifically single out women." He said in vitro fertilization "is not an experimental procedure," and that "it works very well but it is expensive."
He added, "Are they going to discriminate against any kind of procedure that is expensive?"
Ms. Madsen, of Resolve, said she had had to pay for the in vitro assisted births of her sons, now 5 and 8.
"Even though I had health insurance and my husband worked, we were told then that the desire to have a baby was something optional that was not covered, like plastic surgery or a private room at the hospital," she said.
Resolve, which has 13,000 members, and the American Society for Reproductive Medicine have written to Richard Huber, chief executive of Aetna, to protest the change in policy, which also eliminates coverage for fertility technology called gamete intrafallopian transfer, zygote intrafallopian transfer and embryo cryopreservation.
U.S. Healthcare says it will continue to offer a fertility benefit for diagnosis, surgery, drugs taken orally (but not injected), and intrauterine insemination.
Dr. Rosenwaks said it "could be cheaper to do the in vitro procedure in a good clinic than to do a protracted standard treatment that most insurers pay for, which may not work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sari Madden, who is five months pregnant, used in vitro fertilization treatments partly paid for by U.S. Healthcare, an Aetna subsidiary. Aetna plans to end its coverage of most advanced infertility treatments. (William Lopez for The New York Times)(pg. A11)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Hyundai Hopes To Raise Auto Exports by 15%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's largest auto maker, hopes to increase exports by 15 percent this year as it braces for a slump in domestic sales. With the economy expected to fall into recession and car sales forecast to dip 20 percent, Hyundai is gearing up to increase sales abroad, especially in the United States, which accounts for one-quarter of foreign sales. 
 While exports are nothing new for many Korean companies, including Hyundai -- the auto maker exported 48 percent of its 1.25 million production in 1997 -- they have taken on new urgency as recession looms. Hyundai hopes to increase the number of vehicles sold abroad to more than 690,000, or 15 percent more than the 601,851 units that were sold last year.

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Iranians Are Pleased With Khatami's Address
Iranians were satisfied with President Mohammed Khatami's interview with CNN in which he proposed a cultural exchange with the United States and praised American civilization. The President's interview was printed in full in a newspaper in Iran and broadcast twice on television in its entirety, but there were widely different interpretations of what he said. A6 

American officials were encouraged by President Khatami's remarks and said they were willing to explore new cultural exchanges. But they cautioned that substantive problems will continue to exist until Iran ceases its support of terrorism. A6
 
Mowlam Visits Belfast Prison
In an effort to keep the Ulster peace talks on track, Mo Mowlam, the highest ranking official in Belfast, visited a notorious prison where inmates on both sides of the Irish issue have been killed. Protestant prisoners have threatened to derail negotiations unless they are granted early releases. A3
 
Ice Storm Tortures Canada
Canada's harshest ice storm on record wreaked fresh havoc across five eastern provinces, halting air travel, shutting the nation's busiest rail corridor and forcing three million people to endure another day without power. Ten people have died as a result of the five-day onslaught. The authorities deployed more than 4,000 soldiers in the stricken areas to help with relief efforts and to clear away fallen branches. A5
 
Karpov Wins Chess Match
Anatoly Karpov beat Viswanathan Anand in two tiebreaker games and won the International Chess Federation match in Switzerland. He has earned $1.3 million and retained his title and is in a good position to challenge Garry Kasparov to see who is the world's strongest player. A6
 
Chiapas in Disarray
Efforts to calm the turmoil in Chiapas failed as armed forces accused a leading Catholic Bishop of aiding armed Zapatista rebels. President Ernesto Zedillo lashed out at the Zapatista guerrillas, accusing them of blocking Government aid to struggling Indian villages. A7
 
Hotel Figure Killed in Moscow
The general director of the Rossiya Hotel adjoining Red Square in Moscow was shot to death in an apparent contract killing, police said. An unknown gunman fired two shots at the executive, Yevgeny Tsimbalistov, as he left his home in eastern Moscow. He is the second leading hotel official to be murdered in less than two months. The hotel has more than 3,000 rooms, many of them overlooking the Kremlin and the onion domes of St. Basil's Cathedral. (Reuters)
 
Assistance for Iraq
A Chicago-based group of American citizens brought $20,000 worth of medical supplies into Iraq, saying they were doing so at the risk of fines and jail at home. (Reuters)

Logging Roads Banned In Most National Forests
The Clinton Administration plans to suspend construction of logging roads in the back country of most national forests, a major environmental step that would effectively preclude logging on some of the most rugged and pristine public land in the country. A1

The judge in the Unabom trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski scheduled a psychiatric evaluation for the defendant next week to determine if he is legally competent to stand trial. The judge delayed the trial until at least Jan. 22. A1
 
California's Optimistic Budget
Gov. Pete Wilson of California presented the most optimistic budget of his seven years in office, with billions of dollars of proposed new spending for deferred needs from education to school construction, roads, bridges and prisons. A8
 
F.A.A. to Check Boeing Plant
The Federal Aviation Administration will send inspectors to a Boeing plant after reports that part of the tail of the Boeing 737 that crashed in Indonesia three weeks ago appears to have separated from the plane before impact, possible evidence that the crash occurred because fasteners were missing. Clinton Seeks More College Aid
President Clinton proposed increasing spending to help one million students work their way through college by performing community service. The proposal, which Congressional Republicans said they would probably support, would raise total spending on work-study programs in the next budget to $900 million, an increase of $70 million. A10
 
Universe's Energy Is Measured
A bright glow of infrared light that suffuses the heavens, detected and mapped by an American spacecraft, has given astronomers a kind of fossil record of the total energy generated by nearly all the stars that have shone since the beginning of time.

Another Balloon Quest Ends
Two balloonists parachuted into a cactus-studded pasture after a tear doomed their quest to go around the world just an hour after its launching. The balloon, laden with explosive propane fuel tanks, floated off over Texas at 110 miles an hour before coming down in the afternoon. A8

He was eventually arrested trying to cross the border into Canada. B1

HEADLINE: Budget Surplus Is Burning a Hole in California's Pocket

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 9

 BODY:
His state again flush after years of scarcity, Gov. Pete Wilson of California today presented the most optimistic budget of his seven years in office, with billions of dollars of proposed new spending for education, water supply systems, roads, bridges and prisons.
In a weeklong series of announcements culminating in his budget message this morning, Mr. Wilson declared in ebullient tones that California is resoundingly back after years of reverses, and is now "the powerhouse of the Pacific" ready to make many deferred "investments for a 21st century infrastructure." His rosy proposals range from a one-week longer school year to smaller elementary school classes to continued planning for a long-envisioned 10th campus of the University of California system at Merced. 
 Mr. Wilson's good news is emblematic of the politics of plenty now playing out in state capitals across the country. A survey by the Denver-based National Conference of State Legislatures found that a total of 30 states began this year with revenue running ahead of budgeted expectations (in California, they have been about $1 billion above forecasts), with 19 states indicating that elementary and secondary school spending would be their top priority.
In Colorado this week, Gov. Roy Romer, a Democrat, emphasized similar goals in his state of the state speech, while Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia also proposed using some of his state's record fiscal reserves on projects from new runways at rural airports to new classrooms for fast-growing school districts. In Massachusetts, the state's rainy day fund, empty when former Gov. William Weld took office seven years ago, now stands at $800 million, and state officials have agreed to use part of the current year's $130 million surplus to pay off past bills.
But the bittersweet twist for Mr. Wilson is that this $73.8 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1 will also be his last as Governor of the nation's most populous state, because of the term limits law that he supported as a candidate in 1990 and now wistfully acknowledges he wishes he could exceed.
That means that the Governor -- whose popularity sank as his state endured a grueling recession and he ran a brief, failed campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996 -- will be hard-pressed to reap the full benefits of California's recovery, in which the state's job growth is outpacing the nation in every category of non-farm employment and unemployment stands at 5.8 percent, the lowest level in seven years.
"I will genuinely miss this job," Mr. Wilson acknowledged in his annual state of the state message to the Legislature on Wednesday. "Even on its worst days, this is the most fulfilling, best job I've known."
After so many setbacks, Mr. Wilson seems determined not to acknowledge his status as a lame duck, but to make the best bid he can for a legacy. He stayed up, as usual, until 3:30 A.M. Wednesday, polishing his state of the state speech, then jetted around the state to push his proposals. And whatever the shortcomings of his first Presidential bid, the onetime Nixon advance man, who has also served as a United States Senator and Mayor of San Diego, is keeping his options open.
"I don't think he's ruled out running for President at all," said his old comrade-in-arms, Ken Kachigian, a veteran California Republican consultant. "I think everything else being equal, it's going to happen."
This week's budget was, in some ways, less the emergence of a new Pete Wilson than a return of an old one. Mr. Wilson took office in 1991 laying out an agenda for what he called "preventive government," including investments in education and children's health care, but those ideas were quickly swallowed by California's worst economic disaster since the Great Depression. Instead, Mr. Wilson was forced to raise taxes, and he and the legislature struggled each summer for weeks past the budget deadline to dole out the pain.
"California lagged everybody else coming out of the recession," said Arturo Perez, a policy specialist in the fiscal affairs program at the conference of legislatures. "States are definitely now on the upside of the economic cycle, and that is what you'd expect with low inflation and the stock market humming the way it is."
In California's case, the economic recovery began in earnest in 1995, but it took longer for state revenues to reflect the upturn in employment and economic activity, and last year was the first in which Mr. Wilson and the Democratic-dominated legislature found themselves deadlocked over apportioning plenty instead of managing scarcity. In the end, the Governor forced adoption of many of his priorities, including a new statewide test to measure performance of public school students and a compromise $1 billion tax cut package that included an increase in tax credits for children and a greater capital gains exemption for home sales.
Today, the Democratic leader of the State Senate, Bill Lockyer, praised Mr. Wilson's proposal as "a good budget," and quoted an aphorism from Mark Twain's "Pudd'nhead Wilson" that "Prosperity is the best protector of principle." He said Mr. Wilson's proposal for sending $7 billion in construction bond issues to voters for approval seemed "in the ballpark," given the strong economy and low interest rates, but questioned whether the Governor should be so quick to impose his own priorities, like the longer school year, on the education system, or to let local districts use state aid as they see fit.
Since the passage of Proposition 13, which capped local property tax increases in 1978, the share of school budgets borne by localities has shrunk dramatically, but the state is also bound by a later law that requires it to spend at least 40 percent of its general funds on elementary and secondary education. Mr. Wilson's proposals call for spending about 55 percent of the state's general funds on all education, from kindergarten through college, an investment in "human infrastructure" he justified as vital to California's future growth.
California's per pupil spending on education is well down on the list of states, a result of the Proposition 13 limits, but Mr. Wilson warned that "this should not become a state of educational haves and have-nots." Public opinion surveys have repeatedly shown that education is a top priority for state voters. It is expected to be a major issue in the coming race for Governor in which the Attorney General Dan Lungren, a Republican, will face one of a number of potential Democratic challengers, including Senator Dianne Feinstein.
At the same time, Mr. Wilson said the state could not ignore brick-and-mortar needs for new school classrooms, roads, bridges, water conservation programs and prisons, saying, "It is the right thing to do for our people," and adding, "It is also the right way to keep jobs coming."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Pete Wilson of California heading to a budget hearing yesterday at the State Capitol. (Don Preisler for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
Delectable Materialism Catching On in China

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In her neat gray turtleneck, metal-frame glasses and black-and-white Swatch watch, Sang Yan, 27, well educated and thoughtful, could easily fit in on Manhattan's Upper West Side.
Her tastes in clothing, her search for quaint new restaurants, her hopes for a nice apartment are no different than those of her counterparts in much of the rest of the world. 
 She is stylish and aware, and loves to shop. But her shopping is bittersweet, because she must operate on such a stiff budget. Her job -- organizing international exhibitions for a Government-owned textile company -- gives her take-home pay of $182 a month. While that is double the wage of most workers and even many college professors, it does not buy many designer shoes.
What Ms. Sang does buy twice a week, along with 200,000 other Beijing residents for just 12 cents an issue, is the glossy, ad-packed newspaper called Fine Goods Shopping Guide. In the last couple of years this tabloid and a similar one called Shopping Guide have become among the hottest-selling items on Beijing newsstands.
They are the purest evidence that a new generation of Chinese has entered the global consumer culture, whether all can afford it or not.
"It's this way," said Wang Xiaoqian, 35, who makes a modest living as a marketer of Chinese liquor and is an avid reader of the shopping papers. "We've been exposed to the Western life style now, and we want to enjoy it too."
These papers avoid the political cant so common in publications here. They include some "service" articles for the modern, upward-climbing urban dweller: how to decorate that small apartment to make it seem bigger, what to do if your mobile phone is dropped into water, what shoes to wear with a white wedding gown, how to buy a car with monthly payments instead of cash.
These ad-fat, colorful tabloids carry cover stories on movie, soccer and rock stars and carry reviews of movies and restaurants and books. But most of all they are a platform for advertising: ads for video compact disk players and notebook computers, for clothes and cosmetics, for apartments and cars, for curtains and lamps and furniture, for exercise bikes and package vacations to Thailand or Europe, even for liposuction and breast enlargement. Many "articles," on close inspection, turn out to have a commercial sponsor.
There are also personal ads, read by everyone for amusement if not in earnest. Recent examples: "Female, divorced, has two-room house, good figure and appearance, looking for healthy, open-minded man." And, "Male, 29, manager in foreign enterprise, humorous, open-minded, good at computers, looking for pretty girl who loves life." A slice of urban society here has money by any standard and actually buys many of the products offered (though a truly affluent person, Ms. Sang said, would surely read still more upscale magazines like the Chinese version of Elle). But most readers can only shop with extraordinary care.
Mr. Wang and his wife, for example, far from being in the market for private apartments, must crowd in with his parents and an adult brother. His main luxury is a cellular phone -- a convenience and status symbol among young adults that costs more than $500 to buy and register, plus monthly usage fees. Still, the couple forages through the shopping papers.
"It's like window shopping," Mr. Wang said. "We want to see what's going on, what's in the market."
Ms. Sang says she can only buy nice clothes on sale, so she scours her shopping paper to see where the best sales are, as well as to get tips on interesting, inexpensive restaurants.
Private business and substantial foreign trade only got started under the reforms initiated in the late 1970's by Deng Xiaoping. Only in the last several years, as the economy took off, have many people had the money and -- as important -- the opportunity for serious shopping.
Abruptly, glitzy department stores and boutique shopping centers, carrying brands like Benetton, Nautica and Sony, appeared all over Beijing. Slick commercials on television, in magazines and in some newspapers constantly thrust the world of goods and gadgets into everyone's face.
A gaping generation gap has opened up. Like some Americans who suffered through the Great Depression, older Chinese who lived through wars and the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution of 1966-76 try to save every penny and cannot imagine spending, say, $60 for a shirt.
"My parents don't want to buy anything," Ms. Sang said. "They want me to send most of my salary to them so they can save it for me. They can't understand how I can spend so much in a month."
Ms. Sang, who has a degree in English from a prestigious foreign language institute here, is married to a freelance film editor.
They have what many consider the ideal arrangement, known as "one family, two systems." Through her job in a state enterprise, they get housing and medical benefits and security, if not much income. His private job offers risk but at least the possibility of real money.
They, too, are living with the husband's parents, but they are about to receive, through her Government work unit, a two-room apartment with rent that may be less than $20 a month.
For now, they are spending most of their combined income of $725 a month. But their deep hope, Ms. Sang said, is to save enough to buy that apartment, which may cost several thousand dollars. Then they want to have a baby. Ms. Sang fights off feeling guilty about their spending; they are not profligate, she feels sure. She describes a couple she knows who run through $1,200 a month.
"They eat out every night," she said. "They take taxis instead of buses. They are always going to bars or gyms or badminton courts. It's all costly."
The newspapers that cater to today's consumers took their cue from Deng, who in 1992 unleashed a campaign lending new impetus to what he called "market socialism."
Late that year, the first of the papers, Shopping Guide, was started up. New goods were streaming into the marketplace, and more people had a bit of extra money. But people had long been mired in the cant, and cold reality, of sacrifice.
"Producers needed a place to advertise, and consumers needed a place to learn about all the new goods," said the newspaper's editor, Zhao Yinong, 37. What more logical place than the Ministry of Light Industry -- itself a chief producer of consumer items -- to establish a new paper devoted to the art of better consuming.
It is a safe bet, Mr. Zhao agreed, that his semiweekly paper brings in much more profit to the ministry than does its sister publication, China Light Industry News.
Shopping Guide was swiftly followed by a competitor, Fine Goods Shopping Guide, which has since eclipsed it with newsstand sales twice a week of 200,000, double the impressive-enough record of the original. The newer paper is published, improbably, by an institute of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, an academic research center. Its editor said he was too busy for an interview.
Both papers started out slim, with a higher ratio of articles to ads, but now they both offer more than 60 pages each, with the articles often hard to locate. Of the two, Fine Goods Shopping Guide is a bit more more upscale and unabashedly devoted to the pursuit of the best of everything.
Mr. Zhao says his paper, by contrast, aims to serve average shoppers as well as the new rich, and it even has touches of Consumer Reports, including, for example, comparisons of the price of identical shampoos or mobile phones at 10 different stores.
"So we are a great help to the Government, helping to control prices," Mr. Zhao said.
Editors of the stodgy political papers that Government offices around the country are required to buy express envy at the enthusiastic readership and profitability of the shopping, entertainment and other lively newspapers that sell out at the newsstands.
In an apparent attempt to whip up some enthusiasm for itself, this week the Communist Party's mouthpiece, People's Daily, began a Monday economics section with financial and consumer news, a Wednesday society section and a Friday culture section.
It does not appear likely that many Shopping Guide readers will be lured. Wednesday's section carried the first of two articles on the high price of electricity in rural areas and a feature on the troubles of a heroic woman who was crippled while protecting state-owned sheep in a snowstorm. Friday's culture section described a major new television series tracing the life of the late Prime Minister Zhou Enlai.

GRAPHIC: Photos: An eager reader scanning the pages of Shopping Guide in Beijing. Along with its rival, Fine Goods Shopping Guide, it helps thoughts of bargains replace the thoughts of Mao among the upscale and would-be upscale. (Mark Leong/Matrix for The New York Times)(pg. A4)

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk
