HEADLINE: Affirmative Action's Unlikely Foes

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Mass.

 BODY:
At first glance, Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom would seem an unlikely pair to lead the conservative charge against racial preference in America.
In earlier times, Mrs. Thernstrom, now 61 and a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, attended the "little Red schoolhouse," an elementary school for children of a leftist community in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.; sang songs with Pete Seeger, and voted for George McGovern for President. 
 In earlier times, Mr. Thernstom, now a distinguished 63-year-old history professor at Harvard, participated in Marxist study groups as a graduate student there, challenged loyalty oaths and other features of the McCarthy era, and protested the Bay of Pigs invasion.
By all rights, then, the Thernstroms would more likely be champions of affirmative action and all manner of other liberal causes.
Instead, they have emerged as influential voices on the right, thanks to their much-talked-about new book on race, "Black and White in America" (Simon & Schuster, 1997), and Mrs. Thernstrom's much-noticed appearance in December at President Clinton's town hall meeting on race in Akron, Ohio.
The couple are much in demand on the conservative talk-show circuit, where they forcefully argue that racial preferences are wrong, divisive and, as a tool to help minorities, overrated. They serve on the boards of conservative and libertarian public-policy institutes and acknowledge that in recent years they voted for Republican Presidential candidates for the first time in their lives -- Stephan in 1992, Abigail in 1996.
"Abby and Steve Thernstrom grew up on the left and went through a kind of disillusionment and came to the view that there was something canned and ideologically repressive about the left on race," said Jim Sleeper, an ideological soul mate who is the author of "Liberal Racism" (Viking, 1997).
While some may see a remarkable journey in all this, the Thernstroms say the truth is that they never left home. When it comes to race, they say, the issue is not how much they have changed, but how much the left has shifted from color-blindness to color-consciousness.
Seated on a sofa at the couple's home here in Lexington and stroking his ink-black cat, Aslan (named for a character in C. S. Lewis's "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe"), Mr. Thernstrom recalled that in the early 1960's, he supported a bill in the Massachusetts legislature to eliminate all references to race, including the use of photographs, on applications for admission to state colleges.
"That seemed to me then absolutely the ideal -- you admit people without any reference to their race," he said. "And it still seems to be the ideal to me. What's different is that it was a radical idea in 1963, and now it's a so-called conservative idea."
In the 700 pages of their book, thickly packed with charts, footnotes and other references, the Thernstroms juxtapose criticism of racial preferences with an exposition of the remarkable progress they say blacks have made since the 1940's, when Gunnar Myrdal published his classic study "An American Dilemma," on the plight of African-Americans.
The Thernstroms' book argues not only that preferences are divisive but also, implicitly, that they are no longer necessary.
"We do not say that they make no difference whatsoever," Mrs. Thernstrom said. "We do say that they haven't made as much difference as is widely attributed to them and that they carry with them a very high cost. When it comes to race, the test of any public policy is, Will it bring us together or divide us? Preferences flunk that test."
Since publication of the book, the attacks from some on the left have been unrelenting.
Christopher Edley, a Harvard Law School professor who is a consultant to the President's race relations initiative, called the book a "crime against humanity" (a remark he now terms "regrettable"). Although Mr. Edley says he is eager for diverse voices to be heard in the race relations debate, he acknowleges that he strenuously (and unsuccessfully) lobbied to exclude the Thernstroms from a White House meeting that Mr. Clinton held with conservatives in December.
"My whole pitch," Mr. Edley said, "has been the search for the kernel of truth in what the other side is saying. But I think there are some participants, on the far left and the far right, who are too shrill and ideological to be helpful."
Some critics contend that the Thernstroms, in trying to demonstrate dramatic black progress and a lessening of white prejudice, misinterpreted the mountain of data in their book.
Andrew Hacker, professor of political science at Queens College and author of "Two Nations Black and White: Separate, Hostile and Unequal" (Ballantine, 1995), said:
"Here are two white people who are essentially lecturing black Americans, saying: 'What are you complaining about? Stop your griping. Here are the data. You're better off than ever before.' "
Suffused throughout much of their opponents' criticism is a notion that the Thernstroms' work is essentially payback for slights they have endured over the years from those they consider the liberal guardians of racial orthodoxy.
"I think their fixation on the culture wars of the last decade and proving their enemies, the racial liberals, are wrong has in some way distorted their vision and had consequences in the way they interpreted data," said Glen C. Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University.
Mrs. Thernstrom says that in the early 1980's, intimidated by a lawyer working for what she calls a mainstream civil rights organization, she was compelled to decline an invitation to testify at a Senate hearing on extending the Voting Rights Act.
At the time, Mrs. Thernstrom was researching her first book, "Whose Votes Count?: Affirmative Action and Minority Voting Rights" (Harvard University Press, 1987), a critique of the drawing of election districts with large majorities of blacks in order to promote the election of black lawmakers. By her account, the lawyer, whom she declines to identify, told her that if she testified against these so-called majority-minority districts, he would block access to people and data in the South that she needed to complete her book.
"I backed down," Mrs. Thernstrom said. "I never testified."
And in 1988, Mr. Thernstrom, who was among the first historians to use data like bank and home ownership records to trace the social mobility of ethnic groups, was accused by black students of making racially insensitive remarks in his lectures. Although cleared of any wrongdoing, he felt that Harvard's hierarchy had not adequately defended him.
But the Thernstroms vehemently deny that any past indignities influenced their latest work.
"We had some thoughts about writing such a book earlier," Mrs. Thernstrom recalled, "and I said to Steve on a number of occasions, 'You have to get beyond your anger about that situation before you touch this subject.' "
And while acknowledging that the tone of their book may at times be polemical, Mr. Thernstrom said it was difficult to quibble with their empirical findings.
"Whatever the possible truth of the psychological argument," he said, "it's really totally irrelevant to the truth claims of the book."
Yet colleagues and opponents alike say the Thernstroms, especially Mrs. Thernstrom, can be thin-skinned, and at least one former friend says they have a tendency to lash out when criticized.
Mr. Loury, once a close friend of the couple, says the relationship became strained in recent years as he moved somewhat to the left and they, in his view, moved more to the right.
Last year The Atlantic asked him to review their book, and he sent them a draft, which was critical. They sent back a note, he says, that called the review "morally reprehensible, intellectually dishonest and indefensibly nasty."
Mr. Loury and the Thernstroms stopped speaking to each other, although in recent weeks they have begun trying to patch things up.
Asked about Mr. Loury's review, Mrs. Thernstrom said: "I won't talk about Glen Loury, because I don't think it's a story about our book. I think it's a story about our relationship. And that's all I will say."
When her husband started to add something, Mrs. Thernstrom aimed her stocking foot at his shin.
"And," she said forcefully, "I am not going to talk about it."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom misstated the title of their book. It is "America in Black and White: One Nation, Indivisible" (Simon & Schuster, 1997), not "Black and White in America."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
Strong Performers Look at '98

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THOUGH United States stock fund managers turned in a terrific average return of nearly 24 percent for all of last year, the final quarter was much trickier to navigate. They had to contend with ever-growing problems in Asia and the resulting stock market turbulence worldwide -- and many managers fared poorly at year-end.
One who did not was Bill Nygren, who runs the Oakmark Select fund. Not only did he post a stellar one-year return, but his performance for the quarter gained him a top-20 ranking among United States diversified funds with $30 million or more in assets. Also in that league for the quarter were Samuel C. Harvey, manager of Hilliard Lyons Growth, and Irving Levine of the Copley fund. 
 Christian A. Felipe, meanwhile, had a great year managing the MFS Strategic Growth fund, but a big drop in one holding in December trimmed his fund's gain for the fourth quarter.
What went right, or wrong, for them over the year? Each takes a look at the past -- and a stab at what might happen in 1998.
 
The Cable Connection
Under Bill Nygren, the 14-month-old Oakmark Select fund gained 55 percent last year, to finish second in the diversified domestic stock group. And Mr. Nygren is optimistic about 1998.
Oakmark Select, with $514 million in assets, is a concentrated portfolio of midsize and large stocks. The fund holds only 19 issues, and annual turnover is a low 34 percent of assets.
"Our style is long-term value, which focuses more on reducing risk then maximizing return," Mr. Nygren said. "Fortunately," he added, "in 1997 there were no big disasters" in his holdings.
A big position in cable television helped cement his high return last year. Holdings included Liberty Media, at 15 percent of assets; Cablevision Systems, 5 percent, and U S West Media Group, 5 percent.
"The cable industry fell out of favor in 1996 because of concerns that they would lose customers to satellite and telephone companies, but the consensus was wrong," Mr. Nygren said. "Telephone companies have backed away in favor of voice and data, and satellite businesses haven't grown as fast as anticipated."
The takeover of First USA (15 percent of the fund last January) by Banc One also helped.
Mr. Nygren says he searches for stocks selling at a large discount to what the company would fetch in a private transaction. Lower interest rates and a strong economy have pushed up prices paid for businesses, he said. But private values have also risen, and he sees no problem with current valuations, though others call them high.
With a return of 8.3 percent for the fourth quarter -- compared with an average loss of nearly 1 percent for the diversified group -- Oakmark Select ranked 11th among those funds. Mr. Nygren says that was helped by a 50 percent gain in Cablevision Systems, one of his five biggest holdings going into the quarter.
 
Concerned About Asia
Asia is a big worry of Samuel C. Harvey, who runs the $57 million Hilliard Lyons Growth fund, which took first place for the quarter among diversified funds, with a gain of 13.4 percent.
The fund did well for the year, too, with a return of 40.4 percent, but Mr. Harvey is not optimistic about 1998. "The last three years have been times when all the good things that can happen to you in investing did," he said. "It's hard to believe that's going to continue."
As for Asia, "it's less of a concern for the companies that we own, which primarily operate in Europe and the United States," he said, "but we suspect that ultimately what's happening there will have an impact on investor confidence here."
Like Oakmark Select, Hilliard Lyons Growth owns just a handful of large and midsize companies (currently 25 stocks) and has low turnover (just 25 percent). Mr. Harvey built up cash, doubling the position to 20 percent by the end of the year because "some of our stocks became so popular that we decided to cut back," he said. "It's our goal to be fully invested, but it's slow going now finding stocks at a good price."
Financial stocks account for one-third of the fund, with the biggest holdings being Cincinnati Financial and American International Group. "Prices have gone up quite a lot, so they don't have the advantage of being priced attractively right now, but we'll stick with what we have," Mr. Harvey said.
The fund holds no technology stocks. Mr. Harvey looks for companies that have some long-term advantage compared with their rivals; with technology companies, he said, it is difficult to figure how long the competitive edge will last.
 
Utility Shakeout Gives a Lift
Irving Levine is the manager and largest shareholder of the quirky $83 million Copley fund. He attributes his fourth-quarter gain of 11.5 percent -- earning Copley third place among diversified funds -- to the effects of the Asian turmoil and a stock market that he considers expensive.
"If there's a slight trepidation in the stock market, there's a flight to our type of stocks," Mr. Levine said. Copley buys stocks that pay high dividends, are heavily traded and have a history of dividend increases. About 55 percent of the fund is in utilities, he said. When interest rates fall, these stocks tend to do well.
Mr. Levine is not optimistic about the market this year. "I think earnings will not come up to plan, so many stocks won't rise in 1998 for a long time," he said. "Maybe by the fourth quarter they'll right themselves."
Copley is unusual in that it is also an industrial corporation, wholesaling imported handbags. That allows it to exclude 70 percent of its dividend income from taxation, so the fund pays taxes itself and does not make distributions to shareholders. Shareholders then pay taxes on gains only when they redeem their shares.
For most shareholders, this means the tax-adjusted return is about three percentage points higher than a comparable return on another fund, Mr. Levine said.
Helping the fund's big year-end gain, Mr. Levine said, were its holdings in acquisition targets like Colonial Gas, the CT Energy Corporation and Delta Natural Gas.
 
Cautious on Technology
Christian A. Felipe, manager of the $126 million MFS Strategic Growth fund, is more pessimistic than not about the new year. "We think Asia will have a material impact on inflation and the corporate profit outlook," he said, "so we're trying to find places that can grow in the face of a global slowdown."
With a return of 50.4 percent on its A shares, the fund, which buys large growth stocks around the world, garnered fourth place for the year in the diversified group. And that would have been higher but for a fourth-quarter gain of only 3.6 percent.
The fund started the year with a 40 percent weighting in technology, but that was pared back to 30 percent by year-end because of price increases and Asia worries. "We're not avoiding technology, we're just being more selective," Mr. Felipe said. The fund's biggest position, in fact, is Microsoft, at 9 percent of assets.
It was the fund's sizable exposure to a software company, Oracle, that depressed its quarterly return, he said. Oracle stock fell 29 percent in one day in December after earnings fell far short of forecasts. Still, Mr. Felipe said he remained a big believer in the stock for the long term.
In late summer, Mr. Felipe began buying domestic retail stocks, which he figures "have no exposure to the Asian currency crisis." Significant consolidation in that industry also helped his return, he said.
For example, Safeway and Fred Meyer, two grocery chains the fund owns a stake in, are consolidating in California, "which should create a more stable pricing environment along with the improving California economy," Mr. Felipe said. Among pharmacies, the fund has benefited from combinations of Rite Aid and Thrifty Payless and of CVS and Revco.

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 45; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1537 words

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
There's Strength in Diversity

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
RAY POLESE, a savings plan administrator at Lucent Technologies, decided to take the plunge with his own money about a year ago. He sold all the fixed-income investments in his personal 401(k) retirement plan and put the money into three stock funds and Lucent stock. "I started to listen to our financial education programs," Mr. Polese, 49, said. "If you have time before retirement, you should be more aggressive."
Alex Shervet, 34, a software engineer with the Echelon Corporation in Palo Alto, Calif., puts all his 401(k) money in Brandywine, a growth-stock fund. 
 Sound familiar? Financial advisers continue to recommend a major position in stocks for long-term investors -- even people nearing retirement who have other sources of income like pensions. But they are taking pains to emphasize the importance of diversity in 1998.
"Most people coming to us really don't understand what diversification is," said Lou Stanasolovich, president of Legend Financial Advisors in Pittsburgh. "Typically, they're loaded up on large U.S. equities, and most think the market can go nowhere but up."
Mr. Shervet is a case in point. Though Brandywine lost 14 percent in the fourth quarter, he is unbowed. "When I see significant drops, I don't like it," he said, "but I fully expect the fund to come back. It's a cyclical thing. By the time I need my money, it'll be back in good shape."
Portfolio concentrations like his are not for lack of choice. Most retirement plans that allow individuals to make their own investments have added to their menus. The average plan now offers seven choices, and most plans are continuing to fine-tune the offerings. Last year, 32 percent of 401(k) plans introduced at least one new investment option, according to Access Research of Windsor, Conn., a division of the Spectrem Group, a financial services consulting firm. The most popular addition was an international stock fund.
Before jumping into the new choices, investors should review how their portfolios are divided among stocks -- large and small, foreign and domestic -- bonds and cash.
"Asset allocation is the main determinant of portfolio performance," said Jeffrey Schwartz, senior consultant at Ibbotson Associates, the investment consulting firm that pioneered historical asset allocation analysis. "Regardless of which stocks or funds you pick, the majority of your performance is driven by the underlying asset classes."
Even if you settled a while ago on a firm asset allocation that you expected to fit your risk profile for some time, you might have drifted far away from your plan. The stock market's outsized returns the last 12 months mean that an investor who had sought a portfolio mix of 60 percent stocks, 30 percent bonds and 10 percent cash in December 1996 now probably has about 72 percent stocks, 22 percent in bonds and just 6 percent in cash.
The problem is "if there's an equity correction, you're more vulnerable than you thought," said Ned Notzon, executive vice president for the T. Rowe Price Spectrum Income and Spectrum Growth funds.
By mixing stocks and bonds and cash, investors can lower their portfolio risks, according to historical investment returns. Between 1970 and 1996, a United States stock portfolio that included just a dash of foreign equities (20 percent) was less volatile and returned more than an all-United States stock portfolio, 13.8 percent a year versus 13.5 percent, Mr. Schwartz noted.
"You never know what's going to be the best performer," said William McNabb, managing director at Vanguard Institutional Investor Group. Stocks can underperform other investments for a long period. For example, in the 1970's, both intermediate-term government bonds and long-term corporate bonds outperformed large-company stocks.
Anyone heavily in equities is probably looking at bonds now. The fundamentals are "quite compelling," said Theodore Giuliano, fixed-income chief investment officer at Neuberger & Berman, the big fund company. Not only is inflation quiescent and the dollar strong, which should keep foreign investors interested in United States bonds, but supply is contracting with the decline in the Federal deficit. While stocks and bonds have moved more in harmony in recent years, he said, intermediate-term bonds still reduce portfolio volatility.
And Mr. Guiliano wonders how much longer American stocks can provide such extraordinary returns. Long term, United States stock returns have averaged 11 percent, but they have been more than double that over the last three years.
Todd Eberhard, president of Eberhard Investment Associates in New York, is investing clients' money roughly evenly between stocks and bonds. He says bonds can provide double-digit returns this year as interest rates continue to fall.
Prudence suggests that equities remain a big component of many portfolios. Participants in 401(k) plans have been responding to the bull market for stocks and to financial education by plan sponsors that shows that equities beat other investments over the long haul. At the end of 1997, 54 percent of plan assets were estimated to be in equities, primarily stock funds but also company stock, compared with 42 percent at the end of 1994, said Jeffrey Close, marketing director Spectrem.
BUT what's true for the group is not true for individuals. While some people remain wedded to fixed-income accounts, plenty of people became far more heavily weighted in stocks and stock funds. Consider Mr. Shervet, who has everything in Brandywine.
And he's not even the extreme. At least his fund splits its assets among many stocks, more than 400 at last count. David Morris, 58, a staff manager in Lucent's human resources department, is betting heavily on just one stock: Lucent. At the end of 1996, he decided to put 60 percent of his payroll 401(k) contributions into Lucent shares, up from 50 percent the previous year. In 1997, Lucent gained 74 percent percent, well ahead of the broad market. "I feel Lucent has a very, very bright future," he said. "I minimize my risk somewhat by splitting my money with a stable value fund." He also owns five big-company stocks in an outside account.
While that strategy worked well for him last year, financial advisers consider it one of the riskiest maneuvers. A downturn at an employer -- and one company is much more vulnerable than a pool of companies -- could mean a job loss as well as a loss in his retirement portfolio.
Investing not just among American stocks, but among foreign stocks, too, remains the recommendation of many financial advisers. Many foreign markets, notably the beleagured Asia ones, have not done as well as the domestic stock market recently. But believers in worldwide diversity expect a dollop of foreign stocks to help offset any downturn in domestic shares. For periods of foreign outperformance, they need only go back to the mid-1980's. A basket of foreign stocks far outperformed United States stocks from 1983 through 1988, with returns of 33.9 percent and 16.5 percent, respectively, according to Ibbotson.
"Diversifying into foreign markets makes you less susceptible to a problem here," said Mr. Notzon of T. Rowe Price.
A few days ago, Mr. Polese bought into the argument, shifting 10 percent of his payroll contributions to an international stock fund. It's one of eight new choices in the Lucent plan, which has 123,000 participants. "Based on everything that's been going on," Mr. Polese said, "this is probably an opportune time."
The theory is that foreign markets have not had the big run-up of the United States market -- indeed, some have been beaten down -- and may offer more value going forward.
Mr. Shervet, for one, is not convinced. "If there's a downturn, foreign companies will feel it just as much," he said. "I'd rather pay close attention to the American economy."
PORTFOLIO diversification is particularly important for people who may be tapping their investments within five years. Harold Gibbs, quality manager at Cartwright Electronics in Fullerton, Calif., has 75 percent of his investments in two balanced funds, which tend to hold 60 percent stocks and 40 percent bonds. He is 61 and may retire in four years. "I wouldn't want to be caught with the market at a low and have to be withdrawing money at that time," he said. "I feel very comfortable with my investments because I'm well diversified."
Finally, some investors have the luxury of putting most of their retirement capital on autopilot. That is the case with Edwin K. Weiss, 59, a pilot with Trans World Airlines. He puts two-thirds of his company's contributions into a moderate portfolio, which is 65 percent in stock funds, and the remainder of those contributions in an aggressive portfolio, which is 80 percent in stock funds. Each portfolio is rebalanced by the plan's manager whenever an asset class moves 3 percent or more above these targets. His own contributions go into a separate plan that he himself rebalances every quarter. As a result, Mr. Weiss has kept his retirement portfolio 80 percent in stocks, with the rest in bonds and cash.
"Hopefully," he said, "my moderate portfolio will handle a case where the market comes down hard."

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 50; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
Bonds May Win the Catbird Seat

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
A TUMBLE in long-term bond rates in the infant days of 1998 could be the beginning of good news for investors who have been moving holdings into bond funds, seeking a haven from the world's tumultuous equity markets.
Long-term rates dropped to their lowest level in nearly 30 years last week after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, cited the possibility of deflation, or widespread price declines, and gave market professionals reason to hope that the Fed would lower short-term interest rates. And bond rates could fall further, some analysts say, if the Asian financial crisis slows the American economy by more than the market now projects. All in all, many expect bond funds to outperform stock funds this year for the first time since 1993. 
 Mutual fund investors also seem to be betting that way, having stepped up their investments in bond funds in the last three months of 1997. From the stock market skid in late October until mid-December, the rate at which cash flowed into bond funds doubled to $1.3 billion a week, as measured by a four-week moving-average, according to AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund cash flows. The rate of money flowing into stock funds slowed from $3.6 billion a week in late October to $1.7 billion a week by mid-December. And for three weeks during the period, stock funds suffered redemptions totaling $2.4 billion.
"There is clearly some reallocation to the bond market from the stock market," said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data.
And that could continue, some portfolio managers say. James E. Conroy, lead manager of the Smith Barney Government Securities fund, for example, says the Asian crisis runs deeper than is generally believed. As a result, he sees the 30-year Treasury yield slipping from the current 5.73 percent -- the lowest since the Government began issuing the bond regularly, in 1977 -- to 5.5 percent by the end of the first quarter and to 5 percent by year-end.
"We're in uncharted territory," he said, adding that he thought the Federal Reserve would lower rates by the end of the first quarter.
Mr. Conroy's fund posted one of the best performances among domestic intermediate bond funds last year, with a return of 11.2 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking firm in Chicago.
This year, analysts project bond fund returns will be in the 7 percent to 11 percent range, while stocks could be poised for a breather after a long bull market.
If bonds gain on stocks, it would fit a historical pattern: Whenever stocks have outperformed intermediate-term bonds by an annualized average return of nine or more percentage points over a five-year period, the difference between bond and stock returns has narrowed considerably over the next five-year period, according to Ibbotson Associates, the Chicago research firm.
In the most recent period studied by Ibbotson, stocks beat bonds by nine percentage points for the five years ended in 1996; historically speaking, the two sectors' performance should be more in sync.
But others are less sanguine about bonds. While they agree that bonds could be the better investment in 1998, they expect inflation threats to end the rally that began last year. That would force investors to be satisfied with returns of 6 percent to 8 percent for the year -- a far cry from the top returns of 1997.
Rates of long-term securities fell more than a percentage point in the last half-year, helping the average long-term Treasury fund post a total return of 11.99 percent and the average intermediate Government fund to return 8.41 percent for the year, according to Morningstar. Over all, taxable bond funds, including Treasuries and corporate and international holdings, returned 8.85 percent last year. That is well below the 23.72 percent return of the average diversified domestic stock fund, but it is more than respectable for bonds.
Can long-term rates get any lower? Yes, said William H. Gross, who oversees bond investing at the Pacific Investment Management Company, or Pimco.
He, too, predicts that the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond will dip as low as 5.5 percent, and that the Federal Reserve will ease monetary policy sooner rather than later, by half a percentage point. These predictions are based on his expectation that the United States economy will weaken substantially. "That weak economy really comes from Asia," he said.
Some managers of big bond funds, like Ian A. MacKinnon, who heads fixed-income investments at the Vanguard Group, are staking out a middle ground. Mr. MacKinnon, who led Vanguard Fixed-Income Long-Term Treasury to a 13.9 percent return in 1997, predicts that the crisis in Asia will slow the economy, but says the effect might be mitigated by higher inflation in the United States.
Mr. MacKinnon does not see much capital appreciation from bonds in 1998. Still, he added, "bonds are a better buy than stocks right now," because stock prices are likely to be hurt as companies grapple with an influx of cheap Asian imports, while their own labor costs rise at home.
William J. Curtin, chief investment officer for fixed income at Putnam Investments, is one of the most bearish managers of big bond funds. He expects Asia's financial difficulties to stabilize, allowing growth in the United States to remain strong. That could lead the Fed to push up interest rates to avert inflation, he said.
Similarly, Fred Robertson, chief investment officer of fixed income at Nicholas-Applegate Capital Management, expects economic growth to pick up after six months, with yields on long-term bonds moving up to 6.5 percent to 7 percent.

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 51; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 359 words

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
Dazzling Returns Bring a Cash Surge to Junk Bonds

BYLINE: By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
Junk bond funds were among the best-performing bond funds last year. So, unsurprisingly, they are getting an influx of cash.
AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund cash flows, says that in the last three months of the year, junk funds -- those investing in high-risk, high-return corporate debt -- received the most cash of any investment category. In December, more than $5 billion a week flowed into high-yield bond funds, AMG said. 
 These funds posted a return of 12.17 percent on average last year, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking firm. For investors accustomed to double-digit stock market returns, yet getting nervous about equities, the yield on junk looked more desirable than Treasury yields of 6 percent and less. And default rates on junk "went almost to the vanishing point" in last year's strong economy, said Martin Fridson, chief high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
Investors should be wary of chasing past performance in the high-yield arena, however. Weakness in the economy may make it more difficult for managers of high-yield funds to match last year's stellar returns. Still, the United States is unlikely to fall into recession, and that makes high-yield securities more a "hold" than a "sell," said William Gross, head of bond investing at the Pacific Investment Management Company. "Investors will still have confidence in those corporations that pay the interest," he said.
The best course for many investing outside tax-sheltered retirement accounts, said Ian A. MacKinnon, who heads fixed-income investments at the Vanguard Group, may be to invest in long-term, tax-exempt municipal bonds. Munis, he said, are "extremely attractive" relative to the yield on Treasury securities.
Last year, the average long-term, national municipal bond fund returned 8.77 percent, compared with 10.16 percent for the average taxable long-term bond fund. But the muni fund looks better after taxes. For an investor in the 28 percent income tax bracket, taxes would cut the yield on the taxable fund to 7.32 percent; in the top, 39.6 percent bracket, it would be 6.14 percent. ABBY SCHULTZ

LENGTH: 2659 words

HEADLINE: From Gurus to Sitting Ducks

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER; Mark Landler has covered the media and telecommunications industries for seven years. He will become The Times's correspondent in Hong Kong later this year.

 BODY:
EARLY one morning last July, five of the media industry's most powerful executives gathered around a table before a select audience in a windowless conference room at Idaho's Sun Valley Lodge. It was a formidable lineup: Rupert Murdoch, Gerald Levin, David Geffen, Barry Diller and Edgar Bronfman Jr. And because this was the annual conference run by the investment firm Allen & Company, the atmosphere was aggressively casual -- just five guys in chinos and polo shirts chatting about world domination.
On this particular morning, though, the tycoons were about to be taken down a notch. 
 Andrew S. Grove, the chief executive of Intel, the world's largest maker of computer chips, moderated the discussion. Or more precisely, he commandeered it. Mr. Grove's complaint was that the five panelists were Luddites. Digital technology and the Internet were transforming the worlds of media and entertainment, but these captains of industry were resisting the change.
"They don't get technology, and they think it poses a threat to their core business," Mr. Grove declared in an interview that recalled his comments in the closed-door session.
Maybe the media executives are right to be scared. It is unfashionable in this era of techno-intoxication to suggest that technology could result in anything but boundless growth. But for traditional media companies, the digital age poses genuine danger. The Internet and other new types of media could radically alter the economics of the business. By splintering the mass market into a kaleidoscope of narrow niches, technology is threatening to deprive Time Warner, Walt Disney, Viacom and their peers of the mass audiences on which they depend for advertising revenues and profits.
"The fundamental premises of the media business have been eroding even as the big firms have engaged in high-wire deal-making," said Reed E. Hundt, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who also sat on the panel and offered his own Cassandra-like pronouncements about the future of the industry.
As 1998 begins, worries about technology have left the media industry in a deeply ambivalent mood. On one hand, the stock prices of some of the industry's most visible companies -- notably Time Warner -- have soared to record highs lately after several years of anemic performance.
On the other hand, the media chiefs have been stripped of their role as the intellectual trendsetters of the communications industry. At the annual Sun Valley gatherings, Sumner M. Redstone of Viacom and John C. Malone of Tele-Communications Inc. used to dazzle with visions of the information highway: hundreds of channels, movies at the touch of a button, home shopping, and so on. But increasingly, computer and software executives are generating the new ideas and setting the trends. Now, the moguls seem almost like relics next to the likes of Andy Grove and William H. Gates.
At the Allen & Company conference last July, for example, the normally voluble media executives offered only a token response to Mr. Grove's assault. Howard Stringer, the president of the Sony Corporation of America, was in the audience that morning, and he recalled that the group appeared to be thrown off balance by the criticism.
"The traditional media guys seemed to be on the outside looking in," said Mr. Stringer, who spent 30 years in a bastion of traditional media, CBS.
A few media companies have benefited from the techno-mania: The cable operator Comcast, for example, recently secured a $1 billion investment from Microsoft to outfit its coaxial network with high-speed Internet connections.
But many other companies face a future of huge capital spending with an uncertain payoff -- broadcast networks that must prepare for the coming of digital television, for example, and cable operators that must upgrade their aging wires. And many of the executives no longer have the luxury to be visionaries. They are busy grappling with problems that are the legacy of 10 years of furious empire-building -- a period that could reasonably be called the Media Decade. Viacom, the News Corporation and Disney have all been hurt by failed initiatives, internal squabbling, and weak links in their far-flung operations.
And so the chiefs, who once looked like New Age prophets, now seem more like Moses wandering in a desert where the old assumptions no longer apply and the future is more of a threat than an opportunity.
"The problem is, they were wrong. They've been discredited," said Frank J. Biondi Jr., a longtime media executive who has generally shunned sweeping pronouncements and is now the chief executive of Universal Studios. "Gurus only remain gurus as long as they're right."
 
Ushering In a Media Decade
The Media Decade began in 1986, when all three television networks changed hands in a single year. Those deals turned a spotlight on a business that had generally been shunned by Wall Street because of its unpredictable profits and idiosyncratic management.
Over the next 10 years, the industry set off on a spree of promiscuous deal-making. A result was conglomerates like Time Warner, Viacom and Disney, which snapped up both creators of programming (film studios, magazine and book publishers) and distributors of it (broadcast and cable networks, satellite services and home-video retailers).
The executives justified the bloated deals with dubious talk of "synergy," but Wall Street bought the line. "We have a long history in this country of assuming that the heads of the most lucrative industries must be the wisest sages," said Mark Crispin Miller, a professor of media studies at Johns Hopkins University.
Of course, the executives' empires still relied on the same economic models that had supported mass media since the days of William S. Paley and David Sarnoff, the founders, respectively, of CBS and RCA. The companies produce movies and television shows intended to attract the broadest audiences, enabling theaters to sell the tickets and networks the advertising that ultimately underwrite mass entertainment.
Nobody exploited this formula better than Barry Diller, the shrewd television programmer who helped start the Fox network, introducing Bart Simpson to millions of young viewers. Mr. Diller became a sort of Yoda of the information age when he left Fox in 1992 and set off on a nationwide search for the Next Big Thing. What he discovered was home shopping -- an unapologetically cheesy business of peddling quilted pillows and costume jewelry over cable television.
By harnessing digital technology, Mr. Diller promised to transform home shopping into "electronic retailing," a dazzling interactive medium that would forever change the way Americans used their televisions. Few of Mr. Diller's more ambitious plans ever materialized, and he wound up using his home-shopping channel as the vehicle for a run at an old-fashioned movie studio, Paramount Pictures. Now, Mr. Diller is using another shopping channel as a platform to create another television network. In October, he agreed to pay $4 billion to acquire the television assets of Universal Studios, including the USA cable network.
Mr. Diller may not have unleashed the revolution, but he did understand that television was changing in some basic ways. Digital transmission was turning the TV set from a "dumb" box beaming a few programs at a time to big audiences into a video jukebox from which individual viewers could select the information in which they were interested. Soon, every media chief picked up the siren call of interactivity.
In 1994, Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner, trumpeted plans for the company's Orlando, Fla., cable system, which would offer movies on demand and an electronic shopping mall. "When I turn on my television," he rhapsodized the previous year, "I'll be able to switch to anything, anywhere." Similarly, Mr. Malone, as chairman of the nation's largest cable operator, promised to deliver viewers a 500-channel world.
The media chiefs believed that their revenues would explode if they could offer viewers an endlessly varied menu of programming options. What few of them realized was that the technology for genuine interactivity was still years away -- and that no economic model had been devised to support it.
In the meantime, by rushing from mass to niche programming, they were whittling away the economic underpinnings of their business.
 
Viewers Look Elsewhere
Mass media, of course, had been splintering ever since the emergence of cable television in the 1970's. But with the onset of digital technology and the Internet, the fragmentation is accelerating. The Big Three networks, for example, saw their share of the prime-time television audience dip below 50 percent for the first time ever last season.
It is the Internet, in particular, that has media executives spooked. They did nothing to develop it and little to popularize it. And even now, though they all maintain sites on the World Wide Web -- some of them, like the Disney-owned ESPN Sportzone, are extremely popular -- it is not clear how genuinely the media chiefs embrace the Net.
While computer executives see the Internet as a vast new business opportunity, media executives worry about losing television viewers. At the Sun Valley conference, Mr. Grove drew a tart response from Mr. Diller when he showed a chart asserting that in families who routinely use home computers, TV viewership drops by 50 percent. "The drop-off is nowhere near what he claims," Mr. Diller said.
For media executives, the big problem is that they have been resoundingly unsuccessful in squeezing a profit out of the Web.
"The Internet is like the library at Alexandria," Mr. Levin said. "It is enormous, free and democratic, but how you make money on it is not clear yet."
Time Warner, perhaps the industry's most technologically committed company, operates more than 190 Web sites. It has devoted four years and tens of millions of dollars to create one of the largest sites, called Pathfinder, where Time Warner magazines that cost money on the newsstand can be sampled free. But while it generates about $10 million a year in advertising revenue, according to insiders, Pathfinder still loses $10 million a year.
On cable, meanwhile, where digital technology is allowing the giants to edge closer to their vaunted 500-channel universe, the dial is filling up with safe choices rather than the diversity that big media companies seemed to promise. Cable subscribers in New York City, for example, can watch the news on CNN, Headline News, CNBC, MSNBC, New York 1 and the Fox News Channel, in addition to local broadcast stations. Other than for the biggest news events, most of these draw puny ratings.
Other choices on the dial -- American Movie Classics, Turner Classic Movies, Nick at Nite -- have particularly loyal viewers. But they exist not so much to slake a public thirst as to recycle material stored in the vast film and television libraries owned by the moguls' companies. Television may not be the vast wasteland that Newton N. Minow once described, but it is beginning to look a lot like a rummage sale.
A few outlets, notably Time Warner's Home Box Office, continue to produce fresh original programming. But for the most part, more is proving to be the enemy of good. The reason is simple economics.
"As you go from 35 channels to 75 channels, you diminish the audience for everything," Mr. Stringer of Sony explained. "That makes it harder to generate the advertising revenue for quality programming."
That phenomenon already prevails on network television. Andrew Lack, the president of NBC News, said he had no trouble persuading his network to schedule a fourth weekly installment of the news magazine "Dateline NBC" last fall. It wasn't that viewers were clamoring for another fix of Jane Pauley and Stone Phillips; they might have welcomed a new drama, instead. But in the diminished world of network television, "Dateline" is a cheap way to draw a reliable audience, while costly original dramas are just too risky.
The squeeze will become even more acute with the introduction of digital TV this summer, which will allow broadcasters to transmit six programs, instead of one, on a single channel, or else to transmit that single channel in a crystal-clear, high-definition form. With the cost for the conversion to digital TV running into the billions, the networks are wringing their hands about how to use the technology. And why not? They rightly worry that they will not be able to squeeze another nickel out of their advertisers, let alone come up with anything original to broadcast.
Peter Georgescu, the chairman of the ad agency Young & Rubicam, likens the situation to the consumer products business. As companies like Procter & Gamble flood supermarket shelves with "new, improved" soaps and detergents, the profusion of brands turns each product into a commodity. Mr. Georgescu says the media business is entering a similar era, where excess supply is chasing inadequate demand.
 
Will the Paranoid Survive?
To hear Andy Grove and Reed Hundt talk, the media industry is about where the horse-and-buggy business was when Henry Ford first cranked up his assembly line. Mr. Hundt said that people no longer wanted to consume news or entertainment passively. In the future, he predicted, all media would be interactive. And, Mr. Grove said, the Internet could enable advertisers to bypass the conventional media altogether and pitch their products directly, and in targeted fashion, to consumers over their PC's.
"This could be an even bigger deal than what is happening to the telecommunications and personal computing industries," said Mr. Grove in his aptly titled book, "Only the Paranoid Survive," which sums up the arguments he made at Sun Valley.
Media executives dismiss such doomsaying as naive.
"These guys say that movies and TV shows are antique forms of entertainment," Mr. Diller said. "But to think that passive entertainment is going to end is absurd."
He has a point. From "Seinfeld" to James Cameron's "Titanic," television programs and films still have the power to draw mass audiences. Moreover, the media executives' old contentions about the power of their pipelines into the home are getting a new hearing. Shares of Time Warner and TCI have rebounded in the last year, largely because of renewed hopes that cable networks can provide high-speed connections to the Internet. Microsoft and Intel may be frustrated with the media companies, but that has not stopped them from negotiating a bewildering array of deals with them.
Nor is it clear that Mr. Grove or Mr. Gates are any more qualified to divine the future than the media giants whom they seem to have trumped. Right now, the techies are riding high. But there is every reason to believe that they will eventually be hoist by their own petards. In the information age, breakthroughs inevitably become yesterday's news. As the technology executives fall prey to the seductions of the media business, what's to stop their paradigm from collapsing around them?
Perhaps that is why Mr. Levin, a corporate survivor who has ridden every up and down of the Media Decade, seemed less ruffled than some of his colleagues by Mr. Grove's scolding at Sun Valley. Mr. Levin dismissed those comments as "theatrics," and argued that more attention should be paid to ideas than to celebrity executives.
Indeed, Mr. Levin threw cold water on the whole notion that the group who charted the Media Decade's trajectory was ever so elite. The industry, he said, is entering its most fertile period since the 1920's, when radio and talking pictures exploded onto the scene. Yet "one of the things we're lacking," Mr. Levin said, "is a lot of the seminal thinkers and entrepreneurs."
A convenient thought, perhaps, as the sun sets on the moguls' Technicolor dreams.

Laurence A. Tisch

Barry Diller
Started the Fox network, got into home shopping and tried to buy a studio. Now he's building a new network.

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 62; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
The Money Keeps Rolling In for Variable Annuities

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
WHEN Congress cut the capital gains tax last summer, financial analysts predicted a plunge in variable annuity sales.
After all, annuities are intended to provide shelter from taxes for retirement savings. They are part life insurance, which allows taxes to be deferred until money is withdrawn, and part mutual fund, meaning that returns vary, depending on how the money is invested. 
 With taxes of less concern, people might shift to buying plain old mutual funds, which have smaller fees than annuities and no penalties for early withdrawal.
But sales of variable annuities are cruising along. When the tally is completed, the total for 1997 is expected to hit $85 billion, says the Variable Annuity Research and Data Service in Atlanta. That would put sales growth at 17 percent for the year, down from the 47 percent surge in 1996 but still quite strong.
Ever mindful of the threat to their business, a handful of companies that sell variable annuities -- including Fidelity Investments, Nationwide Insurance and the Vanguard Group -- have cut their expenses in recent months, and some specialists expect more companies to join in.
Lower costs may help keep the fire burning, but even without such tactics, variable annuities have a strong following. The reason is that plenty of Americans are more interested in a measure of safety than in maximizing their investment returns.
Buyers of variable annuities tend to be people approaching retirement who worry that they will not have enough money to see them through. They are in their mid-50's, with perhaps a couple of years of college and household incomes of $50,000 or less.
Typically, they have put their money into savings accounts and certificates of deposit, and some have ventured into bonds. But stocks have scared them. Variable annuities let them participate in the stock market without risking everything.
"These are people who have not saved enough money for retirement, but, who, by the same token, cannot afford to risk much money," said Diane Blakeslee, a financial planner in San Luis Obispo, Calif., who works on commission. "With a variable annuity, I can get someone to invest a little more aggressively."
The security comes in several forms, but there are two features written into all the contracts. When an investor dies, his heirs get back at least the original investment, even if he has invested in a stock fund that has plunged in the meantime. Also, an investor who chooses to get periodic payments instead of a lump sum and who has begun making withdrawals will receive payments for the rest of his life. "You can't outlive your money," said Joseph W. Jordan, the senior vice president for marketing at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
There is a trade-off for this added sense of security. Investors usually must pay a penalty to the insurance company of up to 7 percent of their investment if they cash out within seven years. They must also pay a government penalty of 10 percent if they cash in before age 59.
These restrictions, absent from mutual funds, are one reason Richard Lee, a fee-only financial planner in Dallas, discourages customers from buying variable annuities.
But Mary Merrill, a fee-only planner in Madison, Wis., sees these qualities as virtues. "I don't want people to have the temptation of that money being available to spend," she said. "This is kind of forcing them to save for later years."
Either way, variable annuities really make sense only after people have made the maximum contributions to individual retirement accounts, 401(k)'s and other retirement plans that provide an immediate reduction in income tax. Unlike I.R.A.'s and 401(k)'s, variable annuities have no limit on contributions.
WHETHER variable annuities will begin to lose their luster with Americans because of the new tax law is hard to say. For most people who want to be in the stock market and who are saving for retirement, the choice comes down to variable annuities and mutual funds. Because of the insurance costs, the annual fees on variable annuities average a little over 2 percent, or about seven-tenths of a percentage point more than on the average mutual fund. That additional expense eats into returns substantially over time.
Slicing the top capital gains tax from 28 to 20 percent has made mutual funds even more attractive.
Patrick Reinkemeyer, who follows variable annuities at Morningstar Inc., says it now takes 18 years, on average, before a variable annuity produces as much after taxes as a similar mutual fund without the insurance component. The tax change, he said, has added five to seven years to the break-even point.
Here is why: When a long-term investor cashes in his mutual fund, he will owe no more than 20 percent in Federal tax on his capital gain. When the variable annuity owner withdraws his money, he will be taxed at his regular income tax rate, in many cases 28 percent or more.
For someone many years from retirement, the extra years needed to benefit from the annuity may not matter. But the majority of new buyers are in their 50's, and their account values will not be as great when they reach 65 as if they had invested in the underlying mutual fund. Furthermore, if they are in a high income tax bracket, they will pay more in taxes on withdrawals.
Two of the companies that have lowered their fees to help compensate for the tax effect, Fidelity and Vanguard, were already offering variable annuities with expenses below average because they do not use commissioned sales staff to market their products. Fidelity has dropped its total expenses, including insurance and fund management, on its least expensive actively managed annuity to 1.38 percent of assets, from 1.58 percent, slightly more than on the average stock mutual fund. Vanguard's expenses on an actively managed annuity have fallen to as low as 0.75 percent, from 0.81 percent.
Even Nationwide, whose products are most often sold through financial advisers, has cut the insurance component of its fees to 0.95 percent from 1.4 percent on its lowest-cost product. Stock fund management raises total expenses to at least 1.62 percent, depending on the stock account.
Variable annuities are sold directly to consumers by companies like Fidelity and Vanguard, but they are also sold by tens of thousands of insurance agents, along with armies of securities brokers and bankers, all of whom earn commissions of about 6 percent on annuities and about 4.5 percent on mutual funds. The big sales force helps explain how sales of variable annuities zoomed from $9.3 billion 10 years ago to $85 billion last year. The total invested in variable annuities is estimated at $600 billion, much less than the $3.3 trillion that Americans have plowed into stock and bond funds. But by one estimate, variable annuities account for a fourth of the new money into both variable annuities and mutual funds.
Mark Mackey, chief executive of the National Association for Variable Annuities, a national trade group in Virginia, says variable annuities should not be measured solely as investments. He points to the added value of the insurance features.
Yet many advisers say that, for all their allure, the insurance features are of dubious economic value. Given the stock market's growth in the last several decades, they say, it is unlikely that a long-term investment will fall below its initial level, except in the early years.
"I've always thought of the death benefit as something that is really more psychologically valuable than economically meaningful," said Mr. Reinkemeyer of Morningstar. People who want life insurance will often do better by simply buying a term policy, the most economical form.
As for the option of receiving payments to the end of one's life, Limra International, an insurance industry research organization, says few people are choosing it. Most people either take out their money in a lump sum or in a series of periodic payments based on something other than how long they will probably live, said Scott Dunn, a Limra researcher.
The reasons are twofold. Because people are living longer, payments can be very small if based on life expectancy. By taking the money on their own schedule, people can get more money sooner.
The other big drawback to a lifetime stream of payments is that if the investor dies, the payments stop and the account balance reverts to the insurance company, not his heirs. It's a gamble many people do not want to take.
Mr. Mackey of the National Association for Variable Annuities says most comparisons of variable annuities and mutual funds incorrectly assume that a mutual fund will be held for 20 years or so. In fact, he said, many shareholders change funds every two to four years, paying taxes each time. Moreover, managers of stock mutual funds typically turn over about 80 percent of their holdings annually, creating tax costs for investors. These taxes increase the cost of investing in mutual funds.
FURTHERMORE, while Congress cut the capital gains tax rate, it decided that securities must be held for 18 months, instead of 12, to qualify for the best rate. So mutual funds whose managers trade frantically will throw off more taxes and become less tax efficient.
It will take many more months to gauge the full impact of the changes in the capital gains tax. One possibility is that sales of variable annuities will hold up, but that consumers will shift to companies offering lower fees.
"Price war is too strong a term," Mr. Reinkemeyer said. "But I think what you will see is that companies charging lower fees will get an increasing portion of the pie."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 590 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In Asia, Stocks Melt Faster Than in '29

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It's not hard to catch an orange if someone throws one to you. But it gets more difficult if you're juggling eggs at the time.
That is the way Bob Rubin and Larry Summers, this country's top Treasury officials, must feel. If they're not canceling holiday vacations to revive the South Korea bailout, they're packing to fly to Indonesia to try to keep that rescue from unraveling. 
 Asian markets are crumbling again as investors flee. Stock markets in Singapore, Malaysia and the Philippines have lost more than a quarter of their value since the end of 1997. And those are the places that haven't required bailouts.
Markets in industrialized nations have been slower to react than in October. The Dow Jones industrial average went up for the first couple of days of 1998. But alarm is starting to spread. The Dow lost 200 points on Friday, bringing its four-day loss to almost 400 points. Still, it and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index remain well above their October lows, something that cannot be said for indexes of smaller stocks.
Many on Wall Street remain confident that the woes of faraway Asia can't really do a lot of damage to our huge economy. "Supertanker America" was the title of the year-end forecast by Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs strategist whose soothing words helped halt the October plunge.
In Washington, however, they seem worried. The United States has become the world's financial fireman at a time when officials in some of the hottest spots seem more concerned about their own welfare than about financial flames. Our Congress is quite happy to have the fires put out so long as it doesn't have to pay for the water Mr. Summers will carry as he visits Indonesia, where nepocapitalism has left President Suharto's relatives rich and scared of reform.
There has been much talk in recent years about the declining importance of Governments and the rising power of companies and markets. But underneath that talk has been a belief that the monetary authorities -- the finance ministers and central bankers -- could keep everything on an even keel.
Now the juggling skills of those officials are being put to the test. Fears of deflation and shrinking economies are replacing hopeful forecasts of slower growth in Asia. "Historically," said Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, "it has been very rapid asset price declines -- in equity and real estate, especially -- that have held the potential to be a virulently negative force in the economy."
Slow deflation, he said in a speech a week ago, could be handled, but speedy falls in prices were a threat. "The severe economic contraction of the early 1930's, and the associated persistent declines in product prices, could probably not have occurred apart from the steep asset price deflation that started in 1929."
How are we doing now? If you put a dollar into the Singapore stock market at the end of June, just over six months ago, you now have less than 50 cents. If you put it instead into Malaysia, you've got a quarter. From the 1929 peak, it took over a year for the S.& P. 500 to lose half its value, and more than two years for it to fall by 75 percent.
The American economy ended 1997 in something close to a boom, even as Asia was crumbling. Policy makers know what to do to cool down booms, and they have ideas about how to fight deflationary spirals. But combatting both at the same time, albeit in different parts of the world economy, is a new challenge.
Can they do it? Let's hope the answer is yes.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1323 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Hollywood Stock Market: You Can't Lose

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

 BODY:
AS the swooning Dow led you to wonder whether the only difference between Wall Street and the Titanic is that one of them had a band? If so, then maybe you are ready to open an account at the Hollywood Stock Exchange, where shares of the movie "Titanic" (ticker symbol: TITAN) are rising faster than those of Berkshire Hathaway.
The Hollywood what? Yes, it is finally here -- a stock exchange for film fanatics that deals in "Moviestocks" (films in production or recently released) and "Starbonds" (actors), and uses play money called "Hollywood dollars." 
 The exchange, run by HSX Holdings, is simulated and can be found on the World Wide Web at www.hsx.com. The Web site, supported by advertising, was created a year ago by Michael Burns and Max Keiser, two former stockbrokers in their 30's. They hope that the film industry will eventually use the exchange for market research and for financing films -- on the theory that people who are so happy to play a Hollywood-based game might invest in movies for real.
But for now it is still a game, and here is how it works:
After a free sign-up, a player receives an HSX account with $2 million in electronic scrip and is urged to start trading. As in real life, the goal is to buy low (before the films are released) and to sell high (once they are boffo at the b.o., as Variety would put it). Commissions, deducted from the account, reflect the industry standard of 1 percent. There is even a Hollywood Reserve Bank, with the power to adjust interest rates, print more Hollywood dollars and so on.
The prices of the securities are driven largely by actual ticket sales. But just as Wall Street reacts to breaking news, Moviestocks and Starbonds are affected by Hollywood events. A share of "Armageddon," now shooting, jumped 5 percent, for example, on the announcement that Bruce Willis had been signed to star.
And after Gwyneth Paltrow and Brad Pitt split last spring, her Starbond soared while his plunged. "Public perception was that she was better off without him," said David Herman, president and chief operating officer of HSX Holdings. When Will Smith, a star of "Men in Black," wed the actress Jada Pinkett, his bond price rose sharply. "Fans decided that settling down was good for Smith's career," Mr. Herman said.
But on this exchange, players trade strictly for fun, not profit -- though contests during the year offer prizes like tickets to a film premiere or a trip to the Caribbean.
Such goodies are common in the handful of other on-line virtual stock exchanges, too. For instance, CNBC and MCI sponsor a stock-picking contest -- real stocks, play money at www.cnbcsst.mci.com -- for student investment clubs. Winners get T-shirts, and the grand prize is an appearance with the CNBC anchor Bill Griffeth.
So who is playing the Hollywood game? Including the sons of the president of Botswana, 63,000 participants are registered and about 5,000 of them trade each day. The daily volume is about 67 million shares -- approximately double that of the American Stock Exchange. Thirty percent of the players are students, and 20 percent are involved in the media or entertainment industries.
And it is not just movie fans who take their chances on the Hollywood exchange. So do Tinseltown insiders like the actor Albert Brooks, who in 1996 directed and starred in "Mother"; Gordon Paddison, manager of interactive marketing at New Line Cinema, and May Wuthrich, a film scout at the Writers House in New York.
Studio executives seem professionally interested, too. Mr. Paddison said HSX had great potential as a research engine. "Sure, it's only a game," he said, "but everything in Hollywood is perception."
One satisfied customer is Dale J. Borgen, a pastor of an evangelical church in San Dimas, Calif. A popcorn-carrying film buff, he trades on the exchange several times a day and calls the site addictive.
"There's a real intensity about trading against other players," said Mr. Borgen, 28, who has set up an investment site for the game -- http://members.xoom.com/HSJ -- that carries reviews of future initial public offerings (new releases) and fiscal results (box office returns).
Some fans insist that the exchange is educational, though so is driving 90 miles an hour through a Buffalo blizzard to study the laws of traction and aerodynamics. Still, the HSX game can go a long way toward familiarizing people with real investing.
The game has real-time trading and a ticker tape. Starbonds are rated AAA through C. The central bank has a chairman, "Dr. Zeros," who is an HSX employee. There is even program trading. When a sheep was cloned last summer, "sell" programs hit the trading floor as anxious players contemplated the consequences of having not one but six Harrison Fords.
I found out how real the game was when I played it myself. I set out to corner the market on "Deconstructing Harry," (ticker symbol: DECON), the new movie by Woody Allen. My decision was based on positive response from a friend who had worked as an extra for Mr. Allen. But I should have read the small print on my PC screen. HSX, like the Securities and Exchange Commission, requires investors who want to own more than 5 percent of a security to file with the exchange and explain their interests. In other words, Jim Carrey cannot simply buy up all of his Starbonds. To avoid the hassle, I bought less than 5 percent.
The HSX departs from real investing in a way that some people may love: Insider trading is completely legal. "The Internet is very open, so we don't crack down on it," said Mr. Keiser, one of the HSX creators. "You get lighting people, soundmen and gaffers who are all working on projects and gossiping like mad. Traders have to decide for themselves what's fact and what's fiction."
HSX sure seemed educational for Austin Chen, a 23-year-old student at Ohio State University. Mr. Chen won the HSX trip for two to Antigua last year, and he sounds like a winning portfolio manager.
"I tried to find undervalued stocks -- shares in projects that people either didn't know too much about or didn't think would do very well," said Mr. Chen, who may check his portfolio four or five times a day. One of his bigger bets was on "Soul Food," starring Vanessa L. Williams and others. Its stock opened at $10 a share and had reached $35.25 after a month in the theaters.
Meanwhile, Mr. Burns and Mr. Keiser, the founders of the exchange, are working on their plans to take the site beyond simulated investing. Given the rising expense of making movies, HSX is designing a system in which its traders can invest real money in film projects. Mr. Keiser said the idea, which is geared to cash-hungry independent film producers rather than the big studios, will soon be before the S.E.C. for approval.
The HSX managers also say the game can become an audience laboratory for the industry. How movie buffs vote with their play money could supplement the test screenings in Los Angeles suburbs upon which studios often rely. Mr. Herman hopes that studio executives will soon float trial balloons for project concepts on the exchange.
AT times, the sentiments of HSX traders have been impressively on target. Warner Brothers pulled out all the stops for "Batman and Robin" last spring, for example, but the exchange correctly signaled that the Caped Crusaders were headed for the Bat Grave. And while the media had a field day reporting problems on the set of Sony's "Men in Black," its HSX shares generated huge momentum six months before it became a hit last summer.
Well, I have been away from my HSX portfolio for about 10 minutes now, and it is time to get back to trading. I own the limit on Kathy Bates. I had wanted to buy stock in her ever since her 1991 movie, "Fried Green Tomatoes," in which she tells those two obnoxious young women whose car she deliberately smashes, "Face it, girls: I'm older and I have more insurance."

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2; Page 41; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk
