HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
In Search Of A Foothold In Rocky Times

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
AS stock and bond markets around the world became more volatile last year, mutual fund investors sought safety. But they did not always get it.
Some of the very mutual fund managers whose conservative-sounding funds were most in demand reached aggressively for yield, pushing their holdings of relatively volatile types of securities to the limit. 
 Consider the CGM Fixed Income fund, a long-term bond fund. Most such funds perform well when long-term interest rates fall rapidly. But in spite of a decline in rates in the fourth quarter, the CGM fund lost 5 percent of its value as the price of one security cratered. The only bond funds that did worse were invested in Asian emerging markets. CGM declined to identify the problem holding, but it recently pushed its junk bond allocation to a third of its portfolio, the fund's self-imposed limit.
Investors should brace for more blowups in bond funds, said Burton J. Greenwald, who provides advice to mutual funds from his firm in Philadelphia. "I think you may already have some managers who have been tempted to overreach," he said. And stock funds may hold some surprises. "It seems that after three years of such incredible ebullience in the marketplace, some funds might be further out on a limb than investors realize," he said.
If so, it comes at an inopportune time. At the end of last year, investors made a clear shift to more conservative funds. Government bond funds attracted more money than they lost in the fourth quarter -- the first time they had done so in four years. Growth-and-income funds, the most conservative class of general equity funds, took in nearly half of the money coming into American stock funds, the most since 1989. And investors, unnerved by the tumult in Asian and domestic markets, put a bigger portion of their new fund dollars into money market funds.
But fund managers have a far different view of the world. Even as they have posted solid gains, their frustrations have grown because they have found it more difficult to keep up with low-cost unmanaged portfolios, like those that track the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. For the fourth year in a row in 1997, the average stock fund failed to beat the index.
Most bond funds had trouble keeping up with their benchmark, too. As long-term interest rates fell below 6 percent, to their lowest point in two years, the average taxable bond fund produced a total return of 8.85 percent for the year, according to Morningstar Inc., below the 9.6 percent return of the Lehman Brothers Aggregate bond index.
There were a few bright spots. Funds that specialize in financial services, the best-performing sector of the last five years, continued their torrid pace in 1997, gaining 46 percent. And in the final three months of the year, utility funds, one of the worst-performing groups over the last five years, topped the performance lists.
Still, the majority of funds had disappointing returns when compared with their indexes. Is it any wonder that some of their managers reached for higher returns in some surprising ways?
Consider the Oppenheimer Global Growth and Income fund. The manager's midyear report practically screamed "stability," stating in all capital letters that the fund is intended for people "who need to reduce the effect of short-term market fluctuations."
So what were shareholders to think when they opened the most recent report? They found that nearly one-fifth of their assets were invested in some of the most volatile securities around -- zero-coupon Treasury strips, a form of a long-term Treasury bond that reacts sharply to changes in interest rates. By last week, moreover, the portfolio manager, Frank Jennings, had doubled that bet, placing 40 percent of the fund in zero-coupon Treasuries.
So far, the gambit has worked. Declining long-term rates helped the fund to a gain of 28.3 percent last year, and it has gained more than 20 percent in each of the last three years. Yet that performance only put the fund in the middle of the pack of 3,000 equity funds that are tracked by Morningstar and that have been around for three years or more.
After Mr. Jennings took over the portfolio in October 1995, the fund started to adopt some riskier strategies, first by investing more in stocks of small companies and in emerging markets, then, in the last half of 1996, by creeping into zero-coupon bonds.
The fund made a full-fledged bet on the direction of interest rates last fall. As of last week, two-fifths of the fund's $300 million in assets were invested in long-term zero-coupon Treasury bonds -- long-term Treasuries that have the interest coupon stripped away, leaving just the principal.
"They do roughly twice as well as the long bond" when bond prices rise and interest rates fall, Mr. Jennings said of the zeros. "They are equivalent to 50-year Treasury bonds."
Of course, their value also falls more sharply and more quickly when interest rates rise.
A glance back to 1992 and 1994 shows what can happen when rates rise. The average taxable bond fund lost nearly 4 percent in 1994, according to Morningstar, and a few imploded. In 1992, a European currency crisis produced big losses for shareholders in many short-term world bond funds, which aimed to invest in what were then thought to be "safe" government securities. The category has since largely disappeared.
Mr. Jennings bristles at the notion his strategy is speculative. "I'm sensitive to being portrayed as a guy who's just a gunslinger," he said. Zero-coupon Treasuries "are less risky than most junk bonds and most telephone company bonds. And they are less risky than Microsoft stock or a lot of stuff that is in most stock indexes."
Some fund managers disagree. "If a manager's philosophy is primarily to add value by trying to time interest rates, that is as dangerous as an equity manager who tries to time the equity market," said Kevin McClintock, head of taxable fixed-income funds at Dreyfus.
The interest-rate bet seems particularly odd for a fund with a growth-and-income name. Indeed, after the fund made its regular report on its holdings last month, Morningstar moved it into the international hybrid category from the growth-and-income stock category because of its big bet on interest rates. Even Mr. Jennings acknowledges that his strategy is a bit controversial, saying "I've gotten a certain amount of heat on the subject."
STILL, Mr. Jennings points out that only about one-quarter of last year's returns came from his bond positions, and that astute stock picks -- including Nintendo, the electronic game company in Japan, and Dairy Farm International, the supermarket chain listed in Singapore -- accounted for the rest.
Mr. Jennings said his current strategy assumed that the economy could fall into recession, leading to a bear market in stocks and "a massive bond market rally."
"I don't think the average investor appreciates that risk," he said, referring to recessionary prospects.
Investors in the CGM Fixed Income fund might not have appreciated the risks they faced, either. The fund, one in a stable overseen by G. Kenneth Heebner, has been the best-performing general bond fund tracked by Lipper Analytical Services over the last three and five years -- a fact that CGM has trumpeted in advertisements.
But the once-steady performer lost 5.1 percent of its value last quarter, even as long-term interest rates fell and the prices of long-term bonds rose. The average long-term bond fund gained 2.8 percent in the same period, according to Morningstar.
What hurt the CMG Fixed Income portfolio? No one at Capital Growth Management, the Boston company headed by Mr. Heebner, agreed to talk about it.
The fund's most recent portfolio, dated June 30 in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that at least 35 percent of its $44 million in assets consisted of bonds below investment grade -- that is, high-risk junk bonds. Those bonds pay high interest rates, and their value moves more in sync with stock prices than with long-term bonds.
A highly concentrated portfolio is characteristic of the way Mr. Heebner runs his funds. It can lead to significant outperformance when events go the fund's way. But it also means that one holding can cause a portfolio to implode.
A call to CGM's toll-free shareholder information line produced an operator who, while declining to give her name, said "a particular holding" in the fund's portfolio dragged down the fund's performance last quarter. She said that she could not name the holding, but that "the portfolio has since been restructured, about three weeks ago."
The bond market is not the only place where portfolio managers have been tempted to stretch for a performance edge. A stock fund that has done so by reaching down into the tiniest of stocks, known as microcaps, and by betting big is Safeco Growth.
One of the best performers among all diversified American stock funds for the last five years, Safeco Growth gained 50 percent last year, making it fifth best among the diversified stock funds tracked by Morningstar. Assets have exploded, with up to $20 million a day coming into the fund, helping it to triple in size over the last year, to $600 million.
That rapid growth has led the fund to assume increasingly large positions in its favorite stocks. At the end of June, 27 percent of the fund's assets were in companies in which the fund owned more than 5 percent. Less than two years ago, such investments accounted for less than 5 percent of the fund's portfolio.
Some of the fund's positions amount to several times the number of shares that normally trade each day. At the end of September, the Safeco fund owned more than 522,000 shares of Lifeline Systems, which markets an electronic system for summoning emergency medical assistance. That stake amounted to more than 9 percent of Lifeline's total shares, near the 10 percent limit for the fund. Other Safeco funds and employee pension plans owned 6 percent more of Lifeline. Given that a mere 13,500 Lifeline shares trade each day, it would take nearly 60 days for all the Safeco-related funds to sell all that Lifeline stock.
And Lifeline is but one of a dozen companies in which the Safeco Growth fund has stakes of 5 to 10 percent.
"If I believe in a stock, I think it's in the best interest of shareholders not to worry about how to get out of it," said Thomas M. Maguire, the Safeco fund's manager. "This is a diversified portfolio. When I hit a home run with a stock, I'm going to make 300 or 400 percent. I'm not going to hit home runs every time, but the most I can lose in any one stock is 100 percent. The ones I'm right about will more than make up for the ones I'm wrong on."
So far, at least, they have. But sometimes an entire sector falls so far that few individual securities escape unscathed.
For an example, just look at the recent activity in the Asian stock and bond markets. When Southeast Asian currencies went into a tailspin last year, so did stocks in most emerging markets, as well as some bonds and notes issued by Asian Government agencies and banks.
SOME American money market funds held Korean bank debt when those economies began their slump. IBC Financial Data, which tracks money market funds, said the Alliance Money Market Prime portfolio and the Alliance Capital Reserves fund had the biggest exposures last year.
At the end of May, the most recent data filed with the S.E.C. showed that more than 5 percent of each portfolio was invested in bonds issued by the Industrial Bank of Korea and the Korean Development Bank. A spokesman for Alliance said that those funds no longer held Korean securities, adding that the ones in the portfolio early last year matured at full value in October.
The Strong Heritage Money fund, one of last year's best performers among money market funds, also held some Korean securities at the end of August, the date of its last report. A spokeswoman for Strong said that after those securities matured at full value, the fund did not buy any more Korean securities.
While these money market funds escaped harm this time, other funds could get caught leaning the wrong way, especially if interest rates reverse their downward spiral of recent days.

PUB-DATE: January 11, 1998

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2847 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Where Immigrant Dreams Prosper, at a Profit

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
ROSENDO STEWART left Colon, Panama, 19 years ago, hoping to prosper in the United States. For years he worked two jobs in New York, as a cabby and a doorman, but could not unlock the door to his dream through hard work alone.
Last month, though, he got a key to prosperity in the form of a loan to buy a taxi medallion, the city's coveted license to operate a yellow cab. Now, instead of paying roughly half of his gross income to lease someone else's taxi, Mr. Stewart will be building equity in his own business. What is more, medallions -- now selling for $237,000 each -- have made taxis one of the hottest long-term investment vehicles around. In the 60 years since medallions have been sold in the open market, their price has increased an average of more than 18 percent a year, versus the long-term historical average of 10.9 percent for large stocks. 
 "In a few years, with the money from my medallion I will open a little store," Mr. Stewart said. "Or maybe I will buy a second medallion and lease it to someone and make money from someone else's work."
Mr. Stewart's chance to move from working stiff to capitalist, junior grade, was created by a curious mix of a small-business loan program dating back to the Nixon years, an obscure Federal tax break and the city's Depression-era decision to make taxi medallions a form of currency.
It is also a modern version of an old story about how government policies, reshaped over the years by shifting political winds and strong market forces, often produce unintended results. In this case, what began as a program to promote black capitalism after the urban unrest of the 1960's has mutated, in part, into a gateway for hundreds of immigrants to own New York cabs.
Mr. Stewart got his help from the Freshstart Venture Capital Corporation, a tiny lender in midtown Manhattan that is a remnant of the Nixon-era program.
Faulted for falling far short of its goals, as well as for management and investment problems, the program was essentially privatized by the Republican-controlled Congress in 1996. The 80 private investment companies around the country through which it operated, including Freshstart, were allowed to keep their licenses from the Small Business Administration, but no new companies can apply.
The Government stopped providing direct subsidies to the remaining companies in the form of cheap capital, while allowing them to keep several million dollars each in below-market financing. It also preserved a special tax break that is intended to attract stockholders and private sources of capital. The break allows investors who buy shares in the companies to defer capital gains taxes on other stock profits.
Under the S.B.A.'s supervision, the 80 lenders, known as specialized small-business investment companies, must still use their capital to help "socially or economically disadvantaged" people, in the language of the law that created the program. All but six focus on underwriting traditional small-business ventures -- from fast-food restaurants to manufacturing plants -- lending largely to blacks and other members of minority groups who might have difficulty obtaining financing or be forced to pay high rates.
The exceptions -- Freshstart and five other companies, all in New York -- also write traditional loans but have found their niche with immigrants and medallions.
Freshstart stands alone in another respect: it is the only one of the 80 companies to go public, hoping the tax advantage will attract enough investors to fuel its ambitious growth plans. Still working with immigrants, it is already financing restaurants in Florida and laundromats in New Jersey. Its goal is a national reach.
"There is a large market of people to borrow from us," said Freshstart's president, Zindel Zelmanovitch, whose first job after arriving in New York from the Soviet Union in 1972 was driving a cab. "We think investing in immigrants is a good business."
Other companies from the program are eagerly watching to see how Freshstart progresses in attracting investors. If going public pays off, they may follow. If not, they may concentrate more on another S.B.A. program in which many of them also participate. This program, which is not limited to helping the socially or economically disadvantaged, provides substantial subsidies, mostly to small businesses, in the form of cheap capital but does not allow investors a tax break.
For now, at least, Freshstart seems to be doing well. Though it operates out of a third-floor walkup office on West 53d Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, its revenue is expected to exceed $3 million this year, more than double the $1.3 million of its last fiscal year, ended May 31. Its profit margin was a spectacular 41 percent last year, helped by an almost total absence of defaults. And its stock, while thinly traded on Nasdaq, is more than holding its own. Since going public in November 1996 at $4.50 a share, it has traded as high as $7.50 and as low as $3. It is now at $5.875.
 
Problems and Risks
To be sure, Freshstart has its problems. The S.B.A. has suggested to the company and some other lenders that they may be putting too much money into medallions. "We have told these lenders to diversify their portfolios," said Don A. Christensen, the S.B.A. official who oversees the companies.
If New York greatly increased the number of medallions -- there are now 12,187 -- prices could plummet. Though there seems to be little chance that will happen, at least for now, prices have been rising at a more moderate rate, 13 percent a year, on average, in the last five years.
In its prospectus, Freshstart disclosed the potential for conflicts of interest posed by the fact that one of its directors, Neil Greenbaum, who is also the secretary of the company, operates an insurance and medallion brokerage company in the same building. In addition, Mr. Zelmanovitch, the president, owns one of the other investment companies that specialize in medallions, the privately held East Coast Capital Corporation, which has offices in the same building in Manhattan.
Freshstart and Mr. Greenbaum say they fully disclose all their relationships to their clients. Because the clients are often not sophisticated about finance and sometimes still struggle with English, Mr. Greenbaum said, company executives explain as many details of the arrangements as the clients will tolerate.
In any event, industry experts not affiliated with Freshstart say one-stop shopping is common in the business, and they add that the company charges competitive interest rates, currently 8.5 to 9.5 percent, depending on the borrower's credit rating.
Such concerns aside, the Nixon Administration program has finally found success in medallion loans, said Timothy Bates, a professor of urban affairs at Wayne State University in Detroit who has been evaluating the program for the S.B.A. since 1994.
"Lending money on New York City taxi medallions turns out to be a deal made in heaven," Professor Bates said in an interview. "You get golden collateral behind your loan because medallions are highly liquid with very little risk for the lender. And so today, we have more loans made under this program for medallions than to manufacturing, wholesaling and construction companies combined."
 
An Outgrowth of Unrest
Investing in immigrants was not the idea 29 years ago when the lending program began. Richard M. Nixon was in his first year as President and the destructive riots that had swept the country earlier in the decade, from Newark to Detroit to Los Angeles, were still harsh memories. Maurice H. Stans, the Commerce Secretary, declared himself a proponent of black capitalism. The Administration, he said, would commit $500 million to low-cost loans in an effort to nurture black-owned businesses.
The S.B.A. began lending money at low rates to 49 of what were then called minority enterprise small-business investment companies. By October 1970, these companies had invested $43.7 million, through direct stakes or as loans.
Critics were soon complaining, however, that the program was too small and too fragmented to create a significant class of black business owners and that too many loans were being made to businesses that had little potential to grow.
At its peak, the program involved 130 investment companies with $250 million to invest, said William A. Kirk, a partner at the law firm of Reid & Priest in Washington who has worked with some of the lenders.
But despite steady infusions of tax dollars, the program never achieved its stated goals, a failure that was documented in a number of private reports and in studies by the General Accounting Office.
Through 1996, the G.A.O. reported last year, taxpayers lost $61 million just in shutting down investment companies that had failed. It cost taxpayers an additional $79 million to sell back, at a steep discount, preferred stock that the Government had bought to help the companies get started; Freshstart got $1 million of this subsidy. Over all, the S.B.A. said it does not have figures to show the program's net return, in dollars or in the creation of jobs and wealth.
The investment companies clearly backed a number of big successes. One was Reginald Lewis, who bought the McCall Pattern Company. Another was Chester Davenport, who bought a company, now known as Envirotest Systems, an auto-emissions testing business. Two others were Ed Lewis and Clarence Smith, who helped found Essence magazine.
But in too many cases, the lenders were too small to make a difference, Professor Bates said, and the S.B.A. never demanded that their managers have any expertise.
"Many failed, and of those that hung on, many invested in bank certificates of deposit, often putting more than half of the funds into C.D.'s," he said. "The game was to get subsidized funds from the S.B.A. and invest in bank C.D.'s and live off the spread, not to invest in black-owned businesses."
After the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994, they set out to kill the program, succeeding for all practical purposes two years later.
But buried amid the program's debris was an overlooked pocket of success: the companies, like Freshstart, that had been quietly lending to cabbies for years.
Though the cabbies were largely not the program's originally intended beneficiaries, they nonetheless qualified for loans because their immigrant status came within the definition of socially or economically disadvantaged. And what they did with their loans fit the bill exactly: they used them to get a foot in the door.
 
A Pocketful of Cabby Loans
 Freshstart, founded in 1982, has made $24 million in loans to more than 500 cabbies. At that, it is one of the smallest lenders in the taxi niche. The largest are the two companies operated by the Medallion Financial Corporation, a publicly traded company with a total of $192 million in loans, the overwhelming majority of them for medallions. (Medallion's structure does not allow investors to qualify for the special tax break.)
Freshstart and the others "understand the needs of cabbies a lot better than a regular bank," said Bob Mackle, a lawyer, insurance broker and tax adviser to taxi drivers. These companies, he added, "understand how well protected the equity in a medallion is, and they know that even if the cabbie does not have perfect credit, they would still be able to write the loan."
Most cabbies start by leasing their cars and medallions, as Mr. Stewart did for years, and drive 10 to 12 hours a day, six days a week. Mr. Stewart said he took in about $200 a day, including tips, or $1,200 weekly. After paying $100 a day for the lease -- plus gasoline and the cost of any traffic tickets -- Mr. Stewart took home less than $25,000 a year.
To buy a medallion and cab is hardly an inexpensive proposition.
Until 1937, the city sold medallions for $10 each. Then it stopped issuing new ones and allowed the price to be set by the market. The price rose so steeply because few of the 11,787 medallions were being traded, and no new ones were issued until May 1996, when the city held the first of three auctions that put a total of 400 more on the market.
For decades, though, "medallion lending was considered risky business," said Michael Higgins, publisher of Taxi Talk, a monthly newspaper. And the few lenders that made loans required them to be paid off in five years. Many drivers simply could not qualify, leaving many taxis in the hands of corporate fleet owners.
The added competition of lenders like Freshstart and Medallion has driven down interest rates, Mr. Higgins said. Cabbies who once had to pay double-digit rates now pay about 9 percent. Moreover, lenders "are giving borrowers up to 20 and 30 years to pay off a medallion," he said, "and that lowered the monthly cost and made it be like gold."
 
A Deal and a Paint Job
Mr. Stewart, who is 43 and lives in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, with his wife and two children, got his medallion for $226,900 in early December.
He was so happy about his new prospects that he grinned nonstop the other day as he maneuvered through traffic from Manhattan to the Bay Ridge Honda dealership in Brooklyn. He was going to the dealer to see his new cab -- a 1998 Honda Odyssey mini-van, the first new car he had ever bought -- before its metallic gray paint was covered with bright yellow.
In his $261,000 package deal with Freshstart, Mr. Stewart put down $35,000 that he had saved. The deal financed the cost of the medallion, the mini-van customized for taxi duty and a host of fees for a lawyer, insurance and various documents. With the down payment, his loan is for $226,000 at 9 percent interest, a half point above the prime rate. After five years, he will have to refinance at the prevailing market rate for medallions, a typical arrangement at Freshstart. Then, assuming that medallion prices have kept rising and that interest rates have not gone through the roof, Mr. Stewart will be able to take a sizable chunk of cash out of the medallion to buy a house, say, or start another business.
Monthly payments on his loan are $3,100, which is more than the $2,800 he was paying in daily lease fees. But even after taking into account his incidental costs, like gasoline, he is building equity in his medallion because about $800 of his check to Freshstart pays down principal.
Many Freshstart clients know little about their financing, except the interest rate and the monthly payment they must make. Mr. Stewart, for example, said he did not know that if he paid more each month on his loan he would pay off his debt more quickly, increasing his equity and reducing total interest charges.
 
'Cookie-Cutter Business'
Small as it is, Freshstart can point to several people who have prospered after it lent them money.
Sasha Muniak was a violinist in a Polish state orchestra on tour in Yugoslavia when he fled through the woods to Italy more than 25 years ago. He eventually made his way to New York, where he and a brother took turns driving a cab round the clock.
When he got a few thousand dollars together, he turned to fellow Polish emigres for more money and then got a loan from Freshstart for his own medallion and cab. He later sold the medallion to raise money for his first tiny restaurant.
Today he owns the Mangia chain of restaurants in Manhattan and relies on major banks for most of his financing. When his newest restaurant, at 40 Wall Street, ran over budget, however, he went back to Freshstart for about $300,000 in additional financing.
But even with loans to immigrants for fast-food outlets, laundromats and Mr. Muniak's latest restaurant, Freshstart still has three-quarters of its portfolio in medallions and cabs.
All in all, it is a lucrative business.
On that $1.3 million in revenue in the year ended May 31, Freshstart had profits of $527,000. The company has $17 million in outstanding loans, its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission show, and only one of the loans has gone sour. Freshstart took a loss on a $181,000 mortgage on New York City real estate.
As president, Mr. Zelmanovitch was paid $85,320 in the most recent fiscal year. His family owns about one-twelfth of Freshstart, giving them a stake worth $1.12 million, at current market prices.
Compared with Freshstart's 41 percent, the much bigger Medallion Financial has a profit margin of 36 percent, according to S.E.C. filings.
Andy Murstein, Medallion's president, said his company and Freshstart had such high profit margins "because this is a cookie-cutter business with the same forms and the same collateral."
"Our focus," he said, "is on the medallion, the asset we lend against, not the borrower."
But if Mr. Stewart is any indication, the borrower is a pretty solid asset, too.
As soon as he got his medallion, Mr. Stewart increased his daily 10 to 12 hours behind the wheel to about 14. The reason, he said, is "to make sure I bring in enough money to pay my loan."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Balancing Act;
Not So Fast: Here Comes the Budget Crunch

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON displayed his deft political touch last week, calling for the first balanced budget in three decades and in the process taking credit for solving a problem that has dogged Washington since the early years of the Reagan Administration.
How much credit he actually deserves is a matter of dispute. For while the green eye-shade crowd is effusive in praising the tax increases and spending trims that President Clinton engineered in 1993, the improved fiscal outlook is a product of a variety of factors ranging from the stock market boom to the lower prices of imports from deflation-wracked Asia. 
 "Think of it as the reverse of Murphy's Law," suggests Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who is now a senior fellow at the Urban Institute. "Everything that could go right has gone right."
 
Storm Clouds
Paradoxically, the real test of fiscal leadership for President Clinton and his successors may be how they manage the good times ahead. For while there are solid reasons to believe that the budget will remain in surplus for a decade or more, the retirement of the baby boomers is certain to push the budget deeply into the red soon thereafter unless Washington acts preemptively to curtail the future cost of Social Security and Medicare.
"The future still looks terrible, but the day of reckoning has been postponed by a decade or more," said Robert Reischauer, another former Budget Office director who is now at the Brookings Institution.
A glimmer from the end of the deficit tunnel was first spotted in 1990, when President George Bush broke his campaign pledge and acceded to a tax increase. A second round of deficit cutting in 1993 also made a big difference, as has the Midas touch of the Federal Reserve in managing monetary policy. But the pace of deficit reduction, accelerated by the coincidence of stable growth, declining inflation, exceptionally low unemployment and off-the-charts tax receipts, caught virtually everyone by surprise.
Last September, the Congressional Budget Office forecast a $34 billion deficit in 1997 that would rise to $57 billion in 1998 and return to balance only in 2002. Last week the Budget Office revised the 1997 deficit estimate down to just $22 billion and projected a $5 billion surplus for 1998 -- a $62 billion swing in four months without any changes in Federal spending or tax policy.
"Forecasters have repeatedly had to play catch-up since the beginning of 1996," marveled Van Doorn Ooms, director of research at the Committee for Economic Development.
Good news begets more good news. The quicker return to budget surplus means a smaller national debt down the road, along with lower interest rates and smaller annual interest payments to service the debt. It now appears that the "baseline budget" -- one that assumes no changes in fiscal policy -- will remain in surplus until 2012.
 
Mixed Signals
At that point, the retirement of the first wave of aging baby boomers, who are entitled to generous Social Security and Medicare benefits, will darken the budget picture. But Mr. Reischauer points out that the ratio of Federal debt to gross domestic product, arguably the most objective measure of the burden of the debt, will probably continue to fall, with debt declining from the current level of 48 percent of G.D.P. to just 20 percent in 2015. And while the baseline-budget deficit will grow steadily after 2012, it is not expected to climb back to the 1992 magnitude (3.8 percent of G.D.P.) until 2028.
Slippage is possible -- make that, likely -- between now and then. Mr. Clinton has already proposed to invest a chunk of the prospective surplus in day care services, while House Speaker Newt Gingrich is appealing to conservative Republicans with calls for "at least a small tax cut every year" when the budget is in the black.
By the same token, even a modest stumble from the straight and narrow path of low inflation and 2 percent-plus economic growth would reduce projected revenues and ratchet up spending on the social safety net. Moreover, said H. Erich Heineman, an economic consultant in New York, "If there's a serious recession, you can forget about surpluses."
But the deeper fear among economists is that budget bliss will persist well into the next decade, undermining the sense of urgency in rethinking how the nation will pay for the retirement of the baby boomers. For while the prognosis has brightened considerably since fiscal reformers first warned of the coming demographic tsunami, there is still big budget trouble ahead.
In 1991, the economists Alan Auerbach, Jagadeesh Gokhale and Lawrence Kotlikoff estimated that Americans born after 1994 would have to fork over an astonishing 84 percent of their wages to deliver on the nation's promises to the old. A recalculation, expected to be published this year, is likely to reduce this anticipated tax burden to around 50 percent. But this would still be a remarkable stretch compared with the estimated 30 percent lifetime net tax rate -- taxes paid less Government pensions and medical care received -- on Americans born in the 1930's and 1940's.
Mr. Kotlikoff, an economist at Boston University, put it another way. To create an actuarial balance between future revenues and promised Government benefits, he estimated that personal and corporate income tax rates would have to be raised by 20 percent right now and kept at the higher rates indefinitely.
Waiting a decade or two to act, of course, would drastically increase the cost of the fix. "The idea that the problem is solving itself simply ignores fiscal reality," Mr. Kotlikoff argued.
Mr. Penner is tentatively optimistic that policy makers will be able to deal rationally with distant but inevitable demographic change, even as they celebrate the current respite from deficit-driven politics of fiscal scarcity. "I'm very impressed with how the idea of Social Security and Medicare reform has entered mainstream debate," he said.
But that is asking a lot from officials trained by voters to focus on the present, lest there be no future. "It will be several political lifetimes until Washington again faces a budget crisis," Mr. Reischauer said.

HEADLINE: The World;
Democracy, Apparatchik Style

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
SINCE Central Europe emerged from Communism, the nuts and bolts of democracy have been installed across the region. There are elections, newspapers galore, political parties of all kinds, growing numbers of television channels and radio stations in just about every city.
At election time, politicians file into the studios and debate each other as in any other Western democracy. Even between elections, politicians are frequent guests on television and radio talk shows. 
 But for the most part, Central European leaders talk at -- rather than consult with -- the people they claim to represent.
The notion, taken for granted all across the West, that politicians have to involve the people in the important decisions they make has yet to dent the high-handed tradition long followed by apparatchiks.
The political leadership here, argues Jan Urban, a former dissident and co-director of the Institute for Journalism in Transition, doesn't seem to have developed beyond the Communist-era dictum of making decisions first and then talking above the heads of the people.
This haughty style of politics, with scant attempt at engagement, applies to politicians with dissident backgrounds, in addition to those who were cogs within the Communist system, he adds.
Mr. Urban isn't just talking theory. He is a central player these days in a vivid case in point: the question of the Czech Republic's expected membership in NATO.
 
Familiar Face
On billboards all over the Czech Republic, Mr. Urban's group has plastered the beetle-browed face of the late Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev, in his study in the Kremlin, with a title that evokes a parallel TV campaign in which a voice-over says: "Thank you for freely deciding not to join NATO."
The ads are an exercise in sarcasm, intended to shock Czech citizens into wanting to join NATO as badly as their leaders do. The leaders are all in favor, of course, but to date have seemed to lack the political and rhetorical tools needed to rouse public opinion behind them. As a result, for the most part, public opinion polls show fewer than half of Czech citizens in support of NATO membership -- a statistic that does not enhance the Czech case in the United States Senate, where a two-thirds vote will be needed to approve the alliance's expansion.
It is a situation rich in ironies, and it reveals a great deal about what democracy has come to mean in Central Europe.
One of the criteria that Washington established for considering the Eastern European countries as NATO partners was the establishment of democratic institutions, including free elections, independent judiciaries and diverse information media. These are now mostly in place across Central Europe. How they are used is another matter.
"Politicians feel that if they communicate through television by using it as an amplifier, this is sufficient," said Lubos Beniak, who ran a trend-breaking interview program, in the style of Larry King, on the Czech private television channel, Nova. "Generally speaking, television interviews are quite gentle and Czech journalists still feel they are part of politics and want to express their views." It is a formula that makes for deadening public discourse.
And a mentality accustomed to one-party rule is hard to get rid of.
In the Czech Republic, the recently deposed Prime Minister, Vaclav Klaus, who was in office for five years, held regular town hall meetings. But his tolerance for hearing opinions different from his own was fairly limited. On NATO, Mr. Klaus had one rule: the topic was too complicated for ordinary people.
In Poland, where there is overwhelming public support for joining NATO, the politicians have felt little need to explain the difficult issues that come with membership: the responsibilities as well as the rights.
Thus, the necessities of scaling down the huge Polish army, making it more professional and spending money on new equipment have not figured in wide debate. They have been written about in long articles in several highbrow newspapers, but a Polish diplomat jested recently that his nation needed a popular military hero like Gen. H. Norman Schwartzkopf or Gen. Colin L. Powell to explain the everyday realities of NATO to the average Pole.
 
New Approach
One Polish politician has learned the benefits of communicating.
In 1991, Leszek Balcerowicz, the Polish Finance Minister who introduced the hard-knuckle economic measures that helped turn the economy around, was one of the most unpopular public figures. He left office as he came in: tight-lipped.
But he returned in 1995, revitalizing the Freedom Union political party and his own standing. And in last September's elections, he campaigned with a fresh image -- smart ties, new glasses, appealing suits. Most astonishingly, he talked directly and frequently to his coal mining constituents about the need for more tough economic medicine. He was elected to Parliament by one of the biggest margins in Poland.
Still, he is the exception.
The next challenge facing Central Europe after NATO is the European Union. Already prime ministers and presidents from the former Communist nations are flying off to Brussels with victory waves and coming back beaming, saying membership is imminent. They rarely mention the coming hardships -- cutting back agriculture, slimming down steel industries -- that will be needed.
To make sure the people of Central Europe understand the rough ride that European Union membership will initially entail, national television campaigns are being prepared. Not by the invited governments, however. The campaign is being drawn up by the European Union itself.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Crying Need;
Day-Care Quandary: A Nation at War With Itself

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON last week unveiled a $21 billion package of Federal grants and tax breaks in what he called "the single largest national commitment to child care in the history of the United States."
The plan, which faces obvious hurdles in Congress, aims to address a desperate shortage of affordable and qualified care-givers for young children by improving wages, while boosting safety and training at child care centers. Currently child-care workers earn on average $6.12 a hour, or about $10,710 a year -- less than the counter help typically earn at many McDonald's -- and turnover in the field is rampant. 
 Such an infusion of money could transform child care in the United States, doubling to an estimated two million the number of children receiving subsidized day care. But it would probably do little to lift the ambivalence that many parents, particularly working mothers, feel in placing their infants in the care of total strangers, especially outside of the home. For working couples, could there be a better way?
A lot of people familiar with the day-care labor shortage think so. Part of the problem, they say, is that the Government is moving to provide child-care options with one hand while taking them away with the other.
In the past decade, Congress and several Administrations have systematically restricted the entry into this country of the very people who could provide at least a partial solution to the child-care problem: foreign care-givers. Long in an anti-immigrant mood, Congress only recently gave many immigrants a deadline of this week to apply for permanent residency or face being barred from the country for years.
"There are a vast number of women who have had and raised many children who'd be delighted to come to the United States and care for children, for whom it's virtually impossible to get visas," said Michael Maggio, a Washington immigration lawyer.
Legal immigrants involved in child care typically work as nannies in individual homes, not in day-care centers, and they represent a small segment of the industry. But if the Government changed its policy and created a special temporary visa or permanent-resident category for immigrant care-givers, parents and day-care center operators could tap a new supply of child-care professionals.
Expanding this source of domestic help may or may not reduce the cost of nannies dramatically; it might simply legalize the now-illegal market for immigrant child-care workers without affecting their wages significantly. But the pool of legal, qualified providers would undoubtedly expand.
Yet under the immigration code, it is easier to bring in a shepherd or kosher cook than someone to care for children in the home or a day-care center. That paradox raises the question: For whom, exactly, is the United States rolling out the red carpet?
The United States lets foreigners come here to live in two basic ways: as temporary immigrants on work visas (it let 24.8 million into the country in 1996, the last year for which figures are available) and as permanent residents (915,900 came in 1996).
The State Department issues a veritable alphabet soup of temporary work visas (A to S, with many varieties in each category) that benefit everyone from defecting Cuban baseball pitchers to Bulgarian folk dancers. But other than a program for au pairs, there is no temporary category exclusively for child care professionals.
 
Inexperienced Au Pairs
In fact, the au pair program is actually considered a cultural exchange program. Every year, the program provides about 11,000 foreign men and women, ages 18 to 26, with an opportunity to visit the United States for up to 12 months for an educational experience mixed with baby-sitting.
Even that popular source of child care now has a cloud over it after Louise Woodward, a 19-year-old British au pair, was convicted of killing her 8-month-old charge in Massachusetts last November.
"The au pair program brings to the U.S. often the youngest and least experienced child care providers," Mr. Maggio said. "It's children taking care of children."
Au pairs aside, there are very few child-care visas issued each year and, not surprisingly, they benefit mainly the well-off. American business executives, Government employees or foreign correspondents who work overseas but who are temporarily assigned to the United States are allowed to bring household help back with them.
In the second major category of immigrants -- those granted permanent residency, symbolized by the green card -- most of those admitted are sponsored by family members who live here legally or by employers who can demonstrate a lack of American workers to do the same jobs.
The outlook for those seeking green cards for child care is bleak. Congress has shrunk the category used to bring in household help to 5,000 positions a year, down from 27,000 a year a decade ago, extending the wait for applicants from years to decades. "If you start the green-card process for your baby sitter now, she'd be eligible to care legally for your grandchildren," Mr. Maggio said.
There is no specific green-card category for household help. Household workers, no matter how qualified, are typically granted green cards as "unskilled workers," a category that has sharply been reduced to accommodate family members of permanent residents and citizens, and to make room for more workers in what the Labor Department considers higher-skilled occupations.
"This is a hole in our visa system and a hole in our labor force," said Jeanne Butterfield, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association in Washington. "As the economy continues to be strong, people need to step back and realize this is something Congress needs to address."
There is a way to sponsor immigrant household workers and obtain green cards for them in a couple of years -- if you're rich. And the help has to be butlers, chefs or managers who supervise the staff who work at mansions or estates. "But for normal mortals, it's like anything else," Mr. Maggio said. "Getting legal household help has become like getting a Gulfstream IV jet."
And political forces on Capitol Hill have conspired against immigrants who might fill child-care roles. Democrats and Republicans are wary of championing new or expanded categories for foreign-born nannies, because they are perceived as benefiting mainly the upper classes.
Other immigrants who could help fill the child care gap are facing an uphill struggle. Under an agreement lawmakers brokered before Congress recessed last November, immigrants who qualify to become permanent residents have until Jan. 14 -- this Wednesday -- to apply in this country. After that date, they would have to apply for a permanent visa from home, risking being barred from re-entering this country for 3 to 10 years. If they stay here, they are illegal aliens and risk expulsion.
Advocates like Marcy Whitebook, director of the Center for the Child Care Workforce in Washington, want a more rational approach. "The question now is how to build a skilled and stable work force," she said. "People who make the best care-givers are those who see it as a career, rather than feeling it's the only thing they can do." And for many parents, immigrants may fit the bill.

HEADLINE: How Much Is Enough In Saving for Retirement?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Mr. Waddell correctly points out several distortions about the advice that Americans are receiving about their retirement planning. 
 With regard to the problem of excessive savings -- caused, in part, by guessing what future inflation rates will be -- a very simple and effective technique is available that could encourage more people to save by making their goals far more realistic and attainable.
When you consider your retirement accumulation using this technique, called "serial savings," inflation is factored in on a year-by-year basis. The amount of savings is increased each year by the rate of inflation.
Although the dollar amount increases every year, each year's investment will feel the same as a percentage of income.
 
MICHAEL A. KIRSH
Manhattan, Dec. 8
 
The writer is a financial and estate planner.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS

 BODY:

WHEELS
All Very Swiftian
No need to be shipwrecked on an exotic island to have your sense of scale demolished: a modern Gulliver need go no farther than Detroit. At the auto show last week, Volkswagen rolled out its new Beetle, which returns to the Lilliputian end of the United States market after a 21-year absence, while just a few booths away Ford unveiled its Brobdingnagian new F-250, a pickup whose hood ornament is further off the ground than Dr. Ruth Westheimer's chin. Car makers and critics braced for a struggle over the Yahooish way light trucks have of mangling most any car they hit broadside; manufacturers are quietly pushing to have new side-impact standards set no higher than in Europe, where, unlike here, big light trucks are scarce. But the news on the environmental front might please the Houyhnhnms, Swift's race of selfless, sagacious horses: the Big Three and several Japanese companies are talking seriously about making new high-technology, high-mileage cars in the next few model years, and Ford says it will voluntarily upgrade its light trucks to meet the much tougher emissions standards imposed on cars.
 
PRICES
Won't Be Undersold
Wholesale prices fell two-tenths of a percent in December and 1.2 percent for all of 1997, the Labor Department announced, and the "core" rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy numbers, fell for the first time in memory last year. Analysts are calling the inflation outlook the best in a generation, with even the labor markets -- tight, by historical standards -- on good behavior. Among economists, fretting about inflation is beginning to give way to fretting about possible deflation and the economic harm that would come.
 
JOBS
Won't Be Idle
The latest evidence from the astrophysics lab says the universe will keep expanding forever, a characteristic that the American economy and labor force seem to share these days. An unexpectedly plentiful 370,000 new jobs were created in December, but unemployment actually ticked up slightly because an even greater number of new workers entered the labor force, the Labor Department reported. A record 64.1 percent of American adults are now in the labor force, but it wasn't a salary bidding war that drew them in: Real hourly wages rose just 0.1 percent last month.
 
BUDGETS
You Mean There's Extra?
President Clinton said he planned to submit a balanced budget to Congress for fiscal 1999, three years ahead of schedule, and predicted a comparatively trivial Federal deficit of about $22 billion for 1998. Wall Street yawned, having long since predicted that the strong economy would erase the deficit, but political leaders dived gleefully into an unaccustomed task: arguing over what to do with spare money. The President is expected to discuss new initiatives on child care and the environment in his State of the Union message later in the month; House Speaker Newt Gingrich is talking about tax cuts. Consumers are way ahead of Washington this time: They unexpectedly reversed a three-year borrowing binge in November, reducing their total indebtedness by $4.2 billion, according to Treasury Department figures released last week.
 
ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I
Rescues Needing Rescues
It turns out not to be quite as simple as tossing out a multibillion-dollar life preserver and hauling in the rope. Financial rescue plans sponsored by the International Monetary Fund for several Asian countries showed signs of unraveling last week, largely because of the reluctance of the recipients to swim along quietly in the specified direction. Indonesia announced a new budget that blithely ignored the I.M.F.'s fiscal advice, and when the rescuers' displeasure became known, the country's currency and its stock market sank like stones. Dire rumors, panic buying and fears of political instability swept the country. And in Thailand, which was the first Asian domino to fall, I.M.F.-required austerity measures are already pinching too hard for the Prime Minister, who asked for an easing of the terms.
 
ASIAN TURMOIL, PART II
Devil in the Details
Compared with Southeast Asia, South Korea seems calm. Its streets are quiet, and the stock market has stanched its bleeding. But the particulars of the debt restructuring the country badly needs are proving thorny. After a week of squabbling, creditor banks were near agreement on a plan to give the country a breather of 30 to 90 days on loan payments. Still to be sorted out is what happens next: who will buy a proposed bond issue and what kinds of government guarantees they will get.
 
COMPUTERS
New Year, New Prospects
January is the time of year Steven Jobs likes to spring surprises: He introduced the Macintosh computer with a stunning "1984"-themed commercial that ran just once, during that year's Super Bowl; since then new products from Apple Computer have often been announced at the January MacWorld trade show. Mr. Jobs's show stopper this year was his announcement that Apple had managed a small profit in the first quarter of its 1998 fiscal year. The crisis is far from over for the company Mr. Jobs founded -- and is now trying to turn around after a three-year slide in other hands -- but Wall Street was delighted by the progress so far, pushing Apple's stock up 20 percent.
 
TELECOMMUNICATIONS
Buying Local
Why invent what you can buy instead? SBC Communications, which bought Pacific Telesis in 1996 in the first merger among the Baby Bells, has announced a deal to acquire Connecticut's phone company, Southern New England Telephone, one of the few remaining sizable independents, for $4.4 billion. One lure: S.N.E.T. has regulatory permission to sell long-distance service to its local customers, a privilege so far denied to SBC and its former Bell siblings. And AT&T was attracted by a 26-state local franchise when it agreed last week to buy Teleport Communications for $11.3 billion in stock. The deal would spare AT&T the aggravation and cost of building its own new local service from scratch, and had been expected for months.

HEADLINE: Detroit Turns a Corner

 BODY:
For anyone worried about global warming, last week's most heartening news came from an unlikely source -- the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. All three auto makers announced that they were nearing production of marketable cars that will rely less on gas-burning engines and more on exotic power sources like fuel cells. Because conventional engines account for one-third of America's output of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas, this was a revelation of potentially enormous significance.
It was also, in a way, amusing, or so it must have seemed to President Clinton. Mr. Clinton has placed a heavy bet on the proposition that American technological know-how can counter the global warming threat at relatively low cost. For this he has been soundly bashed by the auto makers, the producers of coal and oil and other industries that spent millions of dollars last year belittling the threat of global warming and warning that any serious effort to fight it, like the treaty Mr. Clinton agreed to in Kyoto, Japan, would bankrupt the American economy. Yet here were some of the President's fiercest critics tripping over one another to tout their "green" cars and, in the process, suggesting that Mr. Clinton's faith in technology may not be misplaced. 
 Al Gore could also be forgiven a smile. In his 1992 book, "Earth in the Balance," the Vice President called for "eliminating" the internal combustion engine in the next 25 years -- a comment that reinforced his reputation in some circles as a dangerous thinker. Yet right there at the auto show, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, John Smith, stated flatly that "no car company will be able to thrive in the 21st century if it relies solely on internal combustion engines." To Detroit-watchers, this seemed an epiphany.
To anyone who has followed the big environmental struggles of the past quarter-century, Detroit's change of tune fit neatly into a familiar historical pattern. There has always been a big gap between industrial leaders who say they cannot do something and their engineers, who usually figure out a way to do it. Before Congress passed the 1970 Clean Air Act, Detroit argued that significant pollution reductions would be utterly impractical or prohibitively expensive. Then along came the catalytic converter that, at modest cost, eventually cut harmful tailpipe emissions by 95 percent. Likewise, the oil companies predicted economic doom when Congress mandated cleaner fuels in 1990. Their chemists, however, have since managed to produce such fuels without disturbing profits.
As the record suggests, American industry is not known for spontaneous acts of environmental virtue. But it will respond to timely regulation and commercial realities. One such reality is that Japan is moving quickly to develop low-emission cars. The Japanese caught Detroit flat-footed with their small cars during the oil-price shocks in the 1970's, and Detroit clearly does not wish to be left behind again. In this case, the Federal Government has become an active partner rather than a regulatory adversary. Many of the latest innovations have emerged from the Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles, into which Washington has poured nearly $400 million over the last four years.
One question now is whether the auto makers will continue to oppose the Kyoto treaty. The comment by G.M.'s Mr. Smith suggests that Detroit is beginning to see itself as a critical part of the eventual solution to global warming. If true, that would be the most hopeful news of all from the automobile show.

HEADLINE: Indonesia's Downward Spiral

 BODY:
Despite a generous international bailout last year, Indonesia is sinking deeper into financial chaos and political paralysis. This weekend, emissaries from the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund are traveling to Jakarta for urgent meetings on the crisis. They should insist that Indonesia fulfill its pledges to carry out tough economic reforms. Beyond that, they need to make clear that the markets there have collapsed as much from concern over President Suharto's corrupt brand of crony capitalism as from other underlying ailments.
Mr. Suharto has long been warned that a closed economic and political system must be opened up. Indonesia's continued prosperity provided an excuse for not doing so. Even last week, with the economy in crisis, Mr. Suharto announced a budget with wildly unrealistic projections and took several other steps that backed away from earlier promises of fiscal and monetary austerity. If he does not abandon his complacent approach, he risks a cutoff of the vital funding from overseas needed to keep Indonesia solvent. 
 Indonesia has important strengths, including its ability to export manufactured goods and oil. The current crisis arose as international lenders pumped money into its banking and corporate system, thinking that prosperity would last forever. Once the Indonesian currency started dropping, the loans could not easily be repaid. Last week, the currency all but collapsed, throwing hundreds of banks and companies into bankruptcy. Citizens have begun hoarding food. Fears of unemployment and social unrest are spreading. Some Indonesians even fear possible intervention by the army. For the first time, there is open talk that President Suharto, in power for 32 years, should retire.
There is a danger in Indonesia of confusing the country's interests with Mr. Suharto's. Of course, unemployment, riots and political instability would not benefit anyone. The I.M.F. must be careful not to impose such strict measures that the country is thrown into a ruinous collapse.
But there must be no accommodation for the Suharto family's financial interests, which Mr. Suharto has so far shielded. Import monopolies benefiting companies tied to the Suharto family have been retained. Although 16 insolvent banks were closed, one of the President's sons was allowed to reopen his own bank under a different name. Other needless projects, including an unnecessary power plant on Java, are going forward because of their connections to the Suharto family.
The importance of taking vigorous steps to defend Indonesia's currency and to insure the repayment of loans goes far beyond Indonesia itself. A default by Indonesia could spread throughout the region and, from there, jolt the banking systems of Japan, Europe and the United States. As for Mr. Suharto, he increasingly seems more of an impediment to reform. Until recently, he had been expected to be easily reappointed in a few months to another term by his loyal National Assembly. Instead of clinging to power in a nation now mired in debt, Mr. Suharto may well need to decide that the best thing he can do for his country is to step aside. So far, he has shown no sign that he is prepared to put Indonesia's future ahead of his own.

HEADLINE: Ulster Is Downcast as New Violence Clouds Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The people of Northern Ireland, both the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority, say they fear that after four months of relative calm the sectarian killing here is on the verge of erupting again.
Guerrilla warfare involving the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republican Army, several Protestant paramilitary groups and the British Army has left more than 3,200 people dead in the last 29 years. 
 But last September optimism rose as the main political parties here and the British and Irish Republic Governments finally sat down at the same table to negotiate a peaceful settlement.
The army went back to the barracks, leaving the Royal Ulster Constabulary alone to patrol the streets of Belfast and other cities. At the peace table, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, spoke for British withdrawal from the province while Protestants insisted that it remain British.
British rule has been the crux of the conflict through this century, but now the parties were talking, not shooting. Hopes that the war was really over seemed to rise.
But a recent surge of sectarian violence and a Protestant threat to undermine the talks, which are to resume in Belfast on Monday, has put the army and huge Saxon armored vehicles back on the street.
The people of West Belfast, where much of the killing has taken place over the years, say that they hope it will not happen, but that they expect more bombs and shootings, even as Mo Mowlam, the Northern Ireland Secretary, appeared on Friday to have persuaded Protestant paramilitary groups not to boycott the talks.
Without the participation of the Protestant parties allied to guerrilla fighters, there is not likely to be any significant progress in the negotiations.
"Recent acts of sectarian violence have once again left the people of Northern Ireland very fearful for the future," Ms. Mowlam, the highest-ranking official in the British province, said she told the Protestant prisoners in the Maze prison on Friday.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the most prominent Irish-American politician in Irish eyes, and long an opponent of the violence of the I.R.A. and Protestant guerrillas, reflected the public fear, speaking in Londonderry on Friday night before coming to Belfast today on his first visit to Northern Ireland.
In remarks that received prominent coverage on television and on the front page of newspapers here, he said: "There are some who seek to wreck the peace process. They are blinded by fear of a future they cannot imagine, a future in which respect for differences is a healing and unifying force.
"They are driven by an anger that holds no respect for life, even for the lives of children."
New disputes and stalemates, many people say, will stall the talks. Splinter paramilitary groups, which are not taking part in the talks and are not bound by cease-fires called by larger groups, will continue to use violence in an attempt to end the entire peace effort as the main parties argue over who is ultimately responsible for the new attacks.
"I think it's all going to blow up again," said Aidan Darragh, 31, the owner of a newspaper and candy shop on Andersonstown Road in the Catholic part of West Belfast. "It'll break into total mayhem."
Maureen McCorry, 62, a Catholic housewife, said, "I can't see any answer but civil war." She said her brother, a cabdriver, had once been kidnapped and threatened at gunpoint by Protestant paramilitaries.
On the Shankill Road, an adjacent Protestant area, the mood was the same.
A few yards from where an I.R.A. bomb killed nine Protestants in 1993, Eleanor Toal, 19, who is unemployed, said, "I think it's going to break up in violence again."
Her friend, June McNeill, 32, a kitchen assistant, agreed. "Eighty percent of Protestants think it will blow up," she said.
Mark Armstrong, 26, pastor of the Elim Pentecostal Church on the Shankill Road, said his group fostered optimism and love. "But if the trouble does escalate, we're ready," he said. "We believe that God's going to do a mighty work and change lives here in this road."
The politicians involved in the formal talks seem aware of the pessimism.
"My heart is breaking," said Monica McWilliams, 42, a leader of the Northern Ireland Women's Coalition, a Catholic and a participant in the formal talks. "I will never forgive myself if this blows apart. I am close to despair, close to tears. We're almost within reach of a settlement but once again I find I'm standing on the brink, emotionally and intellectually."
In the interviews in West Belfast, the intolerance and mistrust between Catholics and Protestants that has fueled the guerrilla warfare surfaced quickly, more evident now than when there was a lull in the violence.
Mrs. McCorry, the Catholic housewife, said: "The Protestants don't want to be bothered with Catholics. They think Catholics are rubbish. They don't want us to have an equal share. I'm not an extreme person, but since the I.R.A. started bombing all over the place, suddenly Catholics started to get jobs they never had before. It was the bombing that made the British Government open up its ears. Before, we were knocking at the window with a sponge."
"It's terrible to say," she added, "that people have to be killed for the Government to hear what we're talking about. It used to be that everyone who came to my house, the milkman, the bread man, the oil man, the coal man, was Protestant. Now I have a Catholic milk, bread and oil man."
Ms. McNeill, the Protestant kitchen worker, said of Catholics: "Everything is going their way. They're living in lovely homes, built by the Government -- we're living in dumps."
"Half of them are running about getting the dole," she said, referring to public housing and financial aid for Catholics, who have double the unemployment rate of Protestants in the province. "Even their dole is bigger than ours."
The new violence began two weeks ago when a Protestant paramilitary leader, Billy Wright of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, was shot dead in a prison yard by inmates belonging to the Irish National Liberation Army, a group that had splintered from the I.R.A. Protestant gunmen, members of Mr. Wright's group, then retaliated by killing two Catholic men in Belfast.
Simultaneously, Protestant prisoners at the Maze, outside Belfast, began to tell their political leaders that their interests were being ignored by the British and Irish Governments, the talks' sponsors.
In December, they noted, the Irish Government granted early release to nine I.R.A. men serving time for terrorist crimes. The Protestants made it clear they too wanted to be released early and urged their political leaders, of the Ulster Democratic and Progressive Unionist parties, to consider boycotting the formal peace talks that are to resume here on Monday under the chairmanship of George J. Mitchell, the former United States Senator.
Ms. McWilliams said she still had hope for the formal peace talks.
"It's a ship going into gale force winds," she said. "But if we keep a calm and steady hand on the wheel and all hands on deck then we're going to make our way through the storm. But storms are naturally caused and our storms are man-made."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS AIR FARES CLIMB, PROMPTING CALLS FOR REMEDY

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Business travelers are continuing to pay increasingly higher air fares, with the price of a domestic round-trip coach ticket on at least one route surpassing $2,000 for the first time.
Over all, air fares for business travelers have climbed nearly 40 percent in the last two years, according to American Express Travel. And while there appears to be no immediate end in sight to the increases, they have prompted some members of Congress to take a new look at reining in the airline industry. 
 The extent of these higher business air fares can be seen on the Boston-to-Los Angeles route, where an unrestricted round-trip ticket bought on the day of flight costs $2,004 on any of eight major airlines -- even though a leisure traveler in the next seat, who booked well in advance, might pay as little as $238 for a nonrefundable ticket.
Several other routes are flirting with the $2,000 threshold, including New York to Los Angeles, which now costs $1,836 for an unrestricted round-trip coach ticket.
American Express predicts that business fares will rise an additional 6 percent this year. And corporate efforts to control those costs have shown little success. Last week, a group supported by 58 companies that was the most potent force pressing the airlines to hold down ticket prices suspended its operations in frustration after four years.
Unlike leisure travelers who can buy discounted tickets weeks in advance, many business travelers need to make trips on short notice and without restrictions on flight changes and refunds. Moreover, the planes have become more crowded than they have been in years, making seats available at the last minute scarcer and more expensive.
The rising business fares have led to a growing chorus of complaints about airline deregulation and have increased pressure on the Clinton Administration and Congress to take action. Many politicians blame high air fares for hampering economic growth in their districts.
"I know economically it has hurt us," said Representative Louise Slaughter, Democrat of New York, who represents the Rochester area and plans to introduce the Airline Competition and Lower Fares Act in the coming session.
The new bill will join four similar ones that have already been introduced by, among others, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, and Representative John J. Duncan, the Tennessee Republican who is chairman of the House Aviation Subcommittee.
The major airlines strongly oppose any Government action, arguing that more people are flying at lower fares than ever before. Airline executives say that businesses and politicians did not offer to help them in the early 1990's, when they lost $13 billion. Now that the economy is strong and passenger traffic is at record levels, they believe they should be able to reap the benefits.
Executives also point out that even though airlines are expected to make record profits for the third consecutive year in 1998, their profit margins still lag behind those of many other industries.
Business travelers feel particularly abused because they account for more than half of airline revenue. For in the through-the-looking-glass world of airline pricing, the fares paid by leisure travelers, who book as long as a month in advance and stay over a weekend night, have in many cases declined, while last-minute fully refundable fares, which are most often paid by business travelers, are skyrocketing.
"The carriers always say that the business traveler is inelastic," said Peter M. Buchheit, director of travel and meeting services for the Black & Decker Corporation, which spent $18 million on air tickets for its American employees last year. "We need to travel so we will pay whatever it costs. But it has reached a point where we can't pay it anymore."
The burden of high fares is even greater on small companies. John W. Galbraith, president of Twin Advertising, a small company based in Rochester that had $2 million in billings last year, said he was thinking about dropping clients outside the city because the high cost of visiting them cancels out the profit he makes from having their business.
"Basically, what the airlines have done to companies like ours is kept us from growing," he said.
The airlines say the higher business fares reflect the higher level of service that business passengers expect. They demand a choice of multiple flights to the same place each day and the convenience of being able to walk on a plane at the last minute -- both of which are expensive.
"We could sell out planes 21 days in advance and that would be it," said Tony Molinaro, a spokesman for United Airlines. "But businessmen say, 'I can't plan my business schedule 21 days in advance.' "
As for the $2,000 fare between Boston and Los Angeles, he said that only a small fraction of passengers would pay that amount because so many discounted fares are available.
But the fact remains that business fares have risen drastically at a time when overall inflation is at a record low. American Express Travel calculated that the average coach business fare between 215 pairs of cities in November, the latest figure available, was $890 round trip, the highest level since the company began tracking fares in 1992.
"Frustration is at an all-time high," said Eric Altschul, a vice president at American Express Consulting Services, speaking of large corporations. "Because it is a cost that they can't control."
So far, efforts by businesses to rein in the airlines have been unsuccessful. Nearly four years ago, Kevin Mitchell, a former travel manager at the Cigna Corporation, formed a group called the Business Travel Contractors Corporation. The idea was to use the leverage of corporate purchasing power to persuade the airlines to simplify their fare structures and guarantee the price of tickets over the term of a contract.
Mr. Mitchell managed to get the backing of 58 companies, including Chrysler, Black & Decker and Procter & Gamble, which spend a total of $2 billion a year on travel. But he could not persuade the airlines to make a deal. Instead, the big carriers agreed to some demands and cut side deals with companies.
Last week, he gave up. "Frankly, a lot of corporations were unwilling to jump on until we could get one of the major carriers," he said.
Over the last year, Mr. Mitchell and other advocates became increasingly convinced that the answer to higher ticket prices was more competition, and he focused more on lobbying in Washington.
The bills pending in Congress seek to create more landing and takeoff opportunities at crowded airports in Chicago, New York and Washington and to use the power of the Department of Transportation to discourage the major carriers from driving low-cost challengers out of business.
The Clinton Administration is already preparing a set of guidelines due out soon that would define what incumbent carriers can do when competing with smaller rivals.
"We have had the statutory authority for 19 years since deregulation to move against airlines for unfair competition but have never done so," said Patrick V. Murphy, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Transportation.
But few believe that much will change until the economy cools or the airlines buy so many new airplanes that there is a glut of seats as there was in the early 1990's.
"The market has a voice of its own," said Kevin C. Murphy, an airline industry analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover. "The businesses are complaining, but they are still buying the tickets."
