HEADLINE: Jack Conway, 80, Leader in War on Poverty

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Jack T. Conway, who as an official of the Johnson Administration worked to establish Head Start and several other Great Society programs, died on Tuesday morning at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 80.
The cause was respiratory failure, his family said. 
 A longtime labor worker, Mr. Conway took a leave of absence from his job at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in 1965 to head President Lyndon B. Johnson's Community Action Program, an initiative intended to distribute grants to more than 250 communities as part of the Administration's War on Poverty. The Community Action Program was a part of the Office of Economic Opportunity, the agency primarily responsible for coordinating the anti-poverty drive.
As the program's director, Mr. Conway helped to arrange financing for the Head Start and Job Corps programs across the country. At that time, Head Start was intended to assist preschool children from low-income families. But Mr. Conway later resigned, frustrated by what he saw as political battles between liberals and conservatives in Congress over the programs. The programs came under attack from both sides, who saw them either as promoting political patronage or as doing little of actual benefit to the poor.
Mr. Conway came to Washington in 1960 as the deputy administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency in President John F. Kennedy's Administration. While there, he helped to draft the Omnibus Housing Act of 1961, which established the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
From 1970 to 1975, Mr. Conway was the first president of Common Cause. Among the group's priorities were public opposition to the war in Vietnam and campaign finance reform. Mr. Conway is credited with steering the group through a time of membership and budget difficulties.
Afterward, Mr. Conway was the executive director of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. He later served as the senior vice president of the United Way of America.
An active member of the Democratic Party, Mr. Conway was chairman of the national committee of Americans for Democratic Action in 1968, when the group was in a contentious debate over supporting the Presidential campaign of either Mr. Johnson or Eugene J. McCarthy.
Mr. Conway also worked with a number of nonprofit organizations to improve social conditions in cities.
It was while working for a Buick aircraft engine plant near Chicago in the 1940's that Mr. Conway first became active in the labor movement. He organized workers on behalf of the United Automobile Workers and served as chairman of its bargaining committee.
He also served as an international representative for the United Automobile Workers.
A native of Detroit, Mr. Conway received a bachelor's degree in sociology from the University of Chicago.
He is survived by his wife, LuVerne Conway of Sarasota; three children, Thomas B. Conway of Washington, Jan C. Shapin of Newport, R.I., and Cynthia L. Conway of Sarasota; five grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.

Traffickers in Sex Victimizing Slavic Women
Across the world, the selling of naive and desperate young women into sexual bondage has become one of the fastest-growing criminal enterprises. Since the fall of Communism, experts say, women from Russia and Ukraine are being particularly victimized. "Can people really buy and sell women and get away with it?" asked one dismayed young woman. 1
 
Pressure on Suharto Grows
Indonesia's leading opposition figure, Megawati Sukarnoputri, called on President Suharto to step down when his term ends in March and said she was ready to succeed him. As the nation's economic problems reached crisis proportions, pressure grew from other quarters, too, for Mr. Suharto to end his 32-year rule. 8 

Quake at the Great Wall

Interest Groups to Play Big Role in Campaigns
From the left and from the right, so many independent interest groups are poised to spend large sums on advertising to influence elections this year that Republicans and Democrats alike fear the candidates may find themselves playing bit parts in their own campaigns. The first Congressional campaign of 1998, in Santa Barbara, Calif., offers a preview. 1
 
From Pinnacle to the Brink
With President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore virtually cleared of wrongdoing in the long-running campaign finance imbroglio, Secretary of Interior Bruce Babbitt remains the highest-ranking political figure most at risk from the continuing campaign finance investigation. The irony of it all is not lost on him. 1
 
Ambiguity of Mental Fitness
The decision by the judge in the Unabom trial to order a mental competency evaluation of the defendant, Theodore J. Kaczynski, begins a complex process in which there are few widely agreed upon standards. More than 25,000 evaluations are ordered by the courts each year in the United States. But as Mr. Kaczynski's case has shown, the issues of how and when to carry them out and what it means to be competent to stand trial remain unclear at best, mental health experts said. 1
 
Why Nichols Jury Deadlocked
In vote after vote, a majority of jurors raised their hands to sentence Terry L. Nichols to death, but they were blocked by a few holdouts, according to two jurors in the second Oklahoma bombing trial. Leading the opposition to the death penalty was the jury's forewoman. 14

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Choose One: Koufax or Sutton?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The general managers were given a choice. They could have either of two pitchers, and they could make their selection knowing what the pitchers would do in their careers. One pitcher would pitch for 12 years, having a poor-to-mediocre first six years, then a spectacularly good last six years. The other would pitch for 23 years and win 324 games.
The general managers were asked to choose either Sandy Koufax or Don Sutton. 
 One of the first general managers responding to the question opted for Koufax and predicted that his colleagues would clearly do the same. But they did not. As intriguing as they all found the exercise, the outcome was just as intriguing because the general managers were clearly divided. Eight selected Koufax, six chose Sutton and two said they could not decide.
The exercise stemmed from Sutton's election to the Hall of Fame last week and the continued questioning of his credentials. Yes, Sutton's critics said, he had been the only eligible 300-game winner not in the Hall, but he amassed that total only because he pitched so long. Good health and durability, they argued, do not equal Hall of Fame caliber talent.
But the general managers thought otherwise. Those who chose Sutton generally said pitching is so fragile that it would be difficult to turn down the chance to get a pitcher who could last 23 years and win consistently, if not spectacularly.
"When you look at tying up a pitcher to a long-term contract," Gerry Hunsicker of the Houston Astros said, "one of the primary issues is how many innings is he going to give you and is he durable as opposed to wins. So many things affect wins -- run support, luck to a degree, defense, a lot of things. If you know a guy can give you 250 innings a year, year in and year out, that's the most important thing."
Sutton pitched more than 200 innings in each of his first 15 seasons and 20 of his 23. He had an eight-year stretch during which he exceeded 250 innings. He averaged 33 starts a season and made 34 starts in each of the first three seasons he pitched after his 40th birthday.
Those who opted for Koufax, however, could not avoid his gate appeal and the seduction of his last six seasons, in which he compiled a phenomenal 129-47 record (.733 winning percentage) and a 2.19 earned run average.
"I want the spectacular when you get there," Jim Bowden of the Cincinnati Reds said. "When you win pennants, you win with dominating guys. When you have a guy who wins 20, 25 games for six straight years, it gives your club a chance to win. I'm going to take the most dominating pitcher in baseball because there aren't that many of them."
Doug Melvin of the Texas Rangers cited the attraction that Koufax was and would be if he were dominating teams today.
"In this day and age we've become more entertainment oriented," he said. "I think the spectacular season and the real star status would stand out in today's game. It probably would be a moneymaker."
Ron Schueler of the Chicago White Sox said he would take Koufax "because you probably would have an extra 10,000 people per game that he pitches."
The response from Dave Dombrowski of the Florida Marlins epitomized the difficulty many of the general managers had in making their choices.
"I would love to have had Sandy Koufax in his good years," Dombrowski said. "I'd like to have that guy first of all. Then I'd take the guy who wins 324 games."
But that's taking the easy way out, and that was not one of the choices.
"When you say Sandy Koufax you think of the best pitcher over a time period there ever was," Dombrowski said. "So it's hard to say you wouldn't want Sandy Koufax. But developing him for six years would be a hard chore. I'd rather be getting some return in the beginning. But if I knew I had good starters or the time to develop him properly and you knew you would get those six years, that would be tough to turn down."
Sutton was a consistent pitcher day in and day out, the Marlins' executive added, but he averaged 14 victories a year, not enough to lead a team to a pennant. "I would take the six years of superb because I can't find those guys," Dombrowski concluded. "It gives me a chance to win six straight years."
Pat Gillick of the Baltimore Orioles echoed that reasoning.
"When you have an opportunity to win a pennant, you have to take the opportunity," he said. "With a .733 winning percentage, there's a darn good chance I could win pennants in those six years that Koufax had that record."
Ed Lynch, too, saw the overriding factor as the chance to win.
"There is definitely an attraction toward a pitcher that exhibits consistency for long periods of time," the Chicago Cubs' general manager said. "But the brass ring is the ultimate prize. You could compete for it several times with Sutton, but to get to the top of the baseball universe, Sandy Koufax is more attractive."
And Randy Smith of the Detroit Tigers said: "I'd take the dominating guy. I'd take the ace of the staff rather than the solid contributor."
The general managers who went with Sutton did not summarily dismiss Koufax. But as Bob Watson of the Yankees said: "Sitting in a chair where you'd like to have consistency and longevity, Don Sutton definitely has done that. Here's a solid starter for you. He was a guy you could count on."
Health and durability, Billy Beane of the Oakland Athletics said, come right behind statistical performance, and that is why he chose Sutton.
"If I can have a guy for 23 years," he added, "it's going to help me keep my job. The hardest thing is predictability. When we go into an off season, we project what the next season is going to be for the guy. The easier we can attach a statistical number to a pitcher, the more we can adjust to our strengths or weaknesses."
Bill Bavasi of the Anaheim Angels said he wanted the pitcher who had decent early years. "It's tough to carry a guy," he said.
Woody Woodward of the Seattle Mariners offered a similar view. "I'll take the guy who wins right out of the chute," he said. "I would take Sutton because he could help me win right now."
Terry Ryan of the Minnesota Twins put it simply. "Winning is the name of the game," he said, "and Sutton won."
Steve Phillips of the Mets offered an even simpler reason for his selection. He said he would take Koufax anyway, but remarked: "My owner is good friends with Koufax. I'll pick Koufax."
Fred Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, and Koufax were teammates on their high school baseball team in Brooklyn.
 
300 Victories Hard to Do
The last pitcher to reach 300 victories was Nolan Ryan. He did it in 1990, becoming the sixth pitcher in a nine-season span to get there. Before that stretch, 19 seasons had gone by without a new 300-game winner. Some baseball people wonder if there will ever be another.
Roger Clemens leads active pitchers with 213 victories, followed by Dennis Eckersley with 193, Greg Maddux with 184, Jimmy Key with 180, Orel Hershiser with 179 and Dwight Gooden with 177.
Clemens could have four seasons like the last one, when he won 21 games, and still be three victories shy at 39. That kind of performance would virtually insure him of reaching 300, but no one expects him to reel off four such terrific seasons.
Maddux, who will turn 32 two weeks into next season, would seem to have the most realistic chance of getting there, but he would need six or seven seasons as productive as his past 10, during which he averaged 17.6 victories a season. He is guaranteed $57.5 million for the next five years. Will he have the economic or competitive incentive after that term to keep going? If not, maybe the skeptics will be right.
 
28 Going on 32
Orlando Hernandez, whose adventures as a defector have been well chronicled the past two weeks, has traveled from Cuba to the Bahamas to Costa Rica, but he still cannot shake his past. The pitcher, half brother of the Marlins' Livan Hernandez, says he is 28 years old. However, a baseball card that predated Hernandez's adventures by four years said he was born on Nov. 11, 1965. That would make him 32.

HEADLINE: Money-Losing Capital OTB Is Accused of Abuses in Spending

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Investigators at the New York Racing and Wagering Board say alleged abuses by the president of the Capital Off-Track Betting Corporation and a lack of oversight by its board of directors show that Capital OTB was mismanaged.
With Davis Etkin as president, Capital OTB was the only offtrack betting corporation of the five in the state to lose money for four years in a row. 
 State auditors released a 36-page summary today of what they found at the company. It cited Mr. Etkin's eight cellular phones and $750,000 in complimentary meals for his family and friends.
Besides the allegations of outright abuses, the report alleged faulty fiscal policy, the lack of an independent auditor and the lack of proper oversight by Capital OTB's directors.
It was the second report critical of Mr. Etkin in as many days. On Thursday, an Albany County task force recommended that Mr. Etkin be dismissed.
Both reports conclude that taxpayers in the 17 counties covered by Capital OTB could have enjoyed millions of dollars in tax breaks if Capital OTB's directors had been more vigilant in overseeing Mr. Etkin. He has denied the allegations.
"Every dime we spend is business-related," Mr. Etkin said on Thursday. "Nobody has ever gone on a trip unless it was to a conference of some sort."
He said Capital OTB's revenue was comparatively low because its region was a "poor area" that was large and costly to manage.
But today's report said that "interviews and review of corporate documents identified a significant lack of fiscal oversight by Capital's management and board of directors."
Michael Hoblock, chairman of the racing board, said he was considering fining the Capital OTB directors up to $5,000 each and bringing civil lawsuits to recover misspent money.
Under Mr. Etkin, the management team spent more than $4 million over the last seven years on activities that had nothing to do with off-track betting, including tennis tournaments and tennis sponsorships, the racing board's report concluded.
"This money should have been forwarded to the localities in the form of net operating profits, which would have allowed elected local officials to spend it on property tax reductions or other county programs," the report said.
From 1992 to 1996, Capital OTB incurred losses of nearly $3 million, including a deficit of $510,710 in 1996. It was the only offtrack betting corporation in the state to report a loss that year.
The next-lowest performing offtrack betting corporation that year was the Suffolk County OTB, which made a profit of more than $2.2 million.
Most of the $750,000 in complimentary meals were taken by the Etkin family at the OTB-operated Tele-Theatre in Albany, when boxing matches were being simulcast there. For example, a March 17, 1996, a check for more than $800 was "comped" at the Tele-Theatre for the Etkin family.
Mr. Etkin is paid $219,000 a year as chairman and chief executive of Capital OTB.
Investigators with the office of the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, are going over the racing board's report, but it is too early to say whether a case against Mr. Etkin will be developed from it, said Joe Mahoney, a spokesman for Mr. Vacco.
In September, Mr. Vacco obtained a guilty plea from Julie Frankel, a bookkeeper at an OTB-operated club, for embezzling $85,514.
Based in Schenectady, Capital OTB operates 54 betting parlors in a 17-county area encompassing all of northeastern New York that stretches from south of Albany to the Canadian border and from the Rome/Utica area to the Massachusetts border.

HEADLINE: January 4-10;
Indonesia's Crisis Deepens

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

 BODY:
Just when Washington thought it had contained the Asian contagion in Korea, it erupted again -- this time back in Indonesia. President Suharto's Government promised wide reforms when the International Monetary Fund came in with an economic bailout package in October. But Indonesia has now backtracked on those commitments, especially rules that would impinge on the multibillion-dollar Suharto family enterprises. All week the Indonesian currency fell like a rock, and residents of Jakarta began to hoard food. 
 President Clinton called Mr. Suharto to say he had to comply with the I.M.F. and he sent high American officials to Indonesia to deliver the message personally. But the big issue was whether Mr. Suharto will stay in power or be pushed out by his disillusioned countrymen. DAVID E. SANGER

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

In Spite of El Nino
The warming effects of El Nino notwithstanding, the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation has released a full schedule of cross-country skiing and outdoor skating for this winter.
Cross-country skiing is permitted every day in daylight hours at the following parks, golf courses and nature centers: Blue Mountain Reservation in Peekskill, Croton Gorge in Cortlandt, Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson, Kitchawan Preserve in Yorktown, Lasdon Park and Aboretum in Somers, Mohansic Golf Course in Yorktown Heights, Mountain Lake Parks in North Salem, Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, Cranberry Lake Preserve in North White Plains, Maple Moor Golf Course and Saxon Woods Park in White Plains, Edith G. Read Natural Park and Wildlife Sanctuary and Marshlands Conservancy in Rye, Saxon Woods Golf Course in Scarsdale and Dunwoodie Golf Course, Lenoir Preserve, Sprain Lake Golf Course and Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers. 
 When a white flag with a green ball flies (indicating safe conditions) at the following locations, skating will be permitted: Blue Mountain Reservation in Peekskill, Bronxville Lake, Crestwood Lake in Yonkers and Hartsdale Pond along the Bronx River Parkway, Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla, Mountain Lakes Park in North Salem, Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers, Twin Lakes in Eastchester, Wampus Pond in Armonk and Willson's Woods Park in Mount Vernon.
To check conditions, call the Parks Department's information line at 242-7275 on weekdays. On weekends, call each park directly.
 
Taxpayer Report, Part 2
The Westchester 2000 Research Center, a public-private organization, has released the second volume of "Taxpayers' Report to the Taxpayers." The report on fiscal trends says governments and school districts have made progress in bringing operating costs under control. But because property assessments are eroding and outside aid is shrinking, officials will have to intensify efforts to maintain the gains.
"Real savings lie in cutting down on excessive governments and school districts," said Sal J. Prezioso, the executive director of Westchester 2000. He added that further personnel and organizational changes would be necessary to lower the cost of operations to satisfy taxpayers. The research center's latest report is an update of its 1994 "Governments at the Crossroads" report.
On a positive note, the new report, entitled "Current Fiscal Trends of Westchester Governments and School Districts," said that even though public school enrollments are on the rise, school district costs per pupil have been increasing at a slower rate. But it also said that all levels of government, including school districts, have taken on increasing amounts of public debt.
The report added that despite growth in residential property values, the total assessed value of all properties, including business properties, has been eroding since 1988, and unless the county is able to attract new businesses to help offset further declines, the tax burden on residents will increase.
Copies of the 40-page report will be available on Thursday at libraries, town and village halls and school district offices and Room 901, County Office Building, 148 Martine Avenue, White Plains. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: SIGNOFF;
History Reveals Itself in Strange Ways

BYLINE: By ANDREA HIGBIE 

 BODY:
SO, what'll it be: Must See TV or the History Channel? For more and more people, this is not a silly question.
"We want to really bring history -- which some people think is dry and boring -- to a larger number of people," says Charlie Maday, vice president for historical programming at the History Channel. "We want to make it exciting for them." 
Apparently, the idea is working. The channel, which is owned by A&E, has swept up 43 million subscribers since it began three years ago this month.
Mr. Maday, who is 52, says the channel draws "educated, curious, upscale adults," 35 to 54 years old, and more men than women. It operates 24 hours a day, presenting historical documentaries, movies and mini-series.
Productions are commissioned by the channel, acquired by it, are created with other networks or are part of the in-house library. Two World War II accounts, "Hitler's Henchmen" and "Blood and Iron," were created with Z.D.F. and Krossfire respectively.
"We look for an angle that hasn't been told before," Mr. Maday says. "It's not the same old rehash."
"We told about the last mass execution in the United States," he says of the hanging of seven German prisoners of war at the military prison in Fort Leavenworth, Kan., in August 1945. Commissioned by A&E and produced with Towers, "The Last Mass Execution" is a tale of death camps, military intelligence and lack of same, a defense lawyer with no legal training and a Presidential decision possibly based on re-election prospects. "We broke the story," Mr. Maday says. "It's history revealed."
Even in movie presentations, events are given a historical perspective. When the channel presents the 1996 HBO film "Gotti," starring Armand Assante as John Gotti, boss of the Gambino crime family, next Sunday, it will be with Sander Vanocur interviewing Jerry Capeci, co-author of "Gotti: Rise and Fall."
Not much goes uncommented on. "The Fifties," a series shown on New Year's Day and being rerun in April, presents the decade in the context of the events that led to it and followed, and includes interviews with David Halberstam, author of "The Fifties" (1994). "When the Century Was Young," an offering eventually to be rebroadcast, looks back even further, to colonial empires and World War I, to changing economies, fashions and etiquette.
"We're not interested in nostalgia for nostalgia's sake," Mr. Maday says. "Nostalgia has mostly an emotional appeal, but history touches upon the events and the ideas to make it really relevant. "The Big House," produced by Greystone Communications and scheduled for later this month, is a four-part mini-series about the four most notorious prisons in United States history: Eastern State Penitentiary, Sing Sing, Alcatraz (built to house the "worst of the worst") and Leavenworth. (Did you know that the Birdman of Alcatraz served most of his time, for murder, at Leavenworth?) Arrogance and miscalculation are the lessons of a documentary produced with the BBC titled "The Man Who Wanted to Start World War III." (It was Gen. Curtis E. LeMay.)
"There's nothing we wouldn't show," Mr. Maday says. Indeed. This includes this week's "Abominable Snowman" and "Dragons," produced by Filmroos for the channel's "In Search of History" series, as well as "The Great Depression," with Mario Cuomo, the former Governor of New York, as the host.
The subjects do tend toward the heavy side, but the channel is certainly fun-loving. A program called "Frankenstein," running on Tuesday, examines Mary Shelley's sources of inspiration; there are shows on big buildings, submarines, battleships and the Crown Jewels.
"It's heavy and light," Joe La Polla, director of scheduling for acquisitions, says of the programming. "We're not all about prisons and the history of Rome. We'll have a light look at highway hangouts and a serious look at the Ku Klux Klan."
Because history is omnipresent (though "not always pleasant," as Mr. Maday notes), pretty much any topic is up for grabs. So, what will it be? Must See TV or Must See History?

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Toppling Apartheid

BYLINE: By Geoffrey Wheatcroft; Geoffrey Wheatcroft's books include "The Randlords: The Exploits and Exploitations of South Africa's Mining Magnates."

 BODY:

LOOSING THE BONDS
 The United States and South Africa
 in the Apartheid Years.
 By Robert Kinloch Massie.
 Illustrated. 896 pp. New York:
 Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $40. 
 Five hundred years ago, Europeans made landfall both at the southern tip of Africa and in North America. The contrast between the subsequent histories of what are now South Africa and the United States has been riveting, and in some ways disturbing. In both places, a tiny handful of colonists originally found themselves surrounded by indigenous peoples; the outcome centuries later is drastically different.
That contrast was discussed by the historian George M. Fredrickson in his brilliant book "White Supremacy: A Comparative Study in American and South African History." And in Cape Town in 1966, Senator Robert F. Kennedy gave a speech (which makes one suspect yet again that Bobby was the most interesting and original of the Kennedys) describing his keen interest in a particular land, which had been settled by the Dutch in the 17th century and then taken over by the British, which had acquired independence, and where the native inhabitants were subdued -- "a land which was once an importer of slaves and now must struggle to wipe out the last traces of that form of bondage. I refer, of course, to the United States of America."
That speech is quoted by the Rev. Robert Kinloch Massie at the beginning of "Loosing the Bonds," whose subject is ostensibly less broad than Fredrickson's: the relationship between the two countries in the apartheid period from 1948 to 1994, and especially the campaign in the United States to sever commercial ties with South Africa. Massie is an Episcopal clergyman who has been politically active since he was at Princeton 20 years ago, when he led the campaign to compel the university to disinvest from South Africa. And so he is writing (though with conscious self-effacement) what is among other things personal history, a labor of love as well as a monumental work of scholarship.
Monumental is the word, and I must gently protest about its size. There is a tendency in American publishing at present toward books that are simply too long for their subject. I suspect that this is caused partly by cheap paper, and partly by the personal computer. These little critters are splendid at accumulating material and pouring it forth again. But no one has yet taught them the first rule of writing history, which is that the reader does not want to know everything the author knows.
That aside, this is a well-written and well-informed book, one that is indispensable for anyone interested in South Africa, of which it is in reality a thorough history. Beginning more than 300 years ago, Massie describes the country's gradual evolution, its transformation by mining and its capture politically in 1948 by Afrikaner nationalists, who found themselves (unlike the descendants of white American settlers) a small minority among a huge nonwhite majority, and who constructed their strange quasi-theocratic system, called "apartness," to justify white supremacist rule.
By the 1960's, and especially after the Sharpeville massacre, this system impinged on the consciousness -- and the conscience -- of the world. A campaign began against apartheid, and specifically to impose economic sanctions and withdraw investment. The struggle continued through the 1970's and into the next decade, with waves of black upheaval in South Africa, and with disinvestment abroad building to a crescendo in the late 80's: from January 1986 to April 1988, 1,400 American companies pulled out of South Africa, not quite as late in the day as Argentina's declaring war on Germany in March 1945.
By 1990 Nelson Mandela had been released from his appallingly long prison sentence, and by 1994 he was President of a multiracial South Africa. It was a story in which the world could and did take pride; Massie's account is a reminder of just how brutal the reality of apartheid was. For a work of this scope there are not many slips: the name "Afrikaner" was taken up by the Dutch, or Boers, later than Massie thinks; the Afrikaans word for brute force is "kragdadigheid," not "kragdigheid"; and the "London cricket club" that didn't go to South Africa in 1968 was in fact the English national team.
How much effect sanctions and disinvestment had on toppling apartheid is hard to estimate precisely. In 1977, the South African scholar R. W. Johnson published a fascinating book called "How Long Will South Africa Survive?" He didn't quite answer his own question, but the implied answer was "longer than you think." By the beginning of the 80's, when I first reported from South Africa, it was clear to me that white supremacy was doomed in the long run, and so it proved; but then the run also proved longer than many had been confidently predicting for decades.
It also seemed to me 15 years ago that there was an element of shadowboxing or playacting in the Western anti-apartheid campaign. South Africa could have been brought to its knees by a total embargo on its mineral production -- gold, diamonds, bauxite, vanadium and uranium. But that would have meant a real material sacrifice by the West, which disinvestment did not. There were after all plenty of other places, less obviously unethical but quite as lucrative, for American institutions to invest in.
This is not a retrospective argument against disinvestment. If plenty of those who indulged in prophecy on both sides of the argument now look silly, those like Margaret Thatcher and Henry Kissinger who defended South Africa as a bulwark against Communism look mean as well. But the campaign against apartheid itself sometimes ran the risks of self-righteousness and hypocrisy.
Massie knows this, since he is aware that Americans have a tendency "to caricature racial conflict," and are anyway not always in the strongest position to lecture others about racism. Even so, I think he goes astray when he links the anti-apartheid struggle with the civil rights struggle in the United States. Dr. Johnson said that the greater part of life's follies stems from the attempt to emulate that which we do not resemble; and a large part of political misprision stems from false analogy.
It was entirely natural for black Americans to identify with the oppressed black majority in South Africa. And Secretary of State William Rogers explained in 1970 that American opposition to South Africa was largely due to "increased identification of U.S. Negroes with African causes." But the truth is that African-Americans have almost nothing in common with the Africans of Africa: less than the average run of assimilated Italian-Americans have with Sicilians, say, or most Jewish Americans have with Israelis. That is, unless one chooses to believe in just those theories of ethnicity and "blood" on which apartheid was founded.
And the comparison of those two movements obscures as much as it illuminates. In Harlem in 1990, Massie writes, "Nelson and Winnie Mandela further cemented the symbolic unification of the American and the South African struggles over race when they were introduced to a huge crowd by Betty Shabazz, Malcolm X's widow, who declared that the two struggles were really one and the same." But they weren't. The civil rights struggle was about elementary justice; the South African struggle was partly about justice, but also about power.
For all his own intense involvement in the anti-apartheid cause, Massie is surely aware of the dangers of moralistic lecturing. Maybe he has been watching recent world developments. Different forms of American scolding have managed to unite in resentment the leaders of Western Europe; the rulers of Communist China; Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel; Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who recently blamed Jewish financiers for his country's problems -- and President Nelson Mandela of South Africa, who insisted on going to Libya to embrace Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi despite the vehement objections of the State Department. The rest of the world envies the Americans their good fortune of history and geography. Americans themselves might think more about its implications.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 24; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3014 words

HEADLINE: A Couple of Kingmakers Talking Shop

BYLINE: By Gail Collins; Gail Collins is on the Times editorial board.

 BODY:
Ralph reed and george stephanopoulos, the most famous 36-year-olds in American politics, are in career transition. After six years in the service of Bill Clinton, Stephanopoulos quit his job as senior adviser to the President in 1997 to write his memoirs, teach at Columbia University and serve as resident talking head for ABC News. The same year, Reed left his job as executive director of the Christian Coalition to start a campaign consulting firm for "pro-family, pro-life, pro-free-enterprise" candidates. 
 They agreed to bring their new political per-spectives to a one-on-one discussion recently at The New York Times. Reed, who is credited with giving the religious conservative movement a wider appeal and less threatening image, repeatedly tried to link issues like abortion to broader political concerns like tax cuts. Stephanopoulos, who was hauled before both a grand jury and Congressional investigating committee during his White House career, kept returning to his concerns about the use of political corruption probes as partisan weapons. But they found surprising areas of common ground on topics from political strategy to protests at abortion clinics.
 
A Sentimental Education
Q: Does it ever feel demeaning, serving the political ambitions of others?
Reed: Sometimes I think it is, sure. You're in a position where you're sort of coming of age professionally. You've got some ideas and some aspirations of your own. And you have to sublimate them to the other person. But my own view is that it's a very good skill to learn.
Stephanopoulos: I agree with his analysis, but I don't like the word. I guess I don't think it's demeaning.
Reed: Demeaning's too strong a word.
Stephanopoulos: What you get, in return for sometimes having to, you know, carry bags or pass the towel over, is an education in how to give advice, see a decision taken , then defend it.
 
 Q: Can you criticize your candidate in front of the staff?
Reed: I don't think it's helpful. I think a strategist or adviser in a political capacity is the closest thing to a secular priest.
Stephanopoulos: (laughs) I was going to say altar boy.
Reed: That person has to know he can go into a confession with you, and you're not going to share that with anybody. I've always tried to be the person who set the tone for being the most loyal, defending the indefensible and demon-strating that you don't get anywhere by under-cutting the boss.
Stephanopoulos: Oh, absolutely. And as you're working for people in successively higher jobs, what you can say at a lower level becomes both impolitic and disloyal at a higher level.
 
 Don't Ask, Don't Tell
Q: Is it that you don't want your boss to tell you certain things? Are there certain things you can't say to him?
Stephanopoulos: There are certain things you shouldn't repeat. I mean, even saying this now -- because of the insanity of the criminalization of political disputes -- makes me nervous. People are going to say: What did Clinton tell you that you can't say? What law did he break?
Reed: There are things that all human beings say that if you came back 10 minutes later they wouldn't say again. If you look at the Watergate tapes, one failure on the staff level was that Haldeman and Ehrlichman would go in and meet with Nixon and he would say: we should go do this. And they would go out and do it.
Stephanopoulos: Right. But you know what probably will happen as more tapes come out? My guess is that Haldeman will be known as somebody who stopped 155 bad ideas and let two really bad ones go through that sent him to jail. What a price to pay.
 
 Q: Are there things about the candidate's private life you would never ask about?
Reed: It's a total G.I.-tract exam. You go over everything from taxes to personal life to business dealings to resume, curriculum vitae, grades -- everything is on the table. There's a parable in the New Testament where Christ basically says: don't go out and try to build a tower without calculating what it will cost. Because if you try to build it and you don't finish it, everybody will point to the unfinished tower and say: Look at what a failure you are. So, as an advocate and friend and adviser, you're saying, Let's count the cost. If there are things in your past that could become a major issue in the campaign and could wreak havoc on your life, your family, your marriage and your business partners -- you ought to know before you go.
Stephanopoulos: (laughing) That is the most elegant justification to get a candidate to turn over everything I've ever heard. From Lee Atwater and Machiavelli to Ralph Reed and the parable of the unfinished tower. I am really impressed.
 
Schooled in Scandal
Q: Is it good politics for the Republicans to have continuing investigations of the White House, when the public doesn't seem to care about it?
Stephanopoulos: It didn't work in 1992; it didn't work in 1996. Even if you don't have
a distaste for it, I would think some political strategist would stand up and say hey, it doesn't work.
Reed: I don't think we should try to use that process to try and gain a political advantage.
I mean, in spite of Iran-contra, Michael Dukakis lost in a landslide to George Bush. Ford, in spite of pardoning Nixon, had he run a better campaign probably would have beaten Jimmy Carter.
Stephanopoulos: Could have.
Reed: Could have. Easily. And the Republicans won the White House after Teapot Dome. Harding was dead, of course. (laughs)
Stephanopoulos: One of the things I do think has been unfair to President Clinton: I think he is the first President ever to have a sustained permanent investigation of issues that should have been wiped away by the election. The old rules were: put it before the voters. They decide. And they certainly had enough information.
 
Q: Has using scandal ever really worked to anyone's political advantage?
Reed: I'm not sure it has. You could almost make an argument that the Democrats should be glad the Republicans focused on Whitewater and Paula Jones instead of issues where Clinton could have been beaten.
 
 Q: Like?
Reed: Taxes, health care, term limits, things of that nature. Crime.
Stephanopoulos: I think Ralph's half-right. It was a bit of a gift -- though I'm sure the President would have preferred not to have been given that gift -- for them to do Whitewater and all those things. But I think you're wrong to think those issues are definite winners for Republicans all the time.
 
 Q: What about the flat tax as a future campaign issue?
Stephanopoulos: My slogan against it will be: read the fine print. The minute you have to come up with details you find out it's a tax cut for people earning over $200,000, but a tax increase for people earning under $200,000. If somebody actually tried to enact a flat tax, there'd be about as close as you'd have to a revolution in the country.
Reed: Well. Obviously we disagree. (laughter) I've urged candidates I've assisted to call for a single rate, simple tax that could be filled out on a postcard -- where the average family of four making $40,000 a year doesn't pay a dime in income tax and doesn't even have to file. I think there's a way to get there. We can debate the fine print. But let's pass something. Let's reform the tax system. Gephardt is very smart; he's got his own plan that does this. Gore really doesn't and the Clinton Administration really doesn't.
Stephanopoulos: Well, of course they don't, because what you just said is not possible. You just promised every American earning under $40,000 zero taxes. It's never going to happen. You can win a campaign promising every family they're not gonna pay taxes; I mean, I suppose you can win if people believe it.
 
 Faith, Hope and Charity
Reed: I think there's a great misunderstanding by those outside the religious conservative movement who believe the movement is focused on abortion in almost a reductionist way. I think their concerns are much broader than that. What they are concerned about is a loss of civility, a coarsening of the culture. Abortion is one symptom of that coarsening.
Stephanopoulos: But does that then lead to a shunning of the more coarse aspects of the right-to-life movement?
Reed: Absolutely, if by that you mean those who advocate the use of violence, for example.
 
 Q: What about people who block abortion clinics?
Reed: I think most people believe the First Amendment protects the right of free speech, including the right to sit in, in a nonviolent way. That's what protesters during the civil rights movement did.
Stephanopoulos: I think this is where Democrats make a mistake -- demonizing people who are acting in an honorable tradition of passive civil disobedience. I may not agree on the issue of abortion, but I have the absolute highest respect for somebody who believes enough in an issue that they're willing to go to jail for it. It's been a huge mistake for Democrats to want to harness the power of religious and spiritual movements when they agree, but to rule them out of bounds in the debate when they disagree....I think one of the things a lot of religious voters took away from Clinton, even when they disagreed with him vehemently, was that he was not hostile to the notion of faith.
Reed: No, he was not. In fact, other than Jimmy Carter there hasn't been a president in my lifetime who spoke more openly about matters of faith than Clinton.
Stephanopoulos: I've always wanted to ask you this. How does an average Christian Coalition voter deal with the question: President Clinton is a born-again Southern Baptist who goes to church every Sunday and professes his faith proudly, and Ronald Reagan never went to church, was divorced and didn't see his kids. How do they deal with that contradiction?
Reed: I'll give you a flippant answer and a serious answer. The flippant answer is, we're not electing the Pope....They're not judgmental in the sense that they're looking for someone just like them. They'll vote for a Jewish person who agrees with them on all of the issues -- cutting taxes and balancing the budget and protecting innocent human life and so forth. And they'll vote against someone who's a born-again Christian.
Stephanopoulos: But what does balancing the budget have to do with faith?
Reed: Well, that's a longer theological dis-cussion. But I would argue that a society, a business, a family that is living a level of prosperity by stealing from those who would come later -- that's a moral as well as an economic question.
 
 Q: Could a pro-choice Republican like Christine Todd Whitman get on the ticket in 2000?
Reed: I don't know about her, but without particularizing it, could someone be on the Republican ticket and be pro-choice? The answer, to the best of my judgement, is yes.
Stephanopoulos: If you're right, that's a big boon for the Republicans in 2000.
Reed: But I don't know that it will happen, if you look at who's running, who's likely to be the nominee in 2000, who they'd be likely to pick as a running mate. I think it would be unlikely that you'd have someone who opposed a ban on partial-birth abortion on the ticket.
 
 Sitcom Politics
Q: What about having candidates taking positions on morality in popular culture?
Reed: The one moment in the entire campaign when Dole really had Clinton on his back heels was when Dole gave his Hollywood speech. It was the only time when Dole ever set the agenda.
Stephanopoulos: It was an effective political speech. It was sexy enough to get on the front page of The New York Times, and it sent a message to base voters.
 
 Q: What did you think of Al Gore praising Ellen DeGeneres for coming out on her TV series?
Stephanopoulos: First of all, maybe we can call a moratorium on politicians identifying with characters in sitcoms? There's a difference between a tactical mistake and a legitimate issue. On the issues, I think the President was absolutely right to go to the Human Rights Campaign Fund dinner, to speak out for legislation banning discrimination against homosexuality in the workplace. That is very different from giving a speech in Hollywood praising a sitcom character in a week when the actress is in a fight with her network over how much sex they can show on television. I just think that's dumb politics. It's not a moral issue, it's just stupid.
 
There They Go Again
Stephanopoulos: Politics is such a dirty word that anything that smacks of partisanship is ipso facto questionable. I mean, look at the con-ventions in 1996. Neither wanted to have an avowedly partisan elected politician in prime time. We had Chris Reeve, they had Colin Powell....The least effective speeches at the Democratic convention were the most partisan.
Reed: Same thing at the Republican convention.
Stephanopoulos: What that means is we have essentially dishonest campaigns. Because both sides speak in the same generalities. And it causes greater problems when you actually have to go govern, because you need a partisan campaign to get people on record for what they want.
Reed: The American people are tired of what they perceive as a pointless game of one-upmanship. What I advise the candidates I work for is that rather than making it the gist of your message to condemn and denounce someone else, find something you think is praiseworthy, find some-thing you think is admirable and noble -- elevate that.
 
 Q: Do you tell your clients no negative ads?
Reed: I don't say no contrast ads. But what I do say is that you should generally use them only to respond to attacks against yourself. I think in today's environment the person who goes negative first usually loses.
Stephanopoulos: The person who's perceived as going negative first.
Reed: Yeah. And if you are going to point out differences between your record and your opponent you should probably do it on the issues.
Stephanopoulos: I think every-body knows talking about your opponents in harsh personal terms doesn't work. But maybe you shouldn't abolish negative ads if you're going to define negative ads as those that compare each side's record. And maybe one cheer for partisanship because the biggest gains government has made, politics has made, has been with close victories in partisan fights -- Medicare, the beginning of Social Security. I suppose partisan Republicans would argue the Reagan tax bill of 1981.
Reed: Right.
Stephanopoulos: We could have a debate about that. But generally, that's the only time you get change.
 
 We All Make Mistakes
Q: So much of the way politics runs now was influenced by you two in one way or another. Is there anything you regret?
Stephanopoulos: I regret working on the investigation in 1990 of the October Surprise. Because it was trying to take away by investigation what you didn't win by ballot box. If I had known then how it would have been carried forward, I like to think I wouldn't have done it. But I probably would have.
Reed: While I was at the Christian Coalition, early on, sometimes there was a harshness in tone about the way we said things that I later regretted....There were things we put in fund-raising letters about the radical left and feminists, stuff like that. ...It was an important and painful kind of learning experience. One minute you're a college Republican, and the next minute what you say and do really matters. The decibel is turned up really loud, and you're in Shea Stadium.
Stephanopoulos: I know the exact phe-nomenon you're talking about. If you're lucky enough to get a job like this when you're relatively young, you think you'd be indulged, or excused because of your youth. All of a sudden I was coming before a Congressional committee. I mean, you just can't imagine that someone could think you're a criminal, for something you might have done at work. Even if you made a mistake -- jeez, you were just talking to your friends. It's an odd moment: growing up, but growing up in public.
Reed: I think one of the things that really helped me when I was at the Christian Co-alition was I read some biographies of Martin Luther King. King was 26 years old when he led the Montgomery boycott -- I hadn't realized he was that young. I began to study the way he became the leader that he was, without ever holding an elective office. He was able to do it because he was thinking more eternally about what he was trying to accomplish. For somebody who trained in the Southern Republican political operative school -- for which Lee Atwater set the tone -- that was a very different way of thinking. The way I had been taught was whatever you do, you do to win this election today, and we let everything else sort itself out later. My thinking totally changed
to let's be sure that every word we speak, every meditation of our hearts is something we will be able to stand before a judgment seat and not be ashamed of.
Stephanopoulos: But can that be sustained when you go back to running races?
Reed: No one who hires me wants to do so at the loss of their integrity or mine, or they hired the wrong person.
Stephanopoulos: Think about Kennedy in 1960. Throughout the first few years of his Presidency -- you read about how Sorensen and O'Donnell, people who I revere, would say let's not do the civil rights bill now, we want to get our economic plan through. I like to think if I'd been working for John Kennedy, I'd have been saying, No! Let's do civil rights. But I'm not sure that's true.
Reed: I don't know if 30 years from now some historian will look back on a moment when I could have made a difference and find me wanting. But I do think if we can think beyond the election about what we can defend as a matter of our own conscience, it would make a big difference in the kind of politics we have. Maybe I'm just naive.
Stephanopoulos: I don't know about naive. I just know that in the middle of a race, there's an illusion of necessity. And of course, what you say is: I'm not compromising my principles, I'm just working for a higher principle at this particular minute.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1583 words

HEADLINE: Colorblind

BYLINE: By Alex Kotlowitz; Alex Kotlowitz is the author most recently of "The Other Side of the River: A Story of Two Towns, a Death and America's Dilemma."

 BODY:
One Christmas day seven years ago, I'd gone over to the Henry Horner Homes in Chicago to visit with Lafeyette and Pharoah, the subjects of my book "There Are No Children Here." I had brought presents for the boys, as well as a gift for their friend Rickey, who lived on the other side of the housing complex, an area controlled by a rival gang. Lafeyette and Pharoah insisted on walking over with me. It was eerily quiet, since most everyone was inside, and so, bundled from the cold, we strolled toward the other end in silence. As we neared Damen Avenue, a kind of demilitarized zone, a uniformed police officer, a white woman, approached us. She looked first at the two boys, neither of whom reached my shoulder, and then directly at me. "Are you O.K.?" she asked.
About a year later, I was with Pharoah on the city's North Side, shopping for high-tops. We were walking down the busy street, my hand on Pharoah's shoulder, when a middle-aged black man approached. He looked at me, and then at Pharoah. "Son," he asked, "are you O.K.?" 
 Both this white police officer and middle-aged black man seemed certain of what they witnessed. The white woman saw a white man possibly in trouble; the black man saw a black boy possibly in trouble. It's all about perspective --which has everything to do with our personal and collective experiences, which are consistently informed by race. From those experiences, from our histories, we build myths, legends that both guide us and constrain us, legends that include both fact and fiction. This is not to say the truth doesn't matter. It does, in a big way. It's just that getting there may not be easy, in part because everyone is so quick to choose sides, to refute the other's myths and to pass on their own.
We'd do well to keep this in mind as we enter the yearlong dialogue on race convened by President Clinton. Yes, conversation is critical, but not without self-reflection, both individually and communally. While myths help us make sense of the incomprehensible, they can also confine us, confuse us and leave us prey to historical laziness. Moreover, truth is not always easily discernible -- and even when it is, the prism, depending on which side of the river you reside on, may create a wholly different illusion. Many whites were quick to believe Susan Smith, the South Carolina mother who claimed that a black man had killed her children. And with the reawakening of the Tawana Brawley case, we learn that, although a grand jury has determined otherwise, many blacks still believe she was brutally raped by a group of white men. We -- blacks and whites -- need to examine and question our own perspectives. Only then can we grasp each other's myths and grapple with the truths.
In 1992, I came across the story of a 16-year-old black boy, Eric McGinnis, whose body had been found a year earlier floating in the St. Joseph River in southwestern Michigan. The river flows between Benton Harbor and St. Joseph, two small towns whose only connections are two bridges and a powerful undertow of contrasts.
St. Joseph is a town of 9,000, and, with its quaint downtown and brick-paved streets, resembles a New England tourist haunt. But for those in Benton Harbor, St. Joseph's most defining characteristic is its racial makeup: it is 95 percent white. Benton Harbor, a town of 12,000 on the other side of the river, is 92 percent black and dirt poor. For years, the municipality so hurt for money that it could not afford to raze abandoned buildings.
Eric, a high-school sophomore whose passion was dancing, was last seen at the Club, a teen-age nightspot in St. Joseph, where weeks earlier he had met and started dating a white girl. The night Eric disappeared, a white man said he caught the boy trying to break into his car and chased him -- away from the river, past an off-duty white deputy sheriff. That was the last known moment he was seen alive, and it was then that the myths began.
I became obsessed with Eric's death, and so for five years moved in and out of these two communities, searching for answers to both Eric's disappearance and to matters of race. People would often ask which side of the river I was staying on, wanting to gauge my allegiance. And they would often ask about the secrets of those across the way or, looking for affirmation, repeat myths passed on from one generation to the next.
Once, during an unusually bitter effort by white school-board members to fire Benton Harbor's black superintendent, one black woman asked me: "How do you know how to do this? Do you take lessons? How do you all stick together the way you do?" Of course, we don't. Neither community is as unified or monolithic as the other believes. Indeed, contrary to the impression of those in St. Joseph, the black community itself was deeply divided in its support for the superintendent, who was eventually fired.
On occasion, whites in St. Joseph would regale me with tales of families migrating to Benton Harbor from nearby states for the high welfare benefits. It is, they would tell me, the reason for the town's economic decline. While some single mothers indeed moved to Benton Harbor and other Michigan cities in the early 80's to receive public assistance, the truth is that in the 30's and 40's, factories recruited blacks from the South, and when those factories shut down, unemployment, particularly among blacks, skyrocketed.
But the question most often asked was: "Why us? Why write about St. Joseph and Benton Harbor?" I would tell them that while the contrasts between the towns seem unusually stark, they are, I believe, typical of how most of us live: physically and spiritually isolated from one another.
It's not that I didn't find individuals who crossed the river to spend time with their neighbors. One St. Joseph woman, Amy Johnson, devotes her waking hours to a Benton Harbor community center. And Eric McGinnis himself was among a handful of black teen-agers who spent weekend nights at the Club in St. Joseph. Nor is it that I didn't find racial animosity. One St. Joseph resident informed me that Eric got what he deserved: "That nigger came on the wrong side of the bridge," he said. And Benton Harbor's former schools superintendent, Sherwin Allen, made no effort to hide his contempt for the white power structure.
What I found in the main, though, were people who would like to do right but don't know where to begin. As was said of the South's politicians during Jim Crow, race diminishes us. It incites us to act as we wouldn't in other arenas: clumsily, cowardly and sometimes cruelly. We circle the wagons, watching out for our own.
That's what happened in the response to Eric's death. Most everyone in St. Joseph came to believe that Eric, knowing the police were looking for him, tried to swim the river to get home and drowned. Most everyone in Benton Harbor, with equal certitude, believes that Eric was killed -- most likely by whites, most likely because he dated a white girl. I was struck by the disparity in perspective, the competing realities, but I was equally taken aback by the distance between the two towns -- which, of course, accounts for the myths. Jim Reeves, the police lieutenant who headed the investigation into Eric's death, once confided that this teen-ager he'd never met had more impact on him than any other black person.
I'm often asked by whites, with some wonderment, how it is that I'm able to spend so much time in black communities without feeling misunderstood or unwelcomed or threatened. I find it much easier to talk with blacks about race than with fellow whites. While blacks often brave slights silently for fear that if they complain they won't be believed, when asked, they welcome the chance to relate their experiences. Among whites, there's a reluctance -- or a lack of opportunity -- to engage. Race for them poses no urgency; it does not impose on their daily routines. I once asked Ben Butzbaugh, a St. Joseph commissioner, how he felt the two towns got along. "I think we're pretty fair in this community," he said. "I don't know that I can say I know of any out-and-out racial-type things that occur. I just think people like their own better than others. I think that's pretty universal. Don't you?. . .We're not a bunch of racists. We're not anything America isn't." Butzbaugh proudly pointed to his friendship with Renee Williams, Benton Harbor's new school superintendent. "Renee was in our home three, four, five days a week," he noted. "Nice gal. Put herself through school. We'd talk all the time." Williams used to clean for Butzbaugh's family.
As I learned during the years in and out of these towns, the room for day-to-day dialogue doesn't present itself. We become buried in our myths, certain of our truths -- and refuse to acknowledge what the historian Allan Nevins calls "the grains of stony reality" embedded in most legends. A quarter-century ago, race was part of everyday public discourse; today it haunts us quietly, though on occasion -- the Rodney King beating or the Simpson trial or Eric McGinnis's death -- it erupts with jarring urgency. At these moments of crisis, during these squalls, we flail about, trying to find moral ballast. By then it is usually too late. The lines are drawn. Accusations are hurled across the river like cannon fire. And the cease-fires, when they occur, are just that, cease-fires, temporary and fragile. Even the best of people have already chosen sides.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The St. Joseph River in Michigan separates a black community from a white one. There, and most everywhere in America, sides are chosen along racial lines. (Photograph by Marcia Lippman)

LENGTH: 803 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Clean Up Calverton T.W.A. Site

BYLINE: By JEROME REISMAN; Jerome Reisman is a partner in the Garden City law firm of Reisman, Peirez, Reisman & Calica. He specializes in domestic and international business law.

 BODY:
IT may be one of the most difficult economic development strategies ever implemented anywhere the United States. Riverhead Town officials are seeking to redevelop a former defense factory complex that sits astride, for all intents and purposes, the largest and most expensive aircraft morgue ever assembled in the nation -- the remains of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.
It should come as no surprise that potential developers of Calverton are reviewing potential sites within the complex under the watchful eyes of authorities tasked with protecting the debris. While the Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined that no missile or smuggled bomb brought down the flight, we are on the verge of a blizzard of civil litigation that will bring T.W.A. to the edge of a financial abyss. Every aluminum shard and charred wiring bundle will be produced as evidence by the plaintiffs seeking a verdict. The collection of evidence reconstructed in the prime Calverton hangar will be produced for every trial as the families of the 230 killed people on the flight go to court. 
 Despite brochures and plant tours, the redevelopment of Calverton from an empty defense complex to an economic engine that assists all of Long Island will not be easy. The prior town administration had been struggling over the last several years to create a cogent redevelopment strategy for the 4,000 acres that sit inside the fence and 7,000 acres that act as an environmental buffer outside the security cordon. They had real difficulty replicating Calverton, which poured millions into the region's economy and put thousands of people to work. Without a key industry to replace that role, Calverton would demand $3 million annually from the town just to maintain the complex when turned over by the Navy.
Riverhead officials have proposed movie studios in the massive hangars, confident that East End movie moguls who summer in the Hamptons would find the commute alluring. It failed to fly. Town officials then hoped for a massive theme park on the property, but Six Flags went to Connecticut and Disney is putting its East Coast money into Broadway. Now they are wooing industrial real estate in buildings that once produced fighters. Obstacles include East End (dead end?) transportation woes and high electrical costs. (Remember, Grumman flew its final products out of Calverton and enjoyed special energy rate deals with the State Power Authority.)
Today, the Town of Riverhead faces a difficult decision. To make Calverton far more attractive for investment, they should demand that the National Transportation Safety Board remove the T.W.A. wreckage to an area of lesser economic importance. Yet the leasing of 35,000 square feet of prime space by the National Transportation Safety Board has insured that there is a revenue stream of some $1 million a year that is used to maintain the complex. The Navy is the recipient of that cash and, as a result, has slowed down the process of transferring the site. Losing the wreckage means losing the dollars that insure Calverton remains physically attractive to the next generation of users. Ironically, Riverhead hasn't even seen the $1 million in lieu of taxes it used to receive when Grumman managed the site.
It would appear that Calverton's future will continue to be linked to the 747 wreckage until every last lawsuit is settled. Over time, users will find adjacent office and factory space but a comprehensive plan that integrates those massive hangars will have to wait. Nevertheless, Riverhead Town should be far more aggressive than creating a broker's tour of the facility. Artificial governmental barriers between town, county and state should be thrown down to allow for every economic development option to be considered. Innovative and complimentary uses should also be included that develop town destination centers that would aid the sagging downtown area, including a proposed air museum featuring World War II warplanes and an automobile race track.
Restarting aviation manufacturing at the complex might be the most ironic use but one of the most lucrative. Boeing is currently faced with enormous bottlenecks as it attempts to fulfill multibillion-dollar contracts worldwide for a new generation of aircraft. In their sub-contracting of key work to other companies, Long Island could easily see companies like Lockheed-Martin-Grumman set up a production line in hangars adjacent to the T.W.A. morgue where a new generation of airliners could be assembled.
In the end, perhaps the best use of the wreckage might be to serve the same purpose as the china retrieved from the Titanic. Surrounded by the workings of business and commerce, the Calverton site could serve as a constant reminder of what happens when we take technology for granted.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Lodging Industry in and Near Hartford;
A New Downtown Hotel, and Plans for More in Area

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
PLANS for a new 300-room, full-service hotel in downtown Hartford are the latest example of a market that has rebounded in recent years, with new investment being used to upgrade several existing hotels in the area and hotels newly opened or on the drawing boards in at least six other central Connecticut towns.
"The region has firmed up considerably over the last several years," said David H. Kagan, chief operating officer of the Konover Investments Corporation in West Hartford, which will build the downtown hotel with Albermarle Equities Inc. of Farmington. "Occupancy rates have increased from the mid-50's to the low 70's, and the rates have come up as well. The average rate in the downtown area is about $85 a day right now, which is getting to be in the right range for an in-city, upscale hotel." 
 Based on lodging taxes paid by Hartford hotels, local officials estimate that hotel revenues were $24 million in 1997, topping the previous high of $22.4 million in 1987, even though there were 900 fewer hotel rooms than 10 years earlier.
Scott K. Dresser, vice president of the Greater Hartford Convention and Visitors Bureau, said four of the larger hotels in the region had changed hands recently: the Sheraton Hartford, which underwent a $3.5 million renovation last year; the Radisson Hotel Cromwell; the Holiday Inn in Hartford, which is being upgraded to a Crown Plaza, and the Holiday Inn at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, which is going to be turned into a Doubletree with a $2.5 million investment.
"There's serious money being invested in these hotels by the new owners," Mr. Dresser said. "The Hartford area hotel industry is booming, and it has attracted a lot of national and local attention."
Mr. Dresser said that he knew one developer who owned an apartment complex in Hartford that he planned to convert to a 220-unit hotel, and that another developer would soon announce plans for an all-suites hotel near the Connecticut River.
"Six, seven years ago that kind of consideration would have been unthinkable in this market," Mr. Dresser said. "There's been just a tremendous turnaround."
"More importantly, there's a sense that more rooms will breed more demand," said Philip Schonberger, who owns Albermarle Equities. "Hartford as a market has never had a fully mature convention and trade show market. The more rooms you have, the more events of that type you could accommodate."
Konover Investments and Albermarle Equities are also the leaders of a development group that last month purchased a 15-acre site north of downtown Hartford where they plan a 100,000-square-foot exposition center, with 1,500 parking spaces. In addition, the Connecticut Convention Center Authority, a quasi-public group, is seeking funding for a study of the feasibility of a 200,000-square-foot convention center in the downtown area. The Civic Center has about 67,000 square feet of exposition space.
THE Konover-Albermarle hotel would go on a site that serves as a farmers' market currently, across Main Street from the Old State House.
"Even right now, there is a demand for a business-class, moderate-to-upscale hotel, somewhere between 800 and 1,000 rooms, and if some of these other developments occur that's only going to expand," said Mr. Kagan of Konover. With a convention center and exposition hall added to the market, he said, "I think 1,500 to 2,500 additional hotel rooms would not be unreasonable."
H. Scott Phelps, president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau, said statistics showed the entire region was undergoing a hotel boom, with occupancy rates in 1996-97 the second highest of any metropolitan area in the Northeast and Midwest -- an average of 68.9 percent in the Hartford region, based on lodging tax revenues, topped only by Pittsburgh with 69.1, and well ahead of the 48 percent low reported in Indianapolis.
"We hit bottom in the early 1990's, but those numbers have turned around with double-digit increases in occupancy and revenues for four years in a row," Mr. Phelps said. "A lot of national developers are beginning to look at the possibilities here." In fact, he said, his office has been working with one Washington, D.C.-based hotel consultant who has been contacted by three developers in as many months who are interested in the Hartford area.
It's not just the downtown, either, Mr. Phelps said. Hotels have just opened, are under construction or are approved in Windsor Locks, Vernon, Manchester, Farmington, Rocky Hill and Glastonbury.
A 52-room Holiday Inn Express just opened off Exit 64 on Interstate 84 in Vernon, bringing the number of hotels in that suburban town to four.
"Some people are talking about some other projects, too," said George H. Russell, the Vernon town planner. "Given some of the occupancy rates we're hearing about, there's a market for more, and there is land available here.
"Vernon happens to be very convenient," Mr. Russell continued. "All the hotels are right off the exits of the highway, and therefore are very accessible to the traveling public. At all four of the hotels, you don't have to drive more than a couple of hundred yards after you get off the highway."
The Promus Corporation recently won approval for a 121-unit Homewood Suites hotel near Route 4 in Farmington. Jeffrey Ollendorf, the Farmington town planner, said he expected another application for about the same number of units from another company this month. "We had a lot of phone calls just prior to the recession, in the late 1980's and even into 1990," Mr. Ollendorf said. "At that time there was a lot of interest in the fact that some of the Hartford hotels had closed and companies wanted to pick up the slack in the suburbs. But then the entire economy went into a slump and most of the plans were dropped. About a year ago, the interest started to pick up again as the economy started to rebound.
"I've heard about some of the other projects coming in around the region, though, and you start to wonder how many units we can absorb," Mr. Ollendorf added. "I've had inquiries from other developers who are interested in coming in even after I've told them what's on the books -- it's a little perplexing to me as to how much we can handle."
MOST towns seem to think that the region can absorb the space relatively easily, however. Manchester approved a 90-room Marriott Courtyard in August, and construction began in late fall. Then on Dec. 15 the town approved a 96-room Residence Inn in the same area, off Slater Street and Buckland Hills Drive.
"Hartford has not been adding a lot of rooms yet, and they lost some space in the last real estate crash, so putting 190 rooms in Manchester is not going to be too much," said Mark Pellegrini, Manchester's director of planning and economic development.
Suzanne M. Hopgood, president of the Hartford-based Hopgood Group, which provides hotel investment advice to institutional investors and developers, said there had been a number of quiet changes taking place in the Hartford area hotel market.
The existing hotels are healthier because they have been refinanced or sold. The Hartford Sheraton, which cost almost $125,000 a unit to build, sold for $25,000 a room in the early 1990's. Others have been sold or recapitalized at from $100,000 or more a unit to $50,000 or less, she said, and new operators have brought costs under control.
"You have much more efficient hotel operations, and everyone has recapitalized at numbers that make it possible to make a profit," Ms. Hopgood said. "People who bought a hotel in Hartford in the last three or four years are in a very good position. You can't touch anything for $25,000 a room today."
But the most significant change has been the growth in demand, she said. The business travel that made up most of the business in the region almost disappeared in the late 1980's as companies nationwide began paring their travel budgets. By the end of 1992, occupancy rates averaged just 52 percent, she said.
Over the last few years, however, companies in Hartford such as United Technologies, Aetna, US Healthcare and Travelers have been expanding, and many of them are bringing people from far-flung divisions to Hartford for training or meetings, which has bolstered local hotel stays. By the end of last year, many hotels were reporting occupancy rates in excess of 70 percent. Because so many of a hotel's costs are fixed, that translates to rapidly growing profits.
"The last three years, the Hartford region has seen 11 percent a year growth in hotel revenue, which increases the bottom line by 30 percent," Ms. Hopgood said. "Every room that comes in now, 70 or 80 percent of those revenues are pure profit."
Mr. Phelps said he hoped a 1990 study that showed there is a market for a convention center in Hartford could be dusted off and re-examined. His organization has booked 500 conventions for the next few years; they are expected to bring 100,000 people and $120 million to Hartford, but with a large convention center the city could attract even more.
"We do get some groups up to the 2,000 range, but the majority of them are smaller," Mr. Phelps said. Many other states have made a major commitment to attracting that travel: since 1990, 82 convention centers have been built around the United States, and 171 others have been expanded. Today, only Montana, Idaho and Wyoming have less dedicated convention space than Connecticut, he said.
"It's a real disadvantage to our staff as they're trying to book conventions in Hartford that we don't have that main convention hall with a lot of meeting space," Mr. Phelps said.
