HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
At 10 or at 90, an Actress Is Every-Brahmin

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
MABEL TIDINGS BIGELOW is a memorable fictional character you might like to meet in the person of the enchanting Cherry Jones, who plays her to the core of Mabel's singular being in the Lincoln Center Theater production of "Pride's Crossing," Tina Howe's bittersweet feminist comedy currently at the Mitzi E. Newhouse.
Mabel, now 90, was briefly famous in the late 1920's for having been the first woman to swim the English Channel from England to France, unlike the real-life Gertrude Ederle, who earlier made the crossing in the opposite direction. Though Mabel has a daughter, a granddaughter and a great-granddaughter, she accurately describes herself as the last of her line: Boston Brahmins whose blood has become "too blue, too thin . . . spent." 
 Unless you manage to see these Brahmins at Mabel's exuberantly slapdash Fourth of July croquet party, which concludes "Pride's Crossing," they would look like old people of a certain upper class anywhere else. Their money has almost run out. They get by on dwindling dividend checks. Among strangers they can be fearful, overbearing and up-tight. Some, like Mabel, live in what had been the chauffeurs' cottages on family estates they no longer own.
They feel increasingly isolated in an economic, social and intellectual world that has long since abandoned Boston as its center. Yet they are the direct if distant descendants of the men and women whose accomplishments prompted Oliver Wendell Holmes to call Boston "the Hub of the Universe." What a crew these 19th-century New Englanders were: radically independent divines, philosophers, poets, novelists, abolitionists, historians, naturalists, transcendentalists. And don't forget the adventuring capitalists who helped foot the bills.
Mabel and her surviving friends hang on to their manners, at least in public. They tend their memories with the care they might have lavished on delphiniums when still supple enough to bend over. No one more so than Mabel, who could be a granddaughter of one of the forbidding subsidiary figures in the William Dean Howells novel "The Rise of Silas Lapham."
In the course of the seven days that elapse in "Pride's Crossing," Mabel deals with a past that is as vivid to her as -- and far more important than -- her present circumstances. Her favorite granddaughter, Julia, has arrived for one of her infrequent visits, accompanied by Mabel's 10-year-old great-granddaughter, Minty. To mark the occasion, Mabel insists on having a croquet party because, among other things, Minty is being brought up in Paris where, as is well known, absolutely nobody plays croquet.
The preparations for the festivities prompt Mabel's recollections of earlier, not always happier times and a decision she made as a young woman that has forever haunted her life. Mabel's grandfather might have lived in the Boston of "The Rise of Silas Lapham," but she herself is a kind of female equivalent to the rueful male figures in the Boston fiction of J. P. Marquand. When her test came, she failed it.
Ms. Howe describes "Pride's Crossing" as a tribute to an ancient aunt who never left home, never married and never swam a stroke. In transforming her aunt into a woman who did all of these things, she says she is following a theater tradition that allows us to go beyond fact to create fiction that is no less true for being what might have been. What she is writing about is: "The passion of old ladies. When men age, they just get old, but when women age, they become extremely powerful." That's the sort of generalization that playwrights writing about their works are allowed.
At its best, "Pride's Crossing" offers a buoyant portrait of a woman who, having triumphed in one extraordinary way, never forgave herself for not having gone the one step further that might have spelled true liberation. Instead, she allowed her actions to be dictated by a society that had already atrophied.
As staged with brisk efficiency by Jack O'Brien in the limited space of the Newhouse Theater, "Pride's Crossing" suggests the sweep of a novel, moving easily back and forth through the years as Ms. Jones alternates between Mabel at 90 and her younger selves aged 10, 15, 20, 21, 53 and 60, though not in that neat chronological order. In the Boston society in which Mabel was bred, strong women allowed themselves to be dominated by weak men. Money was the cushion of this existence, as we see in Mabel's memories.
She is the youngest of the three Tidings children and the only daughter. Her oldest brother, Phineas, the child her sports-loving father dotes on, wins an Olympic medal in diving. Frazier, the middle child, appears to be on his way to becoming the kind of homosexual who despises himself.
As a little girl, Mabel escapes the suppressed rage of the arid household by spending her time with the Irish kitchen help, later by swimming. Yet she is susceptible to the lures of society. The summer before she goes to England to swim the Channel, she falls in love with the rich young Porter
Bigelow, who is very handsome and already drinks too much. Initially, she was attracted by the extraordinary pinkness of his bare feet in the green grass.
It's in England that she meets David Bloom, a young Englishman who swam the Channel a year earlier and becomes her trainer. This suddenly is true love as well as a way to break away from the family. That she doesn't seize the opportunity is partly because of her commitment to Porter, but mostly because David is Jewish. Her Boston backbone turns out to be brittle. What follows is a story of drunks, suicides, multiple marriages and estranged children, defeats that ultimately lead to a kind of power she didn't know she possessed. .
Ms. Jones, a Tony Award winner for her performance in "The Heiress," is a delight as the feisty Mabel who, at 90, sounds a bit like Katharine Hepburn and, at any age, is a character of startling, unexpected presence.
With only a minimum of costume changes (some in full view of the audience) and without makeup, she slips from one age to the next with what might be called astonishingly theatrical simplicity. In any succession of scenes she may go from being a deaf old lady with a walker to a svelte Back Bay matron of 35, the old lady again and then a pulled-together, none-too-grieving widow of 60. When required, she even has the figure of a distance swimmer.
TWO WOMEN, ONE LITTLE girl and three men play the 19 supporting roles as effectively as possible, though some of the parts are so small that they hardly register beyond being generic types. Angie Phillips is fine as Vita Bright, the 90-year-old Mabel's live-in companion, but quite lost as Phineas, Mabel's brother who, not mysteriously, just looks like a pretty young woman dressed in men's clothes that don't fit.
This is one of the failed quirks of "Pride's Crossing," whose text directs that Phineas be played by an actress and that a man play Mary O'Neill, the Irish cook who says things like "You're going to be the death of me" to any children who may be underfoot. As the cross-dressed Mary, Dylan Baker carries on as if he were a Hasty Pudding joke, though he is wonderfully wry and patient as Mabel's lifelong Brahmin suitor, the club-footed Chandler Coffin.
There are other lapses. Would Mabel's otherwise bright great-granddaughter not know what the English Channel is? After all, she's 10 and lives in Paris.
Ralph Funicello's sets and Kenneth Posner's lighting help make possible the swift pacing, the abrupt swoops in time and the underlying sense of elegy. Yet as written, directed and acted, "Pride's Crossing" is always Mabel's play. You can believe she is a Brahmin, whether she is describing the curious, time-out-of-time peace experienced by the long-distance swimmer or as the old woman who, suddenly becoming aware of Vita dressed as Paul Revere, crows with pleasure, "I love your hat!" She's a woman of substance and humor as well as class.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Plainsboro, N.J.;
The Woes and Benefits of Growth

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
WITH sprawling office parks and tightly packed garden apartment complexes, Plainsboro, N. J. is trying to catch its breath after nearly 30 years of rampant development. Since 1970, the 11.8-square-mile Middlesex County township has grown tenfold, from 1,600 people to 16,000.
While much of the township retains its agrarian feel, with 60 percent open land, its main roads are snarled with traffic during rush hours and its schools, although excellent, are becoming crowded. 
 On the plus side, the township is one of the few in New Jersey with an AA-1 bond rating. Its tax rate is $2.40 per $100 of assessed valuation, which is fourth lowest of the 25 municipalities in Middlesex County. Sixty percent of its taxes are paid by corporations, the largest of which are Merrill Lynch and Bristol Myers-Squibb, which provide half of the township's 8,000 jobs and help to keep the unemployment rate down to a minuscule 3.5 percent.
"We need to achieve a housing balance," explained Mayor Peter A. Cantu. "In 1971, when the township was nearly all farmland, 5,000 apartments were approved. And, even today, those apartments make up the bulk of our 8,500 housing units. Now, we are approving mainly single-family homes on lots of between one and six acres."
Mayor Cantu said the township was also allowing cluster development, under which developers are allowed to build homes closer together than the zoning law would ordinarily allow. In return for variances, they must donate land to the township for permanent open space. By the time Plainsboro is completely built out, the Mayor expects it to have an additional 1,500 housing units and a total population of 22,000.
Because of its high proportion of apartments, Plainsboro has a high population turnover, the Mayor said. To build a sense of community, the township frequently sends out fliers listing opportunities for volunteering. For the past 12 years, it has also sponsored Founders Day celebrations on the first Sunday in May. Last year's celebration, complete with a community picnic on the town hall lawn and a parade, was attended by 4,000 to 6,000 people.
Current owner-occupied housing in the township ranges from about $50,000 for some small, one-bedroom condominiums to about $500,000 for some five- or six-bedroom homes on lots of more than one acre, said Rich J. Abrams, an agent with Century 21 Carnegie Realty. There are 30 single-family homes on the market, ranging from $158,000 for a three-bedroom ranch that Mr. Abrams said "needs updating" on Grovers Mill Road in the southern section, to $499,000 for a five-bedroom newer colonial on Stults Drive, also in the southern section.
Most of the township's 1,000 condominium apartments are located in three complexes off Plainsboro Road-Ravenscrest, Tamarron and Aspen. Mr. Abrams said they range in price from about $50,000 for some small one-bedroom units to $79,000 for some two-bedroom, two-bath units.
Two-story town-house condominiums are also plentiful in developments off Plainsboro Road, which bisects the township from east to west, and off U.S. Route 1, a north-south highway on the western edge of town. The largest of the town-house areas is Princeton Landing, off Route 1, which has two distinct communities. One has small, 1,000-square-foot, three-bedroom units that sell for between $95,000 and $110,000. The other has wider streets and larger, more luxurious units with two-car garages, and prices ranging from $160,000 for some two-bedroom town houses to $400,000 for some four-bedroom town houses.
Rental apartments range from about $725 for some one-bedroom units to $1,200 for some three-bedroom town houses. The largest rental complexes are in an area called Princeton Meadows off Plainsboro Road. Mr. Abrams said there was a shortage of rental apartments because Raytheon Corporation recently built a corporate facility in neighboring West Windsor.
"When the Raytheon building is fully staffed, it will employ 3,000 people," Mr. Abrams explained. "And, at least in the early stages, those people are renting."
AMONG the newer residents of the township are Robert and Linda Gelfand, who bought a 17-year-old, four-bedroom colonial on half an acre in January 1996. They moved from Brooklyn to shorten Mr. Gelfand's commute to his job as a systems analyst in Somerset, N.J., about 20 miles north of Plainsboro.
"When Robert brought me out here, I couldn't believe that the housing was so near open fields," Mrs. Gelfand recalled. "Afterwards, everything else we looked at seemed too congested."
Among the major attractions for Mrs. Gelfand, who is a special education teacher by profession and is currently a homemaker, was the highly rated West Windsor-Plainsboro Regional School District, which serves the two communities. It has an average class size of 20 and a total enrollment of 7,287 students in five elementary schools, one middle school and one high school. The Gelfands have a 6-year-old son and a 2-year-old daughter.
"The district encourages parental involvement," Mrs. Gelfand said. "I've already become an active member of the P.T.A. I know the teachers, the principal and the guidance counselor, unlike the New York City school system, which is a lot more impersonal."
Dr. Thomas F. Butler, the interim Superintendent of Schools, said computers are introduced in kindergarten and all classrooms in each building are either networked or in the process of being networked. By next May, Dr. Butler said, each classroom in the district will have at least one computer station for the teacher and one or two stations for pupils.
"We stress technology, with at least one computer laboratory in each school building," Dr. Butler added.
The school population is racially mixed, with 59 percent of the students white, 30 percent Asian or Pacific Islander, 8 percent black and 3 percent Hispanic.
"We have 52 languages represented in our school system," Dr. Butler said.
Last September the West Windsor-Plainsboro Regional High School was rated by New Jersey Monthly magazine as one of "62 public high schools that spend a little and get a lot." Last year's 399 graduating seniors scored average combined totals of 1,170 on the verbal and math sections of the SAT tests, about 180 points higher than the state average. The class of 1998 includes 12 National Merit Scholarship finalists.
Plainsboro was formed in 1919, incorporating approximately six square miles each from Cranbury and South Brunswick. Robert Yuell, the township historian, said that one of the area's most prominent attorneys, John Van Buren Wicoff, drafted the township's petition for incorporation after Cranbury rejected his request that $12,000 be allocated for the construction of a new school building to replace a dilapidated structure in what is now Plainsboro. Mr. Wicoff became Plainsboro's first mayor, a post he held for 30 years. His house, next to the current municipal building on Plainsboro Road, is now owned by the township. It serves as the home for the historical society, which has applied to have the structure, built in the early 1900's, included on the New Jersey Register of Historic Places. If it receives the designation, it would be the first structure in the township to be awarded that distinction.
Early histories of the township list only the Dutch as the first European settlers, and Mr. Yuell said that he had not seen any material containing the names of early settlers. However, several buildings dating to the 1740's are still in use, including a former tavern at 4 Dey Place, which is now a private residence, and a house near Carnegie Lake, which has Revolutionary War cannonballs embedded in its foundation.
"The earliest-known settlement actually dates back to 1700 B.C.," Mr. Yuell said. "In 1982, native American artifacts were turned up during excavations for a roadbed. An archeological dig was conducted, which turned up 25,000 artifacts. The most important finds were the remnants of four 15-by-20-foot structures. Although we don't know who those ancient settlers were, it does constitute a settlement."
THE township was a sleepy, nondescript farming community until 1897, when the Walker-Gordon Dairy Farm was started. It eventually included 2,400 acres, making it the largest dairy in the world. The facility was closed in 1971. Afterwards, the land was farmed or used for grazing beef cattle. The site, on the western end of town, has since been sold to a developer for housing construction.
Many of Plainsboro's present corporations are situated in the 1,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center on the western side of town. Nearby is the Princeton Forrestal Village, an upscale factory outlet center off Route 1. The township has three shopping centers, each of which contains a supermarket and a strip of stores. The closest large mall is the Quakerbridge Mall in Lawrence Township, five miles to the south.
Plainsboro has nine public parks, the largest of which is the 80-acre Community Park off Scotts Corner Road, which has three baseball diamonds and two soccer fields. One of the most unusual recreation facilities is the Delaware and Raritan Canal Park off Mapleton Road. It is part of the old canal system built in 1831. The canal is open most of the year for boating and fishing. A bike path and picnic facilities will be added in the near future.
Also in town is the Princeton Meadows Golf and Country Club, an 18-hole, 6,100-yard golf course off Hunter's Glen Drive. Rates during weekdays for those who walk the course are $15 in winter and $30 during the regular season. Golf cart rental is an additional $14.

HEADLINE: Luxury Houses: Strong Market, Low Inventory

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A BLUE-CHIP investment for generations, real estate in high-income areas of the North Shore is experiencing a boomlet that is helping make six-figure salaries more common for top realty agents. Their only complaint is often a lack of inventory.
In a sign that enormous wealth continues to flow into one of the country's richest suburbs, real estate agents in exclusive North Shore villages and enclaves report a resilient market and increasing sales for the most expensive houses. 
 An increasing number of buyers, they said, are knocking down high-priced older houses and replacing them with new ones.
With the economy strong, housing prices stable, mortgage-interest rates low and new Federal tax exemptions that help encourage owners of expensive houses to sell, real estate professionals said they expected that this year would surpass even 1997 and 1996, both exceptionally good.
Agents and officials say young families, newly rich and often beneficiaries of the bull market on Wall Street, snap up houses and properties that cost $1 million, $2 million and higher, sometimes after bidding wars.
The demand for houses between $500,000 and $1 million has also been vigorous, with more than a few bidding wars, they said. Another show of wealth is a trend for buyers to raze expensive houses to build newer, even more expensive houses more to their taste.
"People are buying $900,000 ranch houses and tearing them down," Mayor Leonard Wurzel of Sands Point said. "I've been here 40 years and I've never seen anything like it."
In one case, Mr. Wurzel said, a family paid $2 million for a waterfront home in the village and was preparing to tear it down make way for a larger home.
The phenomenon is sweeping the Hamptons, and housing on farms and other open spaces is leading to the loss of the area's natural beauty, civic and environmental groups say.
The changes are also reportedly occurring in the Five Towns, where major renovations and razing of houses have also increased.
"The strangest thing they are doing here is buying houses in good locations and knocking them down," said Morton M. Haves of Hewlett Harbor, a Realtor in the Five Towns since 1947. "I can't believe my eyes. You see these Dumpsters all over."
The new wealth is also affecting affluent areas in Westchester County, southern Connecticut and New Jersey, said Marc M. Goloven, a senior regional economist for the Chase Manhattan Bank.
"There are strong indications that the suburbs of New York City are experiencing a boom in high-end housing because of the dramatic gains on Wall Street," Mr. Goloven said. "When you consider that $12 billion in bonuses will be paid out by Wall Street, that puts a lot of money in a lot of hands, and part of it is going into high-end real estate."
A regional economist, Thomas Conoscenti of Smithtown, said purchases of expensive houses showed long-term confidence in the region's future and helped assure it. "It's a good sign when people are buying upscale," Mr. Conoscenti said. "It means income levels are moving up, and people have an opportunity to put their money into something less volatile than the stock market."
Mr. Conoscenti said a history of rising property values on Long Island, and particularly in areas with expensive houses, made home ownership an exceptionally sound long-term investment.
The trend has been most pronounced on the North Shore, where villages like Matinecock, Lattingtown, Kings Point, Plandome, Plandome Manor, Muttontown, Laurel Hollow, Old Westbury and Sands Point are perennially ranked among the richest in the country.
Bonnie L. Devendorf, a vice president of a real estate company, Daniel Gale Associates, and manager of its office in Locust Valley, said sales had risen impressively in villages in that area.
"I have been in the business for 25 years and I have never seen anything like this," Mrs. Devendorf said. "There is no question these are among the best years we have ever had."
Luxury builders have returned to the market, she added, buying estates and subdividing and building expensive large-lot houses.
If there was softness in the North Shore market, some brokers said, it was in extremely expensive older estates and houses that reflect older architectural tastes.
Carole Belley, owner of Lovejoy Real Estate in Manhasset, said that meant relative bargains could be found in areas like Sands Point. A classic Tudor with a pool, tennis court and guest cottage on 4.2 acres that went on the market in September 1996 for $2.45 million closed last week for less than $2 million, she said, adding, "That house went for a song."
Mrs. Belley said that the under-$1 million market in the Manhasset and Port Washington areas featured "houses that come on in the 700's and 800's that are gone in a weekend."
Such prices are far above what most buyers on Long Island pay.
The Long Island Board of Realtors and the Multiple Listing Service listed the median sale price of a house in Nassau County as $185,000 in October, up from $179,000 in October 1996. In Suffolk, according to the figures, the median price was $149,000, up from $141,500 a year earlier.
In the North Shore prices rose 6 percent, and inventory fell 15 percent, signs of what the president of the Board of Realtors, Joseph L. Canfora, said was a buyer's market.
Mr. Canfora, owner of Century 21 Selmar Realty in East Islip, said the availability of 30-year fixed mortgages at 7 percent interest rates was stimulating the sales of midrange and lower-cost housing, where sales have also been strong. "We're seeing an increase in activity," he said. "Prices are starting to edge up a bit."
Promises by the state to lower electric rates and a pledge by Gov. George E. Pataki to lower school taxes are also helping the market, Mr. Canfora added.
Low-income to moderate housing remains in short supply, said Jim Morgo, executive director of the Long Island Housing Partnership, a developer in Hauppauge. "The good news is that the banks have really in an unprecedented way responded to the needs of the first-time home buyer," Mr. Morgo said. "There are great mortgage products out there, a great deal of flexibility for these buyers."
For owners of expensive houses, the Taxpayer Relief Act that President Clinton signed in August provides an incentive that may bring more such houses on the market. Under the new law, profits on the sale of a house up to $250,000 for an individual or $500,000 for a couple are exempt from Federal tax. The law has other requirements.
Previously sellers younger than 55 were taxed on profits that were not reinvested in new homes.
The exemption applies only to principal residences.
Realtors said it was too soon to tell whether the exemptions would lead to increased listings. But the buy-and-raze trend in communities like Sands Point is also occurring in the Hamptons and the Five Towns, Realtors in those areas said.
"People want specific locations, but they don't necessarily buy for the house," the president of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate in East Hampton, Melanie A. Ross, said. "They are buying for the address, tearing the houses down and building new ones."
The young newly rich families who are buying on the North Shore are at the leading edge of the Hamptons market, agents in East Hampton and Southampton said.
Other agents said other factors were also at work. "Wall Street is certainly a big part of the very high-end stuff, but, then, I have moved a whole block of guys over from Fire Island in the last few years," said Robert M. Lohman, an associate broker at Agawam Realty in Southampton.
Mr. Lohman said the Southampton inventory was tight, adding, "Everything is selling."
An owner of the Pugatch Realty Corporation in Woodmere, Susan Pugatch, said the strong Five Towns market was fueled by "young people from Brooklyn and Queens and people moving up within the neighborhood."
Mr. Haves said commercial areas of the Five Towns were "like a new Tel Aviv," reflecting a large Jewish population.
For that area and the North Shore proximity to New York City remains important. The Long island Rail Road reports ridership increased in 1996, to 74.4 million passengers, up from 70.2 million in 1992. Ridership through November 1997 was 1.7 percent higher than a year earlier, the L.I.R.R. said.
The railroad said that high employment levels in New York City partly explained the increase, but that noncommuting riders had shown the greatest growth.

HEADLINE: White Plains Center for Culture Makes Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THIS is a city rich in history and shopping dollars, a retail hub known as the birthplace of New York State. But even its boosters admit to a lackluster quality here, a blandness in place of charm and color, a silence where applause and laughter should enliven the night.
The city, taking a close look at itself, recently pinpointed its own lack of sparkle and allure. Art, culture and entertainment were the missing ingredients, said the Common Council, identifying the need for after-hours activity downtown. A marketing and development study conducted by an outside consultant reached the same conclusion in 1995. Several nightclubs have recently opened, raising hopes of a trend, and the possibility of a multiplex cinema to fill the movie vacuum is coming closer to reality. Debate on the optimal location of a multiplex has been going on since Macy's left its prime Mamaroneck Avenue corner 18 months ago. 
 Now, adding to the brew, the Music Conservatory of Westchester -- formerly the Westchester Conservatory of Music -- is moving ahead with a plan for a White Plains cultural center. The conservatory, currently on the the city's outskirts, would move to a downtown site shared by several other arts organizations whose focus is teaching. The Westchester Arts Council is also negotiating for prime space downtown. Although the plans of both the conservatory and the arts council are contingent on the policies of the new city administration, many are confident that a cultural flowering will take place in White Plains in the next five years.
"The concept is a necessity for downtown," said Margo Jones, executive director of the White Plains Business Development Corporation, a nonprofit corporation founded in 1995 to help revitalize the city. Ms. Jones said she is helping Laura Calzolari, executive director of the conservatory, and Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the arts council, in their efforts to broaden the cultural scope of the city. As the two leaders envision it, their organizations would anchor either end of an officially designated arts district much like those prospering in other cities across the United States.
Vince Ferrandino, planning and development consultant for Ferrandino & Associates, an Elmsford group conducting a $93,000 feasibility study for the conservatory, said there was widespread support for a one-stop, after-school cultural center for children in the city's main business district, where high-quality classes and supervised play might stimulate development in surrounding neighborhoods. "We have received strong and enthusiastic support from a lot of movers and shakers in banking, real estate and other interests peripheral to arts and culture," he said. "We have not heard a negative note."
Mr. Ferrandino, whose company conducted the 1995 marketing and development study for White Plains, said the conservatory's study, which has been financed in part by a grant of $46,000 from the National Endowment of the Arts, would be completed in April. The study will evaluate the potential impact of the proposed center on arts groups and the community, recommend the ideal mix of collaborating partners and gauge the effect of cultural activity on retail enterprise. It will also include a financial plan.
Susan Habel, Deputy Planning Commissioner for White Plains, said that while the Common Council had called for more arts and entertainment downtown, it was premature to talk about the city's role in such development. "The timing is bad," she said. "I don't know what the new administration envisions."
She said, however, that it was unlikely that the city could support one private group like the conservatory to the exclusion of other groups. She added that the performing arts programs sponsored by the public library and the school system were the city's first priorities. "We're waiting for the feasibility study," she said. "There are issues: the conservatory's needs versus all the community's needs."
Ms. Calzolari said a severe space squeeze had prompted the conservatory's plan to leave the 14,000-square-foot building on Soundview Avenue it has occupied since 1980. She said the 69-year-old school, which serves 2,500 students in outreach programs and at the Soundview Avenue site, needed at least 25,000 to 30,000 square feet to insure enough teaching and practice studios, rehearsal rooms and administrative offices. The school is considering the re-use of several existing buildings, including its first choice: a four-story, city-owned building a block from the old Macy's building on Church Street.
Many in the county's performing arts community have for decades clamored for a major new theater. Ms. Calzolari said, however, that the proposed cultural center would suit a different purpose. "Our future space needs are the driving force behind this," she said. "I need a new home."
The conservatory itself would select what Ms. Calzolari calls a consortium of partners for the center. The most likely candidates at present include a dance school and an interactive children's museum, she said. The plan also provides for ventures like a restaurant or coffee bar, a music or art supply store and a bookstore or recording studio. Potential educational and recreational uses of the center, she said, include a private day school, day-care services, a health club or a gymnastics program. Additional space may be set aside for a gallery and an arts library, a performance area, study lounges and a technology and media arts center.
Ms. Langsam said the arts council and the conservatory were jointly recommending an arts district in White Plains to dovetail with the city's urban-renewal efforts. It would encompass a rectangular area along Mamaroneck Avenue and Church Street, extending from Hamilton Avenue on one end to Maple Avenue on the other. Ms. Langsam, who served as the Deputy Commissioner of Cultural Affairs for New York City when city-owned buildings were converted to residential-and-work lofts for artists, said she envisions artists living and working in second-floor studios along Mamaroneck Avenue, while public sculptures in pocket parks would provide a respite for shoppers. "One way or another we'd also like to see a theater," Ms. Langsam added. "We think a 500-seat theater could be filled on a regular basis. Groups would kill for an opportunity to showcase their work in the hub."
Tishman Speyer Properties, the Manhattan-based company that is negotiating to buy the former Macy's building, wants to put a multiplex movie theater in the structure. A spokesman, Steven Rubenstein, said the company is also considering other art-related uses, which he declined to mention. The company hopes to close on the building by the end of March, Mr. Rubenstein said.
The arts council, which has been studying its space needs since moving downtown from Westchester Avenue last year, has been in negotiation with several organizations, including Tishman Speyer and Chase Manhattan Bank, to find exhibition or performance space for its affiliates here.
"Tishman Speyer and Chase and the arts council have been in discussions for nine months to see how theater and exhibition space can be made a part of the total block project on Mamaroneck Avenue," Ms. Langsam said.
Arts leaders and others said that present negotiations were at a delicate stage for renewal in this city, which in 1776 was the site of the provincial congress that adopted the resolution establishing the State of New York.
"White Plains in five years will be a very different looking place," Ms. Calzolari said. "These things have to be worked out soon, because later the space will be gone."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Golf Course-Housing Proposal Lands in the Rough

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
HOUSING built in conjunction with an exclusive golf course is fairly common in the South and Southwest. And a few have been built or are under construction in the Northeast, including two in Connecticut -- River Highlands in Cromwell and Silvermine Woods in Norwalk -- and Purchase Estates in Purchase in Westchester County, where an 18-hole golf course and a dozen of a projected 73 houses have been completed.
Now National Fairways, a golf-course developer based in Greenwich, has dipped a toe in Easton waters and found them a bit chilly. 
 The company's proposal to pay $14.1 million for 692 acres in Easton and 45 abutting acres in Weston on which to build a hundred $1-million-plus homes on 3-acre lots and an 18-hole championship golf course for the home buyers is meeting serious resistance because the land is part of the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company watershed.
The project, called Trout Brook Valley, is planned on land designated Class 3 by the Water Supply Division of the state's Department of Public Health -- meaning that it is beyond the drainage area of the reservoirs, and classed as surplus acreage. Nevertheless, the nonprofit Connecticut Fund for the Environment in New Haven, Easton's Conservation Commission, the Town of Weston and most of the more than 250 people who attended a public hearing on the matter on Dec. 22 want the property preserved as open space.
"The development would shoot a hole into the center of 10 square miles of protected land, fragmenting Bridgeport Hydraulic's Class 1 and 2 land, and land protected by the Aspetuck Land Trust, Nature Conservancy, and Redding Land Trust," said Gail Bromer, a member of the Easton Conservation Commission and chairwoman of the town's Open Space Committee.
Class 1 and 2 lands cannot be sold because they include reservoirs or surround reservoirs and drain into them. Class 3 land is beyond the drainage area, considered surplus and off-watershed.
"When we bought these lands from 1910 to 1930," said Daniel Neaton, vice president of real estate for the water company, "we were not sure how much Greater Bridgeport would grow. We never had a specific use for Trout Brook Valley. We don't think it would even be a good water storage area, although there was talk about it at one time."
The company, he said, needs the proceeds from prior, current and future sales of surplus land to help finance a $100 million, federally mandated system of five filtration plants that it has built in its Fairfield and Litchfield County service areas.
And National Fairways says there is a big demand for its product. "Any big name private golf course has a waiting list of five to 10 years," said Marc Bergschneider, its president. "It's impossible to get into a good club at any price."
He said that Easton and Weston had the kind of profile he seeks out. "They are rich towns where nothing is being built under $700,000," Mr. Bergschneider added.
GOLF memberships will cost $100,000, he said, and 20 deposits on preconstruction memberships of $80,000 -- refundable if the course is not built -- have already been received. Twenty town residents, Mr. Bergschneider said, "will be permitted to play on Mondays, when we are closed, at $250 a day."
An alternative for the towns would be to purchase the land themselves. "If they are able to buy we're out," said Mr. Bergschneider, "but the likelihood is close to zero."
State statutes give towns, land trusts and the state's Department of Environmental Protection the right of first refusal to buy water-company-owned property for sale. But William J. Kupinse, Easton's First Selectman, acknowledged that there was no fund set aside for this. "There would have to be a request for an appropriation to be voted on by Town Meeting," he said.
Weston, according to George Guidera, its First Selectman, has been negotiating to buy its portion, but is unable to agree on a price. "This is a significant property," said Mr. Guidera. "If Easton doesn't buy, that has nothing to do with our purchase. If Easton is looking for a contribution they should come to us with a proposal."
Mr. Kupinse and Ms. Bromer noted that at the December public hearing Paul Newman, the actor and philanthropist whose home is in Westport, offered to start a fund for purchasing the property with a pledge of $500,000, to be paid in $100,000 installments over five years.
Darice O'Mara, the actor's personal assistant, said from Mr. Newman's New York office that he had expressed concern for the low level of open space in Connecticut, the protection of drinking and the lack of water studies to determine need far into the future.
National Fairways, a developer of more than a dozen golf courses along the Eastern Seaboard, will appear before the Easton Planning and Zoning Commission tomorrow to support its application for a special-use permit for the golf course. While the housing complies with current two-acre zoning, a hearing on the subdivision is scheduled for Jan. 26.
Under scrutiny are a proposed road width of 24 feet instead of the state standard of 30 feet, and the number of homes on a dead end street, both considered impediments to adequate fire and police protection.
In addition, a complex series of applications and approvals from the two towns' Conservation and Inland Wetlands Commissions, the state Departments of Health, Environmental Protection and Public Utility Control and the Army Corps of Engineers must be processed before the land can change hands and the project move forward. Without the utility-control agency's decision, which is not expected until March 4, no other decisions are enforceable.
"When any utility sells land we look at whether it is required for service," said Beryl Lyons, spokeswoman for the agency. "Common sense tells us that it may not be needed now, but may be needed tomorrow. As an agency concerned with the economics of public utilities, we must look at two independent appraisals submitted by the utility as to the fair market value."
If the sale is approved, she said, her agency would determine the split of future profits between shareholders and rate payers. "In the case of recreational use, including golf courses, the greater portion goes to the shareholders," she said.
Bridgeport Hydraulic, the largest privately owned water company in the state, filed its application to sell its 667.93 acres last Oct. 6. The remainder of the land is owned by the utility's parent, Aquarion of Bridgeport, which was strongly criticized by the Connecticut Fund for the Environment for a perceived conflict of interests.
Aquarion's contract to sell its land, which is exempt from Department of Utility Control review because it is owned by a holding company, not a utility, had options that would allow the holding company to become a part owner of the golf course by taking all of its payment in shares. "It decided to take cash rather than equity," said Larry Bingaman, vice president of corporate relations for Bridgeport Hydraulic. The contract also calls for five memberships in the golf club for top officials of Aquarion.
An additional 160-acre tract of Class 3 watershed land owned by the United Water Company in New Milford has been targeted by the Meadowbrook Golf Company of Chicago for development as a public golf course. "It's in the conceptual stage," said New Milford's Mayor, Arthur J. Peitler. No public hearings have been held to date.
"The alternative," said the Mayor, "could be 85 houses. There would be a clubhouse, possibly a pool and minimal housing, keeping demand for town services low. There would be benefits in cash flow that we would split with the water company in a partnership. People here would get some breaks on greens fees, but membership fees would not be high."
According to Mr. Bergschneider, Trout Brook Valley would provide Easton with $1.5 million a year in homeowners' real estate taxes of $15,000 to $20,000 a year, plus the golf club's taxes.
"We have not gone into a depth analysis of town services required," said First Selectman Kupinse. "It is likely to be tax positive, but who knows what the market for high-priced homes and $100,000 golf memberships will be in two years, when they plan to start construction?"

HEADLINE: Another Familiar Name Quits Downtown Pittsburgh

BYLINE: By CHRISS SWANEY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
REFRIGERATORS, power generators and railroad air brakes were all made here by Westinghouse. But by late 1998, the corporate headquarters that once housed more than 1,000 employees will be home to only 60 as Westinghouse, which acquired CBS Corporation two years ago, completes its transition into a pure media company.
For years, the 23-story, black aluminum and glass structure known as known as the "black box" by employees at 11 Stanwix Street was one of the few holdout headquarters amid the exodus of other Fortune 500 corporations. At one time, Pittsburgh was home to 14 Fortune 500 corporations, but now only a handful still call the old industrial city home. Downtown Pittsburgh's streets now are eerily quiet after 6 P.M., once the 140,000 daytime corporate workers have fled for suburban homes. 
 One after another over the years, major national industrial companies that grew to maturity here -- including Gulf Oil and Koppers Corporation -- have moved away or reorganized or changed in a way that has shifted their business from the imposing downtown headquarters building that once housed them. Now such concerns are being raised about Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which purchased CBS in November 1995 for $5.4 billion and changed its name to CBS Corporation last month. . The company has also moved its headquarters to New York City.
Already, the former Westinghouse has reduced its presence at the headquarters building to 450 employees and put its remaining industrial businesses under the banner of Westinghouse Electric Company or Welco, for short, until a new owner is named.
That's because under a revised separation strategy, the company said that it was abandoning plans to spin off its industrial businesses into a new company that would have kept the old Westinghouse name. Instead, it will sell them piecemeal or as a group by the middle of 1998. In December, the company sold its power-generation business for $1.53 billion to German conglomerate Siemens A.G.
Still, the path the former Westinghouse is taking contrasts strikingly with the approach taken by other corporate giants who have left the city. Westinghouse is leaving with more of a whimper than a bang.
"Westinghouse has been an absentee landlord since the 1980's, so their leaving will not be as significant a loss as the loss of our steel mills," said Dennis Unkovic, a partner at the Pittsburgh-based law firm of Meyer Unkovic & Scott LLP.
He was quick to add, however, that some of the company's remaining industrial businesses might fare a lot better without Westinghouse. "They can now focus operations on serving and fueling nuclear plants that they designed in the early 1980's -- Westinghouse accounts for almost half of the 110 nuclear plants in the United States," he said. Jeffrey Williams, a strategy professor at Carnegie Mellon University's business school, says Pittsburgh will survive because the region "is becoming a 'silicon valley' for high-tech start-ups."
AMONG such companies that have set up operations in or near Pittsburgh, he said, are Fore Systems, an Internet software maker; Transarc, a computer software subsidiary of I.B.M., and Respironics, a high-tech health-care products manufacturer. In all, 3,600 start-up high-techcompanies have created 100,000 jobs in the last decade, according to a report last fall by the Pittsburgh High-Tech Council.
But to retain this emerging high-tech industry and its employees, real estate brokers say the city needs to add upscale restaurants, shops and more space for start-ups, which typically require no more than 40,000 square feet. To provide such space, the former Westinghouse is spending $500,000 a floor to get space ready for new tenants at its 420,000-square-foot building, where existing tenants lease about 10 percent of the space.
Brokers say the Westinghouse headquarters building comes on the market just as other older former Fortune 500 headquarters buildings are still seeking tenants. The Koppers Corporation, an industrial products manufacturer, today occupies only 15 percent of the 459,000-square-foot building on Grant Street that once was its headquarters. Eighty percent of the building is leased by law firms and small service companies.
Next door to the Koppers Building is the former headquarters of the Gulf Oil Corporation, which was once among Pittsburgh's biggest employers. The Chevron Corporation, based in San Francisco, acquired Gulf in 1984. The oil company has no presence in the 44-story structure, though the building is still known as the Gulf Tower. About 80 percent of the building is leased by Transarc, the software maker, and there is a scattering of other small tenants.
One advantage that the Westinghouse headquarters building will find in leasing space or in selling it is a 450-car garage in the building, according to brokers.
"Other large buildings waiting to be leased or on the sales block do not have parking garages," said Peter Sukernek, general manager of Howard Hanna Commercial Services, a regional real-estate brokerage.
Space in the Westinghouse headquarters building comes on the market at a time when 3.5 million square feet of downtown office space is already available. The vacancy rate amounts to 13.7 percent overall, according to Grubb and Ellis, the national real estate firm. Brokers say the aim is to have the vacancy rate drop to between 7 or 8 percent in 1998.
WESTINGHOUSE has been identified with Pittsburgh since 1886, when George Westinghouse began manufacturing air brakes for the railroads. Over the years, the company not only built its headquarters in the city but also developed manufacturing plants for power-generation equipment, research laboratories, training centers and offices for support staff.
At its height in the mid-80's Westinghouse had 12 million square feet of space in buildings in Greater Pittsburgh. CBS Corporation now has 5 million square feet in the area.
"It will still take some time to sort out the future of all our real estate, but we do not plan a fire sale," said John Coulter, real estate director of CBS Corporation.
At the same time, the former Westinghouse has been trying to dispose of many other properties. The company's 138,000-square-foot training center about seven miles east of downtown, which will be vacant in March, is on the market along with 12.2 acres of underdeveloped land. In its heyday it housed about 450 workers who worked on panel boards for nuclear power plants. A million-square-foot technology center in the suburb of Churchill has been on the market for several months. Its sole tenant, Northrop Grumman Corporation, took 180,000 square feet in November 1996.
A 165,349-square-foot research facility near Forest Hills, five miles east of Pittsburgh, is up for sale. The three-story research lab, which sits on 11.7 acres, was built in the 20's.
The former Westinghouse also plans to jettison its 14-acre recreation center site off of Greensburg Pike and is considering donating it to the borough and a group trying to develop a national broadcasting museum rather than selling it for development.
Just last year, Alcoa donated its 31-story, 442,500-square-foot corporate headquarters building to several downtown economic development groups. Alcoa is building a new $40-million, 236,200-square-foot, six-story headquarters on the Allegheny River in Pittsburgh's North Side. The new building, which is scheduled to open in July, is designed for 400 employees. The company now has 1,500 employees at Alcoa's old Sixth Avenue headquarters building erected in 1952. Most of them will be dispersed to office space elsewhere in the city.
Other moves that are expected to help soften the blow of the Westinghouse departure include some new tenant leases and major commercial construction. PNC Bank recently announced plans to build a 400,000-square-foot operation center on the site of the old Baltimore & Ohio Railroad terminal on Grant Street and First Avenue, downtown. PNC Bank also is taking 350,000 square feet of office space at the USX Tower (the former U.S. Steel Tower, built in 1967) on Grant Street -- the high-profile, 64-story office tower has been plagued with office vacancies for more than a decade. With PNC, the occupancy rate in the building will top 90 percent for the first time since 1982.
Construction also has begun on a new 250,000-square-foot Lazarus department store with a 500-car parking garage below. The store will be on the block bounded by Wood Street, Fifth Avenue, Oliver Street and Smithfield Street near other major stores. City officials also have quietly contracted with Chicago-based Urban Retail Properties Company to try to add more upscale shops and restaurants downtown.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Near Downtown New Brunswick, More Housing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago two developers began transforming 6.6 cleared acres not far from New Brunswick's reviving downtown into housing. The original concept called for an enclave of for-sale town houses.
But now plans are in place for the final phase of the redevelopment, which when completed in 1999 will be an element of a mostly market-rate rental community. 
 Construction of the 82 rental apartments, Richmond Court, and 7 town houses with 15 units that will make up the $12.5 million final component is expected to start by this spring, contingent upon receiving approvals. They will join a 5-story, 117-unit rental building, Riverwatch Commons, and 14 other town houses with 18 units now on the site, near the Hyatt Regency Hotel in the Hiram Market area next to northbound Route 18. The total town-house component is called Townhomes at Hiram Square.
When the last element is completed and occupied there will be about 400 people living in the area, said Christopher J. Paladino, president of the nonprofit New Brunswick Development Corporation, which is developing the new rentals with the Applied Companies of Hoboken. Applied, which completed the Riverwatch Commons rental building last May, is developing the new town houses alone.
Mr. Paladino said that slow sales of the first 18 town houses that his group and an earlier private developer had built made it clear that "people were not willing to make a commitment to buy." So two and a half years ago "we seized the opportunity to do rentals, which still gets people with middle incomes to the downtown," he added.
More than $700 million worth of public and private investment has risen in this Middlesex County seat's downtown since its revitalization began in 1975, according to the city's Department of Planning, Policy and Economic Development.
It now has a wide array of new stores, restaurants and office buildings. Among the latter are Johnson & Johnson's corporate headquarters as well as academic and medical buildings for Rutgers University, St. Peter's Medical Center and the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital.
More is under way, including Liberty Plaza, a 130,000-square-foot building rising on George Street at Liberty Street for the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. The $44 million project also has 15,000 square feet of retail space.
Bringing upscale housing downtown has been a slower process. What the new rental structure shows is that "we are building on a sense of community that turned a once bleak tract into a thriving downtown community," Mayor James M. Cahill said in a statement when he announced the project at a news conference last November.
COMPLETING the transformation of the 6.6-acre site is also important because it opens up the opportunity to redevelop two other nearby parcels. All three are part of a larger effort conceived in the 80's by local officials to create a residential neighborhood that would draw upper-middle-class people back to the city.
The plan, which at one point called for a mix of some 500 residences in a $130-million project called Riverwatch, has had its share of challenges. Among them were a long land acquisition process and the collapse of the housing market in the late 80's, which affected the early town houses at the first redevelopment site.
The other sites edging the Raritan River on the opposite side of Route 18 -- a 14-acre site occupied by the city's police headquarters and the 2.5 acre Old City Dock tract -- still await plans for renewal.
The same is true for an additional seven downtown acres that were not part of the original Riverwatch plan. Mr. Paladino said that a new master plan was being drawn up for the three sites, adding that it was expected to be presented to the city by the end of February. Preliminary discussions, he said, center on a mix of uses, ranging from an entertainment complex to office and retail space, to a marina and additional housing.
The shift to market-rate rental housing at the initial downtown site came in 1995 when the Applied Companies began building the five-story rental building, called RiverWatch Commons. At the time the market for such a development had been untested in New Brunswick, where no sizable new market-rate rental projects had taken shape in 30 years.
But Joseph J. Cicala, a vice president at Applied, said that his company "believed young professionals would be attracted to living close to downtown" and that the demand for rentals was -- and still is -- strong in the state. Additionally, he said, financing is more readily available for rental housing than for town houses, adding that the city's demographics supported rentals.
That was borne out at Riverwatch Commons. Three months after it was completed all 117 of the one- and two-bedroom apartments, with 700 to 1,000 square feet of space, were leased at rents of $875 to $1,400 a month.
The market that project attracted -- young professionals working in the city or living in the area and commuting to work in Manhattan -- is also expected to be drawn to the new rentals, Mr. Cicala said and added: "The first project allowed us to create a market, a critical mass; and now there is the potential to continue our efforts."
The size of the apartments and rents are expected to be on a par with those at RiverWatch. But the units will be in two three-story structures that will echo the scale of the existing, as well as the new, town house structures.
The new town houses, like the old ones, will have brick and stone facades. They will contain two- and three-bedroom apartments on one to three levels and with 1,200 to 2,100 square feet of space. Prices are expected to range from $179,000 to $250,000.
Applied has not ruled out converting the 82 rentals into condominiums. "It is important for New Brunswick to build for-sale housing," Mr. Cicala said. "The city is not ready for it now, but that is not to say there will not be a market sometime in the future."
Mr. Paladino agreed and added that the second goal of the Riverwatch plan -- to get middle-income buyers to invest in the area -- will happen, albeit in a more methodical way. The new master plan is being designed to meet the realities of the late 90's, he added, noting that traffic, environmental and market issues posed challenges, especially to the redevelopment of the riverfront tracts.
Meanwhile, improvements to Boyd Park, stretching for a mile and a half along the river, were completed recently and work is under way to refurbish the Delaware and Raritan Canal and towpath as well as to create new car and pedestrian roads. The $11.7 million in improvements will make the linear greenway and the waterfront accessible to the city.
As for the riverfront sites targeted for renewal, plans are to relocate the police headquarters by May 1999 to a site along Livingston Avenue at the southern end of downtown, which is now occupied by a post office. All but the facade of the post office will be demolished and replaced by a four-story 133,708 square foot building that will house the police station as well as the municipal court, the Middlesex County Prosecutor's office and several city departments.
That building and a 118,743-square-foot structure to be built across the street and house county administrative offices would complete Civic Square, another downtown redevelopment. Already in place is a 160,000-square-foot Rutgers academic building.
What ultimately will rise on both sites is unclear. A mix of uses, including a hotel, a marina and additional housing, rather than just housing, is being considered, said Mr. Paladino.
"We want to capitalize on the momentum in place," he said. "It is an opportunity that may not be there in the next decade."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3378 words

HEADLINE: It Was the Year of 'Let's Make a Deal'

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
A FEW years ago real estate executives were coining slogans like "Stay alive till 95" and "Find something to do until 20-02" that expressed the difficulty of operating in a market that was sluggish at best. Today, nobody has the time to think up clever sayings. They are too busy making deals.
"It's been a phenomenal year, the best we have seen on the service side of the business since 1989," said Steven A. Swerdlow, executive vice president in charge of CB Commercial's New York office. Prime space in midtown office towers, Mr. Swerdlow said, has all but disappeared. "In the top 65 buildings," he said, "we are down to a 3 percent vacancy rate, which we have not seen since 1981." 
 The prosperity has been widespread. The downtown Manhattan office market, considered so feeble that a special city incentive program was designed for it in 1995, was host to the five biggest leasing deals of the year. One such deal, the Goldman, Sachs lease at 10 Hanover Square, involved a building that had been considered for conversion to residential use. As a result, many executives expect to see the pace of conversion slow as landlords seek to market their properties as offices.
Out in the suburbs, speculative office building is already under way in northern New Jersey, and local specialists say they expect one or more projects to get under way in Stamford, Conn., this year.
A new office tower is rising between 42d and 43d Streets along Broadway, and another Times Square building is expected at the northwest corner of 42d and Broadway for the Reuters news organization. Bear, Stearns is making plans to put up a new headquarters on the east blockfront of Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Street now occupied by the long-vacant 383 Madison.
These activities are renewing interest in other possible development sites, some well known and others, such as one on Third Avenue between 43d and 44th Streets using the air rights over St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church, that have been little discussed until recently.
The Columbus Circle site now occupied by the Coliseum and the site now used as a parking lot on the half block on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets are probably the most prominent uncommitted sites, along with two remaining Times Square properties that are being marketed by their owner, the Prudential Insurance Company.
"Those Times Square parcels will be developed within a year," said Jeffrey Katz, the president of Sherwood Equities, which manages the building at 1 Times Square. A group led by Mr. Katz sold the triangular building where the ball drops on New Year's Eve for a record $1,100 a square foot last year.
A developer is expected to be designated for the Columbus Circle location from a list that includes Millennium Partners, Tishman-Speyer Properties and a partnership involving Bruce C. Ratner, Donald Brodsky and Peter M. Lehrer. Officials of the Rockefeller Group, which controls the Seventh Avenue plot, invariably referred to as "Rock West," say they expect to sign an anchor tenant in the first half of this year for a new building they would develop.
Other possible office building sites include 310 Madison, at the southwest corner of 42d Street. Researchers at CB Commercial found that the owner, Harry Macklowe, can empty the building if it is scheduled for demolition, so he could move quickly if the right tenant came along.
The Durst family, which is building the 1.6 million-square-foot tower designated 4 Times Square, also controls property to the east, although it is missing a critical L-shaped parcel at the corner of Avenue of the Americas and 42d Street. Douglas Durst, the president of the company, said he had not given up on acquiring the parcel, but said that if unsuccessful, he would go ahead with a midblock building sometime after 2000.
A few blocks to the east, the church of St. Agnes, now being rebuilt after a 1992 fire, occupies a site in the middle of the block between 43d and 44th Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues. To the west is an office tower designated 425 Lexington. To the east is a group of low-rise houses that developers have been eyeing for years as the site of an office tower. Adding the air rights from the church could improve the economics of such a project, if the land can be assembled, CB Commercial's researchers reported.
It may take years for these possible projects to be built. Some, like the Coliseum, appear likely to go ahead quickly, while others will require a lot more things to fall into place before the start of any building. Among them are development on the Ninth Avenue side of the Post Office building at 34th Street and over the Port Authority building at 42d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. But the fact that people are blowing the dust off old plans and figuring out ways to get them done is an indication of how sharply the market has turned in the last few years and how executive mindsets have shifted from trying to stay afloat to changing the skyline again.
Here is how the different sectors of the commercial real estate market performed last year, and the outlook for 1998.
 
Midtown Offices
Lower Vacancy Rate And Higher Rents
Vacancy rates in Class A office buildings in midtown fell to 8.5 percent in December, compared to almost 12 percent a year earlier, while average asking rents, including both direct rentals and sublets, increased to $40.68 from $38.82, according to figures compiled by RELocate, a real estate information company.
These averages understate the kind of prices being paid by tenants who want the best locations in the Plaza District, generally defined as the area bounded by 45th and 59th Streets and Third and Fifth Avenues.
"We are seeing rentals in the $50 to $60 per square foot range, with some reaching as high as $70," said Robert Emden, an executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis New York. In addition, he said, the period of free rent for a new tenant while the interior construction work is performed was no more than six months now, and the amount of construction a landlord is willing to do is no more than $35 to $40 a square foot, compared to 18 months of free rent and $60 a square foot in construction allowances when tenants had the upper hand.
He said that since no new office space had been built for years, demand was outrunning supply. "It is a struggle to come up with space," he said. "You have to get to it before it hits the market."
High prices in the prime midtown core will drive tenants to places they might not have considered before, executives say. "People will move when rates get high," said James D. Kuhn, the president of Newmark & Company Real Estate. "We saw that happen in the 70's and 80's when rates peaked."
Mr. Kuhn said office users would warm to the charms of the Jersey City waterfront, Metrotech in Brooklyn, and Stamford as the differential in rental rates grew. The prices will also effect the pattern of development in Manhattan as well, he said, citing the recent activities of owners, including real estate investment trusts such as Vornado Realty Trust.
"Vornado is paying about $420 million for One Penn Plaza, which would have been unheard of not too long ago," Mr. Kuhn said. He said the price implied that the New Jersey-based REIT felt it could get rents in the range of $30 to $40 a square foot.
He said Vornado's other investments in the area near 34th Street and Eighth Avenue showed it was confident the area would attract a higher caliber of tenant than it does now, and pricier retail stores. "Penn Plaza is going to take its place alongside Times Square and Grand Central" as hubs of activity in the city, Mr. Kuhn said.
Of course, good news for owners can be bad news for tenants. "In this market, owners can get away with murder," said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, which represents tenants. "It is much more difficult now for tenants, and you are going to see companies leave the city."
 
Downtown Offices
Rise in Leasing May Cut Conversions
Like a dozen or so older office buildings near the lower tip of Manhattan thought to be no longer suitable for use as modern office space, the structure at 10 Hanover Square was scheduled for conversion to residential use. Before the conversion could begin, the big financial services firm of Goldman, Sachs reached an agreement to lease all 522,089 square feet of it.
After years in the doldrums, office leasing in the downtown area picked up sharply last year, prompting some owners to reconsider plans for conversions.
Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate, said the reason for the quick comeback of Downtown is that alternatives of the past are unavailable. "In the 80's when pressure built up in midtown, 50 million square feet of light assembly space in Midtown South was converted to office," he said. "Now there is no Midtown South to convert, so Downtown is the bargain overflow area. But it is going to run out."
Six of the biggest leasing transactions of the year took place below Canal Street, including the decision by Standard & Poor's to lease over 930,000 square feet at 55 Water Street.
"Standard & Poor's made a commitment, and that was a catalyst transaction," said Frank A. Cento, a senior director in Cushman & Wakefield's downtown office. "That made other companies realize they had to make commitments as well, and it kicked off a lot of activity."
That activity included Merrill Lynch's purchasing of a 760,000-square-foot building at 222 Broadway (at Fulton Street), the city's Human Resources Administration taking 483,000 square feet at 180 Water Street and, at year's end, Empire Blue Cross-Blue Shield signing for 449,000 square feet at 1 World Trade Center.
Despite the flurry of leasing activity, some executives note that downtown is still based on financial services, and say that a sharp correction in the stock market could produce plenty of empty space quickly again, as it has in the past. "Downtown is a single-industry town," said Anthony E. Malkin, president of W&M Properties, which develops and manages commercial ventures.
 
Investment Sales
REIT's Grow In Importance
On Oct. 3, NRK Management paid $115 million to buy the building at 810 Seventh Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets. Before the year was out, the company had resold it for $143.4 million to Tower Realty Trust, earning a profit of $28.4 million in just 67 days.
"We are long-term holders and we had no intention of selling," said Adam Hochfelder, vice president of NRK, whose president is Richard Kalikow. "The only way I can describe it is to say that they made us an offer that we couldn't refuse."
According to Darcy Stacom, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield and a prominent sales broker, the sales of 810 Seventh and 100 Wall Street, which also turned over in less than a year at a substantial profit, were the most significant of the year because they demonstrated the growing importance of real estate investment trusts in New York.
Tower, which bought 100 Wall for $58.5 million from the Witkoff Group, which had paid $37 million earlier in the year, became a publicly traded REIT this year and evidently felt the need to make acquisitions quickly to meet Wall Street's performance goals. "We had to close by 5 P.M. on Dec. 31, and that's what happened," Mr. Hochfelder said.
Tower, the former Feldman Equities, is one of the new REIT's making their presence felt in the New York market. Others include S. L. Green, which is targeting Class B office buildings that can be upgraded, and Boston Properties, which also sold its initial public offering this year and promptly bought 280 Park Avenue at 48th Street for $321 million and 875 Third Avenue at 52d Street for $210 million.
Not a new REIT but an increasing factor in the city is Vornado Realty Trust, which purchased Bernard Mendik's portfolio of Manhattan office towers and is investing in buildings near Penn Station, which is emerging as the southern anchor of a district being revitalized by the changes in Times Square at the north end.
"There is a lot of capital chasing deals," Ms. Stacom acknowledged, but argued that the economic fundamentals in the city were good.
"Interest rates are low, office vacancies are low and the city is prosperous," she said. "There is a lot to drive up values, and we have a ways to go before we get back to 1980's prices."
Industry analysts say what is happening in New York is part of a national trend. Dennis Yeskey, managing director of Deloitte & Touche's real estate practice in the New York metropolitan area, said that public consolidation of the real estate market was just beginning. "It's the same process that other industries went through in decades past," he said. Real estate is such huge asset class, he said, that even investments of hundreds of billions nationally represent only a few percentage points of the total.
Because New York is a complex market with large individual assets, Mr. Yeskey said, some REIT's felt the need to grow and gain experience in smaller markets before investing here. "They rehearsed out of town before opening in New York," he said. But he said they would be an increasing presence in the market.
 
Suburbs, Other Boroughs
Building in Jersey, Not in Westchester
The development picture in New York's suburbs is decidedly uneven. Office buildings are going up in Parsippany, Florham Park, East Hanover and other locations in New Jersey and there are stirrings along the Jersey City waterfront facing lower Manhattan.
But north of the city, in Westchester County, there does not seem to be anyone willing to put a shovel in the ground. Rocked by corporate downsizings and departures, the county still has an overhang of vacant space, and what activity is taking place is rehabilitation to upgrade existing structures.
Right now the big question marks are hanging over Fairfield County, Conn., and particularly Stamford, where three development sites for office buildings that could total nearly 1.5 million square feet are just about ready for construction to begin. The problem is lining up an anchor tenant who would commit to leasing a substantial portion of a new building.
"This market has shifted," said Jeffrey H. Newman, a senior vice president and manager of the Fairfield office of W&M Properties. "It's less of a corporate headquarters for Fortune 500 companies and more of a place for insurance and information technology companies. Most of the leases we are doing are in the 5,000 to 10,000 square foot range."
Local real estate officials say it is unlikely that any of the projects, which include a cleared site facing Stamford Town Center, will proceed until those elusive anchor tenants can be found. Two of the big companies that decided to move to Stamford recently did not help in this regard. Swiss Bank is building its own headquarters and Zurich RE took over the old headquarters of GTE Corporation.
In the boroughs outside Manhattan, substantial office development is unlikely, although stores like Home Depot, Kmart and Price Costco are finding new locations. The reason, said Joshua Muss, the president of Muss Development Company, is that building costs are almost as high as in Manhattan, but office tenants are unwilling to pay Manhattan rents.
Mr. Muss, who is building Renaissance Plaza, which includes Brooklyn's first new hotel in decades, said that with tax incentives from the city, downtown Brooklyn could have a big future as an office alternative to New Jersey. "Taxes and union pay scales are based on Manhattan, but you can't get Manhattan rents" he said. "You need $30 a foot to make a project pay, but you can't get it."
 
Retail
Rental Rates Hitting the Roof
Rental rates for prime retail space have gone so high that further increases are unlikely, retail real estate specialists say. But even so, there is demand for the large spaces that are likely to become available this year at Rockefeller Center and later at the old Alexander's site at Lexington Avenue and 58th Street and at the Coliseum site on Columbus Circle.
"They are getting $400 a foot on Madison Avenue, $500 a foot on Fifth Avenue and $250 a foot in midtown," said Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director at Garrick-Aug Associates, referring to the annual cost of a square foot of space in a store. "They have gone up so much over the last few years that I don't see them going up by much more than 5 percent in the first quarter and then leveling off in the second."
Alan Victor, executive vice president of Lansco Corporation, said that the biggest problem in the Madison and Fifth Avenue area was finding space, that demand far exceeded supply.
"These days you have to be ahead of the market by developing locations," Mr. Victor said. This often involves buying out the leases of existing tenants and moving them to new locations to accommodate new entrants.
He said one of the big events of the year was expected to be the announcement of the long-awaited plan to redevelop the retail space at Rockefeller Center. Although the center draws millions of visitors a year, the retail space has largely been occupied by small shops, and management has made it clear that it plans to combine the below-ground concourse with the street and upper levels to create space for large destination stores.
"They are going to create a mega shopping area there that will transform the place," Mr. Victor said.
He said he also expected plans for the Alexander's site to be made public this year, with the anticipation that the former department store would be redeveloped by its owner Vornado as a mixed-use building with 300,000 square feet of retail space and 500,000 square feet of living space on the upper floors. Redeveloping the long-closed store would bring new vitality to the neighborhood, something other retailers are already seeking to capitalize on.
"There are a couple of vacancies on 58th Street, and my phone has been melting," Mr. Victor said.
Despite city restrictions on development, retail specialists said they expected to see the continued spread in the city of "big-box" stores -- large spaces devoted to limited categories of merchandise.
"Rockefeller Center is one of the few places with the kind of size that retailers want," Ms. Consolo observed. "But you will also see things like a big Crate and Barrel downtown."
Michael N. Hirshfeld, director of the retail program at Equis of New York, noted that another retail phenomenon, the off-price outlet mall, was creeping closer to the city. Bargain hunters new have to drive about 50 miles to get to Woodbury Common, near Harriman, N.Y. "Metro Mall, a 1.3-million-square-foot outlet mall, is under construction in Elizabeth, which is within 20 miles of the city," he said "It looks like a home run."
 
Hotels
Occupancy Rates And Prices Up
With a booming economy and an influx of tourists to what is now perceived as a safe, vibrant city, New York's hotels filled almost to capacity. According to a study prepared by Coopers & Lybrand's lodging and gaming group, hotel occupancy last year was a record 85.5 percent, and the average room rate increased 9 percent to $175 a night.
Analysts say they do not expect the occupancy rate to increase much this year because of the lack of available rooms, although room rates may increase as hotel operators use the high demand as an opportunity to push prices upward. In spite of the demand, and an increasing flurry of proposals to convert existing buildings to hotels, not a huge quantity of new rooms are likely to reach the market soon. If all the most likely projects happen, they would add about 1,700 new rooms, which would not make much of a splash in a market that already has about 65,000 rooms, according to Coopers & Lybrand.
Tourist-class hotels, which charge under $100 a night, experienced the most growth in occupancy last year, up 7.2 percent, while the two top luxury categories were flat or down. Analysts attribute this to some travelers reducing their standards as rates for convention and first-class hotels increased, and to the attractiveness of New York to visitors on tight budgets.
