HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT;
Threatened Creatures Slowing Some Construction to a Turtle's Pace

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
With the economy healthy, building is going on all over the the state, but in some instances the building of homes, commercial developments or roads is in conflict with the desire to protect the animals and plants that help give the state its special character. It is the job of the state Department of Environmental Protection to see that the animals and plants can live with the construction that keeps the state moving and growing, but it often takes time to work out the details.
For example, the last 1.5 miles of a 7.5-mile stretch of four-lane highway under construction around Freehold will be delayed at least a year in order to give Monmouth County officials time to realign the road to bypass a swampy area where bog turtles live. The bog turtle, a 4.5-inch-long brown turtle with a yellow, orange or reddish blotch on each side of its head, is considered "endangered" by the state government and "threatened" (a lower level of alert) by the Federal government. Monmouth County officials had hoped to advertise for bids for the last section of the Route 33 bypass in the spring, said Michael F. Barrett, director of the county department of public works and engineering, but will probably now wait until spring of 1999. 
 New Jersey has 14 nesting pairs of bald eagles, which are also deemed endangered by the state and threatened by the Federal government. Two of those pairs nest near areas planned for development. In the Smithville section of Galloway Township in Atlantic County, more than 1,800 single-family homes, condominium units or town houses have been completed since the early 1980's. K. Hovnanian, the developer based in Red Bank, had hoped eventually to build up to 6,800 units, but the number has been scaled back to 4,200, partly to protect a pair of bald eagles. Negotiations about the project, which is on both sides of Route 9, have been underway for about a year and are not complete yet, said Michael Gross, a Tinton Falls lawyer who represents the developer.
In Logan Township, Gloucester County, a proposed industrial park, Liberty Properties, is being redesigned to provide a buffer area to protect another pair of bald eagles, said Amy Collings, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection.
In Hanover Township, in Morris County, the blue-spotted salamander -- on both the state and Federal endangered lists -- is affecting a town house development known as Cambridgesquare. The salamander is a five-inch-long creature with dark blue or black skin with light blue speckles. The scope of the development is being reduced to eliminate the impact on the salamander.
The blue-spotted salamander, along with the wood turtle, a species considered threatened by the state (but with no Federal designation), is in the way of the completion of Eisenhower Parkway, which has been proposed to run through the Hatfield Swamp in Essex County, where both animals live. The road now runs 5.3 miles from South Orange Avenue at the Livingston Mall to Route 280. A section that would continue 1.8 miles north from Route 280 to Bloomfield Avenue would cross the swamp. Where the road will eventually go, and when, depends on an environmental impact statement that the county is preparing.

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
In Praise and Remembrance of a Fallen Leader

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL 

 BODY:
CHAMBER music. Would that be four or five people, peaceably playing string quartets or wind quintets in a small concert hall? Not at the 10th annual "Sing in Praise of King" celebration in Newark. Even its previous tributes to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. were chamber music only in the sense that they were presented in nearby churches, and churches are traditionally friendly to chamber music.
The opening of New Jersey Performing Arts Center has made it possible to move this year's eclectic concert on Wednesday to the capacious Prudential Hall, hardly a chamber. A homegrown coalition of performers -- a wind trio and a string foursome from the New Jersey Chamber Music Society, plus a jazz septet led by the pianist and composer Steve Colson -- expands the term chamber music into something more like glorious mosaic, or perhaps smorgasbord. 
 Additional performers will contribute readings, speeches and choral singing in remembrance of Dr. King, who was assassinated 30 years ago. Mr. Colson, who was born in Newark, will lead the premiere of ". . . As in a Cultural Reminiscence." The half-hour work was commissioned by the New Jersey Chamber Music Society, which offers jazz evenings as part of its regular series and is a resident affiliate of the new arts center.
The text of the new work is to be read by its authors, Amiri Baraka of Newark and Richard Wesley of Montclair, both influential in poetry and drama of the black experience. The keynote speaker is Dr. King's daughter, the Rev. Bernice King, who like her siblings works hard to keep his memory alive. At the Chamber Music Society's suggestion, the Newark Community Concert Choir, 70 voices from local churches, was invited to sing spirituals, gospel songs and a chorus from Handel's "Messiah."
"The new piece is probably my best effort so far at merging forces," Mr. Colson said in a telephone interview from his home in Montclair, where several of the musicians live. "It's more devoted to strings than the others are. Jazz allows me to take any form and stretch it. If we were allowed to play what we want, we would have no trouble."
In that veiled complaint, Mr. Colson drew attention to one major difference between jazz and classical music: jazz relies on improvisation, which is by definition not notated. Even using computer software, Mr. Colson says, he had to finish composing in time to transfer the music into written notation, and then extract individual parts and make them legible.
But scheduling problems for such a mixed gathering required compromise: the musicians who were classically trained had to wait to rehearse until they received the score, while the jazz players had to make last-minute adjustments from their unwritten versions. In fact, a special dress rehearsal takes place just before the concert, as a bonus for 1,900 schoolchildren.
"Steve's players are great improvisers," said Oliver Lake, an alto saxophonist and composer from Montclair who has recorded his own music with Mr. Colson. "I'm definitely going to want to be there." It would be background enrichment for Mr. Lake, whose group, Trio Three, is presenting a demonstration of 20th-century chamber jazz on Friday at the Chamber Music America conference in Manhattan.
Describing his new memorial composition, Mr. Colson said: "Basically, it has to do with people and memories. Events pass, and we look in retrospect. The title came to mind when I was playing some miscellaneous pieces for Amiri and Richard. We were trying to put text and music to different strands of memories that have to do with the black experience."
Mr. Colson played music in several moods. "They would stop me and make comments," he said. "Later, I listened and tried to construct music based on their comments that would support the text and give the flavor."
For "Reminiscence," Mr. Colson, who teaches world music at Bloomfield College, updated and incorporated some familiar spirituals named by Mr. Baraka, including "Blessed Assurance," "This Little Light of Mine," "Go Tell It on the Mountain," "O Freedom" and "We Shall Overcome." In Mr. Colson's assessment, "they sound like themselves, but hopefully with an extra layer."
He said he found Mr. Wesley's portion more original because it represented a single individual's personal recollection of events surrounding Dr. King's public life. "I arranged the spirituals with an ear toward the later music," he said. "I will conduct, but there is a brief piano part, which I kind of spread out. My part is partially covered by Brian Carrott on the vibes."
W HILE the classically oriented Chamber Music Society has mounted a jazz series (whose next concert is on Jan. 30 at Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair), Mr. Colson moves in the jazz world and seldom makes the musical crossing. Instead, he performs in places larger than the 2,750-seat Prudential (40,000 at the 1980 Chicago Jazz Festival in Grant Park) and lengthy efforts like a three-hour piece at Symphony Hall in Newark in 1989, with the composer Anthony Davis at the piano and Henry Threadgill on alto saxophone.
But his family members have made other musical crossings, most notably his elder son, an economics major at Yale, who, Mr. Colson confided, prefers rap.

HEADLINE: A Show of Efficiency vs. a Show of Extravagance

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE future of the automobile is definitely green.
The question is whether it is green, as in environmentally friendly, or green, as in big profits. Conceivably, it could be both. 
 The two visions of the future were starkly displayed here last week at the news media preview of the North American International Auto Show, which opened to the public yesterday at Cobo Center. The Detroit show has become the main American platform for introducing concept vehicles that signal the auto industry's future direction, and the prototypes that many of the world's manufacturers showed here will be traveling the auto-show circuit this year, including the New York International Auto Show in April.
Many of the 1998 concepts cars fall into two camps: inventive vehicles that would use far less fuel and produce far less pollution than today's models, and extravagant, powerful, potentially high-profit machines that seem to mock the very idea of conservation and restraint.
In the first group, the hometown teams -- General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler -- showed their latest environmentally sensitive offerings.
G.M. showed a family of advanced-technology vehicles, including an extended-range EV1 electric car and a hybrid-power, all-wheel-drive performance car that it says could get 80 miles to a gallon of gasoline.
The next-generation EV1 and a Chevrolet S-10 electric pickup truck are the first G.M. vehicles to use nickel metal hydride batteries, which double the range of the two vehicles. G.M.'s two new hybrid vehicles include one that uses an electric motor charged by an efficient gas-turbine generator. The other has an electric motor and direct-injection turbo-diesel engine, capable of 80 m.p.g. G.M. also showed a fuel-cell vehicle that runs on electrical energy created from a hydrogen-oxygen chemical reaction and a compressed-natural-gas vehicle with a one-liter, three-cylinder turbo-charged engine.
Ford pulled the wraps off the P2000, a revolutionary family car that, it says, can get 63 m.p.g. The P2000 is about the same size as today's Taurus but about a ton lighter. It is powered by a new, aluminum, 1.2-liter direct-injection engine, in which fuel and air are mixed in the cylinder rather than in an outside chamber. Ford says the engine has low emissions and packs loads of power.
Chrysler's second-generation hybrid-fuel concept car, the Dodge Intrepid ESX2, could drastically reduce the cost of hybrid-powered vehicles. While Chrysler estimated the development and production cost of its first hybrid concept, the Intrepid ESX, at about $60,000 over that of a conventional car, it says the ESX2 reduces that premium to about $15,000. Although it has room for up to six people and more trunk space than the 1998 Dodge Intrepid, the ESX2 is extremely lightweight. The body consists of six plastic panels that weigh half as much as the 80 steel pieces on a conventional car.
Another Chrysler concept car at the show, the Plymouth Pronto Spyder, uses the same materials to make the exotic midengine sports car affordable.
The ESX2's diesel-electric hybrid engine has the potential to meet future emission requirements while achieving a mileage rating of 70 m.p.g. A small battery powers the accessories and an electric motor provides a boost during hard acceleration like passing a car on the highway. But the car is primarily powered by the diesel engine, which is lighter and less costly than a battery and electric motor combination that would produce the same power.
At the other end of the show-car spectrum, electric motors are used only to pamper the occupants of lavish luxury-car prototypes. Mercedes-Benz showcased its Maybach sedan, a car that is likely to go into production as a rival to Rolls-Royce. Powered by a 5.9-liter V12 engine, the Maybach was designed to be a modern intrepretation of the large, chauffeur-driven sedans that once picked up society matrons at the opera. It is 22 inches longer than the Mercedes S-Class sedan and features a humidor for cigars, three telephones, a bar, a flat-screen TV that folds down from above and reclining rear seats with leg rests.
Also in an opulent vein is Chrysler's Chronos, yet another attempt to develop a styling theme for a flagship Chrysler model, this time by drawing on classic designs from Virgil Exner, Chrysler's design chief in the 1950's. The long, low-slung Chronos, with sweeping lines and prominent rear fenders, has a number of luxurious touches, including a prominent chrome grille. Inside, the seats and steering wheel are covered with hand-sewn leather. The Chronos is powered by a 6-liter V10 engine that produces more than 350 horsepower. Like the Maybach, it has a built-in humidor.
Aston Martin's Project Vantage also has a powerful engine: a six-liter V12 capable of 200 miles an hour. But its light body of aluminum and carbon fiber should help it get a respectable economy rating of 20 m.p.g.
A number of concept vehicles represented further forays in cross-breeding cars with sport utility vehicles. The most unusual was the Buick Signia, based on the luxurious Park Avenue sedan but offering the all-wheel drive versatility of a sport utility. Outfitted with retro gauges and the blond wood popular in the 1930's, the Signia is easy to enter and exit because of its low height and extra-wide doors. But the seats are high, offering the commanding feel of a sport ute. The rear floor slides out 15 inches to make loading and unloading easier. The rear hatch is removable. Buick officials say the Signia hints at the division's "near-term product direction."
And for a completely different, even absurd, twist, Chrysler showed a concept vehicle it calls the Jeepster, a cross between a V8 sports car and a Jeep that can traverse rugged terrain. Its new 4.7-liter 32-valve V8 engine will make a production debut in the all-new 1999 Jeep Grand Cherokee.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1493 words

HEADLINE: H.M.O. Premiums Rising Sharply, Stoking Debate on Managed Care

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
Health maintenance organizations in the New York region are asking customers to pay larger -- in some cases much larger -- premiums this year after several years of holding down prices to spur enrollment in an area that long regarded managed care with suspicion.
The increases, mirroring those by managed care companies around the nation, vary by plan and by who is covered. But even big employers, who are typically able to negotiate the cheapest rates, say they expect the first substantial increases in several years. 
 "We're thinking probably in the range of 5 to 7 percent," said Laurel A. Pickering, managing director for the New York Business Group on Health, a trade organization that represents large companies like American Express, Time Warner and Consolidated Edison. The picture was different several years ago, she said, when premiums actually decreased.
Health care experts said they expected premiums to rise by 5 to 10 percent next year, prompting worries about whether the increases are a blip or a troubling sign that managed care is no better at controlling costs than traditional indemnity insurance.
There are many reasons for the increases, experts say: rising drug and hospitalization costs; employers willing to pay more in flush economic times, and plans offering wider choices to patients increasingly frustrated by the limits of managed care.
But many analysts in New York State say the primary reason is that managed care companies had kept prices artificially low for years to encourage reluctant New Yorkers to sign up, and are only now coming to terms with the actual cost of care.
"It's like Nobody Beats the Wiz," said Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, the New York State Health Commissioner, referring to the giant electronics retailer that declared bankruptcy last month. "You go to the Wiz to get a TV at dirt-cheap prices. They go into bankruptcy. Believe me, the similarities are not lost on me."
And as the rates for commercial policies rise, a debate is beginning in New York that is already under way in California and Florida, where managed care serves a far greater portion of the population. (About 40 percent of New Yorkers are enrolled in managed care, compared with 70 percent of Californians.)
The basic question is: will managed care, in the long run, begin to mimic traditional insurance with its looser control over costs and annual premium increases that far outpace inflation?
The theory behind managed care was that health maintenance organizations would eliminate waste by limiting access to specialists and tests that they deemed unnecessary. But some critics of managed care say the savings from such restrictions can be realized only once, and that as the years roll on, large rate increases like those in indemnity plans are inevitable.
"We may have squeezed what we can out of the health care system," said State Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Insurance Committee.
Other experts cite a second, contradictory dynamic: that managed care has, in fact, failed to cut costs significantly as it offers finicky customers in the New York region a level of choice much more like indemnity plans. For example, they say, some plans charge customers a slightly higher monthly fee in exchange for the right to see any specialist they want, whether the doctor is a member of the plan or not.
Critics say that managed care in the New York region is essentially discounted fee-for-service medicine, and that such an approach was a major reason for the financial problems of the largest H.M.O. in New York, Oxford Health Plans.
"Managed care companies do not manage care," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "Instead they manage price: the prices they pay to providers. There are really few good examples of any sound managed care in New York."
Many people in the managed care industry contend that new laws and regulations are forcing the industry to make changes that drive up costs: specifically, regulations like the Managed Care Bill of Rights in New York, which requires health maintenance organizations to disclose certain information to consumers, and laws mandating minimum hospital stays for procedures like childbirth and mastectomies.
"Those are things that add up," said Leslie Moran, a spokeswoman for the New York State Health Maintenance Organization Conference, an industry trade group.
Others in the industry assert that, whatever the problems of managed care, it is still the cheapest and most efficient means of delivering health care and that the increases are overdue after five years of virtually flat costs. HIP Health Plan of New York, for example, plans to raise its rates in 1998 between 4 and 6 percent, the first increase in four years.
Leslie Strassberg, the company's senior vice president, said that managed care will continue to save money as more people enroll and the companies find better ways to balance cost control with service to patients.
"There is an equilibrium that has to be reached, and it's not going to be reached by skipping the squeeze-the-costs-out phase," he said.
It is unclear what broad effects the increases in health maintenance organization premiums will have. Some experts worry that more employers, who have turned to H.M.O.'s as a cheaper alternative, will drop coverage for their workers entirely, especially in small companies with low-paid employees.
In Binghamton, N.Y., Barbara D. Daly, whose two small businesses have been growing rapidly, said she had planned to begin offering her four employees health insurance next year. But after her H.M.O. told her to expect a 15 percent increase next year, she said she wondered if she could afford it, especially if premiums grow year after year.
"Now that health care reform is no longer on the national agenda, we are looking at who-knows-what increases," said Ms. Daly, who runs a coffee and gift shop and an importing business. "It's open-ended."
And people who buy insurance on their own say the increases add yet another layer of worry about whether they will continue to be able to afford insurance.
People who buy insurance on their own tend to be the sickest in the state, requiring the most costly care, and the requested rate increases for those policies are the highest. For example, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield has requested a 51.6 percent rate increase for one such plan to cover what it describes as massive losses.
Linda Gibbs, 45, a singer and freelance bookkeeper in Manhattan who has ovarian cancer, says she worries how she will make her payments to Oxford, already $311 a month, if the premiums go up much more and she gets too sick again to work.
"Health care, housing and food -- they are the body's necessities," she said. "We should be covered for these things. I'm a pseudo-socialist."
In the Northeast, the state with the smallest increases is Connecticut, where regulators and advocates say a keenly competitive market has kept projected increases below 5 percent. But in New Jersey, managed care officials said they expected rates to rise between 5 and 8 percent.
In New York -- where for years premiums have risen very little and some actually have gone down -- seven managed care companies have already asked for rate increases of more than 10 percent in 1998, a level subject to approval by state regulators. In all of 1997, only four companies sought increases that high. The companies submit their increase requests to the state not once a year, but periodically as they decide on their rates.
More broadly, a survey of health maintenance organizations at the start of 1997 in the mid-Atlantic area -- New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania -- estimated an average premium increase of 1.6 percent. For 1998, the companies estimated an average increase of 4.4 percent, according to the survey by Douglas Sherlock, a health care analyst at the Sherlock Company. Estimates, he added, tend to be lower than the actual increases.
Dr. DeBuono, the New York Health Commissioner, said she believed the plans should receive increases to assure their solvency as the state's medical system, for years behind the rest of the nation, becomes more dependent on managed care.
"Medical costs are going up," she said. "Utilization is going up. They are not managing care. So what's a plan to do? Either raise their rates or go out of business."
John Calagna, a spokesman for the State Insurance Department, said that regulators would carefully study the requested increases in the coming months. The department often pares down companies' requests, but Mr. Calagna echoed Dr. DeBuono in saying that companies had kept prices low for so long that some might need increases to stay afloat.
"It doesn't make sense if people can't afford the coverage," he said. "And it doesn't make sense if the companies can't pay the claims. It's a balancing act."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Down In November

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
Orders for machine tools fell in November, though total purchases so far for 1997 remain above the 1996 level, an industry survey showed today.
Orders from American companies for domestic- and foreign-produced machine tools fell 12.7 percent, to an estimated $637 million, from a revised gain of 11.3 percent, to $730 million, in October, a report from the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association said. 
 All regions had a drop in November. The two industry groups previously estimated that October orders rose 6.6 percent, to $699 million.
Estimated machine tool orders for the first 11 months of 1997 totaled $7.51 billion, 18.8 percent ahead of the corresponding period a year earlier. November estimated orders were 15.2 percent more than the $553 million estimated in November 1996.
Machine tool makers and distributors "did not see a substantial change in business" in November, said Ralph Nappi, president of the distributors' group. "There is not a company that isn't enjoying a pretty good year. All indications for 1998 are strong with anticipated growth in the 5 percent to 8 percent range."
Bridgeport Machines, for instance, expects to report stable business for the quarter that ended last month. "Our U.S. business has remained reasonably steady for the past 12 months," said Dan L. Griffith, the chief executive, "and it appears that business will continue to remain steady for at least the near term."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs Magazine Becoming Harder to Predict

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Soon after taking over as the editor of Foreign Affairs in 1992, James F. Hoge Jr. stood before Washington members of the Council on Foreign Relations and presented them with their worst nightmare for their magazine: a mock front cover with the supermodel Cindy Crawford on the logo (instead of the usual rearing horse and rider) and cover lines like, "Boris' Babes," "Best Bets in Dictators" and "Sexiest Ethnic Rivalries."
Mr. Hoge, former publisher of The Daily News of New York, was poking fun at those who feared he would take the magazine in a lowbrow, lightweight direction. 
 Mr. Hoge was chosen because the council, which publishes Foreign Affairs, wanted a new kind of person to shepherd the journal into a new kind of world. And as the magazine moves out of its 75th anniversary year, readers say Mr. Hoge has successfully managed that transition by publishing new voices, tackling new subjects and making the magazine more accessible and less predictable.
"Foreign Affairs used to be the magazine of a certain kind of liberal establishment," said David Rieff, who has written several articles for Mr. Hoge. "He's opened it up, he's allowed the air in."
Still, in a period with no defining international conflict, when other media outlets have drastically reduced their foreign coverage and Americans are assumed to care little about news outside their borders, it remains to be seen what mark Mr. Hoge will ultimately make.
"The jury is out on what is going to happen," said Victor Navasky, the publisher of The Nation, "both in terms of a coherent foreign policy on the part of this country and the role that Foreign Affairs will play."
Indeed, some might expect Mr. Hoge to try to fill the void with something along the lines of George F. Kennan's historic "X" article, published in Foreign Affairs in 1947, which established the nation's policy of Soviet containment.
But although Mr. Hoge said articles submitted to Foreign Affairs were frequently touted as the next "X," he had no grand illusions about setting the agenda for the coming century.
"From the beginning, we've understood that there isn't to be a second Kennan piece," Mr. Hoge said in a recent interview at his book-lined office off Park Avenue. "The circumstances of the cold war allowed for an overarching theme for American foreign policy. That is simply not the case in the post-cold war world."
Indeed, Mr. Hoge and his managing editor, Fareed Zakaria, maintain that this moment in history is more interesting. "The whole world is up for grabs," Mr. Zakaria said. "We can run articles asking, 'Is nationalism the future?' 'Is globalization the future?' 'Is East Asia rising?' 'Is Russia collapsing?' -- all these big topics."
"The cold war had narrowed and focused our perspective," he continued. "Now you have this sort of wonderful confusion."
Mr. Hoge and Mr. Zakaria have exploited this confusion by expanding Foreign Affairs to include unorthodox articles about privatizing pensions and about the gender gap in Eastern Europe.
Though Mr. Hoge has yet to shake things up with a piece on the order of Francis Fukuyama's "The End of History," which ran in The National Interest in 1989, a few articles have generated lasting discussions. "The Clash of Civilizations?" by Samuel P. Huntington, for example, generated impassioned debate and became a book. In that 1993 article, the Harvard professor argued that the fundamental source of conflict in the post-cold war world would be cultural clashes between civilizations, as differentiated by language, culture, tradition and religion.
In addition, Paul Krugman's 1994 article "The Myth of Asia's Miracle" prompted Singapore to revamp its economic policies, according to a 1996 article in The Wall Street Journal. In his article, Mr. Krugman, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, argued that East Asia's impressive growth resulted from investment and labor, not efficiency, and would not last -- a prescient prediction.
And while Foreign Affairs may no longer be considered an establishment mouthpiece, it continues to have influence. "Virtually everyone I know in the foreign policy-national security area of the Government is attentive to it," said Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State.
Stanley O. Roth, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, added: "I would not want to tell you that every edition produces 10 policy issues. On the other hand, people do read it and views get reflected -- if not immediately, then over time."
If Foreign Affairs has become merely a forum for a variety of ideas, some might question its potential influence. But Mr. Hoge said he had the opportunity to affect the debate, if not to define it, and was proud of having no party line. Since its founding, the magazine "has always been at its most useful and influential during times of transition," Mr. Hoge said. "We think it is terribly important, given the position of this magazine, that we not be seen as having a point of view or particular political slant."
Indeed, many readers commend Mr. Hoge for fostering debate by publishing opposing views about sensitive subjects like Bosnia.
Because of the journal's close association with the elite Council on Foreign Relations, Mr. Hoge, 62, and Mr. Zakaria, 33, have also tried to open the "club" to new members, inviting younger voices in, as well as more women, and encouraging less stodgy writing.
"With important authors, one can treat them with kid gloves," Mr. Zakaria said. "The aim now is to edit the magazine for the reader, rather than the writer."
Foreign Affairs has also benefited from an increasingly global economy, building new readers in the business community.
And although Mr. Hoge maintains that he does not expect Foreign Affairs to appeal to a general audience, he has made several concessions to the realities of a competitive magazine market.
In addition to a redesign that included changing the cover from a dull gray to a glossy blue, Mr. Hoge shortened the articles from an average of 7,000 words to 5,000.
He started publishing six times a year instead of four and divided each issue into three distinct sections to make it seem less like an academic journal.
The direct rivals of Foreign Affairs include Foreign Policy, World Policy Journal, The National Interest and several others, all with considerably smaller circulations.
Five years into Mr. Hoge's tenure, Foreign Affairs' vital statistics look good. Circulation has crept up to 100,814, syndication has almost quadrupled and ad pages have increased about 40 percent since 1991, according to David Kellogg, the publisher.
For the last decade, Foreign Affairs has also made several hundred thousand dollars profit, Mr. Kellogg said, adding that this was rare for a scholarly magazine. And leaders of the Council on Foreign Relations say they are pleased with what Mr. Hoge has done.
"It often used to just sit on coffee tables," said Leslie H. Gelb, a former New York Times columnist who has been president of the council since 1993 and who worked in the Defense and State Departments. "Now people are actually reading it."
Because Mr. Hoge was best known as a tabloid publisher and was the first editor in 20 years who had not served in the Government, he has taken some getting used to.
Mr. Hoge's predecessor, William G. Hyland, had served as an aide to Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State; before him, William P. Bundy had served as an Assistant Secretary of State under President Lyndon B. Johnson.
But foreign policy heavyweights who write for the magazine say that Foreign Affairs has retained its seriousness and that Mr. Hoge has earned their respect. "In spite of the fact that it's a little more jazzy today, the content is excellent," said Zygmunt Nagorski, president of the Center for International Leadership, who initially accused Mr. Hoge in a letter of "transforming a Louis XIV wine bottle into a Coke bottle."
In trying to make Foreign Affairs more reader friendly, however, some say Mr. Hoge still has a way to go. "There is often a deadliness to the prose," said the editor of a scholarly journal who insisted on anonymity.
And although the magazine gets only 25 percent of its revenue from advertising, it remains a tough sell on Madison Avenue. "The big agencies are very afraid of Foreign Affairs," said a former advertising executive for Foreign Affairs who refused to be identified. "A lot of media buyers are just out of college. They tend to look at it as assignments they once had and hated."
Moreover, at a time of Web sites and sound bites, one cannot help questioning the very survival of Foreign Affairs. To which experts say the public ignores matters international at its peril.
"I don't think there's been a time since the 1930's when Americans have been more indifferent to foreign policy, but that doesn't make Foreign Affairs any less important, any less good, any less necessary," Mr. Rieff said. "If Foreign Affairs folds, then that will be the kind of proof positive that this has become a truly irresponsible country."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Hoge Jr., left, the editor of Foreign Affairs, and Fareed Zakaria, the journal's managing editor, have expanded the magazine's scope with articles on privatizing pensions and the gender gap in Eastern Europe. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)(pg. D12)

HEADLINE: It Isn't Just Big Brother Who Is Watching

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 11

 BODY:
When Cameron Barrett taught his co-workers to surf the World Wide Web, he never imagined what they would do with their new skills.
At a small advertising agency in rural Traverse City, Mich., Mr. Barrett, 24, was hired to teach some fortysomething female employees how to view and produce Web pages for clients. 
 In a class, he mentioned that he wrote fiction. So several employees visited his Internet home page (www.camworld.com), where they found short stories about sex, humor, violence and estrangement: an unnamed narrator describes killing everyone in a stark white room; a snowman accidentally knocks his wife's head off during lovemaking. ("In the morning, the sun came out and that was the last he ever saw of his wife or children again.")
After six weeks on the job, Mr. Barrett was dismissed. "The owner told me that two of my female co-workers read my fiction, got scared, shared it with their husbands and then went to my boss and said, 'Either he goes or we go,' " Mr. Barrett said. "They thought the character in the stories was me."
Now Mr. Barrett, a specialist in new media, stocks groceries on the night shift for $8 an hour, with no benefits. His former employer declined to comment.
And though there hardly seems to be a national epidemic of people losing their jobs over their home pages, Cameron Barrett is not the only person in this situation. Workers in Virginia, Texas and California said they had been dismissed or disciplined for the content of their Web pages, even though the pages are maintained with their own computers, time and money. Others said they had been ordered to modify their pages.
Both groups said a common directive was to remove any reference to where they work, making it difficult to publish a resume on line.
The dismissals are legal, experts in employment law say. Nearly every American is an "at will" employee, meaning "you can be fired for a good reason, a bad reason or no reason at all," said Mayer G. Freed, a professor of law at Northwestern University. "People say, 'There ought to be a law.' But there's not. There would be a huge cost to the economy if every firing would be the subject of a lawsuit."
Although they may not break new legal ground, the Web page cases do reveal a culture clash between longstanding, unwritten standards of corporate propriety and the new perspective of Web-savvy employees -- the kind of workers that companies are clamoring for.
The employees, often right out of college or high school, are accustomed to publishing on line their narcissistic scrapbooks of highly personal poetry, photos, and a lot of thinking out loud about sex and religion and sex and politics and sex.
Many of these younger workers have been on the Internet for years, comfortably saying to strangers what they would not say to a friend at work. But now millions of people have personal (but public) Web pages -- America Online, the largest on-line service, is adding more than 100,000 a month -- while still more of their co-workers and managers and parents are learning to find those pages on the Web.
In Virginia, more than opinion is revealed on the Web site of Lizz Sommerfield, 23, a 1996 Yale graduate and Internet engineer who goes by "SexyChyck." As SexyChyck, Ms. Sommerfield poses for 1,000 visitors a week in her leopard print underwear. It's not the full-blown nakedness the Web is known for, but she does carry ads for hard-core pornographic sites. "I do it because it's fun," Ms. Sommerfield said. "I like the attention."
Her previous employer, a mom-and-pop publishing company, ordered her to remove any reference to the company, and she did, but felt violated and quit. "It upset me that someone was spending so much time digging into my personal Web site and reading everything and giving it to my boss," Ms. Sommerfield said. "I didn't feel like my boss needed to act like my parents."
She quickly was hired at a large company with many Internet-savvy employees. She showed the site to her employer, who also asked her not to use the company's name. "Almost everybody at the company has a personal Web page," she said. "I am the only person who has been told, 'You may not tell anybody where you work.' I feel kind of bad crumbling under society's foot."
Companies are accustomed to dismissing employees for misuse of computers at work. Many company policies restrict use of E-mail, limit access to offensive Web sites and prohibit disclosure of confidential information. Few policies, if any, directly address personal Web pages.
The closest corollaries in the non-computer world involve dismissals ofworkers for posing nude in magazines like Playboy. Such dismissals -- of New York City police officers, Wall Street stockbrokers, even a ball girl for the Chicago Cubs -- have not been successfully challenged.
"It's an interesting dilemma," said Linnea B. McCord, a professor of business law at Pepperdine University. "Tampering in people's privacy goes pretty far and gives the employer a lot of power. But if you can be fired for bad judgment for sitting in a public place in your underwear, you can be fired for sitting in your underwear on the Internet."
Employees have some safety only if they are dismissed for a reason relating to race, sex, religion, ethnicity, age or disability. Some employees are protected by union or personal contracts that limit reasons for dismissal. State and Federal laws protect whistle-blowers, those who refuse to do something illegal, and workers who file claims for workers' compensation. Some local ordinances prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
There are no applicable First Amendment free-speech protections -- the First Amendment restricts the actions of government, not business.
The employees dismissed in the Web page cases are still free to speak out about their cases -- and they do on their Web pages. Mr. Barrett and Ms. Sommerfield say they do not want to embarrass their employers. They only want to warn others what could happen.
They were bothered, they say, more by Web illiteracy than by corporate heavy-handedness. Particularly galling is the prohibition against including Web links to their employers on their pages As Ms. Sommerfield explained: "They said, 'Well, we don't want to give anyone the possible impression that we endorse what's on there.' A link is not an endorsement."
Mr. Barrett still publishes fiction on the Web. But readers must agree to a contract. Among the terms:
"By reading Cameron Barrett's experimental fiction, I understand that I am able to tell the difference between Cameron Barrett's fictional characters and Cameron Barrett, the person."
"I am a sensible human being and do not think that Cameron Barrett is a psychopath who is going to hunt down and kill his co-workers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cameron Barrett was dismissed from a small advertising agency in Traverse City, Mich., after co-workers read and complained about fiction he wrote on his own Web page. (John Robert William for The York Times)

HEADLINE: Internet Helps to Keep Silicon Valley in a Boom

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
Silicon Valley's booming economy continued at a near-record growth rate in 1997, adding 53,000 jobs and showing surprising strength in the manufacturing sector, which was once widely believed to be dispersing to low-cost labor regions around the world.
The strength of the nation's premier technology region was reported in an annual survey of the region's economic and social health issued yesterday by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley, a coalition of corporate and civic organizations. 
 The report showed that while growth began to slow in the second half of last year, the region's economy, which has long been marked by cycles of boom and bust, is in the midst of a sustained period of growth.
"Employment growth has outstripped labor supply since 1995," said Douglas Henton, president of Collaborative Economics, a Palo Alto, Calif., firm that prepared the report. "We're starting to wonder how the valley can continue to maintain this growth rate."
The growth is being driven principally by the emergence of the Internet as a commercial force.
"We're still very much in the Internet era," Mr. Henton said.
The region now generates 40 percent of California's exports, despite having only about 10 percent of the state's population. In 1996, Silicon Valley surpassed Detroit as the nation's leading exporter, according to the study.
Silicon Valley was once largely limited to Santa Clara County, on the southwest side of the San Francisco Bay. But Joint Venture now defines the valley as an economic and cultural area bounded by San Mateo in the north, Gilroy in the south, Scotts Valley in the west and Fremont and Milpitas in the east.
The region covers about 1,500 square miles and has a population of 2.3 million according to Joint Venture's data. About 23 percent of its residents are foreign born, many of them drawn by high-tech jobs.
The valley is frequently held out as the archetype of the so-called "new economy," which is characterized by a highly skilled labor force.
The biggest job gains were reported in software, where there were 8,300 new jobs, outpacing computers-communications, which added 7,500 jobs.

 BODY:

Sure, They're Expensive, But the Picture Is Great
Offering the viewing audience its first good look at the future of television, the world's electronics manufacturers introduced high-definition production models at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., last week. Nearly all of the digital sets shown were large projection models rather than the "direct view" kind that use picture tubes, despite the fact that such televisions account for 90 percent of the market today. 
 The manufacturers conceded that the introductory models, at $5,000 to $10,000 or more a set, are expensive, but they said prices were likely to fall rapidly. Page D5.
 
Silicon Valley's Boom Stretches On
The economic boom in Silicon Valley roared ahead in 1997, as the region added 53,000 jobs and manufacturing remained strong. An annual survey of the region's economy, long marked by sharp boom-and-bust cycles, is in the midst of a sustained expansion. D4.
 
Pipeline Giant Branches Out
The Williams Companies, already the nation's largest operator of natural gas pipelines, will return to the national communications business with an 11,000-mile fiber optic network. It will offer wholesale high-speed communications services. D10.
 
Web Pages Provoke Backlash
People in states from Virginia to California report that they have been dismissed from their jobs or disciplined for the content of personal home pages on the World Wide Web. Others say they have been ordered to modify their pages. Many are unhappy to find that such actions are perfectly legal. D5.
 
Pepsi to Test Lemon-Lime Soda
Tired of seeing its competitors swallow up the market for lemon-lime soft drinks, Pepsi-Cola plans to test a new version, christened Storm, in at least one city later this year. D2.
 
The Rise of the Do-It-Yourself CD
Custom compact disks, which can now be produced by anyone with a properly equipped personal computer, have found a growing niche market on the Internet. Not only are musicians selling their own CD's on line, but three rival Internet retailers now offer custom CD compilations. Entertainment. D12.
 
Titanic Lives On On Line
A hit movie and a Broadway musical have brought the continuing interest in the story of the Titanic to a fever pitch. But well before these adaptations came along, the World Wide Web offered a rich resource of fact and lore about the unsinkable ship that did. Taking In the Sites. D6.
 
Assignments Raise Questions
Mark H. Willes, the chairman of Times Mirror and publisher of The Los Angeles Times, has provoked controversy among journalists at the company's newspapers, which include Newsday and The Baltimore Sun, by asking three of them to write parts of Times Mirror's annual report. D13.
 
Canadian Push for Satellite TV
Canada's fledgling direct-to-home satellite television industry hopes to lure more customers of gray-market fare from the United States. And if appeals to consciences are insufficient, the satellite companies are willing to pay a bounty for outlaw hardware used to receive American signals. D12.
 
Changes at Advertising Agencies
At least a dozen advertising executives will answer to new masters after a frenzied round of musical chairs at agencies like Wells BDDP, Young & Rubicam and Omnicom Group on Friday. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D10.

HEADLINE: TCI Seeks Variety in Software And Suppliers for TV Boxes

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF with GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
John C. Malone, the chairman of Tele-Communications Inc., believes he can succeed where his predecessors have failed.
With two deals announced at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., this weekend, Mr. Malone has disclosed a plan that is intended to rein in the Microsoft Corporation's power and simultaneously fuel the dynamic economic growth that the cable television industry has been seeking so eagerly. 
 By using Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Java programming language as a counterweight to a consumer version of Microsoft's Windows operating system, Mr. Malone is trying to relegate Microsoft to the same status as his other vendors.
Rather than letting Microsoft provide all of the software for his interactive cable network, Mr. Malone is trying to create a model that puts the various components of the set-top box in the hands of numerous different vendors, much as if the box were a faucet and he were parceling out to different vendors the handle, washer, filter and pipes that affect the flow of the water.
In this case, the water -- or programming -- is supposed to flow both ways, and needs a variety of software and hardware to do so. So Mr. Malone has created a "layer cake" business model in which each vendor provides only one piece of an integrated system that includes set-top box hardware, operating system software, the Java programming environment, software applications and a head-end server for distributing video and other digital content.
But it is a risky gamble.
Industry executives in Las Vegas this weekend said the cable industry infighting reminded them of the early days of the personal computer industry, where in 1981, I.B.M. initially offered PC buyers three competing operating systems: Microsoft's MS-DOS, the Digital Research Corporation's CP/M and UCSD Pascal.
In the PC industry, however, consumers quickly settled on the low-cost alternative. Because Microsoft's operating system was the least expensive option, it became a standard, attracting the widest selection of software applications.
Indeed, despite his efforts to create a more competitive marketplace, Mr. Malone may have repeated over the weekend the blunder made years ago by the International Business Machines Corporation.
"Think of this as a poker table where most of the chips say Windows and William Gates is now holding them," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering Inc., an industry consulting firm in Seaford, N.Y. In Mr. Malone's vision of the future interactive cable industry, the line between traditional television channels and personal computer software applications will rapidly be blurred.
For example, while watching the History Channel, a television viewer will eventually be able to use a handheld clicker to select a character on the screen and call up a box with additional information via the Internet.
Because the new set-top boxes will actually be powerful computers, today's one-way channels will be complemented by the equivalent of personal computer programs that have been converted for the television screen, programs for bill paying, electronic mail or games.
Mr. Malone sees this as nirvana for the ambitious cable television industry, which has consistently promised new services, like home banking, that it has proven unable to deliver. He wants his company to collect a portion of each electronic transaction made over the new interactive set-top boxes that Tele-Communications will begin offering to consumers in 1999.
Tele-Communications is the nation's largest cable operator, with its boxes in 12 million of the nation's 65 million cable-equipped homes. The biggest, Time Warner Inc., is still in negotiations with a variety of potential suppliers for both software and hardware.
Microsoft last year invested $1 billion in another cable company, the Comcast Corporation. Brian L. Roberts, the president of Comcast, said over the weekend, "The industry has been searching for a new revenue stream for a number of years, and the prospect of this convergence is very promising."
Mr. Malone, who is eager to avoid total dependence on Microsoft, is using Sun's Java as an additional layer of software to offer more choices to software developers and an alternative to Microsoft.
The advantage of Java is that it permits software developers to write programs that can be run on many different types of computer hardware. That could be important if different and competing types of hardware are used in the set-top boxes distributed by the cable companies.
A second advantage of Java is its security design, which is better than most personal computer environments today. The language was created by Sun engineers specifically to thwart rogue programs like computer viruses and worms, which threaten computer networks.
Security is an important consideration if cable companies expect to gain the confidence of consumers they hope will do their banking, pay bills and shop via their television screens.
But the more software applications are running, the more memory the set-top box will need, and more memory costs more money.
On Saturday, Mr. Malone acknowledged that in order to run the Java alternative, it would be necessary to add memory chips to the set-top boxes. That, industry executives said, could end up consigning Sun to the same role as the losing personal computer operating systems in the early days of PC's.
People familiar with the cable agreement signed by Sun and Tele-Communications on Friday said that in order to avoid that Sun's chairman, Scott G. McNealy, had agreed to pay Tele-Communications the additional costs to insure that there is room for the Java standards.
Several company insiders said the payments could amount to as much as $10 to $12 a machine. Sun officials would not comment.
At the same time, Mr. Malone also said Saturday that Tele-Communications was continuing discussions with Microsoft on a possible $1 billion investment to help build an interactive television network more quickly.
One cable industry chief executive, who spoke on the condition that he remain anonymous, said the industry badly needs new sources of revenue and that at a practical level, it might be worth ceding domination to Microsoft if that would help add new revenue sources. "Cable has not had a big new product in years," he said. "We need the catalyst of Silicon Valley to move ahead."
At the same time, although the battle has now been joined, it is clearly not over. In addition to Microsoft and Sun, Oracle, Intel, I.B.M. and AT&T are all still jostling for a place at the table -- or inside the new digital set-top box.
Moreover, while Mr. Gates proposed a new computer-oriented digital television standard called HD0 in his speech at the Consumer Electronics Show on Saturday, the nation's television broadcasters have yet to settle on a standard.
And then of course there is the largest unanswered question: Do television viewers care about any of this?
The computer industry is betting heavily that consumers will be willing to open their wallets for these new services. However, with many American homes already paying $25 or more a month for cable, there is little evidence yet that they will be willing to foot the bill for the much-hyped interactive television of the future.

HEADLINE: Why Microsoft Is Taking a Hard Line With the Government

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR with JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation's final chance to avoid being dragged into court by the United States Government came on Oct. 16, when the Justice Department summoned Microsoft's legal team to Washington. For 90 minutes the lawyers were interrogated by Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division, and his staff.
The Microsoft team, led by William H. Neukom, senior vice president for law and corporate affairs, detailed the business and legal reasons for the company's requiring personal computer makers to ship its Internet browsing program as a condition of licensing its industry-standard Windows 95 operating system -- and why Microsoft was intent on continuing that practice. 
 "We thought we had given them a lot more to think about, that this was a complicated matter and that we had a strong legal position," Mr. Neukom recalled.
But to the Justice Department, the product bundling seemed a clear violation of Microsoft's 1995 consent decree with the Government, which prohibited tying the sale of one product to another.
Mr. Klein said he left the Oct. 16 meeting convinced that Microsoft would not budge and would not address the Government's concerns. Four days later, Attorney General Janet Reno, with Mr. Klein at her side, announced that the Government was suing Microsoft.
The Government's suit has escalated into a bitter battle -- and a bruising experience for the company. In recent weeks Microsoft, usually so sure footed, has appeared at times to be throwing a temper tantrum, picking fights with a Federal judge and the Justice Department.
Microsoft's combative stance has prompted a backlash in the industry, trade press and among computer users that even Microsoft executives acknowledge has blemished the company's good name. Last week, Microsoft executives softened their language, but did not change the company's position.
As the courtroom confrontation resumes tomorrow, the question remains: Why is Microsoft taking such a hard line?
To find the answer, go back to the summer of 1994, before the Internet was a household word, long before there was a market for browser software.
In 1994, after four years of Government scrutiny, Microsoft, the Justice Department and Europe's antitrust authorities were poring over a proposed consent decree that focused mainly on slightly altering Microsoft's licensing practices.
On July 13, 1994, Microsoft's legal team was in Washington going over the language of the decree. The draft of the settlement terms said that Microsoft was prohibited from tying the use of one of its products to another. But the provision in the decree included the qualification that "this shall not be construed to prohibit Microsoft from developing integrated products which offer technological advantages."
At 10:30 P.M., William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, called the company's general counsel, Mr. Neukom, and the head of the company's outside legal team, Richard J. Urowsky, a partner of the firm Sullivan & Cromwell, at a Washington hotel. Mr. Gates demanded that the last four words -- "which offer technological advantages" -- be stricken from the decree.
Mr. Gates, according to Mr. Urowsky's account in a court deposition, successfully insisted "that Microsoft would not accept any limitations on its right to design new products."
Microsoft sees its crusade in the current case not as arrogance, as its critics charge, but as an uncompromising defense of principle. It is saying that Microsoft and Microsoft alone should be the arbiter of what goes into its products, and how it defines an integrated product.
Microsoft insists that the Government's consent-decree case, though narrow in some respects, represents a challenge to the way it does business. At stake, Microsoft contends, is nothing less than who will control innovation in the economy -- entrepreneurial companies like Microsoft or Washington and the courts.
To the Justice Department, the case is not about innovation but about the abuse of market power. The heart of the suit, Government officials say, is that Microsoft's Windows operating system and its Internet browser, Explorer, are separate products. By forcing PC makers to bundle Explorer with Windows, they add, Microsoft is using its near-monopoly in operating-system software to restrict competition in the market for Internet browsing software, where its main competitor is the Netscape Communications Corporation.
"This portion of the consent decree adopts a basic antitrust principle," Mr. Klein, the antitrust chief, said. "It prohibits use of monopoly power to beat back a competitor."
In a temporary order on Dec. 11, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of the United States District Court in Washington agreed with the Government on that point. He also ordered the company to come up with a temporary plan for offering PC makers a choice of loading Windows onto their machines with Explorer or without Explorer. A final decision in the case is expected later this year.
Microsoft rivals cheered the December ruling, but it was seen mainly as a moral victory with little impact on the fortunes of the software powerhouse. Because PC makers get Explorer free, few, if any, would choose Windows without Explorer.
Microsoft's solution for complying with the judge's order -- offering Windows without Explorer, but only in an outdated version of Windows -- seemed designed to prove its point: Windows and Explorer have become a single integrated product.
Under Microsoft's reading of the consent decree, the company has the absolute right to declare Windows and Explorer an integrated product and market it as it sees fit.
"This is not about thumping Netscape on the head," Steven A. Ballmer, a Microsoft executive vice president, said. "This is really about the fundamental right to innovate."
Is Microsoft a relentless innovator or a modern monopolist? The current case will not settle that question, but in its thousands of pages of court filings, corporate documents and E-mail memos, it will add grist for both sides of that debate.
The court documents and interviews do clearly show that from drafting the language of the consent decree to responding to the rise of the Internet, Microsoft has kept one central objective in mind -- protecting and extending the reach of its Windows operating-system software, the corporation's crown jewel.
An operating-system program serves as the central nervous system of a computer. More than 80 percent of the world's personal computers run Microsoft's Windows, giving the company a leg up in new markets like Internet software. That is especially true if Microsoft decides, as it has with the browser, that what other companies are selling as a stand-alone product will be an "integrated feature" of Windows for which nothing extra is charged.
That kind of behavior presents a quandary for antitrust policy. The goal of antitrust is to safeguard competitive markets in the interests of consumer welfare. By pulling stand-alone programs into its operating system, Microsoft is giving computer users more product for less money -- a consumer benefit.
For nearly two decades, Microsoft has steadily added more and more to its program, from point-and-click icons to facsimile software. By bringing new features into its operating system, Microsoft has made computers more powerful and easier to use for millions of consumers.
But as its market power has increased over the years, Microsoft has been able to crush competitors -- eliminating competition and perhaps innovation, which could harm consumers. Microsoft can crimp competition with the same strategy it employs to help consumers. What were once separate products, markets and profitable businesses for other companies can be pulled in to become "features" of Microsoft's Windows operating program.
Once it determines that a new company is a threat, Microsoft can deploy its integration strategy with a vengeance. In September 1995, Paul Maritz, the executive in charge of Microsoft's operating-system business, met with executives of the Intel Corporation, the leading microchip maker. It was a month after Netscape had sold shares to the public and the Internet start-up was suddenly a hot company. When the discussion turned to Netscape, one Intel executive, who asked not to be identified, recalled Mr. Maritz saying: "We are going to cut off their air supply. Everything they're selling, we're going to give away for free."
Since August 1995, when Microsoft's Windows 95 was introduced, the Explorer browser has been both marketed as a separate product in retail stores and bundled onto the operating system by PC makers. Each new version of Explorer has been improved and more closely integrated -- sharing more and more programming files -- with the operating system.
An E-mail on Dec. 20, 1996, from Jim Allchin, a senior vice president, to Mr. Maritz, the operating-system executive, urged a hastening of that integration. "The current path is simply to copy everything Netscape does packaging and product wise," Mr. Allchin wrote. He added, "We should think first about an integrated solution -- that is our strength."
The Allchin memo is included in one of the Justice Department's court filings. Microsoft says the memo should be read mainly as a recommendation for improving Windows, which benefits users and Microsoft.
Microsoft's strategy has certainly pounded Netscape. Last week, the Internet pioneer announced that it would report a sizable loss for 1997.
Still, antitrust policy is not intended to protect companies but to protect economic and consumer welfare. Economists who study high-technology markets say the issues in the Microsoft case are complex.
"An operating system is an evolving creature, adding more features and functions over time," said Carl Shapiro, a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley and a former chief economist in the Justice Department's antitrust division. "But there is a problem if Microsoft can use its market power to stifle innovation because start-ups never really get a market test if they are killed in the crib before they become a core threat to Microsoft."

HEADLINE: Russia's Nuclear Temptation

 BODY:
The end of the cold war has produced an alarming nuclear irony. Russia is now more dependent on its nuclear weapons than ever and at the same time those weapons are more vulnerable. That increases the chances that in a severe crisis Moscow might consider using them. It is imperative for Washington to help reverse that trend, and President Clinton has the tools to do so, if he is willing to use them.
When the cold war ended, the Soviet Union had one of the largest land armies in the world, an abundance of conventional weapons and a nuclear strike force nearly equal to that of the United States. Since then, domestic politics, economic problems and general neglect of the military have left Russia with a hollow conventional force. As that force has deteriorated, Russian military planners have placed increased emphasis on nuclear weapons, which are less expensive to maintain. 
 But steeply declining defense budgets have left even some of those weapons dangerously exposed. Most Russian ballistic-missile submarines are kept in port because it costs less to keep them idle than to put them to sea. That makes it easier for another country to knock out Russia's submarine fleet. NATO's ill-advised expansion, if approved, will bring Western forces closer to the Russian border. While a NATO strike against Russian nuclear weapons now seems unimaginable, the psychology of vulnerability on the Russian side is real.
The Clinton Administration should act to defuse this growing nuclear risk. Progress in negotiating and ratifying new arms reduction treaties has slowed, held back in part by the opposition of Communists and nationalists in the Russian parliament and Republicans in the United States Senate. But Mr. Clinton and President Boris Yeltsin of Russia can move on their own to take off high alert some of the 3,000 nuclear warheads each side now has ready to fire at the other on short notice. George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev took a similar step with nuclear bombers and missiles in 1991.
Such a decision would provide additional time for communication and diplomacy in a crisis. About a third of American warheads could now be taken off alert without risking national security. Russia can be expected to reciprocate. Specifically, Mr. Clinton could order the launch keys for part of the MX missile force removed. MX guidance systems could be taken out of the missiles and stored in their silos. Silos could even be covered with heavy objects that would have to be removed before launching.
Several of these ideas have been proposed by former Senator Sam Nunn and Bruce Blair of the Brookings Institution and are viewed favorably by American military planners. All that is needed now is for Mr. Clinton to take political leadership on this issue. Reducing Russia's reliance on nuclear weapons ought to be a concern of the highest order for the Clinton Administration.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Tackle Crisis In Indonesia

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Jan. 11

 BODY:
With Asia's economic crisis threatening to set off political upheaval in Indonesia, a team of President Clinton's top aides arrived here this evening and immediately began searching for ways to stop the free fall of the region's currencies and stock markets.
The officials met tonight with one of Asia's senior leaders, Lee Kuan Yew, the founder of modern Singapore. Both American and Asian officials acknowledged that the potent mixture of Asia's continuing market panic and the sudden political uncertainties over the future of President Suharto of Indonesia will make the situation over the next several days particularly volatile. 
 "This began as an economic crisis, but now it is having political and social consequences that are increasingly difficult to contain," a senior adviser to President Clinton, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in Washington before the delegation of officials from the Treasury, State and Defense Departments and the National Security Council was sent over the weekend.
"It has suddenly become an issue of stability and security," added the official, noting how the stock and currency markets were both triggering and responding to the political uncertainties.
A result is that an array of officials are rushing to Jakarta, Indonesia's capital, to assess President Suharto's economic intentions and his political future. The first to arrive was Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official of the International Monetary Fund, which has made it clear that a $40 billion bailout program for Indonesia could be suspended if the country does not comply with its terms.
On Monday, the American delegation, led by Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, will fly to Jakarta to meet with Mr. Suharto and his economic officials. On Tuesday, they will be joined by Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, who is on a previously scheduled Pacific tour. The director general of the I.M.F., Michel Camdessus, is expected later in the week.
Tonight, after seeking Mr. Lee's assessment of events in Indonesia and elsewhere, Mr. Summers offered few specifics about what he would seek to accomplish in Jakarta.
"We are here on behalf of the President to consult with the countries in the region on economic policy," he said, measuring his words to keep from further roiling the markets, "and to urge sound policies that can promote confidence and stability."
Mr. Suharto is at the center of the concerns. Since taking power in 1965, he has governed the world's fourth most populous nation largely without challenge, enabling his children and friends to snap up the most lucrative of the country's huge infrastructure projects and export operations.
Despite the rampant corruption that has long made Indonesia an expensive place to do business, private investors and major companies poured billions of dollars into the country -- and into Suharto family enterprises -- viewing it as one of Asia's fastest growing and largest markets.
But economic crisis has resulted in a rapid turn of sentiment. And suddenly the ailing, 76-year-old leader is under pressure from three directions.
The markets battered Indonesia's currency with a fury last week, as investors sold it out of fear that the country's resistance to reforms dictated by the I.M.F. could lead to the failure of the October bailout plan.
The hemorrhaging of the currency, in turn, has greatly raised the probability that Indonesian companies could default on its foreign debt, which by most estimates is at least $80 billion. The weakness of the rupiah makes it far more difficult for Indonesian companies to pay back the loans. At current rates, repaying $1 of loan requires more than three times the amount of local currency than it did earlier this year.
The second pressure comes from the I.M.F. and foreign leaders. In a phone call to Mr. Suharto on Thursday, Mr. Clinton stressed the importance of restoring market confidence by enforcing Indonesia's commitments to the I.M.F. But that means enforcing austerity in a country that despite its remarkable growth, still suffers from considerable poverty. Mr. Suharto reportedly told Mr. Clinton that he would enact the reforms.
On Saturday night, according to Indonesian news reports, he ordered the cancellation of billions of dollars in projects, including three power plants and an airport. But there are growing doubts about whether he will follow through.
The third pressure comes as a growing number of Indonesians, including retired generals and few academics, are publicly calling for Mr. Suharto to step aside or designate a successor who could soon take over. Mr. Suharto faces re-election by a national assembly in March, which until a few weeks ago had appeared to be a perfunctory endorsement of his continued rule.
Many Asian officials say they believe that Mr. Suharto will remain in power. He still commands the loyalty of the military. And until now he has successfully kept a tight lid on dissent.
But Mr. Suharto was never challenged in part because of the country's spectacular economic growth. Now, with that growth severely in jeopardy, the country's best-known opposition leader, Megawati Sukarnoputri, the daughter of former President Sukarno, called over the weekend for Mr. Suharto to step down.
The issue of succession is clearly wrapped up in how investors view Indonesia as the markets reopen this week. Several major investors in Asia, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said were already looking past the Suharto era, and wondering whether his successor will end the era of crony capitalism.
In his conversation with Mr. Suharto -- which American officials will only describe in scant detail -- Mr. Clinton reportedly raised the recent example of the bailout of South Korea. In that case, the country's new leader, Kim Dae Jung, who will be inaugurated as President next month, reluctantly endorsed the I.M.F.'s dictates.
Korean banks are now working out an agreement with foreign lenders, including banking giants like Citibank and J. P. Morgan -- to delay repayment of their debts and perhaps to issue bonds, guaranteed by the Government, to restore a flow of capital into South Korea. Its currency has finally stabilized.
But working out a similar solution in Indonesia would be tricky at best. Until a successor is designated, the markets cannot be confident that Mr. Suharto's promises will bind the next government. And Indonesia's debts are spread out over hundreds of private companies, vastly complicating negotiations. Moreover, the United States would be likely to object to giving those debts a Government guarantee because it would send a message to banks and private firms around the world that they can expect to be saved from bad investment decisions if a country faces economic meltdown.
"This has to be all new to Suharto," a senior Singaporean official said tonight. "This is a man who spent his whole life learning how to control a powerful army. And suddenly he, and his army, are trying to figure out how the markets would react to this decision or that."
The American interests in this process are complex. Clearly American officials are loath to be seen meddling in the delicate issue of Indonesian succession, for fear of a ring of colonialism. Mr. Summers is expected to limit his discussion carefully to fiscal policy and economic management. But American officials do not want to lead Mr. Suharto into economic retrenchment decisions that could result in violence on the streets.
And there are effects beyond Indonesia. The Asian market declines last week were staggering, as stocks in Hong Kong fell 14 percent more, Singapore declined by 23 percent, and Manila by 19 percent. Wall Street reacted, in part due to Indonesia, with a fall of 2.9 percent on Friday, and American officials are clearly concerned about the possibility that a general loss of market confidence would spread to Tokyo and the United States.
But there are other concerns about contagion as well. The currency devaluations here could force other countries -- especially China -- to think about devaluing their currencies so that their products remain competitive in export markets. Mr. Summers is likely to travel to Beijing this week to seek renewed assurances from the Chinese authorities that they will not take that course. And the general decline in the value of assets around Asia reduces the ability of countries in the region to invest elsewhere, potentially triggering deeper economic troubles.
