HEADLINE: Budget in the Black: A Dream Come True Proves to Be Somewhat Hard to Cope With

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
What seemed like a pipe dream only months ago now seems all but assured: the Federal Government will start running budget surpluses soon, perhaps even this year, leaving Congress and the White House with a windfall on their hands.
As they begin debating what to do with it, they face three basic choices. 
 They can begin paying off some of the $5 trillion in debt the nation has accumulated, most of it in the last 15 years. They can cut taxes.
Or they can increase spending on any one of a number of popular and pet programs.
Each choice has its advocates, and the most likely outcome will no doubt involve choosing something from each category. It remains unclear whether any surpluses would be substantial enough for major initiatives of any type, and whether the new fiscal flexibility could survive an economic downturn.
But both parties in Congress and the Clinton Administration are gearing up for a battle over how to allocate whatever money does become available, marshalling arguments based on ideology, economics and tactical politics that could help define the nation's priorities as it enters a new century.
The debate centers on how best to insure continued economic growth. Economists generally advocate a reduction in the national debt as the best of the choices that are available, because by reducing the Government's need for credit it would help reduce interest rates and make more money available for private investment in new factories, technologies and other things that help spur growth.
Republicans and Democrats agree, up to a point. But after a decade in which their partisan agendas have been restricted by the deficit, both parties are reviving old priorities and they are maneuvering for advantage in this year's midterm Congressional election and the 2000 Presidential race.
Many Democrats argue that the nation is in need of investment in education, health care, poverty-fighting programs and other social needs. Without such expenditures, they say, a large portion of the population will continue to lose out in today's highly competitive economy, and the middle class will continue to lose ground, creating strains that will ultimately undermine the nation's prosperity.
"There are times when sound social investments bring you back more than reducing your debt," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat, who supports more spending on education, urban transportation and job training, among other programs.
But most Republicans object to additional spending, both on the grounds that it is an inefficient way of promoting economic growth and because it runs counter to their efforts to shrink the size and influence of the Federal Government.
Republicans, therefore, tend to support tax cuts for ideological as well as economic reasons -- and to see great political appeal in tax cuts, too.
"It's about downsizing the size and power of Washington and upsizing the power of individual Americans by leaving more money in their pockets to use as they see fit," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
To economists, the big question is whether anything will be left for reducing the debt after the politicians finish their grab for spending increases and tax cuts.
"The economics are totally disconnected from the politics," said Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, who is now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "The economics of paying down the debt is that it produces distant and diffuse benefits to the economy, which to incumbent politicians have virtually no salience."
 
Paying Off the Debt
The national debt stood at $204 billion at the end of World War II. It took 30 years for the debt to double. Then it doubled again between 1975 and 1982. In the last 15 years it has grown more than four-fold as the Federal Government financed the huge budget deficits it began running early in the Reagan Administration by issuing more and more Treasury bonds.
Eliminating the annual budget deficit means the nation is no longer adding to its total debt. Net interest payments on the debt are one of the biggest Federal expenditures, amounting to $244 billion last year, 15.2 percent of all Government spending and an amount equal to 3.1 percent of the nation's total economic output.
The debt will decline only if Washington makes a policy decision to begin paying it off by applying any surpluses to it.
One of the most compelling reasons to do so is that reducing the debt would give the nation additional financial flexibility in dealing with the likelihood that the approaching retirement of the baby boom generation, starting around 2010, will exhaust the money set aside to pay Social Security and Medicare benefits.
Some analysts think the benefits of reducing the debt, while real, are overstated. They say that as the economy expands, the debt load and the accompanying interest payments will become a correspondingly lesser drag on growth. As a percentage of total economic activity, the Government's net interest payments will be cut in half over the next decade, to 1.5 percent of gross domestic product, the Congressional Budget Office said last week.
Recent polls have suggested that voters see reducing the debt as the best use for any surplus, and many members of both parties in Congress say dealing with the debt has to be at least a part of any approach they adopt. But even advocates of putting debt-reduction first said it would be a struggle to keep the demand for tax cuts and more spending at bay.
"It will be difficult," said Representative Jim Bunning, a Republican from Kentucky. "The political dynamic will have to become secondary to what's best for the country."
 
Cutting Taxes
The economic benefits of tax cuts have been heatedly debated since President Reagan adopted the supply-side argument that broad-based tax reductions would more than pay for themselves by unleashing a wave of additional growth.
Democrats, in addition to many economists, have long derided the supply-side approach, blaming it for leading the nation down the path of huge deficits in the first place.
"I will do everything I can to prevent anyone from using a projected future surplus as a pretext for returning to the failed policies of the past," President Clinton bluntly warned Republicans last week not to push for a big tax reduction.
But the enthusiasm for tax cutting remains undiminished among most Republicans. Even if they make only modest claims for the economic benefits, they see tax cuts as a way to starve and therefore shrink the Federal Government, an ideological goal toward which they have made little progress.
"I have no philosophical objection to reducing the debt," said Daniel J. Mitchell, a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group that is influential among Republicans. "I just don't think you get nearly the return you get from tax relief."
Americans are less taxed than citizens of almost any other nation. Nonetheless, by one important measure -- Federal revenues as a percentage of total economic output, a figure that stands at about 19.9 percent -- the nation's tax burden is hovering close to its post-World War II high. Republicans said that figure alone, which is partly a result of the tax increases of 1990 and 1993 and partly a result of strong economic growth, is justification for more tax cuts now.
But even the most ardent tax cutters agree that some tax cuts are better than others when it comes to increasing growth. Speaker Newt Gingrich is among those who have been calling in recent weeks for any surplus to be applied to an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates or another form of broad-based tax relief.
Conservatives want to avoid settling for narrow tax reductions of the type that the Clinton Administration and the Republican leaders endorsed last year. They included steps like a $500-a-child tax credit that do little or nothing to spur more savings and investment.
The tax-cutting proposal with the most momentum is to reduce or eliminate the so-called marriage penalty. This penalty leaves many married couples in which both partners work with higher tax bills than if they were unmarried. But it would cost the Treasury at least $20 billion a year in foregone revenue to eliminate the marriage penalty completely.
 
Spending More
As with the question of the economic impact of tax cuts, there is a raging debate about the economic payoff from many types of Government spending. But as with tax cuts, there is inexorable political pressure, even among some Republicans, for more spending.
In the last week alone, Mr. Clinton proposed big increases for the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly and of Federal support for child care. Mr. Clinton structured his proposals in a way that he said was fiscally responsible: the proposals to make Medicare and other health coverage more readily available to people as young as 55 would be largely paid for by those who benefit from them. But Republicans said he was already indulging the Democratic penchant for ever-larger Government programs that ultimately will prove wasteful and inefficient and put the taxpayers on the hook.
Proponents of increased spending on education, health coverage, child care, job training and other social needs say the country cannot afford not to invest more in those areas -- and that every dollar spent on improving school systems, for example, or preventing drug abuse, saves much more down the road by keeping people out of jail and off welfare.
The American people "know that throwing money at problems doesn't work," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat. "But they also know that nothing substantial can happen on the cheap, and they understand the urgency of investing in the future."
The other category of spending already being hotly debated in Congress is building roads, bridges and mass transit systems. Proponents, and there are many in both parties, say such projects improve the nation's economic strength by creating jobs and allowing goods and people to move around more quickly.
Opponents say such projects are often little more than old-fashioned pork, something concrete for elected representatives to bring home to their constituents.

HEADLINE: Eldon W. Lyle, 89, a Fighter Of Diseases Affecting Roses

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Eldon W. Lyle, a noted plant pathologist of Tyler, the East Texas town known as a center of rose research, died on Dec. 28 at a Tyler nursing home. He was 89 and had lived in Tyler most of his life.
Dr. Lyle earned international renown in the fight against diseases affecting the rose, like black spot, a devastating fungus that causes leaves to wither and drop and keeps the plants from flowering. He discovered how to control the pest over 50 years ago when he devised a carefully planned pattern of spraying the rose crops that form a mainstay of Tyler's agriculture and the whole region's economy. 
 He also raised the fame of Tyler roses by developing a cutting method that aids the formation of each rose bush and makes it hardy enough to withstand winter's cold. Heading the Texas Rose Research Foundation in Tyler, he was closely associated for many years with the annual Texas Rose Festival and Tyler Rose Park, a huge municipal garden and tourist attraction.
His advice to rose fanciers battling black spot fungus was a steady program of spraying every week to 10 days, from the time the first rose leaf buds break to early fall. His recipe was one-half tablespoon of either maneb (Manzate) or folpet (Phaltan) combined with one-half tablespoon of benomyl (Benlate) to one gallon of water.
"Roses don't need a lot of care," he often said. "They need a little on a regular basis."
A native of Corpus Christi, Tex., he graduated from Oregon State University and began to study roses at Cornell University, where he wrote a dissertation on the control of black spot disease for his doctorate in 1937.
He arrived in Tyler at a time when leading growers were raising their sights from the local market to the state and national levels and started testing their rootstocks scientifically. Hired as a plant pathologist, Dr. Lyle helped breed various varieties as he investigated hybrids, genetic composition, cultural adaptation and fertilizer needs to achieve maximum results.
He expected to conduct full-time research under field conditions to control rust disease and red spider mites and instead found a black spot epidemic raging throughout the region's rose industry. It left bushes weak and market stocks poor, but he managed within three years to control the disease with commercially produced dust fungicides, assuring him a national reputation.
Twice widowed, Dr. Lyle leaves no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Chorus of Politicians, Executives and Experts Is Unable to Agree on the Key

 BODY:
Following are comments from politicians, educators, economists and cultural leaders about the projected budget surpluses and what to do with the money. 

Rep. Bill Archer
Republican of Texas
Chairman, Ways and Means Committee
 I'm conservative in almost all things, but I'm especially conservative when it comes to money. I believe the American people are overtaxed. I believe the Government spends too much. And I believe the Government can't solve people's problems by taking taxes from one group of citizens in order to give it to another group of citizens
Yes, I believe in a balanced budget and I fought hard to enact one. I'm proud of that. But I'm not a conservative because I believe in a balanced budget. I'm conservative because I believe that a smaller government with less power means greater freedom and more opportunity for the American people
It isn't about accounting and it isn't about numbers. It's about our values, our principles, our beliefs. It's about downsizing the size and power of Washington and upsizing the power of individual Americans by leaving more money in their pockets to use as they see fit.
When the day of a surplus arrives, and it will thanks to a Republican Congress, I believe it should be used to reduce the tax burden on the American people and to pay down our national debt.
 
Hugo F. Sonnenschein
President, University of Chicago
 University of Chicago economist Gary Becker won the Nobel Prize in 1992 for successfully showing that "human capital" of the kind created by education is as vital as financial and physical capital to a prosperous economy.
Investments in human capital are the best ways to guarantee that tomorrow's workers will compete successfully in the increasingly competitive global economy. And the success of the American people in the decades ahead depends on the quality of the human capital they bring to the global economic table.
Chicago economist Kevin Murphy has shown that the average college graduate earns twice as much over a lifetime as the average high school graduate. They are twice as productive and will pay significantly higher taxes.
The best, most fundamental education provides students access to the entire world of knowledge and teaches a profound appreciation for the possibilities of human achievement.
Such education creates citizens who will help lead our debates about issues from human cloning to the role of government in social welfare to the importance of the exploration and colonization of space.
There is one more way in which education adds value to society: by training the scientists and scholars who create the innovation -- in science, technology, medicine, business -- that in turn drives our economic growth.
 
Priscilla Lisicich
Executive Director
Safe Streets Campaign, Tacoma, Wash.
 The most important thing I think we need to do is to keep mobilizing the people in our communities to stop violence and substance abuse.
I think we need to free the funds up to come right to the local level. A second arena where I think we need funding is for creating more job and job-training opportunities for our young people as well as for people in disenfranchised communities.
I would like to see more energy focused on building stronger support for education. We need to provide more fiscal support for our communities to provide good schooling and the support systems, insuring a curriculum is available and that teachers receive the kind of training they need to help build young people to be successful in today's economic community.
I also think that we need to provide a focus on rebuilding or improving transportation systems in this nation.
When I think about quality of life, we need health systems, we need to address a national health plan, we need to be able to support particularly our children and insure their healthy future.
I would look to see us reverse the trend on building more jails and we need to invest in prevention and building opportunities for people in communities rather than continuing to incarcerate.
 
Mayor Richard M. Daley
Democrat of Chicago
 I would spend the money in the three areas that are central to the continued revival of our big cities, and of the nation as a whole: education, drug abuse and job training.
In Chicago, we're determined that we have to improve the public schools to give our young people a chance at a decent life and to encourage the middle class to remain in the city. It means spending money to repair and renovate school buildings and to add summer school classes and early childhood programs.
Drugs are the source of many of the evils of our society. They ruin lives, they breed crime, they destroy neighborhoods and they tear families apart. If we could sharply reduce the amount of illegal drugs in our society, we would solve a lot of society's problems.
Finally, the Federal Government could spend some money to strengthen the links between the educational system and the world of work. We need to work with the schools, community colleges, employers and the unions in a coordinated effort to improve job-training programs.
We should start by making sure our young people are prepared to become productive, responsible, caring members of society. That means they have to be well-educated, drug-free and job-ready.
 
Senator Pete V. Domenici
Republican of New Mexico
Chairman, Senate Budget Committee
 After nearly 30 years of deficit spending, news of a black-ink budget is obviously welcome. But as we enter this new era we should be careful to do no harm.
First, the Congressional Budget Office forecast still projects a slight deficit for the current year, and smaller deficits for the next two years. It is not until 2001 that the surplus amounts to much -- $14 billion, growing to $69 billion in 2002. Indeed, over the next five years a vast sum of $73 billion is expected to accumulate.
Over the same period, Federal spending will exceed $8.8 trillion. Therefore, this $73 billion surplus is less than eight-tenths of 1 percent of the Federal spending expected over these next five years. Not a lot of running room for those who have begun to lay claim to it, and certainly well within the range of estimating errors.
Therefore, we should first apply a portion of any surplus to shoring up our Social Security and Medicare systems. Second, I would favor applying a portion of the surplus to a modified marriage-penalty fix in the Federal tax code. And finally I would consider applying some portion toward living up to the Federal Government's prior commitments -- but do not make more commitments until the ones we already have are addressed. Here I'm talking about national parks and Federal infrastructure commitments.
 
Rep. Richard A. Gephardt
Democrat of Missouri
House Minority Leader
 Being from Missouri, I have a "show me" approach to surplus spending -- show me the surplus and then we'll talk about how to spend it. After a lot of sacrifice and discipline, we have put the economy on the right track and essentially balanced the budget. What a wasted effort this would be if we immediately returned to the failed policies of the 1980's that put us in the hole we've been trying to dig our way out of ever since.
In my view, the goal in any budget and spending equation is, How do we keep the economy growing at a high rate? Higher growth means better jobs, higher wages, a higher standard of living and lower deficits. If a high, sustained rate of economic growth is the goal, then every spare dollar should be plowed into the things that grow the economy -- education, child care, Social Security and middle-income tax relief.
Middle income taxpayers made the biggest sacrifices in order to balance the budget. It is those people, together with the President and Congressional Democrats who made the hard decisions, who should decide how best to spend any deficit cutting dividends. The benefit of this dividend, therefore, should be spent on those who made the greatest sacrifice.
The Republican leaders in Congress are the last people who ought to have a say in how any surplus gets spent. They, after all, opposed the budgets in 1990 and 1993 that brought this deficit to the point of producing a surplus.
 
Robert Hormats
Vice Chairman
Goldman Sachs International
 My initial view is that we should avoid a bidding war among politicians to spend a budget surplus that we are not sure we have, and if we have it we are not sure how long it's going to last. And the trouble is when you start deciding how to spend something like this there is a tendency for politicians to get carried away attempting to curry public favor by large spending increases or large tax cuts which could erode any surplus very quickly.
The best investment in the future is to pay down the national debt, or slow its growth, which reduces the future interest-burden on our children and enhances future growth prospects.
If, after a couple of years, we have a substantial surplus we might use some of the money to provide incentives for individuals to establish private retirement accounts to supplement Social Security. That would go hand-in-glove with the idea of meaningful Social Security reform, which would improve the prospects for retirees to have higher income in their old age without increasing payroll taxes on the next generation of workers to pay those benefits.
The remaining portion should address educational needs, because an investment in human capital will provide higher returns to the country and improve prospects for continued productivity, which in turn will strengthen revenues in future years helping to insure continued surpluses.
 
Nathan Leventhal
President, Lincoln Center
I would think that a very modest portion of any budget surplus, should there be one, should be used to restore funding for the nation's cultural institutions, so that each American would be contributing 62 cents rather than the current 38 cents. That would be about $75 million restored through the N.E.A.
On another subject, the concept of substantial Federal support through revenue sharing or other devices to our major urban areas seems to have slipped from the agendas of some of our political leaders. This would be an appropriate time to take steps to reinforce the economic strength of all of our major cities and industrial areas.
Two specific areas would be a revival of Federal support for new construction of housing, which has virtually evaporated in the last decade. Secondly, greatly increased aid to all levels of public education, including public universities, which are struggling throughout the country to keep their tuition affordable to the increasingly lower-income populations that they are serving.
 
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan
Democrat of New York
The current economic expansion is now in its seventh year and shows no signs of ending. The unemployment rate is below 5 percent for the first time in 24 years and the current official inflation rate -- which almost certainly is overstated -- is about 2 percent. The deficit has been reduced from $290 billion in fiscal year 1992 to $22 billion in fiscal year 1997, or less than three-tenths of 1 percent of our G.D.P.
In no small part, this present moment can be attributed to the budget policies included in the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993. The tax increases and spending cuts imposed then were not popular but they were absolutely imperative. As chairman of the Senate Finance Committee at the time, I can assure you that we knew what we were doing. We had to put a stop to the ever-growing and unprecedented level of deficit spending and we did just that.
We have dealt with the deficit, now is the time to deal with the debt.
In 10 to 15 years, the full impact of the baby boomers will appear in the budget. Now is not the time to be cutting taxes. Now is the time to save. It often helps in these matters to have a goal. I suggest that we undertake to reduce the national debt by $1 trillion over the next 10 years. It is doable, and it must be done.

HEADLINE: Governor Proposes Surplus Be Used for Construction

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 11

 BODY:
With New York State's coffers flush with unexpected revenue, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed today paying for a variety of construction projects with $425 million in cash, rather than adding to the state's $30 billion debt by issuing bonds.
In a preview of the 1998-99 budget he plans to release later this month, Mr. Pataki said the state would save $260 million in interest by paying for the projects with cash from the 1998 budget surplus, rather than borrowing to finance them. 
 The construction projects include renovating Rich Stadium in Buffalo and building a sports complex on Coney Island.
"I am proposing that we use this opportunity to do the fiscally responsible thing by paying down the state's debt," Mr. Pataki said in a written statement. "Others may look at surpluses as a reason to increase spending, but I am here to insure that they do not."
Mr. Pataki's proposal helps set the stage for what is almost certain to be a fierce election-year battle over how to spend a budget surplus that is estimated to be as much as $2 billion. Earlier this week, the Governor proposed accelerating property-tax reductions the Legislature adopted last year, saying he wanted to put money back into New Yorkers' pockets sooner than the legislation required.
Mr. Pataki's latest proposal drew a lukewarm response from Mr. Pataki's main rival in the Legislature, Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the Democratic-led Assembly.
Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said the Speaker would not take a position on the Governor's plan until he had the chance to see whether the budget Mr. Pataki proposes this month provides enough money to pay for schools, day care for needy families and other programs that Mr. Silver supports. "We're adopting a wait-and-see approach," Ms. Lynch said.
The Governor's plan is intended to change the way the state pays for the so-called Community Enhancement Facility Assistance Program that he and the Legislature enacted last year. The program allows the state to issue 30-year bonds to pay for a variety of economic development projects.
But the program has been widely criticized by representatives of anti-tax groups and other fiscally conservative organizations. Because the program allows the Governor and legislative leaders to spend $425 million on projects of their choosing, the critics contend, it essentially amounts to a blank check they can use on pork-barrel projects.
Brian Backstrom, the vice president of Change-NY, a conservative group that has been a strong ally of the Governor, described Mr. Pataki's proposal today as an empty gesture.
Mr. Backstrom said that while he supported the idea of retiring state debt, he did not believe it was appropriate for the Governor and legislative leaders to have "a slush fund" that allows them to dole out pork-barrel projects.
"Normally, pay as you go is far more responsible than borrowing and adding to the state's enormous debt load," he said. "But this proposal is nothing but putting a new wrapper on a completely unnecessary and irresponsible slush fund. You can dress it up however you want, but this program belongs in the garbage can."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Back Baltic Membership In NATO, but Not Anytime Soon

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
The United States and the three Baltic nations will sign a formal charter on Friday that explicitly supports efforts by Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to become members of NATO, American officials say.
The document, called the Charter of Partnership, does not promise them membership -- a commitment that Washington could not make on its own in any case. Instead, it is a formal statement of common interests and common goals that future American administrations will find difficult to dilute. 
 Without pledging the United States to the defense of the Baltic countries, the charter embodies a moral and political commitment to the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of the three tiny lands, whose quest for independence sped the disintegration of the Soviet Union.
President Clinton will be joined at a White House signing ceremony by Presidents Lennart Meri of Estonia, Guntis Ulmanis of Latvia and Algirdas Brazauskas of Lithuania.
For the Clinton Administration, this public display of commitment will be the most formal demonstration to date that America's plans for Europe's future are not limited to the first round of NATO expansion.
Even that first round remains controversial. The Senate has yet to approve the admission of Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. A vote on that issue is expected in the spring.
The Baltic charter has involved a year of diplomatic work, with negotiators cognizant not only of Moscow's concerns, but also of those of skeptical NATO allies and American Senators.
"The Russian response so far," one senior Administration official said, "has been surprisingly quiet and matter-of-fact." American officials have begun to brief Russian officials here on the text of the charter and expect a more negative public reaction after the signing on Friday.
In its most contentious and intensely negotiated section, the charter promises the Baltic nations that Washington will do everything possible to get them ready to join NATO and supports their efforts to do so.
But there is significant opposition to their membership on political and military grounds, and officials say the issue is not likely to surface during the presidencies of Mr. Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
America's NATO allies insisted that the charter make clear, as it now does in its final version, that any Baltic membership of NATO will depend not only on each country's readiness to join, but also on NATO's determination that including any Baltic country "would serve the overall strategic interests of the alliance."
A senior diplomat from a NATO country said: "Membership must not be just in the interest of the Baltic states. It must be in NATO's interests." Had Washington pushed Baltic membership now, he said, it would have seriously worsened larger European strategic interests.
While NATO countries have different views, the diplomat said, membership will depend in large part on how well the Baltic countries themselves improve their relations with Russia. That, he predicted, will take a decade or longer.
That is why some critics suspect that the White House wants to have it both ways.
Holding a highly public event with the Baltic leaders and emphasizing that NATO's door remains open is important for American principles as well as for domestic political concerns.
Refusing to recognize the Soviet annexation of the Baltic nations, which followed the Nazi-Soviet pact of 1939, Washington preserved their embassies here. And since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Washington has worked hard to get Russian troops out of the Baltics, to promote economic and political stability and to help give the Baltic countries some idea of how to defend themselves.
At the same time, Washington can rely on NATO allies to insure that Baltic membership in the alliance is put off for the foreseeable future.
Ojars Kalnins, Latvia's Ambassador to Washington, sees the charter as "a culmination of the last six years of the extraordinary U.S.-Baltic relationship since independence."
"This is a historic document in which we assert common interests, values and a common vision of the further development of the European continent, including our integration into that new European security and economic structure," Mr. Kalnins said.
While the Baltic countries would have liked more specifics on NATO membership, he said, they did not expect it.
The charter also establishes some new, concrete institutions: a four-party "partnership commission" of the United States and the Baltic nations, to be chaired by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott; working groups on economic development to be formed by Washington and each Baltic state, to be chaired on the American side by Under Secretary of State Stuart Eizenstat, and similar working groups, already established, on defense issues.
This charter, a senior American official said, is intended to give each Baltic nation "a perspective for the future, to reassure them they are not being forgotten and that they have a level playing field for future NATO expansion."
"We want to show them that they are part of the vision and part of the process," the official said.
That vision, he explained, is that of a fully integrated Europe, where the Baltic nations can become members of all European and trans-Atlantic institutions, including the European Union, NATO and the World Trade Organization.
The Americans have told the Baltic Governments explicitly not to expect to be part of any second round of NATO expansion. Washington would like to see such a round in 1999, assuming that the Senate and the legislatures of other NATO members first approve membership for the Poles, Hungarians and Czechs.
Washington has told Baltic leaders that their own eventual membership is a political and moral "litmus test" of the American strategy for a peaceful and democratic Europe, "whole and free." But at the same time, there is concern over antagonizing Russia.
Paul A. Goble, a Baltic expert and former State Department official who works at Radio Free Europe/ Radio Liberty, said, "In some sense, while I want the Balts in NATO now, I believe that they will not enter NATO until Russia stops fearing NATO" -- in other words, until NATO is so transformed that it is more of an organization of cooperative security than of collective defense.
"I think that's sooner than many think," he said. "NATO is already being transformed, and I tell the Balts that the NATO they get into will not be the NATO they expect to join."
In a speech at Stanford University in September, Mr. Talbott described the American task as balancing the anxieties of the Baltic countries about Russia, combined with their aspirations to join NATO, against "Russia's fear and loathing at the prospect."
"Quite bluntly, Russians need to get over their neuralgia on this subject," Mr. Talbott said. "They need to stop looking at the Baltic region as a pathway for foreign armies or as a buffer zone."
The three Baltic Presidents will take part in a series of public meetings and events in Washington and New York, including meetings with nearly every senior American Cabinet secretary and with think tanks, banks and businessmen.
President Brazauskas of Lithuania is now a lame duck with the recent election of Valdas Adamkus, who was born in Lithuania but fled as a teen-ager as the country was forcibly absorbed into the Soviet Union. He went to the United States, retiring in 1996 as a top administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's Chicago region. His American ties are a sensitive subject for Moscow.
American and NATO officials have carefully monitored Russian reaction. In the last year, American officials and officials of NATO countries say, Moscow has sharply toned down its pressure on and statements about Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and is concentrating more on regional economic cooperation with all countries on the Baltic Sea.
Moscow originally insisted on an American commitment that the Baltic states would never join NATO. But in his summit meeting in Helsinki in March 1997 with Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Clinton refused to rule out Baltic membership. Mr. Yeltsin proved willing to sign a formal agreement of understanding with NATO anyway, breaking the logjam of Russian opposition to the first round of NATO expansion, which was announced in Madrid in July.
The Russians, through Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin in July and Mr. Yeltsin in late October and again last month in Stockholm, have moved to offer the Baltic nations "joint security guarantees," alongside Western and NATO guarantees, so long as the states agree not to join NATO, remaining neutral on the model of Finland.
Russia is also offering normalization of relations and an end to border disputes, including tacit permission, if any were needed, for Baltic countries to join the European Union or any non-NATO organization.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has told Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia that Washington and Moscow should simply agree to disagree on the possibility of future Baltic membership in NATO and work together instead on regional economic and environmental cooperation.

HEADLINE: Crisis in Asia Brings World To New York

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The Italian, British, Japanese and American investment bankers who met last week around a conference table at Citicorp headquarters in Manhattan had at least two things in common: an abiding interest in the economic crisis in Asia, and the belief that the most logical place to talk about it was New York City.
That New York would become central to the Asian story, economists and international trade experts say, was neither obvious nor predictable. Banks in Japan and in Europe have more exposure to debt from troubled countries like South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia -- and thus more at stake -- than banks in the United States. The International Monetary Fund, which is supervising the bailouts in those countries, is based in Washington. 
 Yet the Asian crisis, at least for now, is not being principally addressed in Tokyo or London or Hong Kong, but in the corporate canyons of Manhattan. The strength of the dollar and the stability of the United States economy, the longstanding political relationships between the United States and Far Eastern nations, the staggering profitability of America's biggest investment houses -- almost all based in New York -- have contributed to a single, shared global insight: New York is where the money is.
The decline of world political tensions since the end of the cold war has been a factor as well, experts say. A crisis that would once have raised the highest levels of alert within the State Department has been seen, in the 1990's, as simply an economic crisis and therefore more the concern of the capitalists in New York than the diplomats in Washington.
"The money is being more controlled now, and it's being controlled by New York," said Anthony P. DeCaro, an independent international trade consultant who has worked with many Asian governments.
There is a certain sweet irony for the city in all this. For many years, New York has supposedly been doomed to a future as one among many financial capitals. But the Asian crisis has highlighted the continued importance of a central economic hub. Government officials in South Korea could have gone anywhere for their economic hired guns, but they chose New York-based Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Smith Barney as their official advisers.
In the world of international finance, all eyes are on New York. "We're in a very unusual position," said Jeff Bahrenburg, a global strategist and first vice president at Merrill Lynch. Eventually, he said, other financial centers and nations, especially Japan, will return to greater influence. "But in the interim it's going to force companies to come here to get financing," he said. "New York will be the main center."
Economists and financial experts are divided about how long this New York minute may last or what it might mean for the city, mainly because Asia's turmoil is so volatile and its implications so mixed.
Some banks based in New York, for example, have already been hurt by bad Asian loans. Sales to investors of international stocks and mutual funds are expected to decline, and tourism from Asia to New York has slowed to a trickle. Companies that import goods from South Korea have been hit by crosscurrents: Imports are cheaper because of the currency changes, but Korean producers are more anxious for payment. At the same time, their sales here have shrunk because their customers, Korean immigrants, have been sending millions of dollars to relatives back home.
But the major potential effects on the city, the experts say, are all yet to come -- it is simply too early in a rapidly evolving story to detect them. The important thing, they say, is that New York is in the game and calling the plays.
In the 1980's, for example, when New York similarly became a center for working through a debt crisis in Latin America, it took years for the effects to emerge fully, but they were profound. Many of the foreign banks and securities companies that gradually entered the city to be closer to the Latin American action stayed when it was over. New York's role as a center of what came to be called emerging market investing grew partly from the Latin American experience, said Lawrence R. Uhlick, the executive director of the Institute of International Bankers, a trade group based in New York.
With Asia, the current theme is caution. Few economists are predicting dire effects for the United States or New York as its money capital -- at least at this stage -- but hardly anyone is expecting an employment boom either, except perhaps in the rarefied realm of international traders and analysts. If the crisis can be contained and resolved, however, the long-term benefits to the city will be huge as market barriers are dropped and New York becomes identified as a portal to their entry.
Some firms may get a windfall from the billions of dollars in fees that are expected from bond sales, restructured debts and rewritten legal trade agreements. For example, Coudert Brothers, a law firm based in New York and specializing in international trade, has already seen an increase in business, mainly from export and import contracts that have suddenly had to be amended.
The volatility of the world's money has also increased activity at currency trading desks, where billions of dollars change hands on fractional changes in values. Opportunities have also emerged for companies with profits to invest. Merrill Lynch recently expanded its presence in Asia by buying some assets of a big Japanese investment house.
A World Trade Organization agreement signed last month in Geneva is expected to be particularly favorable for the city in the long run. Under the agreement, capital-starved Asian countries agreed to drop longstanding barriers to financial activity by foreign companies. The agreement, trade officials said, was a direct result of the Asian crisis, and will benefit the United States -- and thus New York as the national money capital -- for years to come.
"Of any region of the country, we are the ones who will benefit the most, because the preponderance of the corporations that will benefit are right here in New York," said Rae Rosen, the senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, referring to the trade agreement.
Although consumers in Asia are expected to buy fewer imported goods in the short term, the effect will likely bypass the New York region, where exports to Asia are a small part of the economic mix.
And economists say imports from Asia -- made cheaper by the fall in Asian currency values -- will act like a lid on prices that will keep down inflation, and thus interest rates. That could lead to a boom in refinancing of debt that would further benefit New York.
"There is potential for a lot of positives," Richard K. Strauss, a financial services analyst at Goldman, Sachs who follows the securities industry. He said one of the main effects of the Asian crisis in the United States -- falling interest rates -- might cause a boom in refinancing, as companies try to get lower rates. That alone could create huge profits for the securities industry, he said.
But New York's moment as economic ringmaster cannot last, the experts say. Tokyo has been humbled for now, but its banks and other financial institutions are rebuilding their strength. London, Paris and Frankfurt have been focused on the internal issues surrounding European economic unification next year, but will probably also re-emerge more aggressively after that. A sale of new South Korean debt would undoubtedly have to involve all the world's markets to be successful, and that will also take the focus off New York.
The bankers who met at Citicorp agreed on Thursday to a crucial step on South Korea's debt -- allowing more time to repay up to $28 billion.
"I don't see 10 years from now New York being the undisputed global center of the world," said Mr. Bahrenburg at Merrill Lynch. The city may get some disproportionate benefits in the short term, he said. But in the long run, he said, "everyone will win," because a more equalized system of financial capitals means more customers for everybody.

HEADLINE: Casinos Paying Top Dollar To Coddle Elite Gamblers

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
It was past midnight at the Mirage Casino and Resort, and the actor Bruce Willis was sitting at a blackjack table, an unlit cigar between his teeth, drinking watermelon juice made especially for him and wagering more than $200,000 an hour. With $8,000 riding on one hand, Mr. Willis was dealt an ace and a 10. He slapped the winning cards down on the felt table. "Look what I got," he bragged.
Relishing a lucky streak and a stack of more than $50,000 in winnings in front of him, Mr. Willis looked over at a group of friends at another reserved blackjack table, drinking free bottles of Louis Roederer Cristal and betting thousands of dollars each hand. Celebrating his good fortune, the movie star thrust his arms above his head, like a referee signaling a touchdown. 
 "Fran, give me a kiss," Mr. Willis said to his dealer, a friendly woman in her 40's who blushed and obliged, blowing a kiss.
With the competition for wealthy, high-stakes gamblers intensifying, casino operators like nothing better than to see some of their top customers, like Mr. Willis, the basketball star Dennis Rodman and the Australian media mogul Kerry Packer, wagering huge sums of money and having a good time doing it.
These men are members of an elite, a growing group of the highest of high rollers who once belonged exclusively to a handful of casinos but who are now being heavily recruited by casinos across the United States and around the world.
Although the spread of casinos has made gambling more accessible to average Americans and prompted companies to expand their use of slot machines, their buffet dinners and their theme-park-style attractions to lure middle-income customers, casinos are nevertheless spending more time and money than ever courting people like Mr. Willis, who is considered a premium player, and Mr. Packer, who is in a top tier of gamblers known as whales.
Premium players, who typically wager from $100,000 to $250,000 a visit, number in the thousands. But whales, who gamble more than $1 million a visit and who may have lines of credit up to $20 million and win up to $26 million in one visit to a casino, number only about 250 in the world, those who recruit them say.
The competition for the top high rollers is global, and because wealthy gamblers are also aggressively pursued by Asian and Australian casinos, American casinos "are trying to compete with these markets in a way that has never been seen before," said Robin M. Farley, a gaming industry analyst at BT Alex. Brown. "A lot of capital is being invested in high-end play."
Along Las Vegas Boulevard, temples of opulence are rising to attract wealthy gamblers. The Las Vegas Hilton recently spent $44 million to build three suites to house its biggest bettors, and Caesars Palace, another favorite of high rollers, spent $13 million on two luxury suites. Mirage Resorts recently spent an estimated $150 million on art, including paintings by Renoir, Monet, Cezanne, Van Gogh and Picasso. They hang behind the frosted-glass doors of the Mirage's high-stakes gambling room, but next year the company plans to move the paintings to the Bellagio, a $1.8 billion hotel and casino it is building to cater to big spenders.
Farther down the Las Vegas Strip, at the MGM Grand, a $700 million redevelopment project will include a building housing 30 private villas called the Mansion, where guests can step into a gigantic courtyard that appears to be outside but is actually enclosed under a climate-controlled dome. "Even the air they breathe will be exclusive," Ms. Farley said.
To stay close to some of the world's richest gamblers, major American casino companies have offices in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore and Sao Paulo, Brazil.
Because so many high-stakes gamblers come from Asian countries, industry executives and Wall Street analysts are trying to gauge what effect Asia's deepening economic crisis will have on the casino business.
"What will happen to the high-roller business for which the casinos are gearing up?" Ms. Farley wrote in a research report. "Will the currency crisis beach the whales?"
Mark Juliano, the president of Caesars Atlantic City, said, "Anybody who tells you the economic crisis is not going to have an effect on their business has got to be kidding."
So far there are few signs that the competition for premium gamblers and whales is slowing. Well-paid marketing executives, or "player development" people, continue to travel around the world, calling on wealthy gamblers, offering them expensive gifts, corporate jets to fly them to the casinos, lavish accommodations, huge lines of credit for gambling and a discount on their losses. Once the gamblers are on the casino premises, 24-hour butlers are at their service, and personal hosts cater to their every need.
The places most frequented by whales and premium players in Las Vegas are the Mirage, the MGM Grand, Caesars Palace and the Las Vegas Hilton. The whales are not sighted in Atlantic City as often, but the Taj Mahal and Caesars are their preferred destinations there.
One of the most widely recognized and wealthiest whales in the world is Kerry Francis Bullmore Packer, the media tycoon and financier who is one of Australian's richest citizens. Mr. Packer did not respond to telephone calls to his office in Sydney.
Other well-known whales include members of Malaysia's Quek family, which has holdings in real estate, banking and manufacturing; the Saudi arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi, who, according to one casino executive, arrives in town with an entourage that includes his barber and masseuse; and the Sultan of Brunei, one of the world's richest men, who, a Las Vegas casino executive said, placed $250,000 chips all over a roulette table for each spin.
One American whom some industry executives include among the whales is Roger King, the chairman of King World Productions, which distributes syndicated television programs like "Oprah" and "Jeopardy." Mr. King is as well known around Atlantic City and Las Vegas for his antics as for his wagering. In 1993, according to a report by New Jersey casino regulators, after a night of gambling and drinking, Mr. King threw up at a casino bar, asked an employee to help him procure a prostitute and later accused employees of stealing his money. Mr. King declined to comment for this article.
A dealer sued Mr. King in 1987 after Mr. King had won $22,500 on a hand of baccarat. The dealer testified that Mr. King, in a fit of excitement, had hugged him and lifted him off the floor by his throat, holding him until others urged him to let go. The dealer won compensatory damages.
The ranks of premium players are much larger. Casino executives name Mr. Willis, the professional basketball players Charles Barkley and Mr. Rodman and the magazine publisher Larry Flynt. Although he may be classified only as a premium player, Mr. Flynt waded into whale territory when he gambled thousands of dollars a hand at blackjack for some 16 hours on a visit to the Las Vegas Hilton, Ralph Priola, an assistant manager at the hotel, said.
Everything the top gamblers receive is complimentary, and few requests are out of the question. Whether it is Chateau Petrus 1982 or Chateau Lafite-Rothschild 1961 -- both sell for thousands of dollars a bottle -- hotel and casino employees comply.
Sometimes the requests are unreasonable or illegal, like procuring prostitutes or drugs, or break local gaming regulations, like setting up a private room for gambling. "We've had people ask for things that we just won't do," said Mr. Juliano, the president of Caesars Atlantic City. But one executive at a major casino in Las Vegas recounted an occasion in recent weeks when hotel employees had to devise a system of code words to deliver dozens of prostitutes to the suite of one high roller. As the women arrived, "if he didn't like them, he'd give them $300 and send them away," said the executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "At one point, he had 30 women in his suite at one time."
All casinos that cater to high-end players have lavish suites available for their best players. The rooms are reserved exclusively for high rollers, and are rarely made available for rent. To receive an invitation to stay in the suites, "we like to see that you've had a million dollars circulating in the casino at one time," Mr. Priola said. He recalled that he had given a tour of the Hilton villas to Donald J. Trump, himself a casino developer. Mr. Trump walked through the smallest of the three villas -- 12,600 square feet of Italian marble, wall and ceiling murals, swimming pool, media room and three bathrooms with Jacuzzis and fireplaces -- and remarked, "The next time I'm out here, I'll have to stay here."
But, Mr. Priola pointed out, Mr. Trump is not a high roller: despite his wealth he would not be permitted to stay in the villas. "The bottom line is, if you don't generate enough credit as a player, even he wouldn't be able to stay here," Mr. Priola said. (Mr. Trump has high-roller suites at his Taj Mahal hotel and casino in Atlantic City.)
Although few in number, whales contribute significantly to a casino's revenues, since many of them have the potential to bet as much as $1 billion annually, industry experts say. The gamblers like anonymity, and casinos provide them with private planes, private hotel entrances, private elevators and gambling rooms away from the public and as close to private as the state allows.
A casino that caters to the top gamblers cannot be fainthearted. Although some whales play blackjack, the game of choice is baccarat, which has only a 1 percent advantage for the house, and the bets often climb as high as $250,000 a hand. A customer betting at this level can win millions on one visit, devastate the company's quarterly earnings and make shareholders cringe. But the casino that can sustain such short-term losses knows that the customer will be back, and over time, the house's advantage will prevail.
A gambler with a $1 million line of credit receives $100,000 to bet with upon arrival. And if that gambler loses $1 million, the casino will discount the loss as much as 20 percent, leaving the customer owing $800,000. The reason for such generosity is clear. Industry analysts estimate total worldwide annual revenues from high-roller play to be about $3 billion.
By providing amenities and services to the small number of whales around the world, casinos are making a relatively safe bet that while they may not trap the gamblers with regularity, they are most certain to make their properties more attractive to the midlevel players who contribute the largest percentage of revenues.
"A lot of this investment in high-end play improves play overall," Ms. Farley said. "The improved standards are a draw to other players."
As much as casinos relish the high rollers, doing business with them can have its pitfalls. When they win, the whales and premium players leave with the casino's money immediately. But when the high-rollers lose, casino operators sometimes have a difficult time collecting the debt. The credit that is extended to the top gamblers is about as binding as a gentleman's agreement, and bettors who wager millions of dollars can be excessive risk takers who eventually run out of money.
For all that they give to lure high rollers, casino companies can never be sure that their coveted catch will stay in the net. "The problem is they might not stay," said Marvin Roffman, a gaming industry analyst based in Philadelphia. "They'll check into the free hotel suite, take the free chauffeured car that the casino gives them, and go over to another casino."

(Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)(pg. A19)

HEADLINE: Paul O'Leary, Economist, Is Dead at 96

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Paul M. O'Leary, an economist who oversaw the rationing program during World War II, died Jan. 1 at the Kendal at Ithaca nursing home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 96.
Dr. O'Leary served on the faculty of Cornell University from 1924 until 1967, taking several leaves to join other economists from Eastern universities in President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "brain trust." During the Depression he was an aide to the consumer advisory board of the National Recovery Administration and later was chief economic analyst for the Commerce Department. 
 His most prominent role, however, was running the rationing program as the deputy chief of the Office of Price Administration in the early years of World War II. Mr. O'Leary oversaw the distribution of the books of paper coupons required for purchases of fuel, food and other commodities. It was a job that forced Mr. O'Leary, described at the time as plain-spoken, to deny many people and industries the goods they wanted.
Faced with what he called a desperate situation in September 1942, Mr. O'Leary decreed that any apartment building or commercial building that could convert to burning coal had to do so to help ease the shortage of fuel oil to heat homes.
Later that year, he decided to ration coffee purchases to one pound every five weeks -- about one cup a day -- despite criticism that there was no need to allocate what was hardly a nutritional requirement.
"We're not making semi-moralistic distinctions between necessary foods and so-called luxury foods," he told The Associated Press in 1942. "We don't feel that it is our business to tell people what they should eat and drink."
In August 1943, Mr. O'Leary resigned after disputes with Prentiss M. Brown, the new head of the Office of Price Administration, who opposed the methods of the "professors and theorists" in the agency. Mr. Brown had dismissed John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economics professor, who had been in charge of the agency's price-setting division.
Mr. O'Leary returned to Cornell, and in 1946 served as the first dean of its newly formed business school. In 1951, he became dean of the college of arts and sciences. In 1957, he returned to teaching and research in his specialty, American financial history.
Mr. O'Leary was born in Lawrenceville, Kan., and studied at the University of Kansas and Harvard before receiving a doctorate from Cornell in 1929. He was the widower of Harriet Barton O'Leary. He is survived by a brother, Theodore O'Leary of Shawnee Mission, Kan.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
U.S. Offers Support To Baltic Nations
The United States and the three Baltic nations will sign a formal "Charter of Partnership" on Friday that, without promising NATO membership to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, explicitly supports their efforts to join the security alliance eventually, American officials said. A1
 
A Gandhi Steps Up in India
In the southern Indian town where Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was assassinated in 1991, his widow, Sonia, said she would "step forward" into the political life of the ailing Congress Party. With elections due soon, many think she will seek the Prime Minister's job. A1 

U.S. Delegation Goes to Asia
A team of President Clinton's top aides arrived in Singapore and met with local authorities to search for ways to stop the free falls of Southeast Asia's currencies and stock markets. They and other experts will meet later with President Suharto of Indonesia, whose reluctance to enact reforms has led to calls for his resignation. A6
 
Hong Kong Bank Shuts Doors
The largest investment bank in Asia outside Japan, Peregrine Investments Holdings, was forced to shut down today, the first major casualty of the economic crisis that has swept through the region and the first major bankruptcy in Hong Kong since the territory reverted to Chinese rule last July. Prices plunged on the Hong Kong stock market, with the Hang Seng market index falling nearly 10 percent immediately after trading began. A6
 
Chiapas Women Protest Army
Indian women gathered to protest the Mexican Army's invasion of their villages in southern Chiapas state, saying the soldiers made children cry. President Ernesto Zedillo ordered the army to search for illegal weapons, but the soldiers have concentrated their searches in villages known to sympathize with Zapatista rebels. A3
 
Belfast Killing Raises Tension
A Protestant paramilitary group said it fatally shot the nephew by marriage of Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. The man killed, Terry Enwright, 28, was working as a doorman at a Belfast night club owned by relatives of the leader of the Progressive Unionist Party, which represents Protestant paramilitary groups at the peace talks on Northern Ireland. A3
 
Envoys Will Go to Algeria
Envoys from Canada and the Arab League are expected to arrive in Algiers today as part of stepped-up international efforts to reduce the violence in Algeria, where hundreds of civilians have been massacred in recent weeks. An armed group attacked the village of Sidi Hammed near Algiers late Sunday, wiping out "dozens of families," the newspaper Liberte reported today. The Government has blamed Islamic militants for the attacks. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A14-19
 
Government Rejects Plea In Unabom Case
After a week in which Theodore J. Kaczynski reduced the Unabom case to chaos, a weekend review of a new offer of a guilty plea was rejected by the Justice Department because Mr. Kaczynski seemed to be trying to retain a chance at freedom, people close to the talks said. The talks showed that both sides in the trial were struggling to find a way to end what has become a public spectacle. A1
 
Reducing Drugs in Prison
President Clinton is expected to sign a directive today ordering the states to report the extent of drug use in prisons, which will be used to create a base figure that each state must improve upon before it can qualify for Federal money for prisons. The document reflects a belief within the Administration that crimping the supply of drugs in prison will cut the demand for them after the convicts are released. A1
 
A Choice Assignment
Congress and the White House have three basic choices in deciding what to with a Federal Government surplus that now seems almost assured: They can begin paying off some of the $5 trillion in debt the nation has accumulated. They can cut taxes. Or they can increase spending on any one of a number of popular and pet programs. Both parties in Congress and the Clinton Administration are preparing for a battle over how to allocate whatever money does become available, marshaling arguments based on ideology, economics and tactical politics. A18
 
School as a Means to an End
Students are increasingly disengaged and view education less as a vehicle to expand their minds and more as a means to increase their incomes, a survey of college freshmen shows. The annual nationwide poll shows that two suggested goals of education -- "to be very well off financially" and "to develop a meaningful philosophy of life" -- have switched places in the past three decades. Professors and administrators say it is not news to them. A14
 
Washington Losing on Meters
The District of Columbia says it is losing millions of dollars a year in revenue from parking meters that have been decapitated by vandals. Only 7,000 of 15,776 meters work, officials say, and repairs cannot keep pace with the vandalism. Motorists, of course, see a benefit. A14
 
First Norplant Trial to Begin
Six Texas women go to trial this week, demanding compensation from Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, the makers of the Norplant birth control device. The women say that they were deceived about the severity of Norplant's side effects. The women are among about 50,000 nationwide who have filed suit over Norplant, which is surgically implanted, and theirs is the first case to go to trial. Women have complained of health problems including severe depression and ovaarian cysts. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
Ice Storm Is Taxing Even the Toughest
Even the hardiest souls find themselves astonished at the scope of damage wrought by the massive ice storm that has paralyzed much of Upstate New York and parts of New England and Canada. But in Watertown, N.Y., officials found reasons for optimism. Most main roads were passable thanks to a melt on Saturday. And there was hope that electricity could be returned to parts of Watertown by today. B6
 
End to Rivalry in Sight
A religious dispute from the Old World has smoldered for years on the tranquil streets of Astoria, Queens, with rivals who are united by culture and separated by 13 days -- the difference between the Gregorian calendar, the one used throughout the Western world and accepted by the Greek Orthodox Church, and the old Julian calendar, to which a smaller movement of Orthodox traditionalists has clung. Now, though, the Greek-Americans of Astoria say reconciliation is in sight. The Old Calendrists have petitioned the New Calendrists to rejoin the Greek Orthodox Church. B1
 
Ferraro Issues Debate Demand
Geraldine A. Ferraro said she would not debate her opponents in the race for Democratic nomination to the United States Senate unless they signed a pledge promising not to "engage in personal attacks" in the primary. Both her opponents said they would sign such a pledge. B3

HEADLINE: Amid Asian Turmoil, Bullish Forecast for New York City

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The Asian economic crisis has created uncertainty and heightened volatility in many parts of the world, but not in New York City. Most economists say that 1998 will be much like 1997: steady, with job growth led by Wall Street, and a continued overall surge in tourism.
The economy, according to most forecasts, is expected to grow more slowly than last year, reflecting a slowing national growth rate. The New York City Office of Management and Budget, for example, expects the city to create about 31,000 new jobs, compared with 47,000 last year. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall's office has projected an increase of 37,000 new jobs for the city. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, slightly more optimistic, is predicting 40,000 new jobs. 
For the most part, the forecasters say, Asia's troubles will remain a distant cloud on the city's horizon. The number of tourists from the Far East is expected to remain depressed, but increasing numbers of visitors from other places, especially other areas of the United States, will offset the drop in Asian tourists. Decreased exports, as Asians reduce their foreign purchases, are expected to have only a minimal effect because exports to Asia are not a big part of the local economy. Employment in manufacturing and government will continue to decline, economists say, but the sharp drops of years past appear to be over.
On the other hand, the boom in tourism leaves little room for growth. A study by PKF Consulting, which tracks the hotel industry, said that the number of hotel night stays in the city would remain flat, because at 83 percent capacity, the city's hotel rooms are for practical purposes all booked up.

HEADLINE: Northern New York Battles Ice Damage

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 11

 BODY:
The people who live in this old mill town do not flinch when a foot of snow falls overnight, or when the mercury plunges below zero, or when the bitter winds whip off Lake Ontario. Everyone remembers the blizzard of '77, when the snow drifts touched the roofs of the old frame houses on Rutland Street. This is not a town for soft people.
But even the hardiest souls find themselves astonished at the scope of damage wrought by the huge ice storm that has paralyzed much of upstate New York and parts of New England and Canada. Heavy ice has splintered thousands of trees and downed thousands of power lines upstate. The precipitation, combined with snow melt, has pushed the Black River and other tributaries to record crests, flooding low-lying areas that include hundreds of houses in places like Watertown and Carthage. 
 The immense upstate counties that run along Lake Ontario and the Canadian border are largely without electrical power. Full repairs could take a month, or longer. Officials at the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation say that much of the power system must be rebuilt.
"It looks like a B-52 made a practice run," said Trooper R. A. Amyot of the state police. "Things are down all over the place."
Today, though, as chalky flakes of snow fell on Watertown, local officials found reasons for optimism. Most main roads were passable thanks to a melt on Saturday. And today's original forecast of a foot of snow and temperatures in the single digits proved too extreme. Only about four inches of snow accumulated and temperatures remained in the 20's. This allowed the nearly 3,000 Niagara Mohawk emergency workers to hurriedly begin restoring power lines and repairing transformers. But they hoped that electricity could be returned to parts of Watertown by Monday.
"We've faced many, many emergencies," said James Cosgrove, a Niagara Mohawk spokesman, "but nothing of this magnitude. These people are hurting." Mr. Cosgrove said Niagara Mohawk attempted to dispatch six helicopters to fully assess damages, but the snowfall and gray skies forced the company to cancel the trips.
In other parts of the country, the storm caused floods across the South and spread thick, clinging ice across the Northeast and the eastern third of Canada. At least five deaths were blamed on the storm in Canada, as well as three in Maine and one in New York.
In southeastern Canada, some 11,000 Canadian Army troops were helping in the effort to restore power to 900,000 households without electricity today. Officials said parts of Montreal could be without power for two weeks.
Utility officials estimated that 229,000 homes and businesses still had no electricity today in Maine, with 41,000 blacked out in New Hampshire and 36,000 in Vermont. Niagara Mohawk officials estimated that 300,000 people across upstate New York remained without power. Gov. George E. Pataki today asked President Clinton to make Lewis the sixth upstate county to be declared a Federal disaster area. On Saturday, Mr. Clinton named Jefferson, St. Lawrence, Franklin, Clinton and Essex Counties as disaster areas.
The Federal Emergency Management Agency has established a disaster field office in Albany. Nearly 5,000 state workers in a dozen agencies are involved in storm relief, including 2,288 National Guard soldiers.
Fire, police and emergency workers rumbled up Interstate 81 early today. Food, bottled water, scores of power generators and other supplies also poured in, though more is needed. The New York City Fire Department dispatched its urban search and rescue team of 11 vehicles, 21 firefighters and two emergency medical technicians.
Bob Hagemann, the Jefferson County Administrator in Watertown, said the lighter snowfall today was a relief but he worried that any amount of snow could cover downed power lines. "We're tremendously concerned about public safety and that people are going to come across live wires," Mr. Hagemann said.
The brunt of the storm hit Wednesday night, and it continued until early Friday, stretching across New York roughly from Watertown through the Adirondacks to Glens Falls. Usually, the North Country would be blanketed in snow by now, but mild winter temperatures meant that this storm's heavy precipitation fell as ice, not snow. The ice coated trees and power lines, weighing them down and allowing heavy winds to tear them apart. In Watertown, the trees on the town square were splintered with huge branches strewn among downed power lines.
Many people warmed their homes with emergency generators or wood stoves or fireplaces. But thousands of others fled to shelters. Mr. Pataki said the total number of people in upstate shelters was 9,031, including 1,200 people in SUNY Potsdam.
In Jefferson County, which has a population of 110,000 people, more than 2,100 people are staying in 40 shelters set up in schools and firehouses. Nearly 300 people have sought refuge inside Watertown High School, and some have been there since Thursday.
Amal Shata took her two small children and her elderly mother, Zeze Salmon, who recently joined the family from Egypt. "My Mom just came last year, and she is shocked," Ms. Shata said. "It was very, very scary."
Mona Henry took her two sons on Saturday afternoon after her youngest, Richard, 2, developed an ear infection from sleeping in their unheated house. "I don't have the money to buy a generator or a kerosene lantern, so I'll wait for the power to come on," Ms. Henry said. Like others, she said she realized that her family may be stuck inside the shelter for the rest of the week.
Across the street at Kinney Drugs, two pharmacists, Ruth Ellen Wickwire and James Peters, filled prescriptions by the light of a battery-operated lantern. Mr. Peters said he was able to stay at his rural home outside Watertown because his wife had driven to Rochester to purchase a 5,000-watt generator.
Mr. Peters said he had collected rainwater from a tub outside, then heated it on a wood stove for a bath. Ms. Wickwire said she and her sister were making do with a kerosene heater and a fireplace.
Waiting for a prescription, a nun, Sister Carol, said 40 sisters and 10 others were huddled at the Sisters of St. Joseph Mother House. She said they were keeping warm with a generator and passing the time playing cards and board games.
"We're praying for all of those who are not as fortunate as we are," Sister Carol said. "If there is anybody who is cold, they're welcome to come to the Mother House."
After using an emergency generator for two days, Watertown's largest hospital, Samaritan Medical Center, suddenly found itself in a crisis at 7:20 this morning. A hospital spokesman, Timothy Gleason, said the generator collapsed from strain, leaving Samaritan without power for seven minutes. In the intensive care unit, nurses manually pumped air for patients on ventilators. A backup generator eventually restored some power.
"Until we get back to full power," Mr. Gleason said, "it's still a real tense situation."
At 3:30 P.M., the hospital regained full power when Niagara Mohawk ran a special electric line.
Despite the strain, 12 babies were born on Thursday and Friday at Samaritan, including Ryan Caldwell. Ryan's father, Eric Caldwell, cleared fallen branches from the driveway on Thursday to drive his wife, Paula, to the hospital. Then Mr. Caldwell spent Saturday in Syracuse buying a generator so the family could return home today.
The practical problems that lie ahead for people in Watertown and throughout the North Country are enormous. Since the banks -- and automated teller machines -- are closed, many people are running out of cash. Jefferson County's 1,000 employees were unable to pick up their paychecks on Thursday. What stores opened today dealt mostly in cash, though there were many examples of generosity. Scott Gray, owner of Gray's Flower Shop, arrived at Samaritan Medical Center with a box of free candles. Mr. Gray estimated that he had distributed thousands of free candles.
"I don't have the heart to sit there and make money off someone's hardship," he said.
The Watertown Police, however, reported a handful of attempted robberies on Saturday night in the town's darkened business district. Mr. Hagemann, the County Administrator, said the long-term effect of this storm would not be known for some time. "It will have a tremendous economic impact," he predicted. "Businesses have been down since Wednesday or Thursday."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Four National Guard soldiers, among 2,288 dispatched to northern New York after a paralyzing ice storm, cleared storm debris yesterday in front of American Red Cross offices on State Street in Watertown. As snow added to the impact of an ice storm in Watertown, N.Y., John Lindstrom, a Consolidated Edison employee, was among thousands of utility workers putting in 16-hour days to restore electricity. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In South Korea, A Prudent Bailout;
What to Do Next

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Lawrence B. Lindsey (Op-Ed, Jan. 6) hit the nail on the head about the danger of bailing out insolvent countries. Since the Mexican rescue, the message has been clear: imprudent investments will be backstopped by Uncle Sam, so swing for the fence. 
 The United States and the International Monetary Fund should announce that they are out of the bailout business as of Jan. 1, 2000. The United States should redirect part of its I.M.F. support to three to five newly chartered, competing bank insurance companies. These should be public-private entities that would offer insurance to foreign banks on market terms. The premiums would be paid in cash, and trading partners would be encouraged to adopt standards of disclosure like those in the United States.
Finally, I.M.F. funds should only be used to support our trading partners' transition from central banks to currency boards, which cannot create money and therefore excess liquidity. The program would encourage the growth of democracy, as cronyism and corruption would be exposed to the light of capitalism.
 
TIMOTHY R. DOWLING
Charlotte, N.C., Jan. 6, 1998
