HEADLINE: ON PRO BASKETBALL;
Say This for Knicks: They're Never Boring

BYLINE: By Mike Wise 

 BODY:
There were 2.4 seconds left, and the Seattle SuperSonics were inbounding under their own basket with a chance to win the game. Gary Payton wanted to pass to Vin Baker, but Baker could not free himself from his defender. In one of those away-from-the-action snapshots, you could understand why.
Buck Williams, classy veteran, elder statesman and all-round swell guy, clenched Baker's jersey in his hands the way a pit bull might clench a rag doll with his teeth. 
 Dale Ellis became Payton's option, and John Starks was shadowing him as he launched the last errant shot of a wildly entertaining game last night at Madison Square Garden that was won, remarkably, by the Knicks, 92-91. "They grabbed my jersey earlier," Williams said. And then, perhaps speaking for his team, he added, "I did what I had to do."
When Coach Jeff Van Gundy said the Knicks had gone from the hunted to the hunter after Patrick Ewing was lost to injury, it sounded as if he had spent his down time watching B-movies. But after nine games without Ewing, whatever the Knicks are pulling from their Injured All-Star Survival Kit is working.
"I've been watching a lot of Classic Sports," Starks said, "and all those guys ever talk about is how mentally tough you got to be. I'm convinced that's all it is."
Can the Knicks keep this up? Who knows? They beat the team with the best record in the National Basketball Association last night after coming within a point of knocking off Chicago on Friday. They are 5-4 in Ewing's absence.
For the price of admission, you are no longer guaranteed a 7-foot superstar. But you do get to ride the Starks roller coaster, watch Williams and Charles Oakley lose layers of skin on their knees and occasionally see Larry Johnson and Allan Houston play like the next best things to franchise players.
"I know people don't think we have what it takes to keep playing like this, but that is irrelevant," Houston said. "Those people aren't playing."
Or as Oakley said succinctly, "We know what we have in our house."
The perception is that they cannot keep this up, that sooner rather than later their adrenaline rush will wear off and they will settle into a world of mediocrity. But the other side of that argument is this: The more they learn to play without Ewing and recognize their new roles, the more cohesive and confident the Knicks will become.
It is not a given, but games like last night's make you wonder. The atmosphere at tip-off had all the electricity of a zoning-ordinance meeting. Even with Payton and Baker and their marvelous team, whose record is 29-7, making their only trip to New York this season.
The Knicks had taken a 47-43 lead at the half, yet the building did not spring to life until near the end of the third quarter, when the Sonics seemed to be hampered by New York's defense. And then Starks, shooting 1 for 9 from the floor after three quarters, ignited his team. With fewer than four minutes left, he hit back-to-back 3-pointers that brought the crowd to its feet. The second shot, a 27-footer from the right wing with a man in his face, put New York ahead by 88-87.
After Ellis's miss at the end, the Knicks embraced. Starks began looking for Van Gundy. "Jeff! Jeff!" he yelled as the coach left the court. Van Gundy finally looked back. Starks clenched his fist and double-clutched twice.
About Van Gundy: masterful game plan. You give him a day to prepare for any team in the league, and the odds are his team will be in the game. He did a few things that surprised Seattle, one of which was to put the 6-foot-6-inch Houston on the 6-3 Payton.
It not only curbed Payton's effectiveness in the post, but also gave him longer arms to shoot over from the perimeter. Van Gundy also used Williams well, playing the 37-year-old power forward an economical 24 minutes when he could have been tempted to play him longer. He also told the Knicks to attack the basket, instead of settling for jump shots against Seattle's vaunted traps and double teams.
Van Gundy has a lot of detractors, but at least he listens to what they have to say. At one point, a talkative fan of about 12 behind the bench told Van Gundy to watch Oakley's defense on Ellis. "O.K., thanks," Van Gundy said. "I will."
The Knicks are making us reconsider what we think about them. They have more warts than the largest toad, more structural flaws than the Mir. But they do what they have to do with the tools they have.
After the madness was over and the antacids were gone, and the Knicks had treated their fans to a third improbable finish in five nights, Starks was asked if this crazy, up-and-down existence -- an existence that was the same when Ewing played -- would ever end.
"That's how it is in New York," he said. "That's how it always is."
There is a good chance the ride will not be as long this year. But here in the arena of America's Tums team, it is still as wild as ever.

HEADLINE: Think Globally, Focus Locally;
Seeking 'Cruising Speed', Washington Post Editors Prefer Stability to Sizzle

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
It's not Ben Bradlee's Post anymore.
The Washington Post that Leonard Downie Jr., the executive editor, and Robert G. Kaiser, managing editor, inherited from Benjamin C. Bradlee seven years ago is bigger, richer, fatter and farther-reaching than ever. 
 But the oversized aura that once suffused The Post -- what Mr. Downie calls the "superman image" that pervaded the newsroom when Mr. Bradlee was pushing his reporters after scoops -- has yielded to a more subdued ambiance.
Mr. Kaiser's announcement last week that he intended to return to reporting after June 30 was a new turning point, and underscored the distance the paper has come under Mr. Bradlee's two proteges.
It is as if Mr. Downie and Mr. Kaiser had managed at last to achieve the "cruising speed" that Mr. Bradlee often said he admired in other great papers. Still, there are plenty of careful Post readers who wish their paper would do less cruising and more of the old hard-driving that gave The Post its reputation in the 1970's.
But Mr. Kaiser thinks the critics remember only the glory, not the gaffes; Watergate, and not the 1981 Pulitzer Prize the paper had to return after the reporter, Janet Cooke, confessed she had invented her story of an 8-year-old heroin user.
"The Post of 1974, for which I was the Moscow correspondent and which I dearly loved, was still Ben Bradlee's Post," Mr. Kaiser said, speaking of the Watergate year, "and Ben's notion of a newspaper was to have a lot of flash and spark and creativity, that it should contain something every day that would get everybody talking about The Post."
But, he added, "It was uneven as hell, and Janet Cooke was the ultimate expression of flash over control."
Mr. Kaiser, 54, said that a record of cool management was epitaph enough. "My proudest accomplishment is that I helped Len get through seven years with no disasters, no explosions," Mr. Kaiser said, "and I consider it our biggest compliment that we have survived the most charismatic newspaper editor in the United States of America."
Steadiness and sobriety, not sizzle, seem to be the watchwords as The Post moves forward. In an era of post-modernism, in the post-cold war world, the paper that Mr. Kaiser's successor will share with Mr. Downie has emerged as the post-Post.
The evidence of change is everywhere.
The Post's news staff now includes 660 full-time and 90 flex-time employees -- most of the latter are working mothers -- making it twice as big as in the Watergate year of 1974, when President Richard M. Nixon resigned as the scandal reached its apex. Then, The Post news staff numbered just 356. Most of the new slots and new space have been used to strengthen the coverage of the city and the surrounding suburbs -- some of the wealthiest areas in the country.
In those suburbs, The Post is king. The paper's weekday circulation is near a record high at 776,000, its 65 percent Sunday penetration of all households in the Washington area is deeper than that of all five leading New York metropolitan region papers combined. And the sheer square footage of newsprint devoted to news each week has increased by almost 50 percent.
To cap it all off, the stock price of its parent, the Washington Post Company, hit a record of $489.63 on December 15; it closed at $465.875 Friday. (In August of 1981, when the only major competitor of The Post, The Washington Star, closed, the Washington Post Company's stock price hovered between $25 and $30.)
The fruits of this economic success have been put back into coverage. In recent months, the paper has begun publishing suburban tabloids two and three times a week for distant counties from a ring of new suburban bureaus, using 30 new reporters, editors and photographers.
Perhaps because the changes have been so sweeping, when the paper's top editors and its publisher, Donald E. Graham, talk about what they have done, they tend to talk more about reach than reporting.
"If you drive 50 miles west of the District of Columbia you end up in a place called Fauquier County, Va., where 47 percent of all adults read The Washington Post on Sundays," said Mr. Graham, 52, who is also president of the Post Company, when asked to describe what his paper had accomplished.
"And if you drive 50 miles east to St. Mary's County, Md., you end up in a place where 40 percent of all adults read The Post," he added.
What is missing in this inventory of success are accounts of the articles themselves. Even readers who love The Post complain that while the paper delivers the news with unstinting depth and breadth, it rarely surprises.
"Their definition of news is more conventional than that of The Los Angeles Times or The New York Times," said Thomas B. Rosenstiel, a former media critic for The Los Angeles Times and now director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism, a media watchdog group chiefly financed by the Pew Charitable Trusts.
"It's more institutional, more process oriented," Mr. Rosenstiel said. "Is that necessarily because they're in Washington and government is the dominant local industry? Or is it because they are operating according to conventions?"
While the paper pays close attention to the processes of government, its management is also closely focused on the newsroom staff. In particular, newsroom managers have made a concerted effort to increase the number of black, Hispanic and Asian journalists.
The effort came at a price. Tensions over race and careers were brought roughly to the surface two years ago, when an article in The New Republic portrayed The Post as a caldron of racial anger, with white staff members blaming minority preferences for stunting their careers, and blacks charging that their work was being held to a higher standard.
Despite some factual errors, Mr. Downie said, the piece hit home. "It reflected reality because we have surfaced those tensions more than any other paper has," he said. "If you don't surface those tensions then people suffer in silence, and when you surface them it creates some discomfort."
At the moment, 14 percent of the newsroom staff is made up of minority journalists; the average for newspapers over all is 11 percent.
But the increasing diversity of the staff has not always salved often- brittle relations between the paper and the city's black communities.
Marion S. Barry Jr., the District of Columbia's charismatic but troubled black Mayor, who was re-elected in 1994 after serving a prison term for misdemeanor cocaine possession, criticizes The Post with thinly veiled racial allusions.
"The Post is obsessed with trying to get me out of office, or keep me from running for office," Mr. Barry said in a statement in response to a request for comment. "It clouds the news objectives and the more they do that the more people see them for what they really are up to."
Mr. Barry's ire notwithstanding, The Post has made coverage of the daily life, achievements and culture of Washington's diverse black community staple fare.
Its efforts have not always won it praise. Ronald Walters, professor of government and politics at the University of Maryland, noted that "They still focus on the worst news coming out of the District and all the criminal justice issues." Although, he adds, "Every now and then, good stories come out of their metro section. . ."
The paper's coverage of the nation and the world has also expanded: since 1974, the number of Post foreign bureaus has gone to 20 from 11 -- the newest is a bureau in West Africa -- and the number of national bureaus has gone to six from two.
Asked about articles, Mr. Kaiser picked a few favorites: David Hoffman's 16-part series on the new Moscow elite last year; Kevin Sullivan's interview, published Friday, with President-elect Kim Dae Jung of South Korea -- a first for a Western paper, he said -- and Mr. Woodward's coverage of Vice President Al Gore's use of a White House phone to raise money for the 1996 Presidential campaign.
Some readers try to explain what is missing from The Post today by pointing to the death last year of Ann Devroy, the paper's formidable White House correspondent who routinely produced 300 articles a year, many of them exclusive reports that made reporters and politicians all around Washington take notice.
Dick Morris, the former political adviser to President Clinton, likened the 1996 Presidential campaign, with Ms. Devroy absent, to "playing the Yankees without Mickey Mantle."
Mr. Graham said that Mr. Downie would select Mr. Kaiser's replacement from within The Post newsroom. The process is expected to take several weeks.
Newsroom handicappers have already drawn up a list of potential successors to Mr. Kaiser, including Karen DeYoung, 48, the assistant managing editor for national news; David Ignatius, 47, the assistant managing editor for financial news, and Milton Coleman, 51, the deputy managing editor.
Some of the developments that will influence the decision involve yet more big changes on the horizon for The Post. Later this year, a new $250 million printing and distribution plant in College Park, Md., will open, allowing a redesigned Post to print color on all section fronts and print three separate zoned sections each day for suburban readers.
For all its reputation as a paper of Capitol Hill and the Federal encampments downtown, The Post is overwhelmingly a suburban paper, with 80 percent of its sales going to readers outside the District. (The Post, Mr. Graham and Mr. Downie separately pointed out, has the largest circulation of any newspaper in Maryland or Virginia.)
 Its reach is a matter of particular pride to Mr. Graham, whose desk is adorned with a flimsy flier from a newspaper vending machine. "Still 25 cents," it says. Mr. Graham keeps the sign as a reminder that The Post's unusually low price -- most big-city dailies charge 50 cents or more -- is part of what makes it a paper for everyone in the Washington metropolitan area, and that its enviable market dominance is confirmed each day when half of the 1.4 million households in the Washington area buy the paper.
"Here's a statistic I like," Mr. Graham said in an interview. "This morning we sold more papers in a market with four million people than The New York Times sold in an area with 14 million." (While The Times's daily circulation is 1,074,741, just 670,000 of those papers circulate in the New York metropolitan region.)
So the paper is sitting on financial, if not emotional, heights. "I think this is a good time to take stock," Mr. Downie said of his process of choosing a new managing editor by leaving the field open at the outset. "Seven years of Bob and Len is ending and we are beginning a new period, with new presses and new projects, and I need to make sure I'm not overlooking anybody."

HEADLINE: First Steps to Reclaim Streets Are Precise, Joyful, Loud

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
The sound of drums echoed through the streets, signifying the hope and renewal of one north-central Philadelphia neighborhood devastated by lost work, poverty and drugs.
Inside the rowhouse on 23d Street where she has lived for 63 years, Alice Barry, 81, put down her sewing and pulled back her curtains. "There goes my children," said Mrs. Barry, who had stitched their first uniforms four years ago. 
 Vicki Thompson, 40, heard the familiar drumbeat in her office in the community center that used to be a Roman Catholic rectory, just up the block from Mrs. Barry. "It's a different noise," Ms. Thompson said. "Years ago it was gunshots."
She hollered out the window: "Go, Foot Stompers! Go, Foot Stompers!"
On the street, Audra Holbrook, 11 years old and all legs, was leading the girls, high stepping in her red and white pleated skirt and white boots with red plumes. LaMark Shorts, 17, the captain of the boys, brought up the rear, the drummers marching tall, pounding out their message: The North Philadelphia Foot Stompers have arrived.
Up and down the block one recent morning, people went to their windows and doorways to soak up the energy of their own drill team, 16 girls and 7 boys, more welcome than any fancy parade. They were practicing, marching through the neighborhood's past and its unfolding future, past abandoned buildings and newly renovated brick rowhouses, past vegetable and flower gardens that will bloom come spring in what used to be vacant lots prowled by drug dealers and prostitutes.
"The neighborhood is rising," said Helen Brown, 56, who kept house for a rich family on Society Hill for years, and went home at night to fight to hold her battered block of 23d Street together so it could rise again.
Nothing symbolizes the rebirth more vividly than the Foot Stompers, not just a drill team, but the heartbeat of the emerging 33-block north-central Philadelphia neighborhood known as St. Elizabeth's-Diamond Street. The story of the Foot Stompers reflects the rebuilding that has required, in addition to money and political muscle, all the organization, creativity, drive and discipline that makes a drill team.
It is a rebuilding amid an urban battlefield. A man was fatally shot the day after Christmas only a block from where the Foot Stompers were marching. The unemployment rate is 29 percent. The median family income is less than $9,000 a year. In this setting, a drill team, with its military roots and rigor, is more fitting than any string band.
"Get those legs up! Get in line!" Mrs. Brown, who lost her only son, Earl, to AIDS and poured her grief and love into the drill team, was commanding the troops from a wheelchair. The cast on her left leg, which she injured while marching, has not held her back, any more than all the other obstacles.
When Mrs. Brown and a neighbor, George Manigault, started the drill team four years ago, the young people had nowhere but the streets to play. "The girls used to jump rope," Mrs. Brown said. "They were arguing among themselves -- 'Who's next?' They were hollering and hooting. All that energy. I said, 'Why don't you get a drill team?' "
Mrs. Brown being Mrs. Brown, the girls knew it was not a question. "We said, 'All right,' " recalled Sharnae Johnson, 12.
"After the jobs left, the drugs moved in," said Mrs. Brown, who went to work as a housekeeper after the electronics factory where she had worked for 26 years shut down, one more statistic in the neighborhood's downward economic spiral.
Thousands of residents had fled. In 1994, over bitter protests, the Diocese of Philadelphia closed St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church and school, long an anchor on 23d Street.
"People had gotten so discouraged," said Sharnae Johnson's grandmother, Evelyn Johnson, 69, whose 24-year-old grandson was shot to death in 1989. "They had lost hope. When a person is without hope, they don't do anything."
There were no after-school programs for the children. There was certainly no money for a drill team. Without drums, the boys practiced by beating sticks against the Philadelphia phone book.
"The phone book is a very good drum," Mr. Manigault said.
The drill team was only one idea Mr. Manigault, Mrs. Brown and others had for the neighborhood. "We had all this vision," Mrs. Brown said, "but we didn't have resources."
Sister Mary Scullion had both.
A Catholic nun and community organizer, she moved into what had been the convent of St. Elizabeth's around the time the drill team got started. Project Home, the community development corporation she founded with an accountant, Joan Dawson-McConnon, to help homeless men and women, was transforming the abandoned convent into a residence for 24 recovering drug addicts.
At 44, Sister Mary has crawled down manholes and into the darkest alleys to invite the homeless to Project Home's shelters.
"Sister Mary, she doesn't come in and say, 'We're going to do this,' " Mrs. Brown said. "She comes in block by block and asks you, 'What can Project Home do to help you?' "
Three years ago, Sister Mary had her first meeting with the residents of Mrs. Brown's block at Mrs. Brown's home. "Mrs. Barry, she said she wanted ceramics classes," Mrs. Brown recalled. "We said we didn't want any more houses to be torn down on our block. We said we would like to see our houses rehabbed."
Everyone wanted a place for the youth. As meetings were repeated on every block, neighbors who had grown wary and withdrawn through the bad times began to reconnect.
"The energy just multiplied," Sister Mary said.
She knew that the Philadelphia Plan, established by Mayor Ed Rendell and Gov. William Casey in 1994, represented a huge opportunity for St. Elizabeth's-Diamond Street. The plan has linked corporations -- the city gives them tax breaks -- with nine community development corporations working to redevelop devastated neighborhoods.
The Crown Cork and Seal Company, an international can company in northeast Philadelphia, made a 10-year, $2.5 million commitment to the St. Elizabeth's-Diamond Street neighborhood through Project Home.
The money has helped pay for the opening of the community center in the former rectory on 23d Street, along with another community center on Diamond Street. Alice Barry got her ceramics classes. There are also aerobics and adult learning classes, computers and health care provided by a part-time nurse.
A youth center has opened in the former Catholic school. A $1 million donation from the Sisters of St. Francis has helped finance the renovation of four houses in the last year, with plans to renovate 10 a year for the next 10 years.
Sister Mary made Mrs. Brown a professional community organizer. "She said I was doing it anyway, why not get paid," Mrs Brown said.
Mrs. Brown hired Ms. Thompson, who went to school to learn mortgage counseling so she could help working poor families buy the renovated three-story houses that sell for $25,000. The first family, a formerly homeless woman and her son, who works two jobs, at an auto parts store and driving a food service truck, will move in soon.
"I've been here through the bad," Ms. Thompson said. "I want to be here through the good."
The drill team has new uniforms, and money to travel to competitions. The Foot Stompers have become ambassadors for the neighborhood -- a drill team with a roomful of trophies, instead of the drug dealers many outsiders have come to associate with north Philadelphia.
"They call us the City of Brotherly Blood, North Filthy," said one of the drummers, Ron Young, 15, known as D.J. "The first thing they see is the graffiti, and it's dirty, and they think people don't care about themselves."
The Foot Stompers came marching down Ron's block two summers ago. "The noise, the marching, the drums," he said. "It was like something I'd never seen before. It was a good noise. I just looked and said, 'Dag, I wish it was me.' "
LaMark Shorts taught him how to play the drums, and soon Ron Young was a drummer, too.
The Foot Stompers say people look at them differently when they march. "They see you as a smart and active kid," Sharnae said.
"When I'm marching, people are like, 'Ooh, you play the drums,' " Ron said.
It is not how everyone sees him when he is in his usual baggy jeans and parka. "They think I'm going to rob them," said Ron, who talks of becoming a lawyer or a doctor.
Nate Robinson, 40, a recovering drug addict in Sister Mary's residence, was answering the phones at the community center when he heard the drums. "It wakes me up," said Mr. Robinson, a fork-lift operator and gospel singer who is marking seven months without drugs.
The neighborhood is awakening too, but the struggle is only beginning. Drugs are still sold openly. The sound of gunshots has faded, but not disappeared. There are still no supermarkets, dry cleaners or banks, though Mrs. Brown and her neighbors hope businesses will begin to return as the improvements continue.
Mrs. Brown, whose son was 32 when he died, knows that the young members of her drill team will have to fight to survive. "We might can't save them all," she said. "But we might can save half of them."

SECTION: Section F; Page 4; Column 1; Science Desk

HEADLINE: Japan Questions Its Costly Program to Predict Earthquakes

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
SHORTLY after 1 P.M. one day last year, the silence of a room full of computers at the Japan Meteorological Agency was suddenly broken by a warning. "An abnormal crustal change has occurred," a recorded voice announced.
A strain meter buried more than 600 feet beneath the ground some 100 miles southwest of Tokyo was showing unusual readings. Could this be a sign that a major earthquake was about to occur? 
 Akio Yoshida, director of the meteorological agency's earthquake prediction information division, pondered whether to summon the "six wise men," a group of expert seismologists who always carry pagers for just such a situation.
The six would immediately be whisked by police cars to a special room in Tokyo, where each seat at the conference table has its own large flat-panel computer screen. If the wise men, after examining the data, concluded that a "big one" was imminent, Japan's Prime Minister would be asked to issue a warning for the region southwest of Tokyo in which four million people live.
Immediately, bullet trains there would stop, highway traffic would be diverted, schools and many businesses would close and hospitals would turn away outpatients to leave room for earthquake victims. Areas prone to landslides or tsunamis would be evacuated.
On this particular day, Mr. Yoshida concluded that because the abnormal readings were coming from only one strain meter, the problem was a broken instrument and the wise men were not summoned.
But the elaborate procedure, required by a 1978 law, attests to the seriousness with which Japan treats earthquake prediction. While most nations, including the United States, believe that forecasting earthquakes is next to impossible and have scaled back such efforts, Japan has continued to spend more than $100 million a year on the task, doing everything from burying strain meters to investigating whether fish get the jitters before upheavals.
But now Japan's program faces an overhaul as well. A government advisory committee report last summer concluded, in effect, that the nation has spent more than $1.3 billion over three decades in pursuit of a nearly impossible dream.
The report only added to questioning that has intensified since scientists failed to predict the massive Kobe earthquake that killed more than 6,000 people in January 1995.
It is not surprising that Japan places so much emphasis on earthquake prediction. This archipelago is one of the most seismically active in the world, lying at the juncture of four of the earth's tectonic plates, which regularly and violently shake the surrounding region as they grind past one another. Every Sept. 1, the anniversary of the Tokyo earthquake of 1923 that killed more than 140,000 people, millions of citizens engage in earthquake preparedness drills.
"If we can succeed, we can save lives and property," Mr. Yoshida said of the prediction efforts.
Forecasting hinges mainly on observing precursors of an earthquake, like foreshocks, crustal movements, changes in the chemical composition or level of ground water or even strange animal behavior.
The Tokyo metropolitan government once sponsored research on whether catfish swim strangely before an earthquake. The Japan Marine Science and Technology Center has a video camera on the bottom of Sagami Bay to observe anaerobic clams that live on top of hydrothermal vents on the sea floor. The hypothesis is that the prequake creaking of the earth might release more methane and sulfides from the sediments, making the clams more active.
The most intensive effort, however, is focused on the Tokai region southwest of Tokyo. It is the only area for which, by law, the wise men can be called and the Prime Minister issue a warning. Scientists said the area, where three tectonic plates come together, last had a huge earthquake in 1854 and is overdue for one of magnitude 8, considered a great earthquake. Two nearby earthquakes in the 1940's were preceded by slippages along the fault. So scientists reasoned that if the same pattern occurred in Tokai, an earthquake could be predicted.
The region is now blanketed by underground strain meters. There are also four seismic stations on the seabed offshore. Minute changes in the tilt of the earth are observed using a water-filled tube more than 1,000 feet long -- sort of a giant carpenter's level. In all, 186 measurements are made round the clock and transmitted to the computer-filled monitoring room in Tokyo.
But so far, there has been no earthquake. And the Earthquake Assessment Committee, as the six wise men are formally called, has never been paged. Nor has any earthquake in Japan been successfully predicted since the first five-year plan to develop prediction methods was started in 1965. Japan is now on its seventh such plan. Some claims elsewhere in the world of successful earthquake prediction, like one in China in 1975, are disputed.
So far, no reliable precursors have been found. Foreshocks, for instance, precede some earthquakes, but not others, and in many cases, small tremors occur that are not followed by big ones. Scientists often claim to have found precursors -- but only after the earthquake has occurred. After the Kobe earthquake, for instance, Hiroshi Wakita of the University of Tokyo found that chlorine levels in the water in one well rose during the 10 months before the quake. But skeptics said it is not clear whether that would have happened anyway.
Robert J. Geller, an associate professor in earth and planetary physics at the University of Tokyo who is the loudest critic of Japan's program, argues that earthquake prediction might be more than difficult -- it might be inherently impossible. Professor Geller, an American, asserts that earthquakes are chaotic phenomena, and that how large one becomes is determined by a myriad of unmeasurable details.
"It's like a chain reaction on the highway," he said. "After the first two cars crash, can you predict how long the pileup will be?" That would require generally unknowable data such as whether the drivers in the oncoming cars are drunk and how well their brakes work.
Dr. Geller and other critics say that money spent on prediction could be better spent on basic earth science research or on designing more quakeproof structures, which might save more lives.
To be sure, some of the prediction budget is spent on pure science. Government agencies and scientists find it easier politically to obtain financing for earthquake prediction than for pure research, just as much basic medical research in the United States was financed as part of the war on cancer.
But even much of this basic research, critics contend, consists of collecting reams of data on earth movements that are not well disseminated to others. Nor is the research peer-reviewed, with the five-year earthquake prediction program being routinely renewed.
"Every time, the report says there has been a lot of progress but there are still some difficulties," said Prof. Masayuki Kikuchi of the University of Tokyo's Earthquake Research Institute. He compared the pattern to that of the Imperial Army in World War II, which kept assuring the public that Japan was winning the war while urging people to fight harder.
But defenders of the program say Japan has an obligation to continue, not only for itself but for the poorer quake-prone countries of the world.
"Can we give up efforts at prediction and just passively wait for a big one?" said Kiyoo Mogi, a professor at Nihon University and former chairman of the wise men's committee. "I don't think so."
He added: "Weather forecasters have thousands of people and satellites and big computers and a long history of data and experience every day. Despite that, they are often wrong. But if we said, 'Let's quit forecasting the weather,' we'd be an international laughingstock."
Professor Mogi argues that if a piece of glass is bent, one cannot predict when it will break because glass is homogeneous and stress is distributed uniformly. But if a piece of wood, which is heterogeneous, is bent, the weak parts will start cracking first, and a sound will be heard before the piece breaks. Similarly, he said, there are heterogeneous parts of the earth like fractures and underground water that might react before an earthquake.
Still, Dr. Mogi believes that making a definitive yes-or-no prediction, as the six wise men are required to make, is beyond current scientific capability. He argued for warnings with some probability attached, so that bullet trains could slow down, rather than stop. When his idea was rejected, he resigned from the wise men's committee in 1996.
That reflects one of the risks of earthquake prediction: a false prediction can be almost as costly as a missed one. It is estimated that if a warning were issued for Tokai, it would cost an estimated $7 billion a day in lost business and other economic disruptions. If the predicted earthquake did not occur, Dr. Mogi said, the public backlash would kill the earthquake prediction program.
"We have made people blindly believe that 100 percent prediction is possible in Tokai," he said.
On the other hand, some question how valuable a vague or probabilistic warning would be. Last Feb. 26, the day of the earthquake scare caused by the faulty meter, the Meteorological Agency did issue an advisory saying that abnormal crustal movements had been detected but that the problem might be an instrument problem. A later survey found that more than half the public ignored it.
The current five-year earthquake prediction plan ends in March 1999. A committee formed by the Ministry of Education is already working on the next plan.
In light of the big budget deficits Japan is now experiencing, the program is likely to be scaled back. But earthquake prediction has a strong constituency among the public, the scientists who receive the money and the agencies that dole it out.
Megumi Mizoue, a professor emeritus at the University of Tokyo who now heads the wise men's committee, said the new plan would devote less money to haphazardly searching for earthquake precursors like changes in underground water levels or animal behavior. But the effort to detect a Tokai earthquake will continue, he said, adding that the big earthquake might be approaching.
After scientists failed to foresee the Kobe earthquake, the response was more spending, not less. A new program of more intensive crustal observations, with its own $100 million annual budget, was started. At 1,000 locations, the Pentagon's Global Positioning Satellite system is being used to detect minuscule earth movements. But the new program is being called "observation" rather than prediction.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Graph: "The Land of Living Dangerously"
 
Japan is riddled with earthquakes because a huge slab of Pacific crust slides very slowly beneath the archipelago, shaking it up periodically. Quakes occur as plates fracture and rub against one another.
 
The major earthquakes that have hit Japan since the year 599. The bigger and darker the dot, the greater the energy released.
 
The graph shows the dramatic rise in earthquake energy on the standard scale, known as moment magnitude. A quake of magnitude 8 releases about 30 times more energy than one of magnitude 7.

LENGTH: 819 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;
Rattling Down Life's Bumpy Road

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
For a memorable rock voice, beauty doesn't count. This column is devoted to albums by songwriters whose voices crack and squeak and bawl and quiver. They're not soothing; they're unvarnished and willful, and in their flaws they reveal their humanity.
 
Victoria Williams
 Teetering between the childlike and the childish, Victoria Williams always takes her time. She sings in the high, quizzical tone of a precocious little girl, but she's no naif. Within the homey delicacy of her music, she muses on history and memory, love and family, about what's left after a life is over. On "Musings of a Creekdipper" (Atlantic), her songs suggest a leisurely rustic sphere where she can contemplate questions like "Who's going to bury the last man when he dies?," provide a wedding benediction and wish for "a train run by the sun/Connect the small towns every one." In "Blackbirds Rise" she visits a graveyard where she looks at the headstones, thinks about the moment when "Mother Earth meets Father Time and takes his hand," and takes comfort from watching the birds fly overhead. Ms. Williams's music rambles from Appalachian folk to Tin Pan Alley to rhythm-and-blues to mountain gospel, all with a casual grace that adds up to a profound tenderness. 

Fred Eaglesmith
 Fred Eaglesmith's voice is as battered and creaky as the vehicles he sings about on "Lipstick Lies and Gasoline" (Razor and Tie). There's a 1963 Stratochief in "Pontiac" that's a getaway car for a messy stickup, and a rattletrap old truck in "Water in the Fuel" that the singer is driving away from a failed romance. In Mr. Eaglesmith's songs, things are always breaking down: gearshifts, love affairs, common morality. He writes with the bluntness of classic country: "Don't ring that bell, don't sound that alarm/There ain't no use, she's already gone." And he responds to disappointment in classic American ways, like drinking, getting a gun, thinking about God, hitting the road. At heart, he knows the highway will only take him further from his hopes. Still, he's not giving up; his music clatters and twangs, like the Band with some blown gaskets, and he sounds too cantankerous not to get himself in more trouble.
 
Jon Langford
 After decades of singing with noisy, disheveled bands like the Mekons, the Waco Brothers and the Three Johns, Jon Langford leads a straightforward, streamlined rock band for his first solo album, "Skull Orchard" (Sugar Free). The songs push ahead confidently, like country-rock with an infusion of the Who, and Mr. Langford applies his gruff voice to full-fledged melodies. Within his clear-cut rockers and waltzes, Mr. Langford has a lot on his mind: commercialization, unemployment, Wales's history, private insecurities and plastic surgery, a procedure he sums up as: "Strive for perfection/Do away with yourself." Smart, cynical and still impassioned about the state of humanity, Mr. Langford has recharged his music by stripping away any indulgences.
 
Lullaby for the Working Class
 Mandolins plink, harmonicas hoot and glockenspiels tinkle in Lullaby for the Working Class, a mini-orchestra of wistful Americana. Ted Stevens, the band's singer and main songwriter, is a connoisseur of the elusive and fragile on the band's second album, "I Never Even Asked for Light" (Bar/None). In a voice that sounds sleepless and troubled, he ponders hazy emotions, the toll taken by progress and a pervasive sense of loss: "How many ways can you say that you've been broken?," he sings in "Man vs. the Tide." Played on acoustic instruments, the music seems folksy, but it's a long way from rustic simplicity. With the oblique imagery and idiosyncratic structures of collegiate rock, Mr. Stevens's reveries wander from family traumas to space travel to the possibility of faith.
 
Various Artists
 Love doesn't go smoothly on "The Rose Grew Round the Briar" (Yazoo/Shanachie), a collection billed as "Early American Rural Love Songs" that were recorded in the 1920's and 30's. Culled from old 78-r.p.m. disks, the album mixes blues and hillbilly songs, with relatively familiar names like Cannon's Jug Stompers and Blind Willie McTell alongside rarities from the likes of Shortbuckle Roark and Family, the duo Eck Dunford and Hattie Stoneman, or Lottie Kimbrough, whose "Lost Lover Blues" includes both whistling and backup yodeling. Backed by claw-hammer banjo picking or ragtimey fingerpicked guitar, most of the singers stoically confess how lonely they are, how even death would be better than unrequited love. Dock Boggs, like a precursor of death-haunted gangsta rappers, sings about a false-hearted lover driving him to his grave, then nonchalantly warns, "The man who won my darling girl/Feel the bite of my .44." Of the 23 songs, only one (by Alfred and Orville Reed) is a corny portrait of domestic bliss; the others balance fatalism with wry acceptance.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Detroit's Big 3 Say Asia Is Forcing Cost Cuts

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The Big Three American auto makers might be expected to pop champagne. After all, the stock market has soared, the economic expansion continues, and interest rates have fallen to record lows, all of which would normally lure buyers to showrooms.
Instead, Detroit is acting almost as if a recession had hit, hunkering down to shave pennies wherever possible in an effort to cut costs sharply in the face of growing competition from Asia. 
 The Ford Motor Company told Wall Street analysts on Friday that it had cut $3 billion in costs last year and planned to trim an additional $1 billion this year.
"This is the first time in the history of Ford that we've reduced our total cost of doing business from one year to the next," Alex Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, said last week. "It is pretty clear now that we will have a record year in terms of profits for 1997."
Indeed, for the Big Three, cutting costs seems to be the only way to increase profits. The market for car and truck sales in the United States is not growing, and it might even shrink slightly this year. In addition, there has been no room to increase car and truck prices, in part because the strengthening dollar has allowed Asian auto makers to lower their prices, forcing the Big Three to follow suit.
John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, said, "What is going on in Asia is putting enormous competitive and pricing pressures on us."
The relative prices of new cars and trucks in the third quarter were the lowest in 17 years, according to Comerica Bank, which calculates how many weeks of work on average it takes to buy a new vehicle. To be sure, the competition -- and the rebates -- are strongest on cars and mini-vans rather than on popular sport utility vehicles.
"We have deflation in the auto industry in spades," said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
The General Motors Corporation said last week that it had spent $1 billion more in 1997 on rebates and other incentives than it had expected to a year ago. And Ford announced on Friday that it would increase the rebates and discounted lease deals it was offering through April 2. Its cheapest car, the 1998 Ford Escort, now costs $10,745 including the $1,000 rebate.
That is still well above the discounted prices of some of its Asian competitors. Because of the strength of the dollar, foreign auto makers may set low prices or introduce rebates without eating into their profits. Just last week, for example, Hyundai, the South Korean auto maker, increased its rebates -- its cheapest car, the Accent coupe, can now be had for $8,534.
Because the Asian currency crisis has left sales so weak at home, Hyundai plans to increase its exports by 15 percent this year, with the bulk of the shipments headed to the United States, the company said on Friday. Some analysts in Asia believe that Hyundai will try to increase exports even further and will be forced to cut prices further to do so.
So far, the largest Asian auto makers, Toyota and Honda of Japan, have used the weakness of the yen to hold down prices on their new models, even while adding new features. Though both companies tend to steer clear of cash rebates, Toyota has been offering discounted lease prices as a way of reducing prices.
Shoppers have forced the Big Three to follow suit, putting pressure on their profits. Because they are earning less on each car they sell, yet do not want to disappoint shareholders with weaker profits, the American companies are trying to make up the difference by cutting costs.
"The opportunity for price increases is virtually nil," said Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, who said the company would have to offer higher rebates to keep its sales strong. "To maintain the current market pace will require more incentives than we had last year."
Chrysler has adopted a limited hiring freeze, adding only essential workers like engineers. The company is concentrating on reducing its expenses in other ways, too. Chrysler cut $1.2 billion in costs during the 1997 model year, and it plans to cut at least $1.5 billion in the current model year, which ends in September, said Thomas T. Stallkamp, the company's president. "We're just about 50 percent of the way there," he said.
The combination of good economic times and all the cost-cutting is expected to produce strong 1997 profits for the Big Three, which are to announce earnings figures this month. Analysts expect healthy profits to continue next year, and one analyst raised his estimate of Ford's prospects after the briefing last week.
G.M. is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of $1.97 a share, up from 55 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 1996, according to a consensus of Wall Street analysts' estimates prepared by First Call. That would bring G.M.'s 1997 earnings per share to $7.83, up from $5.37 the year before. Profits this year are expected to be even higher: $8.01 a share.
John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said that although the decline in Asian currencies "puts competitive pressure" on the company, "all in all, it should be a good year."
G.M., which has increased its profits even as its market share has shrunk in the United States, refused to release information on its cost-cutting efforts, but a spokesman said it had worked hard to meet aggressive, internal cost-cutting goals. "If you don't get it in price and you don't get it in volume and you show a bottom-line improvement, most of that is due to cost-cutting," said Mark A. Tanner, the spokesman.
Ford is expected to report fourth-quarter profits of $1.25 a share, up from 98 cents a share a year earlier. That would bring its 1997 earnings to $5.36 a share, well above the $3.45 a share it earned in 1996. This year, Ford's earnings are expected to decline slightly from 1997, to $5.21 a share.
Profits at Chrysler, hurt in the fourth quarter by a slow introduction of its newest large sedan models, are expected to be the weakest of the lot, though still respectable. Analysts expect it to earn $1.12 a share in the fourth quarter, down from the $1.51 a share it earned in the fourth quarter of 1996. That would bring Chrysler's 1997 profits to $3.96 a share, down from the $5.21 a share it earned in 1996. But earnings are expected to improve markedly this year, when analysts expect Chrysler to earn $4.97 a share.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Wall Street's Stumbling Bull Is Relying Heavily on 2 Legs

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The American stock market has come under severe pressure early in 1998 and has slumped. But it appears that things would be much worse were it not for two disparate groups of buyers: foreigners and individual Americans.
The foreign buying may have been the more important factor in recent months, helping to explain why the big stocks -- the ones known internationally -- have been the strongest. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks remain well above the lows they reached in October, the last time the world grew fearful over Asia. But the Russell 2000, an index of smaller stocks, has fallen to its lowest levels since August, and is 2.2 percent under its October low. 
 Yesterday, however, it appeared that domestic orders, many from individual investors but some from institutions, turned around the latest world flight from equities.
One important way to look at trading is through a market indicator somewhat misleadingly called cash flow. Every time a trade takes place at a level higher than the previous one, the value of that trade is chalked up to positive cash flow; when a trade takes place at a price lower than the previous one, the value of that trade is seen as negative cash flow.
The logic of the indicator is that the price movement shows whether a trade was initiated by a buyer or a seller. Clearly that is often accurate, but not always.
There are separate figures for all cash flow and for that stemming only from large block trades exceeding 10,000 shares.
On Friday, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 220 points, cash flow was negative all day, whether from blocks or all trades. Traders of all stripes were apparently selling.
But yesterday, after a worldwide round of selling caused American stocks to open sharply lower, there was steady buying pressure from smaller accounts, while block trades were heavily negative at the opening of the New York Stock Exchange and then remained slightly negative the rest of the day.
That would seem to indicate that a lot of American investors, given a weekend to think about the Asian crisis, concluded it was not that important to this country. That is consistent with the argument made by many investment advisers: the strong United States economy will suffer little from an Asian collapse.
Logically, those who accept the argument might be expected to be inclined to stick with companies that derive profits primarily in the United States, rather than overseas. But it has not worked out that way in the market, for reasons that appear to have less to do with bad logic than with the role of foreign investors. As for American investors, some of their money may have been diverted from foreign stocks into American ones. The lack of alternative investments in this country may also have played a role. The Asian crisis has sent a lot of money fleeing to the safety of dollar-based investments, and much of that has gone into medium-term Treasuries -- so much so that two-year Treasuries traded yesterday just above a 5 percent yield. For many American investors accustomed to good returns, stocks seem the only place to be.
A buyer of that two-year Treasury will, of course, earn 5 percent a year for the next two years, barring only a Treasury default. By contrast, as many an investor in Asian stocks can attest, an equity investor can lose that much or more in an hour or two, not to mention in a year. But it appears that American investors -- as opposed to the more jittery people who manage money for large institutions -- are not concerned with such possibilities and still view price dips as buying opportunities.
Someday, of course, price dips will no longer be opportunities. But the market's performance reinforces the theory that individual investors will not lead the market down, but will move out of stocks only after something -- perhaps a recession -- has come along that clearly calls into question the wisdom of staying in the stock market.

HEADLINE: French Canadian Is a U.N. Chief's First Right-Hand Woman

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 12

 BODY:
A French Canadian with a flair for finance and a great enthusiasm for New York life was appointed as the first Deputy Secretary General in United Nations history today.
Louise Frechette, the new Deputy Secretary General, is resigning as Canada's Deputy Minister of National Defense to help Secretary General Kofi Annan finish the job of redesigning the United Nations administration from the top down. 
 She was based in New York twice as a diplomat, most recently as Canada's United Nations representative from 1992 to 1994.
"I love New York," she said in an interview today in her more or less empty new office down the hall from Mr. Annan's. "I love the city; it is one of the most vibrant in the world. I'm glad the United Nations is right downtown. There is something about being in the middle of a real city, with all its diversity, its culture."
At the United Nations, she will have the authority to fill in for Mr. Annan as he chooses. A year ago, diplomats were predicting that the General Assembly would never grant such latitude to an official largely outside its control. A number of developing nations wanted the job to be largely one of assisting poor countries, but in the end did not try to block Mr. Annan's plan.
He made it known early in his administration that he was looking for a woman for the job. But today, introducing Ms. Frechette at a news conference, he joked that this was a false impression. "I was looking for the best person to do the job, and it happens to be a woman," he said.
Ms. Frechette, 51, a Canadian born in Montreal and educated in French at the University of Montreal and the College of Europe in Bruges, Belgium, said she never really spoke English fluently until she took a job in Ottawa in her 20's. She also speaks Spanish. From 1985 to 1988, she was Canada's Ambassador to Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, after which she returned to Ottawa to review Canada's relations with Latin America.
Apart from diplomatic assignments, Ms. Frechette has done work in economics, finance and international trade, culminating in her appointment as Assistant Deputy Minister for Economic Policy and Trade Competitiveness in 1991.
Ms. Frechette, who is expected to take a leading role at the United Nations in economic and development issues, said today that the crisis now centered in Asia is a lesson in "how an economic phenomenon can develop at a speed we couldn't imagine" and how no country is immune from the effects.
"We have to wrap our minds around globalization," she said, adding that from a United Nations perspective, this involves going beyond the workings of financial markets to an understanding of the economic and political needs of nations and the speed at which large institutions will have to operate to meet them.
While at the United Nations, Ms. Frechette -- working with Madeleine K. Albright, who was then the chief United States delegate -- was pivotal in devising a peacekeeping operation for Haiti with the return from exile of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in 1994.
She was a regular at the lunches organized by Ms. Albright, now Secretary of State, for the handful of women who represented their countries here, and high-ranking women in the United Nations system. "Madeleine was a very faithful member of the club," Ms. Frechette said.
In Washington, a spokesman for Ms. Albright said that she cheered today's news.
"Secretary Albright remembers Ambassador Frechette fondly, and believes she's the perfect choice for this new position of Deputy Secretary General," James P. Rubin, spokesman for the Secretary of State, said in an interview today. He described Ms. Frechette as "one of the finest diplomats the Secretary has ever encountered."
Haiti continues to be a preoccupation for Ms. Frechette, who considers the issue of how to follow through on peacekeeping missions to be a challenge for the United Nations. The Government in Haiti, for example, is shaky, and there is little money to spend on the development of strong civilian institutions.
"A country needs a well-functioning justice system, a well-functioning police force," she said. "Elections are necessary but are not enough in themselves."
Members of the United Nations have backed away from peacekeeping operations, often citing the unresolved problems they have left behind in many parts of the world. Ms. Frechette said that maybe it is time to stop measuring the work of the organization by its peacekeeping missions.
"Many of the peacekeeping operations had to do with the end of the cold war," she said. "We were helping conflicts come to their final resolution. This era is behind us. We shouldn't assess the U.N.'s performance by whether they are creating a peacekeeping operation every few months."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
White House Bailouts for Asia Draw Fire

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
With the financial turmoil in Asia showing few signs of abating, liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans are stepping up criticism of the bailouts engineered by the Clinton Administration, putting the White House under additional pressure as it prepares to ask Congress for more money.
Although the Administration has won muted support for its stance toward Asia from leaders of both parties, members of Congress at either end of the ideological spectrum have grown increasingly vocal in their objections in recent days, and seem certain to demand a full-scale debate about using American money to contain the crisis. 
 "We must be vigilant and aware of what is taking place, but insist on discipline and thoughtful action before taxpayer dollars are put at risk," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.
Some Republicans object to using taxpayer money to help other nations. They are particularly upset with the Administration's freedom to lend money to embattled nations without Congressional approval.
The more libertarian-minded conservatives say the best approach would be to minimize the involvement of the United States and International Monetary Fund and allow the free-market system to work by penalizing the banks, securities firms, companies and countries that made bad investments. Bailouts, they say, encourage international investors to make risky bets with the confidence that governments will pay for their mistakes.
"The free market is no longer at work in the field of international finance," said Senator Lauch Faircloth, a Republican from North Carolina, who is among the most outspoken critics of the Administration's strategy. "We have privatized the gains and socialized the losses."
Many liberal Democrats are equally opposed to the current policy, designed mainly by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. But they object for different reasons than the Republican critics.
The Democrats say the bailouts are propping up repressive regimes in nations like Indonesia that have little respect for human rights, allow exploitation of workers and condone development plans that damage the environment. In countries such as South Korea, these Democrats say the economic prescription imposed by the I.M.F. will unfairly inflict most of the pain on the middle class and allow financial institutions and international investors to escape with little damage.
"Until we deal with the negative consequences we're going to oppose enhancing the international mobility of capital," said Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat. "If the Administration will take seriously our concerns, it can break what must look to them like an unholy alliance between liberals and conservatives."
Mr. Rubin said the interdependence of the American and Asian economies and financial markets and the broader interest the United States has in a stable, prosperous Asia have left the United States with no choice but to help develop a solution to the crisis.
"Our nation's economic and national security are vitally at stake in the situation in Asia," Mr. Rubin said.
"There's a high level of seriousness in Congress about how to think through and deal with these matters," he added. "But there certainly will be a debate and discussion when Congress reconvenes."
Congress has been out of session for the last two and a half months as the Administration has worked, through the I.M.F. and on its own, to stabilize financial markets in Asia and limit damage to the economy.
But the Administration's decision just before Christmas to lend $1.7 billion of taxpayer money to South Korea galvanized longtime critics of direct American involvement in such bailouts. The failure of the I.M.F. plans throughout the region to calm the markets has brought further criticism from Congress that the White House's approach is flawed.
The first flashpoint in the debate will be the Administration's request for a $3.5 billion contribution to an emergency fund established by the I.M.F. to deal with sudden financial crises of the type afflicting Asia. The request was blocked before Congress adjourned last fall -- largely because it became enmeshed with the separate but equally contentious issue of American support for international family planning efforts -- and is likely to be resubmitted to Congress in the next month or two.
The Administration will also ask Congress this year for an additional $14.5 billion to bolster the I.M.F.'s financial strength under a plan agreed to last fall by the I.M.F.'s 181 member nations.
Consideration of both I.M.F. requests is certain to be tied to efforts by Republicans to limit the Administration's freedom to provide direct loans to foreign nations without Congressional approval through the Exchange Stabilization Fund, a $40 billion kitty that can be used at the President's discretion to deal with international financial problems. The $1.7 billion loan for South Korea came from the stabilization fund.
Mr. D'Amato pushed through legislation several years ago that restricted the size and length of any loans made by the President from the stabilization fund. Those restrictions lapsed on Sept. 30.
Some Republicans, including Mr. Faircloth, want to reimpose those restrictions. Republicans said it was likely that they would tie any new appropriations for the I.M.F. to limits on the Administration's use of the stabilization fund.

Greenspan Heckled
 LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- Community advocates heckled the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, today for defending financial aid to Asia while poor neighborhoods in the United States needed help.
"It's a disgrace," some shouted when the subject of Asia arose during a community financing forum attended by Mr. Greenspan. "You should be ashamed of yourself." One heckler was ejected for refusing to calm down.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Motorola Has Profits Below Expectations

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Hit by the economic turmoil in Asia, Motorola Inc. reported yesterday that its profits for the fourth quarter were slightly below the expectations of Wall Street analysts.
The fourth-quarter results of the company -- whose global businesses range from microchips to cellular phones -- had been anxiously anticipated among investors as an early sign of the impact of the Asian troubles on American high-technology companies. 
 Motorola collects nearly 30 percent of its revenue from Asia, industry analysts estimate, and in a statement last evening, Motorola's senior executives noted the impact of the slide in some of its Asian businesses.
The preliminary reading from analysts, though, seemed to be that Motorola's results were probably not a deeply worrying sign that technology companies were being battered by the Asian financial crisis.
"There is some order weakness out of Asia, but it doesn't seem to be a disaster by any means," said Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.
Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., released its results after stock trading had ended yesterday. The stock fell $1, to $54.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, then slipped further in after-hours trading, to $54.375.
For the quarter, Motorola earned $321 million, or 54 cents a share, up 35 percent from $238 million, or 40 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Excluding special charges for discontinued operations, earnings were $393 million, or 65 cents a share -- 3 cents below Wall Street's expectations, based on the consensus of 28 analysts polled by the First Call Inc., a research firm.
Fourth-quarter sales rose 7.7 percent, to $8.3 billion, from $7.7 billion in the 1996 fourth quarter.
"During the fourth quarter, the deterioration of economic conditions in certain Asian markets had an impact in terms slowing the growth of sales, orders and profits, as well as putting pressure on pricing," Robert L. Growney, Motorola's president and chief operating officer, said in a statement.
A conference call with Wall Street analysts, when Motorola executives are expected to offer additional details of the Asian weakness on the company's individual businesses, is scheduled for this morning.
While the impact of the Asian crisis on Motorola may be less severe than feared, the larger question -- both for the region and for companies with sizable businesses in Asia, like Motorola -- is how deep and how lengthy the downturn will prove to be.
Some American technology companies had been experiencing growth rates of 20 percent and more in the once-booming economies of East Asia.
Christopher Galvin, Motorola's chief executive, said in yesterday's statement that he expected growth of his company's Asian business to slow to 10 percent in the first half of 1998. Yet he added that his cautiously optimistic assessment was based on an assumption that the recent bailout efforts would succeed in steadying the Asian economies.
"We are still facing challenges in the near term, as we expect the economic conditions in certain markets in Asia that affected fourth-quarter results to continue for at least the first half of 1998," Mr. Galvin said. "We are assuming the cooperative efforts of many nations and the International Monetary Fund will help to stabilize the Asian situation."
In the fourth quarter, Motorola said that the Asian slide in particular hit its cellular phone, pager and semiconductor businesses.
Despite the current problems, Mr. Galvin expressed Motorola's corporate confidence in the long-term attractiveness of Asia as a region in which to do business.
"We will continue to control costs," he said, "but we will also continue our investments in Asia where appropriate."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Bond Prices in Spurt, but Stock Rally Later Trims Gains

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Low inflation, Asian financial turmoil, a plunge in the stock market and investor flight to the perceived safety of the American bond market sent Treasury prices sharply higher early yesterday. But a later rebound in stocks took away some of the gains in bonds by the end of the day.
In the morning, the yield on the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, plunged as low as 5.66 percent, from 5.73 percent on Friday. The power behind the demand for Treasuries was investor confidence that the economic collapse in Asia would lead to slower growth and lower inflation in the United States and, in turn, force the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates. 
 Traders said, however, that once the Dow Jones industrial average rebounded from its opening 137-point decline, investors wondered whether the bond market had moved too far, too fast. For example, the yield on the two-year Treasury note fell early yesterday to 5.02 percent, half a percentage point below the Federal Reserve's 5.5 percent target for the shortest of short-term interest rates, the Federal funds rate. The yield had dropped from 5.64 percent just since the end of last year.
"There is a push and pull here on whether the Fed is going to ease," said Rob Kapito, vice chairman of Blackrock Financial Manangement, which manages $55 billion in fixed-income investments. "If the Fed doesn't ease, then the short end has gone too far."
Late in trading, the yield on the two-year note popped back up to 5.17 percent, where it finished Friday.
But the yield on the 30-year bond managed to finish at 5.69 percent, its lowest level since the bond was first regularly issued in 1977. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 20/32, to 106 9/32. Long-term yields on corporate and other bonds also continued to move lower to levels that have not been seen for almost 30 years.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note also fell, dropping to 5.36 percent from 5.41 percent. The positive story on inflation, which is expected to be reinforced today with the report of a minimal increase in December consumer prices, is still holding investor attention, even if some are wondering whether short-term interest rates may have come down too far for now.
"The market over all is a little ahead of itself," said Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc.
The fact that short-term interest rates have moved dramatically below the target for the Federal funds rate, which applies to overnight loans between banks, has convinced many analysts that investors think the central bank will ease interest rates soon. But some of the buying of short-term government securities is coming from foreign investors looking for a safe harbor and some American investors who want an alternative home until the recent stock market volatility cools down. All this means that the dive in short-term interest rates may be overdone.
The surge in the bond market over the last week was started by comments on deflation, which occurs when prices fall rather than rise, that the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, made in a speech on Jan. 3 in Chicago.
Just the mention of deflation -- Mr. Greenspan did not say it was an immediate threat -- was enough to make many investors think that the Fed would now consider lowering interest rates to prevent the Asian turmoil from slowing growth here too much and pulling prices lower.
Then, last Thursday, a Fed governor, Laurence H. Meyer, added to the sentiment when he suggested that the Fed might have to ease interest rates if the Asian crisis slowed the American economy much more than expected.

HEADLINE: 'Made in New York' Is Coming Back Into Fashion

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
In her glass-walled corner office overlooking the garment district, Natalie Walker of Tahiti Apparel designs the many styles of summer: sexy leopard-printed bathing suits, sensible navy-and-white-striped maillots and matching sheer cover-ups. And the suits are made not in Sri Lanka or Hong Kong, like so much other apparel, but across the East River at a factory in Long Island City.
"I'll personally take a subway to Queens and try on the suits myself," said Ms. Walker, the executive vice president of design and merchandising for Tahiti, which owns the license for Jones New York Swimwear and 15 other swimwear brands. 
 Bill Blass, Geoffrey Beene, Oscar de la Renta and Nicole Miller are just some of the major designers who make most of their apparel in New York City. Although designers say labor is still less expensive abroad, making their products locally gives them the flexibility and quickness they need to respond to the market.
"It's all about speed," said Richard Feldman, president of the Feldman Manufacturing Corporation, a private-label manufacturer in Queens that makes swimwear for Jones New York, as well as J. Crew, Eddie Bauer and Victoria's Secret. "The buzzword is quick response. The swimwear can go from here to our warehouse to a distribution center in 48 hours. If you go to the Orient, you need three to four months."
For more than two decades, the garment industry in New York City has hemorrhaged, losing tens of thousands of manufacturing jobs as work moved overseas. But last year, for the first time, there was a slight uptick in New York apparel employment, and while no one is predicting a turnaround, a few trends have made New York a more attractive place for apparel makers.
In the mid-1970's, employment in apparel and textile manufacturing in New York City peaked at about 250,000. By 1991, according to data compiled for the Fashion Center Business Improvement District, the number of employees in the apparel and textile manufacturing sectors had fallen to 104,415. By 1996, the number had sunk further, to 82,500. But last year, for the first time since the bloodletting began, the figure rose, to 84,000.
"It's a modest increase, but in my view, it's a big gain only because you stemmed the tide, you stopped the decline," said Barbara Randall, executive director of the improvement district, a nonprofit organization formed in 1993 to promote the garment district in the West 30's and the fashion industry. "I don't think that all of a sudden, manufacturing is going to come back in droves, but I do think that apparel manufacturing is here to stay. The water has found its level."
The combined manufacturing and wholesale output in New York City totals $20 billion a year, according to a draft study of the fashion industry that was commissioned by the improvement district. Designers say the ultimate cost of making apparel in New York is comparable to overseas production when they factor in the cost of shipping merchandise, traveling to and from the factory and paying the necessary duties and tariffs.
And now that there are six to eight fashion seasons a year, instead of four as in the past, companies must design and produce more different styles of clothing. Making clothes locally enables designers and manufacturers to fill the racks in stores on time.
With instant feedback from bar codes about what is selling and what is not, stores are reducing their own risks by placing smaller orders closer to the seasons, knowing they can reorder styles that sell well. Being able to fill those reorders swiftly can make or break a factory.
Consumer fickleness also makes shifting gears quickly a necessity.
"Pleats or no pleats, plaids or solids," said Bruce Herman, president of the Garment Industry Development Corporation, a nonprofit economic development organization. "Who can say sitting here in December what will be selling in May? If you're sourcing off shore, you've already made that decision. If you decide right, you make a lot of money. If you decide wrong for a few seasons, you're out."
But some apparel companies that have chosen to make all their clothes in New York City grumble about some aspects of local production. Ellen Mullman, the sales manager for Tamotsu, a manufacturer of bridge sportswear that is based in Manhattan and produces 95 percent of its clothing in New York City, loves the time and money she saves by not having to "get on a plane to China or Hong Kong." But she hates having to pay more for inferior work.
"There seems to be less pride in craftsmanship in New York in general," she said. "If you see a Giorgio Armani jacket and turn it inside out, it will be made with loving care."
Others disagree. "We have world-class talent right here in New York," said Janet B. Paszkiewicz, the Garment Industry Development Center's sourcing coordinator. "We have an immigrant population that comes in with the skills already acquired."
The fashion industry is toying with the idea of a "Made in New York" label to cash in on the city's reputation as the world capital of pop culture. (Apparel is still the city's biggest manufacturing sector.)
"That's actually a powerful marketing tool," Mr. Herman said. "We encourage companies to put 'Made in New York' on their labels, but we also feel it has to actually mean something. The garment shouldn't be thought of in New York but made in Sri Lanka."
Alan Sealove, chairman of Victoria Royal, an evening-dress manufacturer in Manhattan, has just returned to New York. After making dresses for years in Hong Kong, his company started producing a small quantity of clothes in New York's garment district only three months ago.
"We liked that we could get the finished product in the store quicker," he said.
