HEADLINE: Sex Bias Is Reported by U.S. At Border Plants in Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Concluding a six-month review of charges of sex discrimination in Mexico, the United States Labor Department reported today that thousands of border assembly plants administer medical tests to weed out pregnant applicants and harass pregnant workers to coerce their resignation.
Others simply dismiss pregnant workers to avoid paying maternity benefits, the department said. 
 Noting that discrimination against pregnant workers appears to be a violation of Mexico's own labor laws, Secretary of Labor Alexis M. Herman followed up on the findings by phoning her Mexican counterpart, Javier Bonilla Garcia, to request consultations, officials said.
"This is a serious issue, and we need to consult with Mexico as to implementation of its employment discrimination laws," Ms. Herman said today in a statement.
The Labor Department's review responded to a complaint filed last year by Human Rights Watch and other American and Mexican rights and labor groups under the terms of a labor side accord of the North American Free Trade Agreement -- or Nafta -- in which Mexico, Canada and the United States agreed to set up offices within their own labor departments to review the other countries' labor rights practices.
The complaint argued that managers of Mexico's tax-free assembly plants, known as maquiladoras, routinely require female applicants to take urine tests and question them about their menstrual cycles and sexual activity to screen out pregnant women.
The vast majority of Mexico's 2,700 maquiladora plants -- which employ more than half a million workers and account for more than $29 billion of Mexico's export earnings -- are owned by United States corporations. How the American and Mexican Governments follow up on the Department's confirmation of widespread sex discrimination will be closely watched because one of the goals of the Nafta accord was to upwardly harmonize labor standards in the three countries.
The Labor Department reported that the harassment or dismissal of female Mexican workers who become pregnant "occurs" and "violates Mexican law."
On the other hand, the report did not so unequivocally characterize as illegal the practice of administering pregnancy tests to women seeking factory jobs. That is because the Mexican Government has expressed contradictory interpretations of its own labor laws, said Irasema T. Garza, who heads the Labor Department's national administrative office and directed the review.
Mexico's Labor Ministry responded to the complaint by arguing that administering pregnancy tests to job applicants was not illegal because Mexico's labor laws protect workers only after they have been hired, Ms. Garza said in an interview. On the other hand, the Interior Ministry and Mexico City's Human Rights Commission have both said that refusing to hire women because they are pregnant violates the law.
"That's why we are seeking these consultations, to clarify inconsistencies in the Mexican Government's position," Ms. Garza said.
Although the Department's findings largely confirmed the charges outlined in the complaint, LaShawn Jefferson, a Human Rights Watch researcher who investigated pregnancy discrimination in 47 maquiladora plants in 1995 and 1996, said she was "disappointed by the equivocal nature of this finding."
"One of our central points was that pregnancy discrimination constituted sex discrimination, which is prohibited by Mexico's labor code, its Constitution and its international agreements," Ms. Jefferson said. "This finding seems to equivocate as to whether it is illegal."

HEADLINE: Health Spending Grew Slowly in '96 but Still Hit $1 Trillion

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
Health spending increased in 1996 at the lowest rate in 36 years, but topped $1 trillion for the first time, the Government reported today.
 Such spending has been growing at the same pace as the economy for four years in a row, contrary to earlier projections, which showed health care eating up a bigger and bigger share of the nation's output. Even so, consumers did not see more money in their pockets, because many employers shifted costs to their workers. 
 The report, from the Department of Health and Human Services, describes pent-up pressures for a possible increase in health care spending in the near future. Health insurance premiums appear to be rising again as insurers catch up after holding the increase in premiums below the growth in medical costs, the report said.
"National health expenditures increased 4.4 percent in 1996, the slowest growth recorded since 1960," said the study, by Katharine R. Levit and other Government economists. The increase was still greater than the change in the Consumer Price Index for all items, which rose 3.3 percent in 1996.
"Despite this slow growth, health spending managed to top $1 trillion for the first time," the report said. "On average, spending for health care in 1996 was $3,759 per person, $126 more than the $3,633 spent in 1995."
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the report showed "significant progress in slowing the growth of health care spending."
And Ms. Shalala said the new balanced-budget law would "help control spending even more."
The report analyzes the slowdown in health costs, part of which is attributable to the growth of managed care.
"Since 1993," it said, "increases in health spending have averaged 5 percent annually, with each year registering successively slower growth." By contrast, from 1966 to 1993, national health spending rose more than 11 percent a year, on the average.
The study found that taxpayers were picking up more of the nation's health care tab. Federal, state and local government programs accounted for 47 percent of all health spending in 1996, up from 40 percent in 1989.
From 1989 to 1996, Ms. Levit said, health spending by government agencies rose 9.7 percent a year, on the average, while health spending by the private sector rose 5.8 percent a year.
Ms. Levit and other Federal officials said that government health spending might grow more slowly than private health spending in the next few years, because of cutbacks made under the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, signed by President Clinton in August.
National health spending reached $1.04 trillion in 1996, up from $991.4 billion in 1995, the Government reported.
Medicare and Medicaid together spent $351 billion in 1996, accounting for one-third of the total.
Medicaid spending by the Federal Government and the states totaled $147.7 billion in 1996, up 5.3 percent from the year before. Medicaid provides coverage for 36 million low-income people.
Medicare, which provides health insurance for 38 million people who are elderly or disabled, spent $203 billion in 1996, up 8.1 percent from the previous year.
The report also made these points:
*The growth of health spending, after adjustment for inflation, was extremely low. The increases were 1.9 percent in 1996, 2.2 percent in 1995 and 3.3 percent in 1994.
*Americans spent 13.6 percent of the gross domestic product, or almost one-seventh of the nation's total output, on health care in 1996. This share has been the same for four years.
*Doctors and hospitals are getting a smaller share of the nation's health care dollar. Prescription drugs and long-term care, which includes home health services and nursing homes, are getting bigger shares.
*Hospitals "capitalize on Medicare's payment regulations to maximize their revenues," discharging patients to nursing homes affiliated with the hospitals.
*Spending for doctors' services has been slowing for six years. It rose just 2.9 percent in 1996, to $202.1 billion.
By contrast, spending for prescription drugs rose sharply. Americans bought $62 billion of medications from retail outlets in 1996, an increase of 9.2 percent over the amount bought in 1995.
The Government said that the growth in premiums for employer-sponsored health insurance had fallen by more than half in four years. Spending on premiums rose just 3.6 percent in 1996, after a growth of 8.4 percent in 1992.
In the last few years, Ms. Levit said, spending for health care benefits has risen faster than premiums, squeezing the profit margins of insurance companies.
Though health spending may rise at a more rapid rate, she said, "there is currently no expectation of a return to the double-digit increases of the 1980's."

PUB-DATE: January 13, 1998

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3008 words

HEADLINE: VACANT CUBICLES -- A special report.;
Software Jobs Go Begging, Threatening Technology Boom

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Every so often, the co-founder of Carnelian Inc., James Kittock, hears the phones at his Silicon Valley start-up company begin to ring in order, from one cloth-covered cubicle to the next: 0976, 0977, 0978. . . . He knows -- everyone in the Valley knows -- it is the recruiters, calling to steal his programmers away, often at huge salaries.
Mr. Kittock, 27, cannot really blame them. Carnelian itself has been known to resort to guerrilla tactics in what has become an increasingly desperate scavenger hunt for highly paid digital-age translators who can mediate between mind and machine. And like other employers nationwide these days, Carnelian has found that there is simply not enough talent to go around at any price. 
 "For us, it was a choice of lowering our standards or waiting, and we chose to wait," Mr. Kittock said, "but it's tough to see time slipping by and things not moving ahead because of a lack of horsepower." His company, which develops software for Internet publishing, could use twice the dozen programmers it now employs.
Mr. Kittock's lament echoes throughout the world of high technology and beyond. As America relies more heavily on computer software than ever before, the demand for people who can develop and use the tools of the modern age has vastly outstripped the existing supply. And the shortage is expected to get much worse as an estimated one million new programming jobs come open in the next nine years.
Help-wanted ads are multiplying for the coders who can write in fashionable computer languages like Java, for the testers who find the bugs that the coders invariably leave behind and for the systems analysts who figure out how to make it all work together.
The talent shortage is so pronounced that members of the Clinton Administration announced yesterday that the Government would invest $28 million in new initiatives to encourage training more programmers. The initiative was announced at a meeting that will continue today with industry officials and academics in Berkeley, Calif., to explore potential solutions.
Under the Administration's plan, which was first reported in The Washington Post, the Labor Department will offer $3 million in grants to schools, businesses and local governments to retrain laid-off workers as programmers, and it will spend another $8 million to build a World Wide Web site where employers can post job offerings and workers can post resumes. The Commerce Department will spend $17 million to bring technology resources, including training, to poor people.
The Administration's initiatives are driven by concern about the economic implications of the programmer shortage when information technology, grossing more than $865 billion a year, is the nation's largest industry, with the software segment growing more than twice as fast as the overall economy.
What is more, the shortage is contributing to a looming crisis known as the year 2000 problem, a legacy of a long-practiced programming economy in which years were denoted with two digits -- using 75 for 1975, for example. Unless all date-sensitive lines of computer code are tracked down and fixed, many businesses and institutions, from banks to government agencies to research labs and air traffic control centers, will be thrown into chaos or simply cease operating on Jan. 1, 2000.
Why the shortfall in programmers? For one thing, in Silicon Valley over the last two years, hundreds of new companies have opened, all hungry for someone -- anyone -- who can string together lines of computer code.
At the same time, the field has yet to recover from a downturn in the late 1980's and early 90's, when downsizing by aerospace companies and big technology concerns like the International Business Machines Corporation and the AT&T Corporation threw many computer scientists out of work and discouraged college students from pursuing computer careers. From a peak of 50,000 in 1986, the number of bachelor's and graduate degrees in computer science plummeted to 36,000 in 1995.
Yet, for students, job security is not the only issue when deciding for or against a career in computer science. Some cite its image: The "nerd factor," marked by the pasty pallor known as a "monitor tan," seems to trump a recent "geek chic" trend in a notoriously antisocial profession. And much of the work is tedious.
"We need a large technical class that is well trained to do work that is mind-numbingly boring," said Eric Roberts, associate director of Stanford University's computer science program.
Over the last two years, the overheated job market has pushed up computer science enrollment, but to nowhere near the level that analysts say will be necessary to meet the industry's needs. Between 1996 and 2006, more than a million new jobs requiring software skills should be created, according to a recent Bureau of Labor Statistics report. That represents a remarkable 6 percent of all new jobs expected to be created in that period.
But those numbers, which make no attempt to measure projected supply, join a slew of other emerging statistics that expose the extent of a labor shortage that could have significant economic repercussions. According to industry estimates, 200,000 to 400,000 jobs requiring computer software skills stand open now.
In Silicon Valley, where the competition for the best and brightest is most fierce, companies like the Netscape Communications Corporation offer perks like car washes at lunch and an in-house dry-cleaning service that provides cubicle-to-cubicle delivery. Alex Musil, a 22-year-old who was hired recently, said he particularly enjoyed Netscape's Le Concierge service, which handles entertainment purchases for employees.
"I bought my parents a cruise through them," said Mr. Musil, who was hired out of Stanford University with an annual salary of $54,000 last year.
Without enough programmers to go around, established companies are being forced to delay or even scrap technology projects, and start-ups are finding it harder to attract the workers they need.
If the talent drought continues, the entire national economy may feel the effect of lost wages and slowed innovation. And the competitive advantage that the United States has long held in technology may be at risk.
"This is like running out of iron ore in the middle of the Industrial Revolution," said Harris N. Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America, which represents computing and telecommunications companies.
 
Paucity of Recruits
Image and Tedium Repel Students
The most pressing question for both research and industry is how to get more computer scientists into the pipeline.
"Despite the fact that there are huge salaries to be made, kids don't choose these fields," said Richard Skinner, president of Clayton College and State University in Atlanta, who heads a Commerce Department task force on how universities are responding to the labor shortage.
A good programmer needs to exist comfortably in the "machine state," writing and meticulously checking and double-checking hundreds of lines of code that are often just a small part of a much larger project. It is a talent that is hard to come by -- and one often disparaged in mainstream culture.
There are few role models for computer-related jobs, and even people like William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation and something of a popular icon, tend to be far better known for their achievements as business moguls than for their skills as software engineers.
"Let's face it, when you think of a programmer, the image is an overweight person eating Snickers bars and drinking Coke and sitting in front of a screen with big glasses on," said Ed Lazaowska, chairman of the computer science department at the University of Washington. "The pitch I make to high school kids is: 'Where's the intellectual excitement? Why would you choose civil engineering or mechanical engineering? There's only so much you can do with asphalt.' "
But Tamer Hendi, 19, a student at the Georgia Institute of Technology, sees little that is cool about computer science. "I couldn't see myself doing it," he said. "I'd rather do chemical or industrial engineering, try to get a job where there will be more dealing with people."
At this week's meeting in Berkeley, in the hope of countering the negative image, industry officials recommended a promotion campaign similar to the dairy industry's "Drink Milk" ads that feature basketball and football stars and other celebrities wearing milk mustaches. Such a campaign, which could be sponsored by the computer industry, would promote the positive aspects of information technology and possibly feature industry leaders like Kim Polese, the young founder of the high-profile software start-up Marimba.
Recruiting more women like Ms. Polese to the field is considered crucial because the share of computer science degrees awarded to women in the United States has fallen steadily, to 28 percent in 1994 from a peak of 36 percent in 1984. A more proportional representation of women could go a long way toward meeting the need for programmers.
Only 17 percent of those taking the advanced placement test for computer science in the nation's high schools last year were women, the lowest of any subject. Girls often lack the early math training that many boys get. And in what Jane Margolis, an anthropologist at Carnegie Mellon University, calls the "computer gene" response, many women she has interviewed simply believe they are not born with the ability to do computer science.
At the same time, many women who demonstrate both the aptitude and appetite for programming are turned off by the nature of the work. For example, Zoe Woodworth, 21, who was one of only six women in her freshman computer science class of 100 at Carnegie Mellon, is also one of three who have since dropped out.
"I love math, but I realized I'm just not a computer scientist," Ms. Woodworth said. "I was burned out, and I didn't care about the subject matter. It just seemed passionless." She is now an art major.
The bigger problem may have less to do with image than with reality. The jobs where programmers conceive and design products are rare. The bulk of the openings are for what students refer to derisively as "cubicle hackers" or "code machines," people who type endless streams of commands to someone else's specifications.
Max Edleson, a Stanford freshman who ran a corporate Web site last summer, knows the drudgery. "I got paid a massive amount to sit in front of my computer eight hours a day, but I got physically ill doing it," he said. "I felt this void of thought that I couldn't deal with."
Mr. Edleson, who said he had intended to major in computer science, is now studying philosophy instead.
Even students like Eric Cheng, a much-sought-after Stanford graduate student, have doubts about the profession.
"There's never a question that you won't get a job," Mr. Cheng said. "There's just the question of will you be bored. If you go in the movie theaters around here on opening night of any science fiction or thriller, you can see the people with monitor tans. I just don't want to be like that. I'm looking for more of a balance."
Graham Miller, Mr. Cheng's classmate, is already thinking about an exit strategy. "Programmers only last up to 10 years or so," Mr. Miller said. "After that, you need to find something else to do."
Still, for Mr. Miller and many of his colleagues, the payoff comes with the thrill of solving a problem, of making a program work. "It's about understanding what the computer is thinking," Mr. Miller said.
 
Broader Job Market
Software Producers And Clients Compete
The hunger for programmers is not limited to companies that make software to sell to others. As the nation's corporations reorganize themselves to take advantage of the huge digital file cabinets known as data bases and of communications networks and software that allow them to increase productivity, the high-technology help-wanted ads are increasingly posted by the likes of Wal-Mart, General Motors and Federal Express. In the job market, that leaves the software producers competing against the buyers of their products.
"In the past, it was just I.B.M., Intel and us looking for these people," said David Pritchard, director of recruiting for Microsoft.
Some economists argue that the work force will naturally swell to meet the demand as salaries for those with software skills climb as much as 20 percent annually compared with the 4 percent annual wage increase of the average American worker. The average programmer earned $58,200 in 1995 and $66,500 in 1996, according to the Information Technology Association of America. But a consensus is growing in industry, academic and government circles that the lure of higher pay may not, by itself, be sufficient to correct the skilled-labor shortage.
"This is not like we need hundreds of more sales clerks," said Shirley Tessler, a researcher at the Stanford Computer Industry Project, a group of academicians investigating the shortage. "There is a serious demand for high-end people. We're talking about people to design software for a critical medical device that goes inside your body, to do product management, to manage quality assurance."
Nor is Ms. Tessler particularly encouraged by the increase in computer science enrollment last year. For one thing, not all of the new students -- particularly women -- will stay the course. In addition, almost one-fifth of all computer science students are foreign nationals, many of whom will return to their native countries after graduating.
Already, American technology companies have set up operations in India, Ireland and the Philippines to take advantage of increasingly skilled foreign labor pools. Information industry employers in the United States sponsor some 15,000 foreign professionals under Federal immigration law, which allows 65,000 professional foreign workers to come to the United States each year, and they are lobbying to raise the cap.
But some economists worry about relying on foreign workers to fill the software gap.
"There's a real danger that we'll assume the market will take care of this, and we'll be right -- only it's a global market," said Jeffrey E. Garten, dean of Yale University's School of Management and the former Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade in the Clinton Administration. "Unless we become much more deliberate in how we address this, we'll find that what could be quite good jobs for Americans will all take place abroad."
Even global supplies of technology workers are no longer as available as they once were. India's universities, for instance, turn out 55,000 students in the field each year but are not keeping pace with that nation's rapidly growing software industry.
What is more, the bidding war for software talent, in which corporations can offer stock options and salaries that universities and research institutions cannot match, makes it harder to find people who will devote themselves to the long-term research that might generate the next technological breakthroughs or to teaching the next generation of computer scientists. The number of advanced degrees granted in computer science has stayed flat, at about 1,000 a year, for the last decade, and doctoral students now often choose a dissertation project based not on whether it advances basic knowledge but on whether it represents a viable business opportunity.
"The phrase is 'eating your seed corn,' and we will pay a price for it," said Michael Garey, director of mathematical sciences research at Bell Laboratories. "So many of the bright people are being siphoned off to shorter-term opportunities that we are not doing a good job of building the foundation we're going to need for the next wave of innovation that might occur 10 or 20 years from now."
 
Filling the Void
No Experience Is Necessary
To remove some of the barriers for people who lack experience, the University of Washington has begun offering a "no background" introductory class. But even if such programs succeed in broadening the appeal of the discipline, it will take time to produce employable graduates. Meanwhile, desperate employers are increasingly reaching out to people who have not traditionally considered technology jobs.
Microsoft has set up a division to train its recruits and others who will be hired by corporate customers. The Defense Department is sponsoring a retraining program for aerospace engineers and others who have skills that could translate into computer expertise. Some technology concerns are working with two-year community colleges to train people quickly and to impart the most current skills in a field where knowledge quickly becomes outdated.
Gail Fitzgerald, director of the Computer Task Group in Buffalo, a company that provides entire staffs of information technology specialists to corporations, says she is training almost anyone she can find. After 12 weeks of intensive training, graduates will not be able to design next-generation weapons systems, but they can diagnose certain kinds of computer problems and earn as much as $35,000 a year.
"We've had an accountant, a lawyer, a high school literature teacher, a professor from the University of Alaska, several musicians," Ms. Fitzgerald said. "We find musicians typically have a very good aptitude."
Whatever the frustrations for employers, and however cloudy the outlook for national competitiveness, there is one business group benefiting in a big way from the dearth of digital talent: technology headhunters.
"The demand is insane," said Bob Jacobs, director of engineering recruiting for Interim Search Solutions in San Francisco. "It's a war. I'm on the 37th floor looking at the San Francisco skyline, and I can see 30 different empty floors where they have 20 cubicles, 2 programmers, and $2 million. They need to fill those cubicles."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1978 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Soar Like a Falcon . . .;
. . . Sink Like an Overextended Investment Bank

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Jan. 12

 BODY:
With the collapse of Peregrine Investments Holdings today, Asia's biggest underwriter of stocks has disappeared off the map of Asian investment banking just one decade after it was created by a swashbuckling former British racing driver and his Hong Kong partner.
The factors behind Peregrine's downfall were many and complex, and had much to do with its brash -- some would say insolent -- culture. Yet some executives at Peregrine, as well as financiers familiar with its final days, said its demise became inevitable only after First National Bank of Chicago, a unit of First Chicago NBD, its lead banker and an investor in the firm's putative restructuring, pulled out of a proposed rescue effort and canceled financing for Peregrine at the last moment. 
 The flame-out of Peregrine, the largest investment bank in Asia outside of Japan, spread panic through the Hong Kong stock market and raised further questions about the depth and duration of the economic crisis that is ravaging the fruits of more than a decade of explosive regional growth.
Yet, in many ways, Peregrine's downfall was emblematic of the fault lines in the foundations of Asia's once-vaunted economic miracle. Its headlong rush to do deals, its reliance on connections in high places and its willingness to skim the edges of legality and propriety mirrored the region's reckless economic growth and its tolerance of widespread corruption and cronyism.
But even in a part of the world where risk-taking had become the key to economic success, Peregrine stood out. It largely pioneered the market for junk bonds in Asia. After cozying up to the Chinese authorities in Beijing, it became the powerhouse behind virtually every initial listing by Chinese companies on Hong Kong's stock exchange. And it foraged markets -- North Korea, Vietnam and Myanmar -- that few others would go near because of their horrendous human-rights records.
Today, as Peregrine filed for liquidation, Hong Kong's stock market plummeted 8.6 percent, continuing a meltdown that has stripped it of more than one-quarter of its value so far this year. Even so, Hong Kong monetary authorities played down the threat the bank's collapse posed to the financial system. Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's financial secretary, turned down Peregrine's request for assistance over the weekend after a rescue package with a Swiss financial group fell apart. Mr. Tsang said a bailout would not be "in the public interest."
 The market rebounded Tuesday, with the main index rising about 5 percent in midmorning trading.
In the end, analysts here and elsewhere said, it was arrogance that did Peregrine in -- an arrogance emanating from the personality of its founder, Philip Tose of Britain, and his Hong Kong partner, Francis Pak To Leung, and that pervaded the bank's culture. That arrogance, they said, led the company to lend too much money for questionable projects and to exercise too little supervision over managers, and especially over Andre Lee, who ran its highly profitable and nearly autonomous bond department.
As a result, when Asia's financial crisis broke last summer, Peregrine was ill equipped to cope with the fallout. Indeed, it was the failure of an Indonesian taxi-cab company that fatally undermined Hong Kong's premier investment bank.
Sometime last summer, when bullishness was still the sentiment of the day, Peregrine made a bridge loan of $260 million to Steady Safe, run by one of Indonesia's flashiest wheeler dealers, Jopie Widjaya. Mr. Widjaya's dream was to move from his profitable but humdrum Jakarta taxi business, with its fleet of 4,000 cabs, to rail projects, ferries and toll roads. Mr. Widjaya had the right connections; he had even bought a stake in a toll road owned by Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, the eldest daughter of President Suharto.
Steady Safe had all the elements of a Peregrine-style deal: access to the corridors of power, seemingly assured earnings and sweeping opportunity. The problem was that Peregrine lent the $260 million in American dollars -- fully one-third of Peregrine's capital -- against Steady Safe's revenues in Indonesian rupiah. At the time, Peregrine seemed convinced that the rupiah was sound and that it could soon resell the bonds backing the loan. Moreover, the fixed-income team that cut the deal had earned 38 percent of Peregrine's profits the previous year; this was just one more deal.
Analysts say such confidence was misplaced. Any lender entrusting the equivalent of one-third of its capital to any borrower, much less a little-known company in a country notorious for corruption, shows poor financial judgment, they say.
But far from having second thoughts after the financial turmoil that shook Thailand last July spread throughout Asia, Peregrine remained upbeat. In late October, even though the rupiah had by then lost 30 percent of its value, Peregrine's own weekly analytical reports, boldly titled Greed and Fear, argued that the rupiah's collapse "certainly looks overdone and suggests a countertrend rally may be overdue."
It was not to be.
That same month, rumors began percolating in Hong Kong that Peregrine had taken $1 billion in trading losses, rumors denied by Mr. Tose. But even as he insisted on the bank's solidity, the rupiah was slipping and Peregrine's chairman was looking for an investor to replenish the company's capital.
In November, Mr. Tose, 51, announced that he had struck a deal with Zurich Center Investments Ltd., part of Zurich Group, a Swiss financial-services company, to buy a 24.1 percent stake in Peregrine for $200 million.
But the deal never went through.
According to Zurich Group, the two companies planned to set up an Asian investment fund, called the Peregrine Direct Investment fund, with a commitment of $50 million from each partner and an expected infusion of $350 million to $500 million from institutional investors.
But the continuing financial tumult in Asia apparently made Zurich nervous. A spokeswoman declined to go into details about the group's decision to back away, saying only it was the "end result of the negotiations to rework the conditions" of Zurich's participation.
Meanwhile, events in Indonesia tumbled out of control, and its currency collapsed. Steady Safe, with its earnings in rupiah, could no longer meet payments on its dollar loans, particularly the huge loan from Peregrine. The taxi company's stock sank to a sliver over one penny and, last week, it locked its doors.
As Peregrine's stock continued to slide, trading in the bank's stock was suspended. As Zurich Group was preparing one final offer to Peregrine, there seemed little hope of a deal. "When Zurich came back last week," said a senior Peregrine official who only agreed to speak anonymously, "they were going to buy our bond portfolio for 16 cents on the dollar. The bond portfolio was $600 million plus; there's a lot of good paper in that portfolio. But when you have a situation where they say you have $260 million, $270 million worth of bad paper, they say, 'What else have you done?' It just snowballed."
At the table with Zurich was First Chicago, one of Peregrine's principal creditors. At about one o'clock in the morning on Friday, First Chicago left the negotiations. "Zurich walked away six hours later," said the Peregrine official. "It just unraveled from there."
A spokesman for First Chicago declined to comment. But executives at both Peregrine and Zurich said today that First Chicago had initially pledged $25 million for a small stake in Peregrine, then had a change of heart. First Chicago's departure from the negotiations Friday morning prompted Zurich's decision to throw in the towel, they said, in part because it did not wish to raise its stake in the company significantly beyond 24 percent.
"They did not want to go up to 35 percent and make a general offer," as required by Hong Kong law whenever a buyer's stake exceeds 30 percent, a Peregrine executive said.
Meanwhile, Peregrine executives desperately tried to salvage something from the fiasco, maintaining that the firm's brokerage and corporate-finance businesses would make good acquisitions for the right buyer. "We still have a first-class franchise and it would be highly regrettable if that was not kept intact," said Timothy Voake, chief executive officer of Peregrine Brokerage Inc., which has headquarters in New York.
After the collapse of negotiations in Hong Kong, a news conference announcing a deal was abandoned. Swiftly, the Securities and Futures Commission ordered Peregrine to stop all trading activities. Peregrine's seat on the stock exchange was also suspended.
Peregrine was bust. Scarcely six months ago, Peregrine was the enfant terrible of Asian banking, a champion of "buccaneering" as Mr. Tose put it.
"One of Peregrine's great advantages in its heyday was to commit its own capital rapidly to transactions, with bridge loans, for example," said Richard Margolis of Merrill Lynch (Asia Pacific) Ltd. "It could take decisions quickly."
Peregrine was created in 1988 on $38 million raised by Messrs. Tose and Leung -- both refugees from Citibank's foundering investment banking venture -- from some of Hong Kong's tycoons, including Li Ka-shing, a leading property and infrastructure developer; Gordon Wu, an Asian infrastructure developer, and Larry Yung, China's principal investment banker here. Peregrine grew exponentially, with Mr. Tose and Mr. Leung capitalizing on personal contacts cultivated over the previous decade. Both men enjoyed lavish life styles.
Connections, combined with speedy decision-making and a penchant for risk, catapulted the bank forward. And it rushed in where others hesitated to tread. Typical was Peregrine's response to China's massacre of civilians in Tiananmen Square in June 1989. "These events were just a hiccup," Mr. Leung said in an interview two years ago. "We decided we wanted to take advantage of depressed market conditions at the time."
Quickly, Peregrine emerged as one of the largest underwriters in Hong Kong. And while China and Hong Kong remained the core of the bank's business, it spread its wings and splashed offices across 14 countries.
Even Asia's widespread culture of corruption did not seem to trouble Mr. Tose. After all, he said in an interview with The South China Morning Post last year, it is "quite an open form of corruption."
"It is not stalling advances in Asia," he added, "but is an accepted way of life in many ways."
Unfortunately for Peregrine, though, it often ruffled the feathers of local authorities. In Vietnam, it formed Peregrine Capital Vietnam with a fast-talking nightclub owner and car dealer named Nguyen Trung Truc, for example. Shortly afterward, Mr. Truc's other businesses were raided by tax authorities, and he wound up spending most of the year in jail for tax evasion. Peregrine itself was fined for operating a business without proper licenses.
Last June, although storm clouds were rapidly gathering on Asia's economic horizons, Peregrine was buoyant. It reported hefty profits for the first six months of $82.5 million (United States) on revenues of $19.6 billion.
When the end came this weekend, however, many people were asking why Peregrine's vaunted connections with some of Hong Kong's wealthiest and most powerful people did not result in the firm's rescue.
As the day wore on today, hundreds of customers shuttled in and out of Peregrine's brokerage operations to close their accounts.
"I was very surprised," said K. Chan, a 60-year-old retiree. "I've been with Peregrine for six or seven years. I'm going to transfer my stocks to another company." But, Mr. Chan continued, Hong Kong was not to blame. "What happened to Peregrine was caused by external forces, the Southeast Asian currencies," he said. "It's not because of Hong Kong itself."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Indonesian Leader Vows Support for I.M.F. Plan
President Suharto of Indonesia committed himself to vigorous enforcement of economic reforms that his country had spurned, an apparent acknowledgment that he has little choice but to send the message that the conditions of the I.M.F.'s bailout of Indonesia will be observed.
While his comments calmed Indonesia's markets, they did little to allay concerns about his hold on power. Page A1. 

Some liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans are stepping up criticism of the Asian bailouts supported by the Clinton Administration, putting the White House under additional pressure as it prepares to ask Congress for more money. D3.
 
The Asian crisis is slowing a military spending spree that has thrown American, European and Russian arms makers into competition for billions of dollars in weapons sales. A1.
 
Wall St. Withstands Asia Pressure
United States stocks recovered from early losses set off by sharp overnight selloffs in Asia. The comeback -- the Dow industrials rose 66.76 points, to 7,647.18 -- suggested that some investors continue to bet that the Asian crisis will not have a severe impact on American corporate earnings. D8.
 
The early plunge in stocks drove investors to buy Treasuries, but the gains in bond prices were pared later in the day. The yield on the two-year note, which has fallen sharply in the last week, was unchanged at 5.17 percent, after falling to 5.02. The 30-year bond yield fell to 5.69 percent from 5.73. D8.
 
Purchases of stock mutual funds reached a second consecutive record in 1997. The growth suggested that the slump in Asia's markets that began last summer has done little so far to dull hunger for mutual funds. D9.
 
A Shortage of Programmers
Help-wanted ads for computer programmers are multiplying and often going unfilled. The talent shortage is so pronounced that the Clinton Administration announced that the Government would invest in new initiatives to encourage training of programmers. A1.
 
Sun to Shift Work Station Line
Sun Microsystems plans to overhaul its work station business, adding lower-priced machines, in response to competition from increasingly powerful PC's. D5.
 
Microsoft Broadens Bias Charge
Microsoft said it had new evidence that a court-appointed adviser harbored prejudice against the software company in its struggle with the Justice Department and that he should be removed. The adviser, Prof. Lawrence Lessig of Harvard Law School, has broad powers to help determine whether Microsoft is illegally attempting to dominate the market for Internet software. D2.
 
Cutting Costs in Detroit
Despite the strong economy, the American auto makers are acting almost as if a recession had hit, cutting costs sharply in the face of growing competition from Asia. D3.
 
The Chrysler Corporation is trying to revive its Chrysler division with a new ad campaign, three new cars and even a new symbol. Advertising. D7.
 
Women's Sports Magazines to Join
Conde Nast Publications said it would acquire Women's Sports + Fitness and give its title to Conde Nast's competing publication, Sports for Women, in a sign of possible nervousness about the market. D7.
 
Year 2000 Problem for F.A.A.
A set of air traffic control computers should not be used beyond 1999 because they may not operate reliably when the date rolls over to 2000, according to I.B.M., which built them. But the F.A.A. is racing to determine whether the problems can be eliminated. A16.

HEADLINE: AIDS GROUP URGES NEW YORK TO START REPORTING OF H.I.V.

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
The Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's leading AIDS service agency, is reversing its position and calling for New York doctors to report H.I.V.-positive people to the State Health Department. The same practice is used for infectious diseases like syphilis and tuberculosis.
The official statement by the organization, the most politically and economically connected group in the world of nonprofit AIDS service, signifies the collapse of a long-standing consensus by AIDS and civil rights groups against H.I.V. reporting. 
 Every state requires doctors to report AIDS cases to public health officials. But officials in New York and California and many other states have not required similar reports about patients who have the AIDS virus but do not have full-blown AIDS.
Influential groups of advocates for people with AIDS, including the Gay Men's Health Crisis, have resisted those efforts, arguing that requiring reports would keep people worried about confidentiality from being tested and treated early.
Whatever New York decides will be significant. Others states tend to look to New York in formulating their own AIDS policy, and a change in Albany could well lead to policy changes in other states.
In a policy statement to be released tomorrow, the group said clinical advances and the need for the most up-to-date information on H.I.V. infection demanded new approaches, and that a system that simply tracked people with AIDS was no longer an effective measure of the extent of the epidemic. The group said that assuring strong safeguards for privacy was as important as ever, but that the large numbers of people who are infected but who do not have full-blown AIDS make it essential that accurate tracking of H.I.V. cases begin.
The statement, an advance copy of which was supplied to The New York Times, does not explicitly oppose reporting names, but instead urges that the state consider using coded identification systems.
 "This is not a static epidemic and our position cannot be a static position," Ronald S. Johnson, a managing director of the organization, said in an interview. "It certainly is a change. We look at it more as a progression in our thinking."
The group, which is based in New York and has an annual budget of roughly $27 million, has been a formidable lobbying force in Washington and Albany, particularly in matters like quicker access to new drugs, increased government financing for AIDS services, and resisting policies viewed as a threat to the civil liberties of its constituency. Its board of directors, contributors and volunteers include a cross section of New York's business, social and professional elite.
A move to H.I.V. reporting in New York would most likely require new state law. No action in Albany is expected until the New York State Advisory Council, which advises the Governor and the Legislature on AIDS policy, makes its recommendations on H.I.V. reporting, expected by March.
Twenty-eight states, including New Jersey, now have H.I.V. reporting for both adults and adolescents. Those states, however, account for about 24 percent of all AIDS cases reported. New York, which does not require H.I.V. reporting, has the highest rate of reported AIDS cases, 69 per 100,000 people. The comparable number is 47 for New Jersey, 37 for Connecticut, and 26 for California.
H.I.V. reporting in New York State would greatly expand -- by thousands -- the number of infected people listed in Government registries, arousing concern about invasion of privacy and discrimination. As many as 150,000 people statewide are believed to be H.I.V. positive, of whom about 80 percent are New York City residents, according to the State Health Department.
A move to H.I.V. reporting would provide a more accurate picture of the epidemic and could lead to earlier treatment. But some advocates for AIDS patients suggest that the policy could open the door to more intrusive and coercive measures, such as tracking down the sexual and needle-sharing partners of infected people. The Gay Men's Health Crisis position paper said it opposes linking H.I.V. reporting to such activities.
In recent months, many advocacy groups have softened their position on H.I.V. reporting because powerful new drugs have delayed many patients' progression to AIDS-related illnesses and death. Most organizations, however, have remained publicly opposed to reporting the names of H.I.V.-positive people to health departments, favoring instead the use of coded identification.
The organization's statement is not explicit in opposing H.I.V. name reporting. The statement says a system of coded identification should be used to monitor H.I.V. infections in New York State, and cited the "unique identifier" systems used in Maryland and Texas as models.
Late last week, the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta announced that a three-year evaluation of the Maryland and Texas systems had found that tracking H.I.V. by codes did not reliably count the cases. The evaluation of the two states concluded that the codes were often incomplete, making it difficult to link them to real people.
Mr. Johnson, of the Health Crisis, said more resources needed to be spent to develop a viable coded identification system. "The Maryland and Texas approaches showed flaws, but they don't necessarily demonstrate that the unique identifier system is impossible," he said.
His organization's new position has dismayed some advocates for AIDS patients, who had hoped that the group would make opposition to the use of names the bedrock of its policy.
"It's disappointing," said Jeffrey L. Reynolds, a member of the state AIDS Advisory Council and the policy director at the Long Island Association for AIDS Care, based in Huntington. "There's so much at stake here. This is the most critical issue that the AIDS community has faced in a decade. And they've taken a middle-of-the-road position. They should have come out with guns blaring and they didn't."
Few groups now oppose H.I.V. reporting in general. The American Civil Liberties Union and the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund do not oppose the approach as long as coded identification is used. That position is also shared by AIDS Action, a national group for 2,500 community providers of AIDS service, AIDS Project Los Angeles and the San Francisco AIDS Foundation.
The New York State AIDS Advisory Council has a special work group on H.I.V. reporting, of which Mr. Reynolds is a co-chairman. The work group has reached a consensus that H.I.V. reporting is necessary. But after its meeting yesterday, Mr. Reynolds said that the question of choosing name or coded identification was still a contentious one. The work group will submit recommendations that will go to a vote before the full council in several weeks.
Even so, the outcome in New York State is inevitable, according to some AIDS policy experts.
"It will move to a system of H.I.V. reporting and ultimately it will go to name reporting," said Lawrence O. Gostin, a director of the Georgetown University-Johns Hopkins University Program on Law and Public Health and a member of the Centers for Disease Control's advisory committee. "New York is the most important state in the country in terms of the AIDS epidemic. It's a matter of time."
Mark Barnes, a health care lawyer in New York City and a former director of AIDS programs in the City Health Department, said many advocates believed that a coded identification system was not workable but that they felt they must satisfy their constituencies. Mr. Barnes said the state was likely to move to name-based H.I.V. reporting gradually, perhaps after experimenting with a coded identification system.
"This train has left the station," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asian Turmoil Putting Brakes On Arms Race

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Jan. 12

 BODY:
The economic crisis in Asia is beginning to have an unforeseen consequence: slowing a military spending spree that has thrown American, European and Russian arms makers into a heated competition for billions of dollars in weapons sales.
In recent years, Asia, particularly Southeast Asia, had become the big growth market for fighters, missiles, tanks and other modern armaments, much to the dismay of arms-control advocates in the United States and other countries. 
 Until now, that is, when the collapse of currencies and spending constraints imposed by international bailout deals are starting to achieve in a few months what all those advocates could not do in years.
The big weapons buyers in Asia are abandoning some major arms deals and postponing ambitious plans for others.
Thailand has asked the United States to help renegotiate its purchase of eight F/A-18 fighter jets for $400 million. In the last week alone, Indonesia announced that it would put off plans to buy $1 billion in Russian weapons, while South Korea said it would delay the purchase of four Awacs, the American-made electronic surveillance jets.
While it is not clear how long the economic crisis will last, the contagion that has swept economies from Malaysia to South Korea could erode one of the few growing markets for American-made weaponry. The prospect is stirring concern at the Pentagon and among the nation's military contractors, who fear that a prolonged downturn could slash sales the Pentagon relies on to keep production costs lower for its own purchases.
"There will certainly be a hiccup of sorts in the Asian procurement," said Joel L. Johnson, vice president of the Aerospace Industries Association, a trade organization in Washington that represents aircraft manufacturers. "The question is whether it's going to be just a hiccup or an Asian flu that could last a long time."
Arriving here on the first stop of a 12-day tour of Asia, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen pledged that the United States would do what it could to help the countries weather the storm, using its leverage with American manufacturers to help salvage weapons purchases.
"Obviously, we are interested in helping these countries who are experiencing difficulties right now also deal with their security concerns -- by either stretching out or finding some other method of payment or some deferral of payments in order to accommodate them," Mr. Cohen said today at a news conference with Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, at a resort south of here.
Mr. Cohen's trip to Asia -- particularly Southeast Asia -- was meant to underscore longstanding American security interests in the region. While security issues remain high on the agenda, the economic crises in Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea -- all of which he is to visit -- will loom large over most of Mr. Cohen's trip.
Perhaps the clearest indication of the trip's changing agenda was the last-minute addition of an official from the Treasury, Todd Crawford, to Mr. Cohen's military entourage.
For major American arms makers, the market in Asia remains relatively small compared to the Pentagon's spending on weapons procurement, which totals roughly $45 billion this year. Arms exports, which are strictly controlled by the State Department, are expected to reach $14 billion to $16 billion, of which no more than a quarter are headed to Asia.
But at a time when the Pentagon has faced budget restraints, Asia has been one of the only growing markets, except for the flurry of purchases in the Middle East after the Persian Gulf war.
After the cold war, the "tiger" economies in Southeast Asia in particular set out to use their deep financial reserves to modernize their militaries, even though they faced no immediate security threats.
Six of the seven countries Mr. Cohen will visit during his trip have spent more than $3 billion on American arms over the last three years. American law forbids the export of weapons to the seventh, China.
Advocates of arms control have sharply criticized the Asian arms buildup, as well as Washington's eagerness to supply it, saying the rush to modernize could destabilize the region by stoking lingering fears and dormant hostilities.
Caleb Rossiter, director of Demilitarization for Democracy, an arms- control group in Washington, called many of the purchases "prestige buys," meant merely to enhance the standing of one country or another in the region.
But he said countries like Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia have also been trying to expand their ability to use force beyond their borders and into the shipping lanes of the South China Sea, where there are potentially dangerous territorial disputes over several island groups.
"Everybody wants to project power," Mr. Rossiter said.
For now, at least, the economic crisis has ended that.
Malaysia, which has seen the value of its currency, the ringgit, drop by half, has revised its budget to scrap plans to spend $500 million to $600 million to buy new equipment, including American attack helicopters, armored vehicles and possibly several F/A-18 fighters.
At the news conference today with Mr. Cohen, Mr. Anwar, the Deputy Prime Minister, said Malaysia had "to defer many of our earlier commitments," although it remained committed to insuring "a sufficient modern, capable military force."
Mr. Cohen said today that he had not discussed sales during his meetings today with Mr. Anwar or the Prime Minister, Mahathir bin Mohamad. And he and his aides have tried to play down the impact the economic crisis was having on arms sales, saying the Administration's main priority was to restore economic stability generally, even if that meant a temporary retrenchment in sales.
But sales are certain to come up during Mr. Cohen's trip.
The Pentagon has already promised to help Thailand, which Mr. Cohen will visit on Friday, to renegotiate its purchase of eight F/A-18's. The deal, signed in 1996, cost Thailand nearly $400 million that it now can ill afford to pay, even as the jets' manufacturer, Boeing, moves ahead with production.
Thailand, like South Korea, has had to cut its military spending as part of the austerity measures imposed by the International Monetary Fund in exchange for a $17 billion rescue plan. While the F/A-18's are the largest single purchase, Thailand may also have to postpone plans to buy other systems as well, including armored personnel carriers.
One official traveling with Mr. Cohen said it was important to demonstrate to countries in the region, which have also been looking to buy from European and Russian manufacturers, that the United States could be a reliable, flexible seller, even in times of crisis.
Although officials declined to specify how the Pentagon and Boeing might restructure the F/A-18 deal, the United States may simply allow Thailand to delay payments on the aircraft or find another buyer.
It is a measure of the priority given to supporting American arms manufacturers and the jobs they create that there has been no talk of simply canceling the sale.

West Aids Bosnian Serb
Though candidates backed by the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, won only 15 of 83 seats in elections in November, her Western supporters have worked hard to block those loyal to her rival, Radovan Karadzic, from obtaining a parliamentary majority. Western diplomats say the government of the Bosnian Serb republic will soon be in her hands despite the fact that supporters of Dr. Karadzic hold 39 of the 42 seats needed for a majority. A3
 
Some Germans Fight The Euro
A prominent group of lawyers and former bankers petitioned Germany's highest court to prevent their country from joining Europe's proposed single currency, the euro. Experts gave the petition little chance of success, but its arguments showed the ambivalence in attitudes toward the idea of abandoning the traditionally strong German mark. A3
 
Official Charged in Mexico
Federal prosecutors in Mexico have accused a state police commander of helping to arm a gang of paramilitary gunmen who killed 45 Indian villagers in December. The charges were the first filed against police and state Government officials who have been under investigation in the massacre. Federal prosecutors indicated that their investigation was closing in on higher state officials who might have provided direct support to the killers. A8
 
Sex Discrimination In Mexico
The United States Labor Department, concluding a six-month review of charges of sex discrimination in Mexico, concluded that thousands of border assembly plants administer medical tests to weed out pregnant applicants and harass pregnant workers to coerce their resignation. Others dismiss pregnant workers to avoid paying maternity benefits, the Department said. A8
 
U.N. Fills New Deputy Post
A French Canadian, Louise Frechette, was named the first Deputy Secretary General in United Nations history. Ms. Frechette, who is resigning as Canada's Deputy Minister of National Defense, will help Secretary General Kofi Annan finish the job of redesigning the United Nations administration. She served as Canada's United Nations representative from 1992 to 1994. A9

Cold and Loss of Power Grip Canada and Maine
At least 15 people have died since a storm began to lash Eastern Canada on Jan. 5. Hydro-Quebec, the provincial-owned utility company, reported that 625,000 residences in Montreal and outlying areas were still without electricity. It will take up to two weeks to restore service to all customers, utility executives said. And since a brief thaw over the weekend, temperatures have dropped 25 to 30 degrees. Already, more than 10,000 people are living in 120 temporary shelters in Montreal. A1
 
Storm damage in Northern New England was expected to run in the tens of millions of dollars. Governor Angus King of Maine called the storm "the biggest disaster of this kind that has ever hit this state." A14
 
Warning on F.A.A. Computers
A set of crucial computers in the nation's air traffic control system should not be used beyond December 1999, because they may not operate reliably when the date rolls over to Jan. 1, 2000, and there is no way to predict the effect on air traffic, according to I.B.M., which built the computers. But the official in charge of that system at the Federal Aviation Administration said "it would be an extraordinary feat" to replace about 40 mainframe computers by then. A16

Theodore J. Kaczynski appeared to be cooperating with the court-appointed psychiatrist who arrived in Sacramento, Calif., to evaluate his competency to stand trial on Federal charges of being the Unabomber, a spokesman for the Sacramento County Sheriff said. A10
 
$1 Trillion in Health Spending
Health spending increased in 1996 at the lowest rate in 36 years, but topped $1 trillion for the first time, the Government reported. Such spending has been growing at the same pace as the economy for four years in a row, contrary to earlier projections, which showed health care eating up a bigger and bigger share of the nation's output. A woman who lost a promised job as a lawyer in the Georgia Attorney General's office, after the state Attorney General learned that she was planning a marriage ceremony with her lesbian partner, failed to persuade the United States Supreme Court to hear her appeal. A15
 
More Realism for Safety Ads
Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said that the Federal Government planned to help produce television advertisements that would promote safe driving by showing graphic re-enactments of automobile crashes. He also criticized Hollywood for encouraging reckless driving by failing to show the pain and suffering caused by the car crashes that so frequently occur in movies and television shows. A17

The Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's leading AIDS service agency, has reversed its position and will call for New York doctors to report people infected with H.I.V. to state health departments. The same practice is already used for infectious diseases like syphilis and tuberculosis. The official statement by the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the most politically and economically connected organization in the world of nonprofit AIDS service, signifies the collapse of a longstanding consensus by AIDS and civil rights groups against H.I.V. reporting. HEADLINE: No Need to Panic Over Social Security

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Jan. 8 news article on Social Security was correct in reporting the wide difference of opinion among policy makers about what changes are necessary to insure its future solvency. However, solid economic evidence exists to suggest that Social Security is not heading for a crisis. 
 The projected bankruptcy of Social Security in 2029 is based on an average economic growth rate of just 1.7 percent from now until 2029. However, for the last 25 years economic growth has averaged 2.5 percent.
With a conservative growth rate of 2.2 percent annually, the trust fund shortfall would be 1.5 percent of taxable payroll, not the 2.2 percent gap projected by the Social Security trustees. This translates into a gap between input and output of $25 billion a year beginning in 2029. Such a gap is manageable. The future ratio of working-age adults to the elderly and children virtually guarantees that we will be able to finance the system in the future without cutting benefits. While minor adjustments may be necessary, it would be premature to rush to raise the eligibility age or move to privatization.
 
JERROLD NADLER
Member of Congress, 8th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Jan. 9, 1998

HEADLINE: No Need to Panic Over Social Security

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Reduction of the $5 trillion Federal debt should be the primary use for the budget surplus (Op-Ed, Jan. 9). Interest payments consume about one-seventh of annual Federal outlays, an excessive amount. These payments are unproductive, conferring little social, political or economic benefit. In fact, many of these payments go abroad, benefiting no domestic objectives. Foreign-held bonds may be cashed in a crisis, leading to a rise in United States loan rates. 
 Reducing our interest payments reduces the need for revenue and increases the money available for worthy objectives like Social Security and Medicare.
 
HENRY E. AUER
Chicago, Jan. 10, 1998

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Rally After Recovering From Overnight Selloff in Asia

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Stocks staged a muted rally yesterday, recovering from early losses that were set off by sharp overnight selloffs in Asia.
The comeback suggested that some investors continue to bet that the Asian crisis will not have a severe impact on the fourth-quarter results of many American companies, which are due in the next few weeks. 
 Large multinational companies like Caterpillar, Procter & Gamble, Pfizer and Merck, which are seen as having only a limited exposure to the Asian crisis, were among the stocks that led major market indexes higher yesterday.
But banking stocks, including Citicorp and J. P. Morgan, faltered, and technology shares were mixed -- Oracle and Compaq Computer were lower, as Intel, Microsoft and Dell Computer eked out gains -- indicating that investors still have concerns about Asia's impact on certain sectors.
"There are very mixed reviews," said Paul Rich, an equity trader at BT Brokerage in New York. "There's optimism about other markets where we have more exposure, such as Europe, but we continue to see selling."
The global wave of selling began in Hong Kong, where the main stock index fell 8.7 percent after the largest Asian investment firm outside of Japan, Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd., collapsed. At the same time, concerns mounted about the crisis in Indonesia, while in Thailand, the currency, the baht, fell to an all-time low.
While the selling slowed on European markets, the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 137 points in the first half-hour of trading, extending a slide on Friday, when the Dow fell 222.20 points, or 2.9 percent. Stocks soon recovered, and the Dow closed up 66.76 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 7,647.18.
The Standard & Poor's 500 company stock index rose 11.52 points, to 939.21, after falling as low as 912.83. The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.36 points, to 1,507.58.
The early selloff dropped stocks to prices that whet the appetite of bargain hunters, analysts said. Investors may also have been heartened by the comments from some market analysts who are forecasting that despite Asia's malaise fourth-quarter earnings could come in better than expected.
"It's not as if Asia doesn't matter, but we think that the impact on the U.S. will be muted," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Most United States companies are well diversified, Ms. Cohen said, and are benefiting from a strong domestic economy.
As a result, she said, "the fourth quarter could be a good quarter." But markets will continue to be volatile, she added, because investors will be nervous about earnings growth until companies actually report performance.
Byron Wien, a managing director and United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said, "The Asian situation has not been arrested yet, but it's getting worse at a slower rate."
A traditional influx of cash into equity mutual funds during January is also driving purchases when stock prices drop, said Timothy M. Stevenson, a senior portfolio manager for First Capital Group, a unit of First Union Bank in Charlotte, N.C. Many portfolio managers who did not perform as well as the Standard & Poor's 500 index in 1997 feel compelled to be fully invested, he said.
While about $917 million flowed into equity mutual funds last week, mostly into large-cap growth funds and growth and income funds, that paled compared with the $8.9 billion that flowed into such funds in the period a year ago, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services in Arcata, Calif.
Last week, bond funds saw cash inflows of more than $700 million, Mr. Adler said, another sign of the mixed views of investors about the near-term outlook for United States companies.

HEADLINE: Journal;
Party Of Lincoln

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Bring back Ralph Reed!
More than one leading Republican moderate said as much to me over the past week as the post-Reed religious right came close to pushing the party into its bloodiest civil war yet, threatening to split it on class, religious and gender lines. As long as the pragmatic Mr. Reed and his slick machine, the Christian Coalition, were the most visible G.O.P. theocrats, there was always some hope that backroom compromises or Sunday-morning-TV spin would soften or camouflage the most extreme jihads of Pat Buchanan or Pat Robertson before they scared away the center of the American electorate. 
 No more. Mr. Reed is now a hired political gun moving to the center himself; he's seen the gender gap and speaks openly of a pro-choice candidate on the Republican ticket. His old boss, Mr. Robertson, is busy counting the zillions from the sale of his Family Channel to Rupert Murdoch. The Christian Coalition is off the media screen, except as an object of ridicule in the hit movie "Scream 2"; its contributions are down, its staff downsized, its much-publicized outreach to inner cities jettisoned. Into this vacuum has stepped Gary Bauer of the Family Research Council, and Mr. Bauer, in contrast to Mr. Reed, is a religious crusader first, a P.R.-minded, deal-making pol last.
It was Mr. Bauer -- emboldened by his humiliation of Bob Dole in the '96 platform fight and by conservative press clips touting him as a plausible Presidential candidate in 2000 -- who led the charge that brought the G.O.P. to the brink this week. The weapon of his insurgency is a resolution to be voted on by the Republican National Committee at its winter meeting beginning in California tomorrow. It calls for the party to withhold money from any candidate who won't support a ban on so-called partial birth abortion -- a litmus test that would in effect cast the two most prominent G.O.P. winners of last fall, Rudolph Giuliani and Christine Todd Whitman, out of their own party, not to mention both Maine Senators, Olympia Snowe and Susan Collins.
Such is the religious right's clout within the G.O.P. machinery that through last weekend the measure was thought to be a possible winner -- with no less a sage than George Will hoping on TV that it could pass. But few predict that victory now. Except for Steve Forbes, who bizarrely embraces the same religious conservatives who tried to bait him about his father's gay life style in '96, most of the mainstream Republican establishment has suddenly circled wagons against the resolution.
What prompted the about-face? The Republican Leadership Council, an organization formed by economically conservative G.O.P. donors to foster "social inclusion" in their party, spoke up big time, raising the specter that they and their rapidly growing purse would bolt the Republican National Committee if the resolution passed. But not only fat-cat and pro-choice forces balked. Knowing that another perceived party cave-in to religious-right bullying would send a disastrous signal of intolerance to moderate voters, Michigan's pro-life Governor, John Engler, and Matthew Brooks, director of the major Republican Jewish group, the National Jewish Coalition, sounded early alarms. The outcry jolted Jim Nicholson, the R.N.C. chairman, out of his studious neutrality, setting off a stampede.
Mr. Bauer isn't going away, however, even if his forces are for once slapped down. A true believer, he'll keep pushing the party not just for his religious orthodoxy on abortion, school prayer and gay civil rights but on the economic issue of free trade. His campaign to fight Christian persecution in China by restricting American business there -- and his Buchananesque contempt for the G.O.P. of "Wall Street and the Fortune 500" -- could divide the party as violently as abortion. Nor is his class and religious warfare without serious cheerleaders. William Kristol's Weekly Standard this week promotes abortion as the "central issue" of 2000 and calls for reversing Roe v. Wade; National Review has bashed Christine Whitman as much for her class pedigree as for her views.
Both sides of the G.O.P. have tried to appropriate the mantle of Lincoln, with religious conservatives equating moral opposition to abortion to opposition to slavery, and moderates likening a woman's right to choose to Lincoln's belief in individual freedom. Either way, a party divided against itself with such vehemence cannot stand.
