SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1622 words

HEADLINE: Business Travel: Who Needs Sidewalks?;
Many 'Road Warriors' Prefer Airport Hotels to Downtown.

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Whenever Dirk Van Dongen flies here on business, as he does often, he checks into the O'Hare Hilton and rarely leaves the premises until he checks out to fly back home.
"Of 17 trips to Chicago in 1997, I've only been to downtown Chicago one time," said Mr. Van Dongen, president of the Washington-based National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, "We hold our meetings in the hotel because it's convenient, efficient and enjoyable." 
 Convenient? Obviously. Efficient? O.K. But enjoyable? At an airport hotel, where if you stroll out to see a show, it will be a ballet of landings and takeoffs?
Yet strange as it might seem, legions of travelers are making such hotels their first choice -- from business travelers who do not want to fight traffic into and out of a city to a growing number of newlyweds en route to honeymoons.
Most of the hotels in and around O'Hare International Airport, the world's busiest with almost 69.2 million passengers in 1996, are consistently filled.
The 858-room O'Hare Hilton, the only one of the 20 O'Hare airport hotels actually on the airport grounds, is perpetually one of the most crowded. "Road warriors from all over live here, and we have lots of repeat business," said Kenneth M. Smith, the hotel's general manager.
And why have so many of the lodging industry's ugly ducklings been transformed into swans? It is no mystery. As record nationwide hotel occupancies and record airline traffic have created a huge demand for hotel rooms, almost any hotel rooms, airport hotels suddenly do not look so bad. And to keep guests coming back, at steadily rising rates, hotel companies have been pouring millions into renovations and amenities. The strategy has paid off in spades.
Through the first 10 months of 1997, the 72.4 percent occupancy rate at airport hotels outperformed every other part of the hotel industry, according to Smith Travel Research. And their $77.89 average room rate, up 8.2 percent over the corresponding 10 months in 1996, is higher than the industrywide average of $75.22.
The lobby of the O'Hare Hilton, with 10 check-in desks, airline arrival and departure monitors, and an American Airlines check-in desk, could easily be mistaken for an extension of Terminal 2, less than a two-minute walk away.
But the terminal does not have private mailboxes for its most frequent guests, who on arrival need only open their mailbox to find their electronic room key, messages or packages. Nor does it have 37 conference rooms, all with fax machines, nor a busy athletic club with all the bells and whistles. A short putt from the athletic club is a simulated golf course, which, the New Jersey-born Mr. Smith said with a knowing smile, "is a huge hit during Chicago winters."
"Eighty percent of our lodging cash flow comes from 25 of the 60 hotels we own and/or manage," said Marc Grossman, corporate spokesman for Hilton Hotels, which also franchises 160 more hotels. "And 6 of those 25," he added, "are airport hotels." One of those 6, the O'Hare Hilton, is consistently among Hilton's top 10.
But there are other stellar performers. In and around San Francisco International Airport, where Hilton and almost every other national chain are represented, the lodging market is going through the roof.
"It's the most buoyant hotel market in California and the fastest-growing hotel market in the nation," said Anwar Elgonemy, a consultant with PKF Consulting. Through September of last year, he said, occupancy at those San Francisco airport hotels averaged 87.7 percent, compared with 85.8 percent in the comparable period in 1996, and rates soared nearly 20 percent, to $92.40 from $77.35.
Similar patterns exist elsewhere. Both the O'Hare Hilton and the nearby Hyatt Regency O'Hare report average occupancy rates of 85 percent and 76 percent, respectively, higher than the 72.5 percent average occupancy rate for Chicago hotels through the first nine months of 1997. And the 111-room Radisson Airport Hotel in Warwick, R.I., across from T. F. Green Airport, which serves Providence, has averaged close to 94.6 percent full since July 1.
Robert Stone, president and chief executive of Access Solutions, a software development company, stays several nights a week in the Radisson, which is owned and operated by Johnson & Wales University in Providence. "I like the layout of its rooms, its food and its service," he said. "And the executive suites make good small meeting rooms."
The Radisson also offers weekend entertainment and lodging packages. Through May it is offering discount tickets to concerts with the Boston Festival Orchestra and the Chorus of Westerly, and packages to performances of the Rhode Island Philharmonic Orchestra. And it is not alone. The Comfort Inn-Cleveland Airport Hotel recently offered a package that includes two free tickets to the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame.
For travelers of modest means, there is, of course, a downside. San Francisco airport hotels are now so popular, Mr. Elgonemy said, that the airline crews and budget-minded travelers of the early 1990's "have been pushed out and replaced by high-yielding corporate and group meeting accounts."
At Hilton airport hotels, 45 percent of guests are individual business travelers, 23 percent are attending company or association meetings, and 11 percent are airline and airport personnel. Individual leisure travelers make up 17 percent, while tour groups account for 3 percent and "other" accounts for 1 percent.
The high occupancies and high rates are igniting a race among hotel companies to acquire even more airport hotels.
Hilton, for example, already has 39 airport hotels in its portfolio and is building a $100 million, 600-room hotel at Logan International Airport in Boston. "We're basically at all the major airports in the country, except La Guardia," said Robert E. Dirks, Hilton's head of marketing, referring to La Guardia Airport in New York. "And when it makes good economic sense, we'll be there, too."
Hilton has also staked out airports in smaller markets, where full-service hotels might not make economic sense but Hilton Garden Inns might. Other hotel companies also have similar limited-service facilities at smaller airports.
The 97-room Ramada Limited Airport Hotel in Oklahoma City, which catered to truckers before its remodeling three years ago, does not have a restaurant, but it has rates between $55 and $65 and attractive Victorian decor and four-poster beds.
"We're not as big as some of the hotels around here, but we get lots of meetings and plenty of small-business travelers," said Sherry Sparks, the hotel's director of sales. "And our occupancy is regularly above 90 percent."
Marriott International added a twist to the concept of smaller, less expensive chain hotels when, at a cost of $8.5 million, it converted its 782-room hotel at the Miami International Airport two years ago into a smaller, full-service Marriott, as well as a less expensive Courtyard and Fairfield Inn -- each with its own checkout desk.
Not far from the Miami airport, on a secluded peninsula, the Miami Airport Hilton attracts not just airport hotel guests, who rarely stay more than one night, but longer-term guests who come to play tennis and water-ski or jet-ski on the hotel's 100-acre man-made lake. The Hyatt Regency Dallas-Fort Worth has an abundance of recreational facilities: a pair of 18-hole golf courses, 7 tennis courts, 10 racquetball courts and 2 health clubs. The Radisson Inn at New Orleans International Airport has four lighted tennis courts, while the New Orleans Airport Hilton, two miles away, has two lighted tennis courts and a putting green.
But even the more conventional airport hotels now offer services and amenities equal to those of their midtown brethren -- including, in some cases, soundproof rooms and ergonomically designed chairs and desks.
Expressing a sentiment seconded by many business travelers, Roger Conner, a spokesman for Marriott, said: "Our two-year-old full-service hotel at the Philadelphia airport is as nice as it gets. There's no trade-off in quality compared with our 1,500-room Center City hotel."
What they are lacking, of course, is the culture, night life and unpredictability of a downtown location.
A Westin hotel at the Philadelphia International Airport, renovated at a cost of $4.5 million, is the first upscale, all-suites business hotel in that city. The Hotel Sofitel, near the Miami airport, boasts not only a French restaurant but also a French bakery, which gives guests free baguettes as they check out.
Because there is no effective way to prevent hotels from adding "airport" to their name, and since most lie outside airports proper, plenty of dowdy, down-at-the-heels properties carry that designation. But many independent hotels and most major chains require that airport hotels be within 3 miles, or 10 minutes, of terminals.
Furthermore, they require them to offer food service 24 hours a day, free airport vans, same-day laundry and pressing service, business centers and multilingual receptionists.
Most Hyatt airport hotels have presidential suites for dignitaries or celebrities. The presidential suites at the Hyatt Regency O'Hare each have two bedrooms, a parlor, two baths, two whirlpools and a wet bar.
Diane Altman of New York was a recent guest at the Hyatt Regency O'Hare, although she did not stay in the presidential suite. The executive editor of McGraw-Hill's school division, Ms. Altman was there not to avoid the local paparazzi but for a meeting of the company's school division.
"When you only go from the airport to the hotel and the hotel back to the airport," she said, "why would you want to stay anywhere else?"

HEADLINE: Jean McKelvey, 89, Professor and Labor Arbitration Expert

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Jean Trepp McKelvey, who hurdled gender barriers in the field of labor-management mediation and opened the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University, died on Jan. 5 at the Kirkhaven Nursing Home in her hometown of Rochester. She was 89.
She taught at Sarah Lawrence College for 13 years until 1946, when Cornell formed the new branch on its Ithaca, N.Y., campus and appointed her as its first faculty member. She wrote the curriculum for the school and taught courses in arbitration, labor law and labor practices. 
 She assumed emeritus status in 1976 but continued to teach and coordinate the school's off-campus graduate credit courses given under extension programs in Albany, Corning, Elmira, Rochester and Syracuse. In a tribute to her and another faculty member, the school, known by its initials, I.L.R., established its first endowed chair in 1994 and named it the Jean McKelvey-Alice Grant Professorship of Labor Management Relations.
Many of her former students went on to fill influential positions as union leaders, arbitrators and jurists. The year after she arrived at Cornell, she became a charter member -- and the sole woman at the time -- in the National Academy of Arbitrators. In 1970, she was the first woman to be elected president of the academy and, mindful of the overwhelming preponderance of men in her metier, came up with an arbitration training program for women.
Outside the classroom, Dr. McKelvey was a sought-after arbitrator for the airline industry as well as other sectors of the economy. Gov. W. Averell Harriman named her to the State Board of Mediation in 1955, and she served on it for 11 years, helping settle thorny disputes like a wholesale butchers' strike in 1961.
President Richard M. Nixon appointed her to the Federal Services Impasses Panel in 1970, and she remained on it until eight years ago. At her death, she was still a member of the Public Review Board of the United Automobile Workers.
She was the author of many papers and books and edited the proceedings of several annual meetings of the National Academy of Arbitrators. Among her books were "Cleared for Takeoff: Airline Labor Relations Since Deregulation" (I.L.R. Press, 1988), "The Changing Law of Fair Representation" (I.L.R., 1985), "New Challenges to Arbitration" (I.L.R., 1977) and "A.F.L. Attitudes Toward Production, 1900-1932" (Greenwood, 1974).
She was born Jean Trepp in St. Louis and graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Wellesley College in 1929. She received her M.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Radcliffe College in 1931 and 1933 and joined the Sarah Lawrence faculty in the year between. During World War II, she was a hearing officer and arbitrator for the National War Labor Board.
She is survived by her husband of 63 years, Blake McKelvey, Rochester's city historian emeritus, and a brother, Richard Trepp of Springfield, Mass.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall as Demand Decreases and Stock Prices Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities fell in choppy trading yesterday as investors warily watched the Asian situation. The flight to quality that had been pushing bond yields lower abated amid rebounding stock prices.
The 30-year bond dropped 29/32, to a price of 105 23/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.73 percent, from 5.69 percent Monday. 
 Prices remained near the day's lows, as traders reported sellers in two- and three-year maturities after a benign Consumer Price Index report in the morning.
Many in the market felt the rally on Monday, caused partly by concern over the impact of the Asian crisis, was overdone.
Talk of a large hedge fund as a big seller of longer-maturity Government securities was countered by talk of a potential rate cut by the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, which helped support bonds. The lack of downward momentum in the market prompted some sellers, who had bet on further declines, to buy bonds instead.
"The lack of inflationary pressures continues to impress market observers," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
The Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in December, bringing the annual gain to 1.7 percent last year, the most subdued inflation since 1986 and almost half of the 3.3 percent rise of 1996. The report suggested there is little reason for Federal Reserve policy makers, who are meeting Feb. 3-4, to raise interest rates despite other signs of resilient economic growth.
"This extremely favorable performance gives the Fed a good deal of latitude to keep monetary policy unchanged for quite some time," Mr. Fine said.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, noted that it was the least inflationary reading of the Consumer Price Index in more than 30 years, with the core rate -- which excludes the cost of energy and food -- at its lowest since 1965.
Although an economic slowdown is widely expected, some recently released data, notably housing and labor markets, have yet to display any evidence of a slackening. Coming statistics for retail sales and industrial production are not expected to show much slowing either.
At the same time, the bond market seems to be signaling that the next Fed move on interest rates will be down, Mr. Fine said. The main evidence is that yields on two-year notes are lower than the Federal funds rate, the overnight loan rate between banks and a sensitive indicator of short-term interest rates.
Other economic news released yesterday had little influence on bond prices. The LJR Redbook Research survey of weekly retail activity showed sales up 1.9 percent for the first two weeks of January, but slightly weaker than the 2.4 percent increase reported last week, with much of the buying attributed to bargain hunting, especially in apparel and electronics.
In another report, a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta showed that a slowdown in business activity in the Southeast continued in December. The Atlanta Fed's business activity index increased marginally, up 1.7 in December from a 2.2 decrease in November.
A rally in the stock market limited the gains in Treasury securities.
"The equity strength kept Treasuries struggling," said John Canavan, a market analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, "limiting the upside. So prices headed back toward the lows."

HEADLINE: Inflation Climbed Only 1.7% in 1997, Its Smallest Increase in 11 Years

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Inflation, once the bane of the economy but these days only a minor irritant, barely budged last month, and for all of 1997 showed its smallest increase in 11 years, the Government reported today.
With the economic turmoil in Asia expected to drive the prices of many imported goods lower in coming months, the outlook is for inflation to remain tame, economists said. 
 Since economists believe official statistics overstate inflation, some analysts think the economy could be on the brink of widespread decreases in the prices of commodities and manufactured goods, although prices for services like medical care and entertainment are likely to go on rising.
Economists have even begun debating the possibility of deflation: an across-the-board decline in prices for everything from real estate and stocks to steel, shoes and the cost of a visit to the dentist.
"Deflation in the prices of many commodities is a reasonable prospect in the months ahead, as the Asian effects work their way through the U.S. and world economies and the strong U.S. dollar against Asian currencies causes a switch in purchases by U.S. consumers to cheap foreign goods," said Allen Sinai, an economist with Primark Decision Economics in Boston.
"With essentially open borders to imports and a consumer mentality that still looks for bargains, it should be a field day on lots of items for Americans."
Today's inflation statistics highlighted the remarkable price stability the nation has enjoyed even as the economy has remained robust and unemployment has fallen to near quarter-century lows.
The Consumer Price Index, the most commonly cited gauge of inflation, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, matching analysts' expectations, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. The index rose 1.7 percent in 1997, the lowest rate since 1986, when oil prices fell sharply. The rate for 1996 was 3.3 percent.
Excluding prices for food and energy, which are made extremely volatile by factors like weather and political tensions in the world's oil-producing regions, the index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December and 2.2 percent for the year -- the lowest annual figure since 1965. The corresponding rate for 1996 was 2.6 percent.
The inflation report led many economists to conclude that the Federal Reserve no longer has to consider raising interest rates at its meeting next month. The central bank has held rates steady since March, but has maintained a policy of leaning toward higher interest rates, a clear signal of its concern that low unemployment rates might push up wages and lead companies to raise prices.
But wage gains, while accelerating somewhat, have remained relatively limited. The Labor Department said today that average hourly earnings, adjusted for inflation, fell six-tenths of 1 percent in December, the first decline in three months. Economists expect wages to rise at a faster pace this year as employers scramble to fill jobs at a time of low unemployment.
But most analysts think the Fed is still not likely to consider reducing rates to forestall deflation. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed deflation at length in a speech earlier this month, but suggested that he did not consider it a "significant near-term risk."
Investors, though, appear increasingly convinced that the Fed will reduce the short-term interest rates it controls. The long-term rates set by the markets have dropped sharply in the last month, partly fueled by a flood of money from Asia being invested in United States Treasury bonds, which are considered one of the world's safest investments.
The report showed that prices for food, gasoline and new cars declined last month, while the costs of housing and clothing rose only slightly and medical care and entertainment prices increased.
The monthly figures were roughly in line with the trends for the year. Prices for services rose 2.8 percent for all of 1997, compared with a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent for goods.
Goods prices have been held in check or pushed down by the strength of the dollar, which makes imported goods relatively cheaper, by intense competition among manufacturers and retailers and by some improvement in productivity, or output per worker. Services are more susceptible to price increases now because labor costs are their biggest component.
In one indication of the changed psychology about inflation, the National Federation of Independent Business, a lobbying group for small businesses, said today that in the 1970's more than 40 percent of its member companies called inflation their No. 1 problem. Last year, the group said, the figure was 1 percent.
William C. Dunkelberg, the group's chief economist, said 16 percent of the members it surveyed reported raising prices in December and 11 percent reduced their prices. Although 30 percent of the companies reported that compensation costs rose for the month, they said they had been unable to pass the costs along in the form of higher prices.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bank Regulators Circulating Secret Data

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Federal regulators are collecting normally confidential information about individual banks' loans to South Korea and are sharing the information with large banks that are leading an effort to extend payments on the loans, according to American commercial bankers.
That such information is even circulating is a measure of the sense of urgency that the Government attaches to the economic crisis gripping much of Southeast Asia. Banks disclose lending information to regulators under strict secrecy guidelines that are breached only in unusual circumstances. 
 American banks and their counterparts in Japan and Europe are trying to extend payment on, or roll over, as much as $28 billion in short-term loans to South Korean banks that come due by March 31. South Korean banks have already technically defaulted on a portion of the debt, and their inability to pay off the loans has tightened credit, threatening the entire South Korean economy.
Regulators have an understandable need for up-to-date information on American lending in South Korea in light of the current crisis. And Federal regulators have been skilled in recent years at mobilizing private sector responses to severe economic problems caused by or involving banks. For example, regulators asked for detailed information about American bank lending during the Latin American crisis of the 1980's and early 1990's, and some of that information circulated freely.
But some banks are bristling that the detailed information they are sharing with regulators is also finding its way into the hands of competitors who may be able to take advantage of the information -- particularly when it involves the identity of borrowers. Banks are typically loath to share information that would violate confidentiality agreements they have with their clients and are even more hesitant if they think the disclosure may encourage another bank to try to steal a client.
In recent days, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates and supervises national banks, has asked American banks to provide information about when their loans to South Korea come due and the identities of the borrowers. And the Treasury Department has also kept up efforts it began making at least a month ago to pressure banks to join the rollover effort.
One American bank said it was recently contacted by a large New York bank that asked it about a loan coming due in South Korea. An executive of the bank said that the caller not only knew when the loan was due but also knew the identity of the bank's client. The bank executive said that the New York bank said it had received its information from the Federal Reserve.
While the Federal Reserve declined to comment, the Comptroller's office, which shares its data with the Federal Reserve, said it had been circumspect about the information it had received.
"We have said repeatedly that we are monitoring this situation closely, and that includes getting information from the banks," said Lee Cross, a spokeswoman for the Comptroller's office. "But we would never disclose any information we receive from one bank to any of the other banks we supervise."
The International Monetary Fund is working closely with South Korean central banking officials in Seoul to gather information on loans made to the Government and the nation's corporations by foreign banks, including American ones. The lending information collected by the I.M.F. is being shared with Federal Reserve officials in Washington.
The Federal Reserve, the nation's leading bank regulator, has ample room to disclose confidential information about banks when it sees fit under guidelines that define its responsibilities.
"They clearly see this as a unique and important event, and I suspect that regulatory intervention will increase," said one American banker, who insisted on anonymity.
Meanwhile, international banks remain divided on how long their rollovers of South Korean loans will last and under what circumstances. American bankers had hoped to get all banks to commit to a 90-day rollover last week, but German banks, which make up South Korea's second-largest creditor group after Japanese banks, have not committed beyond the end of January.
United States commercial bankers say German banks want their rollovers guaranteed by the South Korean Government before they dig themselves in any deeper.
Moreover, Japanese and German banks are balking at a refinancing proposal put forward by J. P. Morgan & Company that would involve exchanging short-term South Korean loans for longer-term bonds. The Japanese and Germans are said to be considering an alternative plan that would involve rolling over their loans for one to three years if the South Korean Government guaranteed the long-term rollovers.
American, French and Japanese banks have already committed to 90-day rollovers, and Italian and Swiss banks are expected to follow suit soon.
In South Korea yesterday, four of the country's largest conglomerates accepted I.M.F.-sponsored reforms, agreeing to adopt more rigorous accounting standards and to stop allowing their subsidiaries to lend money to one another.
The four companies, members of South Korea's dominant group of Government-backed concerns known as chaebol, are Hyundai, LG, Samsung and Sunkyong. Eight of South Korea's 30 largest chaebol collapsed last year beneath the weight of enormous debts and rapid, haphazard expansions.

HEADLINE: Addressing Racial Issues On Wall St.

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Wall Street, which is often perceived as still being a white male preserve, has generally been uneasy about openly discussing issues of race and gender.
In an effort to change that, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and his Rainbow/PUSH Coalition are starting a conference and fund-raiser today at Windows on the World, the restaurant atop the World Trade Center. The meetings are intended to promote economic opportunities for minorities and women. 
 The three-day gathering, which will be addressed by President Clinton, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, commemorates and coincides with the anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's birthday tomorrow, which is celebrated by a national holiday on Monday.
The events represent an effort to draw investment from Wall Street to minority businesses and to create something of a partnership between corporate leaders and minorities and women, according to the three-day gathering's sponsors, which include the Travelers Group, the huge insurance and financial services company, and the New York Stock Exchange, as well as the Rainbow/ PUSH Coalition.
The New York Stock Exchange, for the first time, will close in honor of Dr. King's birthday. While that may reflect the beginnings of change on Wall Street, the greater awareness of racial and gender issues has been driven in part by court actions. Last fall, for instance, Smith Barney Inc., which is now Salomon Smith Barney, a subsidiary of the Travelers Group, settled a class-action suit brought in Federal court by more than 20 women, both current and former employees, who contended that the firm had sat by while the workplace became an arena for gender discrimination and sexual harassment. In their long-running battle with the firm, the group's advocates invoked the rights of minorities, including women.
And while Mr. Jackson, business and political leaders and Wall Street titans may be able to agree on broadly defined goals, such as the need for more economic growth, for equality of opportunity and the need to regenerate inner cities and encourage investments that benefit the black and Hispanic population, the best jobs on Wall Street remain almost exclusively a white male province, and the nation's fund managers rarely direct large sums at projects that benefit minorities.
"The theme of this conference is expanding the marketplace," Mr. Jackson said in a telephone conference with reporters last week, to achieve stronger economic growth and opportunity through the "inclusion" of minorities and women.
"The two largest emerging markets are the black and Hispanic markets in this country," Mr. Jackson said, arguing that it is in Wall Street and corporate America's "enlightened self-interest" to invest in these markets to insure a prosperous economy. David C. Wilhelm, a senior managing director with Everen Securities Inc. in Chicago, who is flying to New York today for the conference and has consulted informally with Mr. Jackson in recent years, said: "I really think he believes this is the next stage of the civil rights movement: civil rights in the workplace and expanding access to capital for minorities.
"He views this as very much in the tradition of the struggle for economic justice that Martin Luther King began. This is a new Jesse Jackson. Jesse Jackson the capitalist."
Most big Wall Street firms are participating in this week's meetings. Sanford I. Weill, the Travelers chairman and chief executive, has been the most active Wall Street figure in organizing and backing the events, according to Mr. Jackson's aides. Despite such support, preparations for the gathering have not been entirely smooth. Both Mr. Greenspan and Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, recently distanced themselves from a fund-raising letter sent by the event's sponsors that mentioned their names.
At the request of the Fed and the S.E.C., the event's sponsors sent out a corrective letter saying that Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Levitt would be there simply to address the meeting, and were not in any way connected with fund-raising for it, according to an S.E.C. spokesman.

HEADLINE: A Road-Building Scandal Forces a Governor's Hand

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 13

 BODY:
Seeking to stem damage from a fusillade of disclosures about patronage and political influence in North Carolina's road-building program, Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. dismissed his Transportation Secretary today, acknowledged mistakes and promised change.
Governor Hunt and his top transportation appointees have figured in months of punishing news accounts about the department's penchant for building roads and bridges that benefit political insiders, often by overriding the recommendations of state highway engineers. 
 But the popular and long-serving Democratic Governor suggested at a news conference today that governors from both parties were responsible for creating a corrupt system.
"Over many decades and through many administrations -- Democratic and Republican, mine and others -- a system has evolved that no longer gives citizens and the taxpayers confidence in how priorities are set and decisions are made," he said.
He also was contrite. "We made some mistakes," Mr. Hunt acknowledged. "Now I want to fix it."
Mr. Hunt has weathered lesser ethical storms during his four terms but none that have touched him so closely: he personally lobbied the state highway administrator to replace a bridge over a reservoir near his Wilson County farm, a decision that contradicted a decision by state engineers.
And in the most sensational disclosure of the transportation mess, a contractor wrote to Mr. Hunt to express his anger that he was not appointed to the Board of Transportation despite raising the nearly $25,000 he claims he was told was the price for a seat.
"We are very disappointed," the contractor, James A. Cartrette of Columbus County, wrote to the Governor last year, "and feel that our money should be returned."
Investigations by the state's newspapers and by public policy groups have revealed that appointments to the 26-member transportation board most often went to political donors and that many board members used their influence to win approval for low-priority projects that benefited themselves, their family members and their friends.
Since the newspaper articles began appearing last fall, two members have resigned under pressure, a third pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges of conflict of interest, the state auditor has ordered a full review of policymaking, and legislative committees have opened hearings.
After months of reports about the growing scandal, Mr. Hunt today removed the Transportation Secretary, Garland Garrett, and made him a staff lobbyist. The Governor named Norris Tolson, who had been the Commerce Secretary, to the post and asked him to restructure the department in a way that would curtail the power of the state highway administrator, Larry Goode.
The rapid-fire disclosures about the transportation board, whose members, appointed by the governor, oversee the department, have provided the most embarrassing moments of Mr. Hunt's 13 years in office, his supporters and opponents agree. And in a capital where Democrats and Republicans are waging an intense war for control of state government, the scandal has gift-wrapped an issue for the Republicans in a legislative election year.
North Carolina Republican leaders have been quick to link the conflict-of-interest cases here to the investigations of Democratic fund-raising practices in Washington. They have pledged to use the ethics issue in their efforts this fall to expand their two-seat majority in the State House and to take control of the State Senate, where Democrats hold a 10-seat advantage.
Mr. Hunt, 60, who served his first two terms from 1977 to 1984 and then was elected again in 1992 and 1996, is one of the South's most enduring politicians. Considered a national authority on education issues, he spent $10.4 million in his 1996 campaign, a record for a governor's race in the state, and cruised to victory with 56 percent of the vote.
Because he is known for his political nimbleness, Mr. Hunt has mystified political analysts in the state by waiting nearly four months before taking action to restore public confidence in the Department of Transportation and its policy board.
But he suggested today that the Board of Transportation, which is by far the largest of its kind in the country, should be smaller, and that politicians and their appointees should not be able to promote road projects through back-channel lobbying and discretionary funding.
Last week, The Charlotte Observer reported that Mr. Hunt's intervention helped persuade the Department of Transportation to approve the replacement of a bridge over the Buckhorn Reservoir, an infrequently used crossing about four miles from his farm that was slated for closure. The $7.7 million project was approved despite an opinion from department engineers that it could not be justified on economic grounds. Six hundred cars crossed the bridge daily, and without it there is a two-and-a-half-mile detour.
Mr. Hunt originally defended his support for the project, saying he had spoken to Mr. Goode on behalf of neighbors who would be cut off from their community without the bridge. But several days later, he ordered the department to put a hold on the project, and today he said that his involvement had been improper. "I understand now that wasn't the way to do it," he said.
The reports about the bridge followed the revelations about Mr. Cartrette's letters, which were first reported by The Star-News of Wilmington. In a letter to Jim Bennett, Mr. Hunt's 1996 campaign finance director, Mr. Cartrette said he had spoken with the Governor about an appointment to the Board of Transportation. Mr. Cartrette quoted Mr. Hunt as responding, "If you will send the money, I will look out for my friends, and you are my friend."
Mr. Hunt said that any suggestion of a quid pro quo appointment was "totally untrue."
But research by Democracy South, an advocacy group that studies the role of money in North Carolina politics, found a strong link between political fund raising and appointments to the Board of Transportation.
The 34 board members who have been appointed by Mr. Hunt since 1993 contributed more than $2 million to state and national campaigns, said Bob Hall, research director of Democracy South. Mr. Hunt, the largest beneficiary, received a total of $652,428 from those donors for his 1992 and 1996 campaigns, Mr. Hall said. Board members appointed by Mr. Hunt have included the fund-raising chairman of his 1996 campaign, a treasurer of the state Democratic Party and the chairmen or finance chairmen of at least 15 county campaign committees. Mr. Garrett, the deposed Transportation Secretary, also was a Hunt fund-raiser.
Several board members have been accused of using their positions to influence road projects that benefited their businesses.
One of them, Carroll Edwards, resigned in October after it was revealed that the state had paved a dirt road leading to his wood products plant, had widened and resurfaced a second road leading there and had agreed to build a third road, which was to provide a shortcut for trucks traveling to the plant.
A month later, a second board member, Odell Williamson, resigned after The News and Observer of Raleigh reported that he had backed construction of a bridge and road-widening projects that would enhance the value of properties owned by him and his family.
Another board member, Charles Grady, pleaded guilty to conflict of interest last year because he used his position on the board to push a land sale to the Department of Transportation that earned his real estate firm a $45,000 commission.

HEADLINE: Blocking Money for U.N. Harms U.S. in Iraq Crisis, Albright Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
As a new crisis built with Iraq, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright sharply accused Congress today of undermining American foreign policy during a tense situation with Iraq late last year by failing to pay American debts to the United Nations.
She criticized "legislative blackmail" on the part of lawmakers, who she said created "a truly ridiculous" impasse that hurt the American people. 
 "The failure to pay our U.N. debts undermines our leverage just as Saddam Hussein was challenging the authority of the Security Council, and it damaged our credibility just as the General Assembly was voting on a plan that could have reduced by roughly $100 million a year the amount we are assessed by the U.N. system," Ms. Albright said in a speech here.
It was a very pointed attack by the Secretary, who began her tenure about a year ago by pledging to work with Congress to advance American foreign policy. She spent much time wooing the conservative Republican chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Jesse Helms of North Carolina. She negotiated the United Nations package, which included many reforms, with Mr. Helms's committee.
But the impasse was caused largely by House members who blocked the money for the United Nations, as well as associated money for the International Monetary Fund, over American participation in international family planning programs.
These members, led by Representative Christopher H. Smith, a Republican of New Jersey, are deeply opposed to abortion and want to stop any "U.S. subsidies to foreign organizations that perform or promote abortions," Mr. Smith said in a statement today. American financing for any foreign organization that performs abortions is already banned.
Representative Smith, traveling in Russia, rejected Ms. Albright's criticism. "I have too much respect for Secretary Albright to believe that she seriously intended to suggest," he said, that if the United States had resolved its dispute with the United Nations over arrears, "Saddam would have let our inspectors look at his chemical and biological weapons."
"This is about as reasonable as blaming Congress for El Nino," the Congressman said.
The United Nations debt has been "around for years," he continued, and "has never prevented the United States from protecting its vital national security interests" or forming an international coalition to fight the Persian Gulf war.
Members of Senator Helms's staff said the family planning issue remained an important obstacle to providing money for the United Nations and the International Monetary Fund, even as Washington is relying on the fund to manage the sweeping Asian economic crisis.
Ms. Albright, in a speech to the Center for National Policy, an organization she used to head, appealed to lawmakers to be more responsible this year, urging them to support the Clinton Administration on NATO expansion, Bosnia and new, targeted aid to Africa.
The Czech-born Ms. Albright said the prospect of NATO expansion had already produced a trend toward peaceful reconciliaton of ancient ethnic and national conflicts in Central and Eastern Europe. "The currents of history are shifting in directions that will make us all more secure," she said.
Ms. Albright used the speech to summarize her first year as Secretary of State, a year, she said, in which "I was included on a national magazine's list of the 25 most intriguing people alongside a cloned sheep." She threw out the first ball of the season for the Baltimore Orioles and sang to Asian diplomats last summer in Malaysia as the first signs of the economic crisis there emerged.

HEADLINE: Whitman's Education Focus: Bid to Carve Out Legacy

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
No longer worried about losing her job, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman offered a series of modest proposals today that may not be politically popular but that could ease the property tax burden and improve public schools.
Mrs. Whitman devoted much of her speech to education, saying she wanted to reduce spending on public schools, which receive the bulk of local tax revenues, but also strengthen educational programs. 
 While some of her ideas -- extending the school day, for example -- won immediate praise, legislative leaders were careful not to embrace three of her most contentious proposals: eliminating tenure for principals, merging school districts and letting students choose which public school they attend.
Almost immediately after she narrowly won re-election last November, Mrs. Whitman said she wanted to be remembered as a governor who improved educational opportunities for children statewide. Her speech today was an attempt to start carving out such a legacy, with proposals that had the potential not only to change education policy but also to reduce the cost of education significantly.
At a time when education reform is the subject of widespread attention, the proposals could also shore up Mrs. Whitman's national reputation, which suffered when she almost lost to her Democratic opponent last fall. But the two most powerful legislative leaders, who are considered to be the leading Republican candidates in the next gubernatorial race, suggested they might make things difficult for the Governor.
The proposals on tenure and school regionalization are sure to anger New Jersey's powerful teachers' unions and suburban voters, whose support is crucial to gubernatorial and legislative candidates. Both Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate President, and Jack Collins, the Assembly Speaker, said they were against merging school districts unless residents agreed to it.
"I think it would be disastrous to try and mandate that," said Mr. DiFrancesco, who was reserved in his applause during the speech and did not clap when Mrs. Whitman proposed allowing school choice and eliminating tenure. "I think she needs to provide incentives, work slowly and take one step at a time."
Mr. DiFrancesco reminded reporters and fellow legislators that he, too, had an agenda, giving a speech of his own in the Senate chambers several hours before the Governor's address. He touched on education but spent far more time announcing plans to preserve open space and improve the state's public transportation system. Mrs. Whitman did not mention either subject in her speech.
"I thought those were areas she wouldn't talk about," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "So I needed to make it a high priority."
One educational issue that was missing from Mrs. Whitman's speech was a recent order by the New Jersey Supreme Court to end disparities between the state's richest and poorest school districts. The court ordered the Governor last spring to send $248 million more to 28 urban school districts and to provide more programs to help urban students overcome disadvantages.
Mrs. Whitman submitted a list of potential programs last fall, and a Superior Court judge will decide by next week whether they are acceptable. If they are not, the Supreme Court could force the state to send millions of additional dollars to the urban districts this year.
A spokesman for the Governor, Pete McDonough, said it would have been inappropriate for her to discuss the programs in advance of the judge's decision.
But Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge, Mrs. Whitman's Democratic opponent last fall, said she should have discussed school financing because it was the most important educational issue in New Jersey. "The Governor's absolute silence on the educational funding question relegates the entirety of the question to the courts," he said.
But by avoiding the issue of school financing and focusing on new proposals instead, Mrs. Whitman was perhaps trying to make a fresh start in the area of education.
During her first term, her most significant education policies came in response to orders from the Supreme Court to improve the quality of educational programs in urban schools. Her proposals today could affect all 600 school districts and 1.2 million schoolchildren in the state, which could indeed give Mrs. Whitman a reputation as an "education governor."
"She's talking about things in education that have not been talked about before," said Frank Belluscio, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, which has long called for eliminating tenure for principals. "It's a good start in making a real impact."
But Democratic leaders said that while the ideas behind Mrs. Whitman's education proposals were bold, the proposals themselves were not bold enough. She left too much up to legislators, many of whom will be up for re-election in 1999 and therefore too skittish to take on issues like regionalization of school districts and elimination of principal tenure, they said. "It was a lateral pass to the Legislature," Mr. McGreevey said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Korea Steadies Itself on the Road to Recovery

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Jan. 14

 BODY:
What stock market around the world has performed the best so far in 1998?
Remarkably enough, the answer is the South Korean market, which rose 2.37 percent earlier today for a total leap of 26.55 percent so far this year. This buoyancy, however precarious and tentative, underscores a rare bit of good news from Asia these days: After a near-death experience last month, South Korea may have stabilized for the moment. 
 Many investors, diplomats and government officials are far more cheery about the nation's prospects than they were just a couple of weeks ago. While the shift may prove fickle, it is striking.
"Soon, South Korea will be again on an ascending trend," Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said at a news conference here on Tuesday at the end of a two-day visit. Referring to an improvement in the balance of payments and some other economic indicators, Mr. Camdessus added, "All of that signals a beginning of recovery."
Tremendous challenges lie ahead, and recovery -- even under the best of circumstances -- will involve a surge of unemployment, bankruptcies and labor unrest. Nonetheless, South Korea is now viewed more positively than almost anybody expected a couple of weeks ago, partly because President-elect Kim Dae Jung has seemed far more serious about revamping the economy than many people had thought possible.
The I.M.F. strategy could use a success story because most of the news out of Asia has been bleak. Moreover, good tidings from South Korea, if they are sustained, are particularly important. South Korea's economy is far bigger than those of Indonesia and Thailand combined, and it is much more integrated than the others with the global economy and the business world of Tokyo and New York.
It is not that the worst is over, for most of the pain of unemployment is yet to come, but rather that it is now possible to see a path that the nation can follow to escape the crisis.
"In contrast to a month ago, when there was so much tension and so much stress that it was difficult to see the way out, now I think more and more people can see that there is an end to this," said Stephen Bosworth, the American ambassador to South Korea. But he added that there would be many trials ahead and that the sting of unemployment would get worse.
Mr. Camdessus echoed the warning. "You shouldn't cry victory prematurely," he said. "You have won the first battle. You have not won the war."
Investor confidence in South Korea has improved in part because the nation has appeared far more committed carrying out the terms of the I.M.F. bailout package than many analysts had predicted. Many investors had worried that Mr. Kim , a populist with close ties to labor unions, would shy away from any moves that would result in layoffs and deep economic pain.
In fact, Mr. Kim has used his political leverage aggressively to carry out the I.M.F. package and to make it easier for companies to lay off unneeded workers. He has also put pressure on large companies to mend their ways, and on Tuesday he reached an agreement with heads of the nation's conglomerates that will lead them to pay more attention to the market and to adopt more modern accounting methods.
Most striking, Mr. Kim is no longer criticizing the terms of the I.M.F. bailout, as he did during his campaign for president, but is praising the agreement as the best way to reinvigorate the national economy.
"This is a blessing in disguise," Mr. Kim said in a talk with his aides this month. "The reforms that the I.M.F. requests are things we should have done long ago."
The rise in the stock market in South Korea -- it has risen 11 of the last 12 trading sessions -- reflects in part its tumbles late last year. But the rise is still surprising because it bucks the trend that since Jan. 1 has sent stock indexes tumbling 18.82 percent in Singapore, even as stocks jumped 7.39 percent earlier today; 13.80 percent in Hong Kong, where stocks rose 6 percent, and 2.62 percent in Indonesia, where stocks were 2.37 percent higher. The Dow Jones index has also fallen, by 2 percent.
In dollar terms, the Singapore market has fallen 22.66 percent this year; the Hong Kong market is down 13.75 percent, and Indonesia has declined 35.08 percent. Because the South Korean currency, the won, is worth less than half what it was a year ago, the South Korean market has risen only 14.91 percent in terms of the dollar.
But the won appears to have stabilized for the moment, and the cheap currency has helped turn around the nation's trade accounts, creating surpluses in the last couple of months. That has helped bolster confidence.
South Korea's foreign debt remains a critical uncertainty, but the sense of crisis seems to have eased slightly. Western banks seem mostly prepared to give South Korea until the end of March to work out a resolution of the problem, and several possibilities are under discussion that would repackage the short-term loans owed by South Korean banks and turn them into longer-term debt at a higher interest rate.
"The imminent fear of default has disappeared," said Ben Q. Limb, a lawyer from New York who is an adviser to Mr. Kim.

HEADLINE: Better Rules for Bailouts

 BODY:
Top officials of the International Monetary Fund rushed off to Indonesia this week to stanch an economic hemorrhage that the fund now concedes it worsened itself. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers, representing a worried Clinton Administration, followed close behind. Americans are understandably wondering whether the fund can be trusted to put together these kinds of bailouts and whether taxpayer dollars ought to be turned over to the fund so that it can indirectly repay Western banks that made foolish loans.
The truth is that the monetary fund is the only organization that can organize an international response to financial crisis. Left alone, currency crises can bounce from one country to another, leading to needless turmoil and economic contraction. If the fund stepped aside, the United States might have tried to prop up South Korea on its own, hardly an enviable prospect. 
 The existence of financial turmoil in Asia is not surprising. Every region suffers some economic turbulence, including the United States in the 1980's. What is surprising is the speed with which some of the world's fastest-growing economies disintegrated. Recent events prove that the prosperity in Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea was built in part around a core of financial rot.
Asian corporations ran on large amounts of loans, which can flee when business turns down. In the West, corporations rely more on shareholder equity, which does not so easily evaporate. Worse, bankrupt corporations were propped up by loans from banks responsive to political leaders, as in the case of Indonesia, or beholden to corporate conglomerates, as in Korea. Corporate failures in Thailand triggered a currency devaluation, spreading Thailand's turmoil to Korea and other trading partners. Once investors grew fearful that Korea's banks would default, they fled and left corporations starved for the loans they needed to survive.
The monetary fund has correctly focused on excising the rot. Its bailout conditions require Korea, Indonesia and Thailand to clean up their banks and, more important, to adopt rigorous accounting and auditing systems that give investors an accurate appraisal of financial health. The fund would also put a stop to crony capitalism, the practice of making loans for political purposes.
Indonesia added to its problems by stalling on the fund-imposed reforms. But the fund erred too, as critics charged and the fund's internal report now admits, by precipitously closing 16 banks, a rash action that alarmed investors. It also cracked down too hard on the fragile Korean and Indonesian economies by requiring them to tighten fiscal and monetary policies, the opposite of what was needed in economies sinking into recession.
There may be ways to prevent, or at least better predict, future crises. The more than 180 countries that are members of the monetary fund should agree, for example, to disclose the true state of their financial institutions according to the open and exacting standards common in the West.
But it is also important that the fund itself be more open. Though it plays a powerful role in Latin America, Asia, Africa and nearly everywhere else, its policy prescriptions and analytical assessments remain largely secret. Had it initially disclosed more about its approach to Korea and Indonesia, some mistakes might have been avoided or identified more quickly. That could have spared millions of innocent workers throughout Asia needless pain.

HEADLINE: Baghdad's Hall of Mirrors

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
After all the drama of last November, the Clinton Administration finds itself back where it started with Iraq: in another annoying and potentially explosive confrontation with Saddam Hussein over United Nations weapons inspectors.
It is the same dispute as last time, when all the permanent members of the Security Council agreed that Mr. Hussein could not dictate the makeup of the weapons-inspection teams. 
 "It does simplify things," a senior White House official said.
But since that last crisis, Iraq has at least succeeded in shifting the debate among the Security Council members toward when and whether to offer Baghdad some "light at the end of the tunnel" of sanctions. And it has so far succeeded in keeping the arms inspectors out of sites it has ruled off limits.
Mr. Hussein backed down last time, allowing the inspectors to return to Iraq and withdrawing his objection to American participation in inspections teams, and officials suspect that he will do the same now. But he had agreed only after the Russians, acting on behalf of the Security Council, convinced him that Moscow would work to ease the sanctions if Iraq complied.
For Mr. Hussein to renege on that agreement now only makes it harder for the Security Council to show Baghdad that "light," American and NATO officials said today, expressing puzzlement as to why Mr. Hussein had chosen to challenge them again on this same issue.
But the officials agreed that the main argument over Iraq is still to come, and it is not about composition of the inspection teams. It is about where the inspectors can go and how long they should pursue each category of banned weapons, and then about how long strict economic sanctions should remain on Baghdad.
And in that battle America's real negotiations, as usual, will be with the other permanent members of the Security Council, where Mr. Hussein is testing the endurance of the coalition against him.
As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright called British, French and Russian counterparts, an Administration official said, "The question is not whether the situation is different today, but whether the willingness of Saddam's erstwhile friends to stand up for their own resolution is going to fade over time."
The presumption among White House and State Department officials is that the French and Russians, who have been most critical of Washington's unbending policy toward Iraq, will stick with Washington, as Britain has always done, on the question of the makeup of the inspection teams.
The French Foreign Ministry issued a statement in Paris today "profoundly" regretting the Iraqi decision to obstruct the inspectors and reminding Iraq of its obligations to cooperate with the United Nations "fully, immediately, unconditionally and without restrictions."
And senior Administration officials said they expected the Security Council to issue a strong statement condemning Iraqi noncompliance in the next couple of days. They said there was general annoyance with Iraq in the Security Council, which only seems to undermine Iraq's longer-term aim of dividing the permanent members over the larger sanctions policy itself.
"We've had many crises," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman. "We've had many times in which Saddam Hussein has sought to dictate terms. And each and every time, he's backed down in the face of the united view of the British, the French, the United States, the Russians and other members of the Security Council. And on this issue, they are united."
But they are divided on other questions, like how to treat Mr. Hussein's claims of presidential immunity over numerous sites in Iraq and how to inspect "presidential palaces," if allowed to do so.
More important, the French and Russians explicitly say they want to give Mr. Hussein some sense of "light at the end of the tunnel" after nearly seven years of sanctions and to help ease the plight of ordinary Iraqis.
These are the harder issues for Washington to manage, and they will come up this month, too, as the Security Council debates Iraqi sanctions.
Last week in Paris, senior American and NATO officials said, Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering and French officials spoke about French ideas to give Mr. Hussein and the Iraqis some sense of progress.
The French are proposing that the United Nations "close the files" on Iraqi possession of missiles and nuclear weapons, and move on to so-called "long-term monitoring" by the United Nations, which is somewhat less intrusive. The French would keep the files open on Iraqi possession of biological and chemical weapons, about which much less is known and more Iraqi cheating has been discovered.
The French and Russians would also like to begin easing the strict economic sanctions on Iraq -- beyond allowing them to sell more of their oil for food, drugs and other nonlethal relief needs -- as an acknowledgment of progress on missiles and nuclear weapons.
The Americans are considering whether it makes sense to close a file or two, officials said. But Washington is not convinced that a period of confrontation with Iraq is a good time to do it. And Washington is adamantly opposed, the officials said, to any "gradualism" in easing sanctions in response.
"The French idea is to show the Iraqis that there's light at the end of the tunnel by checking off on a file," one official said. "But we insist on full compliance before any sanctions are lifted."
The chairman of the United Nations inspection effort, Richard Butler, is due to go to Iraq on Jan. 19, and return to report to the Security Council around Jan. 23. "A lot depends on what he finds and does," a senior official said. "What we choose to do is dependent on Saddam's degree of defiance."
While American spokesman refused to rule out a military attack on Iraq if necessary, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, repeated that "it is always better to act in concert with others when we can."
"The use of force is not ruled out," another senior Administration official said, adding that "an extremely unpopular use of force" would risk breaking up the sanctions effort.

HEADLINE: Whitman Restates Pledge On Taxes and Insurance

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman used her first major speech since her narrow re-election victory last fall to reassure New Jersey voters today that she would address their concerns over paying the country's highest property taxes and auto insurance rates.
In her annual address to the State Legislature, Mrs. Whitman set a March 30 deadline for passage of a bill that would reduce auto insurance rates, but she offered no specifics. On property taxes, she proposed requiring municipalities to win voter approval for tax increases above the rate of inflation. She also called for major changes in the Civil Service system, including giving cities and towns the option of abolishing Civil Service rules. 
 But she cautioned that New Jerseyans would have to consider giving up the state's cherished tradition of local control in exchange for lower property tax rates. She called for a statewide referendum for voters to determine whether they wanted New Jersey to consolidate and merge some of the state's 616 school districts to help reduce the biggest part of property tax bills: the cost of public schools.
"I have long opposed the forced regionalization of schools," Mrs. Whitman said. "Regionalization won't work if the people of New Jersey don't want it. So it's time to find out how New Jerseyans feel about it. We need to discuss whether we're willing to give up some degree of local control of our school districts for significantly lower property taxes."
She also urged that parents and taxpayers get more for their money from public schools. The Governor proposed a pilot project that would allow parents to send their children to public schools outside their school districts. She called for the elimination of tenure for principals. She also suggested extending the amount of instructional time that the state requires from four to six hours a day.
Mrs. Whitman's 34-minute address outlining her legislative priorities for the year is the first of three major policy speeches that she is to deliver in the coming weeks. She is expected to offer her vision for a second term during her inauguration ceremony next week and her spending priorities for the year when she unveils her proposed budget next month.
She drew the loudest applause from the hundreds of supporters and politicians who packed the ornate chambers of the General Assembly when she referred to the court battle with New York State over Ellis Island. She said that New Jersey has been shaping the future of the country since its earliest days, at "the entrance to America, Ellis Island, New Jersey."
There were also loud cheers when she reiterated her commitment to bringing down the cost of auto insurance and property taxes. Mrs. Whitman nearly lost her re-election bid to James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, last fall because voters said they did not think that she had done enough in her first term to address both problems. A turning point in the campaign came in the final days, when she appeared on television and told viewers that she heard their complaints, and she promised to do something about both problems, if re-elected.
But Democrats, including Mr. McGreevey, said her proposals did not go far enough.
"On auto insurance, she tossed the issue into the laps of the State Legislature," Mr. McGreevey said. "And on property taxes, the Governor basically did not recognize any responsibility and said she will allow voters to vote when the property tax levy exceeds a certain limit. It doesn't address the issue."
He said Mrs. Whitman should have considered providing more state money for school districts to help reduce the property tax burden.
Just hours before Mrs. Whitman's speech, the newly elected and re-elected members of the State Legislature were sworn into office.
Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, the two Republican legislative leaders, offered broad praise for the Governor's speech, but they showed little enthusiasm for some of her proposals, such as merging school districts.
Both Mr. Collins and Mr. DiFrancesco are considering running for governor when Mrs. Whitman's second and final term expires, and the politics of the next gubernatorial contest are already under way. The indications are that Mrs. Whitman, who received strong support from Republican lawmakers for much of her agenda in her first term, might have to work harder to win their votes in her second term.
"I know how people feel about their local school districts," said Mr. DiFrancesco, a Republican from Scotch Plains. "I know how my district feels about their home rule and their ability to have some influence in a district. People won't react favorably to that. Is it worth talking about? She said yes." He said he thought that forcing school districts to merge would be disastrous.
Instead of focusing on a single issue in her annual address to the Legislature today, as she did last year with auto insurance, Mrs. Whitman chose to offer lawmakers a grab bag of bold and contentious proposals. As a result, some plans could face a difficult time in the Republican-controlled Legislature, particularly those that involve changing the Civil Service system. Public employee unions have already said they would fight.
On Civil Service, Governor Whitman said job performance, not seniority, should determine which public employees keep their jobs when layoffs are made, and that local public employees should not be able to accumulate unused sick time. She said that compensation should be determined by merit, not seniority.
John Loos, chief lobbyist for the Communication Workers of America, expressed concern about the Governor's Civil Service proposals, saying that the elimination of seniority and other provisions opens the door for "patronage and cronyism" in state and local government.
"Our members will fight very hard to preserve the seniority system in Civil Service," he said.
William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, praised the Governor for trying to change Civil Service. "It is almost impossible for mayors and elected officials to hire the person most qualified for the job," Mr. Dressel said.
Mr. Dressel said he wanted to hear more about what the Governor might say about property taxes before taking a position on whether property tax increase should be subject to voter approval.
Since the turn of the century, school budgets have been subject to voter approval in New Jersey. School spending represents about two-thirds of most property tax bills.
State law limits the amount municipalities and county governments may increase spending in a year. The state sets the limit, after determining the cost of goods and services local governments use. This year, the limit on the increase is 2.5 percent.
But the state does not limit the amount of property taxes cities and towns may raise. The Governor's plan would require municipalities to put budgets up for voter approval when the property tax rate increase exceeds the rate of inflation. For the last four years, the average property tax rate increase was 4 percent.
Democrats criticized Mrs. Whitman's plan, saying that she was "passing the buck to the people."
"We are elected to represent the people," said the Assembly minority leader, Joseph V. Doria. "The Governor was elected to be a leader, not a follower. The speech was basically one in which the Governor said let us talk to everybody and figure out what we are going to do and I will do what everybody says I should do."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MARKETS -- STOCKS;
Intel Earnings Push Stocks Up Sharply

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply yesterday in anticipation of strong fourth-quarter earnings from the Intel Corporation. Investors were hopeful that Intel's results would be a sign that Asian economic turmoil was not battering the nation's high-technology companies.
Although Intel did not report its earnings until after the markets had closed, the results from the world's leading maker of computer chips did prove better than expected. The Nasdaq market, where Intel and many other technology companies trade, rose 34.05 points, or 2.26 percent, to 1,541.63. 
 The eased concern about Asia's impact on high-technology stocks spilled over into other stocks as well. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 84.95, or 1.11 percent, to 7,732.13, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks advanced 12.91, or 1.37 percent, to 952.12. Intel shares rose 1 1/4, to 76 7/8.
"Intel was the key for the markets today," said Jonathan Joseph, an analyst for Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, "because its performance is the broadest and surest measure of the direction of the personal computer industry worldwide and it has a big Asian business."
The company received good news from Washington as well yesterday, when the Federal Trade Commission announced that at least for the time being it would not try to block the company's $420 million purchase of Chips and Technologies Inc., a leading producer of graphics chips.
An Intel rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., also reported its fourth-quarter results after the close of the markets yesterday. Its numbers somewhat surpassed Wall Street estimates, but the company still lost $12.3 million, or 9 cents a share, on revenues of $613.2 million, under heavy pressure trying to keep with Intel.
In the 1997 fourth quarter, Intel reported revenues of $6.51 billion, up from $6.44 billion in the fourth quarter a year earlier. Profits for the quarter were $1.74 billion, or $1.07 a share. That profit level was down from the 1996 fourth quarter, when the company earned $1.16 billion, or $1.06 a share.
The slippage compared with the quarter a year earlier was mainly a result of Intel's shifting production to a new generation of microchip, the Pentium II, which accounted for 25 percent of production at the end of last year and is expected to reach 50 percent of production by mid-1998. Until a new generation of chip reaches high-volume production, the transition is a slight drag on Intel's extraordinary levels of profitability.
Intel reported its results as "basic" earnings. Reported as fully diluted earnings, its profit would have been 98 cents a share, still above the Wall Street consensus estimate of 90 cents a share on a fully diluted basis. The estimate was from 32 analysts polled by the First Call Corporation, a research firm. It was even slightly above the so-called whisper number of 95 cents. Whisper numbers are the last-minute adjustments Wall Street analysts informally mention to clients and traders just before companies report results.
After Intel's earnings announcement and a conference call with the company's executives, Wall Street analysts viewed the results as undoubtedly positive but with a hint of caution about the future.
"It was a solid quarter, but not a blowout quarter," said David Wu, analyst for the ABN AMRO Chicago Corporation.
Some of the caution related to the uncertain outlook for business in Asia. Intel executives said the company's business in Asia had weakened because of the financial troubles in countries like South Korea, Indonesia and Malaysia. In the fourth quarter, business in its Asia-Pacific sales region fell to 17 percent of total sales, compared with 20 percent of sales a year earlier.
That regional falloff would have been even sharper were it not for record sales in the fast-emerging PC markets of China and India. "Thankfully, Asia-Pacific is a very broad region," said Paul S. Otellini, executive vice president for sales and marketing.
The Asian weakness, Mr. Otellini added, was offset by steady sales in North and South America and a strong rebound in European sales.
Because Intel's microchips serve as the electronic brain in 85 percent of the world's PC's, the company tends to have an early reading on the future demand for computers. Mr. Otellini was cautiously optimistic in his assessment yesterday. He noted a recent 1998 forecast by Dataquest, a market research firm, which predicted a 17 percent increase in the number of PC's shipped.
"I wouldn't argue with that number," Mr. Otellini said, while noting the "lack of visibility we have about what will happen in the Asia-Pacific region."
Intel also signaled its intention to push even more forcefully into the new market for PC's priced below $1,000. This market has been viewed as an opportunity for rival chip makers to possibly gain a strong position by undercutting Intel's prices.
But Mr. Otellini said Intel was "committed to serving the market for sub-$1,000 machines."
