HEADLINE: Albany Likely To Get Names Of People With H.I.V.

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
Leaders of New York's legislative health committees said yesterday that the state was likely to begin reporting people with H.I.V. to confidential registries of the State Health Department, and that the practice could be in place by the end of the year.
The legislative leaders said that the fact that the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's largest AIDS service agency, has reversed its position and is now calling for H.I.V. reporting has altered the terms of debate on the sensitive issue. 
 "It makes it easier to explore these things," said a Republican State Senator, Kemp Hannon of Garden City. "If people felt all the advocacy groups were against it, they may feel it would be futile to pursue it."
In an official statement to be released today, the Gay Men's Health Crisis, the most politically and economically connected group in the world of nonprofit AIDS service, calls for New York doctors to report H.I.V.-positive people to the state's Health Department, following the same practice used for infectious diseases like syphilis and tuberculosis. The organization's statement does not explicitly oppose the reporting of names, but instead it urges the state to consider using coded identification systems.
Every state requires doctors to report AIDS cases to public health officials. But officials in New York and many other states have refrained from the similar reporting of patients who are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, but do not have full-blown AIDS. Prominent advocacy groups, including the Gay Men's Health Crisis, have resisted those efforts in the past, arguing that requiring reports would deter people from being tested and treated early.
By reversing its position, the organization shattered a consensus among AIDS and civil rights groups against H.I.V. reporting. It said clinical advances and the need for more accurate information on H.I.V. infection demanded new approaches, and that the system of tracking people with AIDS was no longer an effective gauge of the epidemic's extent.
To move to a system of H.I.V. reporting in New York State would require either a regulatory change or legislation. But health observers said any administrative change of a Health Department regulation might invite an immediate lawsuit, so legislative action is more likely.
Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat, said recommendations due out in early March from the state's AIDS Advisory Council, which advises the Governor and the Legislature on AIDS policy, will be influential. Both he and Senator Hannon said they would press for an H.I.V.-reporting system that uses coded identification instead of the names of infected people.
The Assemblyman said he could envision legislation being introduced early this summer. "In the calendar year 1998, it could be up and running," Mr. Gottfried said.
But Assemblywoman Nettie Mayersohn, a Queens Democrat, said she would not be satisfied until the names of H.I.V.-positive people are reported to health officials. She already has introduced such a bill that would also seek to notify the partners of the infected persons.
Many advocates for people with AIDS are angered that the Gay Men's Health Crisis did not make an explicit statement against revealing names in H.I.V. reporting. They said it is particularly dismaying because the public appetite may be stronger for more coercive and intrusive measures, in light of incidents such as the Nushawn Williams case, the H.I.V.-positive man who is accused of infecting a trail of young women and girls in New York.
"Politically it has hurt us," said Jeffrey L. Reynolds, the policy director of the Long Island Association for AIDS Care and a co-chairman of the AIDS Advisory Council group now reviewing H.I.V. reporting.
"There are real world implications when the world's largest AIDS service organization comes out in tacit support of name reporting. It plays out in all different ways. It opens the door to divide and conquer. It gives the government an opportunity to do it their way. That doesn't reflect the concerns of the community."
Jeanne Bergman, a senior policy analyst with Housing Works, a service agency that finds housing for people living with AIDS in New York City, said she was outraged.
"That is an organization that has always been willing to compromise in order to serve its institutional interests," Ms. Bergman said. "The Federal funding agencies that support name reporting like the Centers for Disease Control, as well as funders in New York State and New York City will look very kindly on them for being very compliant with a relatively conservative agenda. And they will benefit financially in grant awards."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F. Now Admits Tactics in Indonesia Deepened the Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 13

 BODY:
A confidential report by the International Monetary Fund on Indonesia's economic crisis acknowledges that an important element of the I.M.F.'s rescue strategy backfired, causing a bank panic that helped set off financial market declines in much of Asia.
In minute detail, the report describes how political paralysis in Indonesia was compounded by misjudgment at the I.M.F.'s Washington headquarters as to how the Indonesian people would react to bank closings. 
 Instead of inspiring confidence, as hoped, the closings helped bring Indonesia's banking system to the brink of collapse, sending depositors fleeing even from relatively healthy financial institutions and hastening a plunge in an already battered currency.
The report, distributed to I.M.F. members last week, did not imply that the agency bore any responsibility for worsening Indonesia's crisis. It traced most of the blame to President Suharto's Government, which it castigated for failing to enact promised reforms in exchange for the $40 billion international rescue effort.
Mr. Suharto's resistance to the economic changes demanded by the I.M.F. resulted in warnings from the Clinton Administration and the lending agency last week that aid might be cut off. That, in turn, helped cause the nation's currency, the rupiah, to fall steeply and raised fears of political and social ferment in Indonesia, the fourth-most-populous nation.
That was one reason President Clinton dispatched a team of top officials to meet with Mr. Suharto earlier today, in hopes of stabilizing Indonesia's finances before the country's troubles spread further.
I.M.F. officials declined today to comment on the report, which came as the agency's Asian remedies are put under increased attack, particularly from political leaders throughout the region.
Newspapers and television programs are filled with accusations that the remedies prescribed by the I.M.F. -- tight budgets, bank closings, high interest rates -- are worsening the pain just when businesses need loans and Government funds to avoid mass unemployment and bankruptcies.
I.M.F. and Clinton Administration officials say publicly that the only way to truly clean up Asian economies is to dive into market reforms, however painful this may be in the short run. But the fund's report on Indonesia suggests just how hard it has been for governments and international organizations to turn that philosophy into specific policies and to apply them to the fast-moving Asia crisis.
The I.M.F.'s report -- formally the Indonesia Standby Agreement: Review Under the Emergency Financing Procedures -- describes a turning point in the country's financial deterioration in November, when officials here were forced by the lending agency to close 16 insolvent banks, including at least one controlled by a son of President Suharto. The I.M.F.'s economists thought that some bank closings would restore confidence in the rest of the country's banking system, by eliminating the bad apples.
Instead, the closings caused panic, the report acknowledged, in language that showed that the I.M.F. hardly expected consequences opposite those intended.
"These closures, however, far from improving public confidence in the banking system, have instead set off a renewed 'flight to safety,' " the report said.
Indonesians withdrew their money, taking $2 billion out of the banking system and shifting further funds from private banks that they feared would be the next ones ordered closed. Some of that money was transferred to state-owned banks -- institutions that many here believe guarantee greater safety.
By the end of November, the report said, two-thirds of all the country's banks "had experienced runs on their deposits."
The problem grew so critical, it added, that the Indonesian central bank had to pump money into the private banks "equivalent to about 5 percent of G.D.P. over the past two months," meaning Indonesia's gross domestic product, or output.
The harried effort to keep the banking system afloat undermined efforts to deal with Indonesia's other major financial problem, the plummeting value of its currency, the report said.
The main mechanism any government or central bank uses to defend a currency's value is to raise interest rates. But pumping more money into a banking system -- making the currency more plentiful -- is a form of interest-rate reduction. So the central bank quickly found itself torn between two contradictory goals, and swayed back and forth between them.
"This situation has led to an uneven monetary policy, in which the central bank has shifted its focus from one objective to another, depending on the one which seemed most pressing," the report said.
The requirements imposed on Indonesia by the I.M.F., including the closing of insolvent banks, were similar to those demanded of Thailand and South Korea, other Asian nations that have needed enormous international bailouts in recent months.
Neither of those two seems to have experienced a bank run of the magnitude of Indonesia's. Still, these countries' financial markets have remained volatile; their currencies seem vulnerable to further declines, and few economists or politicians will venture a guess as to when the crises in those countries might pass.
This is not the first time an I.M.F. order to close banks resulted in panic. When some banks were closed early in the Mexican crisis in 1995, depositors reacted by hastily withdrawing money.
Banking officials who went through the Mexican experience say there is always a risk that when regulators close one group of banks, the public will conclude that they are making a broader statement about the health of the entire system. Less experienced regulators -- like Indonesia's -- can frequently compound this problem by failing to make their intentions clear, and by failing to separate troubled banks from healthier ones.
In this case, one of the banks shut down, which was owned by a son of Mr. Suharto, reopened under a different name a few days later after the son challenged the Indonesian Finance Ministry's right to close his bank at all.
While the I.M.F.'s acknowledgment that the bank closings went awry is sure to provide new ammunition to critics of its austerity-driven approach, that miscalculation was only one element of a report that chiefly finds Mr. Suharto's Government responsible for the worsening crisis by failing to take required economic reforms seriously.
In language far more direct than officials have used in their meetings over the last two days with the 76-year-old leader, the I.M.F. concluded that within days of the signing of the $40 billion accord, "economic reforms seemed to disappear from the Government's agenda."
President Suharto reconfirmed his commitment to the I.M.F.'s prescriptions today in a meeting at his residence with the American Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, Lawrence H. Summers. But the terms are clearly being revised, and changes are expected to be announced on Thursday when the I.M.F.'s Director General, Michel Camdessus, is expected here.

HEADLINE: For Many Americans, Nothing but Blue Skies

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Lashed by freezing rain and pummeled by wicked gales roaring off Lake Michigan, Henry Hoornweg trudged doggedly toward the rattling El train in the city's Loop, entitled to feel a bit miserable.
Instead, his eyes were dancing. 
 "These are wonderful times," said Mr. Hoornweg, a 51-year-old legal secretary, exulting over an American decade that might be called The Good News 90's: anticipated Government budget surpluses, falling crime, galactic stock prices, low unemployment and puny interest rates.
To people like Mr. Hoornweg and his wife, a nurse, the national economic numbers translate into real personal gain: "We're buying a house for the first time -- four bedrooms, three bathrooms, out in the suburbs," said Mr. Hoornweg, standing at the el platform one recent evening. "When working folk like us can live like that, it says something."
To be sure, not everyone is riding the A train to Blissville. On the street below the el platform, a homeless man without a coat begs for money as he shivers. In burned-out, dispirited urban pockets unknown to most prosperous Americans, sirens still wail and gunshots ring. Many blue-collar workers feel threatened by a market that smiles on companies that cut wages and workers. And while experts warn that the good times will not last forever, on balance, Americans see an economy that is humming, judging from dozens of interviews, from San Francisco to Boston, from South Dakota to New York, and here in this straight-talking capital of the industrial and agricultural heartland.
Looking for a new job recently, Jennifer Thomas, a 26-year-old Chicago office worker, needed less than a month to find a better position, and promises of advancement, a triumph for a woman without a college degree and a background that was scarcely affluent.
"I felt pretty dismal in high school, assuming that I would be stuck in the same lower-middle-class life I grew up in -- and that the only way out was to get married young and depend on a man," said Ms. Thomas, who is single and not eager to settle down. "But now, there are so many opportunities out there. It's especially great for independent women."
Ms. Thomas said she was making enough money to lead a life she once thought out of reach: an apartment of her own, and enough spare income to travel a bit and dine at places like the trendy Clark Street Bistro.
"Today," she said, "I was calling around for tickets to 'Rent,' " a play that charges up to $67 a seat, "and tonight I'm going shopping."
Views about the general economy tended to follow the same trajectory as personal economic circumstances. Not surprisingly, people who had found new jobs, bought big houses and earned big raises saw nothing but blue skies from now on. But those struggling mightily to survive saw little relevance in the Government statistics, other than a familiar pattern of the rich getting richer.
 Edna Juette, for one, a 52-year-old personnel department clerk, weary after a hard day's work, said she had noticed little improvement in her life as she headed home to a Chicago west side neighborhood that is thick with gangs.
"My salary's not going up," she said, "but my rent is. They say crime is down. But there's still plenty of shooting in my neighborhood. And gangs, they're everywhere."
When it comes to Government surpluses, people are predictably split about what to do with the extra money: cut taxes, promote more social programs or reduce the $5 trillion national debt. In true American spirit, of course, some people say they would like to do all three.
But if liberals and conservatives, and those in between, agree on anything, it is a lack of faith in Washington to wisely use the windfall.
"They're already fighting over it like a bunch of hyenas," said Fred Kawas, 59, who runs a grocery store in the Mission District of San Francisco. "They'll find a way to spend it, and it'll probably be to bail out Indonesia or Korea or somebody."
President Clinton gets a 62 percent approval rating for his handling of the economy in most polls but many people interviewed in the past week said the credit for the prosperity goes in many directions, to Mr. Clinton and Alan Greenspan, the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to technological advances and to a growing sense of personal responsibility. Doin Cummings, a 26-year-old statistical analyst who grew up the son of a janitor in a rough-at-the-edges South Side Chicago neighborhood, said that the credit has to go to the people pulling the weight.
"I grew up lower-middle class, and now I guess I'm middle-middle class," said Mr. Cummings, who plans to marry a nurse soon and take a wedding trip to the Virgin Islands.
Ms. Thomas, the young woman who has tasted prosperity after growing up without much, agreed, saying, "Are the good times going to continue? For me, they will."
Whatever the state of the economy, many of those interviewed said there should be more to the nation's health than money.
In suburban Atlanta, Joan Rasputin said she could not see how life was getting any better, only more expensive. But more than that, she lamented, whatever the size of the nation's economy these days, its spirit seemed to have taken a beating.
"There are no heroes anymore, nobody to tell my children about," said Ms. Rasputin, an artist. "In sports, all we see is people who bite off somebody's ear or beat up their coach."
The nation's reputed moral decay comes up in almost any conversation about the future of the country. It is difficult to find anyone over age 30 who does not complain about a youth culture -- too many drugs, too many videos, too many possessions -- that they believe is morally slack.
But Marty Shanahan, a 47-year-old certified public accountant in Riverside, a Chicago suburb, said people who shudder at the private pecadilloes of politicians should look back to history. And he said that people his age could hardly throw any stones at the excesses of young people.
"I lived in the 60's and 70's," he said, with a sheepish wince. "I think the moral fiber today is better than it was then."
To Frank Schwerin, a 58-year-old Chicago lawyer, there is simply too much anxiety in American life, even among the prosperous, who seem to be chasing goals that appear unattainable.
"The average work month is something like 20 hours more than it was a generation ago," he said. "Everywhere you look, both parents are working, usually because they think they need to."
What has happened, Mr. Schwerin surmised, is that people now have more money than time, and that means more stress.
"There are more activities than ever, especially where kids are involved," he said. "It's just getting harder to keep up."
Renata Kocho, a 32-year-old bank teller who moved to Chicago from the former Soviet Union six years ago, said she, too, was struck by the "busy, busy, everybody busy" nature of life in this country. She questioned why Americans worry about money, when they seem, at least by comparison to the people of her home in the Republic of Georgia, to have so much.
She said she looks at Americans and often thinks: "You are healthy, handsome, you have jobs, nice houses, nice cars, money in the bank."
And then she paused, with a puzzled expression. "So why are you all taking depression pills?"
But to other Americans, the emergence of antidepressants is simply one more indication of a nation conquering its problems, a belief that life is good.
Even Mr. Schwerin, the lawyer who voiced concerns about the focus on economic prosperity, noted that if affluence did not mean nirvana, it certainly was better than a stick in the eye.
"Money may not buy happiness," he said. "But lack of money buys a lot of unhappiness."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

I.M.F. Acknowledges Misjudgment in Indonesia
A confidential report by the International Monetary Fund concedes that an important element of its rescue strategy for Indonesia backfired and helped cause a bank panic that contributed to other financial market declines in Asia.
Though the report cites failures by the Indonesian Government, it acknowledges a misjudgment over how the Indonesian public would react to bank closings. Page A1. 

Surprise: Comeback in Korea
After suffering a near-death experience in the waning weeks of 1997, the South Korean stock market has enjoyed a remarkable comeback so far in 1998, with a gain of nearly 24 percent. However precarious, the revival provides a rare bit of good news from Asia. D10.
 
Federal regulators are collecting normally confidential information about individual American banks' loans to South Korea and are sharing it with large banks leading an effort to extend payments on the loans, according to commercial bankers. D10.
 
Thailand recorded the biggest current-account surplus in 20 years in the fourth quarter, reversing three years of trade deficits. D10.
 
Inflation Still Largely Dormant
Inflation remained tame as last year ended. The Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in December, matching analysts' expectations, and only 1.7 percent for all of 1997, the lowest rate since 1986. D2.
 
Treasury securities fell, despite the benign inflation news. The 30-year bond yield rose to 5.73 percent from 5.69. D12.
 
Jackson Begins Wall St. Drive
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and his Rainbow/PUSH Coalition have begun an effort to promote economic opportunities for minorities and women, both in finance and beyond. D4.
 
Cable Deregulation Delay Possible
Cable television customers are paying more for the service because there is no serious competition, the F.C.C. said. The agency's findings, which confirmed what many cable TV subscribers may have suspected, could result in a delay of the planned deregulation of the industry next year. D6.
 
ABC Keeps Football Rights
ABC retained the rights to "Monday Night Football," joining CBS and Fox in paying staggering sums to broadcast National Football League games. NBC now finds itself without N.F.L. broadcast rights. C1.
 
Madison Avenue is sending a message to the television networks that will broadcast N.F.L. games: If they think they are going to recoup the far higher payments they now face by sharply raising ad rates, fuhgeddaboudit. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D4.
 
Profit Rises at Ameritech
Ameritech said that its earnings rose 7 percent in the fourth quarter, in line with estimates, as demand for new phone lines lifted sales. D11.
 
Nasdaq to Offer New Trade System
Nasdaq intends to offer a high-technology trading system being backed by mutual funds and other professional investors, even though many Wall Street dealers are lukewarm about the system, in part because it could eat into their profits. Market Place. D11.
 
Work Force Cut at J. Crew
J. Crew, the retail and catalogue company, dismissed about 100 employees, or about 10 percent of its work force, as it struggles to meet profit expectations. D2.

HEADLINE: Iraq Bars Arms Inspectors Again, Saying American in Charge Is Spy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 13

 BODY:
Iraq carried out its threat today to block an arms inspection by an American-dominated team, instantly provoking calls for action in Washington and foreign capitals, and forcing the Security Council to look again for an effective way to condemn Baghdad without threatening force.
The Council, which was the focus of today's action, reacted with a unity born of despair that Iraq had thrown another crisis in the way of accounting for its weapons of mass destruction. But today no one was "making excuses for Iraq," said a diplomat who attended the meeting. 
 United States officials reiterated earlier warnings but did not suggest what the Security Council should do.
"It's completely unacceptable, and we would expect that the Security Council will take the issue up and issue an appropriate condemnation of the action on the part of the Iraqis," the Secretary of Defense, William Cohen, said.
In Washington, Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said, "I am not going to speculate on what fashion an appropriate response will take."
"It is always better to act in concert with others when we can," he added, "but there is never any reluctance to act alone if we must."
The Council is expected to issue a statement, possibly on Wednesday, after diplomats have had time to consult their Governments.
Mr. Cohen said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq "should not and is not in a position of being able to dictate who can conduct inspections," adding, "It's the equivalent of a parolee deciding who his parole officer is going to be."
Nevertheless, when William Scott Ritter Jr., a former Marine captain, set out for work in Iraq today, leading a team of about 33 inspectors from 12 nations, he was turned back, as the Iraqis said he would be because they are refusing once again to allow Americans to take part in weapons inspections. This morning an Iraqi newspaper called Mr. Ritter a "hyena." Usually Mr. Ritter, who served in the 1991 war against Iraq, is merely branded a spy.
In Baghdad today, Mr. Ritter noted that the inspection team included scientists and technicians with expertise in chemical and biological weapons as well as missiles. He would not say whether he had requested entry at what Iraq calls "sensitive" sites.
In Washington, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, discussed Iraq in a telephone conversation with the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, and planned to speak with Hubert Vedrine, the French Foreign Minister, American officials said.
In the past, France and Russia have urged the Council to ease the sanctions that have frozen the Iraqi economy for more than seven years. But both Russian and French representatives at the United Nations said today that there is no question of allowing Iraq to evade its responsibilities under the accord that set up a plan for eliminating Iraqi weapons.
In Moscow the Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Valery Nesterushkin, said Russia "was taking active steps to find a way out of the situation." In November Mr. Primakov persuaded the Iraqis to drop an earlier ban on American inspectors, apparently in return for Russia's best efforts at speeding up the inspections and tinkering with the United Nations Special Commission, which was created to disarm Iraq. The Russians were rebuffed.
The Russians did raise a number of questions today about the functioning of the investigations. After the Security Council meeting, Sergey Lavrov, the Russian representative, said his questions were about "arithmetic."
Bill Richardson, the United States representative, acknowledged late in the day that the Russians had raised questions. But earlier he had described the Council as "very, very united in viewing Iraq's actions as unacceptable."
Iraq was able to make some points during this standoff, however, among them that the commission has become heavily weighted with American and European experts, especially Britons.
To counter this trend, Richard Butler, the executive chairman of the commission, has taken commissioners from a variety of countries with him on visits to Baghdad. In December he was accompanied by commission members from Russia, France and Britain. On a trip next week he plans to take commissioners from China, Canada and Italy.
China has offered for the first time to send full-time arms experts to the commission. In the past the Chinese have refused, apparently because of the cost. The financial ability to lend experts to the commission, coupled with the reservoir of expertise needed, have largely created the situation in which Americans dominate inspection teams.
It has been evident for nearly a year that the Special Commission, first under Rolf Ekeus, a Swedish diplomat and disarmament expert, then under Mr. Butler, that the investigators were closing in on President Hussein's most closely guarded secrets. Repeated Iraqi claims that it had shown the inspectors everything were dismissed as unacceptable.
NBC News reported tonight, for example, that a prison the inspectors asked to see on Monday was thought to be the site of human tests of chemical and biological weapons. United Nations officials said tonight that they had long suspected that Iraq was testing such weapons on animals. They added that there was an outside chance that humans, too, had been used for testing, but said they had no specific information.
Against that background, Baghdad began its campaign to deepen splits in the Security Council about how to proceed if sanctions were ever to be lifted. At the same time, Iraq has continued to expand areas it declares off limits to inspection, a tactic that Russia, France and China have joined in condemning.
Mr. Butler, who briefed the Security Council today, was asked by reporters whether Mr. Ritter's team may have been getting too close to a significant discovery. "I know that the reasons Iraq gives for objecting to Ritter are false," he said. "Logically there must be some other reason."
Iraq has also stepped up a campaign to convince the world that its people are suffering unacceptably from the sanctions. American and British officials counter with charges that from 1991 to 1996 President Hussein refused to accept an offer to sell oil to buy food and medicines. The plan was finally adopted a year ago, but contracts have been delayed and deliveries of civilian goods have been slow.
This week Iraq expects to resume exporting oil after a delay while a new food-distribution plan was drawn up.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Academy Bets on the Borough

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
After 15 years of making and (mostly) winning courageous bets on artists at its Next Wave Festival, the always bold Brooklyn Academy of Music is entering an ambitious new phase, a next wave of the institution itself.
By almost any measure, the Brooklyn Academy is one of New York City's success stories. Back in 1967, when Harvey Lichtenstein became president and executive producer, there was talk of turning the elegant 135-year-old opera house into tennis courts. 
 Today its audiences, overwhelmingly from Manhattan, stream there to see and hear cutting-edge artists from around the world, and the academy has become a sparkling if idiosyncratic lure on the southern fringe of what had long been a deteriorating downtown Brooklyn.
Now the academy has taken on a new challenge, one calculated to connect it with its home borough and neighborhood in an unparalleled manner. The heavily subsidized institution famous for avant-garde programming and short seasons is plunging into a for-profit movie and restaurant business on a 14-hour-a-day, 7-day-a-week schedule. Further, it is buying nearby real estate to foster an arts-fueled night life that Bruce Rattner, the academy's chairman, predicts will become "the Left Bank of New York City."
Mr. Lichtenstein said: "We put an anchor in this area and helped save it from going down the drain. Now we're ready to help it build." The idea is to use infusions of city money and a little help from state agencies to accelerate the economic development of an area that for decades suffered decay.
The price tag is considerably less than the $180 million spent in Newark to build a new performing arts center as a magnet for urban development, but the effort is part of a national trend from Pittsburgh to Cleveland to Oakland, Calif.
Indeed, the expansion in Brooklyn directly emerged from a 1996 study by the Regional Plan Association on how to revitalize the downtown neighborhood, which was once home to dozens of theaters. The report urged steps to encourage a "vibrant 24-hour community with an exciting mix of activities." The path may be easier in Brooklyn than Newark in the sense that the immediate neighborhood is already bouncing back. But success is hardly guaranteed, not least because some nearby residents and business owners regard the academy as essentially an island of Manhattan elitism in a working-class, mostly black neighborhood, a place many visit only on round-trip charter buses from midtown.
The people who run the academy "need to understand that just because they're the big guys doesn't give them the right to walk all over other people," said Selma Jackson, co-owner of 4-W Circle, a gift shop in a nearby strip of Afrocentric boutiques and cafes.
The academy's first initiative, expected to be completed in September, is the reconstruction of major features of the opera house by Hardy Holzman, Pfeiffer Associates, the firm that renovated the academy's Majestic Theater and the New Victory Theater in Times Square. The opera house project, under way for more than a year, includes the conversion of the Carey Playhouse and Lepercq performance space into a cafe, a bookstore and a multi-screen theater showcasing independent films not regularly shown in Brooklyn.
The second, bolder venture is to reach out into the surrounding neighborhood to jump-start smaller arts organizations, restaurants and night clubs, in some cases by actually buying buildings and leasing them to others. The academy has revived a local development corporation that had been dormant for a decade.
 
Cultivating The Neighborhood
The city has put up $18 million for the academy's internal expansion, and the state is selling it a vacant building at 2 Lafayette Street, across from the opera house, at the low price of $185,000. The Mark Morris Dance Group, long one of the academy's most popular attractions, will make the building its permanent home, along with at least one restaurant, perhaps a branch of Sylvia's of Harlem or the New City Cafe in neighboring Fort Greene.
H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a strong backer of the academy's initiative, cautioned that success depended on the careful cultivation of neighborhood relations, among other factors. He pointed out that it took more than a decade for Lincoln Center to spark its neighborhood.
When Mr. Lichtenstein, now 68, came to Brooklyn three decades ago, after serving as an executive at the New York City Ballet, part of the opera house was rented to a martial-arts school, and there was talk of selling the building. Then came new artists, Next Wave and even a $15 million endowment. The academy's current operating budget is $17.2 million.
"Harvey never runs out of new ideas," Mr. Shostal said. "He is one of the most remarkable innovators in the arts and community arts. The institution has taken risks like nobody else in the city, but successful risks."
Mr. Lichtenstein said risk was necessary for the sort of institution he and a small cadre of dedicated aides have created. "We want to be five steps ahead of everybody else," he said. "That's our role."
Borough President Howard Golden saw the Brooklyn Academy as an initial entertainment lure for a wider area that could benefit from its 300,000 annual visitors. He appropriated $5 million, and the city followed with $13 million from its general coffers.
Mr. Rattner characterized the effort as the opposite of Newark's top-down approach of creating something from nothing through government fiat. He said the academy's new district was intended to "percolate up" as the result of numerous local initiatives. "In a way, it's kind of like Brooklyn," he said, a reference to the borough's reputation for scrappy independence.
The academy hopes to create a buzz, a sense that the corner of Brooklyn where the city tried and failed to persuade the fleeing Dodgers to move is now the place to be. "One thing leads to another," Mr. Lichtenstein said. "With Mark Morris, we'll have other arts organizations that want to move in."
Michael Ayoub, who operates two restaurants in Park Slope, Cucina and Mike and Tony's, about a half-mile from the academy, draws crowds from its events. Partly as a result, Mr. Ayoub was chosen as operator of Cafe BAM, which opened in October, quickly expanding to 200 seats from the initial 120. It has so far been open only during the Next Wave Festival.
Mr. Ayoub is planning to open yet another place. "This whole area is hotter than a pistol," he said. "I'm putting my money where my mouth is."
Other factors have contributed to what some call a Brooklyn renaissance: Metrotech, an office complex, opened a dozen blocks north six years ago, and Atlantic Center, a shopping mall five blocks to the south, opened in 1996. Both are projects of Mr. Rattner's company, Forest City Rattner. Downtown Brooklyn's first new major hotel in more than 60 years is scheduled to open this summer.
Education is another shot of energy to the area. Enrollment at Long Island University nearby on Flatbush Avenue has doubled to 9,000 in six years. Other Brooklyn institutions are also thriving only a few miles away, including St. Francis College, Pratt Institute and Brooklyn Polytechnic.
This is not the academy's first expansion. A decade ago, it took the shell of a once grand theater on Fulton Street, the Majestic, several blocks from the opera house and fashioned a darkly whimsical space that has become a major stage for the academy's eclectic theater productions. The activity at the Majestic has stimulated other developments, particularly at the neighboring Strand Theater, which is not part of the academy but houses several arts organizations, including Urban Glass, a glass-blowing studio. The Strand may soon become a production site for theater productions by Brooklyn groups.
Linking with the emerging strip of black businesses on nearby Fulton Street is a particular goal of Mr. Lichtenstein and other academy officials. Called by the merchants the Bogolan District, for the Mali word for mud cloth, the six-block district has boutiques, shops and cafes, including the Brooklyn Moon Cafe, which features art shows and poetry readings.
"What appears to be happening is that area is becoming an African SoHo," said Jonathan Rose, an academy board member who was one of the earlier developers of Atlantic Center until it was taken over by Mr. Rattner's company.
Not a few business owners in the Bogolan District see the academy as a big, impersonal entity that has little to do with them. They note that Sylvia's, which the academy is courting to move into the neighborhood, was the exclusive caterer at its concerts in Fort Greene Park last summer, not local restaurants, and that the academy held a reception to honor the poster of its Dance Africa series at a Manhattan gallery.
"There is no connection with businesses in the neighborhood," said Ms. Jackson, the gift shop owner.
 
Polarized Responses
Local focus groups convened for the academy have also underlined a potential racial divide. "The black audience was very, very vocal," said Socrates Nicholas of Nicholas Research Associates International Inc., which organized the focus groups. "They don't want to be left out and pushed out. The white audience said it's wonderful, because they won't have to go to Manhattan."
Mr. Lichtenstein and others respond that they plan film series of black directors and other programs with African-American themes and will particularly reach out to Spike Lee and other Brooklyn-based filmmakers. They also say they have greatly expanded their educational programs, serving predominantly minority children in the area.
And with the opening of the movie theater next fall, complete with Dolby sound and $8 tickets, anyone will be free to lounge in comfortable chairs in the informal part of the cafe, whether they buy anything or not.
At Cafe BAM recently, on the evening of a performance of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, the future looked bright. The cafe preserves the feeling of spaciousness in what was the Lepercq performance space, but now features huge vaulting red arches, each lined with silver-tipped light bulbs. Every seat was filled.
 
'It Took The First Week'
"I was astonished by how quickly people were there," said Hugh Hardy, who designed the cafe and cinema. "I thought it would take the first year, and it took the first week."
Next month, the cafe will hold its first culinary event, a Hungarian festival. George Lang, who owns Cafe des Artistes in Manhattan and the Grundl restaurant in Budapest, will present two Hungarian chefs using spices generally unavailable in the United States. Mr. Lang will create the menu.
The 850-seat movie complex is expected to be an even bigger draw when it opens next fall. Sales of 100,000 tickets are projected for the first year. George Wachtel, president of Audience Research and Analysis, said two-thirds of Brooklynites who now travel to Manhattan for independent films say they will switch to the new theater.
If all these projections come true, the academy may face an odd new challenge, maintaining its cutting-edge, nonconformist stance even as its empire swells.
"We're still on the outskirts," Mr. Lichtenstein insisted. "We're still the outsider." As for himself, Mr. Lichtenstein does not predict when he will retire. He says the current projects will take a year or two. "Then I'll see," he said. "It depends on how I feel my strength. I feel good now, and my energy's good."

From Ballet to Beckett: An Opera House Season
Here are some highlights of the spring season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Information: (718) 636-4100.
VAGANOVA BALLET ACADEMY -- of St. Petersburg, New York City debut, with principal dancers of the Kirov Ballet, Feb. 25-28.
MOSCOW ART THEATER, -- Chekhov's "Three Sisters," Feb. 6, 7 and 10-14.
LES ARTS FLORISSANTS, -- conducted by William Christie, in a concert version of Rameau's "Zoroastre," March 28-29.
CHEEK BY JOWL, -- "Much Ado About Nothing," March 25 to April 5.
ROYAL NATIONAL THEATER, -- "Othello," directed by Sam Mendes, starring David Harewood and Simon Russell Beale, April 8-11.
ROYAL SHAKESPEARE COMPANY, -- "Hamlet," directed by Matthew Warchus, starring Alex Jennings, May 21-30.
EDWARD PETHERBRIDGE, -- "Krapp's Last Tape," May 27-29.

HEADLINE: DuPont Prize for 'Frontline'

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
"Frontline," the public television documentary series produced by WGBH-TV in Boston, won the highest award, the Gold Baton, last night at the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards.
The series was among 12 winners chosen by a seven-member jury from 626 submissions of radio and television programs that were broadcast between July 1, 1996, and June 30, 1997. 
 "Frontline" was cited for remarkable quality and sustained commitment to controversial and sensitive stories, investigative reporting and political coverage as exemplified by four programs.
They included "Murder, Money and Mexico," an investigative report on the rise and fall of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and his brother Raul; "The Choice '96," a two-hour film portrait of the Presidential candidates Bob Dole and Bill Clinton; "Secret Daughter," a two-hour autobiographical film on racism by June Cross, and "Innocence Lost: The Plea," about charges of sexual abuse in a day care center in Edenton, N.C.
Of the 11 Silver Batons, one went to CBS News for "Enter the Jury Room," which showed jurors in the process of deliberation. Another went to WABC-TV, New York, for "Room 104: The Overcrowding Crisis," which focused on a first-grade classroom in Brooklyn.
ABC News won for "Prime Time Live: Debt Reckoning," a report on the Associates Corporation, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company that used manipulative practices to sell mortgage loans to unsophisticated borrowers. Another Silver Baton went to KCET, Los Angeles, and the BBC for the series "The Great War and the Shaping of the 20th Century," broadcast on PBS.
Also honored were Wisconsin Public Television for "Welcome to Poverty Hollow," which followed three families in an innovative anti-poverty effort that responded to the state's welfare reform; and the Center for New American Media for "Vote for Me: Politics in America," a PBS mini-series that focused on local campaigns and candidates. The PBS presentation of "An American Nile," about the Colorado River, won a Silver Baton for the filmmakers, Jon Else, Sandra Itkoff and Marc Reisner.
NBC News and Scripps Howard New Productions won for "Why Can't We Live Together?," an hourlong documentary that examined the self-fulfilling prophecies of race relations in Matteson, Ill., a Chicago suburb.
KTCA in St. Paul won for "News Night Minnesota: Unisys," a series of reports on the impact of downsizing on long-term employees of the Unisys Corporation.
Blowback Productions received a Silver Baton for "CIA: America's Secret Warriors," a three-hour series on the Discovery Channel that coincided with the 50th anniversary of the Central Intelligence Agency.
And KUSC Radio, in Los Angeles, was honored for "Marketplace," a half-hour nightly program on economic issues, broadcast on Public Radio International.
With Christiane Amanpour, the senior international correspondent for CNN, as host, the awards ceremony in the rotunda of Low Memorial Library at Columbia is to be broadcast nationwide today on PBS.
The awards were established in 1942 by Jessie Ball duPont in memory of her husband, Alfred I. duPont.

HEADLINE: $2.8 Million for Tiny Site Vital to Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Only after Reuters American Holdings and the Rudin Organization signed a deal last October to build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square did the two partners realize that the site for the project was not quite big enough.
The subsequent shortfall touched off a contretemps among those involved in the redevelopment of the square and lots of movement in the jigsaw puzzle that has become Times Square, according to those involved in the deal. 
 Reuters, the giant British media company, and the developer have now agreed to pay $2.8 million to buy the extra space it needs, a small four-story building and alleyway on West 43d Street that sits next to their site at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue.
The building, which is to be demolished, is owned by the New 42d Street, a nonprofit group established by the state to oversee six theaters in the area. The extra space will enable Reuters and Rudin to build the 855,000 square-foot tower they had originally planned.
The small white building on 43d Street currently serves as office space and a back entrance for the New Victory Theater on 42d Street. The Rudin Organization has agreed to provide the theater with office space and an entryway in the new tower, known as the Reuters Building.
The New 42d Street, in turn, plans to use the money to help pay for a new 10-story, $18.5 million building on the north side of 42d Street that will house rehearsal studios, workshop space, offices and a 199-seat theater.
The group's plans for the rehearsal space suffered an unexpected blow shortly before Christmas, when the terra cotta entrance to the Selwyn Theater, which was to have formed the entrance, collapsed along with a six-story building. New 42d is now redrawing its design.
Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, confirmed that the deal was in the works.
"This helps the New 42d serve the needs of Broadway," Mr. Millard said, "and it helps the Rudin-Reuters team develop a better site."
John J. Gilbert, chief operating officer of the Rudin Organization, declined to comment, as did Cora Cahan, president of the New 42d.
State and city officials are now remeasuring the site and the proposed building to be certain that Reuters and Rudin can legally build the tower. Complicating matters is the fact that measuring square-footage is more of an art than a science in New York City real estate, where landlords, tenants and city officials frequently use widely differing yardsticks.
The latest deal did not come without some hard bargaining.
The Rudin Organization and Reuters had been upset about the problem after buying the development site from the Prudential Insurance Company of America in a deal that the insurance company valued at $90 million. Reuters needed as much space as it could get for several 20-foot-high trading floors.
Not wanting to build a smaller, less lucrative tower, the developer asked Prudential to remedy the situation by transferring development rights from another nearby site controlled by the insurance company, according to executives close to the talks. Prudential balked, suggesting that the buyer got what he paid for.
In recent weeks, Rudin opened talks with the New 42d Street about buying the four-story building at the back of the New Victory Theater. In the early 1980's, the parcel had been part of the office development site now owned by Reuters and Rudin. But in 1988, the state pushed Prudential to give up the parcel so that the New Victory Theater would have a delivery entrance.
Now, the New 42d Street is selling the same parcel.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stability in Technology Stocks Seems to Bolster Markets

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
After months of drifting lower, technology stocks are beginning to show some signs of stability.
While many technology issues are still trading well below levels reached in October, there are indications that the selloff might have been overdone and that company profits could be surprisingly solid. 
 One early indication came from Intel, which reported strong fourth-quarter earnings after the market closed Tuesday, easing some fears that technology stocks would suffer enormously from the crisis in Asia.
More good news, which had been expected, came yesterday, when Apple Computer said after the market closed that it had posted its first quarterly profit in a year.
Yahoo Inc. -- an Internet search engine -- also reported a profit after the market closed, raising hopes that some companies selling products and services related to the World Wide Web might find a way to generate profits.
"The outlook for the industry remains extremely strong," said Alec Ellison, a managing director at Broadview Associates, a technology banker. "But the growth in certain segments has come down from extraordinary levels to simply strong levels."
That kind of sentiment has lifted an array of technology stocks this week, and perhaps even helped strengthen the broader market. Yesterday, the Nasdaq market, where many technology issues trade, rose 7.13 points, to 1,548.76. The Dow Jones industrial average rose for the third consecutive session, gaining 52.56 points, to 7,784.69.
Although concerns persist about fierce pricing competition at home in the computer business and slower growth in Asia, some analysts say the evidence emerging this week indicates things are more complicated than investors had thought.
"The positive factor is the Internet is growing strongly, and that's helping a lot of technology sales," said Mary Meeker, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "The negative factor is weakness in Asia, and that could impact other countries and have a rolling effect that could affect us."
Because of slowing growth in Asia, a number of Wall Street analysts have sharply cut earnings estimates, which has eroded the value of many technology stocks, including titans like Intel and Microsoft.
"Technology investors were expecting Asia to be a plus," said Frederick Taylor, chief investment officer at the U.S. Trust Company. "Instead of being a plus, it's at best a neutral and probably a negative."
Mr. Ellison at Broadview suggested that technology stock prices would vacillate because the industry was known for sudden growth spurts and slowdowns. "These are inherently volatile stocks because everyone is trying to figure out what their growth rates are," he said. "Intel is down 25 percent from its high, and yet its prospects are growing."
One big test might come next week, when Compaq Computer, I.B.M., Microsoft and Seagate Technology report earnings.
Among the bright spots are Internet companies, vying to make the Web into a profitable electronic playground. While a large majority of Internet companies continue to do poorly in the stock market, sinking far below their offering price years after going public, a few have seen spectacular gains.
Part of the reason is that a few companies are beginning to show signs of profitability. A few weeks ago, E-Trade, an on-line discount brokerage firm, posted a strong fourth-quarter profit. A number of other hot young Internet companies are showing improved prospects, including @Home, America Online and Amazon.com. Shares of those companies have soared in the last year.
 Keith Benjamin, a technology analyst at BancAmerica Robertson Stephens, said that Internet companies, unlike semiconductor equipment makers with operations overseas, were somewhat inoculated against the current slowdown in Asia.
"That's because the single-biggest driver of stock prices has been E-mail," he said. "And a majority of corporate America doesn't even have it yet."
Still, analysts insist that investors have become increasingly skeptical about some Internet products and services.
"The market has become viciously selective," said David Simons, a managing director at Digital Video Investments, a technology research firm in New York. "There's been this enormous tiering of the market."
That might be why fewer Internet companies went public in 1997. Twelve companies had initial public offerings in 1997, down from 22 in 1996, the Securities Data Company said.
Lise Buyer, an Internet analyst at the DMG Technology Group, said investors cared less about a prospective company's vision and more about its business model.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increased 0.7% in December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
Retailers rang up their biggest sales gain in half a year during December, helped by last-minute holiday shoppers as well as strong demand for cars, and analysts and retailers said consumers were likely to continue fueling economic growth early this year.
The Commerce Department said today that retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, meeting analysts' expectations and more than double November's revised increase of three-tenths of 1 percent. 
 "For shoppers, this is the best environment in more than a decade," said Ira Silver, chief economist at the J. C. Penney Company. "People will take advantage of that -- when they have money, Americans spend it."
The unemployment rate is low and incomes are rising. Moreover, said Christopher Low, an economist at HSBC Markets Inc., further consumer spending could be prompted by a spate of mortgage refinancings resulting from lower interest rates and by early income tax refunds.
"The conditions for consumer spending in the first quarter are phenomenal," he said.
During all of last year, retail sales rose 4.2 percent, slower than the 5.2 percent gain in 1996 and the worst showing since 1991. In part, analysts said, the slowdown reflected the fact that inflation was at its lowest rate in a decade, which kept the cost of goods low as the volume of sales rose. The Government report measures the amount spent, not volume.
Peter Kretzmer, an economist at the Nationsbank Corporation in New York, said the slowing sales growth also indicated that consumers were spending more on services and other goods that were not included in the retail sales report.
December's gain was led by sales of autos, furniture and apparel. Auto sales rose 2.3 percent as car makers continued to use rebates and low-cost financing plans to lure customers.
Excluding vehicles, December sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Sales of durable goods -- big-ticket items like autos, appliances and furniture -- rose 1.9 percent. Orders for nondurable goods, ranging from groceries to clothing, decreased one-tenth of 1 percent.
Sales at apparel stores rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, while those at department stores increased two-tenths of 1 percent.
Analysts said rising retail sales would not necessarily lead to higher prices because shoppers were buying discounted items and retailers were keeping prices low to compete with inexpensive imports from depressed Asian economies.
Last week, retail stores reported strong December sales, aided in large part by purchases made during a few days immediately before and after Christmas. The Goldman, Sachs & Company same-store sales index, which compares the results of stores open at least a year, showed a 4.4 percent gain in sales during December, up from only 2.9 percent in December 1996.
Because the wave of shopping came so late in the month, today's report may have understated the size of December's gain. The Government measures actual sales for the first half of the month but estimates sales for the second half.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Outbid on Pro Football, NBC Retains 'E.R.' in Record Pact

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 14

 BODY:
NBC agreed today to a deal to pay Warner Brothers, the studio that owns the drama "E.R.," about $13 million an episode over the next three years for a total of more than $850 million, making the medical series the most expensive television show ever.
The deal came a day after the National Football League concluded the richest television deal in history, a $17.6 billion deal with three networks, not including NBC. 
 Taken together the deals showed how the television networks, weakened by losses of viewers to cable channels, feel compelled to pay once- unheard of prices to retain the few programs that generate consistently large audiences. The NBC agreement comes close to tripling what the network had agreed to pay earlier this year for what turned out to be the last season of its hit comedy series "Seinfeld."
Many network executives said in interviews here that the crushing programming costs were likely to lead networks to increase their efforts to own or control every program they put on the air.
NBC announced it had concluded negotiations with Warner Brothers to hold onto television's most popular show without giving any financial details. But several executives on both sides of the negotiations said the price was $13 million an episode, a figure that exceeded even early predictions that it could go as high as $10 million.
The show features an attractive cast of young doctors and nurses working in a Chicago hospital emergency room. It is the most valuable property in television for numerous reasons, beginning with its high ratings and the attractive makeup of its audience, which includes a high percentage of the adults between the ages of 18 and 49 that most advertisers seek to reach.
The show has also proved to be television's best lead-in in decades to local news on affiliated stations, and it helped rebuild NBC's "Tonight" into television's dominant late-night franchise.
Don Ohlmeyer, the president of NBC's West Coast entertainment division, said NBC had factored all those things into its bid to retain "E.R.," although he added that NBC was confident "we won't lose money" on the deal, even without considering those ancillary benefits.
Still, the per-episode price of $13 million towers over anything previously paid for the rights to broadcast a television series.
Most series cost networks between $1 million and $1.5 million. "E.R" itself now costs about $2 million. This season NBC agreed to paid a then-record $5.5 million an episode for "Seinfeld."
But the star of that series, Jerry Seinfeld, announced last month that he was shutting down production on the comedy in May. That only increased the pressure on NBC to keep possession of its other ratings leader, "E.R."
Mr. Ohlmeyer acknowledged that the imminent loss of "Seinfeld" helped force more millions out of the NBC treasury.
"Obviously the loss of 'Seinfeld' increased the importance of making sure we kept 'E.R.,' " he said.
Robert Daly, the chairman of Warner Brothers Inc., agreed that the timing of Mr. Seinfeld's decision "certainly didn't hurt our negotiations."
Indeed, NBC acted rather swiftly to lock up "E.R." as its Thursday night anchor at 10 P.M., Eastern standard time, after it learned it would no longer have "Seinfeld" as its 9 P.M. centerpiece. Mr. Ohlmeyer said the "E.R." deal was "basically concluded" even before NBC entered the final phases of its National Football League negotiations, during which it lost the rights to the American Football Conference games, which it had held for more than 30 years.
NBC was long aware that its competitors had publicly stated their intention to bid for "E.R." and Mr. Daly acknowledged that while Warner Brothers could not negotiate with any other party, "Everybody talked to us."
NBC's exclusive negotiation period was not set to begin until February, but Mr. Daly said he received a call from Mr. Ohlmeyer soon after the holidays seeking to initiate the "E.R" discussions.
"The whole process only took four or five days," Mr. Daly said. "NBC made a very fair offer that we felt reflected the show's market value."
That market value is enormous. One senior executive from a competing network said NBC had made about $200 million a year in profit on the series.
Mr. Daly noted that NBC had reaped these enormous profits during the first four years of "E.R." when it held an exclusive contract for the show and did not have to increase the license fee it paid to Warner Brothers, which is a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc.
"It was time for that to change," Mr. Daly said.
Warner Brothers had actually made an effort to change the terms in the show's second year. Several current and former Warner Brothers executives said the studio had asked NBC, which is owned by General Electric, to increase the license fee to $4 million a year in exchange for a two-year extension on the initial four-year contract. When NBC declined, the executives said, Warner executives were upset and refused subsequent NBC efforts to extend the "E.R" deal before it reached the crisis point this year.
Mr. Ohlmeyer noted that Warner Brothers had sought to open up the "E.R" deal at the same time it was looking for better terms for its comedy "Friends."
"We accepted the proposal on 'Friends' and not on 'E.R'," Mr. Ohlmeyer said.
Mr. Daly said that Warner Brothers had preferred all along to keep the show at NBC, where it has thrived on Thursday night, and where Warner Brothers has placed several other shows including "Friends" and "Veronica's Closet."
"E.R." will remain on Thursday at 10 P.M. and will include all members of the current cast, at least for next season. After that, George Clooney is free to leave, but a Warner Brothers spokeswoman said the rest of the show's ensemble cast was under contract for two to four more years.
With "Seinfeld" which is also under the Warner Brothers banner, the studio controls four of the five shows now on NBC's powerhouse Thursday night lineup.
"We really have good relationships at NBC," Mr. Daly said. The studio already had commitments from NBC to put at least two other Warner Brothers shows on its schedule next fall.
One prominent Hollywood business executive said the most likely impact of the deal was heightened pressure on the networks to own everything they put on the air.
He added, "I think you might hear NBC executives say: 'We had to pay for "Frasier," for "Seinfeld" and we got it stuck to us by "E.R." Never again.' "
One outcome may be much longer initial deals for series, the executive said, or perpetual options to insure that a series could not be offered to an outside network.
Trying to put the scale of the "E.R." deal and the N.F.L. deals in context, one senior network executive said, "We're in a period of great desperation in television."
But Mr. Ohlmeyer argued that the "E.R" deal, big as it was, was chiefly a reflection of how the television economy has traditionally worked, with a studio waiting for an initial four-year license period with a network to run out so that it can seek huge increases for renewals of hit shows.
"If you look at the history of television," he said, "When you have an enormous hit the network benefits for the first four years it's on the air. After that, the studio takes advantage. There's no real difference here."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Retreat After Bouncing Around

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities fell slightly yesterday after bouncing around as investor attention shifted among a variety of factors, from the Asian turmoil to the United States stock market to the economy and inflation.
The 30-year bond fell 1/8, to 105 19/32, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, unchanged at 5.73 percent. 
 The stock market's weak opening surprised bond market participants, forcing those who had expected strength in stocks -- and thus, weakness in bonds -- to retreat from their bearish positions in the bond market, lifting prices.
Talk of foreign central banks buying Treasury securities with two- and three-year maturities gave the bond market support, as did some futures purchases by hedge funds.
The Government reported yesterday that retail sales in December were stronger than expected, rising seven-tenths of 1 percent, which might have been expected to cause fears of inflation, hurting the bond market.
But a number of economists said the underlying trend was really weaker than the number indicated after auto sales were excluded. As a result, the report had little impact.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said investors were still focusing on international news.
Worries about fallout from the Asian financial crisis have driven bond yields to their low levels. "We will probably stay within this range another two to three weeks," he said.
"If you look at day-to-day trading at this time, there are green lights in all directions for interest rates," Mr. Pugliese said.
"The bull market wish list has all the ingredients for low rates and higher prices and people are coming to the realization that rates are down to stay for the foreseeable future and likely to go lower."
The low interest rates are prompting municipal and corporate borrowers to come to market for new cash or refinancing of old debt to lower debt service payments.
Among the more notable deals this week were Tuesday's $650 million bond offering by New York City's Transitional Finance Authority through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company, and yesterday's $1.25 billion corporate financing by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation through Bear Stearns and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter.

HEADLINE: Environmentalists and Hearst Heirs Locked in Battle at San Simeon

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SAN SIMEON, Calif., Jan. 14

 BODY:
It spreads like a rolling green and brown blanket from the mountains to the sea, 77,000 acres of pristine ranch land crowned by the private castle of treasures that William Randolph Hearst called La Cuesta Encantada, his Enchanted Hill.
The house and grounds have been a state park since 1958 and now draw nearly a million visitors a year. But Hearst's heirs still own the bulk of this spectacular 15-mile stretch of the central California coastline, and their proposal to build a 650-room resort complex and a 27-hole golf course overlooking the ocean has sparked a colossal battle among environmentalists, ranchers, unions, pro-development groups and local officials over the future of land that has remained virtually unchanged since Spanish colonial days. 
 "It's probably the coastal issue of the 90's," said Peter Douglas, executive director of the state's powerful Coastal Commission.
The commission will hold an unusual daylong hearing on the plan, and perhaps a vote, in nearby San Luis Obispo on Thursday. Indeed, the Embassy Suites hotel there, where the members have been meeting all week, resembles nothing else so much as a state legislature at budget time, with dozens of lobbyists haunting the hallways and overflow crowds of more than 1,000 people expected.
The issue has shaped up as a classic fight over private property rights and environmental concerns in a state where the environmental movement and coastal protections have long been strong but where population growth and economic recovery are putting new development pressures on once-sleepy locales.
The Hearst-built resort would take up a small part of what has been a working cattle ranch ever since the family patriarch, the mining magnate George Hearst, began buying land here in 1865. The idea is not new, having languished in one form or another for three decades as the Hearst Corporation, the family-controlled media conglomerate, tried in vain to win final approval for a project large enough to justify what it now estimates could be a $100 million investment to build a world-class resort complex in several phases over the next 15 years.
Now the plan is up for review again, as part of a broader coastal planning revision that San Luis Obispo County was required to submit to the state. The county's plan would allow a broader range of development along its coastline stretching southward from the rocky cliffs of Big Sur, by relaxing rules that insure rural character with strict limits on the scale of buildings in scenic areas and the retention of agricultural land.
The county's Board of Supervisors approved that relaxation, and the incorporated Hearst proposal, by a 3-to-2 vote last year, after two seats changed in the 1996 elections, making for a pro-development majority.
"It's good for the county, it's good for the economy," said the board's new chairman, Michael P. Ryan, a rancher. "We have a beautiful county here, growing slowly, and I like that. But it has to grow, and this is a slow, planned, sensible way to do it."
Spokesmen for the Hearst Corporation emphasize that the county's plan is only a broad zoning overview and that each proposed project, from the golf course to a dude ranch and two other proposed hotels, would have to face the usual gantlet of building permits and environmental review before a brick could be laid or a hole dug. They have undertaken a major lobbying campaign that might have made the old tycoon smile, sending direct mail to every registered voter in the county, running full-page newspaper advertisements and buying time for a promotional videotape on local cable television.
"We feel the phase-in is the built-in protection," said Philip M. Battaglia, a Los Angeles lawyer who has represented the Hearst Corporation for 20 years.
But it is precisely because the county's plan would set so broad a framework that environmental groups are worried. They fear that development on the Hearst land would put pressure on ranchers up and down the coast to sell off to developers, so as to meet rising property taxes.
As a result, the Hearst plan looms as a "drop-dead, save-it-or-lose-it" issue, in the words of Susan Jordan, a volunteer with the League for Coastal Protection, one of a broad coalition of environmental groups that has fought the project -- especially the golf course, planned for the bluffs above San Simeon Point.
Last month the Coastal Commission's executive staff recommended denial of the Hearst plan, especially the golf course, on the ground that it would be inconsistent with the state's Coastal Act by obstructing views and public access, converting agricultural land to recreational uses and intruding on sensitive wildlife habitats and scarce water resources, including streams that are home to the threatened steelhead trout.
The staff recommended cutting the total number of hotel rooms to 375 and concentrating virtually all new development around the coastal village of Old San Simeon, which consists mostly of some 19th-century warehouses where Hearst stored some of his vast collection of art during the 30-year construction of the castle, begun in 1919.
The Hearst Corporation contends that the resort would be economically unfeasible at that size, with per-room development costs rising to $24,000 from $15,000 for the larger complex.
Today, in a misty winter rain, the 12-member commission, together with lobbyists for both sides, took a field trip around the site. They stopped for lunch at the Hearst Castle visitors' center, where members of the commission's staff complained that it had been hard to keep some advocates from buttonholing commissioners on the bus. Sara Wan, the commission's vice chairwoman, said she expected the hearing on Thursday to be the most contentious in her memory, because of what was at stake.
"This is California," she said, gesturing toward the majestic coastline outside the door.

HEADLINE: Thomas J. Stanton, 69, Banker; Restored Jersey City Waterfront

 BODY:
Thomas J. Stanton Jr., a Jersey City banker who helped turn his hometown's waterfront from a moldering stretch of rotten piers and rusty rail yards into a sleek corporate district that came to be known as the Gold Coast, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 69.
The cause was a heart attack, family members said. 
 It was Mr. Stanton's devotion to Jersey City that led him in 1967 to build the corporate offices of First Jersey National Bank, a company he ran for more than 20 years, in a ramshackle part of town that could have been plucked from the set of "On the Waterfront."
The decision, considered foolhardy in a summer of urban strife, eventually ignited commercial and residential building along the Hudson River from Hoboken to West New York.
Mr. Stanton was born and reared in Jersey City. In 1954, he began his long banking career there when he joined First Jersey as a business loan officer. Within six years, he was promoted to vice president and in 1967, at the age of 39, he became president and chief executive officer.
Under his control, the bank mushroomed from a local lending agent into a statewide operation with assets of nearly $5 billion and a staff of more than 4,000.
Mr. Stanton retired in 1990, two years after First Jersey was acquired by National Westminster Bank P.L.C., but he remained active in urban renewal projects like the Liberty Science Center and served as a trustee for numerous corporations and educational institutions.
Of the myriad projects that Mr. Stanton undertook as president of one of the state's premier banks, the restoration of Jersey City's brownstone district was perhaps his favorite.
In the early 1970's, when the middle class was fleeing the grubby neighborhood, Mr. Stanton stepped forward with the financial might of First Jersey and began to offer countless trailblazing mortgages that eventually helped turn the area into a redoubt of young, stroller-pushing professionals.
Properties auctioned off by the Federal Government for as little as $7,500 in 1977 were selling for nearly $300,000 just 10 years later.
Mr. Stanton is survived by his wife, Jean Emily Maloney; four sons, Thomas J. Stanton 3d of Verona, N.J., Charles A. Stanton of Jersey City, John M. Stanton of Washington, and Robert J. Stanton of Bloomfield, N.J.; three daughters, Louise Lynch Stanton of Trenton, Patricia B. Stanton of Portland, Ore., and Katherine A. Stanton-Paule of Bloomfield; two sisters, Katherine Kramer of Ocean Grove and Louise Longhurst of Morristown; two brothers, Reginald Stanton of Morristown and John M. Stanton of Carlisle, Pa., and five grandchildren.
