HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Cheaper Oil Propels Import Price Drop

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Competitive pressure, a drop in oil prices and the financial turmoil in Asia helped knock the prices of imported goods down six-tenths of 1 percent in December and 4.9 percent last year, the largest decline since the Government began collecting such data in 1983.
The drop in the price of petroleum imports was the biggest -- 5.4 percent in December and 25.5 percent last year -- and it reflected a sharp fall in 1997 in the price of crude oil, which pushed it below $17 a barrel. 
 But economists focused on the prices paid by importers for commodities other than petroleum, in an effort to gauge how much Asian currency devaluations and the strengthening dollar might restrain inflation in the United States. In December, the prices of imports from Japan dropped four-tenths of 1 percent and those from other Asian nations fell five-tenths of 1 percent.
"Asia already did contribute to a substantial import price decline, and we can expect that much more significant declines are on the way," said Richard Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Robert A. Brusca, chief economist of Nikko Securities, added: "I would have thought we would have seen a bigger impact. The currency declines have been very severe, and they date to July. But we should see some more."
There is hot debate over the effects from Asia because of growing talk about deflation, which occurs when prices decline rather than increase. Prices have already been falling on some goods, like computers. But the discussion has expanded to the possibility of a more general price decline that could be disruptive to the economy, in part by cutting corporate earnings while wage levels remain fixed.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, made the debate more visible when he discussed deflation in a speech earlier this month, though he did not indicate that there was any imminent threat.
But the recent rally in the bond market shows there are many investors who believe that the restraint on growth and prices because of the economic slowdown in Asia will be sufficient to force the Fed to cut its short-term interest rates to spur growth and prevent prices from falling.
The price declines in oil are important for a separate reason. If they hold, they could be a stimulus to the economy. Economists think of drops in oil prices as being like tax cuts because they can directly put money into consumers' pockets. Such a stimulus could help offset the decline in purchases of American exports resulting from the slowdown in Asia.
The restraint on prices from lower import costs shows up in several ways: Products like television sets and cars that are made abroad cost less because the American dollar buys more. In the case of Asia, foreign companies may also be cutting prices to gain sales that they are losing at home as their own economies slow down. Imported components for products assembled here cost less, and mean that American companies may be able to hold current prices. And competition from lower-priced imports is expected to keep American producers from raising prices on their rival products.
But in addition to the impact from Asia, the import price data, from the Department of Labor, show that there was a separate, longer-term competitive force pushing down prices before the Asian turmoil was touched off in July. In the first half of 1997, for example, import prices from South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan -- the four original "Asian tigers" -- had already fallen 1.7 percent. For all 1997 they were down 4.7 percent, while the price of imported goods from Japan dropped 5 percent. In 1996 they fell 2.9 percent.
Joel Popkin, the head of his own research company in Washington, said a lot of these earlier price cuts reflected growing industrial overcapacity that had developed in Asia in the last few years. In addition, the decline in computer prices has brought import prices lower.
One reason that the statistics have not reflected the full impact from Asia is that the Government, when calculating a certain month's import prices, uses the previous month's foreign-exchange figures. The exchange figures used to calculate the December import prices are averages for November. Because the dollar rallied much more against Asian and other currencies in December, this month's data -- which will be adjusted based on December's foreign-exchange values -- should show further downward pressure.
For example, the dollar rose 11.4 percent against the South Korean won in November and then jumped 44.3 percent in December.
Bill Alterman, an economist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that in the past there has been a six-to-eight-month lag between changes in currency values and the resulting adjustment in import prices. One of the reasons for the lag is the fact that many Asian imports are priced in dollars and these prices are set months ahead in contracts.
This means that currency changes do not affect the prices immediately and will not change until the contracts are revised.
But Mr. Berner of Mellon Bank said he thought that the lag would be shorter this time because Asian companies would be scrambling to offset poor sales at home by cutting prices of their exports.
The report showed that the prices of American exports also declined, falling four-tenths of 1 percent last month and 1.1 percent for the year. This decline reflected a sharp drop in other American commodity prices, like wheat, and the pressure on American producers to cut prices to keep them competitive as the strong dollar made them more expensive abroad.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Poor Credit? Rent-to-Moan Is Wooing You

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: UNION CITY, N.J.

 BODY:
THE brown velvetlike sofa in the window of the Rent-A-Center on Bergenline Avenue has puffy Michelin Man arms, wood trim and a matching love seat. The other day, a young couple with two toddlers, two elderly women in dressy church hats and Justina Tomas, a waitress at a local restaurant, were all gazing at this sofa as though it were an exotic creature.
"It would fit in the apartment," Ms. Tomas said, giving it the once-over. "It would look really good in that apartment." 
 It would cost her, though. The price of owning the set is $26.99 a week for 91 weeks, or $2,456.09. That doesn't include the wood coffee table and end table, which would add another $8.99 a week for the same period, or over $800.
Ms. Morris said she asked a salesman what the interest rate amounts to, but he wouldn't say. "He pointed to the cash up front price and the other price," she said. "I know you end up paying at least twice as much as what it's worth. But once you got it in the house, you don't think about it."
This is precisely why rent-to-own stores appeal to people like Ms. Tomas, a 41-year-old single mother of three (and custodial grandmother of two) from the Dominican Republic, who has no credit cards or checking account. They may be unheard of in the suburbs, but in neighborhoods where check-cashing stores act as banks and owning a home is a lottery dream, rent-to-own stores are springing up like pawnshops in Atlantic City.
THE stores charge higher than most retail outlets for basic household items like furniture, appliances and electronics. Then they add much more to the price when the item is paid by the week, the selling point for most of its customers.
In New Jersey, according to a state Public Interest Research Group study done in June, interest rates for products bought with weekly payments average 88 percent, with one store in Elizabeth charging an interest rate of 140 percent.
Consumer groups have been lobbying for at least 10 years for laws that would regulate the industry, which has grown to 7,500 stores throughout the country with nearly three million customers. In New Jersey, though, consumer groups are celebrating the defeat of a bill this week that would have sanctioned the industry practice of charging more than market value for merchandise and then doubling that amount under the installment plan.
"In this legislative session, we'll be looking to support a bill that would force the industry to abide by basic consumer protection laws, like the criminal usury law that caps interest rates at 30 percent," said Benita Jain, a field coordinator for N.J.-PIRG's Citizen Lobby.
Industry representatives said the rent-to-own stores do not charge interest rates at all, but a fee for services -- namely, renting an item, with little money down, to people without credit whom regular stores would turn away.
But the bill's defeat marks the second significant loss for the industry here in recent months. In Camden, Judge E. Stevenson Fluharty of Superior Court, deciding a class-action lawsuit filed against Rent-A-Center on behalf of 78,000 customers, found last year that the company violated consumer protection and fraud laws and ordered it to pay partial refunds to all its customers going back to 1988. The company is appealing.
UNLIKE many rent-to-own stores, the Bergenline Avenue Rent-A-Center here lists the price if the item is paid in full next to the price under the weekly plan. A used basic model RCA videocassette recorder is listed for $503.64 if paid for at once, and $839.40 if rented to own at $13.99 a week for 60 weeks. Viewing the two prices side by side, it is easy to see why many stores refuse to list them.
Ms. Tomas studied the two prices of the sofa set: just over $1,400 if paid for at once, some $1,000 under the installment price. A friendly salesman told her he would throw in the tables for $5 a week and give her four weeks free. If she referred a friend to the store, she'd get $25 or a free week.
But she has heard some stories. A neighbor paid $20 a week on a 32-inch television every week for more than a year, but missed one payment when her disabled son became sick. The set was repossessed the next week. "That's money down the drain," Ms. Tomas said.
She was staring at the sofa set. "You know," she said, "I wouldn't pay $1,400 for this if I had it. I wouldn't even pay $500. I don't even really like it."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Export, Asia's Key to Survival, Could Crash Into U.S. Barriers

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF with SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 14

 BODY:
It is one of those embarrassing things that executives are forced to do these days to try to save their companies.
Kim Jong Deuk, the scholarly president of a small pharmaceuticals company here, will travel to the United States later this month to sell antibiotics. But if he cannot find buyers for antibiotics, he will try to sell ginseng. Or bowls and plates, made by a friend's company. Or toys, made by other friends. Or anything. 
 "The most important thing for a company is to survive," Mr. Kim said glumly as he sat in his office, near a world map with pins stuck in the cities abroad where he has trading contacts. "So, when we see a business opportunity, we're ready to jump into a fire to get it."
Mr. Kim's company is trying to do what thousands of other businesses across Asia are aiming to do: increase exports to the United States. Yet as Asia gazes adoringly at the American consumer, one of the great economic and political uncertainties of 1998 is whether this love will be requited.
The risk is that a rush of exports to the United States, bolstered by falling currencies in Asia, could lead to a historic collision. The danger arises because Asia is counting on saving itself with a surge of exports to America just as the 50-year American consensus in favor of free trade and internationalism shows signs of wearing thin.
Some diplomats and scholars fear that a tidal wave of Indonesian lingerie, Thai jogging clothes and Malaysian clock radios could inflame the United States trade deficit, anger American workers and provoke growing protectionism in the United States. Many speak of the risks of a severe economic downturn around the world and recall that protectionist moves in the United States and Europe contributed to the Great Depression.
"You're going to be able to buy a Hyundai car at $8,500; you're going to get your teddy bear at F.A.O. Schwarz at 35 percent cheaper," said Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist for Deutsche Bank Group Asia-Pacific. "It's going to drive the U.S. trade numbers crazy, and that obviously is going to create a political problem."
The collision between Asian hopes and American fears, if it happens, still lies ahead, for Asian companies are only now gearing up to shift exports to the United States. But it is remarkable how many executives in Asia are working the phones, keeping the fax humming and rummaging through directories, all in search of the Holy Grail of an open market for goods now that demand in Asia is shrinking.
"Exports in the region are the only hope," said Neil Saker, a Singapore-based economist at SocGen-Crosby Securities. "The more exports they send out, the better."
With buyers at home sitting on their hands and most other export markets around the world weak, the vast American market beckons as if with neon lights that glitter across the battered economic landscape of Asia. On the factory floors and in cramped trading offices in Asia, America's affluent consumers are seen as the last, best hope.
At the headquarters of Hyundai, South Korea's largest conglomerate, 1,000 top executives gathered for a pep rally, and as a brass band played they chanted slogans like "Double Exports!" Hyundai has raised its export targets and plans to move staff to its export division and hold a special series of meetings to monitor overseas sales.
Exports can be the salvation of some Asian economies because of their economic structure. While exports account for just 8 percent of the economic output in the United States and 10 percent in Japan, they make up 79 percent of the total economic output in Malaysia, 29 percent in Thailand, 27 percent in South Korea and 25 percent in the Philippines.
"All of these countries are export-led economies," said Linda Tsao Yang, the United States envoy to the Asian Development Bank in the Philippines. "They need to export, export, export. As long as the U.S. economy stays on an even keel, the U.S. can absorb these exports and our consumers can benefit from much cheaper toys and clothes."
Yet for all the benefits to consumers, is the American political system really prepared to accept a deluge of Asian goods?
The defeat in Congress last year of "fast track" trade legislation -- which would have made it easier for the President to negotiate trade agreements -- was one sign that the internationalist consensus that has prevailed in the United States since the era of Franklin D. Roosevelt may be in trouble. A pillar of that consensus, faith in free trade and open markets, may be sorely tested if the United States is flooded with Asian products just as Congressional candidates are looking for good campaign issues.
Though the gap between imports and exports would be much smaller as a share of the overall economy, increased imports of Asian products and a falloff in United States exports to Asia would add to the United States current account imbalance, which may soon surpass its record of $168 billion, set in 1987.
"The U.S. trade deficit will expand at a rapid pace and drag down the domestic economic growth in the U.S.," predicted C. H. Kwan, an economist at Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo.
One result is apprehension in Asian capitals.
As Lee Hong Koo, a former Prime Minister of South Korea who lived in the United States and has had close ties with Americans for four decades, put it: "The U.S. in a way has become isolationist, or a selfish nation, and it doesn't have its old sense of mission. Americans are a bit tired. But when you become a superpower, with all that wealth and power of America, this is something that you cannot avoid. If you do, then you risk your own future."
To be sure, it is not clear that Asian companies will be as successful in exporting as they hope. Several countries are competing against one another, so that one's success may partly displace the business of another. Faced with a profusion of Asian-made televisions, for instance, American consumers may benefit from a broader selection and cheaper models. But they will not buy five more television sets.
Moreover, the financial crisis has, for now, gummed up the trade system from Malaysia to Korea. Working capital is scarce, letters of credit and other trade finance mechanisms are more difficult to arrange, and imported raw materials are more costly now that local currencies have been devalued.
Chung Youn Goo, a clothing manufacturer in Seoul, said his business was suffering because Korean consumers "have just stopped buying clothes." But he said that exports are not now a feasible solution for his company, because of the domestic consequences of the crisis.
"This is a bit embarrassing to say, but we haven't received payments on time from our customers," Mr. Chung said. "Exports require money to plan, and we don't have it. We don't have the luxury of planning for the future. We're just fighting to survive."
Japan in particular faces difficulties increasing exports, because it exports more than twice as much to the United States as any other country in the region, and its rising trade surplus with the United States is again beginning to cause tension.
Japanese officials insist that they will not try to increase exports to resolve their economic difficulties.
"We don't think exports will be a solution," said Osamu Moriya, director of the trade research division at Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "Politically, it's not going to be a solution."
He and other Japanese officials say their trade surplus with the United States will not soar. But already, as the falling yen makes Japanese products more competitive, Japanese exports are rising again. And if that continues, it is not clear what Tokyo will offer but empathy.
"Although we can't do so much about our trade balance directly, we care," Mr. Moriya said.
Indirectly, of course, Japan will also contribute to the trade imbalance because its own economic troubles mean that Japanese will be buying fewer goods from other Asian countries, forcing them to sell their products elsewhere.
With much of the region obsessed with exports, one risk is that countries will engage in competitive currency devaluations to get a bit more edge in overseas markets.
Over the last few years, the currencies of China and Japan had both effectively declined against other Asian currencies. That made Thai and Korean goods less competitive in world markets and helped precipitate the Asian crisis. But now that Thai and Korean currencies have collapsed, China and Japan face pressures to respond. A result could be a new round of devaluations.
China has repeatedly said that it will not devalue its currency, and Japan has said that it does not want the yen to fall. But in fact the yen keeps falling, bolstering Japanese exports and making everyone nervous about the economic and political repercussions.
"The worst scenario is clearly, I think, everyone trying to depreciate their currencies ahead of the others, with everyone trying to export to the U.S.," said Minoru Makihara, the president of the Mitsubishi Corporation, the huge Japanese trading company.
"The U.S. won't like that," he added, "so it'll go protectionist."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chung Youn Goo, at clothing plant in Seoul, says exports won't save his company: "Exports require money to plan, and we don't have it. We don't have the luxury of planning for the future. We're just fighting to survive." (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)(pg. D12)

HEADLINE: U.S. Strikes at Smuggling Ring That Exploited Foreign Nurses

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
More than 500 nurses were smuggled into the United States from the Philippines and South Korea over the last several years by an illegal ring that capitalized on the nationwide nursing shortage plaguing hospitals and nursing homes earlier in the decade, Federal prosecutors said today.
Federal officials said this was the first time that the law-enforcement authorities had uncovered a smuggling network involving so many people with such high professional skills. 
 "We've never found a case of this magnitude," said Paul E. Coggins of Dallas, the United States Attorney for the northern district of Texas, where many of the nurses worked.
Apart from the numbers involved, the case is extraordinary because the workers were brought into the United States not under blankets in trucks coming across the Mexican border but on major airlines with fraudulently obtained visas.
The nurses were funneled to at least 35 states and cost American nurses an estimated $13 million in lost salaries by taking jobs at substandard wages, according to Mr. Coggins's office.
Five Americans pleaded guilty to fraud charges today in connection with the smuggling ring. The five, one in New Jersey, one in Texas and three in California, lured the foreign nurses into their smuggling ring by promising them specific jobs in the United States.
Under a Congressionally approved program from 1989 to 1995 to alleviate the nursing shortage, a foreign nurse who indicated that a specific position was promised could obtain a special visa to the United States.
The defendants admitted that they had lied to the Government by saying they were first unable to find nurses in the United States to fill the positions. Congress ended the program more than two years ago because foreign nurses were supplanting so many American workers.
The foreign nurses, many of whom were unable to arrange specific jobs on their own, paid the American operatives $1,500 to $7,500 to obtain the special visas fraudulently and to bring them to the United States, where they were often sent to jobs different from those they had been promised, Federal prosecutors said.
Although nursing homes and hospitals were charged $1,000 for each foreign nurse, Mr. Coggins said they were probably not aware of the scheme. Prosecutors said 570 nurses had been illegally placed in positions, paid substandard wages and lived in crowded, unsanitary conditions. They said they not aware that any of the nurses had delivered substandard care to patients.
The nurses could be charged with fraud and deported, said Lynn Ligon, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Dallas.
Officials said sophisticated smuggling rings were becoming increasingly prevalent as more people around the world sought to enter the United States, particularly when the economy is so strong and companies seek cheaper labor.
Such operations are also increasingly complex, officials said. It took officials from several Federal agencies more than 33 months to uncover the nursing ring, and the investigation is still going on.
The first clue was picked up by a consular officer at the United States Embassy in Manila, who detected an unusually high number of petitions for special visas filed by nursing homes in Texas and Oklahoma. They were all signed by the same person, Billy Denver Jewell of Lubbock, Tex., whom officials identified today as the ring leader.
In a two-year period, Mr. Jewell submitted more than 1,100 fraudulent petitions to bring in registered nurses, said Mr. Coggins, the United States Attorney. More than 20,000 visas were issued to foreign nurses from 1993 to 1996.
Complicating Mr. Jewell's operation was the fact that the nursing shortage turned to a glut. This was largely because of shifts in the health care system but also partly because of the influx of foreign nurses, at least in Texas.
Many of the foreign nurses were registered nurses, who in Texas make up to $14 an hour. But the foreign nurses were employed as nurse's aides and paid as little as $5 an hour.
The authorities said that in August 1993, Mr. Jewell made an agreement with Haesook Kim, also known as Clara Kim, owner of International Nurses Exchange of Wayne, N.J., in which Ms. Kim would furnish 20 South Korean nurses to be employed at the Southern Manor Nursing Home in Lubbock. Ms. Kim, who also pleaded guilty today, paid Mr. Jewell $1,000, for a total of $19,000, for each nurse who obtained a visa through a petition filed by the nursing home.
The others who pleaded guilty were Holly Arthur Estreller of Los Angeles and Sidney and Veronica Hewitt of San Diego. Officials are still seeking Nelson Alomajin Sin of Sugar Land, Tex., who is believed to have fled to the Philippines.
Each count of visa fraud carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and fines of $250,000. Sentencing by Judge Sam R. Cummings of Federal District Court in Lubbock is expected in two months.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Billy Denver Jewell, top, pleaded guilty to conspiracy, and Nelson Alomajin Sin is believed to have fled to the Philippines. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
All Those Billions (and It Sounds So Reasonable)

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
Who's nuts now? Four years ago when Fox overturned the sports economy by paying $1.58 billion to get into the National Football League, many snickered at the insolence and imprudence of Rupert Murdoch's broadcast weblet. They wondered if Bart Simpson would diagram plays with a crayon. But the expectations of folly never came true.
If Murdoch -- who did have to write off $350 million in losses early on -- was deemed harebrained, how do we judge what happened this week: CBS signed on to pay $4 billion to get back into pro football; Disney committed $4.4 billion to keep "Monday Night Football" on ABC (ousting NBC from the N.F.L.) and $4.8 billion to put the entire Sunday night cable package on ESPN (kicking TNT out), and Fox agreed to spend $4.4 billion to keep what it had. 
 CBS is considered the looniest for paying monumentally more than NBC did for the American Football Conference package -- renting a nice house in a very expensive neighborhood. The confidence of its executives is astounding.
"Michael Jordan, Mel Karmazin and I won't let us lose money on this deal," said Sean McManus, the president of CBS Sports, referring to promises by his bosses of herculean sales and promotional efforts to make the A.F.C. deal pay.
Chase Carey, the co-chief operating officer of News Corporation, Fox's parent company, knows what it's like to be isolated by criticism.
"A lot of the statements made about CBS were made about us," he said. "In a television world that is more and more fragmented, the N.F.L. will keep rising in value. But the ability to capture value depends on your execution."
The harshest critic has been Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports. He would not renew his A.F.C. deal, then offered too little to take "Monday Night Football" away from ABC. He said CBS's deal is an invitation to annual losses of at least $175 million.
"We made a cold, calculated decision that these losses are intolerable," he said. "In a tough economy, like in '86 or '91, we're talking about doubling those losses. We decided it was reckless folly."
He added: "As businessmen, we're winners. Absolutely."
McManus of CBS objected. "Maybe at these numbers, it doesn't make sense for Dick, but the numbers make a whole lot of sense for us," he said.
Ebersol joked that during NBC's final N.F.L. game, the Super Bowl on Jan. 25, he would add a corner score box -- something he has refused to do -- and an informational crawl to the bottom of the screen to detail estimates of his rivals' coming losses.
What will NBC do to fill the football gap? This fall, movies. For the 1999 season, he said he's cooking up a plan to create programming with NBC News.
Carey of the News Corporation suggested that Ebersol's projections of doom should be taken "with a grain of salt," that they are statements "made by someone left out of the process."
Carey admitted that the $550 million-a-year deal was more than he expected to pay, but the presence of CBS forced all prices up.
Nonetheless, he confidently labeled Fox's new deal -- up 39 percent from $395 million a year -- better than the previous one. His reasoning was that every part of Fox is stronger than it was four years ago; all games now carry three extra advertising spots; and Fox can reap the benefits of selling two Super Bowls through 2002, plus a third in the last three years of the contract if the league does not reopen it for renegotiations after the fifth year.
A search for prudence, at least in a relative sense, among the N.F.L. winners leads to Disney, where Robert Iger, the president of ABC, retained "Monday Night Football" for $550 million a year.
"I believe we wouldn't have gone a penny higher," Iger said.
With the network deals done, the announcer deals start. The biggest question involves John Madden. He hasn't voiced public loyalty to Fox, but has made known his yen to work on Monday nights. It makes sense. He could plan his bus trips months in advance and he would co-star in the league's biggest showcase.
"If he wants to stay here, great; if he wants to go to 'Monday Night,' he'll go with our best wishes," said David Hill, the president of Fox Sports.
Fox may not scrap to keep Madden. He has delivered what they wanted: credibility, star power and football savvy. He is not needed as a network centerpiece as he was in 1994. ABC or CBS will have to pant heavily for his services if his salary is to stay at its current $7.5 million. "We'll know what he will do in the next 48 hours," said Sandy Montag, his agent.
If Madden goes to ABC, then Dan Dierdorf is out, headed to a less prominent role, and Frank Gifford has probably called his final game. Fox could slip Matt Millen into its No. 1 analyst slot, but Hill has talked to NBC's Phil Simms.
If Simms goes to Fox as the top analyst, Millen could be miffed enough to jump back to CBS. NBC's Greg Gumbel could return to CBS. Certainly, Fox and CBS would covet NBC's Cris Collinsworth, the best studio analyst around.
McManus has plenty of stocking up to do. He has play-by-play voices like Jim Nantz, Sean McDonough and Tim Ryan on staff, but he needs analysts. Verne Lundquist could return from TNT. NBC's Randy Cross and Paul Maguire should be in demand at CBS and Fox. But no one can snare Terry Bradshaw from Fox; he signed a five-year deal on Tuesday to stay as co-host of Fox's studio show.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 933 words

HEADLINE: Corruption Charges Irritate a Tiny Town Battling Obscurity

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Jan. 14

 BODY:
This tiny blue-collar town, situated just across the Hudson from Manhattan's Upper West Side, has always had something of an identity crisis.
"Every time I say it, I say West New York, New Jersey," said Oscar Miqueli, who has lived here for 37 years and is still pointing out that he does not live somewhere within the great Gothic skyscape across the river. 
 Now, Mr. Miqueli, the coordinator of West New York's Urban Empowerment Zone, and other local officials say they must overcome an even darker image: the characterization of the town as perhaps the most corrupt in the state. On Monday the former police chief and eight other former or current members of the Police Department were indicted on Federal charges that they extorted and accepted money in exchange for protecting illegal gambling, prostitution and after-hours liquor sales.
For West New York, which like other working class towns has suffered tremendously as manufacturing jobs have disappeared in recent years, the corruption scandal is a large bump in the already-difficult road to economic recovery. And yet, with news of the Federal investigation swirling about since early last spring, the arrests also brought a certain sense of relief.
"The public was almost expecting this," Mayor Albio Sires said in an interview today at his office in Town Hall. "I think they wanted this to take place to clean up this mess that we had here." Noting that the indicted officers had been immediately suspended without pay, he said, "We are already moving forward to say, 'Hey, this is over.' "
To say it is over, even to wish it so, will not be so easy. "Our work in West New York is not yet done," William C. Megary, the special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey, said at the news conference announcing the arrests of the police officials and 11 others. Investigators said they expected additional arrests of both police officers and civilians, as well as additional plea bargain agreements with potential witnesses.
The arrests come just as signs of economic recovery have begun to emerge in West New York. The real estate developer K. Hovnanian recently started the first phase of construction of what is expected to be 4,100 new housing units on a long-vacant riverfront site, including rental apartments and town houses expected to sell for $200,000 to $500,000. As part of the project, a new soccer field and an accompanying parking lot are also being built on the waterfront.
Prospects of a redeveloped riverfront and increased tax revenues from a growing population has offered a flash of hope to the town, whose 40,000 residents, many of them Latin American immigrants, are some of the poorest in New Jersey.
But across the town's neat grid of treeless streets, with bodegas and go-go bars peppered among the aging houses and small apartment buildings, residents said this afternoon they were stung by the arrests, and they expressed a growing sense of suspicion of public officials. "It hurts me because you want to live in a good place," said Miriam Robles, 43, who has lived in West New York for five years. "This is terrible. You don't know who to trust."
Louis Beeber, a 77-year-old crossing guard, who has lived in an apartment building on Boulevard East for 23 years, said the case had made him suspicious of political complicity in the bribery scheme. "I wonder if the old mayor wasn't connected to this," he said, referring to the late Mayor Anthony M. DeFino, who was in office when many of the police officials now under indictment were being promoted through the ranks.
Mr. DeFino, who after 24 years in office decided not to run for re-election in 1995, died in December 1996, three weeks after suffering a heart attack. A lifelong resident of West New York, Mr. DeFino was a mammoth-sized man, who often salted his public remarks with phrases in Italian that reflected the heritage he shared with so many of the immigrants that populated the town throughout its early history.
In the 1960's, as Italian and other European immigrant groups began to move away, West New York experienced a huge influx of immigrants from Cuba. Mr. Sires, the current mayor, was born in Cuba and came to West New York with his parents 37 years ago at the age of 10. Like other longtime residents, he says the town does not deserve its new unflattering label as a crime haven.
According to the indictment filed in United States District Court in Newark, the former police chief, Alexander V. Oriente, led a band of colleagues in a racketeering operation that earned them at least $600,000 in bribes and payoffs between 1989 and 1997. Investigators said they believed Mr. Oriente began accepting bribes long before he became chief of police in 1994.
"I love this community," Mr. Sires said. "I grew up here. It just hurts that this is such a nice community and it should get such a black eye."
Echoing some of the warnings by Federal investigators that small, tightly knit towns of New Jersey may by nature face serious risk of municipal corruption, Mr. Sires said West New York was long overdue for a change when he took office in May 1995. As the Federal investigation mounted, Mr. Sires urged the Hudson County Prosecutor's office to take control of the Police Department.
"The problem with these communities is that everything is done from within," he said. "You have to break a cycle. Sooner or later, you have to bring in new blood, new people from the outside, new ideas. You need to have a different approach. For too many years it's always the same thing."

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
U.N. Vote Rebukes Iraq For Blocking Inspectors
The Security Council voted unanimously to rebuke Iraq for blocking United Nations arms inspectors and said Iraq must honor its earlier promise to allow the inspectors "full, unconditional and immediate access" to sites suspected of concealing biological, chemical and nuclear weapons. But it did not say what it would do if Iraq did not comply. A1 

Israel Adopts Guidelines
The Israeli Government adopted sweeping guidelines on what it would regard as vital interests in any future negotiations regarding the West Bank. After long and inconclusive debate in recent weeks over alternative maps, the Cabinet drew up only general principles, saying the broad approach avoided a showdown in the Cabinet and would give Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu more room to maneuver in his impending meeting with President Clinton. A8
 
Quid Pro Quo for Iran?
An adviser to President Mohammed Khatami of Iran said the Clinton Administration should respond to Mr. Khatami's public overture to the American people with a gesture of its own. The adviser suggested three possibilities: a review of the American sanctions against Iran, an easing of visa regulations for travel to the United States and an investigation of frozen Iranian assets. A8
 
Jews Recall Swiss Camps
A report prepared for the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles said that many of the more than 22,000 Jewish refugees in Switzerland during World War II were kept in unheated barracks and forced to sleep on straw. Men were put to work in fields, forests and factories while women and girls cleaned homes. A3
 
A Thousand Mourn in Belfast
A crowd of 1,000 people joined the funeral procession in Belfast for Terry Enright, a 28-year-old Roman Catholic shot by Protestant gunners. Mr. Enright, a nightclub bouncer and community worker, was apparently not involved in politics or paramilitary violence. A3
 
Chinese Dissident Stays Put
Qin Yongmin, a longtime democracy campaigner in China, has defied the powerful Ministry of State Security by publicly refusing to leave China for the United States. Mr. Yongmin, who recently called for free labor unions, said security agents had instructed a friend to tell him he should immediately seek a passport and move to the United States. A6
 
Algeria Rejects Mission
Algeria's military-backed Government said it would reject a mission that the 15-nation European Union wanted to send to learn how to stop the killings of civilians there, which number in the tens of thousands in a six-year civil war. The Europeans had received indications earlier that officials from Luxembourg, Britain and Austria would be welcome in Algiers, but only if they limited their discussions to the Government's efforts to combat terrorism. A9
 
NATIONAL A12-18
 
Homicide Rates Are Rising In Some Midsized Cities
Some cities with populations of several hundred thousand are experiencing increases in killings, contrary to trends that show homicide rates falling in many big cities since 1994. Police officials and other experts point to evidence of a rising, more violent drug trade in medium-sized cities, and the fact that some of these cities are just catching up with the latest trends in crime-fighting. A1
 
A Nurse-Smuggling Operation
More than 500 nurses were smuggled into the United States from the Philippines and South Korea over the last several years by an illegal ring that capitalized on the nationwide nursing shortage that plagued hospitals and nursing homes earlier in the decade, Federal prosecutors said. A14
 
Courting Youthful Smokers
Internal records from one of the nation's largest cigarette companies, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, provide new evidence of the extent to which the company courted young smokers, including some as young as 14, for decades, regarding them as the future of its business. A12

HEADLINE: Clinton Race Panel Hears Emotional Tales at Phoenix Forum

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 14

 BODY:
President's Clinton's advisory board on race made its first foray outside the Washington area today and was subjected to two sides of the national conversation on race: erudition and emotion.
After listening to a sometimes dry and academic discussion by a panel of experts about the reasons for disparities in employment, income and poverty between whites, six of the seven panel members later heard from ordinary citizens, many of whom wanted to vent their frustrations over acts of discrimination they said they had suffered. 
 A late afternoon forum held at a middle school near downtown featured a long line of speakers who, among other things, urged the board to help maintain affirmative action, investigate police brutality, and recommend the spending of Federal money for whites to undergo psychological counseling to rid themselves of racism.
All of the speakers, including the chairman of the Arizona Democratic Party, could be described as political liberals, or at least supporters of affirmative action or other policies for helping minorities. No one spoke out against such programs.
Members of the advisory board said they had tried to entice people with more conservative views to attend the forum. None showed up.
Those who spoke instead poured out emotional tales of personal travails of what they described as instances of discrimination. A Federal worker showed the advisory boarda sheet of paper that included a racist message that she said she had found in her desk drawer at work. Many complained that the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission did not enforce laws against job discrimination. One waved pictures of her elderly parents who she said were beaten by police officers evicting them from their home.
"Please listen to my story," said Darlene Lopez Spahn, who is part Hispanic. "If you don't, nobody will. God sent you."
While many said they supported the advisory board's work, some expressed skepticism that it would amount to much.
"I pay taxes," said Wade Henry, a black real estate agent from Phoenix. "I want value for my dollar. I appreciate you being here, but I want something done. If not, then stop wasting my money."
A number of recent racial incidents have taken place in the Phoenix area, setting nerves on edge and, perhaps, contributing to the emotion of the late afternoon session.
In October, at a trial involving a discrimination suit filed by Jesus Torres, a Scottsdale police officer who was dismissed from the force, Mr. Torres testified that he had overheard some white police officers discuss the imposition of a zone barring blacks in a wealthy section of the city. Mr. Torres said any black or Latino found in that section of town after dark would be searched.
Scottsdale police officials deny that such a policy had been established.
The State Attorney General's office also found fault with some sweeps conducted by the local police in Chandler, a nearby suburb, and Federal immigration officers. During the sweep, officers stopped several American citizens of Hispanic origin and demanded that they provide prove of citizenship.
Several of the local residents speaking in the late afternoon session referred to the two incidents.
"There are pockets of bigotry and there are pockets of hate," said Ruben Noel, a white public relations specialist from Phoenix who referred to the Chandler police as "jack-booted street thugs."
The site of the first of a series of sessions to be held by the race panel nationwide, Phoenix was chosen because the board hoped the region's large Hispanic and American Indian population would permit more of a discussion of issues involving them.
The late afternoon session was a marked contrast from the board's morning program, which featured racial issues in the workplace. Much of that session revolved around of how much the lagging performance of black and Hispanic people was the result of discrimination or a gap in the level of education and skills.
"It's clear that American employers are more reluctant to hire blacks than any other ethnic group in the United States, especially black men, especially younger black men," said Henry J. Holzer, a white professor of economics at Michigan State University. "That's true even when people have comparable credentials, education, comparable work experience and the like."
James Smith, a white economist at the Rand Corporation, urged the panel to concentrate on the disparities between blacks and whites.
"If you look at the aggregate data, you do not see large wage difference in all these other ethnic groups with the white majority, except for blacks," he said. "There is something quite different going on here."
But others challenged that notion.
"The best way to get the high-paying job as a lawyer in Texas is to be born white," said Jose Roberto Juarez Jr., who is Hispanic and the associate dean for academic affairs at St. Mary's University Law School in San Antonio.
"It doesn't matter how well you did in school. The best predictor I can give you for your achieving a high salary is to happen to be born white. Those are the realities."

HEADLINE: As Asia's Economic Turmoil Deepens, Pentagon Chief Reassures Indonesia

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 14

 BODY:
As financial crises continued to rumble across Asia, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen met here today with President Suharto to discuss expanding security ties with the beleaguered Indonesian Government.
Though Mr. Cohen's public statements avoided any talk of Mr. Suharto's political future, American officials said the meeting and the Secretary's comments afterward were intended as a gesture of support. 
 Mr. Suharto, who took power in a coup 32 years ago that left a reported 500,000 people died, has recently faced rare calls from opponents to step down.
Mr. Cohen's statements, the officials said, were part of a two-pronged strategy to press Mr. Suharto to make the economic concessions that will insure an international bailout of his country's economy, while trying to prevent the crisis from sowing political instability.
Should Mr. Suharto's position become tenuous, American officials said, the Clinton Administration, particularly the normally cautious military, does not see any clear or easy line of succession.
Mr. Cohen therefore focused on talk of continuity and stability in military relations, and his 40-minute meeting dealt with military matters rather than economics.
"I am not here as any sort of financial expert," Mr. Cohen said at a news conference after the talks. "I am here to talk about security issues and ways in which we can expand upon our security relationship."
Officials here and those traveling with Mr. Cohen on his 12-day tour of Asia have repeatedly expressed concern that any further erosion of Indonesia's economy could lead to widespread unrest and even, in the worst case, the disintegration of a country, the world's fourth-largest, with scores of ethnic groups spread over 13,677 islands.
"You can't have an Indonesia that becomes destabilized without security concerns arising in the region," a senior United States official said before Mr. Cohen's meeting with Mr. Suharto.
Administration officials have said they fear that a prolonged economic crisis could revive regional rivalries that have remained largely dormant while Asia's "tiger" economies flourished.
During his tour, which was planned before the financial crises, Mr. Cohen visited Malaysia and plans stops in Singapore and Thailand, trying to rebuild a military presence that was vastly reduced after the Vietnam War and the loss of American bases in the Philippines.
The Pentagon hopes to increase its presence in Indonesia and elsewhere in Southeast Asia, not through permanent bases but through joint exercises and periodic visits by American warships.
Along those lines, Mr. Cohen announced today that the United States and the Philippines had reached a tentative agreement to resume military contacts, which were cut off a year ago when the Philippines removed legal protections for visiting forces.
The United States has not had forces stationed in the Philippines since 1992, when the sprawling base at Subic Bay was closed at Manila's request. The agreement -- signed in Manila today by Ambassador Thomas C. Hubbard and Foreign Minister Domingo Siazon -- should lead the way to a resumption of exercises, joint training and port calls.
"Today, amidst the uncertainty we are currently facing in the Asia Pacific, the United States and the Government of the Philippines have taken an important step to reassure the region and promote peace and stability," Mr. Cohen said at a news conference at the American Embassy here.
Mr. Cohen and his aides also dismissed speculation, rampant only a few days ago, that the Indonesian military might seek to topple President Suharto. Instead, the officials said, any threat to Mr. Suharto's rule would very likely come from riots between ethnic or religious groups, or protests in the streets. In the past, displays of unrest have been met with harsh military crackdowns.
A senior American official here also expressed the fear that the economic crisis, if it persisted, could lead to "a rise in Islamic radicalism" in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim nation.
Mr. Cohen said he took pains to avoid any discussion of Mr. Suharto's future as Indonesia's ruler. He said Mr. Suharto, who is 76, raised and dismissed rumors that he was ill. "And those rumors, he felt, were contributing to the lack of stability in the region," Mr. Cohen said.
Short of outright collapse, there are also concerns that the economic austerity imposed by the I.M.F. could lead to a backlash against the United States if Washington is seen as the enforcer. There have already been small protests here against the I.M.F. and its backers.
Mr. Cohen, who also met with the Minister of Defense, Gen. Edi Sudradjat, emphasized the role Indonesia had played "in maintaining regional stability" through its leadership in the Association of South East Asian Nations.
Mr. Cohen did not reach any concrete agreements with the Indonesians on increasing military contacts, but he received assurances, his aides said, that Indonesia supported the idea generally.
Mr. Cohen said he did not discussion arms sales to Indonesia, which last July canceled the purchase of at least nine F-16 fighter jets after becoming frustrated with opposition in the United States Congress over Indonesia's record on human rights.
But General Sudradjat pointedly said that when Indonesia's economy recovered enough to allow it to purchase weaponry, it would not necessarily turn to the United States.
"We buy from everywhere, what we need and what we judge as good quality," he said in a news conference with Mr. Cohen outside the President's home, "but there are no links or commitments whatsoever."

HEADLINE: Initiative to Save Theaters May Drive Out Artists

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Peter Stone (Op-Ed, Jan. 10) exposes only part of the sham of a rezoning plan that will allow Broadway theaters to expand the sale of their "air rights" (giving new buildings in midtown their nonexistent upper floors). 
 As the proposal stands, special residential protection in Hell's Kitchen will be stripped away to allow the development of larger high rises. A neighborhood that houses a huge number of people involved in theater will be prey to real estate speculators and sudden price inflation.
If theaters must float air rights beyond adjacent properties, as is currently allowed, let them sell to locations in the city where zoning already permits it. There is no need to link Broadway to the obliteration of zoning protection for the residents of Hell's Kitchen.
 
CYNTHIA L. COOPER
New York, Jan. 10, 1998

HEADLINE: Forest Plan Leaves Too Many Trees at Risk;
Preserve Our Heritage

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I applaud the Clinton Administration's effort to protect the last remaining American wilderness areas (editorial, Jan. 14). Subsidies to the timber industry once made sense as a way to grow the economy by increasing exports and providing low-cost lumber to home builders, pulp for paper products and livable wages to those in remote regions. However, given the economy's current strength, the growth of alternative resources and recycling practices, and the desire of most Americans to protect our few remaining wild areas, we must re-evaluate outdated Federal policies that pour millions of dollars each year in support of privately held timber concerns. 
 While it takes only a few years to harvest timber from a forest, it takes hundreds of years for that forest to return to its natural state. Are we willing to deny so many future generations the chance to experience the beauty and diversity of America's wilderness? These forests serve not only as a reminder of our rich natural heritage, but also as a reminder that there are still some things in life that money cannot buy.
 
ROBERT McGUIGAN
New York, Jan. 14, 1998

HEADLINE: Civic Parties Of Pageantry And Pledges;
It's Swearing-In Season For Council Members

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
By the time City Councilman Angel Rodriguez raised his hand to take the oath of office, the 300 people gathered in a Brooklyn grade school auditorium had already sat through the singing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" and the Puerto Rican anthem, "La Borinquena." They had witnessed a colorful lion dance performed by the Latin American Chinese Association Cultural Dancers and a presentation of flags by a Boy Scout troop -- followed by an invocation by a Roman Catholic priest, translated from English into Spanish and then Mandarin.
After taking the oath to thunderous applause, Mr. Rodriguez, a newly elected Democrat from ethnically diverse Sunset Park, led the crowd of neighborhood residents, campaign workers, friends and relatives upstairs to a reception in the library of Public School 314. There they enjoyed a feast of rice and beans, boiled yuca and pasteles, the Puerto Rican plantain and beef turnovers, made by Mr. Rodriguez's 63-year-old mother. 
 It mattered to no one that Mr. Rodriguez had officially been a member of the City Council for nearly two weeks or that he was administered the oath of office by the City Clerk at City Hall last month. From a political standpoint, this was the real swearing-in ceremony -- on his home turf, before his constituents and fellow politicians, with all the pomp of civic spectacle.
This is New York City's season of the swearing-in ceremony. While the Mayor's inauguration draws broad news coverage and Borough Presidents command some attention, the ceremonies are no less important to the 51 members of the City Council (and, in odd-numbered years, to state lawmakers). Part pageant, part inaugural ball, part political conclave, the events are a bedrock of the city's governmental landscape, a ritual practiced by both the newly elected and the veteran.
They bring together masses of ordinary neighborhood voters to celebrate the victory of their candidate. At the same time, the events offer fellow politicians a perfect venue for some subtle campaigning of their own among hundreds of the most politically active voters.
"Next to funerals and weddings, the public event that politicians have the most emotional investment in is the swearing-in ceremony," said New York City's Public Advocate, Mark J. Green, who is a candidate this year for United States Senate. "They are a great art form."
No matter that the oratory might not match the history-book cadences of Presidential inaugurals. Or that the effort to drape an essentially parochial event in the trappings of grandeur can sometimes carry a hint of absurdity.
"It's very important to the elected official, because it enables supporters to remind themselves that they had a great cause and that they succeeded in getting the official elected," said Mr. Green, who has already attended nearly a dozen ceremonies for other politicians in the last two weeks, and plans to fit in as many more in the next few weeks.
This January, the ritual has been enacted in an ornate library in the University Heights section of the Bronx, a spacious Roman Catholic church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, a high school on the south shore of Staten Island and a hall on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.
While the motivations are similar, the form of the events varies widely. The ceremony for City Councilwoman Una Clarke, a six-year Democratic incumbent in Brooklyn, seemed patterned on a Westminster Abbey coronation. Walking at the rear of a procession of red-robed choir members, a string of clergymen and a line of judges, Ms. Clarke, dressed in a white gown, made her way down the aisle of an East Flatbush Episcopal church as a solemn hymn was played on a pipe organ.
For Margarita Lopez, a Democratic newcomer to the Council from the Lower East Side, grass-roots participation was the watchword. She took a series of oaths, administered by neighborhood residents, pledging to devote herself to a range of positions, from reaching out to minority-owned businesses to supporting community cultural centers. Ms. Lopez, a longtime advocate for the homeless, held her event at the Great Hall at Cooper Union, where she was arrested years earlier at a demonstration.
For Adolpho Carrion Jr., a recently elected Democrat from the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, the event was something of a family affair. Standing in the marble-filled rotunda of a library at Bronx Community College, Mr. Carrion's father, a Pentecostal minister, offered the invocation, and the Councilman's 8-year-old daughter, Raquel, sang the national anthem before a crowd of about 400. Mr. Carrion himself sang "La Borinquena" in a resounding tenor before offering an address of which brevity was not the most striking attribute.
Not surprisingly, a lengthy speech from the officeholder is a focal point of most swearing-in ceremonies. Newcomers tend to focus on qualifications and promises; old-timers are quick to recite a list of youth centers opened or parks renovated under the Council member's auspices. Sometimes, swept up in the moment, the speaker ventures into broader themes. "We must diversify our city economy," Walter L. McCaffrey, a Queens Democrat entering his 12th year on the City Council, told a crowd of 300 at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City. "The success of Wall Street is filling our tax coffers and employing hundreds of thousands. But a downturn could once again happen."
For campaign workers, party loyalists and friends, the events serve as both reunion and victory party."It was touching," said Udelka Tapia, a 34-year-old accountant who collected petition signatures, worked telephones and put up posters for Mr. Carrion. "His family was there, the community was there. For many of us who had volunteered for him, this was a great, great program."
Of course, the events invariably attract a large number of other elected officials. "It's an occasion when elected officials can come around some of the most politically active citizens," said Ludovic J. Blain, a lobbyist with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "It's a good time for politicians to seek the support of a particular constituency."
And in this, an election year, swearing-in ceremonies are magnets for candidates running for everything from United States Senate and Governor to the Assembly. Mr. Green and Representative Charles E. Schumer, another candidate for the Democratic primary for Senate, have often run into each other crisscrossing the city to attend them, sometimes several in one day.
They also provide a vantage point to determine which politicians are aligned. "They are an important way to demonstrate the strength of not only the newly elected person, but the strength of the people who helped him get elected," said Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic chairman who devoted much of his energy last year to Mr. Carrion's election.
The occasions can also be the venue for political adversaries to try to heal rifts. Mr. Rodriguez, for example, invited all four of his opponents in the Democratic primary -- three of whom attended, including one, Robert A. McDermott, who helped serve the food.
Martin J. Golden, a newly-elected Republican Councilman from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, invited his Democratic predecessor, Sal F. Albanese, who stepped down to run for Mayor and vigorously supported Mr. Golden's Democratic opponent. "I attended because I believe in orderly transitions," said Mr. Albanese, now a lawyer in private practice. "Even though I didn't support him, he is my successor and he is my representative."
Then, Mr. Albanese, who served in the Council for 15 years, added that he was considering running for Mayor again in 2001. "Swearing-in ceremonies attract a lot of people and there is a lot of community activism there," he said. "So, it was my way of assuring them that I'm not going anywhere and that I plan to remain involved politically."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 42; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Furniture Of Frontier New England

BYLINE: By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
In the 1600's, when America's early colonists said, "Go west," they meant western Massachusetts. Today, it's hard to think of the Connecticut River Valley as a frontier outpost, but that's what it was: 48 were killed in Deerfield, Mass., during a 1704 French and Indian attack. The town rebuilt itself continuously.
The settlers' indefatigable spirit is evident in a loan exhibition of decorative arts from the house museums of Historic Deerfield at the Winter Antiques Show, at the Seventh Regiment Armory (Park Avenue at 66th Street) through Jan. 25. As a result of 50 years of restoration, Deerfield intentionally looks like a New England village that time forgot. 
 Founded in 1669, the rural hamlet still has only one street. It is lined with tall elms and 18th- and 19th-century wooden houses and barns. Behind them stretch acres of protected fields, meadows and woodlands. Two miles away, the Deerfield River runs into the Connecticut, the Great River, which is also the title of a seminal 1985 book of essays edited by William N. Hosley Jr. covering the area's history, architecture and the decorative arts (published by the Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford).
At first sight, Deerfield's houses seem simple. Then you notice the Baroque doorways, with overscaled broken-scroll pediments and fluted pilasters, glass fanlights and distinctive hardware. This is no ordinary village. It had 18 feet of top soil to nurture wheat, corn and tobacco. It harvested and sent timber to market down the river, and raised oxen that went to Boston to slaughter.
"Of all the interior settlements, the Connecticut Valley was the richest," said Mr. Hosley, executive director of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society in Hartford. "The valley was the dominant artistic culture and economy in the interior of the colonies in the 17th and 18th century." Several of these historic houses are still occupied by the Bement School and Deerfield Academy, founded in 1797; some are privately owned, and 14 constitute the house museums of Historic Deerfield.
"The golden age of the Connecticut River Valley was from 1750 to 1820," Donald Friary, executive director of Historic Deerfield, said. "Deerfield was a crossroads. It was on the main road to Albany and up the river from Hartford." Houses were furnished with objects from the urban centers, and local furniture was made with native woods, which were less popular in other regions: red and white oak, yellow pine, ash and maple. By 1750, cherry was the favored wood, and it was often stained to look like imported mahogany.
As Roger Gonzales, a furniture restorer and dealer in Kent, Conn., put it, "Don't forget, Connecticut Yankees were cheap." They were also into style, their own style. "The furniture makers interpreted British designs, but their emphasis is more on form than decoration," Mr. Hosley said. "They did not emphasize uniformity. For them, pizazz is achieved through exaggerated lines and robust motifs." They were not trying to copy the high style of Newport, Boston or New York.
One of the finest pieces in the loan exhibition is a four-drawer cherry chest with a scallop top made in Deerfield in 1786 by Benjamin Munn 3d. Philip Zea, the Historic Deerfield curator, said the scallop top was a popular motif. "These undulating symmetrical tops provide visual excitement in an inexpensive, two-dimensional way," he said.
Mr. Hosley emphasized that these furniture makers were doing custom work. "So they had to reinvent the wheel with every commission. You see deeply carved rosettes, undulating vines, serpentine tops, scallops and complex curves: the frontier spirit in furniture design."
Several Connecticut River Valley antiques will be auctioned at Sotheby's and Christie's this week. Christie's sale of the Bertram D. Coleman collection today includes a Queen Anne mahogany tray-top tea table from Connecticut, circa 1740. Very light in weight, it looks a bit like a yearling, with tall, spindly, elegant legs (estimate: $15,000 to $20,000). There is also a tall, exuberant Connecticut Chippendale-style cherry chest-on-chest from 1785-1800. The pediment has maple inlaid pinwheel rosettes above an inlaid patera. There is an inlaid fan above its reverse-serpentine drawers, and each of the 10 drawers is bordered with an inlay of a lighter wood, perhaps maple. (Estimate: $12,000 to $18,000.)
"In Connecticut, there is an interest in ornament and decoration to an extent you don't see in more sober centers like New York," said Dean Failey of Christie's.
Arthur Sack, a Manhattan dealer, said: "These small-town cabinetmakers were high-spirited and individualistic. Everything they do is different and experimental, sometimes even humorous." Zeke Liverant, a Colchester, Conn., dealer in business for 65 years, added: "The cabinetmakers were very imaginative. They had regional style."
And Wendell Garrett of Sotheby's said: "The exaggerated shells and acanthus leaves are almost a caricature of high-style, urban taste. In the rural translation, furniture takes on funny colloquialisms. It's artisan mannerism. It uses the same architectural motifs one sees in the doorways, mantlepieces, pilasters and pediments. There's an echo between architectural decoration and furniture decoration."
Many collectors prize such idiosyncratic interpretations. Last year, in the James Keene sale at Sotheby's, a Queen Anne cherry dressing table, circa 1770, with an undulating top set a record for a Connecticut piece: $387,500.
"Connecticut River Valley furniture has great personality," said Leslie Keno of Sotheby's. "It has human qualities. It looks as if it's walking toward you. It makes you smile."
In its Americana sale today, Sotheby's is offering a Queen Anne cherry bonnet-top chest of drawers from Connecticut, circa 1760. It has a swan's neck crest with three finials, a pinwheel in the tympanum and carved pilasters that end in fish scales and pinwheels. The fish-scale capitals have been decorated with punchwork that looks like polka dots. (Estimate: $60,000 to $80,000.)
Sotheby's is also auctioning an elegant Chippendale cherry armchair, circa 1785, attributed to an Eliphalet Chapin of East Windsor, Conn. The front legs have exaggerated cabriole legs; the rear legs are straight but round. The talons in the claw-and-ball feet are thick, "like Tootsie Rolls" said Mr. Keno, who added that this was a Chapin characteristic. (Estimate: $50,000 to $80,000.)
Stella Show Management has organized two affordable antiques shows this weekend. "Americana at the Piers" will be tomorrow and Sunday, with 400 dealers, at the Passenger Ship Terminal, Piers 90 and 92 (Hudson River at 50th Street). It includes a loan exhibition, organized by the Manhattan dealer Laura Fisher, featuring quilts made from pictorial ephemera. "Antiques at the Other Armory" is today through Sunday, with 100 dealers, at the Gramercy Park Armory (Lexington Avenue at 26th Street). Information for both shows: (212) 255-0020.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 1786 chest from Historic Deerfield, at the Seventh Regiment Armory. (Amanda Merullo/Historic Deerfield)
