SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 3249 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
The Peal of Horns Aplenty From a Big-Band Cornucopia

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
Oblivious to economics and cultural trends, the big band plays on.
You can trace the death of the big-band era, circa 1945, to social and financial realities. Gas and rubber shortages during World War II made travel expensive for touring bands; once the war ended, the un-hip suburbs sprouted, leaving live jazz behind in urban pockets. Many of the great bands broke up, spilling musicians into a thousand small groups that found it easier to survive. 
 So how come the 18-piece band led by Maria Schneider drew a capacity crowd a few weeks ago for the last Monday night of a five-year weekly engagement at the club Visiones, in the West Village? How come, at last count, there are 14 big bands in regular weekly slots at New York City jazz clubs, playing music from swing to free jazz? And how come the most accurate cross section of the city's jazz world, both players and listeners, is found at these shows?
You can theorize: Wynton Marsalis and the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra, and Jon Faddis with the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band, have toured extensively for the last 10 years, filling a near-total vacuum, inspiring young musicians' big-band dreams. Another theory is essentially the reverse of what happened 50 years ago. Touring is so expensive and difficult -- except for bands supported by a record label, or, in the case of the Lincoln Center orchestra, by corporate sponsors -- that even small groups find it hard to stay together, freeing players to spend one night a week in a club's house orchestra.
The last decade has also seen enrollments rise in university jazz programs. The products of that surge have graduated and descended upon New York looking for work. And a musician can make great strides, as well as great contacts, by playing in a regular weekly gig with a 10- to 18-piece group, even if the pay is less than cab fare.
"I've always been in one," said Steve Wilson, a saxophonist with a considerable reputation of his own, who often plays with the Mingus Big Band at the Fez, in the East Village. "People forget that even Coltrane and Bird were in big bands. It's a personality-forming experience. You're not in the spotlight all the time, and it teaches you to control your sound."
Big bands are also about having a good time. But the ritual of jazz big bands -- even without a dance floor -- is inherently social. You hear jokes and shouting, grumbles of dissent or encouragement, from both musicians and listeners. If the group performs in a small club, you're at close quarters with the band, with no fourth wall separating players from audience.
But most of all, big bands have persisted because musicians love them. "Jazz musicians have a very elemental need for groups to play in and original music to play," said Bill Kirchner, a composer and historian of big bands. "You have to create these opportunities yourself, and it's usually against all odds. Big bands are always going to be there, as long as there are jazz musicians."
Here's a look at some of the big bands you can see in and around New York over the next few weeks.
 
Vanguard Jazz Orchestra
The cornetist Thad Jones and the drummer Mel Lewis formed a big band in 1966, and it started playing Monday nights at the Village Vanguard that year. Max Gordon, then the Vanguard's owner, gave them a three-week commitment. "We're still negotiating the same contract," John Mosca said on Monday, from the trombone section of what is now called the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra.
Jones left the group in 1979 to lead the Danish Radio Big Band. (He died in 1986.) But in his 13 years of big-band writing at the Vanguard, he created a body of work that has become a jazz subculture for baby-boom cognoscenti. And you can still hear his music each Monday night at the club, as well as pieces written by the band's current composer in residence and pianist, Jim McNeely.
The Vanguard band became incorporated some years ago, which enabled it to seek grants; that's how it was able to finance the recording of "Lickety Split," an album of Mr. McNeely's compositions on the New World label that is likely to raise the band's stock and gain it some new listeners. The group likes to telescope a long chord across the brass section, luxuriating in tone; the blocks of sound that make up this big band are distinct; the harmonies and arty dissonances are articulated with beautiful clarity.
Mr. McNeely brings the entire band book, a distressed accordion folder with nearly 100 arrangements, to work with him each week, and the 15 other musicians cart along nearly as much sheet music. They could always agree on the set list earlier in the day, but that's a little too businesslike, and sort of un-jazz.
"It's like when the quarterback calls an audible," said Mr. McNeely, a large man in his late 40's who looks more like a blocker. "Sometimes you want to change your mind about what you want to do."
 
The Incubators
Mr. McNeely also teaches a seminar in orchestration at New York University and is the co-leader of the BMI Orchestra Workshop, a group of 25 or 30 New York players who convene once a month to rehearse new work written by its members. The musicians give the composers feedback, and the band plays a few concerts every year. This is one of the ways that musicians surmount the logistical difficulty of creating big-band music: rounding up 18 players with 18 schedules.
Another big-band workshop, the Composers Big Band, run for the last year in Montclair, N.J., by the pianist Diane Moser, offers more frequent public concerts. Ms. Moser, an unfazable booster for improvised music, cultivates a collection of New Jersey musicians and invites a different composer once a month to bring in new work. A local church gives her free rehearsal space (she writes church-service music in return); the band then performs the work at Tierney's Tavern, in Montclair.
One of Ms. Moser's regulars is the saxophonist and composer Oliver Lake. "I hadn't done a big band in a while," said Mr. Lake, whose last performance with one was five years ago at Town Hall in Manhattan, "and this got me back into writing." But he needed help.
Ms. Moser explained: "He had written a lot of this stuff a long time ago, and he wanted to revise it. There were sections that needed to be opened up, and other sections where he really needed to be more concise. And we let him know!"
 
Oliver Lake Big Band
With his big-band book redeveloped, Mr. Lake approached the Knitting Factory, which signed him on for every Monday this month.
The modern big-band sound funnels directly back to the Count Basie band from the 1950's, with its pinpoint blending of reeds and brass and dynamic drumming. Not Mr. Lake's. He mixes blues and gospel, funk and free; but his free jazz is never maundering. He likes players with a sense of humor and style; his pieces explode with bursts of chaotic energy but don't lose direction. Two weeks ago, his trombonist Frank Lacy took a terrific solo during which he took apart his trombone, continuing to play through the various bits of hardware.
 
Next Legacy Orchestra
Similar in style, with a lot of collective improvisation and exploratory solos over funk and swing grooves, is one of New York's best overlooked bands, the Next Legacy Orchestra, led by the saxophonist Benny Russell.
The band, in a previous incarnation, had been led for a number of years at the Knitting Factory by the saxophonist David Murray, who recently moved to Paris. Mr. Russell gave the group its present name and started focusing more on his own writing. He now leads it every Sunday night at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, a brownstone in Park Slope, where he is also a teacher and director of the jazz department.
"We have to struggle," Mr. Russell said before starting a sparsely attended concert last week, in the conservatory's large front room. "But, as Frederick Douglass said, if there's no struggle, there's no progress."
It's gratifying to stumble across New York's better players in supporting roles in these groups. The Next Legacy band includes some excellent musicians, like the pianist Roberta Piket, the trumpeters Eddie Allen and Derrick Gardner, and the alto saxophonists James Spaulding and Jorge Sylvester. These are musicians with records and other bands and careers to pursue, yet here they are, unadvertised, getting knowledge and giving it.
 
Make-Believe Ballroom Orchestra
Mr. Russell spends his Thursday evenings in the saxophone section of a different world. Swing music of the 1940's has created a little youth scene in Los Angeles for about a decade, with the musicians fitted out with suspenders, vintage shirts and cigarettes behind their ears. But I was surprised recently to walk into Swing 46, a new club on Restaurant Row, and see the same rituals being enacted in the cynical capital of the world. This is where swing dancers go, and where the jazz audience doesn't.
The segregation is a shame, because swing people are the least predictable music fans I've seen. There is absolutely no pattern or stereotype of race, age, sex, dress or affectation.
"Awright cats, on the dance floor, on the double!" yelled George Gee, a short man with thick glasses and a fedora (doffed repeatedly to reveal a buzz cut), grinning madly, completely aware of his cornball talk but also in a bit of a euphoric delirium. Mr. Gee runs the club's house band, the Make-Believe Ballroom Orchestra.
"Swing 46, where the hip meet the hep," he crowed. "Get hip, get hep, get right in step."
An out-of-practice bassist, Mr. Gee prefers to be unencumbered by an instrument. He leads the band in a Cab Calloway sort of way: as figurehead, chanter and cheerleader. He was inspired to head a big band in 1979, when as a college radio disk jockey in Pittsburgh he interviewed Count Basie. Ten years later, he sought out the Basie band's chief arranger, Frank Foster, who shared arrangements with him.
Mr. Gee then connected with the New York Swing Dance Society, which now holds its dances every Sunday night at Irving Plaza, and his band began to build a reputation. He's busy with weekly engagements, parties and national battle-of-the-bands tours.
Playing tunes like Basie's "Broadway" and Benny Goodman's "Roll 'Em," the band is unself-consciously retro with no ironic spin. The surprise for a fan of new jazz is that the band is full of good musicians seen elsewhere around town, not just Sunday duffers.
 
Ghost Bands
There are three bands in regular rotation now that exclusively play the music and style of deceased band leaders: ghost bands as they're called.
The Mingus Big Band, a success from its six years of weekly appearances at the Fez in the East Village, is perhaps the best embodiment of a band flourishing on the existing pool of talent in New York. Its players frequently tour and follow other commitments, but Sue Mingus, the widow of the composer and bassist Charles Mingus, has assembled a pool of substitute players large enough to make eight big bands. She has also organized several recordings; the most recent is "Que Viva Mingus" (Dreyfus).
The group has been an important force in New York's jazz scene during this decade; some of the younger musicians who have gotten a boost out of playing with the band include the star saxophonists James Carter, Mark Shim and Chris Potter.
Also at the Fez, on many Sunday nights, is the 18-piece Sun Ra Arkestra. (Its next appearance is set for Feb. 1.) Sun Ra died in 1993, and the band, once a Philadelphia-based collective, is now mostly New Yorkers. But it's run by the Arkestra's long-standing alto saxophonist, Marshall Allen, whose Johnny Hodges-like smeared glissandos embody the eccentric dreaminess that the band is all about. The 90-tune repertory is full of the band's old numbers like "Interstellar Low Ways," as well as untraditional (for a jazz group) choices of standards like "Ol' Man River" and "Over the Rainbow."
Much else is untraditional about the band: there are three percussionists and two baritone saxophonists. On a recent Sunday, Art Jenkins sat in the trumpet section, but had only a megaphone in his hands, through which he howled his parts. And at one point, he transformed himself into a baritone crooner, belting out "When You Wish Upon a Star."
A benign raggedness is the band's latter-day trademark, though not an indispensable element of the music; I hope some better-known New Yorkers might drift into its ranks, a la Mingus band, and change the formula a little. It's easy to imagine, for instance, the saxophonist James Carter and the pianist Rodney Kendrick bolstering its wild sound, although Mr. Allen apparently has no desire to have another pianist replace the departed leader.
Upon the death of Mercer Ellington last February, his son, Paul Mercer Ellington, a 19-year-old high school senior, became the leader of the frequently touring Duke Ellington Orchestra. Paul learned to conduct by watching videotapes of Duke Ellington, his grandfather, and later studied composition, conducting and piano with the pianist Tommy James, who has been with the band for 10 years.
Starting this week, the group plays on Tuesday nights at Birdland, and Mr. Ellington will mix his own compositions into his grandfather's repertory.
"I'm concerned a little bit with fulfilling expectations," Mr. Ellington said. "But it's not that hard. I do write like my grandfather when I write for the big band."
The band, which I haven't heard at Birdland, respects the audience's frequent calls for "Take the A Train" and "Sophisticated Lady," but its book also includes some of Duke Ellington's lesser-known work, like his sacred music and parts of the "Far East Suite," his mid-1960's masterpiece.
 
Other Bands
Birdland has invested heavily in big bands, settling regular Mondays for Toshiko Akiyoshi's excellent 70's-era modernism and Sundays for Chico O'Farrill's group.
The 76-year-old Mr. O'Farrill is the living symbol of Afro-Cuban music's marriage to jazz in the be-bop era. He wrote music for Benny Goodman, Dizzy Gillespie and Machito, including the famous "Afro-Cuban Suite." With his son, Arturo, at the piano, Mr. O'Farrill conducts the band through his own intricately structured compositions, as well as idiosyncratic arrangements of tunes like "Perdido" and "Chicago." He revived his big-band career a few years ago, and this is the first time he has had a regular engagement.
The city's tiniest clubs are even following suit. Chuck Clark's 10-piece band takes up a third of the Internet Cafe, in the East Village, on many Monday nights; its next appearance is on March 9. Across town, Jason Lindner, a 25-year-old pianist with a clean and swinging style, has led a big band on Monday nights at Smalls in the West Village for three years.
Though Mr. Lindner writes most of the group's music, like the best band leaders, he encourages its players to contribute pieces. Mr. Lindner enrolled in an orchestration course while studying at the New School but ditched it after a couple of classes. Accordingly, his band doesn't have a studied sound but seems to arise more naturally from the capabilities of its individual voices.
It's a soloist's band, dense with promising new talent like the tenor saxophonists Jimmy Greene, Greg Tardy and Charles Owens; the bassist Omer Avital, and the percussionist Khalil Kwame Bell. The sound of the band has been captured on a new Impulse records sampler, "Live at Smalls."
"I guess the bumper stickers are right," said Jim McNeely, laughing. "The big bands are back."
The point is, they never left.
 
Rows and Rows of the Finest Virtuosos
 
Here is a sampling of forthcoming big-band performances in clubs and halls in the New York metropolitan region:
 
BROOKLYN CONSERVATORY OF MUSIC, 58 Seventh Avenue, at Lincoln Place, Park Slope. The Next Legacy Orchestra. Every Sunday at 7 and 9 P.M. Admission, $10. Information: (718) 622-3300.
BIRDLAND, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton. Chico O'Farrill's Afro-Cuban Jazz Orchestra, every Sunday at 9 and 11 P.M. HEADLINE: Observer;
Poor Old Mister Money

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
The excesses associated with Sodom and Gomorrah, the last days of Pompeii and the administration of Ulysses S. Grant are now visible in New York.
Nowhere is the grossness of the age more obvious or more loathsome than in New York's real-estate market. This isn't surprising. Real estate is to New York what the after-dinner orgy was to Rome. 
 Nothing lights a fire in the New York eye or makes New York blood pound faster than news of a real-estate desperado extracting the wealth of the Indies from some hapless customer. Nothing makes the New Yorker roar with pleasure more surely than a ghoulish tale of competing apartment hunters racing the undertaker over a threshold where the lone occupant of a decent apartment has just wheezed his last.
Such was the stuff that passed for Manhattan dinner conversation even in the not-so-good-old days before the new barbarianism burst out of Wall Street. Now that the gutters are awash in money, real-estate stories reflect a state of depravity too advanced to be expunged by a mere 40 days and 40 nights of rain.
Just last week The New York Times carried a story that must have repelled every civilized reader. That The Times was willing to print it testifies to the integrity with which the paper pursues its obligation to keep the public fully informed.
The subject was the rental price of Manhattan housing for the well-to-do. Disgusting though it be to read about, landlords are now charging $25,000 a month for their fancier digs.
That's $300,000 a year after taxes, which, in New York, can strip the conscientious citizen of nearly 50 percent of his paycheck. It is dizzying to go on. A $300,000 rental requires $600,000 in pre-tax earnings, and doesn't even yield equity.
That's not rent, it's a bank heist. What's more, the tenant still doesn't have any groceries, car insurance, tip money for the doorman, skis for the slopes at Aspen, or the scratch needed to put his youthful produce into Manhattan's private schools.
Public school would be madness. Once word got around the playground that the youngster's father was paying $300,000 in rent, somebody, possibly the principal, would be tempted to try his skill at kidnapping for ransom. Private schools know this, and charge accordingly.
But enough with arithmetic. We are talking obviously of people who have transcended normal humanity's money problems.
There have always been such fortunate souls, but except for buying Rembrandts and building castles in Newport they have generally hewn wisely to the theory that flaunting it is not only vulgar, but also bad economic policy.
Provoking the envy of the impecunious may bring churls into the streets with sticks and stones and -- worse! -- result in a hike in the tax rate on capital gains. Better to reassure the poor devils that money can't buy happiness.
The great bull market of the Clinton Age has done for conspicuous consumption what free agency has done for baseball players. It has made excess a way of life.
In some ways the worst of it is what has happened to money's reputation. Once, money was a thing to be respected. Now it's a trivial thing created with a piece of plastic at an A.T.M.
It's a blip on a computer screen, it's a meaningless tonnage of paper shipped to real-estate agents in boxcar lots. This is a terrible thing that has happened to Old Mister Money.
All the dignity has been squeezed out of him. Anyone nowadays who referred to the dollar as "the iron man" or praised something for being "sound as a dollar" would be considered a lunatic.
Can you still be corrupted by love of money now that money is no longer lovable, but only laughable, like the Ralph Bellamy character too laughable to get the girl?
The Times story on rentals reported that 60 properties each fetched over $300,000 in rentals last year. One agent, Beatrice Ducrot, told of offering a rental on Central Park West at $27,000 a month: nine rooms "and a handful of terraces."
She had "people lined up, three or four deep. . . . it rented in a day. These tycoons do not just wait around," she observed.
Indeed, why should our tycoons wait around? Dawdle too long and angry Vesuvius may catch you disgracefully long on cash.

HEADLINE: On Wall St., Fervent Plea For Minorities

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson exhorted Wall Street and the nation's business managers yesterday to offer decent investment and job opportunities to blacks and other minorities. The call came on the first day of an unusual gathering of business, political and labor leaders at the World Trade Center to discuss issues of race and opportunity in America.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. "understood that equal opportunity required entry into the marketplace and access to jobs, education and private investment," Mr. Jackson said, invoking his mentor, whose birthday will be celebrated on Monday. The purpose of the Wall Street conference, Mr. Jackson said, is "to expand the marketplace to offer opportunity to all." 
 Mr. Jackson yesterday drew support from President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who both came to New York City to address the meeting. "Our economy is going to fall far short of its potential unless it is for all of us," Mr. Rubin told the conference in his speech yesterday morning, arguing that offering more opportunities to minorities is good for profits. "Inclusion," he said, "is critical to the bottom line."
Such words seemed to echo Mr. Jackson's own themes. "We'll pay for not investing; we're in one big tent," Mr. Jackson told reporters earlier this week, as he discussed the Wall Street conference, arguing for a fairer allocation of resources that would direct more toward inner cities, blacks and other minorities.
Mr. Jackson also said this week that his coalition was acquiring small stockholdings in a number of big companies, allowing it to monitor, and lobby, on minority hiring and procurement practices to insure the companies paid sufficient attention to minority interests. He did not identify the possible companies.
"Rikers Island is a more expensive university than N.Y.U.," Mr. Jackson said, referring to the cost of running New York's crowded state jail. "What's missing in this dialogue has been corporate America. They must lead the way on making the case, as educators and in skills and training. There is this wealth gap here. The biggest since 1929."
The conference, at Windows on the World atop the World Trade Center, is the first annual gathering of the Rainbow/PUSH coalition that Mr. Jackson leads. The coalition opened an office on Wall Street a year ago to draw attention to minority issues and to lobby the country's financial leaders on their home ground.
This week's gathering attracted hundreds of businessmen and financiers, including many blacks, and several top Wall Street executives and corporate leaders, including Jacques Nasser of the Ford Motor Company; John S. Chalsty, the chairman and chief executive of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a unit of Equitable and James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney Inc., a subsidiary of Travelers Group.
Mr. Dimon, whose firm is one of three co-sponsors of the conference along with the New York Stock Exchange and Rainbow/PUSH, addressed executives during the conference's morning session, commending his own firm's approach to diversity and its stated intention to reward those managers who seek out and hire sufficient numbers of women and minorities.
These new policies resulted from the settlement of a class-action lawsuit brought by more than 20 Smith Barney women employees, which contended that the company had frequently shown gender bias and that there had been substantial sexual harassment in the workplace.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Securities End Mixed After New Inflation Warning

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday after bouncing around a bit on weakness in the stock market, an inflation warning from a senior Federal Reserve official, new evidence of an economic slowdown and a glut of corporate bond offerings.
The 30-year bond fell 4/32, to a price of 105 15/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.74 percent from 5.73 percent. Short-term maturities rose in price. 
 Bonds initially advanced in reaction to a sharp selloff overnight in the Hong Kong stock market on resilient anxiety about the impact of the financial crisis in Asia. Concerns about Asia also contributed to weakness on Wall Street and sent some investors into the safe haven of the bond market.
But prices declined after Susan M. Phillips, a Fed governor, said in a speech that labor shortages could contribute to higher wages, "which can then turn into inflation."
Her remarks were interpreted as a sign that the central bank has not ruled out an increase in interest rates to thwart inflationary pressure, despite prevailing evidence that inflation remains benign and that the financial crisis in Asia is likely to mean steady or lower rates.
John Canavan, a markets analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, said bonds were also pressured lower by a regional Philadelphia Fed survey, a barometer of broader trends, that showed an unexpected surge in manufacturing.
But other evidence of a possible economic slowing also emerged. The Commerce Department reported the 17th consecutive monthly increase in business inventories during November, and the Labor Department reported an unexpected rise in weekly jobless claims to a five-month high. Even in the Philadelphia Fed survey, manufacturers reported sharply lower inflation pressure and their outlook for the the next six months was pessimistic.
Nearly $4 billion in new corporate debt also contributed to weakness in long-term bond prices. Many companies are rushing to sell debt to take advantage of the lowest long-term financing costs in years.
Doug Burtnick, a managing analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the absorption of this new corporate debt had made it more difficult to interpret the market's behavior.
"When you add in the continuing evolving situation in Asia and what looks like a strong inverse tick-for-tick correlation with the stock market," Mr. Burtnick said, "bonds promise to be more of a technical beast than a real read on the economy."

HEADLINE: Dun & Bradstreet Spinoff Will Split in Two

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 15

 BODY:
The Cognizant Corporation, one of three companies created by a breakup of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said today that it would split into a separate television ratings business and a provider of health care information.
Cognizant said the breakup would enable each business to focus on its core operations. 
 One company will be Nielsen Media Research, which collects television ratings, and the other will be IMS Health, which gathers health care information.
"These two operating businesses have fundamentally different growth outlooks, operating characteristics and customer requirements," said Robert E. Weissman, the chairman and chief executive of Cognizant. He said they would be more valuable to shareholders as separate companies.
Shares of Cognizant gained $1.125, to $46.
Cognizant shareholders will receive a tax-free dividend of one share of IMS Health stock for each Cognizant share. Once the breakup is completed this summer, Cognizant plans to call itself Nielsen Media Research.
The split is subject to approval from the Internal Revenue Service and Cognizant's board.
In January 1996, Dun & Bradstreet announced a three-way split into Cognizant, a reorganized Dun & Bradstreet and A. C. Nielsen, which tracks consumer retail buying.

HEADLINE: Korea Opposes Plan by U.S. Banks to Repackage Loans

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
In a blow to American banks, the South Korean Government opposes a debt refinancing plan put forward by the banks, which will meet on Wednesday with Korean officials to discuss how to repackage as much as $28 billion in short-term loans that are smothering the beleaguered nation's economy.
American commercial bankers said prospects had dimmed that South Korea would accept a plan devised by J. P. Morgan & Company to exchange private-sector loans for longer-term debt guaranteed by the Government. 
 "Things don't look good for us," said one American banker involved in the negotiations.
The apparent failure of the J. P. Morgan proposal to find immediate favor with the Government does not mean South Korea is shut off from considering other refinancing options. In fact, the country must consider other options because its economy remains on life support with assistance from international lending agencies like the International Monetary Fund. Without such aid, and temporary loan-forgiveness from international banks, South Korea's Government and corporations would be in default.
And with South Korean officials set to arrive in New York next week to meet with international bankers from Europe, Japan and the United States, the Government's hardened stance toward the J. P. Morgan proposal may be nothing more than a pre-negotiating ploy.
Nonetheless, American bankers believe the South Koreans' thinking has turned against them.
With South Korean financial markets showing renewed vigor and many international banks supporting a plan to extend payment on, or roll over, most of South Korea's short-term loans until March 31, the South Korean Government has every reason to believe it has a stronger hand to play with the banks.
"I certainly think they've gotten more comfortable over the last week," an American commercial banker said.
The J. P. Morgan plan, which the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Citicorp also support, has had many variations since it was first presented informally to South Korea at the end of December. The current plan, known as Version 3.0, as if it were a software title, is valued at approximately $25 billion. It calls for a new $10 billion bond offering to replenish Government reserves, while a remaining undetermined portion would be split between a debt exchange and longer-term debt extensions, or rollovers, guaranteed by the Government. New bonds would be issued in a public auction.
Long-term rollovers were not originally part of the plan but are now included because Japanese and German banks, South Korea's two largest creditor groups, prefer them as a way of maintaining relationships with South Korean clients. Nonetheless, the revisions are still not entirely in keeping with how the Government perceives its interests.
Although the South Koreans would like to refinance their debt as soon as possible, they are wary of a bond auction that could require them to pay onerous interest rates should there be a lack of investors willing to buy the bonds. In previous meetings with the banks, the South Koreans have expressed a desire for a negotiated, or fixed, rate on the bonds. That stance, however, also might make the bonds less attractive to investors who consider the interest rate to be be too low for the risk.
The South Korean delegation meeting at Citicorp's headquarters next week will include Kim Yong Hwan, director of President-elect Kim Dae Jung's emergency economic committee; You Jong Keun, an economic adviser to Mr. Kim; Chung Dok Ku, vice minister of finance for the outgoing Government, and Chung In Yong, the ambassador for international financial affairs.

HEADLINE: Nation's Biggest Atomic Utility to Shut 2 Units

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan 15

 BODY:
In the biggest retreat from nuclear power to date, Commonwealth Edison said today it would close 2 of its 12 nuclear generators because they were too expensive to operate now that the industry was being deregulated.
Commonwealth Edison, the nation's largest private operator of nuclear plants, said closing the two plants, which sit side by side on Lake Michigan in Zion, Ill., 40 miles north of Chicago, was purely economic. 
 But anti-nuclear advocates noted that Zion's woes had been compounded by a long history of labor and safety problems. Last fall, the nuclear industry's own watchdog organization issued a scathing review of operations at Zion and other Commonwealth Edison plants.
The case for closing Zion rather than trying to upgrade it and return it to service was "overwhelming," said James J. O'Connor, chairman and chief executive of Commonwealth Edison's parent, the Unicom Corporation of Chicago.
Nuclear power accounted for about 20 percent of the nation's electricity output last year, down slightly from 21.9 percent 1996.
Although some states, including Illinois, will remain highly reliant on nuclear power for years, analysts expect the overall share to decline steadily in the next two decades because no new plants are under construction in the United States.
The decision to close Zion came just one day after Northeast Utilities, the owner of the three Millstone nuclear plants at Waterford, Conn., said it had indefinitely suspended efforts to reopen Millstone 1, the smallest and oldest of the units. Many utilities are also shutting down aging or heavily polluting coal-fired plants to prepare for stiffer price competition.
The Zion generators, each capable of producing 1,000 megawatts, were the largest nuclear plants in the nation when they came on line in 1973 and 1974. Safety and maintenance problems had led the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to put them on its watch list of troubled plants. One has been idle since September of 1996 and the other since February 1997.
The enormous cost of closing Zion will be reflected in an accounting charge of $515 million, or $2.38 a share, against Unicom's fourth-quarter earnings. But Wall Street, which had been anticipating and urging the Zion closing, was undisturbed. Unicom's shares dipped 25 cents to close at $30.6875.
"It shows they are evaluating all their resources in the context of a competitive market, which is what we expect," said Samuel Brothwell, who follows the company for Merrill Lynch in New York.
The closing is not expected to affect the reliability of service in northern Illinois, where Commonwealth Edison serves 3.4 million customers. The generators at Zion will be replaced with equipment to help Commonwealth Edison manage its network more efficiently. The utility is also investing in transmission lines and energy efficiency programs to adjust its capacity and the demand. Spent fuel will be stored on site until 2014, the year final decommissioning is scheduled to begin.
Mr. O'Connor, Unicom's chairman, insisted that the closing did not mean that Commonwealth Edison could not safely manage its 12 nuclear properties.
Critics were skeptical.
"They've done the right thing, but they didn't have any choice," said Howard Learner, executive director of the Environmental Law and Policy Center, a Chicago research group.
Mr. Learner said the Zion closing was only the first step needed to convince Federal regulators that the company could break away from its dismal track record of having new problems crop up in its nuclear portfolio just as it was attacking old ones. In addition to Zion, 4 other Commonwealth Edison plants are on the nuclear commission's watch list, and only 4 of the 12 are now generating electricity.
Mr. Learner predicted that at least two of the other troubled units, those near LaSalle, Ill., would also have to be closed in the next year or two to allow Commonwealth Edison to better focus its oversight efforts. He cited reports this week that poor management of the Quad Cities nuclear plant near Moline, which was shut down late last year after violating safety procedures, could land it on the commission's watch list just as the two improving Dresden units near Morris, Ill., come off the list.
Commonwealth Edison admitted at a meeting with regional commission officials on Wednesday that it had lost its focus on safety at Quad Cities.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Earnings Reports Push Major Stock Market Indexes Down

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Uncertainty about the outlook for corporate earnings pushed investors toward the exits yesterday as major stock market indexes posted their first declines of the week.
As the pace of quarterly earnings reports begins to quicken, investors are not getting a clear picture of how expectations of slower economic growth in the United States and the financial crisis in Asia will affect American companies. A mild euphoria brought about by positive earnings surprises from companies like Intel and Apple Computer earlier this week was tempered yesterday by mixed results from companies like Eastman Kodak and Unisys. 
 "There's this feeling from investors that they don't know which way to go," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York.
"Some companies are saying we've made it through the battle, but the war is not over," Mr. Bond said. Intel, for example, recorded strong fourth-quarter revenue, which fueled Tuesday's market rally, but the company warned that first-quarter 1998 earnings may be flat and that profit margins could shrink this year.
The reports yesterday from Unisys and Eastman Kodak -- both companies' results were hurt by big one-time charges, though operating earnings were generally in line with expectations -- helped drag blue-chip stocks lower. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 92.92 points, or 1.2 percent, to 7,691.77. The index had gained 204.27 points earlier in the week. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index slipped 7.21 points, to 950.73. It had gained 30.25 points in the previous three days.
But the Nasdaq composite index fared much better, closing at 1,547.06, down 1.70 points, hardly denting the week's 45-point advance. The technology-laden index was buoyed by a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report from Sun Microsystems.
Earlier, Wall Street was rattled by further volatility in Asian markets. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell more than 7 percent yesterday on fears that a large commercial property company could face financial problems, while Indonesia's benchmark stock index fell 4.1 percent. But South Korea's main index gained 6.5 percent.
In the United States, the Government reported further signs of slowing economic growth. Business inventories rose four-tenths of a percent in November, to a seasonally adjusted $1.04 trillion, the 17th month without a decline, while business sales slipped two-tenths of a percent, to $758.1 billion, the Commerce Department said.
Also, the Labor Department said first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose by 3,000 last week, to 335,000, the highest since mid-August. Economists had expected a slight decline.
With economic output showing signs of moderating, investors are grappling with the prospects of slower earnings growth at the same time that some stocks are still considered to be expensive, said Richard Cripps, chief investment strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc.
When fourth-quarter earnings are released, it is common for companies to give investors a view about the coming year. This year, corporate officers seem less sanguine about growth prospects. "In the past they were a bit more optimistic," Mr. Cripps said.
However, a bright spot for stock market investors can be gleaned from the recent decline in long-term interest rates, shown by the 30-year Treasury bond yield's decline from 5.92 percent at the end of 1997 to 5.74 yesterday, said John Ballen, chief equity officer at Massachusetts Financial Services.
"Lower interest rates have made stocks look cheaper despite the declining earnings," Mr. Ballen said. "But it's confusing people, because lower interest rates are good, but declining earnings are not good. If you were a purist, with interest rates lower, stocks should go up."
The uncertainty continues to aid companies whose businesses are largely domestically focused, analysts said. One indication of this is the modest decline this year in Morgan Stanley's index of consumer-oriented companies, which is down 1.1 percent. That compares with a 2.6 percent decline in the firm's index of 30 cyclical, or economically sensitive, stocks, which includes companies like Allied Signal, Citicorp and Motorola.
Analysts anticipate that health care companies, drugstore chains and food retailers should do well in this environment.

HEADLINE: Officials, Fearing Falling Masonry, Close Sidewalk

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
The police blocked off the sidewalk in front of a Times Square hotel yesterday after building inspectors determined that masonry on the facade was in danger of falling.
Guests were not forced to leave the hotel, the Carter, at 250 West 43d Street, but those who chose to leave were told by the city that they could not return until the building owner had installed a construction canopy to protect passers-by. The canopy was completed last night, and officials began to let guests return.
 The Buildings Department issued a violation against the owner last month, giving him until Feb. 2 to repair defects like cracks, chips and bulging lintels and to hire an engineer to assess the building's stability. But officials decided that they could not wait after an inspector returned to the 24-story hotel on Tuesday and found that no work had been done, said the Buildings Commissioner, Gaston Silva. 
 On March 4, an engineer inspected the facade and issued a report in which he "strongly recommended that the brickwork, which can become loose in the not-too-distant future, be replaced as soon as possible." The report, by Alan D. Marcus of the Rand Engineering Company, described many defects and said that most of the windows on the top six floors had "cracked, bulged lintel line brickwork and joints."
But Mr. Marcus concluded that "no unsafe conditions were detected," despite the need for "precautionary repair work."
On Jan. 9, security officers at The New York Times, across the street from the hotel, found a brick chunk on the sidewalk outside the newspaper and complained to the Buildings Department that the hotel was performing masonry work without netting to protect pedestrians.
Mr. Silva said yesterday that the city could not determine whether the brick had fallen from the hotel.
Neither the hotel owner, Truong Tran, nor his lawyers at the firm of Levy, Boonshoft & Lichtenberg responded to telephone calls yesterday.
The announcement of an "emergency condition" was the latest of several alarming incidents around the city, including falling masonry at a midtown building on Madison Avenue, the collapse of a building near Times Square and the death of a 16-year-old who was struck by construction debris that fell from scaffolding at a school in Brooklyn.
In November, lawyers for the Hotel Carter complained that the demolition of a row of buildings on 42d Street to make way for a new entertainment and hotel complex was causing vibrations and cracks in the rear wall of the hotel, forcing some residents to leave. The hotel obtained a court order to halt the demolition. But that was lifted two days later, after an inspection by the Buildings Department.
The department has not found any evidence that the excavation intensified the problems with the facade, a spokeswoman, Ilyse Fink, said.
Richard M. Keilar, senior vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, the developer of the complex, said his company had observed cracks in the hotel facade before the excavation began. "We have not caused any damage to his building," Mr. Keilar said.
The Building Department, Ms. Fink said, has not determined whether the excavation caused a vacant building at 231 West 42d Street to collapse on Dec. 30, the day before 500,000 thousand people gathered nearby to ring in the new year. Ms. Fink said officials expected that investigation to take several weeks.
Mr. Marcus's report was submitted to the Buildings Department under a 1980 law that requires buildings six stories or higher to be examined by an engineer every five years. Had Mr. Marcus described the building as unsafe, instead of needing precautionary work, the department would have taken immediate action against the owner, Ms. Fink said.
Mr. Marcus was out of town yesterday. The operations director of Rand Engineering, Stephen Varone, said the building would have been designated as unsafe only if the inspector believed that the masonry was in immediate peril of falling.
Because the emergency involved only the exterior, residents were not required to leave, and no figures were available on how many remained. The Housing Preservation and Development Commissioner, Richard E. Roberts, said 23 guests went to a makeshift center a block away, including two who needed help in finding temporary housing. One other person, a tourist, was referred to a hotel, said Chris Wood, a spokeswoman for the Red Cross.
Maureen LeRoy said she had been at the Carter for two weeks because she was unemployed and "between apartments." As Ms. LeRoy left to move in with friends, she said she was not going to miss the hotel.
"Nothing works," Ms. LeRoy said. "There's no hot water, no heat, and the sink doesn't work. I feel like I should get my money back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A guest, Maureen LeRoy, leaving the Carter Hotel yesterday after officials said that masonry was in danger of falling. Ms. LeRoy, who was going to move in with friends, said she would not miss the hotel. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Sun Microsytems Earnings Are Stronger Than Expected

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems Inc. reported stronger-than-expected earnings for its fiscal second quarter today as the company continued to evade the Asian economic crisis and the Microsoft Corporation's relentless assault on its core market.
Sun executives said that major corporations were still choosing their work stations and servers, running their Solaris version of the Unix operating system, over Microsoft's Windows NT for the most critical tasks.
During the quarter ending last month, Sun, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., announced plans to create a version of Solaris that would run on the Intel Corporation's forthcoming 64-bit microprocessor, and that Tele-Communications Inc., or TCI, would incorporate Sun's Java programming into its cable TV set-top box specifications. 
 "Reasonably soon, this taint of the assumption that NT is the tidal wave that will drown them is going to go away, and the second quarter is a good indication of that," said Daniel Kunstler, an analyst with J. P. Morgan. "Sun could very well be the star of this quarterly earnings season."
For the quarter, Sun made $149.4 million, or 38 cents a share, down 16 percent, from income of $178.3 million, or 46 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Earnings in the quarter reflected charges of $110.1 million related to acquisitions.
Without the charges, Sun had earnings of $223.2 million, or 57 cents a share, up 24 percent from a year earlier. Securities analysts had expected the company to earn 54 cents, according to First Call, the research firm. Revenue grew 17.7 percent, to $2.45 billion, from $2.08 billion in the second quarter of fiscal 1997.
"It was really a very, very solid performance all around," said Stephen Smith of Paine Webber. "They basically did very well at the high end of the server market, but they've just launched a new desktop product line, and yet that business held up well during the quarter as well."
Sun Microsystems stock closed today at $43.0625, up 75 cents, in Nasdaq trading of nearly nine million shares. The company reported its results after the market closed.
Two other computing companies, Digital Equipment and Unisys, reported mixed results, with Digital modestly above Wall Street expectations, and Unisys about 2 cents short, not including a one-time charge that resulted in a loss.
For its second quarter, which ended on Dec. 27, Digital reported earnings of $74.8 million, or 44 cents a share, more than double the $31.9 million, or 15 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter dropped slightly to $3.32 billion, compared with $3.36 billion reported in the similar quarter the previous year.
Analysts expected Digital to earn 43 cents a share, according to First Call. The company's shares rose $1.875 to close at $39.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Unisys reported a net loss of $965.7 million, compared with net income of $43.6 million, or 14 cents a share, in the comparable period the year before. Revenue rose 4.8 percent, to $1.90 billion, from $1.81 billion in the fourth quarter of 1996.
The Unisys results reflected a one-time charge of $1.1 billion, including the write-off of $884 million in good will related to the 1986 merger of Burroughs and Sperry; $127 million mainly related to personal computer operations, and $42 million related to the conversion of $271 million in debt. Without the charge, Unisys earned 25 cents a share; analysts had expected 27 cents, according to First Call. Its shares declined 68.75 cents to close at $15.375.

HEADLINE: Arabs Want Israel to Feel U.S. Pressure

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 15

 BODY:
With the Israeli Government taking a tougher stand on Middle East peace, Arab leaders are making clear their hope that President Clinton will use a meeting in Washington next week to take unparalleled steps to persuade Israel to change course.
In private conversations, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria in particular has become increasingly blunt, according to Western diplomats, in saying that Washington must turn up the heat on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel if it does not want the quest for a broader peace to collapse altogether. 
 And even in public, the usually circumspect Syrian leader has suggested that the position on any broader peace with the Palestinians that was adopted this week by the Israeli Government should have demonstrated even to Mr. Netanyahu's supporters in Washington that he has no real commitment to peace.
"It is clear that the Arabs are not the ones who kill peace and the peace process, but the Israelis," Mr. Assad said here late Wednesday night after an unexpected meeting with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. "The whole world knows and says that the Arabs cling fast to the peace process; others do not."
The Egyptian Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, has publicly warned that the situation has become so fragile that the peace effort is in danger of disintegration unless American intervention next week can produce some kind of confidence-building reconciliation between Israel and the Palestinians.
Noting that the Clinton Administration has voiced disappointment at the position taken by the Israeli Government, some prominent Syrians have even suggested in interviews that the meeting next week should serve as an occasion for Washington to use financial pressure.
They hope that Mr. Clinton will threaten to withhold some of the $3 billion in military and economic aid that is provided by the United States to Israel each year unless Israel shows a willingness to reconsider its peace stands.
The talks here between Mr. Assad and Mr. Mubarak, which were announced only as they began, were the clearest sign of a widening Arab alarm over the new Israeli stand.
Mr. Assad's spokesman, Jubran Kourieh, said today that the main focus of the talks had been "the peace process and the dangerous situation it reached because of the negative attitude of the Israeli Government."
The meeting scheduled for next Tuesday between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Netanyahu is to be followed by another on Thursday between the President and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.
The sessions have been widely expected to focus on the perilous relations between Israel and the Palestinians. But in private meetings in Damascus with American members of Congress and other visitors in recent days, Mr. Assad has also suggested that Mr. Clinton use his time with Mr. Netanyahu to try to salvage negotiations between Israel and Syria, which have not held peace talks at all since Mr. Netanyahu took office 18 months ago.
Mr. Netanyahu has refused to resume talks under a framework worked out between Syrian negotiators and his Labor Party predecessors, which would have seen Israel withdraw fully from the Golan Heights in return for security assurances and a full peace.
The hard line that Mr. Netanyahu has taken in his separate talks with the Syrians has left Mr. Assad to publicly despair of the prospect that peace talks with Syria could ever be restarted while Mr. Netanyahu remains in office. In the past, the Syrian Government has consistently disparaged Mr. Arafat for his decision to make a separate peace with Israel, and until now Damascus has insisted that it will now take its own steps toward any peace with Israel without respect to what happens between Israel and the Palestinians.
But the sympathy felt across the Arab world for Mr. Arafat in the face of Mr. Netanyahu's treatment of him is now resonating so deeply in Syria that one Western diplomat said, "It is an open question at this point whether Assad would engage now in the absence of real progress on the Palestinian track."
At the same time, however, diplomats say Syrian officials are bristling over the neglect shown by Washington toward the Israeli-Syrian track over the last year as Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and the American special envoy, Dennis B. Ross, have devoted the bulk of their efforts in the Middle East toward trying to salvage prospects of a permanent peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
The diplomats said that Mr. Assad told a visiting American Congressional delegation last week that next week's meeting should serve as an occasion for Mr. Clinton to urge Mr. Netanyahu to be more open to the prospect of resuming talks with the Syrians in a way consistent with the conditional assurance provided by Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin as early as July 1994.
It was at that time, American and Israeli officials have said, that Mr. Rabin told Secretary of State Warren Christopher that Israel would be willing to withdraw from the Golan Heights to the lines that were in place before the 1967 war in return for security assurances and the full normalization of relations between the two countries.
That assurance was the basis of talks between Syria and Israel that reached their peak at the Wye Plantation, a conference center in Maryland, in early 1996. The talks were halted after a series of bombings in Israel.

HEADLINE: 10,000 Jobs Must Be Cut, Seagate Says

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Seagate Technology Inc., the world's largest maker of disk drives for personal computers, said yesterday that it would dismiss 10 percent of its employees, or about 10,000 workers, as it struggles to cope with pressure from its competitors and a cooling market for its products.
The company announced last week that it would take $250 million in charges against its earnings for the quarter ended last month as it tried to streamline its operations. It said yesterday that the charge, equal to about 98 cents a share, would help cover the cost of the layoffs. 
 The company, which is based in Scotts Valley, Calif., did not announce how much it expected to save as a result of the cuts, saying only that it intended to explain more of the financial implications of the move when it releases its latest quarterly financial results on Tuesday.
A Seagate spokeswoman said that 1,350 of the layoffs would occur in the United States, 1,120 in Europe and the remainder -- about 7,530 -- in Asia. Most of the cuts in this country will be in California, Minnesota and Oklahoma. Ireland will bear the brunt of the European dismissals. The Asian cuts will be concentrated in Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand.
The Asian countries are already reeling from financial crises. Seagate said that a weakening of demand for its products in Asia had made a minor contribution to the need for the layoffs.
"This is necessary to realign our operation with the decline in revenue that we've experienced over the last nine months," said Donald L. Waite, Seagate's chief financial officer.
"There's been really intense competition and some oversupply in the industry," Mr. Waite said, "resulting in intense pricing pressure and a softness, particularly in what we call the high end of the business, the high-performance drives which are used for high-performance systems, work stations, mainframes."
Hard disk drives made by Seagate and other companies, such as I.B.M., the Quantum Corporation and the Western Digital Corporation, are used by computers to store large amounts of information even when the machines are turned off. Hard disk drives generally cannot be removed as easily as the small disks that most computer users can insert into the front of a personal computer.
The disk drive industry in general has been battered since around the middle of last year because of severe overcapacity.
Yesterday's announcement was the third bit of bad news from Seagate in the last five weeks.
Twice since early December the company has warned Wall Street analysts that results for its second fiscal quarter would be disappointing. Analysts polled by Zacks, a financial research firm, estimated that Seagate would post an operating loss of 17 cents a share for the quarter.
But the price of Seagate's stock has tumbled since May, when it traded as high as $54.25. The company made the announcement yesterday after major financial markets closed. Earlier, Seagate shares rose 50 cents, to $19.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts say many of the industry's woes are a result of aggressive expansion earlier this decade, when it appeared that the market for personal computers, and hence for disk drives, would continue to blossom.
But the PC market has not grown as quickly as anticipated, and many corporations are now directing their information technology budgets toward faster communications networks rather than toward more capable desktop machines.
Quantum announced yesterday that its quarterly earnings were 10 percent below those of the comparable period a year ago. The company said that before special charges it had earned $47 million, or 29 cents a share, down from $52.4 million, or 36 cents a share, in the comparable period of 1996.
"Demand has been just a bit softer than people had originally expected," said David Takata, an analyst for Gruntal & Company in Beverly Hills, Calif. "That alone shouldn't have thrown the industry into such a tailspin, but it coupled with the fact that everyone overbuilt in trying to capture market share."
Mr. Waite, Seagate's chief financial officer, said that the company got about 17 percent of its sales in the Far East during the quarter that ended last September. As much of Asia has careered into currency crises, slower sales there have hurt the company.
Some analysts said yesterday that job cuts could be an important step in returning Seagate to financial health.
"I'm not sure this is a blow," said Joel Pitt, a financial analyst for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "You've got oversupply, and under those circumstances you really have a couple of choices. One is that companies pull back and try to align themselves with the demand they're seeing. The other is that they rush headlong over a cliff trying to beat each other's brains out."

HEADLINE: An Ethnic Morass Is Returned to Croatia

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: VUKOVAR, Croatia, Jan. 15

 BODY:
There were two ceremonies today in this scared and neglected corner of Croatia.
One saw dignitaries celebrating, under heavy police security, the peaceful transfer of the last Serbian enclave in the nation to Croatian control after two years of United Nations administration. 
 The second ceremony, in a farming village called Grabovac, saw a small group of neighbors solemnly bury Emil Dragicovic, 78, a Serb who was shot to death by a Croat who had recently returned home.
The suspect is not unknown to the police: Martin Cerda, 61, was arrested in connection with the killing of another Serb on Dec. 9 with a hand grenade. Inexplicably, and despite protests by United Nations officials, Mr. Cerda was freed by Croatian authorities the day after the first attack. He was arrested again when he was found shooting at the inert body of Mr. Dragicovic.
"It is up to the Croatian authorities now," said Milos Vojnovic, a senior Serbian leader. "If they sit by as ethnic Serbs are murdered and harassed, everyone will flee. Zagreb has promised not to force Serbs from their homes, to prevent attacks against us and to let those who have homes in other parts of Croatia return. The test begins today. I am worried."
The Serbian enclave in eastern Slavonia saw some of the most savage fighting of Croatia's war to secede from Yugoslavia. The Yugoslav Army shelled Vukovar into rubble in 1991. Today, whole neighborhoods are eerily silent. Jagged walls are pock-marked with bullet and shell holes, and the city's edge resembles a lunar landscape, with craters filled with brackish water.
By the time the Serbs took control of the enclave, they had killed some 10,000 Croats, hundreds of them unarmed, and expelled another 80,000.
The return of eastern Slavonia to Croatian control was a rallying cry for the nationalist Government led by President Franjo Tudjman for six years. Zagreb was poised to seize eastern Slavonia by force in the fall of 1995, but accepted an agreement brokered by Peter W. Galbraith, then the United States Ambassador, to permit a gradual reintegration during two years of United Nations administration.
The enclave, which has some of the richest farmland in the country as well as an oil field, absorbed 60,000 Serbs who were driven out of two other enclaves taken over by the Croatian Army in early 1995. These Serbs have not, however, been allowed to return to their original homes in Croatia. Most are camped in the homes of Croats who are expected to return.
Ostoja Buncic, 66, and his wife stood forlornly outside the small city hall in the town of Ilok.
"Our papers to return came through," he said, unfolding four sheets, "but our village was burned to the ground when it was taken by the Croats. We have been given permission to return to a house that does not exist. We are scared. The owner of the house we are in is coming back. We have nowhere to go."
The Serbs who are in their own homes also worry that Zagreb will exert pressure on them to leave.
Today Marija Klajic, 48, was putting a padlock on the front of the restaurant she has owned since 1986. A painted message in the window bore greetings for the new year.
"We applied for a license to operate from the Croats and they refused to give us one," said the woman, a Serb. "This is the only way we can make a living. If these incidents continue, combined with this kind of economic pressure, Serbs will gradually pack up and go."
United Nations officials estimate that 10,000 of the 120,000 Serbs here have fled in the last few weeks.
"The dichotomy is not between ethnic groups," said Mr. Galbraith, who attended today's ceremony, "but between the urban and the rural population. The Croats from the urban areas are less likely to return. There are no jobs here; the apartments are ruined and these Croats have established a new life. The people who will come back are the peasants who have spent the last six years in miserable conditions in run-down hotels on the coast. Their farms are often intact and occupied by Serbs from other parts of Croatia. This will be the thorniest problem."
Many Croats who returned today appeared too overwhelmed to consider such complexities. "I took tranquilizers before coming back to Vukovar," said Ljubica Kubalek, 53, as she stood near the gutted city center. "I spent three months in the basement of that building over there. I can still hear the shells."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Revised I.M.F. Bailout Could Transform Indonesia
Indonesia began a new and risky chapter in its history when President Suharto agreed to economic changes that if carried out would overturn the country's entrenched ways of doing business and curb its economic growth. 
 Mr. Suharto signed a bailout deal with the I.M.F., the second in four months, that requires him to cut spending and dismantle monopolies linked to his friends and family. Page A1.
 
Opposition to Korea Debt Plan
The South Korean Government opposes a plan by American banks to refinance debt that is smothering the country's economy. D4.
 
Nuclear Plants To Be Closed
Commonwealth Edison said that it would close two of the company's most troubled nuclear power generators, in Illinois, acknowledging that the cost of keeping them alive had made them unprofitable. A10.
 
Tobacco Settlement in Texas
Five leading cigarette companies have tentatively agreed to pay the State of Texas $14.5 billion to resolve smoking-related health claims, in the largest settlement of a lawsuit against the tobacco industry. A1.
 
Dow Falls for First Time This Week
Uncertainty about corporate earnings hurt stock prices, sending the Dow industrials down 92.92 points, to 7,691.77. D7.
 
The 30-year Treasury bond yield rose to 5.74 percent from 5.73. D7.
 
Sun Microsystems Beats Forecasts
Sun Microsystems reported stronger-than-expected earnings as the company continued to evade the Asian economic crisis and Microsoft's relentless assault on Sun's core market. D2.
 
Opportunity Sought for Minorities
The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson exhorted Wall Street and the nation's business managers to offer opportunities to minorities. D4.
 
Solid Results for Banks
First Chicago NBD and several other big banks reported increases in profit that were largely in line with expectations. D4.
 
Bear Stearns Earnings Drop
Bear Stearns said its quarterly operating earnings were down 3.3 percent as expenses surged and trading revenue fell. D4.

HEADLINE: McCaughey Ross Receives $2 Million From Husband

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross has received a $2.25 million contribution to her gubernatorial campaign from her multimillionaire husband, giving a boost to her effort to transform herself from spurned sidekick to avenging giant-slayer by ousting Gov. George E. Pataki from office.
Ms. McCaughey Ross's campaign reported yesterday that it had $2.3 million in the bank, including the single $2.25 million donation from her husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., senior managing director of the New York investment bank, Rothschild Inc. The disclosure filing also showed that Ms. McCaughey Ross and Mr. Ross had paid for nearly $55,000 in campaign expenses with their own money. 
 Ms. McCaughey Ross, who switched from the Republican to the Democratic Party last fall after Mr. Pataki dropped her from his re-election ticket, now has more money in her campaign account than any of her Democratic rivals, all of whom are more seasoned. The candidate with the next highest amount, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, has raised $2.2 million and has $1.8 million in the bank.
The $2.25 million contribution is likely to lend new credibility to Ms. McCaughey Ross's candidacy, allowing her to set up an extensive campaign apparatus and finance television commercials. Ms. McCaughey Ross, who was a political neophyte when Mr. Pataki selected her as his running mate in 1994, has been criticized as unpredictable and politically naive.
Mr. Ross has suggested in the past that he was willing to spend even more on his wife's campaign. His donation recalls other candidates who tried to bolster their campaigns by dipping into family money, including Lewis E. Lehrman, who spent more than $8 million of his own funds in the 1982 gubernatorial race. Mr. Lehrman, a Republican, narrowly lost to Mario M. Cuomo.
Under state law, candidates and their spouses are allowed to make unlimited contributions to their own campaigns, said Lee Daghlian, a spokesman for the State Board of Elections.
Ms. McCaughey Ross's spokesman, Kevin Lembo-Frey, said the $2.25 million contribution demonstrated the couple's "strong personal commitment to a campaign that would talk about how New York can do better." Mr. Lembo-Frey also noted that the campaign had received about $100,000 in other contributions.
Mr. Ross did not respond to telephone messages seeking comment. He and Ms. McCaughey Ross married in 1995.
An aide to one of Ms. McCaughey Ross's Democratic rivals, Jim Larocca, a former state transportation commissioner, attacked the contribution. "We don't believe the nomination of the Democratic Party should be up for sale," the aide, Ron Foley, said.
Mr. Pataki's office did not respond to requests for comment.
None of the Democrats have raised as much as Mr. Pataki, whose campaign formally reported yesterday that it had collected $11.8 million and had $11.2 million the bank. Mr. Pataki is believed to have taken in more money for his campaign at this point in the election cycle than has any other gubernatorial candidate in state history.
The Pataki campaign's disclosure records showed that he had received scores of donations of $5,000 or more, and several of $25,000. Individuals are allowed to give a maximum of $28,000 to a gubernatorial campaign, a ceiling far higher than the one governing most Federal and New York City elections.
Mr. Pataki received $27,500 from Carroll Petrie, the wife of the late philanthropist and retail magnate Milton Petrie; $20,000 from Ivan Seidenberg, the vice chairman of the Bell Atlantic Corporation; $25,000 from Bell Atlantic's political action committee, and $25,000 from Hushang Ansary, a former Iranian finance minister who is now a United States citizen and an oil industry executive.
Several real estate developers gave $20,000 each, including Donald J. Trump, Daniel Brodsky, Bernard H. Mendik, Burton P. Resnick, Stephen M. Ross, Larry A. Silverstein and Donald Zucker. Mr. Trump, Mr. Brodsky and Mr. Ross are separately trying to buy the New York Coliseum site, which is owned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an agency controlled by Mr. Pataki.
The state Republican Party, whose fund-raising operation is closely linked to Mr. Pataki's, reported similar success yesterday. The Republicans collected close to $10 million in 1997 for their various campaign funds, said Terry O'Brien, a party spokesman.
That dwarfed the amount taken in by the State Democratic Party, which has struggled to raise money since Mr. Pataki defeated Mr. Cuomo in 1994. The state Democratic Party reported raising a total of about $630,000 in 1997, said David L. Cohen, its executive director.
Among the other Democratic gubernatorial candidates, Mr. Larocca has raised $725,000 and has $365,000 in the bank. Richard Kahan, a former state economic development official, has collected $1.5 million and has $1.2 million in his account. The $1.5 million includes a $1 million personal loan that Mr. Kahan made to his campaign. Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, said he has $150,000 in the bank and has just begun fund-raising.
In the state comptroller's race, the incumbent, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, has raised $3.9 million and has $2.8 million the bank. No Republican challengers have entered the contest so far.
Dennis C. Vacco, the State Attorney General, a Republican, has collected $2.2 million for his re-election campaign and has $2.1 million in the bank.
Among his Democratic rivals, Eliot L. Spitzer has raised $1.3 million, including $1 million of his own money, and has $1.27 million in the bank. G. Oliver Koppell, who was Attorney General in 1994, has raised $515,000 and has $361,000 in his campaign account. State Senator Catherine M. Abate of Manhattan has raised $357,000 and has $306,000 on hand. And Evan Davis, who served as Mr. Cuomo's counsel, has raised $202,000, with $176,000 in the bank.
