HEADLINE: Chase's Global Pit Boss;
Executive Leads Bank Into High-Stakes Markets

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Donald H. Layton doesn't have a desk job.
On hectic days -- and there have been plenty of those lately -- Mr. Layton, the vice chairman of Chase Manhattan for global-markets business, can be found stalking the trading floor of the country's largest bank, peppering his staff with questions. As an electronic pager feeds him information about worldwide movements in currency, stock and bond prices, Mr. Layton rapidly makes what he describes as "buy-versus-dump decisions" on millions of dollars worth of financial products. 
 "What are those days like?" Mr. Layton, 47, asks rhetorically. "I don't worry about the paperwork in my in box. They consist of lots of time on the floor talking to people and late-night phone calls into Asia. Then the next morning, you're getting up early to talk to Europe -- and they're not waking me up."
Large commercial banks can no longer survive on the once-cushy, predictable business of lending to companies. Much of that business has disappeared or is only marginally profitable. As the legal wall separating traditional commercial banking from investment banking has eroded in recent years, America's big banks are staking claims in the real meat of modern financial services -- selling stocks and bonds, providing advice on mergers and acquisitions, concocting newfangled financial products and trading.
At the center of the storm are bankers like Mr. Layton, who oversees one of the most lucrative trading operations in the world.
"We tell our people around here: 'Don't say you're a banker. Say you're a businessman who works for a bank,' " he said. "We are in a highly competitive financial-services business, and we have to be tough competitors."
And as financial markets worldwide have cartwheeled in recent months, primarily because of wrenching economic problems that are still sweeping across Southeast Asia, executives like Mr. Layton have played crucial roles in determining the level of international confidence in far-flung places like Thailand, Argentina and the Czech Republic. For example, Chase is a key player in international bankers' attempts to repackage a mountain of short-term debt threatening to topple the economy of South Korea. The latest proposal, however, is meeting with resistance. Page 4.
Entering the high-octane world of securities has been difficult for many banks, not only because it is uncharted territory but also because giant firms that have been in these rich fields for decades are quite able to defend their turf. At the top of the heap are firms like Merrill Lynch, Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. Meanwhile, the globalization of financial services, and the often precarious financial links this creates among dozens of countries, makes the challenge much more complicated.
Chase's ability to remain competitive, and profitable, in such unpredictable markets will continue to test the bank -- and Mr. Layton.
In an industry dominated by large egos and hardball tactics, Mr. Layton has drawn praise for his easygoing nature and accessibility. "He's very, very capable," said David Berry, a banking analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. "He's common-sensical, straightforward and not caught up in his own rhetoric and pomposity."
He has also made a name for himself by making his department a nimble exception in a bank that despite its vast resources is still regarded in many ways by analysts as an elephant that can't dance. Chase's corporate banking business -- made up of Mr. Layton's trading business and the syndicated-lending operation overseen by James B. Lee -- was nearly twice as profitable in 1996 as consumer banking, which was roughly equal in revenue. And it had pretax earnings that were nearly three times greater than all of the profits of international giants like France's Societe Generale S.A. and Japan's Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd.
Mr. Layton talks openly about the strategic directions he would like Chase to take. He says that Chase intends to expand its presence in stock underwriting and sales but that the bank can afford to wait for the right opportunity. He cited Paine Webber Inc. as a brokerage firm Chase might consider buying.
But that is for another day. For now, trading is similar to riding a roller coaster, and the going has not been easy for Chase recently. It suffered a $160 million trading loss in October, primarily related to a battering it took in Brazilian and Russian markets, where the value of bonds issued by those nations nose-dived sharply and unexpectedly. As of late September, the bank also had about $4 billion in loans to Korea, the most of any American bank.
Part of Chase's exposure to South Korea includes highly volatile derivatives -- financial products that derive their value from an underlying asset like a stock or a currency -- which fall under Mr. Layton's purview. He declines to talk specifically about the economic problems in South Korea, other than to say that he thinks they represent a crisis of confidence that will soon pass and, if contained, do not represent a serious threat to Chase's well-being.
It is a testament to the strength of the business Mr. Layton has built that a $160 million trading loss, while extremely painful, can still be absorbed. When the bank reports its fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, analysts are expecting much lower trading numbers than Chase has been used to in recent years but no great surprises.
Even so, the results are likely to contrast with the performance of Chase's global-markets business in the first nine months of this year, when it earned $898 million, or 32 percent of Chase's overall profits -- evidence of how much the once-staid banking business has changed.
Trading in three categories -- foreign currencies, interest rate contracts and bonds, especially emerging-markets bonds -- contributed $1.91 billion of the $2.59 billion in revenue that Chase's global-markets business brought in during the first three quarters of 1997. Mr. Layton refers to this troika as his "gorillas" and says he wants to bring other trading lines into their company. This includes underwriting United States bonds.
Mr. Layton predicts that Chase will break into the top tier, or the "bulge bracket" as it is known on Wall Street, of American bond underwriters within two years. Chase is already the eighth-largest underwriter of investment-grade bonds and the fourth-largest underwriter of highly lucrative junk bonds. But the bank's goal is to be among the top three companies in any business it is in because that is where most of the profits are.
"Don has had a very consistent view of how he wants to build that business at Chase," said Judah Kraushaar, a Merrill Lynch banking analyst. "It starts with a commitment to Chase's customers. He approaches it like a solid businessman and not like a gunslinging trader."
Of course, trading will always involve a certain amount of gunslinging. In 1994, Victor Gomez, a currency trader working for Mr. Layton at what was then Chemical Bank, lost $66 million through unauthorized and erroneous bets on the direction of the Mexican peso. Mr. Gomez was sentenced last year to 37 months in prison for conspiring to defraud Chemical by falsifying records.
Despite episodes like these, Mr. Layton is regarded as a sober-minded and cautious executive who carries out his duties with far less flamboyance than another heavyweight at the bank, Mr. Lee.
As Chase's vice chairman of investment banking, Mr. Lee runs the bank's enormous syndicated-lending business, which arranges loans for big companies and then parcels out the pieces to other banks. The two men, both of whom are driven and ambitious, compete in the same markets. For example, while Mr. Layton's currency traders may be making money on the volatility in Asia, even as his bond traders may be taking losses there, Mr. Lee oversees Chase's large loans to Asian conglomerates.
With neither executive ready to concede turf to the other, the two executives have struggled to get along. But Mr. Layton dismisses the friction between them as "normal differences of opinion."
Mr. Layton thinks the surest path to power in a big company is to take charge of a growing business -- the reason he chose trading even though it was just a small part of the banking business when he entered the industry more than two decades ago.
Mr. Layton received bachelor's and master's degrees in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1972 and then earned an M.B.A. from Harvard University in 1974. He joined the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in 1975, which merged with the Chemical Banking Corporation in 1991. When Chemical merged with Chase in 1996, Mr. Layton, already Chemical's chief trader, was put in charge of the combined trading operation.
Although Mr. Layton is among a core group of senior Chase executives who are considered front-runners to succeed Walter V. Shipley, Chase's chief executive, current and former Chase employees say the fact that Mr. Layton is Jewish may hurt his chances. Large commercial banks have been known historically as hotbeds of anti-Semitism. Although that has changed in recent decades, Chase employees say a less pronounced bigotry still informs decisions about top jobs at many banks, including Chase. For his part, Mr. Layton brushes off the topic.
"I think in this day and age it's not an issue," he says.
Mr. Layton, ever the number cruncher, is more at ease emphasizing the profitability of his business. Chase has made a habit of comparing its profitability with that of J. P. Morgan & Company, because, more than any other former commercial bank, J. P. Morgan has made the most complete transformation into an investment bank.
J. P. Morgan makes for an easy target right now. While it has made admirable gains in the investment-banking business over the last decade, it still lags behind all of the securities giants both in terms of market share and profitability. J. P. Morgan's expenses have swelled as the bank has provided the fat salaries demanded by merger-and-acquisitions specialists and paid heavily to compete with the Merrills and Goldmans of the world in helping corporations issue stock.
Although Chase is big in bonds, it has yet to make its mark in the equities business and, at some point, will certainly pay the price of doing so. Aside from speculation about Paine Webber, bank advisers say Mr. Shipley, the chief executive, has a strong desire to merge with Merrill Lynch. Neither institution would comment on that point.
Still, Mr. Layton remains hungry.
"I'd like to be a gorilla," he says, "in every business known to mankind."

Chart: "Placing Its Bets"
Chase Manhattan has become one of the most aggressive American banks by going beyond traditional corporate lending to take greater risks in issuing foreign debt, trading in currencies and concocting newfangled financial products. Much of this rish-taking has paid off handsomely; sometimes it has not. Here are a few examples of Chase's 1997 deals.
1. The bank rang up heavy trading losses in Brazil when the price of Government-issues bonds fell sharply. It led a $4 billion bond deal in Venezuela, the largest global bond offering ever.
2. It handled several big bond offerings in Britain, Turkey and Greece, some for more than $500 million.
3. In Russia, the bank handled a $200 million bond offering for Vneshtorgbank but also suffered millions of dollars in trading losses.
4. The bank will not talk about its trading exposure in Asia, but it is the largest American lender in South Korea, with about $4 billion outstanding.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2240 words

HEADLINE: Public Still Backs Abortion, But Wants Limits, Poll Says

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Twenty-five years and nearly 30 million abortions after the Supreme Court's landmark Roe v. Wade decision, the American public still largely supports legalized abortion but says it should be harder to get and less readily chosen, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
At base, the country remains irreconcilably riven over what many consider the most divisive American issue since slavery, with half the population considering abortion murder, the poll found. Despite a quarter-century of lobbying, debating and protesting by the camps that call themselves "pro-choice" and "pro-life," that schism has remained virtually unaltered. 
 But beneath that basic divide, public opinion has shifted notably away from general acceptance of legal abortion and toward an evolving center of gravity: a more nuanced, conditional acceptance that some call a "permit but discourage" model.
Almost half of those polled said it was too easy to get an abortion these days. Public support for legal abortion plummets from 61 percent if it is performed in the first three months of a woman's pregnancy to only 15 percent in the second three months. And a few reasons sometimes given for choosing abortion have become less persuasive.
In 1989, for example, when people were asked whether a pregnant woman should be able to get a legal abortion if her pregnancy would force her to interrupt her career, 37 percent said yes and 56 percent said no; in 1998, only 25 percent said yes and 70 percent said no. Similarly, in 1989, 48 percent thought an interrupted education was enough to justify a teen-age girl's abortion; that dropped to 42 percent this year.
Support remained overwhelming, however, for women who sought abortions because they had been raped, their health was endangered, or there was a strong chance of a defect in the baby.
The survey, which was the first New York Times/CBS News Poll devoted to abortion since 1989, was based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 10 to 12 with 1,101 people around the country and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Overall, since 1989 supporters of generally available legal abortion have slipped from 40 percent to 32 percent and the ranks of those who say it should be available but stricter have increased to 45 percent from 40 percent. The contingent who said abortion should not be permitted comprised 18 percent in 1989 and is now at 22 percent.
The public's attitude toward abortion largely lines up with President Clinton's phrase that abortions should be "safe, legal and rare," said Elizabeth Adell Cook, a professor of government at the University of Maryland and co-author of "Between Two Absolutes," (Westview Press, 1992), an analysis of public opinion on abortion.
Studies indicate an emerging consensus that "it should be allowed under some circumstances but it isn't to be taken too lightly," Dr. Cook said in an interview Wednesday. "People think if there's a serious enough reason, it's O.K., but if they don't think the reason is compelling enough, they think it's wrong."
That willingness to judge applies even close to home, the poll found. Among the 58 percent of respondents who said someone they knew well had undergone an abortion, 30 percent said they thought it was the right thing to do, but 24 percent said they believed it was wrong.
At work is the search for a compromise between two views -- that abortion is murder and that it is a woman's right -- that seem absolutely contradictory and yet so powerful that they often coexist within the same person.
In responses so paradoxical that they astound even experts like Dr. Cook, one third of the poll's respondents who said they considered abortion to be murder also agreed that abortion is sometimes the best course in a bad situation.
As the 25th anniversary of Roe v. Wade approaches, 60 percent of the poll's respondents said they thought the ruling, which established a woman's constitutional right to abortion, was a good thing.
But many had to be told first what the decision entailed. Despite the decades-old fervor surrounding the abortion debate, nearly 45 percent of those asked the status of abortion law either gave the wrong answer, said they did not follow the issue enough to know, or simply gave no answer.
That could be in part because the picture has become more complicated since Roe v. Wade. In 1989, another Supreme Court decision permitted states to whittle away at the edges of Roe v. Wade by passing restrictions on abortion like a 24-hour waiting period. More than 30 states have passed such laws.
The Times/CBS News Poll indicates that those new state laws tap a significant vein of public opinion. Nearly 80 percent of respondents supported both parental consent and waiting periods.
In general, however, the abortion issue seems to have only limited political resonance these days. Just over half the respondents said they did not think it necessary to know a public official's position on abortion.
Such indications that abortion is becoming less of a political issue and more of a private, moral one jibe with the belief expressed by nearly 60 percent of those polled that the Government should stay out of decisions on whether abortion should be legal. And the idea of a constitutional amendment banning abortions appears supremely unpopular: more than three-quarters opposed it.
Roger Rosenblatt, an essayist who distilled the "permit but discourage" idea in his book, "Life Itself: Abortion in the American Mind," (Random House, 1992) said it was to be expected that the American public would move toward limiting abortion -- but only in the moral arena, not the political one.
"Sooner or later you're going to have a system where you say, 'One simply doesn't do that, one simply doesn't cavalierly have an abortion,' " he said in an interview yesterday. "It's not against the law, but one simply doesn't do it, or if one does it, one recognizes the moral digression."
The question of whether women often have abortions "cavalierly" appears to be having a powerful influence on changes in attitudes.
Among people polled who offered a reason for why most women have abortions, 49 percent said that reason was not serious enough to justify an abortion, up from 41 percent in 1989.
Along those same lines, sympathy has dwindled for women who seek an abortion because they do not want to marry the father. In 1989, 50 percent said they did not think such a woman should be able to get a legal abortion; now, 62 percent hold that position.
Those and other findings appear to indicate that the country's growing experience with legal abortions -- more than 1 million are performed each year -- is not leading to growing sympathy or acceptance.
"It's too easy an out for these women," said Sharon Paasch, 44, a records clerk in Caledonia, Wis., in a follow-up interview after the poll. "I don't think they're accepting the responsibility of sex before they have it. If you're going to have sex, you better prevent having a baby if you don't want it. I think you should accept the responsibility and the consequences of your actions, and not look to being bailed out by having an abortion afterwards."
Neither age nor a person's sex appeared to have an effect on people's current views on abortion.
In contrast, people's attitudes toward abortion appeared to depend so profoundly on the circumstances surrounding it that for some, the circumstances even determine whether it is murder.
"A teen-ager who is unable to take care of the child, that would be a reason for it -- she's still a child herself," said Stephanie Mendez, a 25-year-old student in Brooklyn. But "if it's an adult in that situation, then I think it's murdering a child."
Motivation is a nebulous thing, however; it was about timing that Americans expressed their clearest sense of a hierarchy of sin.
Sixty-one percent said they thought abortions should be permitted during the first three months of pregnancy, up from 50 percent in 1982; but that support dwindled to 15 percent in the second three months and just 7 percent in the third.
That looming gap helps explain why the opponents of abortion have chosen a form of abortion they refer to as partial-birth abortion as a rallying point in Congress.
While the emphasis on partial-birth abortion has worked as a political tactic, however, it does not appear to have penetrated far into the national consciousness. A majority had heard nothing or not much about the partial-birth debates.
As for the current effort by some anti-abortion Republicans to convince the party that only candidates who support a ban on partial-birth abortions should receive campaign money, Republicans who were polled appeared split. Forty-nine percent opposed the idea while 43 percent supported it.
In general, Republicans were likelier to think the party should oppose legal abortion than support it. Thirty-seven percent endorsed its opposition while 26 percent thought the party should support legal abortion.
Democrats who were polled, meanwhile, strongly backed their party's support for legal abortion.
But about one-third of both Democrats and Republicans thought their parties should take no stand on the issue, once again showing unwillingness to turn abortion into a political issue. And even a politician with President Clinton's approval ratings -- generally well above 50 percent on issues like the economy and foreign policy -- gets caught in the divide on abortion: only 38 percent approve of his handling of abortion, while 29 percent disapprove.
The importance of timing also appeared to bode well for public acceptance of new techniques that allow a woman to end a pregnancy much earlier than before.
People know little about "morning-after pills," hormones that women can take up to 72 hours after sex to prevent a fertilized egg from developing, the poll found. But 65 percent of respondents said they would be likely to consider them a form of birth control rather than abortion. Less than one-fifth said they would consider use of the morning-after pills to be a form of abortion.
Similarly, respondents appeared receptive to the idea of a drug-induced abortion, now possible in the first seven weeks of pregnancy using a combination of drugs called RU-486, as an alternative to surgical abortion. Though nearly 70 percent said they had heard little about RU-486, 50 percent said they would favor its use as an alternative to surgical abortion, while 36 percent said they would oppose it.
Several aspects of American popular thinking on abortion appear to directly defy the work that advocates on both sides of the issue have been doing for so many years. Neither side of the fight has capitalized on the public's concern with the timing of an abortion -- abortion rights advocates because they focused mainly on the sanctity of a woman's right to choose, and abortion foes because they focused on the sanctity of the life of a fetus of any age.
If advocates on both sides have made little progress, it could be partly because of their image. Forty-four percent of respondents said they thought the anti-abortion advocates in their states were extremists, the same level as in 1989. Their image of abortion rights advocates, always somewhat better had slightly improved. In 1989, 57 percent said they thought most abortion rights advocates in their state were reasonable; that rose to 66 percent in 1998.
The closest thing the American public comes to a consensus on abortion is in its predictions on the intractability of the conflict. A whopping 88 percent said they did not believe the disagreements between supporters and opponents of legal abortion would ever be resolved.
"It's not an issue that's necessarily based on black and white facts," said Rick, a 41-year-old engineer in Blue Rock, Ohio, who asked that his last name be omitted. "It's a moral decision and I don't think the two sides will ever come together."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 10 to 12 with 1,101 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for women as a group it is plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
China's Central Bank Vows to Hold Yuan Rate

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

 BODY:
The governor of China's central bank pledged today to hold the exchange rate of the Chinese currency stable amid the crisis sweeping other Asian currencies. The governor, Dai Xianglong, also said that while interest rates would be adjusted sometime this year, there were plans for an immediate cut in rates. 
 The Chinese currency, the yuan, is used only for trade, and is thus not freely available to investors. That, and the fact that China's markets are relatively small, have insulated the country from the cash outflows that have rocked Asian markets. Mr. Dai said China would overcome the effects of the Asian crisis to maintain economic growth of around 8 percent this year, down from 8.8 percent in 1997. Mr. Dai's comments echoed those of Deputy Prime Minister Zhu Rongji on Wednesday. Mr. Dai also said that China would continue to support the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the United States dollar.

HEADLINE: Why Computer Jobs Go Begging;
Hire Foreign Workers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Software Jobs Go Begging, Threatening Technology Boom" (front page, Jan. 13) explores the United States' woefully inadequate supply of computer professionals. Demand far outstrips the supply of talent, and unless we can fill all the positions, our industry and economy will be stifled. There is an immediate solution to the problem. Employers can hire qualified foreign nationals on temporary work visas. 
 But Congress must raise the artificially imposed cap of 65,000 of such visas issued each year. This cap was reached last year months before the fiscal year ended. If our Government recognized the value such foreign workers bring to our economy, it would eliminate the cap entirely and allow American businesses and industries the human capital they need to keep growing.
 
SUSAN J. COHEN
Boston, Jan. 13, 1998
 
The writer is an immigration lawyer.

NEW YORK/REGION B1-9
 
Clinton Offers $120 Million To Hire Police Officers
President Clinton, reaching across party lines to fight crime and share political credit for the results, appeared with Mayor Giuliani to announce a Federal grant of $120 million to help the Mayor fulfill a pledge to hire 1,600 more police officers. A1
 
Year-Round Schools Proposal
Governor Pataki intends to propose legislation that would bolster Chancellor Rudy Crew's effort to send some city students to school in the summer in order to relieve school overcrowding the rest of the year, Mr. Pataki's aides said. The Governor's proposal would let school districts in the state stagger student vacations over the entire year, so that fewer students were in any one building at any one time. B1
 
Woman Sues Son in Lottery
A New Jersey woman sued her son for half of his lottery winnings, contending that the ticket he redeemed was partly paid for by her. B1
 
Trade Center Robbery Arrests
Two of the three men suspected of stealing more than $1 million from security guards making a delivery in the World Trade Center have been arrested, law enforcement officials said, adding that they were closing in on the third suspect. B3
 
Mayor Calls for Apology
Mayor Giuliani, who had questioned whether "Giuliani time" was ever uttered by police officers accused of torturing a black man, said that his critics who had invoked the phrase "owe the people of the city an apology" now that the victim has reportedly retracted that assertion. B4
 
Molinari vs. Hynes
Longstanding animosities between Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island and District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn erupted in a Brooklyn courtroom when Mr. Molinari accused Mr. Hynes of waging a politically motivated prosecution of a police officer who lives on Staten Island. B7

OBITUARIES B11
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-20
 
Indonesia-I.M.F. Pact
President Suharto of Indonesia, capitulating to international pressure, signed a remarkably specific bailout agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the second in four months, that requires him to curb spending and dismantle the monopolies that have allowed the businesses of his friends and family to prosper while strengthening his control over the economy of the nation he has ruled for 32 years. A1
 
President Suharto and his family now find their financial empire under threat. A1
 
Seagate to Cut Work Force
Seagate Technology, the world's largest maker of disk drives for personal computers, said it would dismiss 10 percent of its employees. D1
 
Keating Convictions Reinstated
A Federal appeals court reinstated the criminal convictions of Charles H. Keating Jr., a leading figure in the nation's savings and loan crisis. D1

An entry in the News Summary on Jan. 16 about a withdrawal of United Nations peacekeepers from a region in the Balkans misidentified the region. It was western Slavonia (part of Croatia), not western Slovenia.

PUB-DATE: January 17, 1998

SECTION: Section B; Page 19; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 452 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Squeezing Companies For Profit

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Hedrick Smith begins "Surviving the Bottom Line," his four-part report on the American economy, with an incisive look at the way a few Wall Streeters go about making enormous profits at the expense of many Main Streeters. "Running With the Bulls," which can be seen at the uninviting hour of noon tomorrow in the New York area, focuses on big players whose single-minded goal is to extract the most money from the companies they take over regardless of what that means for workers, communities and business ethos.
What it means is seen through the tactics of two multimillionaires, Michael Price, a mutual fund operator who forced the merger of Chase and Chemical Banks, and Albert J. Dunlap, a hired gun who has made fortunes for himself and stockholders by downsizing businesses, cutting wages and dismissing workers. They say they are compelling stodgy corporate managers to bring investors higher returns, which as they see it is what capitalism is all about. 
 Critics of such high fliers note that most Americans have not benefited from the booming market, that the truly big gainers are the richest 1 percent of investors, like Mr. Price, seen playing polo, and Mr. Dunlap, seen living it up in his mansion. These men are not bothered by being called predators. Their strategy -- "a cut-and-run technique," Mr. Smith calls it -- is to turn as quick and big a profit as possible, never mind the consequences for those who can't afford to play the game or are left stranded by it.
A cautionary if untypical tale is offered about one company that apparently pushed cost-cutting past the danger point. The program says that Valujet, a bare-bones airline, became a Wall Street favorite while it scrimped on service, experience, maintenance and safety. A 1996 accident in which 110 people died brought improvements, but by then the speculators had cashed in and turned to new opportunities.
In the second hour, "Living on the Fault Line," Mr. Smith draws attention to the problems of workers in once-booming San Diego who have lost full-time careers and had to settle for temporary jobs. And the series ends with happier examples of educational reforms and cooperative efforts to make the economy work in more humane ways. Mr. Smith's hope is that capitalism need not be a fang-and-claw operation.
As for the prospects for serious journalism on public television, being consigned to noon on Sunday is nothing to be bullish about.
 
SURVIVING THE BOTTOM LINE
Channel 13, New York, tomorrow at noon and 1 P.M.
 
"Running with the Bulls": Marc Shaffer, producer; Ariadne Allan, field producer. "Living on the Fault-Line": Barak Goodman and Tia Lessin, producers. Hedrick Smith, reporter.

SECTION: Section D; Page 16; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 258 words

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Ends the Year Strong

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Industrial production increased half a percent in December, the 14th consecutive monthly gain, and 5 percent in the full year, the Federal Reserve said today.
December's gain, which followed an increase in November of eight-tenths of 1 percent, reflected "widespread increases among most major market and industry groups," the Fed said. However, "the overall gain in output was held back a bit by a decline in motor vehicle production, which had been quite high in November." 
 Auto and truck production decreased 3.4 percent in the month. Excluding motor vehicles and parts, industrial production rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December.
The 5 percent increase in 1997 exceeded 1996's 3.5 percent gain and was the strongest annual showing since 1994.
The plant-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity in use, increased to 83.4 percent in December, its highest level since September 1995. November's rate was revised to 83.3 percent from the 82.2 percent reported initially.
Despite the healthy production figures, Asia's financial crisis "should eventually cool off the manufacturing sector" in 1998, Anthony Chan, chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, said in a recent research report. Demand for exports will decline in Asian countries, and American producers will have to contend with inexpensive imports and the strong dollar.
In another measure of the economy, the University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer confidence in January rose to 104 from 102.1 last month.
